Damper is a simple soda bread traditionally baked in the coals of a campfire, its crust charred and smoky, its crumb dense and satisfying. This Northern Territory version folds in roasted wattleseed (Acacia victoriae) — a native Australian ingredient with a complex flavour of coffee, chocolate, and hazelnut that Aboriginal peoples have ground and eaten for over 40,000 years. Torn open while still warm and drizzled with golden syrup (Australia's beloved cane sugar syrup, a pantry staple since federation), this is bush tucker at its most comforting and ancient.
ingredients: 3 cups (375 g) self-rising flour (or 3 cups all-purpose flour + 4 tsp baking powder + 1/2 tsp salt)
2 tbsp roasted ground wattleseed (available at specialty Australian grocers or online)
2 tbsp (30 g) cold unsalted butter, cubed
1 cup (240 ml) whole milk, plus extra for brushing
Golden syrup (such as Lyle's), for serving
steps: Preheat oven to 400°F (200°C). Line a baking sheet with parchment paper.
Whisk together the flour, wattleseed, sugar, and salt in a large bowl. The wattleseed will add a nutty, coffee-like aroma.
Rub the cold butter into the flour mixture with your fingertips until it resembles fine breadcrumbs.
Make a well in the center and pour in the milk. Stir with a butter knife using a cutting motion until a shaggy dough forms — do not overwork. The dough should be soft and slightly sticky.
Turn onto a lightly floured surface and gently pat into a round about 7 inches (18 cm) across and 2 inches (5 cm) high. Place on the baking sheet.
Score a deep cross into the top of the loaf (this is traditional — it helps the damper cook evenly and makes it easy to tear into quarters). Brush with a little extra milk.
Bake for 30–35 minutes until deeply golden brown and the base sounds hollow when tapped.
Serve warm, torn into pieces at the table, with generous lashings of butter and golden syrup drizzled into every crevice.

Australian Capital Territory.description: The Sunday roast is a sacred institution in Canberra, where the cold winters of the Australian capital and the rhythms of public service life make weekend gatherings around a table non-negotiable. The Australian Capital Territory sits in the Southern Tablelands of New South Wales — prime lamb country — and the local farmers' markets at EPIC and the Old Bus Depot overflow with superb grass-fed lamb from the surrounding Yass Valley and Bungendore region. This herb-crusted rack of lamb, roasted until the fat renders to crackling gold and the eye of meat stays blushing pink, is the centrepiece of the Canberra Sunday table. The native pepperberry in the crust is a nod to the ACT's embrace of bush food culture, while the classic Dijon-herb coating comes straight from a generation of Canberra grandmothers who learned to roast from their British-born mothers.
ingredients: 2 racks of lamb (8 ribs each, about 1.5 lbs / 680 g per rack), Frenched
1/2 cup (30 g) fresh breadcrumbs (from day-old sourdough)
3 tbsp fresh flat-leaf parsley, finely chopped
1/2 tsp ground native pepperberry (or substitute freshly cracked black pepper)
steps: Remove lamb from the refrigerator 30 minutes before cooking. Preheat oven to 425°F (220°C).
Combine breadcrumbs, parsley, rosemary, thyme, garlic, olive oil, pepperberry, and salt in a bowl. Mix with your fingers until the crumbs are evenly green and fragrant.

Season the lamb racks all over with salt. Heat a skillet over high heat and sear the lamb racks fat-side down for 2–3 minutes until the fat is golden. Sear the meat side briefly for 1 minute. Remove from heat.
Brush the fat side and meat side of each rack with a thin, even layer of Dijon mustard.
Press the herb-breadcrumb mixture firmly onto the mustard-coated surfaces, building a thick, even crust. Drizzle with melted butter.
Place the racks bone-side down on a rack set in a roasting pan. Roast for 20–25 minutes for medium-rare (internal temperature of 130°F / 54°C) or 28–30 minutes for medium (140°F / 60°C).
Rest the lamb loosely tented with foil for 10 minutes — the internal temperature will rise another 5°F. This resting is essential; it lets the juices redistribute.
Carve between the bones into individual cutlets. Arrange on a warm platter and serve with roasted root vegetables and a green salad.

drink.description: Canberra is Australia's coldest capital city, where winter mornings see frost blanket the parliamentary triangle and fog settle thick over Lake Burley Griffin. The Canberra Fog — an Earl Grey tea latte sweetened with local honey — has become a staple of the city's thriving café scene along Lonsdale Street in Braddon and the Kingston Foreshore. It's a warming, aromatic hug of bergamot-scented tea and frothy steamed milk, sweetened with honey from the hives that dot the bush capital's nature reserves. The drink bridges Canberra's British heritage (tea, always tea) with its modern café culture (beautifully steamed milk) and local produce ethos (the honey).
ingredients: 2 bags Earl Grey tea (or 2 tsp loose leaf Earl Grey)
2 tsp honey (Canberra region wildflower honey preferred)
Pinch of ground lavender (optional, for a 'London Fog' variation)
steps: Steep the Earl Grey tea bags in 1/2 cup (120 ml) of boiling water for 4–5 minutes. You want the tea strong — this is the backbone of the drink. Remove the bags and stir in the honey and vanilla until dissolved.
Heat the milk in a small saucepan over medium heat until steaming. Froth using a milk frother, French press (pump 15–20 times), or whisk vigorously until foamy.
Pour the hot, concentrated tea into a large mug. Slowly pour the steamed milk through the foam, holding back the froth with a spoon, then spoon the foam on top.
Dust with a pinch of ground lavender if desired. Wrap your hands around the mug and sip slowly on a Canberra winter morning.

dessert.description: The most distinctive tart in the Australian baking tradition — small, round shortcrust pastry shells filled with a layer of raspberry jam and topped with mock cream, then finished with a striking two-toned icing: one half chocolate, one half white. Neenish tarts are a CWA (Country Women's Association) classic that has appeared in Australian cookbooks since at least the 1920s, though their exact origin is debated (some claim the name derives from a Mrs. Neenish, others that it's a corruption of a German word). What is not debated is their place in the Australian afternoon tea canon — every grandmother in the ACT has her recipe, every Canberra bakery from Silo to the National Library café stocks them. The contrast of the jammy base, fluffy cream, and crisp, sweet icing is pure Australian comfort.
ingredients: 1/2 cup (1 stick / 115 g) cold unsalted butter, cubed
1 cup (125 g) powdered (icing) sugar, sifted (for icing)
1 tbsp unsweetened cocoa powder (for chocolate half)
steps: Make the pastry: pulse flour, icing sugar, salt, and butter in a food processor until it resembles coarse sand. Add egg yolk and ice water; pulse until the dough just comes together. Wrap in plastic and refrigerate 30 minutes.
Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Roll the pastry out to 1/8-inch thickness. Cut rounds and press into a 12-cup standard muffin tin or tart tin. Prick the bases with a fork.

Blind bake: line each shell with a small piece of parchment and fill with pie weights or dried beans. Bake 12 minutes, remove weights, and bake another 5–8 minutes until the pastry is golden and crisp. Cool completely in the tins.
Spoon a teaspoon of raspberry jam into the base of each cooled tart shell, spreading to cover the bottom.
Whip the cream with powdered sugar and vanilla until it holds stiff peaks. Spoon or pipe a generous mound into each tart shell, smoothing the top flat with a palette knife.

Make the icing: mix 1 cup sifted icing sugar with 2–3 teaspoons warm water to a thick, spreadable consistency. Divide in half. To one half, add the cocoa powder and a drop more water if needed to reach the same consistency.

Working one tart at a time: using a small palette knife, ice one half of the tart top with white icing and the other half with chocolate icing, creating a clean dividing line down the center. Smooth gently.
Let the icing set for 30 minutes at room temperature before serving. The icing should be firm and glossy.

AUT.description: The golden icon of Vienna. By law, a true Wiener Schnitzel must be veal. The secret lies in the 'soufflé' effect—frying it swimming in fat so the breading separates from the meat, creating a rippled, crispy crust.
ingredients: 1 cup (100 g) fine breadcrumbs (Kaiser roll crumbs preferred)
1 cup (240 ml) clarified butter (Schmalz) or high-heat oil
steps: Place veal between plastic wrap and pound gently until very thin (approx 4mm). Season with salt.
Set up 3 shallow bowls: Flour, Beaten Eggs, Breadcrumbs.
Dredge veal in flour (shake off excess), dip in egg, then coat gently in breadcrumbs. Do not press the crumbs into the meat.
Heat butter in a pan (meat must float). Temp should be approx 170°C.
Fry schnitzel, shaking the pan constantly to swirl oil over the top. This creates the rippled crust.
Flip once. Fry until golden brown (approx 3 mins total). Drain and serve immediately.

drink.description: A classic Viennese aperitif: crisp white wine lengthened with soda water—simple, cold, and refreshing.
ingredients: 5 oz (150 ml) dry white wine (Grüner Veltliner recommended)
steps: Chill a wine glass or highball.
Fill with ice.
Pour in the wine, then top with soda water.
Stir once gently.
Add lemon if you like; serve immediately.

dessert.description: The legendary Viennese chocolate cake, created at Hotel Sacher in 1832: a dense, dark chocolate sponge split with a thin layer of apricot jam, glazed in a mirror-smooth dark chocolate fondant. Served with a generous dollop of unsweetened whipped cream (Schlagobers)—because the Viennese insist the bittersweet cake demands it.
ingredients: 5 oz (140 g) dark chocolate (70% cacao), chopped
1/2 cup (1 stick / 115 g) unsalted butter, softened
1/2 cup (160 g) smooth apricot jam, warmed and strained (see preliminary steps)
steps: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Butter and flour a 9-inch (23 cm) round springform pan; line the bottom with parchment.
Melt dark chocolate gently over a double boiler (or microwave in 20-second bursts). Cool slightly.
Beat butter with half the sugar until pale and fluffy, 3–4 minutes. Beat in egg yolks one at a time, then stir in melted chocolate and vanilla.
In a separate bowl, whisk egg whites with a pinch of salt until soft peaks form. Gradually add remaining sugar and whip to stiff, glossy peaks.
Fold one-third of the whites into the chocolate batter to lighten it, then gently fold in the remaining whites in two additions. Sift flour over the top in batches, folding gently after each.
Pour into the prepared pan and smooth the top. Bake 40–50 minutes until a skewer comes out with moist crumbs (not wet batter).
Cool in pan 10 minutes, then unmold onto a rack and cool completely.
Slice the cake horizontally into two even layers. Spread the warm, strained apricot jam over the bottom layer, then replace the top.
Brush the entire outside of the cake with a thin coat of apricot jam (this helps the glaze adhere). Let it set 10 minutes.

Pour the warm Chocolate Fondant Glaze over the center of the cake, tilting and using a palette knife to cover the top and sides in one smooth motion. Let set at room temperature until the glaze is firm and glossy.
Serve each slice with a generous spoonful of unsweetened Schlagobers.
Warm the jam with water in a small saucepan over low heat until liquefied.
Press through a fine-mesh sieve to remove any fruit pieces. Keep warm until needed.

ingredients: 6 oz (170 g) dark chocolate (70% cacao), finely chopped
steps: Combine sugar and water in a saucepan. Bring to a boil and cook until the syrup reaches 235°F (113°C) on a candy thermometer (thread stage).
Remove from heat and stir in the chopped chocolate until melted and perfectly smooth.
Let cool to about 90°F (32°C)—it should be pourable but slightly thickened. Use immediately.

AZE.description: The undisputed 'King of Pilafs'—a showstopper reserved for Azerbaijani weddings and grand celebrations. Jeweled saffron rice and tender braised lamb, studded with dried fruits and chestnuts, are sealed inside a drum of buttered lavash that bakes into a shattering, golden crust called gazmaq. When the dome is cracked open at the table, fragrant steam billows out to gasps of delight.
ingredients: 3 cups (600 g) basmati rice, soaked in salted water for 2 hours
1 lb (450 g) boneless lamb shoulder, cut into 1-inch cubes
1/2 cup (75 g) roasted chestnuts, roughly chopped
1/2 cup (115 g) unsalted butter, melted, divided
1/2 tsp saffron threads, steeped in 3 tbsp hot water
1 tsp kosher salt (plus more to taste)
steps: Drain the soaked rice. Bring a large pot of salted water to a rolling boil, add the rice, and parboil for 5–6 minutes until the grains are tender on the outside but still firm in the center. Drain and set aside.
Season lamb with salt, pepper, and turmeric. In a skillet over medium-high heat, sear the cubes in 1 tbsp of the melted butter until browned on all sides, about 6 minutes. Remove and set aside.
In the same skillet, sauté the apricots, prunes, and chestnuts in 1 tbsp butter for 3–4 minutes until lightly caramelized. Toss with the seared lamb.

Brush the inside of a heavy, oven-safe pot (or Dutch oven) generously with melted butter. Line with lavash sheets, overlapping them so they drape over the rim by several inches—this will wrap over the top later.
Spread a thin layer of parboiled rice on the bottom. Top with the lamb-fruit mixture, then cover with the remaining rice. Drizzle the saffron water and 2 tbsp melted butter evenly over the top.
Fold the overhanging lavash tightly over the rice to seal the dome completely. Brush the top with the remaining melted butter.
Cover with a tight-fitting lid (or foil and then the lid). Bake at 350°F (175°C) for 1 hour until the lavash is deeply golden and crackly.
Invert the pot onto a large platter so the crispy gazmaq faces up. Crack the crust open at the table and serve.

drink.description: Tea is the soul of Azerbaijani hospitality. Strong black tea is brewed in a two-tiered samovar-style pot, poured into pear-shaped armudu glasses that keep the top cool for sipping and the bottom warm. Served with a cube of sugar held between the teeth, a spoonful of cherry jam, and aromatic herbs—it is a ritual that bookends every meal.
ingredients: 3 tsp loose-leaf black tea (Azerbaijani or Ceylon)
4 cups (960 ml) freshly boiled water, divided
2–3 dried rose petals or a small sprig of thyme (optional)
Cherry or quince jam (mürəbbə), for serving
steps: Warm the teapot by swirling a splash of boiling water inside, then discard.
Add the loose tea leaves (and cloves or rose petals if using) to the pot. Pour in 1 cup (240 ml) of boiling water. Let steep 3–4 minutes.
Top up with the remaining 3 cups (720 ml) of boiling water. Cover and let stand 2 more minutes for a deep, amber brew.
Pour through a fine strainer into pear-shaped armudu glasses, filling just below the waist of the glass so the rim stays cool enough to hold.
Serve with lump sugar on the side (traditionally held between the teeth while sipping) and a small dish of cherry or quince jam.

dessert.description: Azerbaijani baklava, the jewel of the Novruz holiday table: layers of thin pastry enveloping a fragrant ground walnut and cardamom filling, soaked in a saffron-infused honey syrup until glistening. Cut into diamond shapes and crowned with a walnut half, each piece is a golden, sticky celebration of Azerbaijan's rich confectionery tradition.
ingredients: 1 lb (450 g) phyllo dough (or homemade yufka), thawed
steps: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Brush a 9x13-inch (23x33 cm) baking pan with melted butter.
Mix ground walnuts, sugar, cardamom, and cinnamon in a bowl.
Layer 6–8 sheets of phyllo in the pan, brushing each generously with melted butter.
Spread half the walnut filling evenly over the phyllo.
Layer 4–5 more buttered phyllo sheets, then spread the remaining walnut filling.
Top with 6–8 final sheets of phyllo, brushing each with butter. Brush the very top sheet generously.
Using a sharp knife, cut into diamond shapes (cut parallel diagonal lines, then cross them). Press a walnut half into the center of each diamond.
Brush the top with beaten egg yolk for a golden finish.
Bake 40–50 minutes until deeply golden and crisp.
Remove from oven and immediately pour the cooled Saffron Honey Syrup evenly over the hot pastry.
Let soak and cool completely at room temperature (at least 3–4 hours, ideally overnight) before serving.

ingredients: Generous pinch saffron threads, steeped in 2 tbsp hot water
steps: Combine water and sugar in a saucepan. Bring to a boil, stirring until sugar dissolves.
Add honey and lemon juice. Simmer 8–10 minutes until slightly thickened.
Stir in the saffron with its steeping water. Remove from heat and cool completely before using.

Andaman and Nicobar Islands.description: A reflection of the island's tropical abundance. Fresh fish is marinated in turmeric and chili, then simmered in a light, tangy gravy made with coconut milk and local spices.
ingredients: 1 lb King Fish or White Snapper
steps: Marinate fish with turmeric and salt. Lightly fry.
Sauté mustard seeds, curry leaves, and onions.
Add tomatoes and cook until soft.
Add coconut milk and simmer.
Add fish and cook gently for 5-7 minutes.

drink.description: Island refreshment: cold coconut water straight from a young coconut.
ingredients: 1 young coconut (or 8–12 oz / 240–355 ml coconut water)
steps: Chill well.
Serve straight (over ice if desired).

BDI.description: The heartbeat of every Burundian table—humble red beans slow-simmered with tomatoes, garlic, and a swirl of palm oil until they collapse into a thick, spoonable stew. Enriched with a spoonful of peanut butter for velvety richness, Ibiharage is ladled over plantains, rice, or cassava and eaten communally, as all good Burundian meals are.
ingredients: 2 cups (400 g) dried red beans, rinsed
8 cups (1.9 L) water (plus more as needed)
2 tbsp (30 ml) vegetable oil (or palm oil)
1 tsp kosher salt (plus more to taste)
2 tbsp (32 g) peanut butter (optional, for richness)
steps: Combine beans and water in a pot. Bring to a boil, then simmer partially covered until beans are tender, 1 1/2–2 hours (add water as needed).
In a separate pan, heat oil and sauté onion until soft, 5–7 minutes. Add garlic; cook 30 seconds. Add tomatoes and cook until jammy, 6–8 minutes.
Stir the tomato mixture into the beans. Season with salt, pepper, and cumin (if using). Simmer 15 minutes to meld flavors.
If using peanut butter, whisk it with a ladle of hot bean broth, then stir back into the pot. Simmer 5 minutes.
Serve hot with plantains, rice, or cassava.

drink.description: A traditional Great Lakes banana beer: ripe bananas mashed, strained, and fermented with sorghum flour.
ingredients: 6 very ripe bananas (the riper, the better)
1/2 cup (70 g) toasted sorghum flour (see preliminary steps)
1/4 tsp active dry yeast (optional, for reliability)
steps: Peel bananas into a large bowl and mash thoroughly into a smooth pulp.
Add warm water and mix well. Strain through a fine sieve or cheesecloth into a clean fermentation jar.
Stir in toasted sorghum flour and a pinch of salt. Add yeast (if using).
Cover loosely and ferment at room temperature 12–24 hours until lightly effervescent and aromatic.
Strain again if desired, chill, and serve cold.

dessert.description: Steamed banana parcels—the pure, gentle sweet ending of every Burundian meal. Ripe bananas are mashed with a touch of sugar, wrapped snugly in banana leaves, and steamed until soft, fragrant, and lightly caramelized. Simple and deeply satisfying, Ibitoke celebrates the banana in its most elemental form.
ingredients: 6 very ripe bananas (plantains or sweet bananas), peeled
6–8 banana leaves, washed and softened over a flame or in hot water
Kitchen twine or strips of banana leaf for tying
steps: Mash the bananas in a bowl until smooth but still slightly chunky. Stir in sugar, cinnamon (if using), and a pinch of salt.
Cut banana leaves into rectangles roughly 10x12 inches (25x30 cm). Briefly pass them over an open flame or dip in hot water to make them pliable.
Place about 1/3 cup (80 g) of the banana mixture in the center of each leaf.
Fold the leaf around the filling like a parcel: fold the long sides over first, then tuck in the ends. Tie securely with kitchen twine or a thin strip of banana leaf.
Arrange the parcels in a steamer basket (or on a rack set inside a large pot with 2 inches / 5 cm of simmering water beneath).
Steam over medium heat for 30–40 minutes until the parcels are soft, fragrant, and the banana has darkened slightly.
Unwrap carefully and serve warm. The banana will be soft, sweet, and gently caramelized at the edges.
Toast sorghum flour in a dry skillet over medium heat, stirring constantly, until lightly nutty and fragrant, 3–5 minutes.
Cool completely before adding to the drink.

BEL.description: A national obsession pairing the bounty of the North Sea with the world's best fries. The mussels are steamed simply in white wine and aromatics, while the potatoes are fried twice in beef tallow for that signature Belgian crunch.
ingredients: 4 lbs (1.8 kg) fresh mussels, cleaned and bearded
steps: Inspect the mussels: discard any with cracked shells or that do not close when tapped. Pull off any remaining beards.
In a large pot, melt butter over medium heat. Sauté shallots and celery until soft and translucent, about 4 minutes.
Crank the heat to high. Add the mussels and immediately pour in the white wine.
Cover tightly and cook, shaking the pot vigorously every 30 seconds, for 3–4 minutes until the shells pop open.
Discard any mussels that remain closed. Toss with chopped parsley and give the broth a final stir.
Ladle mussels and broth into deep bowls and serve alongside a generous cone of hot Belgian frites and mayonnaise.

drink.description: A traditional Belgian style: lambic gently sweetened (historically with brown sugar or syrup). Lightly tart, lightly sweet—meant for easy drinking.
ingredients: 12 oz (355 ml) lambic (or gueuze) beer, well-chilled
1–2 tsp dark brown sugar or Belgian candi syrup, to taste
steps: Chill a tulip glass or goblet in the freezer for 5 minutes.
Add sugar (or syrup) to the chilled glass.
Pour in the lambic slowly down the side to preserve carbonation, then stir gently just to dissolve the sugar.
Taste and adjust sweetness—Faro should be balanced, not cloying.
Garnish with a lemon slice if desired and serve immediately.

ingredients: 2 lbs (900 g) Bintje or Yukon Gold potatoes, peeled
Beef tallow or peanut oil for deep frying
steps: Cut potatoes into 3/8-inch (1 cm) batons. Soak in cold water for 30 minutes to remove excess starch, then drain and dry thoroughly with towels.

Heat tallow or oil to 280°F (140°C). Fry the batons in batches for 5–6 minutes—they should be cooked through but still pale. Remove and drain on a wire rack. Let cool at least 15 minutes (up to several hours).
Just before serving, reheat the oil to 375°F (190°C). Fry the blanched frites a second time for 2–3 minutes until deeply golden and audibly crisp.
Drain briefly, toss with fine sea salt, and serve immediately in paper cones.

dessert.description: The REAL Belgian waffle—nothing like the fluffy impostor served at brunch buffets. A rich, yeasted brioche dough is studded with chunks of Belgian pearl sugar that caramelize into irresistible crunchy, sticky pockets when pressed in a hot waffle iron. Dense, chewy, and deeply sweet, the Liège waffle is eaten by hand from a paper wrapper and needs no toppings whatsoever.
ingredients: 3/4 cup (170 g) unsalted butter, softened and cut into cubes
3/4 cup (135 g) Belgian pearl sugar (do not substitute)
steps: Dissolve yeast in the warm milk and let stand 5 minutes until foamy.
In a stand mixer with the dough hook, combine flour, eggs, vanilla, granulated sugar, and salt. Add the yeast-milk mixture and knead on medium speed for 5 minutes until a smooth, elastic dough forms.

With the mixer running on low, add softened butter a few cubes at a time, waiting until each addition is incorporated before adding the next. Once all butter is in, increase speed to medium and knead 5–7 minutes more. The dough will be very soft, sticky, and brioche-like.
Cover the bowl tightly with plastic wrap and let rise at room temperature until doubled, about 1 1/2–2 hours.
Punch down the dough, cover, and refrigerate at least 4 hours or overnight (cold dough is essential for handling).
Remove dough from the fridge. Gently fold in the pearl sugar by hand—press it in rather than kneading, so the chunks stay intact.
Divide into 6–8 portions (about 3 oz / 85 g each). Shape into rough balls.
Preheat a waffle iron to medium-high heat (a Belgian or standard iron both work). Lightly grease if needed.

Place a dough ball in the center of the iron and press closed. Cook 3–5 minutes, checking often—the sugar caramelizes fast and can burn. The waffle is done when deeply golden with visible caramelized sugar pockets.
Eat warm, by hand, from a paper wrapper. No toppings needed—the pearl sugar is everything.

BEN.description: A Beninese tomato- and palm-oil–tinted cornmeal paste, often served with fried fish, chicken, or a spicy sauce.
ingredients: 2 cups (280 g) fine cornmeal (or maize flour)
1 cup (240 ml) tomato purée (or crushed tomatoes blended smooth)
1/4 cup (60 ml) red palm oil (or vegetable oil)
4 cups (960 ml) hot water or warm vegetable/chicken stock
1 tsp kosher salt (plus more to taste)
steps: Heat palm oil in a heavy saucepan over medium heat. Add onion and cook until translucent, 5–7 minutes. Add garlic and cook 30 seconds.
Stir in tomato paste and cook 1–2 minutes. Add tomato purée, salt, pepper, bay leaf (if using), and cayenne (if using). Simmer 5 minutes.
Pour in the hot water/stock, bring to a steady simmer, and taste for seasoning.
Whisk in the cornmeal in a slow stream to avoid lumps. Switch to a sturdy spoon and stir continuously until very thick, 5–8 minutes.
Reduce heat to low, cover, and cook 10 minutes, stirring and scraping the bottom every couple of minutes.
Shape into mounds with a wet spoon or serve family-style. Traditionally served hot with a protein and sauce.

drink.description: A Benin-inspired cocktail built on sodabi arrangé (infused sodabi), brightened with lime, mint, and cucumber.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) sodabi arrangé (or plain sodabi)
3/4 oz (22 ml) simple syrup (see preliminary steps)
steps: Place cucumber slices and mint leaves in a cocktail shaker. Muddle gently—press and twist to release the juices without shredding the mint.
Add sodabi, lime juice, and simple syrup to the shaker.
Fill with ice and shake hard for 10–12 seconds until the shaker frosts over.
Double strain through a fine-mesh sieve into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.
Top with chilled soda water and give one gentle stir. Garnish with a mint sprig and a cucumber slice.

dessert.description: A beloved West African dessert-drink-pudding hybrid: small pearls of steamed millet couscous folded into thick, sweetened yogurt or sour cream, delicately flavored with vanilla and a whisper of nutmeg. Served chilled, Dèguè is creamy, grainy, and utterly refreshing—a staple at Beninese celebrations and street stalls alike.
ingredients: 1 cup (180 g) millet couscous (dégué grains or fine millet couscous)
2 cups (480 ml) plain whole-milk yogurt (or thick sour cream)
1/2 cup (120 ml) sweetened condensed milk (or 1/3 cup / 65 g sugar dissolved in the yogurt)
steps: Place millet couscous in a bowl. Sprinkle with the water and toss with your fingers until the grains are evenly moistened (not wet).
Steam the moistened couscous in a couscous steamer or fine-mesh sieve set over a pot of boiling water, covered, for 15–20 minutes until the grains are tender and fluffy.
Spread the steamed couscous on a tray and let it cool completely (fluff with a fork as it cools to prevent clumping).
In a large bowl, whisk the yogurt (or sour cream), condensed milk (or sugar), vanilla, nutmeg, and salt until smooth.
Fold the cooled millet couscous into the yogurt mixture until evenly combined. If too thick, thin with a splash of evaporated milk.
Cover and refrigerate at least 2 hours (overnight is even better—the millet softens further and the flavors meld).
Serve well-chilled in glasses or bowls. Stir before serving as it may separate slightly.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan. Heat just until the sugar dissolves (no need to boil hard).
Cool completely and refrigerate in a clean jar up to 2 weeks.

BFA.description: A West African “fat rice” dish popular in Burkina Faso—tomato rice cooked with meat and vegetables until richly seasoned.
ingredients: 1 tsp kosher salt (plus more to taste)
2 cups green beans or cabbage, chopped
steps: Heat oil in a heavy pot. Brown the chicken/beef on all sides. Remove to a plate.
Sauté onion until soft, 5–7 minutes. Add garlic and cook 30 seconds.
Stir in tomato paste and cook 1 minute. Add crushed tomatoes, thyme, bay leaf, salt, pepper, and (if using) chile. Simmer 5 minutes.
Return meat to the pot and add stock. Bring to a simmer and cook 15 minutes.
Stir in rice and vegetables. Cover and cook on low until the rice is tender and liquid absorbed, 18–25 minutes (time depends on rice).
Rest 10 minutes off heat, then fluff and serve.

drink.description: A Burkinabè ginger drink often made with tamarind and a touch of millet for body; served cold.
ingredients: 1/2 cup tamarind pulp (or 3 tbsp tamarind concentrate)
3-inch piece fresh ginger, peeled and grated
steps: In a bowl, soak tamarind pulp in 3 cups warm water for 15 minutes, then mash and strain to extract the tart liquid. (Skip if using concentrate.)
In a pot, bring the remaining 5 cups water to a boil with the grated ginger. Simmer 5 minutes, then turn off heat.
Whisk millet flour with a splash of cool water to make a thin slurry. Stir it into the hot ginger water (off heat).
Add tamarind liquid (or concentrate), sugar, and salt. Stir well, strain if desired, and cool.
Chill thoroughly and serve over ice with mint.

dessert.description: Crispy fried millet fritters, golden-brown and sweetened with wild honey, spiced with a warm kick of ginger. Sold by women at every Ouagadougou market corner, Gonré are the irresistible street-side sweet of Burkina Faso—crunchy outside, tender within, and impossible to eat just one.
ingredients: 3/4 cup (180 ml) warm water (or as needed)
steps: Whisk together millet flour, all-purpose flour, sugar, ginger, cinnamon, nutmeg, baking powder, and salt in a large bowl.

Make a well in the center. Add the egg and warm water. Stir until a thick, scoopable batter forms (add more water 1 tbsp at a time if too stiff—it should be thicker than pancake batter but not a stiff dough).
Let the batter rest 15 minutes.
Heat 2–3 inches (5–7 cm) of vegetable oil in a deep pot or Dutch oven to 350°F (175°C).
Using two spoons or wet hands, drop walnut-sized balls of batter into the hot oil. Do not crowd the pot—fry in batches of 5–6.
Fry, turning occasionally, until deeply golden brown on all sides, 3–4 minutes per batch. Remove with a slotted spoon and drain on paper towels.
While still warm, drizzle generously with the Honey-Ginger Drizzle or dip the fritters directly into the warm honey mixture.
Serve warm or at room temperature.
Warm honey, grated ginger, water, and a pinch of salt in a small saucepan over low heat, stirring, until thin and fragrant (about 2 minutes).
Strain out the ginger pieces (or leave them in for extra bite). Use warm.

BGD.description: The undisputed pride of Bengal and the most revered fish dish on the subcontinent. Silvery Hilsa steaks—prized for their rich, oily flesh—are draped in a fiery, pungent sauce of freshly ground black and yellow mustard seeds, green chilies, and golden mustard oil. Every Bengali family guards their own balance of heat and sharpness; the sauce should sting the nose, sting the eyes, and leave you reaching for another bite with a mound of steaming white rice.
ingredients: 6 pieces Ilish (Hilsa) fish steaks (about 1 1/2 lb / 680 g total)
1/2 cup (120 ml) mustard oil (essential for authentic taste)
1 tsp salt, plus more to taste
1 cup (240 ml) water (for the mustard paste)
steps: Soak mustard seeds in warm water, then blend into a smooth paste with 2 green chilies and a pinch of salt.
Rub fish steaks with turmeric and salt. Let sit for 10 mins.
Heat mustard oil in a pan. Temper with nigella seeds and slit green chilies.
Mix the mustard paste with 1 cup water and pour into the pan.
Gently slide the fish steaks into the gravy.
Cover and simmer on low heat for 10-15 minutes. Do not flip too often as fish is delicate.
Finish with a drizzle of raw mustard oil on top before serving with steaming white rice.

drink.description: Not a polite afternoon cuppa—Bangladeshi cha is brewed hard and fast in roadside stalls across Dhaka: loose-leaf black tea simmered until nearly bitter, then tamed with a generous pour of whole milk and sweetened until the spoon almost stands up. Served in small glass cups, it fuels the entire nation from dawn to midnight.
ingredients: 2 tsp (4 g) loose black tea (CTC or Assam-style)
Optional: 1/2-inch (1 cm) piece fresh ginger, smashed
steps: Bring water to a rolling boil in a small saucepan. Add cardamom and ginger if using.
Add tea leaves and boil vigorously for 2–3 minutes—the liquor should turn very dark.
Pour in the milk. Return to a simmer and cook 2–3 minutes, letting it rise and foam. Watch closely to prevent boiling over.
Add sugar and stir until dissolved.
Strain through a fine-mesh strainer into small glass cups, pouring from a height to create a frothy top.
Serve immediately while piping hot.

dessert.description: The pride of Bengali confectionery: spongy white balls of fresh chhena cheese, kneaded until silky-smooth, then simmered gently in a light sugar syrup until they swell and absorb the sweetness, becoming pillowy-soft and dripping with syrup at every bite. A dessert of deceptive simplicity that demands perfect technique.
ingredients: Chhena from 1/2 gallon (1.9 L) whole milk (see preliminary steps)
1 tsp fine semolina (rava/sooji) or 1/2 tsp all-purpose flour
1/4 tsp rose water (optional, mixed into the chhena)
1 tsp rose water (for the syrup, optional)
steps: Prepare the chhena (see preliminary steps). While still fresh and warm, knead it on a clean surface with the heel of your palm for 8–10 minutes until completely smooth, soft, and crack-free. Mix in semolina (or flour) during kneading.
Divide into 14–16 equal portions and roll each into a smooth ball with no cracks on the surface. They will expand to roughly double their size.
Prepare the syrup: combine sugar and water in a wide, deep pot. Bring to a rolling boil, stirring to dissolve sugar. Skim any scum.
Gently lower the chhena balls into the boiling syrup. They will sink at first.

Cover and cook on medium-high heat for 15–18 minutes. The balls will swell dramatically and float to the surface. Do not open the lid for the first 10 minutes—the steam pressure is essential for the spongy texture.
After 15–18 minutes, remove from heat. Add rose water and cardamom to the syrup if using.
Let the roshogolla cool in the syrup. They will absorb more sweetness as they rest. Refrigerate at least 4 hours before serving.
Serve chilled or at room temperature, in small bowls with plenty of syrup.

ingredients: 1/2 gallon (1.9 L) whole milk (full-fat, not ultra-pasteurized)
3 tbsp lemon juice or white vinegar, mixed with 1/4 cup (60 ml) water
steps: Bring milk to a full boil in a heavy pot, stirring to prevent scorching.

Reduce heat to low. Add the lemon juice mixture slowly, stirring gently. The milk will curdle and the whey will turn greenish-clear within 1–2 minutes. Stop adding acid as soon as full separation occurs.
Pour through a cheesecloth-lined colander. Rinse under cold water for 30 seconds to remove the acidic taste.
Gather the cheesecloth and squeeze out excess water. Hang for 30–45 minutes (no longer) until the chhena is moist but not dripping. It should be soft and pliable, not dry or crumbly.

BGR.description: A symbol of Bulgarian hospitality. Whisked eggs and sirene cheese are layered between filo pastry sheets, then baked until golden. It is eaten for breakfast, Christmas, and New Year's—often with lucky charms hidden inside.
ingredients: 1 lb (450 g) package filo pastry sheets (about 20 sheets), thawed if frozen
2 cups (300 g) sirene cheese (Bulgarian feta), crumbled
1 cup (240 g) Bulgarian yogurt (or full-fat plain yogurt)
1 stick (115 g / 1/2 cup) unsalted butter, melted
steps: Preheat oven to 350°F (180°C). Brush a round baking pan (12-inch / 30 cm) generously with melted butter.
Whisk eggs, yogurt, baking soda, and a pinch of salt in a bowl. Stir in the crumbled sirene cheese until evenly combined.
Lay one sheet of filo on a clean surface, brush lightly with butter, and spread 2–3 tablespoons of filling along one long edge.
Roll the filo sheet into a loose cigar shape. Coil it in the center of the buttered pan. Repeat with remaining sheets, wrapping each new roll around the growing spiral.
Brush the top generously with the remaining melted butter. Sprinkle a few drops of water over the surface (this helps the top layer puff).
Bake 30–40 minutes until deeply golden and crisp on top. Let rest 10 minutes before slicing into wedges.
Serve warm with plain yogurt on the side.

drink.description: A thick, mildly sweet, gently fermented cereal drink popular in Bulgaria and the Balkans—served chilled, often with a sprinkle of cinnamon.
ingredients: 3/4 cup granulated sugar (150 g), plus more to taste
1/2 tsp active dry yeast (2 g) (or 2 tbsp plain yogurt as starter)
steps: Whisk millet flour with 2 cups of the water in a pot until smooth.
Add remaining water and a pinch of salt; bring to a gentle simmer, whisking often, 20–30 minutes until thickened and starchy.
Cool to lukewarm (about 90°F/32°C). Stir in sugar until dissolved.
Stir in yeast (or yogurt starter). Cover loosely and ferment at room temp 8–16 hours, until lightly tangy and gently bubbly.
Refrigerate until cold (it thickens more as it chills).
Serve cold, stirred; dust with cinnamon if you like.

dessert.description: A legendary Bulgarian chocolate-walnut cake born at the Hotel Garash in Ruse: finely ground walnuts and dark chocolate folded into clouds of whipped egg whites, baked into a dense, flourless torte, and glazed with a rich, dark chocolate ganache. Intensely chocolatey, deeply nutty, and impossibly elegant—Garash Torte is Bulgaria's finest contribution to European pâtisserie.
ingredients: 2 1/2 cups (250 g) walnuts, very finely ground (almost to a flour)
3 oz (85 g) dark chocolate (70% cacao), finely grated
steps: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Line the bottoms of two 9-inch (23 cm) round cake pans with parchment. Do not grease the sides.
Whisk egg whites and cream of tartar until soft peaks form. Gradually add sugar, beating until stiff, glossy peaks form.
Gently fold in the ground walnuts, grated chocolate, and vanilla in three additions, being careful not to deflate the whites.
Divide the batter evenly between the two pans. Smooth the tops gently.
Bake 25–30 minutes until the tops are set and lightly golden (the centers will still feel slightly soft—they firm as they cool).
Cool in pans 10 minutes, then carefully unmold onto wire racks. Remove parchment and cool completely.
Place one layer on a serving plate. Spread a thin layer of Chocolate Ganache Glaze between the layers and sandwich together.
Pour the remaining warm ganache over the top of the torte, letting it cascade down the sides. Use a palette knife to smooth if needed.
Let the glaze set at room temperature (about 1 hour) until firm and glossy.
Slice with a hot, dry knife. Serve at room temperature.

ingredients: 8 oz (225 g) dark chocolate (70% cacao), finely chopped
steps: Heat cream in a saucepan until it just begins to simmer (do not boil).
Pour over the chopped chocolate in a heatproof bowl. Let stand 2 minutes, then stir from the center outward until completely smooth and glossy.
Stir in butter until incorporated. Use while still warm and pourable (about 90°F / 32°C).

BHR.dish: Machboos Dajaj (مجبوس دجاج) — Bahraini Chicken Rice
BHR.description: Bahrain’s signature spiced rice: chicken cooked in a tomato-and-aromatic broth with loomi (dried black lime), then the rice is steamed in the same stock for deep, layered flavor.
ingredients: 2 tbsp (30 ml) neutral oil or ghee
1 whole chicken (3–4 lb / 1.4–1.8 kg), cut into pieces
1 dried black lime (loomi), pierced with a knife
2 tsp kosher salt, plus more to taste
3 cups (600 g) basmati rice, rinsed and soaked 20 minutes, drained
4 1/2 cups (1.1 L) water (or enough to cover chicken and later measure stock)
Optional: pinch saffron steeped in 2 tbsp hot water
Optional garnish: 1/3 cup (50 g) toasted almonds or raisins
steps: Heat oil in a large pot. Sauté onion until deeply golden, 10–12 minutes. Add garlic and cook 30 seconds.
Stir in tomato paste, then tomatoes; cook until jammy, 5–7 minutes.
Add chicken, loomi, bay, cardamom, cloves, cinnamon, cumin, coriander, turmeric, pepper, and salt. Add water to barely cover.
Bring to a boil, skim, then simmer covered 35–45 minutes until chicken is cooked.
Transfer chicken to a tray. Measure the cooking liquid; you need about 4 1/2 cups (1.1 L). Add water if short or boil to reduce if long. Taste and adjust salt.
Add drained rice to the pot. Bring to a gentle boil, then cover tightly and cook on low 15 minutes. Rest off heat 10 minutes.
Meanwhile, broil or oven-roast the chicken 8–12 minutes to brown.
Fluff rice, drizzle saffron water if using, and serve topped with chicken and optional nuts/raisins.

drink.dish: Karak Chai (شاي كرك) — Spiced Milk Tea
drink.description: Sweet, strong, and fragrant—Bahraini-style karak is black tea simmered with cardamom (often with saffron) and finished with milk.
ingredients: 2 tsp loose black tea (or 2 tea bags)
6 green cardamom pods, lightly crushed (or 1/2 tsp ground cardamom)
2 cups (475 ml) whole milk (or evaporated milk)
steps: Lightly crush the cardamom pods with the flat of a knife to release the seeds.
Bring water to a simmer in a small saucepan. Add tea leaves, crushed cardamom, and saffron (if using).
Simmer on medium-low heat for 3–5 minutes until the brew is very dark and aromatic.
Pour in the milk. Increase heat slightly and bring to a gentle boil, then reduce to a simmer.
Simmer the milky tea for 5–8 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the color deepens to a rich caramel-amber and the volume reduces slightly.
Add sugar and stir until dissolved. Taste and adjust sweetness—karak is traditionally quite sweet.
Strain through a fine-mesh strainer into small glass cups (karak cups or istikana). Serve immediately while hot.

dessert.description: Bahraini halwa: a translucent, jewel-like confection slow-stirred for an hour from cornstarch, sugar, saffron, rosewater, and ghee until it pulls away from the pot in a glossy, aromatic mass. Studded with toasted almonds and perfumed with cardamom, this is the treasure served at weddings, Eid celebrations, and with Arabic coffee. Making halwa is an act of patience rewarded with something transcendent.
ingredients: Generous pinch saffron threads, steeped in 3 tbsp hot water
1/2 cup (50 g) blanched almonds, toasted and halved
steps: Dissolve cornstarch in 2 cups (475 ml) of the water in a bowl, whisking until smooth. Set aside.
In a heavy-bottomed pot, combine sugar and the remaining 2 cups (475 ml) water. Bring to a boil, stirring until sugar dissolves. Simmer 5 minutes to make a thin syrup.
Reduce heat to medium-low. Slowly pour the cornstarch mixture into the sugar syrup, stirring constantly with a wooden spoon to prevent lumps.
Add the ghee a tablespoon at a time, stirring vigorously after each addition. The mixture will begin to thicken and become translucent.
Stir in the saffron (with its water), rose water, and cardamom. Continue stirring constantly over medium-low heat.

Cook, stirring without stopping, for 45 minutes to 1 hour. The halwa is ready when it is deeply golden, translucent, pulls away cleanly from the sides of the pot, and the ghee has been fully absorbed.
Fold in the toasted almonds (and pine nuts if using).
Pour into a greased dish or plate, smooth the top, and press additional almond halves into the surface for garnish.
Let cool and set at room temperature. Cut into squares or diamonds, or scoop with a spoon. Serve alongside Arabic coffee.

BHS.dish: Cracked Conch with Peas and Rice
BHS.description: The Queen Conch is the icon of the Bahamas. For this dish, the tough muscle is pounded until tender ('cracked'), battered, and fried to golden perfection, capturing the essence of island life alongside savory pigeon peas and rice.
ingredients: 1 goat pepper or habanero, seeded and minced
Oil for deep frying (about 4 cups / 950 ml)
Bahamian Peas and Rice (see preliminary steps)
steps: Place conch between sheets of plastic wrap and pound vigorously with a meat mallet until about 1/4-inch (6 mm) thick and tender. Cut into 3-inch (8 cm) pieces.
Toss conch with lime juice, minced goat pepper, and a pinch of salt. Marinate for 15–20 minutes.
Whisk eggs and milk together in a shallow bowl for the egg wash.
Combine flour, salt, pepper, garlic powder, and cayenne in another shallow bowl.
Heat oil to 350°F (180°C) in a deep pot or Dutch oven. Line a plate with paper towels.
Dip each conch piece in the egg wash, then dredge in the seasoned flour, pressing to coat evenly. Shake off excess.
Fry conch in batches (do not crowd) for 2–3 minutes per side until deep golden brown. Do not overcook—conch turns rubbery quickly. Drain on paper towels.
Serve immediately with lime wedges, tartar sauce or hot pepper sauce, and a generous scoop of Peas and Rice.

ingredients: 4 oz (115 g) salt pork or thick-cut bacon, diced
1 can (15 oz / 425 g) pigeon peas (or 1 cup dried, soaked overnight and pre-cooked)
2 cups (400 g) long-grain white rice, rinsed
3 cups (720 ml) water or chicken stock
2 sprigs fresh thyme (or 1 tsp dried thyme)
steps: In a heavy pot, render the diced salt pork (or bacon) over medium heat until the fat is released and the pieces are crispy, about 5–7 minutes.
Add onion and sauté until softened, 3–4 minutes. Stir in tomato paste and cook 1 minute.
Add pigeon peas, water (or stock), thyme, salt, and pepper. Bring to a boil.
Stir in the rice, return to a boil, then reduce heat to low. Cover tightly and cook 18–20 minutes until rice is tender and liquid is absorbed.
Remove from heat, keep covered, and let steam 5 minutes. Fluff with a fork before serving.

drink.description: Born at Miss Emily's Blue Bee Bar on Harbour Island, the Goombay Smash is the unofficial cocktail of the Bahamas—a sun-drenched blend of coconut rum, dark rum, and tropical fruit juices that tastes like a lazy afternoon on a powdery pink-sand beach. Dangerously easy to drink, it sneaks up on you with island charm.
ingredients: 1/2 oz (15 ml) simple syrup (optional, adjust to taste)
1 cup crushed ice, plus more for serving
Pineapple wedge or orange slice, for garnish
steps: Combine coconut rum, dark rum, pineapple juice, orange juice, lime juice, and simple syrup (if using) in a cocktail shaker.
Add crushed ice and shake vigorously for 10–15 seconds until the shaker is frosty.
Strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh crushed ice.
Garnish with a pineapple wedge or orange slice on the rim.
For a frozen version, blend all ingredients with 1 cup of ice until smooth and pour into a tall glass.
Serve immediately—this drink does not wait.

dessert.description: The Bahamian national dessert: a steamed or boiled suet pudding rolled around a sweet, fragrant guava filling, sliced into thick rounds, and drenched with a warm, buttery rum sauce poured lavishly over the top. The sauce—rich with butter, sugar, and dark rum—is the soul of Guava Duff, transforming a humble steamed pudding into an island masterpiece.
ingredients: 1/3 cup (75 g) vegetable shortening or cold butter, cut into small pieces
2 cups (300 g) ripe guava, peeled and diced (or 1 can / 14 oz guava shells, drained and chopped)
steps: Whisk together flour, baking powder, cinnamon, nutmeg, and salt in a large bowl.
Cut in the shortening (or butter) with a pastry cutter or fingertips until the mixture resembles coarse crumbs.
Add milk gradually, stirring with a fork, until a soft dough forms (use just enough to bring it together—do not overwork).
Roll the dough out on a floured surface into a rectangle about 10x14 inches (25x35 cm) and 1/4 inch (6 mm) thick.
Toss the diced guava with sugar and spread it evenly over the dough, leaving a 1-inch (2.5 cm) border.
Roll up the dough tightly from the long side, like a jelly roll. Pinch the seam and ends to seal.
Wrap the roll snugly in a double layer of cheesecloth (or a flour-sack towel), tying the ends with kitchen twine.
Place the wrapped roll in a large pot fitted with a steamer rack (or on an inverted plate). Add enough boiling water to come halfway up the roll.
Cover tightly and steam over medium heat for 1 1/2–2 hours, adding more boiling water as needed to maintain the level.
Carefully unwrap the duff and let it rest 10 minutes. Slice into thick rounds.
Spoon warm Butter-Rum Sauce generously over each serving. The sauce is not optional—it is the entire point.
Melt butter in a saucepan over medium heat. Add sugar and stir until dissolved and smooth.
Remove from heat and let cool for 2 minutes. Whisk in the beaten egg very gradually (temper it in slowly to avoid scrambling).
Return to low heat and stir constantly until the sauce thickens slightly, 3–4 minutes (do not boil).
Remove from heat and stir in the rum, vanilla, and nutmeg. Serve warm over the sliced duff.

BIH.description: The Balkan king of kebabs. Small, hand-rolled sausages made of minced beef and lamb, grilled over charcoal and tucked into soft somun bread with raw onions and kajmak.
ingredients: 4 cloves Garlic (minced and boiled in 1/2 cup water - use the water)
steps: Mix meats, salt, pepper, baking soda, and the garlic water (strained). Knead well for 10 mins.
Refrigerate mixture overnight (crucial for texture).
Form into small finger-sized sausages.
Grill on high heat (charcoal is best) until browned and bouncy.
Serve tucked inside warm somun bread with a side of raw onions and a scoop of kajmak.

drink.description: Strong, foam-topped coffee made in a džezva and served with sugar cubes and lokum—central to Bosnian hospitality.
ingredients: 2 tsp very finely ground coffee (Turkish grind) (6–7 g)
To serve: sugar cubes and/or lokum (Turkish delight)
steps: Add water to a džezva (small long-handled pot) and heat until just below a boil.
Remove from heat, add coffee (and sugar if sweetening in the pot), and whisk to combine.
Return to low heat. When foam rises, remove before it boils over.
Let foam settle, then repeat the foam-rise once more for a richer top.
Pour slowly into small cups, dividing the foam between cups.
Let grounds settle 1–2 minutes before sipping.

dessert.description: The jewel of every Bosnian kafana: whole apples hollowed and poached in fragrant sugar syrup until tender and translucent, stuffed with a generous mound of crushed walnuts, and crowned with a rosette of whipped cream. Each spoonful marries the honeyed softness of the fruit with the crunch of nuts and the floral sweetness of the syrup—a dessert that has graced Bosnian celebrations for centuries.
ingredients: 6 medium firm apples (Granny Smith or Golden Delicious)
steps: Peel the apples, leaving them whole. Using a melon baller or small knife, carefully hollow out the core from the bottom, creating a cavity for the filling—leave the top intact.
Prepare the sugar syrup according to the Chef's Essentials below. Gently lower the apples into the simmering syrup.
Poach the apples for 20–30 minutes, turning occasionally, until they are tender and slightly translucent but still hold their shape.
Carefully transfer the apples to a deep serving dish. Reduce the syrup by a third over medium-high heat until it thickens and turns golden.
Stuff each apple cavity generously with chopped walnuts, mounding them on top.
Pour the warm reduced syrup over and around the stuffed apples. Let cool to room temperature, then refrigerate for at least 2 hours.
Whip the heavy cream with powdered sugar and vanilla until stiff peaks form.
Serve each apple in a pool of syrup, crowned with a generous dollop of whipped cream.
Combine sugar and water in a wide, heavy-bottomed saucepan. Stir over medium heat until the sugar fully dissolves.
Add lemon juice, cinnamon stick, and cloves. Bring to a gentle boil.
Reduce heat and simmer for 10 minutes until slightly thickened and fragrant.
Remove the cinnamon stick and cloves before using. Stir in vanilla if desired.

BLR.description: The ultimate potato pancake. Belarusians claim to consume the most potatoes per capita, and this crispy, shallow-fried fritter—grated finely to release starch—is the delicious reason why.
ingredients: 1 tsp kosher salt, plus more to taste
Neutral oil for frying (about 1/4 cup / 60 ml)
To serve: sour cream; optional chopped dill
steps: Grate potatoes and onion on the fine holes of a box grater (or use a food processor).
Wrap in a clean towel and squeeze hard to remove excess liquid; pour off liquid and keep the starch that settles at the bottom.
Mix grated potato/onion with egg, flour, reserved potato starch, salt, and pepper.
Heat a thin layer of oil in a skillet over medium-high.
Drop heaping tablespoons of batter, flatten slightly, and fry 3–4 minutes per side until deeply golden.
Drain briefly on a rack or paper towels. Serve hot with sour cream (and dill if you like).

drink.dish: Birch Sap Kvass (Бярозавік / Fermented Birch Drink)
drink.description: A lightly fermented, gently sparkling drink made from birch sap (often sold bottled), sweetened and fermented with raisins or a pinch of yeast.
ingredients: 2 quarts birch sap (1.9 L), chilled (bottled birch sap works)
1/4 cup honey or sugar (60–70 g), to taste
Optional (for faster fermentation): 1/8 tsp active dry yeast
steps: In a clean 2–3 quart jar, dissolve honey/sugar in the birch sap.
Add raisins, lemon slices, and mint (if using).
If using yeast, sprinkle it on top and stir once.
Cover loosely (or use an airlock) and ferment at room temp 12–36 hours, until lightly fizzy.
Strain, bottle, and chill. Open carefully—pressure can build.
Drink within 3–5 days.

dessert.description: A Belarusian grandmother's pride and the sweetest secret of the countryside: tender dumplings wrapped around juicy, tart cherries, boiled until they float, then dusted with a snow of powdered sugar and served with a generous spoonful of cool smetana. Each bite bursts with warm cherry juice against the pillowy dough—rustic, nostalgic, and utterly comforting.
ingredients: 1/4 cup (30 g) powdered sugar, for dusting
1 cup (240 ml) smetana (sour cream), for serving
steps: Prepare the dumpling dough and cherry filling according to the Chef's Essentials below.
Roll out the dough on a lightly floured surface to about 1/8 inch (3 mm) thick. Cut circles using a 3-inch (7.5 cm) round cutter.
Place 2–3 cherries with a small spoonful of their sugared juice in the center of each circle.
Fold the dough over into a half-moon and pinch the edges firmly to seal, ensuring no juice can escape.
Bring a large pot of lightly salted water to a gentle boil. Working in batches, drop the dumplings in and cook until they float to the surface, about 3–4 minutes.
Remove with a slotted spoon and toss gently with melted butter to prevent sticking.
Arrange on a warm platter, dust generously with powdered sugar, and serve immediately with cold smetana on the side.
Mound the flour on a clean surface and make a well in the center.
Add the egg, warm water, salt, and oil to the well. Gradually incorporate the flour from the edges, mixing until a shaggy dough forms.
Knead for 8–10 minutes until smooth and elastic. Wrap in plastic and rest at room temperature for 30 minutes.

ingredients: 2 cups (300 g) fresh or frozen pitted sour cherries
steps: Toss the pitted cherries with sugar and cornstarch in a bowl.
Let macerate for 15–20 minutes until the cherries release some juice and the sugar dissolves.
Drain off excess liquid (reserve it for drizzling if desired).

BLZ.dish: Stew Chicken with Rice and Beans
BLZ.description: The Sunday dinner of Belize. This comfort dish gets its signature crimson hue and earthy flavor from Red Recado (annatto paste), a Mayan spice staple, paired perfectly with rice cooked in fresh coconut milk.
ingredients: Rice & Beans: 2 cups Rice, 1 cup Red Kidney Beans (stewed), 1 cup Coconut Milk, Garlic
steps: Dissolve recado in a little vinegar/water. Rub over chicken with salt and pepper. Marinate.
Brown chicken pieces in a pot. Remove.
Sauté onions and peppers. Return chicken. Add water to cover. Simmer for 45 mins until tender and gravy thickens.
Rice: Mix cooked beans (with liquid), coconut milk, garlic, and uncooked rice in a pot.
Simmer covered until rice absorbs all liquid and is fluffy.
Serve with fried plantains and potato salad.

drink.description: A Belizean crowd-pleaser: coconut rum and pineapple juice, served cold and simple.
steps: Fill a tall glass with ice.
Add coconut rum and pineapple juice; stir.
Serve immediately.

dessert.description: Found at every roadside bakery and village shop from Belize City to San Ignacio: flaky, golden pastry shells cradling a sweet, sticky filling of freshly grated coconut slow-cooked with brown sugar, warm nutmeg, and vanilla until caramelized and fragrant. These palm-sized tarts are Belize in a bite—Caribbean warmth, Mestizo pastry craft, and the perfume of coconut groves all at once.
ingredients: Tart Pastry Shells (see Chef's Essentials below)
3 cups (225 g) finely grated fresh coconut (or dried unsweetened shredded coconut, rehydrated)
1 cup (220 g) dark brown sugar, packed
steps: Prepare the tart pastry shells according to the Chef's Essentials below. Blind-bake and set aside.
In a heavy-bottomed saucepan, combine the grated coconut, brown sugar, coconut milk, and butter over medium heat.
Stir continuously as the mixture bubbles and the sugar dissolves. Cook for 12–15 minutes, stirring frequently, until the coconut turns sticky, deeply golden, and the liquid has been absorbed.
Remove from heat and stir in the vanilla, nutmeg, cinnamon, and salt.
Spoon the warm coconut filling generously into each pre-baked tart shell, pressing down lightly.
Allow the tarts to cool completely at room temperature—the filling will set as it cools into a chewy, caramelized center.
Serve at room temperature. These keep well in an airtight container for 2–3 days.

ingredients: 1/2 cup (115 g) cold unsalted butter, cubed
steps: Whisk flour, sugar, and salt together. Cut in the cold butter using a pastry cutter or your fingertips until the mixture resembles coarse crumbs.
Beat the egg with 2 tbsp ice water and add to the flour mixture. Mix until the dough just comes together, adding more water a teaspoon at a time if needed.
Wrap in plastic and refrigerate for at least 30 minutes.
Roll out to 1/8-inch (3 mm) thickness. Cut and press into greased tart tins or muffin cups. Prick the bottoms with a fork.
Blind-bake at 375°F (190°C) for 10–12 minutes until lightly golden. Cool before filling.

ingredients: 2 tbsp bitter orange juice (or 1 tbsp orange + 1 tbsp lime)
steps: Toast achiote seeds briefly in a dry pan (30–60 seconds).
Grind achiote with peppercorns, cumin, cloves, oregano, and cinnamon to a powder (spice grinder).
Blend with garlic, citrus juice, vinegar, and salt into a thick paste.
Refrigerate up to 1 week, or freeze in portions.
Toast achiote seeds 30–60 seconds.
Blend or grind seeds with vinegar, garlic, salt (and cumin) until a red paste forms.
Strain if gritty. Refrigerate up to 1 week.

BMU.description: A British naval legacy adapted to island life. This dark, aromatic chowder is non-negotiable without its two sidekicks: a splash of Gosling's Black Seal Rum and a dash of Sherry Peppers sauce, added tableside to cut the richness.
steps: Sauté onion and celery. Add tomatoes and fish stock. Bring to a boil.
Add fish, herbs, and spices. Simmer for 30-40 mins until fish flakes apart.
Mash the fish against the side of the pot (it should be a chowder, not chunky stew).
Simmer for another 20 mins.
Serve hot. Crucial step: Each person adds a splash of Black Rum and Sherry Peppers sauce at the table.

drink.description: A Bermudian classic built on rum and fruit juices—often called Bermuda’s national drink.
steps: Shake all ingredients with ice.
Strain into an ice-filled glass.
Garnish if desired and serve.
Note (quick grenadine): simmer equal parts pomegranate juice + sugar until dissolved; cool before using.
Warm pomegranate juice and sugar in a saucepan over medium heat, stirring until dissolved (avoid a hard boil).
Cool; stir in orange blossom water if using.
Bottle; add vodka if using for shelf-life.
Refrigerate and use within 3–4 weeks (longer if vodka added).

dessert.description: Bermuda's gift to the world of baking: a dense, impossibly moist dark cake steeped in Gosling's Black Seal rum and enriched with black treacle, warm spices, and dried fruit. Baked in a Bundt pan and drenched in a hot rum syrup while still warm, it deepens in flavor for days—if it lasts that long. Found in every Bermudian kitchen during the holidays, but beloved year-round.
ingredients: 1 cup (200 g) dark brown sugar, packed
1/2 cup (120 ml) Gosling's Black Seal rum (or dark rum)
2 tbsp (30 ml) black treacle (or blackstrap molasses)
1 cup (150 g) mixed dried fruit (raisins, currants, candied peel), soaked overnight in 1/4 cup rum
1/2 cup (60 g) chopped walnuts or pecans
Rum Soaking Syrup (see Chef's Essentials below)
steps: Preheat oven to 325°F (165°C). Grease and flour a 10-inch (25 cm) Bundt pan generously.
Cream butter and brown sugar until light and fluffy, about 4 minutes. Beat in eggs one at a time, then the treacle and rum.
Whisk together flour, baking powder, baking soda, cinnamon, nutmeg, cloves, and salt in a separate bowl.
Alternately fold the dry ingredients and buttermilk into the batter in three additions, beginning and ending with the dry mix. Do not overmix.
Fold in the rum-soaked dried fruit (with any remaining liquid) and the chopped nuts.
Pour into the prepared pan and bake for 50–60 minutes, until a skewer inserted in the center comes out clean.
While the cake bakes, prepare the Rum Soaking Syrup (see Chef's Essentials below).
Remove the cake from the oven. While still hot and in the pan, poke holes all over with a skewer and slowly pour half the hot rum syrup over the cake. Let it absorb for 15 minutes.
Invert onto a serving plate and pour the remaining syrup over the top, letting it cascade down the sides.
Allow the cake to cool completely. Wrap tightly and let it mature for at least 24 hours—the flavor deepens dramatically. Serve in thick slices.

ingredients: 1/3 cup (80 ml) Gosling's Black Seal rum (or dark rum)
steps: Combine sugar, water, and butter in a small saucepan over medium heat. Stir until the sugar dissolves and the butter melts.
Bring to a boil and cook for 2 minutes without stirring.
Remove from heat and carefully stir in the rum (it may sputter).
Use while hot for maximum absorption into the cake.
Combine all ingredients in a clean jar.
Cover and let steep at least 2–3 days (better after 1–2 weeks).
Strain if you want a smoother sauce; keep refrigerated up to 1 month.

BOL.description: The soup you can eat with your hands. These golden, braided pastries hold a sweet-and-spicy gelatinous stew that turns into rich broth upon baking. Legend says they were created by an exiled Argentine writer in Bolivia, hence 'Salteña'.
ingredients: Flavor: Aji Amarillo (yellow chili paste), Cumin, Oregano, Sugar (for sweetness)
Dough: 4 cups Flour, 1 cup Lard/Butter, Achiote (for color), Sugar, Warm water
steps: Make 'Jigote' (Filling): Sauté beef with spices and sugar. Add broth and gelatin. Simmer until thick. Stir in potatoes and peas.
Chill the filling overnight. It must be solid (gelatinized) before wrapping.
Dough: Mix flour, hot lard (with achiote), and sugar water. Knead until smooth. Rest.
Assembly: Roll dough ovals. Place solid filling, egg, and olive in center. Seal with a braided seam (repulgue) on top.
Bake at very high heat (500°F/250°C) for 12-15 mins until golden and dark spots appear.
Eat carefully without spilling the juice!

drink.description: Bolivia’s classic highball: singani with ginger ale and lime—simple and refreshing.
steps: Fill a glass with ice.
Add singani and lime juice.
Top with ginger ale and stir gently.
Serve immediately.

dessert.description: The unmistakable scent of Bolivian carnival: golden spirals of fried dough, crispy at the edges and chewy within, dusted with a blizzard of powdered sugar and drizzled with warm cane syrup that pools in every twist and curl. Shaped by hand into their signature coiled form, tawa-tawas are street food at its most joyful—eaten hot, standing up, with sticky fingers and no regrets.
ingredients: 1/2 tsp ground anise or anise extract
1/2 cup (60 g) powdered sugar, for dusting
steps: Whisk together flour, cornstarch, baking powder, sugar, anise, and salt in a large bowl.
Make a well in the center. Add eggs, melted butter, and warm water. Mix until a soft, pliable dough forms. Knead for 3–4 minutes until smooth.
Cover and rest the dough for 20 minutes.
Divide the dough into small balls (about 2 tablespoons each). Roll each ball into a long rope about 10 inches (25 cm) long, then coil into a spiral shape.
Heat oil to 350°F (175°C) in a deep pot or fryer. Fry the spirals in batches, turning once, until puffed and deep golden on both sides, about 2–3 minutes total.
Drain on paper towels. While still warm, dust generously with powdered sugar.
Drizzle with warm cane syrup and serve immediately.

ingredients: 1 cup (240 ml) unrefined cane sugar or panela, grated
steps: Combine all ingredients in a small saucepan over medium heat.
Stir until the sugar dissolves, then simmer for 8–10 minutes until the syrup thickens enough to coat the back of a spoon.
Remove the cinnamon stick, cloves, and orange peel. Serve warm.

preliminary_steps.item: Aji Amarillo Paste (Best: store-bought; quick homemade substitute)
ingredients: Recommended: store-bought aji amarillo paste, OR
2–3 yellow/orange hot chiles (or habanero in a pinch, not traditional)
1 tbsp white vinegar or lime juice
steps: For authenticity, use store-bought aji amarillo paste.
For a quick substitute: blend chiles with oil, vinegar/lime, salt (and garlic) into a smooth paste.
Refrigerate up to 5 days.

BRA.description: A gastronomic monument to Brazil's history. Once food for the enslaved using leftover cuts, it is now a national celebration. This smoky, inky-black stew of beans and salted pork is traditionally served on Saturdays with orange slices to cut the richness.
ingredients: 1/2 lb Carne Seca (Dried Beef) or Beef Jerky
steps: Soak beans and dried beef overnight (change water for beef to reduce salt).
In a massive pot, boil beans, beef, and ribs with the orange (helps cut the grease) and bay leaves.
Simmer for 1.5 hours.
In a pan, fry bacon and sliced sausage. Add garlic and onion. Sauté until fragrant.
Add a ladle of beans to the pan, mash them into a paste, then stir this mixture back into the main pot (this thickens the broth).
Simmer for another 45 mins until meat falls off the bone and broth is thick.
Serve with white rice, farofa (toasted cassava flour), and shredded collard greens.

Acre.description: A hearty, late-night-to-breakfast classic from Rio Branco markets: fluffy cuscuz de milho topped with well-seasoned carne moída and a runny fried egg. The name (“mess”) stuck because the plate looks chaotic — and the flavor absolutely works.
steps: Make the cuscuz: Mix flocão, water, and salt until evenly hydrated. Rest 10 minutes. Steam in a cuscuz pan for 10–12 minutes until fluffy. Fluff with butter.

Cook the beef: Sauté onion in a little oil until translucent. Add garlic, then ground beef. Brown deeply. Stir in tomato, cumin, paprika, salt, and pepper. Cook until the tomato melts and the mixture is juicy but not watery. Finish with cheiro-verde.
Fry eggs: In a hot pan with oil, fry eggs sunny-side up so the yolks stay runny.
Assemble: Mound cuscuz on plates, top with beef, then one egg per serving. Add hot sauce if you want it properly Acreano.

drink.description: An Amazonian fermented drink traditionally made from cassava/manioc—commonly associated with Indigenous communities in the western Amazon.
ingredients: Optional: pinch of yeast (for a modern, non-traditional assist)
steps: Mix mashed cassava with warm water in a clean jar; add sugar (and yeast if using).
Cover loosely and let ferment at room temperature 24–48 hours (until lightly tangy).
Stir, strain if desired, chill, and serve.

Alagoas.description: From the lagoons and mangroves around Maceió: sururu (small mussels) simmered in coconut milk with dendê and herbs. It’s coastal, Afro-Brazilian, and unapologetically fragrant.
steps: Sauté onion and bell pepper in dendê until softened. Add garlic and cook 30 seconds.
Add tomato and cook until it breaks down.
Add sururu, lime juice, and a splash of water. Cover and steam 3–4 minutes.
Pour in coconut milk, simmer gently 5–7 minutes. Season and finish with cilantro.
Serve immediately with rice (and farinha on the side if you’re doing it right).

drink.dish: Cachaça with Orange Peel (Alagoas-style Aguardente Aromatizada)
drink.description: Alagoas is known for sugarcane spirits; an orange-peel infusion is a common, simple local style.
steps: Add orange peel (and sugar if using) to a clean jar; cover with cachaça.
Infuse 2–5 days, tasting daily, then strain.
Serve 1–2 oz (30–60 ml) neat or over ice.

Amapá.description: Macapá’s signature: shrimp steamed (“no bafo”) with aromatics and often a splash of cachaça. It’s simple, briny, and meant to be eaten with your hands and farofa.
steps: Toss shrimp with salt, lime juice, garlic, and cachaça. Rest 10 minutes.
In a wide pot, make a bed of onion, tomato, and bell pepper.
Add the shrimp on top. Cover tightly and steam over medium heat 8–12 minutes, shaking the pot once or twice, until shrimp are just cooked.
Serve hot with farofa and extra lime.

drink.description: A traditional ginger-based drink with cultural roots in Amapá’s Afro-Brazilian communities; often lightly fermented and served chilled.
ingredients: Optional: 1/8 tsp active dry yeast (for light fermentation)
steps: Simmer water with ginger 5 minutes; cool to lukewarm.
Stir in sugar and lime juice.
Optional: add yeast, cover loosely, and ferment 12–24 hours for light fizz.
Chill and serve over ice.

ingredients: 2 cups farinha de mandioca (toasted cassava flour)
steps: If using bacon, cook until crisp; keep rendered fat in the pan.
Add butter (if needed) and sauté onion until soft.
Add farinha and toast, stirring constantly, until lightly golden and aromatic (3–6 minutes).
Season with salt; finish with herbs if using.

Amazonas.description: A layered celebration dish from Manaus made with ‘bacalhau da Amazônia’ (salted pirarucu), bananas, potatoes, and farofa. Salty, sweet, crunchy, and built for a crowd.
steps: Desalt fish: Soak in cold water 12–24 hours, changing water 3–4 times. Poach gently 10–12 minutes, then flake.
Fry plantain slices until golden; drain.
Make the refogado: Sauté onions in oil until deeply soft. Add garlic, then tomatoes, cook to a thick sauce. Add flaked pirarucu and black pepper; cook 5 minutes. Stir in cheiro-verde.
Assemble in a baking dish: a thin layer of farofa, then potatoes, then fish mixture, then fried plantain. Repeat layers, finishing with farofa.
Bake at 375°F (190°C) for 20–25 minutes until hot and lightly crisped on top.

drink.description: A beloved regional guaraná soda from Amazonas—best served ice-cold.
steps: Fill a glass with ice.
Pour in Guaraná Baré and add lime if you like.
Serve immediately.

ingredients: 2 cups farinha de mandioca (toasted cassava flour)
steps: If using bacon, cook until crisp; keep rendered fat in the pan.
Add butter (if needed) and sauté onion until soft.
Add farinha and toast, stirring constantly, until lightly golden and aromatic (3–6 minutes).
Season with salt; finish with herbs if using.

Bahia.description: Bahia’s Afro-Brazilian icon: fish simmered with coconut milk and dendê, perfumed with coentro. It’s one of those dishes where the aroma hits before you even see the bowl.
ingredients: 2 lbs Firm white fish (grouper/snapper/monkfish), in chunks
Cooked rice, pirão, and farofa (to serve)
steps: Marinate fish with lime, garlic, salt, and pepper for 20 minutes.
In a clay pot or heavy saucepan, layer onion, tomato, pepper, then fish. Repeat layers.
Add coconut milk. Simmer covered 15–20 minutes until fish is just done. Do not stir aggressively (you’ll break the fish).
Stir in dendê and cilantro at the end. Simmer 2 minutes more.
Serve with rice and farofa; make pirão from the broth if you want the full experience.

drink.description: A creamy beach cocktail associated with southern Bahia (Porto Seguro), typically made with vodka, guaraná powder, and warm spices.
steps: Blend everything with a handful of ice until smooth.
Serve immediately in a chilled glass.

ingredients: 2 cups farinha de mandioca (toasted cassava flour)
steps: If using bacon, cook until crisp; keep rendered fat in the pan.
Add butter (if needed) and sauté onion until soft.
Add farinha and toast, stirring constantly, until lightly golden and aromatic (3–6 minutes).
Season with salt; finish with herbs if using.

Ceará.description: A Ceará staple: rice cooked with feijão-de-corda (cowpeas), often with queijo coalho and carne seca. It’s the Northeast in one pot — practical, rich, and communal.
ingredients: 1 cup Cooked feijão-de-corda (cowpeas) with a bit of broth
steps: Desalt carne seca overnight, then simmer until tender and shred.
Sauté bacon (if using) until fat renders. Add onion and cook until soft. Add garlic and cumin.
Add shredded carne seca and fry lightly.
Add rice and stir to coat. Add beans with enough broth/water to cook rice (about 2 cups total liquid).
Simmer covered until rice is tender. Fold in butter and queijo coalho at the end. Finish with herbs.

drink.description: A clarified cashew-apple drink closely associated with Brazil’s Northeast; served chilled and lightly sweet.
ingredients: 8–12 oz (240–355 ml) cajuína (bottled) or clarified cashew-apple juice
steps: Chill well.
Serve straight (over ice if desired).

Distrito Federal.description: A Brasília favorite with roots in the Center-West: chicken and rice cooked together with saffron-like color (açafrão-da-terra) and comfort built into every grain.
steps: Season chicken with salt, pepper, and garlic. Brown in oil until golden; remove.
Sauté onion in the same pot. Add turmeric and tomato; cook until jammy.
Add rice and stir to coat. Return chicken.
Add hot water/stock (about 4 cups). Simmer covered until rice is done and chicken is tender.
Fold in peas if using, rest 5 minutes, finish with herbs.

drink.description: Brazil’s national cocktail—widely enjoyed in Brasília and across the country.
steps: Muddle lime wedges with sugar in a rocks glass.
Fill with ice and add cachaça.
Stir well and serve.

Espírito Santo.description: Espírito Santo’s pride: moqueca without dendê or coconut — lighter, tomato-forward, and traditionally cooked in a panela de barro. It’s the ‘other’ moqueca and it’s not a consolation prize.
steps: Season fish with salt and pepper.
Layer onion, tomato, and pepper in a pot. Add fish and drizzle with olive oil and annatto oil.
Add stock/water, cover, and simmer gently 15–18 minutes until fish is done.
Finish with cilantro and serve with rice and lime.

drink.description: Espírito Santo is a major producer of conilon (robusta) coffee—typically brewed strong and served simply.
steps: Brew coffee using your preferred method (filter, French press, or moka).
Serve hot; sweeten if desired.

Goiás.description: Goiás’ emblematic savory pie stuffed with chicken, sausage, and often pequi. It’s rustic party food that eats like a full meal.
ingredients: Filling: 1/2 lb Linguiça, sliced and browned
steps: Dough: Rub flour and salt with cold butter until sandy. Mix in eggs, then add water just until it comes together. Chill 30 minutes.
Filling: Sauté onion and garlic, add tomato, then chicken, browned linguiça, olives, and corn. Cook until cohesive. Season well; cool completely.
Assemble: Line a deep pie dish with dough, fill, top with dough lid. Seal edges. Brush with egg wash.
Bake at 375°F (190°C) for 45–55 minutes until deeply golden. Rest 15 minutes before slicing.

drink.description: A Goiás/Cerrado specialty liqueur made from pequi’s distinctive aroma—served in small glasses after meals.
ingredients: 2–3 tbsp pequi pulp (or pequi flavoring, if available)
steps: Combine cachaça, pequi pulp, and sugar in a jar; shake well.
Infuse 2–3 days, then strain (or leave a little pulp for aroma).
Serve 1–2 oz (30–60 ml) chilled or on ice.

Maranhão.description: Maranhão’s signature rice made with vinagreira (hibiscus leaves), sesame, and dried shrimp. Tart, savory, and unmistakably São Luís.
ingredients: 2 cups Cooked white rice (or 1 cup uncooked)
steps: Blanch vinagreira leaves 1 minute; drain and chop.
Sauté onion in oil until soft, add garlic.
Add vinagreira and sauté 2–3 minutes. Add dried shrimp if using.
Stir in rice and sesame seeds. Season and heat through until aromatic.

drink.description: A famous pink guaraná-flavored soda strongly associated with Maranhão—sweet, spiced, and best ice-cold.
steps: Chill well.
Serve straight (over ice if you like).

Mato Grosso.description: A Mato Grosso classic: rice cooked with carne seca and aromatics. A one-pot meal from cattle-country practicality.
steps: Desalt carne seca (overnight), then simmer until tender; dice.
Brown carne seca in oil. Add onion until softened, then garlic.
Add rice and stir to coat. Add hot water (about 3 cups) and simmer covered until rice is done.
Rest 5 minutes, fluff, finish with herbs.

drink.description: Cold-brewed mate traditionally sipped through a bombilla; common across the Center-West, especially in hot weather.
steps: Fill gourd/cup with erva-mate on a slant.
Pour in ice-cold water and sip through bombilla (or steep in a glass and strain).
Top up with more cold water as you drink.

Mato Grosso do Sul.description: A Japanese-Brazilian staple that became a state identity dish in Campo Grande: noodle soup with pork broth, omelet strips, and cheiro-verde. MS is one of Brazil’s strongest examples of migration shaping ‘regional’ cuisine.
ingredients: 1 tbsp Mirin (optional) or a pinch of sugar
1/2 lb Pork belly or shoulder, thinly sliced
steps: Broth: Bring broth to a gentle simmer. Season with soy sauce, mirin/sugar, salt, and white pepper to taste.
Cook noodles according to package; rinse briefly to remove excess starch, then reheat quickly in hot water.
Cook pork slices in the simmering broth until just done.
Make a thin omelet, roll and slice into strips.
Assemble: Noodles in bowl, ladle broth and pork, top with omelet strips and herbs.

drink.description: Mato Grosso do Sul is especially associated with tereré—cold mate, often with herbs or citrus.
ingredients: Optional: a few mint leaves or a squeeze of lime
steps: Add erva-mate to a gourd/cup.
Pour in ice-cold water (and mint/lime if using).
