Sip and top up as you go.

Minas Gerais.description: Minas on a plate: beans tossed with farinha, eggs, and pork. Born from the tropeiros (muleteers) who needed durable, caloric food on long routes.
ingredients: 3 cups Cooked pinto beans (drained; reserve a little broth)
steps: Fry bacon until crisp; add linguiça and brown. Remove excess fat if needed.
Sauté onion in the fat, add garlic.
Add beans and warm through. Push to the side and scramble eggs in the same pan.
Add farinha gradually, tossing until everything is coated and lightly toasted. Adjust with a splash of reserved bean broth if too dry.
Season and serve with sautéed couve and orange slices.

drink.description: Minas Gerais is famous for small-batch cachaça; traditionally served neat in small pours.
steps: Serve neat at cool room temperature.
Sip slowly, often with snacks like queijo and torresmo.

Pará.description: Pará’s street-food rite: hot tucupi broth with jambu (the tingly leaf), goma de tapioca, and dried shrimp. If it doesn’t numb your lips a little, it’s the tourist version.
steps: Boil tucupi with garlic and salt for 15–20 minutes.
Blanch jambu until tender; drain.
Cook goma: Mix tapioca starch with water, then heat, stirring until it turns translucent and thick.
Assemble: goma in bowl, add jambu, pour hot tucupi, top with shrimp. Add chili sauce to taste.

drink.description: A Pará signature twist using jambu (the numbing herb of the Amazon) via jambu-infused cachaça.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) cachaça de jambu (or cachaça infused with jambu)
steps: Muddle lime wedges with sugar in a rocks glass.
Fill with ice and add cachaça de jambu.
Stir well and serve.

ingredients: 1–2 cups fresh jambu leaves and tender stems (and/or flowers), rinsed and patted dry
Optional: 1 tsp sugar (rounds edges; not required)
steps: Lightly bruise the jambu (crush gently with your hands or a muddler to help extraction).
Add jambu to a clean jar and pour in the cachaça. Seal.
Infuse in the fridge or a cool, dark place; start tasting after 6–8 hours.
Strain when the aroma and the numbing/tingly effect are noticeable but not harsh (often 12–48 hours).
Bottle and keep chilled. Use within 1–2 weeks for best freshness.
Combine tucupi, peppers, garlic, and salt in a saucepan.
Simmer gently 10–15 minutes.
Cool and bottle; refrigerate up to 2 weeks.

Paraíba.description: A Paraíba comfort dish: rice and beans cooked together with queijo coalho and often carne de sol. It’s creamy, savory, and built for family tables.
ingredients: 1 cup Cooked beans (feijão verde or feijão macassa) with some broth
steps: Desalt and cook carne de sol if needed; sauté until lightly crisp.
Sauté onion and garlic. Add rice and stir to coat.
Add beans plus enough liquid to cook rice (about 2 cups total). Simmer covered until rice is tender.
Fold in butter and queijo coalho at the end. Rest 5 minutes. Finish with herbs.

drink.description: Paraíba has a strong cachaça tradition; simplest is best: serve neat or as a lime-and-sugar caipirinha.
ingredients: Optional: lime + sugar + ice (for a caipirinha)
steps: Serve neat in a small glass, or use it as the spirit for a basic caipirinha.

Paraná.description: A coastal Paraná tradition (Morretes/Antonina): beef slow-cooked for hours in a sealed clay pot until it shreds into a thick stew, served with farinha and banana.
ingredients: Farinha de mandioca and sliced banana (to serve)
steps: Season beef with garlic, cumin, pepper, vinegar, and salt. Rest 30 minutes.
In a heavy pot, layer onions and beef with bay leaves. Add stock just to barely cover.
Seal tightly (foil under lid helps mimic the traditional clay-pot seal). Simmer on very low heat 4–6 hours until falling apart.
Shred beef in the pot and reduce to a thick stew. Serve with farinha and banana.

drink.description: Hot mate tea (chimarrão) is strongly associated with Southern Brazil, including Paraná.
steps: Fill a gourd/cup with erva-mate on a slant.
Add hot water (not boiling) and sip through a bombilla (or steep and strain).
Top up with more hot water as you drink.

Pernambuco.description: The sertão's pride: goat meat slowly braised with onion, tomato, bell pepper, cilantro, and fiery malagueta pepper until falling apart. Bode guisado is the soul food of Pernambuco's dry interior—every vaqueiro (cowboy) eats it with rice and farofa.
ingredients: 2 lbs bone-in goat meat cut into chunks (900 g)
White rice and farofa for serving
steps: Season goat with salt, pepper, cumin. Brown in olive oil on all sides. Remove.
Sauté onion and garlic until golden. Add tomato and bell pepper, cook 5 minutes.
Return goat. Add wine and malagueta pepper. Add 1 cup water.
Cover and simmer on low heat 2-2.5 hours until the goat is fork-tender.
Stir in cilantro. Serve over rice with farofa.

drink.description: Pitú is a classic Pernambuco cachaça brand; used here in the national caipirinha format.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) Pitú cachaça (or any cachaça)
steps: Muddle lime and sugar in a rocks glass.
Fill with ice, add cachaça, stir, and serve.

dessert.description: Pernambuco’s showpiece dessert: ultra-thin cake layers rolled with goiabada into a tight spiral. A colonial adaptation of European rolled cakes, made obsessively thin.

ingredients: 2 lbs ripe guavas (or 4 cups guava pulp)
steps: If using fresh guavas: simmer guavas with water until soft; blend and strain seeds.
Cook guava pulp with sugar and salt over medium-low heat, stirring frequently, until very thick and paste-like (30–60 minutes).
Add citrus if using. Pour into a lined pan and cool to set.
Refrigerate up to 2 weeks.
Make goiabada spread: Melt goiabada with water into a smooth paste; cool.
Beat butter and sugar until pale and fluffy. Add eggs one at a time.
Fold in flour and salt just until smooth.
Bake very thin layers: Spread a paper-thin layer of batter on a parchment-lined sheet. Bake at 350°F (180°C) for 4–6 minutes, just set.
Flip onto a towel, spread a thin layer of goiabada, and roll tightly while warm.
Repeat with more thin cake layers, rolling onto the existing log to build spirals. Chill, slice thin, dust with powdered sugar.

Piauí.description: Piauí’s traditional ‘paçoca’ is not candy: it’s carne de sol pounded with farinha and aromatics into a savory crumble. Portable, salty, and historically practical.
steps: Desalt carne de sol overnight, then simmer until tender. Shred very finely.
Sauté onion and garlic in butter until soft. Add shredded meat and fry until dry and flavorful.
Add farinha and toast, stirring until evenly crumbly. Season with pepper and herbs.
Serve with rice and beans or with banana; it’s also a killer stuffing for tapioca.

drink.description: Piauí is especially associated with cajuína (clarified cashew-apple juice), served chilled.
steps: Chill well.
Serve straight (over ice if desired).

Rio de Janeiro.description: Rio’s Saturday institution: black beans simmered with pork cuts, served with rice, farofa, couve, and orange. A dish that turned leftovers into a ritual.
ingredients: 1 lb Pork ribs or shoulder chunks
steps: Soak beans overnight.
Brown bacon and sausage; remove. Brown pork ribs/shoulder; set aside.
Sauté onion and garlic in the same pot. Add beans, bay leaves, browned meats, and water to cover.
Simmer 2–3 hours until beans are creamy and meats tender. Skim excess fat and adjust seasoning.
Serve with rice, couve, farofa, and orange.

drink.description: Iconic all over Brazil and a staple in Rio’s bars and beaches.
steps: Muddle lime and sugar in a rocks glass.
Fill with ice, add cachaça, stir well, and serve.

ingredients: 2 cups farinha de mandioca (toasted cassava flour)
steps: If using bacon, cook until crisp; keep rendered fat in the pan.
Add butter (if needed) and sauté onion until soft.
Add farinha and toast, stirring constantly, until lightly golden and aromatic (3–6 minutes).
Season with salt; finish with herbs if using.

Rio Grande do Norte.description: A Rio Grande do Norte staple: salted sun-cured beef with buttery cassava (macaxeira/aipim). The technique was a solution to heat and distance — now it’s pure comfort.
steps: Desalt carne de sol by soaking 6–12 hours, changing water. Pat dry.
Sear or grill the meat until browned and cooked through; slice.
Boil macaxeira until very tender; drain. Mash with butter and black pepper (or serve in chunks with butter).
Sauté onion and garlic in butter and spoon over the meat.
Serve meat with macaxeira and lime.

drink.description: A traditional ginger drink found in parts of Brazil, including Rio Grande do Norte; served chilled and sometimes lightly fermented.
steps: Simmer water with ginger 5 minutes; cool to lukewarm.
Stir in sugar and lime juice.
Optional: add yeast, cover loosely, ferment 12–24 hours for light fizz.
Chill and serve over ice.

Rio Grande do Sul.description: Rio Grande do Sul’s culinary identity: slow-roasted beef over wood embers with nothing but coarse salt. Technique and fire do the talking.
ingredients: 1 large Beef short ribs rack (costela), 6–10 lbs
Optional: chimichurri-style molho (parsley, garlic, vinegar, oil)
steps: Salt generously 40–60 minutes before cooking.
Cook over indirect embers (no flames) on a parrilla or churrasqueira for 4–6+ hours, turning occasionally, until deeply browned and tender.
Rest 10–15 minutes. Slice and serve with farofa or pão, and molho if desired.

drink.description: Rio Grande do Sul’s signature: hot mate shared socially, bitter and aromatic.
steps: Fill gourd/cup with erva-mate on a slant.
Add hot water (not boiling) and sip through a bombilla (or steep and strain).
Top up with more hot water as you drink.

ingredients: 2 tbsp dried oregano (or 1/4 cup fresh, chopped)
1/2 tsp red pepper flakes (or to taste)
steps: Mix parsley, garlic, oregano, and chili flakes in a bowl.
Stir in vinegar, then olive oil; season with salt and pepper.
Rest 20–30 minutes before serving (better after a few hours). Refrigerate up to 3–4 days.

ingredients: 2 cups farinha de mandioca (toasted cassava flour)
steps: If using bacon, cook until crisp; keep rendered fat in the pan.
Add butter (if needed) and sauté onion until soft.
Add farinha and toast, stirring constantly, until lightly golden and aromatic (3–6 minutes).
Season with salt; finish with herbs if using.

Rondônia.description: An Amazonian fish stew common in Rondônia: tucunaré (peacock bass) simmered with vegetables, herbs, and a rich broth for arroz and pirão.
steps: Season fish with lime, salt, and pepper.
Layer vegetables and fish in a pot; drizzle with olive oil.
Add stock to just cover, simmer gently 20–25 minutes until fish is done.
Finish with cilantro and serve with rice and pirão.

drink.description: Rondônia is known for robusta coffee cultivation; brewed strong and served simply.
steps: Brew coffee using your preferred method.
Serve hot; sweeten if desired.

Roraima.description: An Indigenous-origin stew in Roraima made with fish, peppers, and tucupi. It’s sharp, hot, and deeply regional — not a softened ‘Brazilian’ version.
ingredients: 2 lbs Fresh fish (firm, cut into chunks)
steps: Boil tucupi with garlic and salt for 15 minutes.
Add onion and peppers; simmer 5 minutes.
Add fish and cook gently 8–10 minutes until just done.
Finish with cheiro-verde. Serve with cassava or rice.

drink.description: A traditional fermented cassava beverage associated with Indigenous communities in northern Brazil; this is a simplified home method.
steps: Mix mashed cassava with warm water in a clean jar; add sugar if using.
Cover loosely and ferment 24–48 hours until lightly tangy.
Stir, strain if desired, chill, and serve.

Santa Catarina.description: A Santa Catarina coast tradition: a ‘sequence’ of shrimp courses — from crispy to creamy — showcasing local fisheries. This is restaurant culture turned regional identity.
steps: Season shrimp with salt, pepper, and lime.
Course 1 (fried): Bread half the shrimp and fry until golden; keep warm.
Course 2 (creamy): Sauté onion and garlic in butter, add tomato sauce, simmer 5 minutes. Add remaining shrimp and cook 2–3 minutes. Stir in cream and heat gently.
Serve the fried shrimp first, then the creamy shrimp over rice (or together, like many places do).

drink.description: A classic winter/Festa Junina drink popular in Southern Brazil: cachaça simmered with ginger and spices.
steps: In a pot, simmer water, sugar, ginger, and spices 10 minutes.
Add cachaça and heat gently 3–5 minutes (do not boil hard).
Strain and serve hot in mugs.

São Paulo.description: São Paulo’s classic plate: beans thickened with farinha, served with pork, couve, egg, banana, and rice. It’s a working-city meal that became tradition.
ingredients: 2 cups Cooked beans (carioca) with some broth
steps: Cook pork: Pan-sear chops/sausages until done; keep warm.
Virado: Warm beans in a pan, then stir in farinha gradually until thick and spoonable. Season.
Couve: Sauté garlic in oil, add couve and stir-fry quickly until just wilted; salt.
Fry eggs. Optionally fry banana slices.
Plate with rice, virado, pork, couve, egg, and banana.

drink.description: A classic São Paulo cocktail: cachaça and sweet vermouth, often with a dash of bitters.
steps: Fill a mixing glass with ice.
Add cachaça, vermouth, and bitters; stir 15–20 seconds.
Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice. Express orange peel if using.

Sergipe.description: Sergipe’s coast in a pot: crab cooked with tomatoes, peppers, and herbs, eaten the traditional way — hands messy, table loud.
steps: Sauté onion, pepper, and garlic in olive oil until fragrant.
Add tomatoes and cook into a rough sauce.
Add crabs, lime juice, a splash of water, cover and simmer 15–20 minutes until crabs are cooked through.
Finish with cilantro and serve with farofa and vinaigrette-style salad.

drink.description: Mangaba fruit is strongly associated with Sergipe; the juice is fragrant, creamy, and served cold.
steps: Blend mangaba pulp with water and sugar until smooth.
Strain if you prefer it thinner.
Serve over ice.

ingredients: 2 cups farinha de mandioca (toasted cassava flour)
steps: If using bacon, cook until crisp; keep rendered fat in the pan.
Add butter (if needed) and sauté onion until soft.
Add farinha and toast, stirring constantly, until lightly golden and aromatic (3–6 minutes).
Season with salt; finish with herbs if using.

Tocantins.description: A Tocantins hallmark: beef shank stewed slowly with aromatics until gelatin-rich and spoon-tender, typically served with rice and farinha. Simple, but when done right it’s luxurious.
steps: Season shanks with salt and pepper. Brown in oil.
Sauté onion and garlic, add tomatoes, cumin, and bay leaves; cook down.
Return shanks, add stock to cover halfway. Simmer covered 2.5–3.5 hours until very tender and broth is gelatinous.
Adjust seasoning, finish with cilantro. Serve with rice and farinha.

drink.description: Buriti (a Cerrado palm fruit) is used for juices in parts of the North/Cerrado; served chilled.
steps: Blend buriti pulp with water and sugar until smooth.
Chill and serve over ice.

drink.description: Brazil’s signature cocktail built on cachaça, muddled lime, and sugar—bright, grassy, and dangerously easy to drink.
ingredients: 2 tsp superfine sugar (or 2 tsp granulated sugar)
steps: In a rocks glass, add lime wedges and sugar.
Muddle gently to release juice and oils without pulverizing the bitter pith.
Fill the glass with crushed ice.
Add cachaça and stir well to dissolve the sugar and chill the drink.
Top with a bit more crushed ice if needed and serve with a short straw.

dessert.description: The chocolate truffle that defines Brazil: born in the 1940s and named after a beloved brigadier, these impossibly rich, fudgy spheres of condensed milk and cocoa powder are rolled in chocolate sprinkles and served in tiny paper cups at every birthday party, wedding, and celebration across the nation. With just four ingredients and pure alchemy, brigadeiro proves that the simplest things can be the most extraordinary.
ingredients: 1 can (14 oz / 395 g) sweetened condensed milk
1 tbsp (15 g) unsalted butter, plus extra for greasing hands
1 cup (150 g) chocolate sprinkles (granulado) for rolling
steps: Combine the condensed milk, cocoa powder, butter, and salt in a medium nonstick saucepan over medium-low heat.
Stir continuously with a silicone spatula, scraping the bottom and sides of the pan, for 10–15 minutes. The mixture will thicken gradually.

The brigadeiro is ready when it pulls away from the sides of the pan as one mass and you can tilt the pan without it sliding—a spoon dragged across the bottom should leave a clean trail that holds for a moment.
Transfer to a buttered plate or shallow bowl. Spread evenly and let cool to room temperature, then refrigerate for at least 1 hour until firm enough to handle.
Grease your palms lightly with butter. Pinch off tablespoon-sized portions and roll into smooth balls between your palms.
Roll each ball in chocolate sprinkles until fully coated. Place in small paper candy cups.
Serve at room temperature. Brigadeiros keep refrigerated for up to 5 days.

ingredients: 2 cups farinha de mandioca (toasted cassava flour)
steps: If using bacon, cook until crisp; keep rendered fat in the pan.
Add butter (if needed) and sauté onion until soft.
Add farinha and toast, stirring constantly, until lightly golden and aromatic (3–6 minutes).
Season with salt; finish with herbs if using.

BRB.description: The 'Land of the Flying Fish' on a plate. This dish pairs a smooth, polenta-like cornmeal and okra mash (Cou-Cou) with the island's abundant flying fish, stewed in a gravy bursting with Bajan seasoning and Scotch Bonnet heat.
ingredients: 4 Flying Fish fillets (or mild white fish like Tilapia/Snapper)
Seasoning: Lime, Thyme, Onion, Garlic, Scotch Bonnet pepper
Sauce: Tomato, Onion, Garlic, Curry powder (optional)
Cou-Cou: 2 cups Cornmeal, 10 Okras (sliced), 4 cups Water, Butter
steps: Season fish with lime and herbs. Let sit.
Make Sauce: Sauté aromatics and tomatoes. Add water and simmer. Poach the fish in this gravy for 10 mins.
Cou-Cou: Boil okras in water until soft. Remove okras but keep liquid.
Whisk cornmeal into the hot okra water gradually (prevent lumps). Stir constantly with a 'cou-cou stick' (wooden spoon).
Add cooked okra and butter. Cook until mixture pulls away from the pot sides.
Serve the smooth cornmeal mound with the fish and gravy in the center.

drink.description: Barbados has one of the Caribbean’s most iconic rum punch styles—lime, sugar, rum, water, bitters, and nutmeg.
ingredients: 2 tsp sugar (or 1/2 oz / 15 ml simple syrup)
1 oz (30 ml) water (or chilled black tea)
steps: Shake rum, lime juice, sugar, and water with ice.
Strain over fresh ice.
Add bitters and grate nutmeg on top.
Note (simple syrup): stir equal parts sugar + hot water until dissolved; cool.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.

dessert.description: Sweet, dense, and deeply fragrant, this is the bread that scents every Barbadian kitchen: freshly grated coconut folded into a spiced batter with plump raisins, bright glacé cherries, and a whisper of almond essence, then baked until the crust turns mahogany and the center stays moist and chewy. Sliced thick and eaten at any hour—with tea, after church, or simply because someone baked one—Bajan coconut bread is comfort in its purest Caribbean form.
ingredients: 2 cups (150 g) finely grated fresh coconut (or dried unsweetened, rehydrated in 1/2 cup coconut milk)
2 tbsp dark brown sugar, for topping
steps: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Grease and line a 9x5-inch (23x13 cm) loaf pan with parchment paper.
Whisk together flour, sugar, baking powder, cinnamon, nutmeg, allspice, and salt in a large bowl.
Add the grated coconut, raisins, and cherries. Toss to coat evenly with the flour mixture.
In a separate bowl, combine the melted butter, coconut milk, beaten eggs, almond essence, and vanilla.
Pour the wet ingredients into the dry and fold together until just combined—the batter will be thick and heavy. Do not overmix.
Scrape the batter into the prepared pan and smooth the top. Sprinkle with dark brown sugar.
Bake for 55–65 minutes, until the top is deep golden-brown and a skewer inserted in the center comes out clean.
Cool in the pan for 15 minutes, then turn out onto a rack. Serve warm or at room temperature, sliced thick.

BRN.description: Brunei’s iconic starch dish made from sago (ambulong). It’s intentionally mild and eaten by twirling the sticky gel onto a bamboo fork (candas) and dipping into punchy ‘cacah’ sauces.
ingredients: Cacah dipping sauce (see Chef's Essentials below)
steps: In a heatproof bowl, whisk sago starch with 1 cup (240 ml) water and salt until smooth.
Bring remaining 2 1/2 cups (590 ml) water to a rolling boil.
While whisking constantly, carefully pour the boiling water into the starch mixture. Keep whisking until it turns glossy and translucent and thickens into a stretchy gel.
Serve immediately with cacah dipping sauce (see preliminary steps).

ingredients: 1 tbsp tamarind pulp (or 1 tbsp tamarind concentrate + 2 tbsp water)
steps: If using shrimp paste, toast it briefly in a dry pan 30–60 seconds to mellow it.
Mix chilies, shallot, garlic, lime juice, tamarind, sugar, and shrimp paste (if using).
Season with salt. Let sit 10 minutes so flavors round out; adjust sweet/sour/salt to taste.

drink.description: ‘Pulled tea’—strong black tea sweetened with condensed milk and repeatedly poured between cups to create a foamy head. Brunei’s kopitiam classic.
ingredients: 2 tbsp loose black tea (or 4 tea bags)
1/2 cup (120 ml) evaporated milk (or whole milk)
Optional: 1–2 tsp sugar (usually not needed with condensed milk)
steps: Steep tea in boiling water 5–6 minutes for a strong brew; strain.
Stir in condensed milk and evaporated milk (and sugar if using).
‘Pull’ the tea: pour it back and forth between two mugs from a height several times until frothy.
Serve hot.

dessert.description: The quintessential Hari Raya cookie of Brunei: crumbly, melt-in-your-mouth shortbread-style morsels made from ground roasted peanuts, ghee, and powdered sugar that dissolve on the tongue in a cloud of nutty sweetness. Pressed into delicate molds and arranged on tiered trays, kuih mor are the first thing offered to guests during festive celebrations—a small bite that carries enormous warmth and tradition.
ingredients: 1 1/2 cups (200 g) roasted peanuts, skins removed
3/4 cup (180 g) ghee, melted and slightly cooled
steps: Grind the roasted peanuts in a food processor until they form a fine, slightly oily powder—be careful not to turn them into peanut butter.
In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, ground peanuts, powdered sugar, and salt.
Pour in the melted ghee and mix with a spatula until a soft, crumbly dough forms that holds together when pressed.
Pinch off small portions (about 1 tablespoon each) and press into cookie molds or shape into small rounds, pressing gently with a fork for decoration.
Place on a parchment-lined baking sheet. Bake at 300°F (150°C) for 18–22 minutes—they should remain pale with just the faintest golden blush on the bottom. They firm as they cool.
Let cool completely on the tray—they are extremely fragile when warm.
Dust with extra powdered sugar and arrange in paper cups or on a serving tray. Store in an airtight container for up to 2 weeks.

BTN.description: Bhutan’s emblematic comfort dish: chilies treated as a vegetable and simmered with cheese into a simple, fiery stew often eaten with red rice.
ingredients: 10–12 fresh green chilies (about 8 oz / 225 g), sliced lengthwise
7 oz (200 g) feta or farmer cheese, crumbled (traditional uses local cheese)
Optional: 1/2 cup (120 ml) milk for a creamier stew
steps: Combine chilies, onion, garlic, butter, and water in a saucepan. Simmer 10–12 minutes until chilies soften.
Add cheese (and milk if using). Simmer gently 5–8 minutes, stirring, until the cheese melts into a creamy sauce.
Taste and salt lightly (cheese may already be salty). Serve hot with rice.

drink.description: A warming Himalayan staple: strong tea blended with butter, milk, and salt for a savory, energizing cup—common in Bhutanese homes and monasteries.
ingredients: 2 tbsp black tea leaves (Assam works well) or 3 tea bags
steps: Boil water, add tea, and simmer 5–7 minutes for a strong brew. Strain.
Add milk and bring back to a simmer.
Blend with butter and salt (use a blender or immersion blender) until emulsified and slightly foamy.
Serve hot.

dessert.description: From the buckwheat-terraced valleys of central Bhutan, these rustic pancakes are as honest as the mountains themselves: nutty buckwheat batter cooked into thin, lightly crisp rounds and served drizzled with wild honey and a pat of fresh butter that melts into golden rivulets. Khur-le is breakfast, snack, and dessert all at once—simple, warming, and deeply tied to Bhutanese highland life.
ingredients: 2 tbsp (30 g) unsalted butter, melted, plus extra for cooking
To serve: 1/4 cup (85 g) honey (wild or raw preferred)
To serve: 3 tbsp (45 g) unsalted butter, softened
steps: Whisk together the buckwheat flour, all-purpose flour, sugar, and salt in a mixing bowl.
Make a well in the center and add the eggs, water (or buttermilk), and melted butter. Whisk from the center outward until a smooth, thin batter forms. Let it rest for 10 minutes.
Heat a nonstick skillet or well-seasoned cast-iron pan over medium heat. Add a small knob of butter and swirl to coat.
Pour a scant 1/4 cup (60 ml) of batter into the pan, tilting to spread it into a thin round about 6 inches (15 cm) across.
Cook until the edges lift and the surface is set with small bubbles, about 1 1/2–2 minutes. Flip and cook the second side for about 1 minute until lightly golden.
Stack the pancakes on a warm plate as you go, covering with a clean towel.
Serve warm, topped with a generous pat of butter and a long drizzle of honey.

BWA.description: Botswana’s national dish: beef (or goat) simmered until falling-apart tender, then pounded/shredded and served with a starchy side.
ingredients: 3 lb beef chuck or brisket, cut into large chunks
2 tsp kosher salt (plus more to taste)
steps: Place beef in a heavy pot. Add onion and bay leaves (if using). Add water to just cover.
Bring to a boil, skim foam, then reduce to a gentle simmer. Cover and cook until the beef is extremely tender, 2 1/2–3 1/2 hours.
Remove beef to a bowl. Reserve about 1 cup of the cooking liquid; discard onion/bay.
Shred and pound the beef with a wooden spoon or pestle until fibrous and fluffy.
Return beef to the pot with a splash of reserved liquid. Season with salt and pepper and cook uncovered 5–10 minutes to concentrate flavor.
Serve hot (commonly with pap/bogobe, rice, or bread).

drink.description: A traditional homemade ginger drink found in Botswana and across Southern Africa—lightly fermented and served well chilled.
ingredients: 1/2 tsp cream of tartar (optional, for tang)
1/8 tsp active dry yeast (optional, for consistent fermentation)
steps: Bring 6 cups of the water to a boil. Stir in sugar and grated ginger. Simmer 5 minutes.
Turn off heat. Add remaining 4 cups water to cool it down, then stir in lemon juice and cream of tartar (if using). Cool to lukewarm.
Pour into a clean jar. Add raisins and yeast (if using). Cover loosely and let ferment at room temperature 12–24 hours.
Strain, bottle, and refrigerate. Serve very cold over ice.

dessert.description: Botswana's beloved fat cakes—the golden, pillowy street food found at every taxi rank, school gate, and market stall across the country. These deep-fried dough balls puff up into crispy-shelled, cloud-soft spheres that beg to be torn open while still hot and dusted with sugar or drizzled with golden syrup. Magwinya are the taste of everyday celebration—affordable, irresistible, and made with love in every Motswana household.
ingredients: 2 tbsp (30 ml) vegetable oil, plus more for deep frying
To serve: granulated or powdered sugar for dusting
To serve: golden syrup for drizzling (optional)
steps: In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, yeast, and salt.
Add the warm water and 2 tablespoons oil. Stir until a soft, sticky dough forms.
Knead in the bowl for 2–3 minutes—the dough should be soft and slightly tacky, not stiff.
Cover with a damp cloth and let rise in a warm spot for 1–1 1/2 hours until doubled in size.
Heat oil to 340°F (170°C) in a deep pot—the oil should be at least 3 inches (7.5 cm) deep.
With oiled hands, pinch off pieces of dough about the size of a golf ball. Gently shape into rounds without overworking.
Carefully lower 3–4 balls at a time into the hot oil. Fry for 2–3 minutes per side, turning once, until deeply golden and puffed.
Drain on paper towels. While still warm, roll in sugar or drizzle generously with golden syrup.
Serve hot—magwinya are best eaten fresh, though they reheat well in a warm oven.

CAF.description: Central African pumpkin-seed meatballs simmered in a savory peanut-tomato sauce.
ingredients: 1 medium onion, divided (half grated, half chopped)
steps: Toast pumpkin seeds in a dry skillet until fragrant, 3–5 minutes. Cool, then grind to a coarse meal.
In a bowl, mix ground beef, egg, ground pumpkin seeds, grated onion, half the garlic, salt, and pepper. Form golf-ball meatballs.
Heat oil in a pot and brown meatballs lightly on all sides. Remove to a plate.
Sauté chopped onion until soft. Add remaining garlic and tomato paste; cook 1 minute.
Whisk in peanut butter and stock to make a smooth sauce. Add paprika and chile (if using).
Return meatballs to the pot. Simmer gently 20–25 minutes until cooked through and the sauce thickens. Taste and adjust salt.
Serve with rice, cassava, or plantains.

drink.description: A sharp, sweet ginger drink common across Central Africa; served cold.
ingredients: 6 oz fresh ginger, peeled and chopped
steps: Blend ginger with 2 cups water until very smooth. Strain through a fine sieve or cheesecloth into a pitcher.
Add remaining 6 cups water, sugar, lime juice, and a pinch of salt. Stir well.
Chill thoroughly and serve over ice.

dessert.description: Golden, crispy deep-fried banana fritters dusted with sugar and cinnamon—the beloved street food dessert of Bangui. Ripe bananas are mashed into a simple batter with flour and a whisper of vanilla, then dropped by spoonfuls into shimmering oil until puffed and bronzed. Served piping hot from roadside vendors, Makala captures the sweet, fragrant soul of Central African street cooking.
steps: In a large bowl, mash the bananas until mostly smooth with a few small lumps remaining.
Add the flour, granulated sugar, egg, vanilla, cinnamon, and salt. Stir until a thick, cohesive batter forms.
Heat 2 inches (5 cm) of vegetable oil in a heavy pot or deep skillet to 350°F (175°C).
Drop rounded tablespoons of batter into the hot oil, working in batches of 5–6 to avoid crowding. Fry 2–3 minutes per side until deep golden brown and cooked through.
Remove with a slotted spoon and drain on paper towels.
Dust generously with powdered sugar and a light sprinkle of cinnamon while still warm. Serve immediately.

CAN.description: A messy, glorious symbol of Quebecois culture born in 1950s rural diners. True poutine demands fresh cheese curds that 'squeak' against your teeth, melting slightly under a deluge of hot, savory brown gravy over crispy fries.
ingredients: 2 cups Fresh Cheese Curds (must be room temp for squeak)
steps: Cut potatoes into 1cm sticks. Soak in cold water for 1 hour.
Make gravy: Melt butter, whisk in flour to make a roux (cook 2 mins). Whisk in beef and chicken stock. Simmer until thickened. Season with pepper.
Deep fry potatoes at 325°F (160°C) for 3-4 mins. Remove and cool.
Increase oil to 375°F (190°C). Fry again until dark golden brown.
Assembly (Crucial): Place hot fries in a bowl. Add cheese curds on top.
Pour boiling hot gravy over the curds to warm them (slightly melt) but keep the squeak.

drink.description: Canada’s signature savory cocktail: vodka with Clamato, hot sauce, and Worcestershire, typically with a celery-salt rim.
steps: Rim a highball glass with celery salt (run a lime wedge around the rim, then dip in celery salt).
Fill the glass with ice and add vodka.
Add Clamato, Worcestershire, and hot sauce; stir.
Garnish with a lime wedge (and celery stalk/pickle if you like).

dessert.description: The iconic no-bake Canadian bar cookie named after the city of Nanaimo, British Columbia. Three luxurious layers—a dense chocolate-coconut-graham crumb base, a silky vanilla custard buttercream middle, and a glossy dark chocolate ganache top—combine into a rich, fudgy confection that has become a symbol of Canadian baking. Found in every bakery and potluck from coast to coast.
steps: Prepare the Chocolate Crumb Base and press firmly into the bottom of an ungreased 9×9-inch (23×23 cm) baking pan. Refrigerate 15 minutes until set.
Prepare the Custard Buttercream Layer and spread evenly over the chilled base. Refrigerate 15 minutes until firm.
Prepare the Chocolate Ganache Topping and pour over the buttercream layer, tilting the pan to cover evenly.
Refrigerate at least 2 hours (or until the chocolate is fully set) before slicing.
Cut into bars with a sharp knife dipped in hot water for clean edges. Store refrigerated.

ingredients: 1/2 cup walnuts or almonds, finely chopped (60 g)
steps: Melt butter, sugar, and cocoa in a double boiler or heatproof bowl set over simmering water, stirring until smooth.
Remove from heat and stir in the beaten egg quickly (the residual heat will cook it). Return to low heat and stir 1–2 minutes until the mixture thickens slightly.
Remove from heat. Stir in graham crumbs, coconut, and chopped nuts until evenly combined.
Press firmly and evenly into the bottom of the pan.

ingredients: 1/2 cup unsalted butter, softened (4 oz / 113 g)
2 tbsp vanilla custard powder (Bird's brand traditional)
steps: Beat softened butter with an electric mixer until light and fluffy, about 2 minutes.
Add heavy cream and custard powder; beat to combine.
Gradually add powdered sugar, beating on low then increasing to medium-high until smooth and spreadable.
Spread evenly over the chilled crumb base.

ingredients: 4 oz semi-sweet or dark chocolate, chopped (113 g)
steps: Melt chocolate and butter together in a double boiler or microwave (in 20-second bursts, stirring between), until smooth and glossy.
Let cool 2–3 minutes (still pourable but not hot), then pour over the buttercream layer.

CHE.description: Alpine survival food turned global luxury. 'Half-and-Half' refers to the blend of Gruyère and Vacherin Fribourgeois cheeses, melted with white wine and garlic into a communal pot of liquid gold.
ingredients: 1 tbsp Cornstarch (dissolved in a splash of Kirsch)
steps: Rub the inside of the caquelon (fondue pot) with the garlic clove.
Add wine and bring to a simmer.
Gradually add the cheese, stirring constantly in a figure-8 motion.
Once melted, stir in the cornstarch/Kirsch mixture to stabilize.
Keep warm over a flame. Dip bread cubes and stir to prevent burning.

drink.description: A classic Central Swiss coffee drink: hot coffee “corrected” with kirsch (or other fruit brandy).
steps: Warm a mug with hot water, then discard the water.
Add kirsch (and sugar if using).
Pour in hot coffee and stir.
Serve immediately.

dessert.description: The legendary nut tart of Switzerland's Engadine valley in the Graubünden mountains—a buttery, crumbly shortcrust pastry shell concealing a heart of caramelized walnuts bound in cream and honey. Every Konditorei in the region proudly displays its version of this centuries-old alpine treasure. Dense, rich, and deeply nutty, Bündner Nusstorte travels well and tastes even better a day after baking.
ingredients: 3/4 cup cold unsalted butter, cubed (6 oz / 170 g)
1 egg yolk mixed with 1 tbsp cream (for egg wash)
steps: Make the pastry: Whisk flour, powdered sugar, and salt. Cut in cold butter with a pastry cutter or your fingertips until the mixture resembles coarse meal. Add the egg and mix until the dough just comes together (add cold water if too dry). Wrap in plastic and refrigerate 30 minutes.
Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Butter a 9-inch (23 cm) tart pan with a removable bottom.

Divide chilled dough roughly two-thirds / one-third. Roll out the larger portion on a floured surface to about 1/8 inch (3 mm) thick and line the tart pan, pressing into the edges and leaving a slight overhang.
Pour the cooled Caramelized Walnut Filling into the pastry shell, spreading evenly.
Roll out the remaining dough and place over the filling. Press edges to seal and trim excess. Prick the top several times with a fork.
Brush the top with egg wash.
Bake 35–40 minutes until the pastry is deep golden brown.
Cool completely in the pan before removing. Slice thin—this tart is very rich.
Spread walnuts on a baking sheet and toast at 350°F (175°C) for 8 minutes until fragrant. Roughly chop and set aside.
In a heavy saucepan, heat sugar over medium heat, stirring gently, until it melts into a golden amber caramel (5–7 minutes). Watch carefully to avoid burning.
Remove from heat. Carefully stir in the cream (it will bubble vigorously), then the honey and butter. Return to low heat and stir until smooth.
Fold in the toasted walnuts and a pinch of salt. Let cool to room temperature before filling the tart shell.

CHL.description: A summer classic fusing Andean corn (choclo) with Spanish influence. This 'corn pie' hides a treasure trove of 'pino' (seasoned beef), chicken, olives, and raisins beneath a sweet, caramelized corn crust, baked in traditional clay pots.
steps: Make the 'Pino': Sauté onions until soft. Add beef, cumin, salt, and paprika. Cook until browned. Stir in raisins and olives.
Blend the corn kernels with milk and basil until smooth. Cook this paste in a pot with butter and sugar until thickened (approx 10 mins).
Assemble: In a clay pot or baking dish, spread the beef mixture (Pino) at the bottom.
Layer the shredded chicken and slices of hard-boiled egg on top.
Cover everything with the thick corn paste. Sprinkle sugar on top for caramelization.
Bake at 400°F (200°C) for 30-40 minutes until the top is golden brown and bubbling.

drink.description: A South American classic (claimed by Peru and Chile): pisco shaken with lime, simple syrup, egg white, and bitters.
steps: Add pisco, lime juice, simple syrup, and egg white to a shaker (no ice) and dry-shake 15 seconds.
Add ice and shake hard 15–20 seconds until very cold and frothy.
Double-strain into a chilled coupe or rocks glass.
Dot the foam with bitters and serve immediately.
Note (simple syrup): stir equal parts sugar + hot water until dissolved; cool.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.

dessert.description: The quintessential Chilean comfort dessert—baked milk custard that evokes warm memories of every Chilean childhood. A silky, egg-rich custard perfumed with vanilla is poured over a caramel-coated dish and baked until the top turns beautifully golden and lightly crackled. When unmolded, the amber caramel pools around the custard like liquid gold. Simpler than flan yet deeply satisfying, Leche Asada is Sunday lunch tradition from Santiago to Patagonia.
ingredients: 1 cup granulated sugar, divided (200 g total: 1/2 cup for caramel, 1/2 cup for custard)
steps: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C).

Make the caramel: Place 1/2 cup (100 g) sugar in a small saucepan over medium heat. Stir gently until it melts into an amber caramel, 5–7 minutes. Immediately pour into a 9-inch (23 cm) baking dish or oven-safe skillet, tilting to coat the bottom evenly. Set aside.
Warm the milk with the lemon zest (if using) in a saucepan over medium heat until steaming but not boiling. Remove from heat and discard the zest.
In a large bowl, whisk the eggs with the remaining 1/2 cup (100 g) sugar and vanilla until well combined but not overly frothy.
Slowly pour the warm milk into the egg mixture, whisking constantly to temper without scrambling.
Strain the custard through a fine-mesh sieve into the caramel-lined dish.
Place the dish in a larger roasting pan and pour hot water into the pan to come halfway up the sides of the custard dish (bain-marie).
Bake 45–55 minutes until the custard is set around the edges but still has a gentle wobble in the center and the top is golden brown.
Remove from the water bath and cool to room temperature, then refrigerate at least 2 hours.
To serve, run a knife around the edge and invert onto a serving plate, letting the caramel sauce flow over the top.

CHN.description: Imperial cuisine. Requires technique to get the skin glass-like and crispy.
steps: Clean duck. Pump air under the skin to separate it from the meat (use a straw or pump).
Blanch the duck in boiling water for 1 minute to tighten skin.
Glaze: Mix melted maltose, soy sauce, and spices. Brush all over duck.
Hang the duck in a cool, breezy place for 24 hours to dry out the skin completely.
Roast vertically at 400°F (200°C) for 30 mins, then lower to 350°F until skin is mahogany red.
Carve the crispy skin first, then the meat.
Serve wrapped in pancakes with scallion, cucumber, and hoisin.

Anhui.description: Named after Li Hongzhang, a prominent statesman of the Qing Dynasty, who reportedly enjoyed this dish during his travels. It is a classic example of Huizhou cuisine, known for its rich broth and diverse combination of meats, seafood, and vegetables. Anhui cuisine, also known as Hui cuisine, is one of the Eight Culinary Traditions of Chinese cuisine. It is known for its use of wild ingredients and its emphasis on simple and precise preparation methods, with braising, stewing, and steaming being frequently used.
ingredients: 1 lb chicken bones or 1 whole chicken (about 2–3 lbs), cut into pieces
1/2 lb pork bones (optional, for richer flavor)
1/4 lb squid, cleaned and sliced into rings
1/4 lb fish fillet (e.g., cod or tilapia), sliced
4 dried shiitake mushrooms, soaked and sliced
1/2 cup wood ear mushrooms, soaked and sliced
1/2 cup firm tofu, cut into 1-inch cubes
1 cup glass noodles (mung bean vermicelli), soaked
steps: Prepare the Broth: In a large stockpot, combine the chicken bones (or whole chicken pieces) and optional pork bones. Add 8 cups of cold water, smashed ginger, 3-inch scallion pieces, Shaoxing wine, and 1 teaspoon of salt. Bring to a boil over high heat, then skim off any foam. Reduce heat to low and simmer, uncovered, for 1.5–2 hours until the broth is fragrant and slightly reduced.
Prepare Ingredients: While the broth simmers, prepare all the hotchpotch ingredients as specified in the ingredient list.

Sauté Meats: Heat 2 tablespoons of vegetable oil in a wok or large skillet over medium-high heat. Add the minced garlic and minced ginger, stir-frying for 30 seconds until aromatic. Add the thinly sliced chicken and pork, stir-frying for 2–3 minutes until just cooked through. Remove and set aside.

Sauté Seafood: In the same wok, add the shrimp, squid, and fish fillet. Stir-fry for 1–2 minutes until the shrimp turn pink and the squid curls slightly. Be careful not to overcook. Remove and set aside with the chicken and pork.

Combine and Simmer: Bring the prepared broth to a gentle boil in the stockpot. Stir in the soy sauce, oyster sauce, sugar, and white pepper. Add the soaked shiitake mushrooms, wood ear mushrooms, bamboo shoots, carrot, and lotus root to the broth. Simmer for 5–7 minutes until the vegetables are tender-crisp.
Add Remaining Ingredients: Add the firm tofu, napa cabbage, and soaked glass noodles to the broth. Cook for another 3–5 minutes until the cabbage is tender and the noodles are cooked through.
Final Assembly: Return the sautéed chicken, pork, shrimp, squid, and fish to the pot. Simmer for 2–3 minutes to meld the flavors, ensuring not to overcook the seafood.

Serve: Drizzle 1 teaspoon of sesame oil over the hotchpotch for a nutty, aromatic finish. Ladle the hotchpotch into a large serving bowl or individual bowls, ensuring each portion has a balance of meats, seafood, vegetables, and noodles. Garnish with chopped scallions. Serve hot, ideally with steamed rice.

drink.description: A flagship baijiu from Anhui’s Bozhou area, typically enjoyed neat in small cups during banquets and toasts.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) Gujinggong baijiu (or another Anhui strong-aroma baijiu)
steps: Serve at cool room temperature (or lightly chilled if you prefer).
Pour 0.5–1 oz into small cups.
Toast and drink in small sips (or ‘ganbei’ in one go, banquet-style).

Beijing.description: A world-renowned dish with a history spanning over 600 years, originating from the Ming Dynasty imperial cuisine. Initially reserved for emperors, it became a symbol of prestige and refinement. Its popularity grew during the Qing Dynasty, and it has since become a cultural icon, even playing a role in diplomacy. The specific breed of duck used is the Pekin Duck, known for its mild, moist flavor. The preparation is meticulous, involving air-drying for hours to achieve a paper-thin, crispy skin. The duck is traditionally roasted in a wood-fired oven and served with thin pancakes, hoisin sauce, and slivered green onions and cucumbers.
ingredients: 3 tbsp Shaoxing rice wine (or dry sherry/another white wine)
½ tsp ground star anise (or 2 whole star anise)
1 large cucumber, thinly sliced or julienned
½ bunch scallions, thinly sliced or julienned
steps: Rinse the duck thoroughly, inside and out, and pat it completely dry with paper towels. Remove any excess fat, especially around the cavity.
Place the duck on a wire rack set in a clean sink.

Bring 3 cups of water to a rolling boil in a large saucepan. Carefully pour half of the boiling water over the duck, ensuring all skin is scalded. Flip the duck and pour the remaining boiling water over the other side. This helps to tighten the skin.
Pat the duck dry again and use a knife tip or skewer to poke small holes all over the skin, being careful not to pierce the meat.
In a small bowl, mix the baking soda and kosher salt. Sprinkle this mixture evenly over all sides of the duck.

In a small saucepan, combine the honey, maple syrup, Shaoxing rice wine, and ¼ cup water. Bring to a simmer over medium-high heat and cook for 8-10 minutes until the mixture thickens slightly into a syrup. Remove from heat and let it cool to room temperature.
In another small saucepan, combine the hoisin sauce, cinnamon, ginger, brown sugar, red wine vinegar, sesame oil, and star anise. Bring to a boil, then remove from heat and let cool.
Liberally brush the duck all over with the cooled honey-maple syrup glaze. Then, brush with the hoisin-spice glaze.

Transfer the duck, still on the wire rack, to a baking pan. Refrigerate uncovered for at least 8 hours, or preferably overnight (up to 24 hours). This crucial step allows the skin to dry out, which is essential for crispiness. If possible, ensure good air circulation around the duck.
Remove the duck from the refrigerator 30 minutes before cooking to bring it closer to room temperature.
Preheat your oven to 375°F (190°C).
Place the duck, breast-side up, on the wire rack in the roasting pan. You can add 1-2 inches of water to the bottom of the roasting pan to catch fat and prevent splattering.

Roast for approximately 80 minutes, or until the skin is dark brown and crispy. The internal temperature in the thickest part of the breast should reach 160°F (71°C). If the skin starts to get too dark, loosely tent the duck with aluminum foil.
Once cooked, remove the duck from the oven and loosely tent it with foil. Let it rest on a cutting board for 20-30 minutes. This allows the juices to redistribute, resulting in more tender meat.
While the duck is resting, warm the Mandarin pancakes (you can wrap them in moist paper towels and microwave for 15 seconds). Slice the cucumber and scallions into thin slivers.
Carve the duck into thin slices, ensuring each piece has some crispy skin. Arrange the duck on a platter with the pancakes, hoisin sauce, cucumber, and scallions.
Diners can assemble their own Peking Duck wraps by spreading hoisin sauce on a pancake, adding duck meat and skin, and topping with cucumber and scallions.

drink.description: Beijing’s classic everyday baijiu, traditionally drunk neat with food and bold toasts.
steps: Serve neat at cool room temperature.
Pour 0.5–1 oz into small cups.
Toast and drink with savory dishes.

ingredients: 2 tbsp neutral oil (for brushing between pancakes)
steps: Mix flour with boiling water, stirring with chopsticks/spoon until shaggy. Add room-temp water as needed to form a soft dough.
Knead 5–8 minutes until smooth. Cover and rest 30 minutes.
Divide into 12–16 pieces. Roll one piece into a small circle, brush lightly with oil, top with a second circle, and roll the pair together thin (about 6 inches).
Cook in a dry skillet over medium heat 30–60 seconds per side until pale golden spots appear (don’t brown heavily).
While warm, peel the two pancakes apart. Keep covered with a towel to stay soft.

Tianjin.description: Jianbing has a history of over 2,000 years, traced back to the Three Kingdoms period in Shandong province. Legend says chancellor Zhuge Liang invented it to feed his soldiers who had lost their woks. The Tianjin style became famous and was first documented in a newspaper in 1933. Jianbing Guozi is a popular breakfast street food. The Tianjin style is famous for its use of mung bean flour for a softer crepe and is typically filled with youtiao (fried dough sticks), whereas the original Shandong version uses crispier crackers. In 2017, the skill of making Tianjin Jianbing Guozi was listed as a municipal intangible cultural heritage.
steps: Prepare the Batter: Combine warm water, mung bean powder, soybean powder, and all-purpose flour in a mixing bowl. Whisk until smooth. The batter should be thick but runny. Let it rest for at least 20 minutes.

Cook the Crepe: Heat a griddle or a non-stick pan over medium heat with a thin layer of oil. Pour about a cup of batter onto the griddle and spread it evenly in a circular motion to form a thin crepe.
Add Egg and Toppings: Crack the eggs directly onto the crepe and spread them evenly. Before the eggs are fully cooked, sprinkle with chopped green onions and sesame seeds.
Assemble the Jianbing: After about 10 seconds, flip the crepe. Brush the cooked surface with your sweet bean paste or hoisin sauce.
Place the crispy crackers or youtiao in the middle.
Fold the two sides of the crepe over the filling, then fold it in half again to create a rectangle.
Serve immediately while hot and crispy.
ingredients: ¼ cup sweet bean paste or hoisin sauce
2 crispy fried crackers or 1 youtiao (fried dough stick)

drink.dish: Meigui Lu Jiu (玫瑰露酒) – Rose-Infused Spirit
drink.description: A fragrant rose-flavored spirit associated with Tianjin (often used both as a drink and in cooking). This home-style infusion mimics the traditional profile.
ingredients: 1 cup (240 ml) baijiu or neutral spirit (vodka works)
steps: Combine spirit, rose petals, and sugar in a clean jar (add orange peel if using).
Seal and steep 2–5 days at room temperature, shaking once daily, until fragrant.
Strain through a fine sieve/coffee filter.
Serve in small glasses, neat or over a single cube of ice.

Sichuan.description: Created in the late 19th century by a woman named Chen Ma Po (Pock-marked Grandma Chen) in Chengdu. It began as a humble dish for laborers but became the definitive example of Sichuan's 'Mala' (numbing and spicy) flavor profile. The soul of this dish is 'Pixian Doubanjiang', a fermented broad bean paste with chilies from Pixian county. Authentic versions must include Sichuan peppercorns for the signature tingling sensation.
ingredients: 1 block Soft or Silken Tofu, cut into 1-inch cubes
1 tbsp Fermented Black Beans (Douchi), rinsed and minced
1 tsp Sichuan Peppercorns, toasted and ground
1 tbsp Cornstarch mixed with 2 tbsp water (slurry)
steps: Blanch tofu cubes in boiling salted water for 2 minutes. Drain carefully.
Fry ground meat in a wok until crispy. Push to the side.
Add doubanjiang to the oil and fry until the oil turns red. Add garlic, ginger, and black beans.
Pour in stock, soy sauce, and sugar. Bring to a boil.
Gently slide in the tofu. Simmer for 3-5 minutes (do not stir vigorously, shake the pan).
Stir in the cornstarch slurry to thicken the sauce.
Finish with chili oil and a generous dusting of ground Sichuan peppercorns and scallions.

drink.description: One of Sichuan’s most famous baijius, traditionally enjoyed neat in small pours at celebrations and formal meals.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) Wuliangye baijiu (or another Sichuan strong-aroma baijiu)
steps: Serve neat at cool room temperature.
Pour 0.5–1 oz into small cups.
Toast and sip (or ‘ganbei’) alongside rich, spicy food.

preliminary_steps.item: Pixian Doubanjiang (Fermented Chili Bean Paste) – sourcing note
ingredients: Authentic option: Pixian doubanjiang (recommended to purchase)
steps: Pixian doubanjiang is a long-fermented chili broad-bean paste; the traditional process takes months.
For authenticity, purchase a reputable Pixian doubanjiang and use as directed in the recipe.
If the recipe calls for cooking it, stir-fry it briefly in oil to ‘bloom’ the flavor before adding liquids.

Guangdong.description: A staple of Cantonese 'Siu Mei' (roasted meats). The name 'Char Siu' literally means 'fork roasted', referring to the traditional method of skewering seasoned pork with long forks and roasting it over an open fire. The signature red ring and glossy sheen come from a glaze of maltose and sometimes red fermented bean curd (Nam Yu). It is often hung in restaurant windows and is considered one of the four 'Kings' of Cantonese roasting.
ingredients: 2 lbs Pork Shoulder or Pork Butt (cut into long strips)
Marinade: 2 tbsp Hoisin Sauce, 2 tbsp Oyster Sauce, 2 tbsp Soy Sauce
1 tbsp Red Fermented Bean Curd (Nam Yu) + sauce
steps: Cut pork into strips about 2 inches thick. Pierce with a fork to help absorption.
Mix all marinade ingredients. Rub over pork and marinate overnight in the fridge.
Preheat oven to 400°F (200°C). Place pork on a rack over a roasting pan filled with a little water.
Roast for 20 minutes. Flip and roast for another 20 minutes.
Brush generously with maltose/honey glaze. Roast for 10 more minutes until charred and glossy.
Rest for 10 minutes before slicing against the grain.

drink.dish: Liang Cha (凉茶) – Cantonese Herbal Tea
drink.description: A traditional Cantonese “cooling” herbal tea, commonly sipped for balance in hot/humid weather.
ingredients: 1 tbsp dried prunella (xia ku cao), optional but traditional
1–2 thin slices dried licorice root (or 1 tsp licorice tea)
Rock sugar or honey, to taste (optional)
steps: Bring water to a simmer. Add herbs and gently simmer 10–15 minutes.
Turn off heat, cover, and steep 10 minutes.
Strain. Sweeten lightly if you want.
Serve warm or chilled over ice.

preliminary_steps.item: Red Fermented Bean Curd (Nam Yu) Sauce – sourcing note
ingredients: Authentic option: red fermented bean curd (nam yu) plus its brine (recommended to purchase)
steps: Red fermented bean curd is a fermented product; for authenticity, purchase it.
Mash 1–2 cubes with 1–2 tbsp of its brine to form a smooth sauce before adding to the dish.

Hunan.dish: Mao Shi Hong Shao Rou (Mao's Red Braised Pork)
Hunan.description: Named after Chairman Mao Zedong, a Hunan native who famously loved this dish. Unlike other braised pork recipes, the Hunan style traditionally uses caramelized sugar rather than soy sauce for its deep red color. Hunan cuisine, or Xiang cuisine, is known for its 'gan la' (dry heat) and use of fresh chilies, garlic, and shallots. This dish balances savory, sweet, and spicy notes with melt-in-your-mouth pork belly.
ingredients: 2 lbs Pork Belly, cut into 1.5-inch cubes
steps: Blanch pork belly cubes in boiling water for 3 minutes. Drain and pat dry.
In a wok, heat oil and melt rock sugar on low heat until it turns amber and bubbly (caramelization).
Immediately add pork and coat in the caramel. Fry until slightly browned.
Add ginger, star anise, cinnamon, and dried chilies. Stir fry for 1 minute.
Add Shaoxing wine and enough hot water to just cover the pork.
Add scallions. Cover and simmer on low heat for 60-90 minutes until pork is fork-tender.
Remove lid, turn up heat, and reduce the sauce until it is thick, sticky, and glossy.

drink.description: A well-known Hunan baijiu, typically served neat for toasts and banquets.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) Jiugui-style baijiu (or another Hunan baijiu)
steps: Serve neat at cool room temperature.
Pour 0.5–1 oz into small cups.
Toast and drink with spicy dishes.

Jiangsu.description: Dating back to the Sui Dynasty, these giant meatballs stewed with napa cabbage leaves resemble a lion's head with a mane. It is a classic Huaiyang dish, known for meticulous cutting and soft textures. The secret to the texture is chopping the meat by hand (not grinding) and mixing in water and fat to ensure the meatballs are fluffy and tender, not dense.
ingredients: 1 tbsp Cornstarch, 1 tbsp Shaoxing Wine, 1 tsp Sugar
steps: Combine pork, water chestnuts, ginger, scallions, egg, cornstarch, wine, and sugar.
Stir vigorously in one direction for 5 minutes until the mixture becomes sticky and paste-like.
Form into 4 large meatballs. Fry in oil until golden brown (to set shape) or steam them.
In a clay pot or heavy pan, line the bottom with cabbage leaves.
Place meatballs on top. Cover with more cabbage.
Pour in chicken stock and soy sauce. Bring to a boil.
Simmer covered on low heat for 2 hours until the meatballs are incredibly soft and the cabbage is melting.

drink.description: A signature spirit from Jiangsu, traditionally served neat in small cups at meals and celebrations.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) Yanghe Daqu baijiu (or another Jiangsu baijiu)
steps: Serve neat at cool room temperature.
Pour 0.5–1 oz into small cups.
Toast and sip with food.

Zhejiang.description: Named after the famous Song Dynasty poet and statesman Su Dongpo. Legend says he improved the traditional pork dish by slow-braising it in yellow wine while distracted by a game of chess. The pork is traditionally cut into 2-inch squares, tied with twine to hold its shape, and cooked with equal parts wine and soy sauce. It should be tender enough to be cut with chopsticks.
ingredients: 2 lbs Pork Belly (skin-on), cut into 2-inch squares
steps: Blanch pork squares in boiling water for 5 minutes. Clean any scum.
Tie each square with cooking twine to keep the layers together.
In a clay pot or heavy Dutch oven, create a bed of whole scallions and ginger slices at the bottom (prevents burning).
Place pork skin-side down on the aromatics.
Add rock sugar, soy sauces, and Shaoxing wine. Add water if needed to just cover.
Bring to a boil, then cover and simmer on very low heat for 2 hours.
Flip pork skin-side up. Simmer for another 30 minutes.
Optional: Steam the pork in a bowl for 30 minutes for extra tenderness and to remove excess grease.

drink.dish: Longjing Tea (龙井茶) – Dragon Well Green Tea
drink.description: Zhejiang’s most iconic green tea. The brewing is simple but precise: cooler water, short steeps, and fragrant leaves.
steps: Warm your cup or small teapot with hot water; discard.
Add tea leaves. Pour in 175°F/80°C water.
Steep 1–2 minutes, then drink; refill and re-steep 2–3 more times, shortening steeps as the leaves open.

Fujian.description: A classic dish from Fuzhou, the capital of Fujian. Despite the name, it doesn't always contain lychees; the pork is cross-hatched and curled during frying to resemble the bumpy skin of a lychee fruit. It is known for its bright red color and sweet-and-sour flavor profile, typical of Min cuisine.
ingredients: 1 tbsp Red Yeast Rice powder (for color)
Sauce: 2 tbsp Ketchup, 1 tbsp Sugar, 1 tbsp White Vinegar, 1 tsp Soy Sauce
steps: Cut pork into cubes. Score the surface of each cube in a cross-hatch pattern (this makes it curl).
Marinate pork with salt, pepper, and red yeast powder.
Coat pork and water chestnuts in cornstarch batter.
Deep fry pork until it curls and is crispy. Fry water chestnuts briefly.
In a wok, sauté garlic and scallions. Add sauce ingredients and thicken with starch slurry.
Toss the fried pork and water chestnuts in the sauce until coated.

drink.description: A celebrated Fujian oolong, often brewed gongfu-style for multiple short, aromatic infusions.
steps: Warm cup/teapot, then add tea leaves.
Pour 195°F/90°C water over leaves and steep 30–60 seconds for the first infusion.
Pour out completely and drink. Re-steep several times, adding 10–15 seconds each round.

Shandong.description: Shandong (Lu) cuisine is the oldest of the Four Great Traditions and influenced imperial cooking. This dish features a whole carp fried into a U-shape. The sauce is a perfect balance of sweet and sour, traditionally made without ketchup.
steps: Score the fish deeply on both sides at intervals, cutting towards the head.
Lift the fish by the tail and shake to open the cuts. Dust completely with cornstarch.
Deep fry the fish. Hold the tail and head to curve the body into a U-shape in the oil until set.
Fry until golden and crispy.
Make the sauce: Sauté aromatics, add vinegar, sugar, soy sauce, and water. Thicken with starch.
Pour the hot sauce over the crispy fish immediately before serving.

drink.description: A Shandong-inspired cocktail: baijiu meets the province's beloved hawthorn fruit (shanzha), mixed with sparkling water and lime. Hawthorn candy and tanghulu are iconic Shandong street snacks.
steps: Fill a tall glass with ice. Pour in the baijiu, hawthorn syrup, and lime juice.
Top with soda water. Stir gently once.
Garnish with a dried hawthorn slice.

Yunnan.description: Yunnan's most famous dish. Legend says a scholar's wife invented it to keep his lunch warm by covering the broth with a layer of chicken oil. It is served as a boiling hot bowl of broth with separate plates of raw ingredients that cook instantly when added.
ingredients: Raw ingredients (sliced paper-thin): Pork loin, Fish fillet, Ham
Vegetables: Bean sprouts, Chives, Pea tips
steps: Simmer chicken for hours to make a rich, golden broth. Do not skim all the fat (it insulates the heat).
Boil noodles separately and place in a bowl.
Slice meats paper-thin (crucial for cooking safety).
To serve: Bring the broth to a rolling boil in a heated stone bowl.
Add the raw meats and eggs first to cook them. Then add vegetables and noodles.
Mix and enjoy immediately.

drink.description: Yunnan’s iconic fermented tea, brewed with near-boiling water for earthy, layered infusions.
ingredients: 2 tsp Pu'er tea (loose or a small chunk of a cake)
steps: Rinse the leaves quickly with hot water (5 seconds) and discard the rinse.
Pour in hot water and steep 20–40 seconds for the first infusion.
Pour out completely and drink. Re-steep multiple times, gradually increasing steep time.

Shaanxi.description: Often called the 'Chinese Hamburger', this street food dates back to the Qin Dynasty. It consists of chopped, stewed pork belly stuffed into a 'mo', a type of flatbread that is crispy on the outside and soft inside. The meat is spiced with over 20 aromatics.
ingredients: Master Stock: Ginger, Scallions, Star Anise, Cinnamon, Cloves, Fennel, Cardamom
Mo Bread: 2 cups Flour, Yeast, Water
steps: Cut pork into chunks. Blanch in boiling water.
Simmer pork in the master stock with spices and soy sauce for 2-3 hours until it falls apart.
Make the dough. Roll into disks and pan-fry without oil until baked through.
Chop the pork finely with a cleaver, mixing in some of the rich stock and chopped green peppers (optional).
Slice the bun open and stuff generously with the meat.

drink.description: A well-known baijiu style associated with Shaanxi, served neat for toasts and banquets.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) Xifengjiu (or another Shaanxi baijiu)
steps: Serve neat at cool room temperature.
Pour 0.5–1 oz into small cups.
Toast and drink with food.

Shanghai.description: The famous soup dumpling. The magic lies in the 'aspic'—a solidified meat broth jelly that is wrapped inside the dumpling. When steamed, the jelly melts into a rich, savory soup encased in the delicate dough skin.
ingredients: Aspic: 1 lb Pork Skin/Trotters, Water, Ginger, Scallions (boiled down and chilled into jelly)
Dough: 2 cups All-purpose flour, Hot water
Black Vinegar and Ginger slivers (for dipping)
steps: Make Aspic: Boil pork skin/trotters for hours. Strain liquid and chill until it turns into a firm jelly. Dice the jelly.
Mix ground pork with ginger, wine, and seasonings. Fold in the diced jelly cubes.
Make dough with hot water (hot water dough is softer). Roll into thin circles.
Place filling in center. Pleat the edges (traditionally 18 pleats) and seal the top.
Steam in a bamboo steamer lined with cabbage or paper for 8-10 minutes.
Eat carefully: Bite a small hole, sip the soup, then eat the dumpling.

drink.description: A 1930s Shanghai cocktail bar classic inspired by the Peace Hotel on the Bund: huangjiu (Shanghai yellow rice wine) shaken with ginger, honey, and a dash of Angostura bitters. Old Shanghai glamour in a glass.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) aged huangjiu (Shaoxing or Shanghai-style yellow wine)
steps: Shake huangjiu, ginger juice, honey syrup, and bitters with ice.
Strain into a chilled coupe glass.
Garnish with candied ginger on a pick.

Chongqing.description: A signature dish of Chongqing cuisine, famous for its numbing heat. It consists of bite-sized pieces of chicken deep-fried until crispy, then stir-fried with a mountain of dried red chilies and Sichuan peppercorns. The experience is often described as 'finding chicken in chili'.
ingredients: 2 cups Dried Red Chilies (cut in half)
steps: Marinate chopped chicken with salt, wine, and soy sauce for 20 mins.
Deep fry chicken in hot oil until golden and crispy (twice-fried is best). Drain.
Leave a little oil in the wok. Fry ginger, garlic, and peppercorns until fragrant.
Add the dried chilies. Fry briefly (don't burn).
Toss in the fried chicken. Stir fry rapidly to coat with spice aroma.
Sprinkle with sugar, sesame seeds, and scallions. Serve immediately.

drink.description: A modern, lighter-style baijiu brand closely associated with Chongqing, commonly enjoyed neat or as a simple mixer.
ingredients: Optional: 4 oz (120 ml) chilled soda water + lemon wedge (highball)
steps: Traditional: serve neat in small cups at cool room temperature and sip or toast.
Highball option: fill a tall glass with ice, add baijiu, top with soda, and squeeze in lemon.

Guangxi.description: The pride of Guilin. These thick, round rice noodles are traditionally eaten 'dry' with a splash of brine/gravy, topped with crispy roasted pork or beef slices, fried peanuts, and sour pickled beans/bamboo shoots.
ingredients: 1 lb Fresh Rice Noodles (thick round type)
Brine/Gravy: Star anise, cinnamon, fennel, licorice, ginger, soy sauce, rock sugar (simmered for hours)
Meat: Crispy Pork Belly or Braised Beef slices
steps: Prepare the brine by simmering spices and soy sauce until concentrated.
Blanch the rice noodles in boiling water for 10-20 seconds. Shake dry.
Place noodles in a bowl. Add a ladle of the brine.
Top generously with meat slices, fried peanuts, pickled beans, and bamboo shoots.
Add chili oil and herbs. Toss well before eating.

drink.description: A classic rice spirit from Guilin in Guangxi, usually enjoyed neat in small pours.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) Guilin Sanhua jiu (rice spirit)
steps: Serve neat at cool room temperature.
Pour 0.5–1 oz into small cups.
Sip slowly; pair with savory snacks.

ingredients: 2 cups long beans, cut into 2–3 inch pieces
steps: Bring vinegar, water, sugar, and salt to a simmer to dissolve; cool slightly.
Pack beans (and garlic/chili if using) into a jar; pour brine over to cover.
Chill at least 24 hours. Keeps 2–3 weeks refrigerated.

Hainan.description: The ancestor of the famous Singaporean Hainanese Chicken Rice. Originating from Wenchang city, this dish uses free-range chickens fed on coconut and banyan seeds. The chicken is poached simply to highlight its natural flavor and served with a ginger-garlic dip.
ingredients: Dip: Minced Ginger, Minced Garlic, Salt, Hot Oil, Lime juice
steps: Rub chicken with salt. Stuff cavity with ginger and scallions.
Poach in sub-boiling water for 40-50 mins (skin should be intact). Plunge into ice water to make skin jelly-like.
Make the dip: Mix minced ginger, garlic, and salt. Pour sizzling hot oil over it.
Chop chicken bone-in.
Serve with 'oily rice' cooked with chicken fat and broth.

drink.description: Hainan is famed for coconuts; fresh coconut water (or lightly sweetened coconut milk drink) is a classic local refreshment.
ingredients: 1 fresh young coconut (or 8–12 oz / 240–355 ml bottled coconut water)
Optional: pinch of salt or squeeze of lime
steps: Chill coconut or coconut water well.
Serve straight, optionally with a pinch of salt or a squeeze of lime.

Xinjiang.description: A hearty, spicy stew that reflects the fusion of cultures in Xinjiang. Chunks of chicken and potatoes are braised in a rich, spicy sauce often flavored with beer. It is always served on a massive communal plate, with wide hand-pulled noodles added at the end.
ingredients: Sauce: 2 tbsp Doubanjiang (Bean Paste), Dried Chilies, Star Anise, Cumin, 1 can Beer
steps: Caramelize sugar in oil until brown. Add chicken and coat in the color.
Add dried chilies, star anise, ginger, and garlic. Stir fry.
Add doubanjiang and beer. Bring to boil.
Add potatoes. Simmer until chicken and potatoes are tender (20 mins).
Add peppers and onions. Cook 5 more mins.
Serve on a huge plate. Mix boiled wide noodles into the sauce.

drink.description: A traditional Uyghur grape wine from Xinjiang, typically enjoyed as a sweet, fragrant local pour.
ingredients: 5 oz (150 ml) Musallas (or another Xinjiang-style sweet grape wine)
steps: Serve at cellar temperature or lightly chilled.
Pour into small wine glasses and sip slowly.

preliminary_steps.item: Pixian Doubanjiang (Fermented Chili Bean Paste) – sourcing note
ingredients: Authentic option: Pixian doubanjiang (recommended to purchase)
steps: Pixian doubanjiang is a long-fermented chili broad-bean paste; the traditional process takes months.
For authenticity, purchase a reputable Pixian doubanjiang and use as directed in the recipe.
If the recipe calls for cooking it, stir-fry it briefly in oil to ‘bloom’ the flavor before adding liquids.

Hubei.description: The quintessential breakfast of Wuhan. Alkaline noodles are cooked, oiled, and then tossed in a rich, thick sauce made of sesame paste (tahini), soy sauce, and chili oil. It is 'dry' because there is no soup, just the creamy, nutty coating.
ingredients: Sauce: 4 tbsp Chinese Sesame Paste, 1 tbsp Soy Sauce, 1 tbsp Dark Soy Sauce, 1 tsp Sugar
steps: Dilute sesame paste with a little sesame oil until smooth and pourable.
Boil noodles until al dente. Drain well.
Toss noodles with a little oil to prevent sticking if not serving immediately.
To serve: Place hot noodles in a bowl.
Pour over the sesame sauce, soy sauces, and garlic water.
Top with pickled radish, beans, and chili oil. Mix thoroughly until noodles are coated in brown paste.

drink.dish: Enshi Yulu Green Tea (恩施玉露)
drink.description: A famed Hubei green tea, known for a clean sweetness; brew with cooler water to avoid bitterness.
steps: Warm cup/teapot; discard water.
Add tea leaves and pour 175°F/80°C water over them.
Steep 1–2 minutes; drink and re-steep 2–3 times.

ingredients: 2 cups long beans, cut into 2–3 inch pieces
steps: Bring vinegar, water, sugar, and salt to a simmer to dissolve; cool slightly.
Pack beans (and garlic/chili if using) into a jar; pour brine over to cover.
Chill at least 24 hours. Keeps 2–3 weeks refrigerated.

ingredients: 1 cup daikon or red radish, finely chopped or julienned
steps: Stir vinegar, water, sugar, and salt until dissolved.
Add radish and chill 30 minutes (better after a few hours). Keeps 1 week.
Mix minced garlic with warm water and a pinch of salt.
Let stand 5–10 minutes before using (mellows the raw bite).

Gansu.description: The most famous noodle soup in China, originating from the Silk Road city of Lanzhou. It is defined by five colors: clear broth, white radish, red chili oil, green cilantro, and yellow noodles. The noodles are hand-pulled to order in seconds.
ingredients: High-gluten Flour (for noodles) or Fresh Wheat Noodles
Spices: Star Anise, Cinnamon, Sichuan Peppercorns, Ginger, Sand Ginger
steps: Soak beef in water to remove blood. Boil with spices for 3-4 hours to make a clear, aromatic broth.
Remove beef, let cool, and slice thin.
Cook radish slices in the beef broth until translucent.
Cook noodles separately (if fresh) or pull dough if skilled.
Assemble: Noodles in bowl, ladle hot broth and radishes, top with beef slices.
Finish with a generous spoon of red chili oil and chopped cilantro.

drink.description: A refreshing Lanzhou cocktail: baijiu mixed with chrysanthemum tea and honey. Gansu's dry climate makes chrysanthemum tea a daily staple.
steps: Chill well.
Pour into a glass (optional) and serve immediately.

Guizhou.description: A signature dish of the Miao people in Kaili. The vibrant red soup base is made from fermented tomatoes and rice water, creating a unique sour and spicy flavor that is distinct from vinegar-based sourness. It is often served as a hot pot.
ingredients: 1 cup Red Sour Soup Base (Fermented Tomato Paste)
Litsea Oil (Mu Jiang Zi) - essential lemon-scented spice
steps: Fry ginger, garlic, and tomatoes in oil until soft.
Add the Red Sour Soup base and fry until fragrant.
Add water or stock. Bring to a boil.
Add the fish (cut into chunks). Simmer until cooked.
Add a few drops of Litsea oil (crucial for authentic aroma).
Serve with a dipping sauce of chili powder, fermented bean curd, and cilantro.

drink.description: Guizhou’s most famous baijiu, traditionally served neat in tiny pours during formal toasts.
steps: Serve neat at cool room temperature.
Pour 0.5 oz at a time into small cups.
Toast and sip; it’s intense—small pours are the point.

Hebei.description: A famous street food from Baoding. The saying goes: 'In Heaven there is dragon meat, on Earth there is donkey meat.' Savory, braised meat is chopped and stuffed into a crispy, flaky, rectangular bun.
ingredients: 1 lb Donkey Meat (or Beef Shank substitute)
Braising Liquid: Soy Sauce, Star Anise, Cinnamon, Cloves, Fennel
Dough: Flour, Water, Oil (for the bun)
steps: Braise the meat in the spiced master stock for hours until it falls apart. Let it cool in the juices.
Make a dough. Roll it out, brush with oil, roll up, and flatten to create layers.
Pan-fry the buns until golden and crispy.
Chop the braised meat finely (mix with a little green pepper if desired).
Slice the hot bun open and stuff it with the cold or warm meat and a spoonful of the braising jus.

drink.description: A distinctive baijiu style associated with Hebei, traditionally served neat in small cups.
steps: Serve neat at cool room temperature.
Pour 0.5–1 oz into small cups.
Toast and sip with hearty food.

Heilongjiang.description: A classic Harbin dish created for Russian tastes in the early 20th century. Sliced pork is coated in potato starch and fried twice until shattering crisp, then tossed in a sweet and sour sauce made with vinegar and sugar (no ketchup).
ingredients: 1 cup Potato Starch (soaked in water for 30 mins, water poured off)
Sauce: 1/2 cup Sugar, 1/2 cup White Vinegar, 1 tsp Salt
steps: Mix the soaked wet starch with a little oil to make a thick batter. Coat pork slices.
Deep fry pork at 350°F until set. Remove.
Increase heat to 400°F. Fry again until golden and extremely crispy.
In a wok, heat the vinegar and sugar until it bubbles and thickens slightly (syrupy).
Toss in the ginger and carrots.
Add the pork. Toss rapidly to coat (5 seconds max). Serve immediately.

drink.description: A Harbin-inspired Moscow Mule riff: vodka (Harbin's Russian heritage), fiery ginger beer, and lime. Russia's influence in Harbin birthed a vodka culture unique in China.
steps: Chill well.
Pour into a glass (optional) and serve immediately.

Henan.description: One of China's top ten noodles. It features wide, hand-stretched noodles in a nourishing, milky-white mutton broth. The soup is rich with the essence of bone marrow and herbs.
steps: Boil mutton bones and meat on high heat for 2-3 hours to create a milky white broth.
Soak kelp and tofu sheets.
Cook the wide noodles in the mutton broth.
Add the kelp, tofu sheets, and vermicelli.
Serve in a large bowl topped with sliced mutton, cilantro, and chili oil.

drink.description: A storied baijiu name associated with Henan; typically served neat for meals and toasts.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) Dukang baijiu (or another Henan baijiu)
steps: Serve neat at cool room temperature.
Pour 0.5–1 oz into small cups.
Toast and drink with food.

Inner Mongolia.description: The ultimate dish of the grasslands. Large chunks of mutton are boiled simply in water to preserve the natural flavor of the meat, served with salt and wild chive sauce. It is traditionally eaten with hands using a knife.
ingredients: Dip: Wild Chive Flower Sauce (or Garlic, Soy Sauce, Vinegar)
steps: Soak the lamb in cold water for 1 hour to remove blood.
Place lamb in a pot with cold water. Bring to a boil.
Skim off the foam meticulously until the broth is clear.
Add ginger, onion, and peppercorns. Do not add salt yet (it toughens the meat).
Simmer on low heat for 1.5 to 2 hours until the meat can be easily pierced with a chopstick.
Add salt in the last 10 minutes.
Serve the meat on a platter with the dipping sauce and a bowl of the broth on the side.

drink.dish: Mongolian Milk Tea (奶茶 / Suutei Tsai style)
drink.description: A salty, comforting milk tea common in Inner Mongolia—more like a meal-drink than a sweet café tea.
ingredients: 2 tbsp black tea leaves (or 2–3 black tea bags)
steps: Bring water to a simmer. Add tea and simmer 3–5 minutes.
Stir in milk and salt; gently simmer 2–3 minutes.
Optional: whisk in butter for a traditional richer cup.
Strain (if using loose tea) and serve hot.

Jiangxi.dish: Steamed Pork with Rice Flour (Fen Zheng Rou)
Jiangxi.description: A rustic dish where pork belly slices are coated in a coarse, spiced rice powder and steamed. The rice absorbs the pork fat, becoming soft and flavorful, while the pork becomes melt-in-the-mouth tender without being greasy.
ingredients: 1/2 cup Sticky Rice + 1/2 cup Regular Rice
Spices: Star Anise, Cinnamon, Sichuan Peppercorns
Marinade: 2 tbsp Soy Sauce, 1 tbsp Fermented Bean Curd juice, 1 tsp Sugar
steps: Toast the rice and dry spices in a dry pan until golden and fragrant. Grind into a coarse powder.
Marinate pork slices with soy sauce, bean curd juice, and sugar for 30 mins.
Coat each pork slice thoroughly in the rice powder.
Place potato cubes at the bottom of a steamer bowl.
Layer the rice-coated pork on top.
Steam for 1.5 to 2 hours until the pork is gelatinous and the rice powder is soft.

drink.description: A representative baijiu from Jiangxi, traditionally enjoyed neat in small toasting pours.
steps: Serve neat at cool room temperature.
Pour 0.5–1 oz into small cups.
Toast and sip alongside food.

Jilin.dish: Chicken Stew with Hazel Mushrooms (Xiao Ji Dun Mo Gu)
Jilin.description: A famous Northeastern (Dongbei) stew. It uses wild hazel mushrooms which have a distinct, intense aroma, simmered with chicken and glass noodles. It is a warming winter staple.
