ingredients: Star Anise, Ginger, Scallions, Dried Chilies
steps: Sauté chicken pieces in oil until browned and fat renders.
Add ginger, scallions, star anise, and chilies. Stir fry until fragrant.
Add soy sauces and sugar. Stir to coat.
Add the soaked mushrooms and water to cover. Bring to a boil.
Simmer for 40 minutes.
Add the glass noodles and cook for another 10 minutes until noodles are soft and have absorbed the broth.

drink.description: Jilin is famed for Changbai Mountain ginseng; a common traditional preparation is ginseng infused in strong spirit, served in small medicinal pours.
ingredients: 1 cup (240 ml) baijiu or neutral spirit (vodka works)
1–2 tbsp dried ginseng slices (or 1 whole small dried root)
steps: Add ginseng (and sugar/honey if using) to a clean jar and cover with spirit.
Seal and steep in a cool dark place for 2–4 weeks, shaking every few days.
Strain if desired (or leave the ginseng in for continued infusion).
Serve 1–2 tbsp (15–30 ml) in small cups after a meal.

Liaoning.dish: Suan Cai Bai Rou (Sour Cabbage with Pork)
Liaoning.description: A Manchu-style hot pot dish. Pickled Chinese cabbage (Suan Cai) is stewed with pork belly slices and blood sausage. The acidity of the cabbage cuts through the rich fat of the pork.
ingredients: 1 lb Pickled Chinese Cabbage (Suan Cai), rinsed and shredded
1 lb Pork Belly (boiled whole, then sliced)
steps: Boil the whole block of pork belly with ginger and anise until cooked through. Let cool, then slice paper-thin.
In a wok or pot, stir fry the shredded sour cabbage to release aroma.
Pour in the pork cooking broth (or stock).
Layer the pork slices and blood sausage on top of the cabbage.
Simmer for 15 minutes.
Add vermicelli and cook until soft.
Serve with a dipping sauce of minced garlic and soy sauce.

drink.description: A historic baijiu brand associated with Shenyang, Liaoning—served neat for toasts and meals.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) Laolongkou-style baijiu (or another Liaoning baijiu)
steps: Serve neat at cool room temperature.
Pour 0.5–1 oz into small cups.
Toast and sip with savory dishes.

ingredients: 1 medium napa cabbage (about 2 lbs), cut into large pieces
2 tbsp kosher salt (about 2% by weight; adjust for cabbage size)
Optional: 2–3 slices ginger or a few Sichuan peppercorns
steps: Toss cabbage with salt and massage 2–3 minutes until it starts releasing liquid.
Pack tightly into a clean jar or crock. Add enough water to submerge if needed (a light brine).
Weight cabbage under the brine (use a fermentation weight or a small bag filled with brine).
Ferment at cool room temperature 3–7 days until pleasantly sour. Skim any surface foam as needed.
Refrigerate when it tastes right. Rinse before cooking if very salty/sour.

Ningxia.description: Ningxia is the 'Home of Goji Berries'. This dish pairs the region's high-quality Tan sheep meat with local wolfberries (goji), creating a dish that is both savory and slightly sweet, believed to be very nourishing.
ingredients: 2 lbs Lamb Chops or Stew Meat
steps: Blanch lamb in boiling water. Drain.
Heat oil and melt rock sugar until amber colored.
Add lamb and coat in the sugar. Add ginger and scallions.
Add soy sauce, wine, and water to cover.
Simmer for 1 hour until tender.
Add the goji berries in the last 10 minutes (cooking them too long destroys nutrients).
Reduce sauce until thick and glossy.

drink.description: Ningxia is China’s most famous modern wine region; this is the signature local pour.
ingredients: 5 oz (150 ml) Ningxia red wine (Cabernet blend is common)
steps: Serve slightly below room temperature (about 60–65°F / 16–18°C).
Pour into a wine glass and let it breathe a few minutes before drinking.

Qinghai.description: A hearty staple of the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau. Small squares of dough are pinched off by hand and thrown into a savory mutton or beef broth loaded with vegetables like tomatoes, squash, and radishes. It is simple, warming, and filling.
steps: Make a stiff dough with flour and water. Let rest.
Stir-fry meat with aromatics. Add vegetables and water to make a rich broth.
Flatten the dough into strips. Pull and snap small squares of dough directly into the boiling broth.
Cook until noodles float. Stir in leafy greens just before serving.

drink.dish: Qingke Baijiu (青稞酒) – Highland Barley Spirit
drink.description: A traditional highland barley liquor of the Tibetan Plateau (common in Qinghai and Tibet), served neat and warming.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) Qingke baijiu (highland barley liquor)
steps: Serve neat at cool room temperature.
Pour small toasting pours (0.5–1 oz).
Sip slowly; it’s strong and aromatic.

Shanxi.description: The 'King of Noodles'. The chef holds a large block of dough and shaves noodles directly into boiling water with a special curved knife. The resulting noodles are thick in the middle and raggedly thin at the edges, creating a unique texture.
ingredients: Water (ratio is crucial for stiff dough)
Pork Meat Sauce: Ground Pork, Sweet Bean Paste, Soy Sauce, Star Anise
steps: Knead a very stiff dough. Rest for 30 mins.
Make the meat sauce: Fry pork, add bean paste and spices. Simmer.
Boil a large pot of water. Hold the dough block and shave strips into the water using a sharp knife.
Boil until floating. Drain.
Top with meat sauce, vinegar, and fresh cucumber.

drink.description: Shanxi’s famous light-aroma baijiu, traditionally served neat for toasts.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) Fenjiu (or another Shanxi light-aroma baijiu)
steps: Serve neat at cool room temperature.
Pour 0.5–1 oz into small cups.
Toast and sip with food.

preliminary_steps.item: Pork Meat Sauce (Sweet Bean Paste Sauce)
ingredients: 2 tbsp sweet bean paste (tianmianjiang) or hoisin
steps: Heat oil; brown pork.
Stir in sweet bean paste, soy sauce, and sugar; fry 1 minute to bloom.
Add water/stock (and star anise if using) and simmer 10–15 minutes until saucy.

Tibet.description: The most iconic dish of the Himalayas. These steamed dumplings are filled with yak meat (or beef/pork substitute) and onions, flavored simply with ginger and Sichuan pepper, served with a fiery chili sepem (sauce).
ingredients: Dip: Dried Red Chilies, Garlic, Tomato
steps: Mix flour and water to make a smooth dough.
Mix filling ingredients. The onion ratio should be high for juiciness.
Roll small circles of dough. Place filling in center.
Pleat the edges to seal (round or crescent shape).
Steam for 10-15 minutes.
Serve hot with chili sauce.

drink.description: A salty, buttery tea traditionally churned until emulsified—built for cold, high-altitude weather.
ingredients: Optional: 1/4 cup (60 ml) milk for a softer profile
steps: Pour hot tea into a blender (or use a thermos and vigorous shaking).
Add butter, salt, and milk (optional). Blend 20–30 seconds until foamy and emulsified.
Taste and adjust salt/butter.
Serve hot.

drink.description: A widely loved Chinese-style tea: fragrant jasmine aroma over a clean green-tea base.
ingredients: 1 tsp jasmine green tea (loose leaf) per 8 oz water
steps: Heat water to about 175°F (a gentle simmer, not a rolling boil).
Add tea to a teapot or infuser.
Pour in hot water and steep 2–3 minutes.
Strain and serve plain (traditional), or re-steep the leaves for additional infusions.

dessert.description: Plump, chewy glutinous rice flour dumplings filled with a luscious, slightly bitter black sesame paste, served bobbing in a fragrant sweet ginger syrup. An essential food of the Lantern Festival (Yuanxiao Jie) and Winter Solstice (Dongzhi), tangyuan symbolize family reunion and togetherness—their round shape representing completeness and harmony. The contrast of the soft, stretchy wrapper against the rich, nutty filling in warm, ginger-scented broth is one of China's most beloved dessert experiences.
ingredients: 2/3 cup warm water (160 ml), added gradually
steps: Prepare the Black Sesame Filling and chill until firm enough to roll, about 30 minutes.
Roll the filling into 12 small balls (about 1 tsp each) and place on a parchment-lined plate. Freeze 15 minutes for easier wrapping.
Make the dough: Place glutinous rice flour in a bowl. Gradually add warm water, stirring with chopsticks, then kneading until a smooth, pliable dough forms (like Play-Doh). Cover with a damp cloth.

Pinch off a walnut-sized piece of dough (about 1 tbsp) and flatten into a 2-inch (5 cm) disc in your palm. Place a frozen sesame ball in the center. Wrap the dough around the filling, pinching to seal, and roll gently between your palms into a smooth ball. Repeat for all 12.
Prepare the Ginger Syrup and keep it at a gentle simmer.
Bring a large pot of water to a rolling boil. Drop in the tangyuan and stir gently to prevent sticking. Cook until they float to the surface, then continue cooking 2–3 more minutes.
Transfer the cooked tangyuan into bowls. Ladle the warm Ginger Syrup over them and serve immediately.

ingredients: 2 tbsp unsalted butter or coconut oil, softened (30 g)
steps: Toast black sesame seeds in a dry skillet over medium-low heat for 3–4 minutes until fragrant and starting to pop. Cool slightly.
Grind toasted seeds in a spice grinder or mortar and pestle until a coarse, oily paste forms.
Mix the ground sesame with sugar and softened butter until a thick, moldable paste comes together.
Refrigerate until firm enough to roll into balls, about 30 minutes.

ingredients: 3 oz fresh ginger, sliced (85 g, about a 3-inch piece)
1/3 cup brown sugar or rock sugar (70 g)
1 small piece dried tangerine peel (optional, traditional)
steps: Combine water, ginger slices, sugar, and tangerine peel (if using) in a saucepan.
Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer 20 minutes until fragrant and slightly reduced.
Taste and add more sugar if desired. Keep warm until serving.

ingredients: 2 tbsp neutral oil (for brushing between pancakes)
steps: Mix flour with boiling water, stirring with chopsticks/spoon until shaggy. Add room-temp water as needed to form a soft dough.
Knead 5–8 minutes until smooth. Cover and rest 30 minutes.
Divide into 12–16 pieces. Roll one piece into a small circle, brush lightly with oil, top with a second circle, and roll the pair together thin (about 6 inches).
Cook in a dry skillet over medium heat 30–60 seconds per side until pale golden spots appear (don’t brown heavily).
While warm, peel the two pancakes apart. Keep covered with a towel to stay soft.

CIV.description: An Ivorian chicken stew cooked ‘à l’étouffée’ (covered) with vegetables and aromatics—traditionally with little to no added liquid.
ingredients: 1 tbsp vegetable oil (optional; traditional versions may omit)
1 tsp kosher salt (plus more to taste)
steps: In a heavy pot with a tight lid, combine chicken, onions, tomatoes, pepper, eggplant (if using), garlic, ginger (if using), chiles, salt, pepper, and thyme.
If using oil, drizzle it over the top. Cover tightly.
Cook over medium-low heat 45–60 minutes, shaking or stirring gently every 10 minutes so it doesn’t stick.
When chicken is tender and vegetables have collapsed into a sauce, uncover and simmer 5–10 minutes to thicken if needed.
Taste and adjust salt. Serve with rice, attiéké, or plantains.

drink.description: Ivory Coast’s popular ginger drink—spicy, citrusy, and served ice-cold.
ingredients: 8 oz fresh ginger, peeled and chopped
steps: Blend ginger with 2 cups water until very smooth. Strain through a fine sieve or cheesecloth into a pitcher.
Add remaining 6 cups water, sugar, citrus juice, a pinch of salt, and mint (if using). Stir well.
Chill thoroughly and serve over ice.

dessert.description: Abidjan's beloved sweet street snack—thick slices of ripe plantain fried until deeply caramelized and golden, then finished with a dusting of sugar, a squeeze of fresh lime, and a pinch of chili for a thrilling sweet-heat contrast. Found on every corner of Côte d'Ivoire's bustling markets and evening food stalls, Alloco is the taste of Ivorian street life: smoky, sweet, tangy, and just a little fiery.
ingredients: 4 very ripe plantains (skins mostly black), peeled
1/4 cup vegetable or palm oil (60 ml)
1/4 tsp cayenne pepper or ground dried chili
steps: Peel the plantains and cut on a diagonal into 1/2-inch (1 cm) thick slices.
Heat the oil in a large skillet or deep frying pan over medium-high heat until shimmering.
Fry the plantain slices in a single layer (work in batches) for 2–3 minutes per side until deeply golden brown and caramelized at the edges.
Remove to a paper-towel-lined plate. While still hot, sprinkle with granulated sugar, a pinch of flaky salt, and cayenne pepper.
Squeeze fresh lime juice over the top. Toss gently to coat.
Serve immediately while warm and crispy.

CMR.description: Cameroon’s famous bitterleaf-and-peanut stew, often made with beef and shrimp and served with plantains, rice, or fufu.
ingredients: 1/2 cup dried shrimp (or 1 lb fresh shrimp, peeled)
1 cup smooth peanut butter (or 1 1/2 cups ground roasted peanuts)
1/4 cup red palm oil (or vegetable oil)
1 tsp kosher salt (plus more to taste)
steps: Wash and squeeze bitterleaf repeatedly in hot water until the bitterness is reduced (see preliminary steps). Drain well.
Simmer beef in stock with half the onion, salt, and pepper until tender, 45–75 minutes.
In a pot, heat palm oil. Sauté remaining onion until soft. Add garlic and ginger; cook 1 minute.
Stir in peanut butter and a splash of hot stock to loosen, making a smooth sauce.
Add cooked beef with its broth, then add bitterleaf and shrimp. Simmer 15–20 minutes until thick and glossy.
Taste and adjust salt. Serve hot.

drink.description: A Cameroonian hibiscus drink commonly infused with ginger and served chilled.
steps: Bring water to a boil. Add hibiscus and ginger, reduce to a simmer, and cook 5 minutes.
Turn off heat, cover, and steep 20 minutes.
Strain, sweeten while warm, and cool. Stir in lime juice if desired.
Chill thoroughly and serve over ice.

dessert.description: Light, airy, golden-puffed fried dough—the heartbeat of Cameroonian mornings and evenings alike. Every neighborhood in Douala and Yaoundé has its beignet vendor, serving these pillowy spheres hot from the oil, dusted with a cloud of powdered sugar, and often accompanied by chocolate sauce or fruit jam for dipping. Cameroonian beignets are simpler and more rustic than their French cousins, relying on a yeast-risen batter that yields an impossibly tender, slightly chewy interior beneath a crisp golden shell.
ingredients: Chocolate sauce or fruit jam, for dipping (optional)
steps: Dissolve yeast in warm water with 1 tsp of the sugar. Let stand 5–10 minutes until foamy.
In a large bowl, whisk together flour, remaining sugar, nutmeg, and salt.
Add the yeast mixture, warm milk, egg, melted butter, and vanilla. Stir until a thick, sticky batter forms (slightly looser than bread dough).
Cover the bowl with plastic wrap or a damp towel and let rise in a warm spot for 1 1/2–2 hours until doubled in volume and bubbly.
Heat 3 inches (7–8 cm) of vegetable oil in a heavy pot to 350°F (175°C).

Using two oiled spoons or wet hands, scoop golf-ball-sized portions of batter and gently drop into the hot oil. Fry in batches of 4–5, turning occasionally, until puffed and deep golden brown on all sides, 3–4 minutes total.
Remove with a slotted spoon and drain on paper towels.
Dust generously with powdered sugar while still warm. Serve with chocolate sauce or jam for dipping.
Rinse bitterleaf, then soak in hot water for 5 minutes.
Squeeze and rinse repeatedly until the bitterness is reduced to your preference.
Drain very well before adding to the stew.

COD.description: The national dish of the Democratic Republic of Congo. Chicken is braised in moambe—a rich sauce made from the pulp of the African oil palm (or, at home, red palm oil and peanut butter)—with tomatoes, ginger, and pepper. Often finished with spinach or cassava leaves and served with rice, fufu, plantain, or sweet potato.
ingredients: 4 lbs chicken thighs (bone-in, skin-on or skinless)
1/2 cup smooth peanut butter (optional; traditional in some regions—omit for palm-only moambe and use 6 tbsp red palm oil total)
2 cups fresh spinach, roughly chopped (optional but traditional)
Cooked white rice, fried plantains, or fufu (to serve)
steps: Heat the palm oil in a large Dutch oven over high heat until nearly smoking. Brown the chicken in batches, 3–4 minutes per side; transfer to a plate.
Reduce heat to medium-low. Sauté the onion until golden brown, 5–7 minutes. Add the garlic and stir until fragrant, about 30 seconds.

Add the tomato paste and stir constantly until it darkens slightly, about 3 minutes. Add the diced tomato, ginger, red pepper flakes, water, and salt to taste. Return the chicken and any juices to the pot. Bring to a boil over high heat, then reduce to low, cover, and simmer 20 minutes.

If using peanut butter: ladle 1–2 cups of the sauce into a bowl, whisk in the peanut butter until smooth, then pour back into the pot. If using spinach, stir it in now. Simmer uncovered 5–10 minutes until the sauce is thick and glossy.
Taste and adjust salt. Serve hot over rice with fried plantains or fufu on the side.

drink.description: Traditional palm wine in the DRC is known as Malafu (Kikongo) or Nsámbá (Lingala). Fresh sap from the oil palm is collected and ferments naturally within hours into a lightly fizzy, mildly sweet drink; consumed the same day it is at its best.
ingredients: Fresh palm sap (from tapping oil palm or raffia palm), as available
steps: Collect fresh palm sap into a very clean container; keep shaded and cool.
Allow to ferment naturally at room temperature 4–8 hours for a lightly sweet, lightly fizzy palm wine (about 2–4% alcohol).
Chill and drink the same day. Longer fermentation yields a stronger, more sour beverage.

dessert.description: The beloved fried dough balls of Kinshasa's street vendors—golden, slightly sweet, and impossibly puffy. Mikate (also called mikaté or beignets congolais) are a daily ritual across the Democratic Republic of Congo, sold in paper-lined baskets at every market corner and bus stop. A simple yeast-risen batter is dropped by spoonfuls into hot oil, where it puffs into airy, tender spheres with a delicate crunch on the outside. Eaten plain, dusted with sugar, or alongside morning coffee.
steps: Dissolve the yeast and 1 tsp of the sugar in warm water. Let stand 5–10 minutes until foamy.
In a large bowl, combine flour, remaining sugar, and salt. Pour in the yeast mixture and vanilla. Stir vigorously until a thick, sticky batter forms.
Cover with plastic wrap or a damp cloth and let rise in a warm place for 1 1/2–2 hours until doubled and bubbly.
Heat 3 inches (7–8 cm) of vegetable oil in a heavy pot to 350°F (175°C).

Using two oiled spoons or wet hands, drop rounded tablespoon-sized portions of batter into the hot oil. Fry in batches of 5–6, turning occasionally, until puffed and golden brown all over, 3–4 minutes.
Remove with a slotted spoon and drain on paper towels.
Dust with powdered sugar if desired. Serve warm.

COG.description: A Congolese-style chicken stew enriched with moambe (palm butter) and served with rice or a starchy mash.
ingredients: 1 cup moambe (palm butter) or palm nut concentrate
steps: Season chicken with salt and pepper. Brown in oil in a heavy pot. Remove to a plate.
Sauté onion until soft. Add garlic; cook 30 seconds.
Add tomatoes and tomato paste; cook 5 minutes.
Return chicken to the pot. Add stock and chile (if using). Cover and simmer 30 minutes.
Stir in moambe until dissolved. Add okra (if using) and simmer uncovered 10–15 minutes until thick and glossy.
Taste and adjust salt. Serve hot.

drink.description: Fresh palm sap that begins fermenting within hours; best consumed the same day for a lightly fizzy, mildly alcoholic drink.
ingredients: Fresh palm sap (from palm wine tapping), as available
steps: Collect fresh palm sap into a very clean container and keep it shaded and cool.
Let it ferment naturally at room temperature 4–8 hours for a lightly sweet, lightly fizzy palm wine.
Chill and drink the same day. Longer fermentation makes it stronger and more sour.

dessert.description: A uniquely Congolese twist on banana bread—ripe bananas baked with a touch of red palm oil, sugar, and warm cinnamon into a dense, moist, deeply fragrant cake. The palm oil gives the crumb a subtle golden hue and a richness that butter alone cannot achieve, connecting this dessert to the moambe tradition so central to Congolese cooking. Served in thick slices as an afternoon treat or a simple finish to a meal.
ingredients: 4 very ripe bananas, mashed (about 1 1/2 cups / 360 g)
1/3 cup red palm oil or melted coconut oil (80 ml)
steps: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Grease a 9×5-inch (23×13 cm) loaf pan.
In a large bowl, mash the bananas thoroughly. Stir in the palm oil, sugar, eggs, and vanilla until well combined.
In a separate bowl, whisk together flour, baking soda, cinnamon, nutmeg, and salt.
Fold the dry ingredients into the banana mixture until just combined—do not overmix.
Pour the batter into the prepared pan and smooth the top.
Bake 50–60 minutes until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean and the top is deep golden brown.
Cool in the pan 10 minutes, then turn out onto a wire rack to cool completely before slicing.

COL.description: A caloric juggernaut from the Antioquia region, originally designed to fuel coffee growers for an entire day. This 'Paisa Platter' is a challenge to the appetite, featuring nine distinct components including beans, chorizo, chicharron, and avocado.
ingredients: 2 cups Red Beans (cooked with pork hock)
steps: Cook beans until creamy. Stir in a 'hogao' (tomato/onion sauce).
Score pork belly skin, rub with baking soda, boil water off, then fry until skin blisters and cracks.
Cook rice and ground beef separately.
Fry plantains and eggs.
Assembly: On a large platter, arrange the beans and rice. Place the chicharron, beef, chorizo, plantain, arepa, and avocado slice around.
Top the rice with the fried egg.

drink.description: Anise-flavored sugarcane spirit popular in parts of South America, commonly served chilled in small pours.
steps: Serve chilled in a small glass.
Sip or take as a small shot; chase with citrus if desired.

dessert.description: Colombia's beloved rendition of the iconic three-milk cake—a feather-light sponge drenched in a luscious trio of condensed milk, evaporated milk, and heavy cream until it becomes a moist, custardy marvel. Crowned with billowy meringue torched to golden peaks and showered with toasted coconut, this is the centerpiece of Colombian birthday parties, family gatherings, and bakery display cases from Bogotá to Cartagena.
ingredients: 1/3 cup sweetened shredded coconut, toasted (25 g)
steps: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Grease and flour a 9×13-inch (23×33 cm) baking pan.
Whisk flour and baking powder together.
Beat egg yolks with sugar until thick and pale, about 3 minutes. Stir in milk and vanilla.
Fold in the flour mixture until just combined.
In a clean bowl, beat egg whites to stiff peaks. Gently fold into the batter in two additions.
Pour into the prepared pan and bake 25–30 minutes until a toothpick comes out clean and the cake springs back when pressed.
Cool the cake completely in the pan. Pierce the top all over with a fork or skewer.
Prepare the Three-Milk Soak and pour slowly and evenly over the cake. Refrigerate at least 4 hours (overnight is best) so the cake absorbs the liquid fully.
Prepare the Meringue Topping and spread or pipe it over the soaked cake. Toast with a kitchen torch or under a broiler for 30–60 seconds until golden peaks form.
Sprinkle with toasted coconut. Keep refrigerated until serving.

ingredients: 1 (14 oz) can sweetened condensed milk (396 g)
steps: Whisk together condensed milk, evaporated milk, heavy cream, and vanilla until fully combined.
Use immediately, pouring slowly over the cooled, fork-pierced cake.
Combine egg whites, sugar, and cream of tartar in a heatproof bowl set over a pot of simmering water (do not let the bowl touch the water).
Whisk constantly until the sugar dissolves and the mixture reaches 160°F (71°C), about 3–4 minutes.
Remove from heat. Beat with an electric mixer on high speed until stiff, glossy peaks form, about 5–7 minutes. Beat in vanilla.
Spread or pipe immediately over the chilled, soaked cake.

COM.description: A Comorian classic: cassava leaves simmered with aromatics and coconut milk, often cooked with fish.
ingredients: 1 lb cassava leaves (frozen is easiest), thawed
1 lb firm white fish (or tuna), cut into chunks
1 tsp kosher salt (plus more to taste)
steps: Heat oil in a pot. Sauté onion until soft. Add garlic, ginger, and turmeric; cook 1 minute.
Add cassava leaves, coconut milk, and water/stock. Season with salt and add chile (if using). Simmer covered 25 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Add fish and simmer gently 10–12 minutes until fish is just cooked through.
Finish with lime juice. Taste and adjust salt. Serve with rice.

drink.dish: Tchayi ya Dziwa (Comorian Spiced Milk Tea)
drink.description: Comoros-style chai: black tea simmered with warm spices and milk.
ingredients: 2 tbsp black tea (loose) or 4 tea bags
steps: In a saucepan, bring water to a boil with cardamom, cloves, cinnamon, and ginger (if using). Simmer 5 minutes.
Add tea and simmer 2 minutes. Add milk and sugar, then bring back just to a gentle simmer.
Turn off heat and steep 3–5 minutes. Strain and serve hot.

dessert.description: The Comoros' beloved celebration cake—a dense, fragrant coconut rice cake perfumed with cardamom and vanilla. The batter, made from soaked rice blended with thick coconut milk, bakes to a golden crust while remaining moist and sweetly chewy within. No Comorian wedding, grand mariage, or religious holiday is complete without trays of mkatra foutra, its aroma of toasted coconut and warm spice filling the house.
ingredients: 2 cups (400 g) white rice, soaked 4 hours and drained
1/4 cup (60 ml) coconut oil, melted, plus more for the pan
Seeds from 6 green cardamom pods, finely ground
steps: Preheat oven to 350 °F (175 °C). Grease an 8-inch (20 cm) round cake pan with coconut oil and line the bottom with parchment.
Blend the soaked, drained rice with the coconut milk in a blender on high for 2–3 minutes until you have a smooth, pourable batter with no gritty bits.
In a large bowl, whisk the eggs and sugar together vigorously until pale and slightly thickened, about 2 minutes.
Stir the melted coconut oil, vanilla, ground cardamom, salt, and lime zest (if using) into the egg mixture.
Fold the blended rice batter into the egg mixture until fully combined and uniform.
Pour into the prepared pan and smooth the top with a spatula.
Bake 45–55 minutes until the top is a deep golden brown and a skewer inserted in the center comes out clean.
Cool in the pan 15 minutes, then run a knife around the edge and unmold onto a wire rack. Serve warm or at room temperature, cut into wedges.

CPV.description: Cape Verde’s national stew of hominy and beans, slow-cooked with meats and vegetables; versions range from ‘pobre’ to ‘rica’.
ingredients: 2 cups dried hominy (or dried corn kernels)
1 cup dried lima beans (or another white bean)
1 tsp kosher salt (plus more to taste)
1 lb squash or sweet potato, cubed
steps: Drain soaked hominy and beans. Add to a large pot with 8 cups water and bring to a simmer.
In a separate heavy pot, cook bacon until it renders. Add chorizo and brown briefly. Add onion and cook until soft, 5–7 minutes. Add garlic 30 seconds.
Add tomatoes, paprika, bay leaves, salt, and pepper; cook 5 minutes.
Add chicken and brown lightly. Pour in the hominy/bean mixture with enough of its liquid to cover. Simmer partially covered until hominy and beans are tender, 2–3 hours (add water as needed).
Add carrots, cabbage, and squash/sweet potato. Simmer 25–35 minutes until vegetables are tender and the stew is thick.
Rest 10 minutes. Taste and adjust salt. Serve hot.

drink.description: Cape Verde’s classic punch: grogue sweetened with cane syrup/molasses and brightened with citrus.
ingredients: 2 oz grogue (or unaged rhum agricole/cachaça as substitute)
1 oz cane syrup, honey, or light molasses
steps: Add grogue, syrup, and lime juice to a shaker with ice. Shake 10 seconds.
Strain into a small glass over fresh ice. Garnish with lime.

dessert.description: Cape Verde's silky caramel custard—a legacy of Portuguese confectionery baked into island simplicity. Sweetened condensed milk, eggs, and a whisper of lemon zest are blended into a velvety custard, poured over a layer of dark amber caramel, and baked in a water bath until just set. When unmolded, the pudim reveals its glossy caramel crown cascading down the sides, a dessert as elegant as it is comforting.

steps: Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan over medium heat. Swirl the pan gently (do not stir) until the sugar dissolves and turns a deep amber, 5–7 minutes.
Immediately pour into a 9-inch (23 cm) round baking dish or loaf pan, tilting to coat the bottom evenly. Set aside to harden.

ingredients: 1 can (14 oz / 397 g) sweetened condensed milk
steps: Preheat oven to 325 °F (165 °C). Bring a kettle of water to a boil for the water bath.
In a blender, combine the condensed milk, whole milk, eggs, egg yolks, vanilla, lemon zest, and salt. Blend until perfectly smooth, about 30 seconds.
Strain the mixture through a fine-mesh sieve into the caramel-lined dish to remove any zest bits and ensure silkiness.
Place the dish inside a larger roasting pan. Pour boiling water into the roasting pan until it reaches halfway up the sides of the custard dish.
Bake 50–60 minutes until the custard is set around the edges but still has a gentle wobble in the center.
Remove from the water bath and cool to room temperature, then refrigerate at least 4 hours or overnight.
To unmold, run a thin knife around the edge. Place a serving plate on top, invert confidently, and lift away the dish—the caramel will cascade over the pudim. Slice and serve chilled.
Soak hominy and beans separately overnight (8–12 hours).
Drain and rinse before cooking.

CRI.description: Meaning 'Spotted Rooster' for its speckled appearance, this is the heartbeat of Costa Rican breakfast. The secret isn't just the rice and beans, but the alchemy of frying them with Salsa Lizano, a vegetable condiment that defines the Tico flavor profile.
ingredients: 2 cups Cooked White Rice (day old is best)
1 cup Cooked Black Beans (with some broth)
3 tbsp Salsa Lizano (Vegetable sauce, essential for authenticity)
steps: Sauté onion and bell pepper in oil until soft.
Add the beans and a few tablespoons of their black broth.
Add the rice. Stir fry to mix evenly. The rice should take on the dark color of the beans.
Add Salsa Lizano. Cook until liquid evaporates and rice is slightly fried.
Stir in cilantro.
Serve with scrambled eggs, fried plantains, tortillas, and 'natilla' (sour cream).

drink.description: Costa Rica’s sugarcane spirit, commonly used in mixed drinks or served with citrus.
steps: Fill a highball with ice.
Add guaro, lime juice, and syrup.
Top with soda and stir.
Note (simple syrup): stir equal parts sugar + hot water until dissolved; cool.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.

dessert.description: Costa Rica's lighter take on the beloved tres leches—a cloud-soft vanilla sponge baked until golden, then soaked in a luscious trio of whole milk, evaporated milk, and sweetened condensed milk until impossibly moist. Ticos crown theirs with billowy whipped cream dusted with ground cinnamon, the result more ethereal than dense. Found in every soda, bakery, and family kitchen across the country, it is the grand finale to any Tico celebration.

steps: Whisk all four ingredients together in a bowl or measuring pitcher until fully combined.
Refrigerate until the cake is ready to soak.

ingredients: 1 1/2 cups (360 ml) cold heavy whipping cream
steps: Preheat oven to 350 °F (175 °C). Grease a 9x13-inch (23x33 cm) baking dish.
Beat egg yolks with the granulated sugar until thick and pale, about 3 minutes. Stir in milk and vanilla.
Sift flour, baking powder, and salt together. Fold gently into the yolk mixture until just combined.
In a separate bowl, whip egg whites to stiff peaks. Fold one-third into the batter to lighten, then gently fold in the rest.
Pour into the prepared dish and bake 25–30 minutes until golden and a toothpick comes out clean.
Let cool 10 minutes. Poke holes all over the cake with a fork or skewer. Slowly pour the Three-Milk Soak evenly over the surface, letting it absorb gradually.
Cover and refrigerate at least 4 hours or overnight for full absorption.
Before serving, whip the heavy cream with powdered sugar until soft peaks form. Spread over the cake and dust generously with ground cinnamon. Slice and serve cold.
Whisk everything together in a small saucepan.
Simmer 5–8 minutes until slightly reduced and cohesive.
Cool and bottle; refrigerate up to 2 weeks.

CUB.description: Literally translating to 'Old Clothes', this dish's shredded beef resembles tattered rags, but tastes like royalty. Originating from Sephardic Jews in Spain, it became Cuba's national symbol, featuring flank steak braised until it falls apart in a rich tomato-wine sauce.
steps: Boil the flank steak with aromatics until very tender (1.5 - 2 hours). Shred the meat with forks.
In a large pan, sauté onions and peppers until soft.
Add garlic, tomato sauce, wine, cumin, oregano, and the shredded beef.
Simmer for 20-30 minutes allowing flavors to meld.
Stir in olives near the end.
Serve with white rice and black beans (Moros y Cristianos).

drink.description: Cuba’s famous rum-and-mint highball: lime, mint, sugar, rum, and soda—bright and cooling.
steps: In a glass, gently muddle mint with sugar and lime juice.
Fill the glass with ice and add rum.
Top with soda water and stir gently.
Garnish with a mint sprig.
Note (simple syrup): stir equal parts sugar + hot water until dissolved; cool.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.

dessert.description: Cuban coconut flan—a rich, trembling custard made with coconut milk and cream of coconut, baked low and slow in a caramel-lined mold until silky throughout. When unmolded, the flan reveals a glossy, dark amber crown that slowly melts down its pale, coconut-scented sides. This is the dessert that closes every Cuban feast, from Nochebuena to Sunday comida, its tropical richness a testament to the island's love of coconut in all its forms.

steps: Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan over medium heat. Swirl gently (do not stir) until the sugar dissolves and turns a deep amber, 6–8 minutes.
Immediately pour into a 9-inch (23 cm) round cake pan or flan mold, tilting to coat the bottom evenly. Set aside to harden while you make the custard.

ingredients: 1 can (14 oz / 397 g) sweetened condensed milk
1 can (13.5 oz / 400 ml) full-fat coconut milk
4 oz (120 ml) cream of coconut (such as Coco López)
steps: Preheat oven to 325 °F (165 °C). Bring a kettle of water to a boil for the water bath.
In a blender, combine the condensed milk, coconut milk, cream of coconut, eggs, egg yolks, vanilla, and salt. Blend until completely smooth, about 30 seconds.
Strain through a fine-mesh sieve into the caramel-lined pan for a perfectly silky texture.
Place the pan inside a larger roasting pan. Pour boiling water into the roasting pan until it reaches halfway up the sides of the flan pan.
Bake 55–65 minutes until the custard is set around the edges but still has a gentle, jelly-like wobble in the center.
Remove from the water bath, cool to room temperature, then cover and refrigerate at least 6 hours or overnight.

To unmold, run a thin knife around the edge. Set a rimmed serving plate on top, invert with one confident motion, and lift away the pan—the dark caramel will flow over the pale coconut custard. Slice and serve cold.

CUW.description: A testament to Caribbean ingenuity. Like its Aruban cousin, this dish originated when Dutch colonists discarded cheese rinds. Locals filled them with spiced meat and raisins, baking them into a gooey, savory-sweet masterpiece that defines the island's cuisine.
steps: Sauté meat with onions and spices. Add prunes, olives, and piccalilli. Cook until done.
Grease a baking dish. Line the bottom and sides completely with cheese slices.
Pour in the meat filling. Pour beaten eggs over the meat.
Cover the top with remaining cheese slices.
Bake at 350°F (180°C) for 30 mins until bubbly and golden.

drink.description: A simple, locally-relevant highball built around Curaçao’s famous blue liqueur.
steps: Fill a highball glass with ice.
Add blue curaçao and top with tonic.
Stir gently and garnish with lime.

dessert.description: Curaçao's dark, dense, intoxicating rum cake—a Caribbean fruitcake studded with dried fruits macerated for days in dark rum and blue curaçao liqueur. The batter, rich with butter, brown sugar, molasses, and warm spices, bakes low and slow into a mahogany-colored cake of extraordinary depth. Wrapped in rum-soaked cheesecloth and aged, bolo di rum only improves with time, appearing at every Curaçaoan Christmas, carnival, and wedding.

ingredients: 1/4 cup (40 g) candied citrus peel, diced
steps: Combine all dried fruits in a jar. Pour the dark rum and blue curaçao over them.
Seal and let macerate at room temperature at least 3 days (up to 2 weeks for best results), shaking the jar daily.

ingredients: Macerated Dried Fruit with soaking liquid (see preliminary steps)
1 cup (200 g) dark brown sugar, packed
steps: Preheat oven to 300 °F (150 °C). Grease and line a 9-inch (23 cm) round cake pan or bundt pan with parchment.
Cream butter and brown sugar until fluffy, about 4 minutes. Beat in eggs one at a time, then stir in molasses and vanilla.
Whisk flour, baking powder, baking soda, cinnamon, nutmeg, cloves, and salt together. Fold into the butter mixture in two additions until just combined.
Fold in the macerated fruit along with all the soaking liquid. The batter will be thick and heavy.
Scrape into the prepared pan and smooth the top. Bake 1 hour 30 minutes to 1 hour 45 minutes, until a skewer comes out with only a few moist crumbs.
Cool in the pan 20 minutes. Unmold and brush generously all over with the extra dark rum while still warm.
Once fully cooled, wrap tightly in plastic wrap or rum-soaked cheesecloth. Store in an airtight container—the cake improves over 1–2 weeks. Slice thin and serve.

CYM.description: A Christmas tradition from the days when fresh beef was a rare luxury. Local cattle were slaughtered and slow-cooked in their own juices with fiery Scotch Bonnet peppers until the meat shredded effortlessly, creating a spicy, savory holiday feast.
steps: Cut beef into chunks. Season heavily with garlic, pepper, and thyme.
Place in a heavy pot with the whole scotch bonnets (do not burst them).
Cover and simmer on very low heat for 3-4 hours. The beef will release its own juices.
Once tender, remove the lid and turn up heat to fry the beef in its own rendered fat until dark and shredded.
Serve with rice and beans.

drink.description: A creamy cocktail closely tied to Grand Cayman—vodka, coffee liqueur, and Irish cream served over ice or blended.
ingredients: Optional: chocolate syrup for the glass
steps: Optional: drizzle chocolate syrup inside a rocks glass.
Shake vodka, coffee liqueur, and Irish cream with ice.
Strain over fresh ice and serve.
Whisk cocoa, sugar, water, and salt in a saucepan.
Simmer 2–3 minutes, whisking, until smooth and slightly thickened.
Cool; stir in vanilla if using. Refrigerate up to 3 weeks.

dessert.description: The Cayman Islands' dense, beloved cassava celebration cake—made from finely grated fresh cassava bound with coconut, sugar, butter, and warm spices, then baked until firm and deeply caramelized. Called 'heavy' for its satisfyingly dense, almost fudge-like crumb, this cake appears at every Caymanian holiday gathering, church social, and family reunion, its rustic sweetness a taste of the islands' culinary heritage.
ingredients: 2 lbs (900 g) fresh cassava, peeled and finely grated
1 cup (80 g) freshly grated coconut (or 1 cup unsweetened desiccated coconut moistened with 1/4 cup coconut milk)
steps: Preheat oven to 350 °F (175 °C). Grease a 9x13-inch (23x33 cm) baking dish generously with butter.
Squeeze excess liquid from the grated cassava using a clean kitchen towel or cheesecloth.
In a large bowl, combine the squeezed cassava, grated coconut, sugar, melted butter, coconut milk, beaten eggs, vanilla, cinnamon, nutmeg, allspice, and salt. Mix thoroughly until uniform.
Pour into the prepared dish and spread evenly, pressing down firmly with a spatula.
Bake 1 hour to 1 hour 15 minutes, until the top is deep golden brown and the center is firm when pressed.
Cool completely in the dish—the cake firms further as it cools. Cut into squares and serve at room temperature.

CYP.description: Literally 'Stolen Meat'. Historically, bandits stole sheep and cooked them in sealed underground pits to avoid smoke revealing their location. Today, it's leg of lamb slow-roasted in parchment paper until it falls off the bone.
ingredients: 1 Leg of Lamb (bone-in, chopped into portions)
steps: Marinate lamb and potatoes with lemon juice, olive oil, garlic, oregano, salt, and pepper for 2 hours.
Place a portion of lamb and potatoes onto a large sheet of parchment paper.
Wrap it tightly into a parcel (tie with string if needed).
Bake at 320°F (160°C) for 3 to 4 hours.
The meat should be meltingly tender and the potatoes soaked in juices.

drink.description: A Cypriot classic: brandy brightened with lemon and bitters, then topped with soda—light, citrusy, and meant for warm evenings.

steps: Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar dissolves (do not boil hard).
Cool completely, then store covered in the fridge up to 2 weeks.
Fill a highball with ice.
Add brandy, lemon juice, simple syrup, and bitters.
Stir briefly to chill.
Top with soda water and stir once more.
Garnish with a lemon slice and serve.

dessert.description: Cyprus' beloved honey puffs—light, airy balls of yeasted dough fried to a crisp golden shell while remaining pillowy-soft inside, then immediately drenched in warm honey syrup fragrant with cinnamon and lemon. Finished with a shower of crushed walnuts and a final dusting of cinnamon, loukoumades are the quintessential Cypriot sweet, served at festivals, family gatherings, and feast days across the island.

steps: Combine honey, water, lemon peel, and cinnamon stick in a small saucepan.
Bring to a gentle simmer over medium heat and cook 3–4 minutes until slightly thinned and fragrant.
Discard the lemon peel and cinnamon stick. Keep warm until ready to drizzle.

ingredients: Vegetable or sunflower oil for deep frying (about 4 cups / 1 L)
steps: In a bowl, whisk flour, yeast, sugar, and salt. Add warm water and olive oil, stirring until you have a smooth, sticky batter (thicker than pancake batter but not a dough). Cover and let rise in a warm spot 1 hour until doubled and bubbly.
Heat frying oil in a deep pot or Dutch oven to 350 °F (175 °C).

Dip two teaspoons in water. Scoop a small ball of batter with one spoon and use the other to push it into the hot oil. Fry 6–8 puffs at a time, turning occasionally, until evenly deep golden and cooked through, 3–4 minutes per batch.
Drain briefly on paper towels, then transfer to a serving platter.
Drizzle generously with the warm Honey Syrup, sprinkle with crushed walnuts, and dust with ground cinnamon. Serve immediately while warm and crisp.

CZE.description: A masterpiece of Czech Sunday lunches. Beef sirloin is larded with bacon, braised in a vegetable cream sauce, and served with bread dumplings and a tart cranberry garnish.
ingredients: 2 lbs Beef Sirloin (larded with bacon strips)
steps: Sear the beef in a pot. Remove.
Sauté the root vegetables until soft. Add sugar to caramelize slightly.
Return beef, add water/stock, and braise until tender (2 hours). Remove beef.
Blend the vegetables and liquid into a smooth sauce. Stir in cream and boil briefly.
Slice beef. Serve with sauce, dumplings, and a dollop of cranberries on a lemon slice.

drink.description: A Czech staple highball—its name comes from BEcherovka + TONic. Herbal, bitter, and very easy.
steps: Fill a highball glass with ice.
Pour in Becherovka.
Top with tonic water.
Give a gentle stir.
Squeeze in the lime wedge and drop it in.

dessert.description: Prague's famous chimney cake—a hollow cylinder of sweet yeasted dough wound in a spiral around a wooden or metal stick, then slowly grilled over hot coals until crisp and golden on the outside and tender within. Still warm, the cylinder is rolled in a fragrant mixture of sugar, crushed walnuts, and cinnamon that caramelizes against the hot pastry. Originally from Skalica in Slovakia but adopted as a Czech street-food icon, trdelník fills the cobblestone lanes of Prague's old town with its irresistible aroma of toasted dough and caramelized sugar.

steps: Toss sugar, chopped walnuts, and cinnamon together in a shallow dish.
Set aside for rolling the hot pastry.

ingredients: 1/2 cup (120 ml) whole milk, warmed to 110 °F (43 °C)
3 tbsp (45 g) unsalted butter, melted, plus more for brushing
steps: Whisk flour, sugar, yeast, and salt in a large bowl. Add warm milk, egg yolks, melted butter, and vanilla. Stir until a soft dough forms.
Knead on a floured surface 8–10 minutes until smooth and elastic. Place in a lightly oiled bowl, cover, and let rise in a warm spot 1 hour until doubled.
Punch down the dough and divide into 6 equal pieces. Roll each piece into a long rope about 24 inches (60 cm) long and 1/2 inch (1 cm) thick.
Wrap each rope in a spiral around a greased trdelník stick or thick dowel (about 2 inches / 5 cm diameter). Slightly overlap the edges so they seal together.

If grilling: cook over medium-hot coals, rotating slowly, 8–12 minutes until evenly golden brown. If baking: place on a lined sheet and bake at 375 °F (190 °C) for 18–22 minutes, rotating once, until golden and hollow-sounding when tapped.
Brush the hot pastry lightly with melted butter, then immediately roll in the Walnut-Cinnamon Sugar mixture, pressing gently so it adheres.
Slide off the sticks and serve warm. Best eaten the same day.

Chandigarh.description: While popular across North India, this is the quintessential indulgence of Chandigarh. Spicy, tangy chickpeas (Chole) served with puffy, deep-fried bread (Bhature).
ingredients: Bhatura Dough: Flour, Yogurt, Semolina, Baking Powder
steps: Boil chickpeas with tea bags and whole spices.
Cook gravy with onions, tomatoes, and spice powders.
Simmer chickpeas in gravy.
Roll out dough and deep fry into balloon-like breads.
Serve with pickled onions.

drink.description: A Chandigarh/Punjab-region staple: thick yogurt drink, lightly sweet.
ingredients: 1 cup (240 ml) cold water or milk
steps: Blend until frothy.
Serve cold.

DEU.description: A dish of patience and history. This pot roast is marinated for days in vinegar, wine, and spices to tenderize the meat and infuse it with a distinct sourness, balanced by a sweet gravy thickened with gingersnaps.
ingredients: 3 lbs Beef Roast (Rump or Bottom Round)
steps: Marinade: Boil vinegar, wine, water, and spices. Pour over raw beef in a container.
Refrigerate for 3 to 5 days, turning daily.
Remove meat, pat dry. Sear in oil until brown. Remove.
Sauté onions in the same pot. Add the marinade liquid.
Return meat. Cover and braise in oven (325°F/160°C) for 3-4 hours.
Remove meat. Strain gravy.
Stir crumbled gingersnaps into gravy to thicken and sweeten it.
Slice meat and serve with gravy, potato dumplings (Kartoffelklöße), and red cabbage.

drink.description: A classic German shandy: lager mixed with sparkling lemonade—lower ABV, crisp, and ideal in warm weather.
ingredients: 6 oz sparkling lemonade (or lemon soda), well-chilled (180 ml)

preliminary_steps.item: Quick Sparkling Lemonade (If You Don’t Have Lemon Soda)
ingredients: 1 1/2 oz simple syrup (45 ml) (or 3 tbsp sugar, dissolved)
steps: Stir lemon juice and simple syrup in a pitcher.
Top with club soda and stir gently.
Chill and use as the lemonade component.
Chill a tall glass.
Add ice if you want (many serve without).
Pour in the lager.
Top with sparkling lemonade in a 1:1 ratio.
Stir once gently and serve.

dessert.description: Germany's most celebrated cake, born in the mist-shrouded Black Forest region of Baden-Württemberg. Layers of dark chocolate sponge are brushed with Schwarzwälder Kirschwasser, then stacked with kirsch-soaked Morello cherries and billows of lightly sweetened whipped cream. Chocolate shavings cloak the sides and a crown of whole cherries finishes the masterpiece. Every forkful balances bitter chocolate, boozy fruit, and ethereal cream—a cake that has charmed the world since the 1930s.
ingredients: 3 cups (720 ml) heavy whipping cream, well-chilled
3 tbsp (45 ml) Kirschwasser (cherry brandy), for brushing layers
Chocolate shavings or curls for coating, about 4 oz (115 g) semisweet chocolate
12–16 fresh or maraschino cherries with stems, for decoration
1 jar (24 oz / 680 g) Morello cherries in juice (or 2 cups pitted sour cherries + 1/2 cup juice)
steps: Drain the cherries, reserving 1 cup (240 ml) of the juice. Set the cherries aside.
In a saucepan, whisk the reserved juice with sugar and cornstarch. Cook over medium heat, stirring constantly, until thickened and glossy, about 3 minutes.
Remove from heat, stir in the Kirschwasser, and fold in the drained cherries. Let cool completely before using.

ingredients: 1/4 cup (57 g / 1/2 stick) unsalted butter, melted and slightly cooled
steps: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Grease and line three 9-inch (23 cm) round cake pans with parchment.
Beat eggs and sugar with an electric mixer on high speed for 8–10 minutes until very thick, pale, and tripled in volume (ribbon stage).
Sift flour, cocoa, and salt together. Gently fold the dry ingredients into the egg mixture in three additions using a spatula—do not deflate the batter.
Drizzle melted butter around the edge of the bowl and fold in gently until just incorporated.
Divide batter evenly among the three pans. Bake 18–22 minutes until a toothpick comes out clean and the layers spring back when touched.
Cool in pans 10 minutes, then turn out onto wire racks. Peel off parchment and cool completely.
Whip the heavy cream with powdered sugar and vanilla until stiff peaks form. Refrigerate until needed.
Place the first chocolate sponge layer on a cake board or plate. Brush generously with 1 tbsp Kirschwasser.
Spread about 1 cup of whipped cream over the layer, then spoon half the cherry filling evenly over the cream.
Place the second sponge layer on top. Brush with Kirschwasser, spread another cup of cream, and add the remaining cherry filling.
Set the third sponge layer on top and brush with the last of the Kirschwasser.
Frost the top and sides with the remaining whipped cream, reserving about 1 cup for piping rosettes on top.
Gently press chocolate shavings onto the sides of the cake with your hand.
Pipe rosettes around the top edge and place a cherry on each one. Refrigerate at least 2 hours before slicing to set the layers.

DJI.description: Djibouti’s signature spiced rice dish, often made with lamb and warm aromatics similar to the wider Horn of Africa.
ingredients: 1 1/2 lb lamb shoulder, cut into 1-inch pieces
1 tsp kosher salt (plus more to taste)
steps: Heat oil/ghee in a pot. Brown lamb on all sides. Add onion and cook until soft, 6–8 minutes.
Add garlic and tomato paste; cook 1 minute. Stir in spices, salt, and pepper; cook 30 seconds.
Add hot stock/water and bring to a simmer. Cover and cook 35–45 minutes until lamb is tender.
Stir in rice (and raisins if using). Cover and cook on low 15 minutes.
Turn off heat and rest covered 10 minutes, then fluff. Garnish with cilantro if desired.

drink.description: A Horn of Africa-style spiced tea served in Djibouti: black tea simmered with cardamom and cloves, finished with milk and sugar.
ingredients: 2 tbsp black tea (loose) or 4 tea bags
steps: Bring water to a boil with cardamom, cloves, and cinnamon (if using). Simmer 5 minutes.
Add tea and simmer 2 minutes. Add milk and sugar and bring back to a gentle simmer.
Turn off heat, steep 3–5 minutes, then strain and serve hot.

dessert.description: Djibouti's golden semolina halwa, served at every celebration from weddings to Eid al-Fitr feasts after Ramadan prayers. Coarse semolina is slowly toasted in generous ghee until fragrant and nutty, then bound with a cardamom-perfumed sugar syrup and stirred patiently until the mass turns glossy, pulls from the pan, and sets into a dense, aromatic confection. Pressed into molds and studded with almonds, each piece melts on the tongue in waves of buttery sweetness and warm spice—a taste of the Horn of Africa's hospitality.
ingredients: Pinch of saffron threads, steeped in 1 tbsp warm water (optional)
2 tbsp (20 g) blanched almonds or pistachios, for garnish
steps: In a saucepan, combine sugar and water. Bring to a boil, stirring until sugar dissolves completely. Keep the syrup warm over low heat.

In a separate heavy-bottomed pan, melt the ghee over medium-low heat. Add the semolina and stir constantly with a wooden spoon for 10–15 minutes until it turns deep golden and releases a rich, nutty aroma.
Carefully pour the warm sugar syrup into the toasted semolina—it will bubble vigorously. Stir continuously to prevent lumps.

Add the cardamom, cinnamon if using, and saffron water if using. Continue stirring over low heat for 5–8 minutes until the mixture thickens, turns glossy, and pulls away cleanly from the sides of the pan.
Pour into a greased tray or individual molds. Smooth the top and press blanched almonds or pistachios into the surface in a decorative pattern.
Let cool to room temperature until set, then cut into squares or diamond shapes. Serve at room temperature alongside strong Djiboutian coffee.

DMA.description: The soul of the 'Nature Island'. This vibrant green soup is a celebration of the dasheen (taro) plant, blending its tender leaves with coconut milk and land crabs caught during the rainy season for a creamy, earthy, and distinctly Caribbean flavor.
ingredients: 2 Crabs (cleaned and cracked) or Salted Pork
steps: Sauté onion, garlic, and herbs.
Add chopped dasheen leaves and water. Boil until leaves are very soft.
Add coconut milk and crab/meat. Simmer for 20 mins.
Drop in small flour dumplings (spinners). Cook until dumplings float.
Adjust seasoning. The soup should be thick and creamy.

drink.description: Dominica is known for “bush rum”—rum infused with local herbs/spices. This is a simple home infusion.
ingredients: 1/2 vanilla bean or 1 tsp vanilla extract (optional)
steps: Combine everything in a jar and seal.
Infuse 5–14 days, tasting occasionally, then strain.
Serve 1–2 oz (30–60 ml) neat or over ice.

dessert.description: Dominica's beloved coconut fudge—called 'tablet' or 'sugar cake' across the island—is a fixture at Carnival, Independence celebrations, and Saturday market stalls. Freshly grated coconut is cooked low and slow with dark brown sugar, fiery ginger, and bright lime zest until the bubbling mass thickens into a dense, chewy confection with a caramel-like depth. Cut into small squares and left to set, each piece delivers a rush of tropical sweetness tempered by the warmth of ginger and the citrus zing of lime—the Nature Island distilled into candy.
ingredients: 3 cups (225 g) finely grated fresh coconut (or 2 1/2 cups unsweetened desiccated coconut rehydrated in 1/2 cup water)
2 cups (400 g) dark brown sugar (muscovado if available)
steps: In a heavy-bottomed saucepan, combine the brown sugar and water over medium heat. Stir until the sugar dissolves completely and the syrup begins to simmer.
Add the grated coconut, ginger, lime zest, cinnamon, nutmeg, and salt. Stir to combine thoroughly.
Cook over medium-low heat, stirring frequently and scraping the bottom to prevent burning, for 20–25 minutes until the mixture thickens considerably and begins to pull away from the sides of the pan.
Stir in the butter until melted and fully incorporated. The mixture should be very thick and hold its shape briefly when dropped from a spoon.
Pour into a greased 8×8 inch (20×20 cm) pan or onto a sheet of parchment paper. Press firmly into an even layer about 3/4 inch (2 cm) thick.
Score into 1-inch (2.5 cm) squares while still warm. Let cool completely at room temperature until firm, then cut along the score lines.
Store in an airtight container at room temperature for up to 1 week—if it lasts that long.

DNK.description: The undisputed national dish of Denmark. Thick slices of pork belly are fried until crispy and served with boiled potatoes and a rich, creamy parsley sauce.
ingredients: 1 1/2 lb pork belly slices (about 1/2-inch thick) (680 g)
2 lb small waxy potatoes (Yukon Gold) (900 g)
For parsley sauce: 3 tbsp butter (42 g)
For parsley sauce: 3 tbsp all-purpose flour (24 g)
For parsley sauce: 2 cups whole milk (480 ml), warmed
For parsley sauce: 1/2 cup finely chopped flat-leaf parsley
steps: Boil potatoes in salted water until tender, 15–20 minutes; drain and keep warm.
Season pork belly lightly with salt and pepper.
Pan-fry or bake: Cook pork belly until crisp and browned (pan: medium heat 6–8 min per side; oven: 425°F/220°C on a rack 20–30 min, flipping once).
Make parsley sauce: melt butter in a saucepan, whisk in flour 1 minute. Slowly whisk in warm milk until smooth.
Simmer gently 3–5 minutes until thick enough to coat a spoon; season with salt, pepper, and optional nutmeg.
Stir in chopped parsley right before serving.
Serve crisp pork belly with boiled potatoes and lots of parsley sauce.

drink.description: Nordic mulled wine served through winter: warm red wine steeped with spices, citrus, raisins, and almonds—optionally fortified with aquavit.
ingredients: 1/2 cup granulated sugar (100 g) (or to taste)
Zest of 1 orange (plus 2 strips of peel)
Optional: 3/4 cup aquavit or vodka (180 ml)
steps: In a pot, combine water, sugar, orange zest/peel, and spices; warm 5 minutes to dissolve sugar.
Add red wine and heat gently until steaming (do not boil).
Cover and steep 20–30 minutes off heat.
Stir in raisins and almonds.
If using aquavit/vodka, add off heat.
Ladle into mugs, including a spoonful of raisins/almonds in each.

dessert.description: Denmark's most iconic dessert and a tongue-twister that doubles as a pronunciation test for foreigners. This silky red berry pudding—a shimmering compote of red currants, raspberries, and strawberries—is gently thickened with potato starch until it reaches a trembling, jewel-toned consistency somewhere between sauce and jelly. Served cold in a bowl with a generous pour of heavy cream that pools and swirls into the crimson surface, it is summer in Denmark captured in a spoon: tart, sweet, and impossibly elegant in its simplicity.
ingredients: 2 cups (250 g) fresh or frozen red currants
2 cups (250 g) fresh or frozen raspberries
1 cup (150 g) fresh or frozen strawberries, hulled and halved
3/4 cup (150 g) granulated sugar (adjust to taste)
3 tbsp (45 ml) cold water, for the starch slurry
1 tsp vanilla extract or seeds from 1/2 vanilla bean
steps: Combine the red currants, raspberries, and strawberries with sugar and 2 cups water in a saucepan. Bring to a gentle boil over medium heat, stirring occasionally. Simmer 8–10 minutes until the berries have broken down and the juices run deep red.
Strain through a fine-mesh sieve, pressing gently on the solids to extract maximum juice. Return the strained liquid to the pan. For a chunkier texture, stir half the berry pulp back into the liquid.
Bring the berry liquid back to a gentle simmer. Stir in the vanilla and lemon juice if using.
In a small bowl, whisk the potato starch with the 3 tbsp cold water until perfectly smooth. Pour the slurry into the simmering berry liquid while stirring constantly.
Cook, stirring, for 1–2 minutes until the pudding thickens to a silky, pourable consistency—it will firm up further as it cools. Remove from heat immediately.
Pour into individual serving bowls. To prevent a skin from forming, sprinkle a thin layer of sugar on top or press plastic wrap directly onto the surface.
Refrigerate at least 2 hours until well chilled. Serve cold with a generous pour of cold heavy cream over the top—the cream pools around the crimson pudding in the traditional Danish way.

Region Hovedstaden.description: Copenhagen’s iconic open-faced rye sandwiches. Technique: butter the rye bread to the edges so it stays moist; layer ingredients in order (protein, sauce, garnish); keep each bite-sized and visually distinct. Served cold with a knife and fork.
ingredients: Slices of dense, dark rugbrød (Danish rye bread)
Topping option A: thin-sliced roast beef, remoulade, fried onion rings, horseradish
Topping option B: pickled herring, red onion, capers, dill
Topping option C: smoked salmon, cream cheese, dill, lemon
steps: Slice the rugbrød about 1/2 inch (1.2 cm) thick. Butter each slice to the edges so the bread does not get soggy from toppings.
Choose one protein per slice. For roast beef: layer thin slices on the buttered bread; add a stripe of remoulade; top with crispy fried onion and a little grated horseradish.
For herring: drain the herring; place fillets on the bread; add thin red onion rings, capers, and fresh dill.
For salmon: spread a thin layer of cream cheese; add smoked salmon; garnish with dill and a squeeze of lemon.
Season lightly. Serve cold, one or two pieces per person, with a knife and fork. Pair with akvavit or Danish beer.

drink.description: A modern Copenhagen cocktail celebrating Denmark’s love of akvavit and rhubarb: caraway-infused akvavit shaken with rhubarb syrup, fresh lemon, and egg white into a silky, pink, foamy sour. Served in the New Nordic cocktail bars of Vesterbro.
ingredients: 1 oz (30 ml) rhubarb syrup (or rhubarb compote strained)
steps: Dry-shake the akvavit, rhubarb syrup, lemon juice, and egg white (no ice) for 15 seconds to emulsify the egg white.
Add ice and shake hard for another 15 seconds until very cold and frothy.
Strain into a chilled coupe glass. The foam should be thick and pink.
Garnish with a thin slice of fresh rhubarb or a sprinkle of caraway seeds.

Region Midtjylland.description: Classic Danish pan-fried meatballs from the heart of Jutland. Technique: a panade (bread and milk) keeps them tender; mix just until combined to avoid toughness; fry in butter over medium heat so they cook through without burning. Served with potatoes and gravy or red cabbage.
ingredients: 2 slices white bread, crusts removed, torn into small pieces
1 lb (450 g) ground pork (or half pork, half veal)
steps: Soak the bread in the milk 5–10 min until soft. Squeeze out excess milk and mash with a fork to a paste (panade).

In a bowl, combine the meat, onion, egg, flour, allspice, nutmeg, and the panade. Mix with your hands or a spoon until just combined; do not overwork. Add cream if using. Season with salt and white pepper. Rest 15–30 min in the fridge.
With wet hands, shape into oval patties about 2 inches long and 3/4 inch thick (traditional shape).

Melt butter in a large skillet over medium heat. Fry the frikadeller in batches, 3–4 min per side, until golden and cooked through (internal temp 160°F / 71°C). Add more butter as needed. Keep cooked ones warm.
Serve with boiled potatoes, gravy (from the pan drippings and a little stock or cream), and red cabbage or cucumber salad.

drink.description: A Jutland-inspired long drink: golden Danish mjød (mead) topped with ginger beer and a squeeze of lemon. Vikings drank mead; modern Danes drink it with bubbles.
steps: Fill a tall glass with ice.
Pour in the mead and lemon juice. Top with ginger beer.
Stir gently once. Garnish with a lemon wheel.

Region Nordjylland.dish: Kogt Torsk med Sennepssovs (Poached Cod with Mustard Sauce)
Region Nordjylland.description: North Jutland’s coastal classic: delicate cod poached in a court bouillon, served with a warm mustard-dill sauce. Technique: gentle poaching so the fish stays flaky; sauce is built in the pan and finished with butter and dill.
ingredients: 4 cod fillets (about 6 oz / 170 g each), skinless, pin bones removed
2 cups (480 ml) water or light fish stock
6 black peppercorns, 1 bay leaf, 2–3 sprigs dill

For mustard sauce: 2 tbsp butter, 2 tbsp all-purpose flour, 1 cup (240 ml) poaching liquid (strained), 2 tbsp Danish or Dijon mustard, 2 tbsp chopped dill, 1–2 tbsp heavy cream (optional), salt and white pepper
steps: Bring water or stock, wine, carrot, onion, celery, peppercorns, bay leaf, and dill to a gentle simmer; cook 10 min to infuse. Strain and return to the pan; keep at a bare simmer.
Add the cod fillets; they should be just submerged. Poach 4–6 min until the fish flakes with a fork and is opaque. Remove carefully and keep warm. Reserve 1 cup of the poaching liquid.

For the sauce: melt the butter in a small saucepan. Whisk in the flour and cook 1 min. Gradually whisk in the reserved poaching liquid; bring to a simmer and cook until thickened, 2–3 min. Whisk in the mustard, dill, and cream if using. Season with salt and white pepper.
Serve the cod on warmed plates with the mustard sauce, boiled new potatoes, and steamed vegetables or a simple salad.

drink.description: A sparkling Nordic cocktail: akvavit, elderflower liqueur, fresh lime, and soda water—bright, floral, and bracingly cold. The elderflower grows wild across Jutland.
ingredients: 1 oz (30 ml) elderflower liqueur (St-Germain or similar)
steps: Shake the akvavit, elderflower liqueur, and lime juice with ice.
Strain into a tall glass over fresh ice. Top with soda water.
Garnish with a sprig of fresh dill.

Region Sjælland.description: Traditional Zealand dish of fried bacon and apples, sweet and savory. Technique: render the bacon first; cook the apples in the fat until tender and lightly caramelized; balance sweet, salt, and a touch of thyme. Served with rye bread or as a side.
ingredients: 1 lb (450 g) thick-cut smoked bacon (or slab bacon), cut into 1/2-inch dice or strips
3–4 tart apples (e.g. Granny Smith), peeled, cored, and sliced
steps: In a large skillet over medium heat, fry the bacon until it has rendered fat and is golden but not crisp. Transfer to a plate; leave the fat in the pan.
Add the apple slices (and onion if using) to the bacon fat. Sprinkle with sugar and thyme. Cook, stirring occasionally, until the apples are tender and lightly golden, 8–12 min.
Return the bacon to the pan; stir to combine. Taste and adjust with salt, pepper, and a little more sugar if needed. The dish should be a balance of sweet and salty.
Serve hot with dense rye bread and optionally a green salad. Leftovers reheat well.

drink.description: A warming Sjælland cocktail: Danish apple cider heated with akvavit, honey, cinnamon, and star anise. Perfect for the damp Zealand autumn.
ingredients: 4 oz (120 ml) warm Danish apple cider
steps: Warm the apple cider gently (do not boil). Stir in honey until dissolved.
Pour the akvavit into a heat-proof glass. Add the warm cider.
Drop in the cinnamon stick and star anise. Garnish with an apple slice. Serve warm.

Region Syddanmark.description: Southern Denmark’s hearty winter dish: curly kale simmered until tender, then creamed and served with smoked pork or sausage. Technique: blanch the kale to soften and reduce bitterness; long, gentle simmer so it melds with the cream; often served at Christmas or with flæskesteg.
ingredients: 2 lbs (900 g) curly kale (fresh or frozen), tough stems removed, leaves chopped
1 1/2–2 cups (360–480 ml) whole milk or cream
Salt, white pepper, and a pinch of nutmeg
Smoked pork belly or medisterpølse (Danish sausage), to serve
steps: If using fresh kale: bring a large pot of salted water to a boil; blanch the kale 3–5 min until wilted. Drain and squeeze out excess liquid. Chop finely. (If using frozen, thaw and squeeze; no need to blanch.)
Melt the butter in a heavy pot. Whisk in the flour; cook 1 min. Gradually add the milk or cream, whisking until smooth. Bring to a gentle simmer.

Add the kale and sugar. Simmer uncovered, stirring occasionally, 20–40 min until the kale is very tender and the sauce has thickened. Add a little more milk if it becomes too thick. Season with salt, white pepper, and nutmeg.
Serve hot with boiled potatoes and sliced smoked pork or medisterpølse. Traditional at Christmas alongside flæskesteg.

drink.description: A southern Danish cocktail: local herbal snaps shaken with fresh lemon and lingonberry preserves into a tart, fruity sour with a Nordic edge.
steps: Combine all ingredients in a shaker with ice. Shake hard.
Fine-strain into a chilled coupe glass.
Garnish with a few lingonberries or a lemon twist.

DOM.description: The 'Dominican Flag' on a plate, representing the nation's tricolor. White rice (peace), red beans (blood of heroes), and meat (strength) form the holy trinity of the Dominican lunch table, served daily with a side of crispy tostones.
ingredients: Beans: 2 cups Red Kidney Beans, Squash (Auyama), Cilantro, Onion, Garlic
Meat: 2 lbs Chicken or Beef, Sugar (for browning), Sofrito (Peppers, Onions, Garlic, Cilantro), Tomato paste
steps: Meat: Marinate with sofrito and oregano. Heat oil, add 1 tsp sugar and let it caramelize to dark brown. Add meat and sear (this gives color). Add water and tomato paste. Stew until tender.
Beans: Simmer cooked beans with squash chunks, cilantro, and onion until the sauce is creamy and thick.
Rice: Cook white rice until fluffy (Concon/crust at bottom is prized).
Assembly: Arrange on plate like a flag—Rice (White), Beans (Red), Meat.
Serve with a simple salad and tostones.

drink.description: Dominican infused rum traditionally made by steeping herbs and woods, then topped up with rum, red wine, and honey.
ingredients: 2 oz prepared mamajuana infusion (store-bought or pre-steeped)
steps: Serve mamajuana at room temperature or over ice.
Sip slowly; it’s typically served as a digestif.

ingredients: 1 bottle of mamajuana ‘raíces’ (commercial dried bark/herb mix)
steps: Cure (first soak): fill the bottle with rum (or a rum/wine mix) to cover the raíces. Seal and steep about 5–7 days. Discard this first liquid (it’s typically used to ‘wash’ the herbs).
Finish: add the rum, red wine, and honey. Stir or shake gently to dissolve honey.
Steep at least 24 hours in the fridge; better after several days to 1 week. Shake gently once per day.
Serve chilled as small pours (digestif) or mix into cocktails.
Refill method: when the bottle is ~1/3 full, top back up using roughly the same rum/wine/honey balance and let rest 1–2 days before serving again.

dessert.description: An extraordinary Dominican dessert that transforms the humble red bean into liquid velvet. Habichuelas con Dulce is the undisputed queen of Dominican Lenten sweets, served throughout Holy Week and Easter in homes across the island. Dried red kidney beans are simmered until tender, puréed until silky, then cooked again with coconut milk, evaporated milk, sugar, sweet potato, raisins, and warm spices into a luscious, creamy porridge. Served ice-cold in cups with crumbled milk cookies on top, it is sweet, rich, and utterly unlike any bean dish you have ever tasted—proof that Dominican ingenuity can turn anything into dessert.
ingredients: 2 cups (400 g) dried red kidney beans, soaked overnight and drained (or three 15 oz cans, drained and rinsed)
1 cup (200 g) granulated sugar (adjust to taste)
1 medium sweet potato, peeled and cut into 1/2-inch (1.3 cm) cubes
Milk cookies (galletas de leche) or small butter cookies, for serving
steps: If using dried beans, boil the soaked beans in fresh water until completely soft, about 1–1 1/2 hours. Drain, reserving 1 cup (240 ml) of the cooking liquid.
Blend the cooked beans with the reserved cooking liquid (or 1 cup / 240 ml water if using canned) until very smooth. Strain through a fine-mesh sieve for extra silkiness.
Pour the bean purée into a large pot. Add coconut milk, evaporated milk, sugar, cinnamon, nutmeg, cloves, and salt. Stir to combine.
Add the sweet potato cubes. Bring to a gentle simmer over medium heat, stirring frequently to prevent sticking. Cook 15–20 minutes until the sweet potato is tender.
Stir in the raisins and vanilla extract. Simmer another 5 minutes until the mixture is creamy and thick enough to coat the back of a spoon.
Remove from heat and let cool to room temperature. Refrigerate for at least 4 hours or overnight—Habichuelas con Dulce is traditionally served very cold.
Serve chilled in bowls or cups with milk cookies crumbled on top or alongside for dipping. The quintessential taste of Dominican Easter.

DZA.description: The ultimate celebratory dish of Algeria, featuring fluffy semolina grains and a rich seven-vegetable meat stew.
steps: In the bottom of a couscoussier (steamer), brown the lamb and chicken in oil with onions and spices.
Add tomato paste, chickpeas, and 2 liters of water. Simmer for 30 minutes.
Rub couscous grains with olive oil and water. Place in the steamer basket above the boiling stew.
Steam couscous for 15 minutes. Remove, fluff with water/butter, and steam again (repeat twice for fluffiness).
Add carrots and turnips to the stew. Cook 20 mins. Add zucchini and merguez last.
Serve couscous mounded on a platter, topped with meats and veggies, with broth served on the side.

drink.description: Sweet mint tea served throughout North Africa—green tea brewed with fresh mint and plenty of sugar.
ingredients: 1 tbsp Chinese green tea (gunpowder) per 3 cups water
steps: Rinse the tea leaves briefly with a splash of hot water; discard the rinse (optional but traditional for gunpowder tea).
Add tea and water to a teapot and steep 3 minutes.
Add mint and sugar; steep 2 more minutes.
Pour a small amount into a glass and return it to the pot (to mix), then serve. Traditionally poured from height to aerate.

dessert.description: The pride of Constantine and one of North Africa's most treasured pastries. Makroud are diamond-shaped semolina cookies concealing a heart of spiced date paste, deep-fried to a shattering golden crust, and plunged into warm honey that seeps into every crevice. The semolina dough—mixed with butter and orange blossom water—has a sandy, crumbly bite that yields to the sticky-sweet date center, while the honey glaze adds floral fragrance and a glistening sheen. Found in every Algerian pâtisserie and at the center of every Eid table, Makroud are proof that the simplest ingredients, handled with patience, become extraordinary.
ingredients: 1/2 cup (120 ml) melted unsalted butter or olive oil
1/2 cup (120 ml) warm water (approximately, as needed)
2 cups (350 g) pitted Deglet Noor dates (or Medjool)
steps: If dates are dry, soak in warm water for 15 minutes and drain well.
Process dates in a food processor until a smooth, sticky paste forms. Add orange blossom water, butter, cinnamon, and cloves; pulse until evenly combined.
Roll the date paste into long ropes about 3/4 inch (2 cm) in diameter. Set aside.
Combine honey and water in a small saucepan over medium heat. Stir until the honey dissolves and the mixture is warm and fluid.
Remove from heat and stir in the orange blossom water and lemon juice. Keep warm for dipping the fried makroud.
In a large bowl, combine semolina and salt. Add melted butter and rub between your palms until the mixture resembles wet sand. Add the orange blossom water.
Gradually add warm water a few tablespoons at a time, kneading until the dough holds together and is smooth but not sticky. Cover and rest 15 minutes.
Divide the dough into portions. Roll each portion into a long log about 3 inches (8 cm) wide and 1/2 inch (1.3 cm) thick. Press a channel down the center with your finger.
Lay a date paste rope into the channel. Fold the dough over the filling and seal, rolling gently into a smooth log about 1 1/2 inches (4 cm) in diameter.
Cut the filled logs on the diagonal into diamond shapes about 2 inches (5 cm) long. Score the top of each piece with fork tines for the traditional pattern.
Heat vegetable oil to 340°F (170°C) in a deep pan. Fry the makroud in batches for 3–4 minutes per side until deep golden brown. Drain briefly on paper towels.
While still hot, dip each makroud into the warm honey soak for 30 seconds, turning once to coat. Transfer to a wire rack set over a tray to drain. Let cool before serving—the pride of Constantine.
Mix all spices thoroughly.
Store airtight up to 2–3 months.

ingredients: 6 dried red chilies (or 2 tbsp chili flakes; adjust heat)
steps: If using whole dried chilies, cover with hot water 20 minutes; drain.
Blend chilies with garlic, spices, lemon juice, salt, and olive oil into a thick paste.
Refrigerate up to 2 weeks (cover surface with a thin layer of oil).

Dadra and Nagar Haveli and Daman and Diu.description: Daman is famous for its seafood and Portuguese influence. Fresh crabs are cooked simply in a rich sauce of butter, garlic, and pepper to highlight the sweetness of the meat.
steps: Melt butter in a wok.
Add garlic and sauté until golden.
Add crabs and toss to coat.
Add a splash of water, cover, and steam for 10 mins.
Finish with lots of black pepper and spring onions.

drink.description: The coastal west has strong Portuguese-era spirit traditions; cashew feni served as a simple highball fits the region well.
steps: Fill a tall glass with ice.
Add feni and lime, top with soda, stir gently, and serve.

ECU.description: Ecuador's national obsession and the ultimate 'levanta muertos' (hangover cure). This robust tuna and yuca soup, topped with tangy pickled onions, traces its roots to the Valdivia culture (3500 BC), proving that good fish stew is timeless.
ingredients: Broth: Tomatoes, Onion, Garlic, Cumin, Cilantro, Chili powder
steps: Boil tuna in water with onion, tomato, and spices until cooked. Remove tuna and flake into chunks.
Blend the vegetables from the broth to thicken it. Return to pot.
Add yuca to the broth. Boil until soft.
Serve in a bowl: Yuca and broth at bottom, topped with tuna chunks and a mountain of pickled red onions.
Garnish with cilantro and serve with chifles and popcorn on the side.

drink.description: A traditional Ecuadorian hot cinnamon drink, sweetened with panela/sugar and finished with aguardiente.
ingredients: 6–8 oz aguardiente (or white rum), to taste (about 1–2 oz per mug)
steps: In a pot, combine the water, cinnamon sticks, and panela. Bring to a simmer and cook 10–15 minutes, stirring until the panela dissolves and the cinnamon infuses.
Remove from the heat and let it cool slightly (so the alcohol doesn’t boil off).
Stir in aguardiente to taste (start with ~1 oz per mug).
Serve hot in mugs.

dessert.description: Quito's beloved street dessert—towering pastel swirls of meringue cloud piped into cones and sold from glass-fronted carts on every corner of the Ecuadorian highlands. Ripe guava pulp, fragrant and rosy pink, is folded into a stiff meringue of whipped egg whites and sugar, creating a mousse-like confection that is lighter than air yet bursting with tropical fruit flavor. Eaten frozen from a wafer cone or soft and billowy straight from the piping bag, Espumilla is pure joy: part meringue, part sorbet, and entirely Ecuadorian. The sight of a vendor piping a perfect pink spiral is as much a part of Quito as the Panecillo.
