ingredients: 1 cup (240 ml) guava pulp (from about 4 ripe guavas, seeded and blended, or frozen guava pulp thawed)
Wafer cones or small cups, for serving
steps: If using fresh guavas, peel, halve, and scoop out the seeds. Blend the flesh until smooth and strain through a fine-mesh sieve to remove any remaining seeds. Measure 1 cup (240 ml) of pulp.

In a spotlessly clean, dry bowl, beat the egg whites and salt with an electric mixer on medium speed until foamy. Increase to high speed, adding sugar 1 tablespoon at a time, and beat until stiff, glossy peaks form—about 8–10 minutes.

With the mixer on low, gradually pour in the guava pulp, lime juice, and vanilla extract. Increase speed to medium and beat for 2 more minutes until the meringue is uniformly pink and cloud-like in texture.
Transfer to a piping bag fitted with a large star tip. Pipe tall, dramatic swirls onto a parchment-lined tray or directly into wafer cones.

For a frozen treat, freeze the piped swirls for at least 2 hours until firm but still creamy inside. Alternatively, serve immediately as a soft, mousse-like treat scooped into cones—the way Quito's street vendors do it.
Serve frozen or soft. Each cone should be a towering pastel cloud of guava meringue—Quito's sweetest street-side tradition.

ingredients: 1/2 cup fresh lime juice (or a mix of lime + vinegar)
steps: Toss onions with salt (and sugar if using).
Add lime juice; massage briefly. Let sit 30 minutes to 2 hours until pink and softened.
Refrigerate up to 1 week.

EGY.description: Egypt's national street food. A carb-heavy powerhouse of pasta, rice, and lentils topped with spicy tomato sauce.
ingredients: Sauce: Tomato puree, Garlic, Vinegar, Cumin, Chili flakes
steps: Boil lentils until tender. Boil macaroni until al dente. Cook rice.
Crispy Onions: Fry onion slices in oil until dark brown and crispy. Drain. Save the oil.
Sauce: Fry garlic in the onion oil. Add vinegar (sizzle!), then tomato puree and spices. Simmer.
Dak'ka (Garlic Sauce): Mix minced garlic, vinegar, lemon juice, cumin, and water.
Assembly: Layer rice, then lentils, then macaroni.
Top with tomato sauce, chickpeas, and a mountain of crispy onions. Serve with Dak'ka on side.

drink.description: A popular Egyptian-style hibiscus drink—tart, ruby-red, and served hot or cold.
steps: Bring water to a boil, add hibiscus, and simmer 5 minutes.
Turn off heat and steep 10 minutes.
Strain and sweeten to taste.
Serve hot, or chill and serve over ice.

dessert.description: Egypt's queen of desserts and a dish steeped in legend—said to have been created to celebrate a Mamluk sultan's rise to power. Flaky puff pastry (or torn croissants) is scattered in a deep baking dish, showered with a mosaic of nuts, raisins, and coconut, then drenched in sweetened milk infused with vanilla and warm spices. A final veil of heavy cream is drizzled over the top before the dish enters a blazing oven, emerging golden, bubbling, and impossibly fragrant. Each spoonful is a study in contrasts: crisp caramelized edges giving way to a custardy, bread-pudding center rich with pistachios and almonds. Om Ali is comfort, celebration, and history in every bite.
ingredients: 8 oz (225 g) puff pastry (1 sheet), or 4 large croissants torn into pieces
1 can (14 oz / 400 ml) sweetened condensed milk
steps: If using puff pastry, bake at 400°F (200°C) for 12–15 minutes until puffed and golden. Let cool, then tear into rough, bite-sized pieces. If using croissants, tear them directly into pieces.
Preheat the oven to 425°F (220°C). Scatter the pastry pieces evenly across a large baking dish, about 9×13 inches (23×33 cm).
Sprinkle the raisins, almonds, pistachios, coconut, and pine nuts (if using) evenly over the pastry.
In a saucepan, warm the whole milk, condensed milk, vanilla, cinnamon, and cardamom over medium heat until steaming and well combined. Do not boil.
Pour the hot milk mixture evenly over the pastry and nuts. Let it soak for 5 minutes so the pastry absorbs the liquid.
Drizzle the heavy cream over the top in a thin, even layer.
Bake for 15–20 minutes until the top is deeply golden and bubbling, with patches of caramelized cream. For extra color, broil for 1–2 minutes at the end, watching carefully.
Serve immediately, scooped hot from the dish. Om Ali waits for no one—it is at its glorious best straight from the oven, golden, creamy, and fragrant.

ESP.description: The original Paella. No seafood here—just rabbit, chicken, beans, and saffron.
steps: Level the paella pan over the fire. Add olive oil.
Fry chicken and rabbit slowly until well browned.
Push meat to edges. Fry beans in center. Add paprika (don't burn) and grated tomato.
Add water to the rivets of the pan. Boil for 20 mins to make broth. Add saffron.
Sprinkle rice evenly. Do not stir after this point.
Cook on high for 10 mins, then low for 8 mins.
Listen for the 'socarrat' (crackling sound of rice caramelizing on bottom).
Let rest 5 mins before eating straight from the pan.

drink.description: Spain’s classic wine punch: red wine with fruit, citrus, a little sweetener, and a splash of brandy—served cold over ice.
steps: In a pitcher, dissolve sugar into the orange juice.
Add wine, brandy, and citrus slices.
Chill at least 2 hours (overnight is better).
Just before serving, add soda water to taste.
Serve over ice with fruit in each glass.

dessert.description: Crispy fried ridged dough sticks served with thick Spanish hot chocolate for dipping—Madrid's beloved breakfast ritual and Barcelona's midnight indulgence. The dough is piped through a star-shaped tip into shimmering oil, emerging golden and corrugated, shattering at the first bite to reveal a tender, slightly chewy interior. The chocolate is not a drink but a sauce: so thick a churro stands upright in it, made with real dark chocolate and thickened with cornstarch in the old Madrid style. Dip, bite, repeat—the only proper way to end a Spanish evening or begin a Spanish morning.
ingredients: 1 large egg (optional, for a lighter churro)
Vegetable or sunflower oil for deep frying
1/4 cup (50 g) granulated sugar mixed with 1 tsp ground cinnamon, for rolling
Thick Hot Chocolate (see Chef's Essentials below)

preliminary_steps.item: Thick Hot Chocolate (Chocolate a la Taza)
ingredients: 3.5 oz (100 g) dark chocolate (70%), finely chopped
steps: Whisk the cornstarch into 1/4 cup (60 ml) of the cold milk until completely dissolved.
Heat the remaining milk in a saucepan over medium heat until steaming. Add the chocolate and sugar, whisking until melted and smooth.
Pour in the cornstarch slurry, whisking constantly. Cook 2–3 minutes until the chocolate thickens enough to coat the back of a spoon. Remove from heat and serve immediately in small cups for dipping.
In a saucepan, bring the water, butter, sugar, and salt to a rolling boil over medium-high heat.
Remove from heat and add the flour all at once. Stir vigorously with a wooden spoon until the dough forms a smooth ball and pulls away from the sides of the pan.
Let cool 2 minutes, then beat in the egg if using, stirring until fully incorporated and the dough is smooth and glossy.
Transfer the dough to a piping bag fitted with a large open-star tip (1/2 inch / 1.5 cm).

Heat oil to 375°F (190°C) in a deep pot or fryer. Pipe 4–6 inch (10–15 cm) lengths of dough directly into the hot oil, cutting with scissors. Fry in batches of 4–5, turning once, until deep golden and crisp, about 3–4 minutes total.
Drain on paper towels, then roll immediately in the cinnamon-sugar mixture.
Serve hot alongside cups of the thick hot chocolate for dipping.

Andalucia.description: Córdoba's thicker, richer cousin of gazpacho: dead-ripe tomatoes, stale bread, raw garlic, and a river of extra-virgin olive oil blended into a velvety, coral-pink cold soup, then topped with jamón serrano and diced hard-boiled egg. Salmorejo is not gazpacho—it has no cucumber, no peppers, no vinegar. Just four ingredients and the patience to blend until impossibly smooth. In the scorching Córdoban summer, this is breakfast, lunch, and therapy.
ingredients: 2 lbs ripe tomatoes (the ripest you can find), cored and roughly chopped (900 g)
7 oz stale white bread (baguette or pan de pueblo), crusts removed, torn (200 g)
1/2 cup extra-virgin olive oil (120 ml), plus more for drizzling
3 oz jamón serrano or ibérico, diced (85 g)
steps: Place the tomatoes in a blender and blend until completely liquefied. Strain through a sieve to remove skins and seeds. Return to the blender.
Add the torn bread and garlic to the tomato juice. Let soak 10 minutes so the bread softens completely.

Blend on high until perfectly smooth. With the blender running, pour in the olive oil in a slow, steady stream—like making mayonnaise. The mixture should emulsify into a thick, creamy, coral-pink soup. Season with salt.
Chill at least 2 hours (overnight is better). The salmorejo thickens as it rests.
Serve in bowls, topped with diced hard-boiled egg and jamón. Finish with a generous drizzle of olive oil.

drink.description: The official cocktail of the Feria de Abril in Seville: fino or manzanilla sherry mixed with lemon-lime soda and fresh mint over ice. Rebujito is dangerously drinkable—light, cold, slightly nutty from the sherry, and the reason no one remembers the second day of Feria. Served in half-litre cups and consumed by the gallon.
ingredients: 3 oz (90 ml) fino or manzanilla sherry, well chilled
steps: Fill a tall glass with ice. Pour in the sherry.
Top with the lemon-lime soda. Stir gently once.
Tuck in several mint sprigs. Drink under a Sevillana sun.

dessert.description: Pestiños are the ancient sweet of Andalucía — small, honey-glazed fried pastries perfumed with sesame, anise, and orange that trace their origin to the Moorish al-Andalus of the 9th century. They appear on every Andalusian table during Semana Santa and Christmas, fried in olive oil (never sunflower) until they puff and crisp, then dunked while still hot in warm honey thinned with a splash of orange juice or orange blossom water. The word may derive from the Arabic 'pestis' (pressed), a reference to the folding technique that creates their characteristic rectangular shape. The dough contains wine — traditionally fino sherry or dry white — which evaporates during frying to leave the pastry impossibly light. Every family has its own proportion of anise to sesame; every grandmother insists hers is the one true recipe. Eaten hot, standing over the stove while the honey drips from your fingers and clings to your chin, watching the olive groves through the kitchen window, they are the taste of Andalucía in its most elemental form.
ingredients: For the dough: 2 cups (250 g) all-purpose flour, plus more for dusting
1/3 cup (80 ml) good olive oil (mild, not too peppery)
1/3 cup (80 ml) dry white wine or fino sherry
Olive oil for deep-frying (about 2 cups / 480 ml)
For the honey glaze: 1/2 cup (170 g) mild honey (orange blossom or acacia), 2 tbsp fresh orange juice or orange blossom water
Ground cinnamon and sesame seeds for garnish
steps: Heat the olive oil in a small saucepan over medium heat. Add the sesame seeds and anise seeds; fry gently for 1 minute until fragrant but not brown. Add the orange zest and cinnamon; stir 30 seconds. Remove from heat and let the spiced oil cool slightly — about 5 minutes.

Place the flour and salt in a large bowl. Pour in the warm spiced olive oil and the wine. Mix with a fork, then knead gently in the bowl until a smooth, soft, non-sticky dough forms — about 3 minutes. Do not over-knead. Cover with plastic wrap and rest 30 minutes at room temperature.

Lightly flour your work surface. Roll the dough very thin — about 2mm, like pasta. Cut into rectangles about 3x4 inches (8x10 cm). Fold each rectangle: bring both short ends toward the center, overlapping slightly, and press the center firmly to seal — this creates the characteristic package shape. Press the sealed side against the work surface to flatten slightly.

Heat 2 inches (5 cm) of olive oil in a heavy-bottomed pot to 350°F (175°C). Fry the pestiños in batches, sealed-side down first, for 2–3 minutes per side until golden and crisp. Drain on paper towels. While still hot, transfer to a clean dish.

Warm the honey with the orange juice in a small saucepan until fluid and runny. Pour the warm honey over the hot pestiños, turning to coat all sides. Alternatively, dip each pestiño individually in the warm honey. Scatter sesame seeds and a dusting of cinnamon over the top. Serve immediately while the honey is still warm and glossy.

Aragon.description: Aragón's most prized dish: a whole leg of ternasco (milk-fed lamb under 90 days old, PDO-protected) roasted simply with garlic, white wine, and lard until the exterior is mahogany-crisp and the interior is impossibly tender and sweet. Aragonese shepherds have raised ternasco in the Pyrenean foothills for millennia. The lamb needs almost nothing—quality speaks for itself. Served with roast potatoes that cook in the lamb drippings.
ingredients: 1 leg of ternasco or young lamb (about 4 lbs / 1.8 kg)
2 lbs potatoes, peeled and sliced 1/4 inch thick (900 g)
Salt and freshly ground black pepper
steps: Preheat oven to 400°F (200°C). Make small incisions all over the lamb leg and insert garlic halves into each cut. Season generously with salt and pepper. Rub with lard.
Spread the sliced potatoes and onion rings in a roasting pan. Season with salt. Place the lamb leg on top. Pour the white wine over everything. Tuck rosemary sprigs around the lamb.

Roast 20 minutes at 400°F, then reduce to 350°F (175°C). Roast 1.5–2 hours total (about 25 min per pound), basting occasionally with the pan juices. The potatoes should absorb the drippings and crisp at the edges.
Rest 15 minutes before carving. Serve sliced, with the potatoes and pan juices spooned over.

drink.description: A rustic Aragonese summer drink: ripe peach slices steeped in chilled red wine with a touch of sugar and cinnamon. Every Aragonese grandmother makes this in August when the Calanda peaches ripen.
ingredients: 1 bottle (750 ml) young red wine (Garnacha from Cariñena)
steps: Place peach slices, sugar, and cinnamon in a pitcher. Pour over the wine.
Refrigerate at least 2 hours.
Serve cold over ice. Eat the wine-soaked peaches.

dessert.description: Frutas de Aragón are the jewels of Aragonese confectionery — whole candied fruits from Aragon's famous orchards (peaches from Calanda, cherries from the Jiloca valley, oranges from the Ebro basin, pears, figs, plums) encased in a thick shell of bitter dark chocolate. They are the most formal, precise, and beautiful sweet of the region, made by the master confectioners of Zaragoza, protected by a Denominación de Origen. The technique is ancient: whole fruits or large pieces are candied slowly over days in progressively stronger sugar syrups until every drop of moisture is replaced by sugar, preserving them indefinitely while giving them a translucent, jewel-like quality. Then they are enrobed in couverture chocolate — at least 60% cacao — which contracts around the fruit as it cools, creating a shell that cracks cleanly and gives way to the intensely sweet, perfumed fruit within. The contrast is perfect: bitter, snapping dark chocolate and concentrated fruit sweetness, a single bite that contains all of Aragon's orchards and the memory of its Moorish candy-makers.
ingredients: For the candied fruit: 1 lb (450 g) firm whole fruits or large pieces — peaches, pears, apricots, cherries, or orange peel; all peeled or prepared as appropriate
3 cups (600 g) granulated sugar for the first syrup
Additional sugar for successive syrups (about 4 more cups / 800 g total over 5 days)
For the chocolate coating: 12 oz (340 g) high-quality dark chocolate (60–70% cacao), finely chopped
1 tsp neutral vegetable oil or cocoa butter
steps: Day 1 — first syrup: Dissolve 3 cups sugar in 3 cups water in a saucepan, bring to a boil, then cool to 140°F (60°C). Place prepared fruit in a non-reactive container (glass or ceramic). Pour the warm syrup over the fruit. Weigh down with a small plate to keep fruit submerged. Cover and rest 24 hours.

Days 2–5 — building the syrup: Each day, drain the syrup into a saucepan. Add 3/4 cup (150 g) additional sugar per cup of syrup. Bring to a boil, dissolve completely, cool to 140°F (60°C), pour back over the fruit. The syrup grows progressively more concentrated each day. By day 5, the fruit should be firm, translucent-looking, and very sweet. Drain completely and dry the fruit on a rack for 1–2 days until the surface is dry and slightly tacky but not wet.

Temper the chocolate: Melt two-thirds of the chocolate in a double boiler to 115°F (46°C). Remove from heat. Add the remaining third, stirring constantly, until the temperature drops to 88–90°F (31–32°C). The chocolate is tempered when it coats a knife cleanly and begins to set with a slight sheen within 5 minutes at room temperature. Stir in the vegetable oil.

Enrobe the fruit: Using a dipping fork or two forks, dip each piece of candied fruit into the tempered chocolate, letting excess drip off. Place on a parchment-lined tray. If the chocolate starts to thicken, warm briefly over a double boiler and re-temper.

Allow the chocolate to set completely at cool room temperature (65–68°F / 18–20°C) for at least 1 hour — do not refrigerate or the chocolate will bloom. Store in a cool, dry place in an airtight tin between layers of parchment for up to 3 weeks.

Asturias.description: The king of Spanish stews and Asturias' greatest gift to gastronomy: massive white fabes (butter beans) simmered low and slow with a compango of chorizo, morcilla (blood sausage), lacón (cured pork shoulder), and tocino (salt pork). The beans must stay whole and creamy, never broken; the broth should be thick and silky from the bean starch. This is mountain food from the green, rainy north—hearty, deeply savory, and built to sustain coal miners and cattle herders through Asturian winters.
ingredients: 1 lb dried fabes de la Granja or large white butter beans, soaked 12 hours (450 g)
1/2 lb lacón or smoked ham hock (225 g)
1/4 lb tocino (salt pork belly) or pancetta (110 g)
Large pinch of saffron threads (about 1/2 tsp)
steps: Drain the soaked beans. Place in a large, heavy pot. Add the lacón and tocino. Cover with cold water by 3 inches. Bring to a very gentle simmer over medium heat—never let it boil hard or the beans will break.
When it reaches a simmer, add the chorizos and morcillas. Add the bay leaf. Reduce heat to the lowest setting. The surface should barely tremble.

Cook 2–3 hours, adding cold water in small splashes whenever the liquid drops below the beans (this is called 'asustar las fabes'—shocking the beans—and helps them cook evenly). Never stir with a spoon; instead, shake the pot gently.
In the last 30 minutes, dissolve the saffron and pimentón in a ladle of broth and stir in gently. Season with salt (careful—the pork is salty).

Remove the meats. Slice the lacón and tocino; cut the chorizo and morcilla into thick rounds. Serve the beans in deep bowls with the sliced compango arranged on top. The broth should be thick and clinging.

drink.description: Asturian cider is not a drink—it is a performance. The escanciador (pourer) holds the bottle above their head with one hand and the glass near their hip with the other, pouring a thin stream that splashes into the glass from a height of 3 feet. This 'escanciar' aerates the flat, dry cider, creating a brief sparkle (estrella) that lasts only seconds—you must drink the culín (splash) immediately in one gulp. Repeat.
ingredients: 1 bottle Sidra Natural Asturiana (750 ml), room temperature (never chilled)
steps: Hold the bottle high above your head in one hand, glass low near your hip in the other.
Pour a thin stream into the glass—the cider should travel 3 feet and splash off the inner rim to create foam.
Pour only a culín (2–3 oz / 60–90 ml) at a time. Drink immediately in one gulp while the estrella (fizz) lasts.
Flick out the last drops from the glass (this cleans it). Repeat.

dessert.description: Arroz con leche is made all over Spain, but Asturias has made it its own to the point of obsession and culinary identity. The Asturian version is thicker, creamier, and richer than any other Spanish rice pudding — and it finishes with a technique borrowed from the other side of the Pyrenees: a thin crust of sugar is caramelized on top with a red-hot iron, exactly like a crème brûlée, creating a brittle amber sheet over the cream below. The secret of Asturian arroz con leche is time and fat: the rice must cook slowly in whole milk from Asturian cows (the raza frisona of the mountain valleys, their milk uniquely rich), absorbing the milk over 45 to 60 minutes, stirred constantly with a wooden spoon until the starch thickens the milk into a cream almost the consistency of a thick custard. Lemon zest and cinnamon perfume it. The butter added at the end gives it a silky finish that lingers. Served cold with that crackled cinnamon-sugar top, it is the taste of a rainy Sunday afternoon in Oviedo, the fireplace going, the cider breathing in the glass.
ingredients: 1 cup (200 g) short-grain white rice (Arborio or Spanish bomba rice)
4 cups (960 ml) whole milk, plus more if needed
Peel of 1 lemon (removed in a single spiral with a vegetable peeler)
4–6 tbsp granulated sugar for caramelizing the top
steps: Rinse the rice under cold water and drain. Combine the rice, milk, cream, lemon peel, cinnamon stick, and salt in a heavy-bottomed saucepan (ideally a wide, low pot for even cooking). Bring to a gentle boil over medium heat, stirring frequently.

Reduce heat to low. Cook, stirring continuously and gently with a wooden spoon, for 40–50 minutes. The milk will gradually absorb into the rice; if at any point it looks too thick before the rice is tender, add a splash of warm milk. The rice should be fully tender and the mixture very thick — it should fall slowly from the spoon and hold its shape briefly when poured. This long cooking cannot be rushed.

Remove the lemon peel and cinnamon stick. Stir in the sugar and cook 5 more minutes, stirring, until the sugar dissolves and the mixture thickens further. Remove from heat and stir in the butter until melted and glossy.
Pour into individual shallow ceramic ramekins or one large dish to a depth of about 1 inch (2.5 cm). Smooth the surface. Let cool to room temperature, then refrigerate at least 2 hours or overnight.

To serve: Dust the surface of each dish with a thin, even layer of ground cinnamon. Sprinkle 1–1.5 tsp of granulated sugar evenly over the cinnamon. Caramelize with a kitchen blowtorch, moving in small circles until the entire surface is an even amber caramel and crackling. Wait 2 minutes for the sugar to harden into a brittle shell. Serve immediately — the contrast between cold, creamy rice and hot caramel crust is the entire point.

Baleares.description: Mallorca's vegetable masterpiece: layers of fried potato, fried eggplant, and fried red pepper, each cooked separately to perfection, then stacked in a clay dish and bathed in a fresh tomato sauce. Tumbet is the Balearic ratatouille—but where ratatouille stews everything together, tumbet keeps each vegetable distinct and proud. Served at room temperature as a side or main, it is the taste of a Mallorcan summer.
ingredients: 2 large potatoes, peeled and sliced 1/4 inch thick
2 eggplants, sliced 1/4 inch thick, salted 30 minutes and patted dry
3 red bell peppers, seeded and quartered
Olive oil for frying (about 1 cup / 240 ml)
Salsa de Tomate Mallorquina (see Chef's Essentials below)
2 lbs ripe tomatoes, grated on a box grater (discard skins) (900 g)
steps: Heat olive oil in a saucepan. Add garlic, cook 1 minute. Add grated tomato, sugar, and salt.
Simmer 20–25 minutes until thick and deep red, stirring occasionally.
Fry the potato slices in olive oil until golden and just tender. Drain on paper towels. Season with salt.
Fry the eggplant slices until golden on both sides. Drain. Season.
Fry the red pepper quarters until softened and lightly charred. Drain.
In a clay dish (greixonera) or baking dish, layer: potatoes on the bottom, then eggplant, then peppers. Pour the warm tomato sauce over the top layer.
Serve at room temperature. In Mallorca, tumbet accompanies grilled fish or roast pork, but it stands beautifully on its own.

drink.description: Menorca's legendary gin cocktail: Xoriguer gin (distilled in Mahón from juniper and Mediterranean botanicals in wood-fired copper stills since the British occupation) mixed with cloudy lemonade. Pomada is served in every Menorcan fiesta and beach chiringuito—the ratio is sacred: roughly 1 part gin to 3 parts lemonade.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) Xoriguer Mahón gin (or London dry gin)
steps: Fill a tall glass with ice.
Pour in the gin. Top with cloudy lemonade.
Stir gently once. Garnish with a lemon slice. Drink on a Menorcan beach at sunset.

dessert.description: The Ensaimada is Mallorca's edible emblem, recognized across Spain and beyond by its extraordinary form: a large spiral coil of airy, featherweight brioche-like dough, brushed with lard (saïm in Catalan — hence the name), coiled into a snail shape, and baked to a pale gold. It is then buried under an avalanche of powdered sugar so generous it creates a white snowfield on the bakery counter. The dough is made with eggs, sugar, flour, and water — no butter, which would interfere with the lard's unique effect. The lard creates lamination without crunch — soft, yielding, layered gossamer sheets that uncoil as you pull it apart. Mallorca's ensaimadas come plain (llisa) or filled: cabello de ángel (strands of candied spaghetti squash), custard cream, sobrasada sausage for the savory-sweet, or dark chocolate. They are flown in sealed cardboard hat-boxes from Palma airport as gifts for the mainland — the first thing every Mallorquín carries home after a trip away.
ingredients: For the starter: 1 tsp instant yeast, 3 tbsp warm water, 3 tbsp (25 g) all-purpose flour, 1 tsp sugar
For the dough: 3 cups (375 g) all-purpose flour, 1/2 cup (100 g) granulated sugar, 2 large eggs plus 1 egg yolk, 1/3 cup (80 ml) warm water, 1/4 tsp fine sea salt
1/2 cup (115 g) high-quality lard (manteca de cerdo), softened to a creamy consistency — do not substitute butter
Powdered sugar for an extremely generous final dusting
steps: Make the starter: Combine the yeast, warm water, flour, and sugar. Mix until smooth. Cover and let rest 20 minutes until bubbly.

In a stand mixer with a dough hook, combine the flour, sugar, and salt. Add the eggs, egg yolk, warm water, and the starter. Mix on low 3 minutes, then medium-high for 8–10 minutes until the dough is smooth, elastic, and slightly tacky but not sticky. It should pull cleanly from the bowl sides. Wrap and refrigerate 30 minutes.

On a lightly floured surface, roll the dough as thin as possible — ideally less than 2mm, almost translucent, like a large sheet of pasta. Spread the softened lard over the entire surface of the dough in a thin, even layer, reaching the edges. Roll the dough up tightly into a long sausage, stretching it gently as you roll to make it as long and thin as possible.

Coil the rope into a loose snail-spiral on a parchment-lined baking sheet, leaving space for expansion. The center should be raised slightly higher. Cover loosely and let rise at room temperature for 8–12 hours (traditionally overnight) until the coil has puffed dramatically and looks airy and voluminous.

Preheat the oven to 375°F (190°C). Bake for 18–22 minutes until pale golden — it should not be dark. The interior stays very soft. Cool completely on a rack. Then dust enormously with powdered sugar — use at least 1/4 cup (30 g) per medium ensaimada, sifted over the entire surface until it creates a thick white layer. Serve the same day, ideally within hours of baking.

Canarias.description: The Canary Islands' most iconic dish: small waxy potatoes boiled in seawater (or heavily salted water) until the water evaporates and a white crust of salt crystals forms on the wrinkled skins. Served with two sauces—mojo rojo (red, with dried peppers and cumin) and mojo verde (green, with cilantro and parsley). The potatoes must be small, unpeeled, and cooked until the skins wrinkle and crack. The salt crust is the point.
ingredients: 2 lbs small waxy potatoes (fingerlings or new potatoes), unpeeled (900 g)
1/2 cup coarse sea salt (enough for a very salty brine)
4 dried ñora peppers (or 2 dried guajillo chiles), soaked 20 minutes
steps: Drain the soaked peppers and remove seeds. Blend with garlic, cumin, pimentón, vinegar, and salt until smooth.
With the blender running, drizzle in the olive oil until emulsified. The sauce should be thick but pourable.

ingredients: 1 large bunch fresh cilantro (stems and leaves)
steps: Blend cilantro, parsley, garlic, green pepper, cumin, vinegar, and salt until smooth.
Drizzle in the olive oil with the blender running. Adjust salt and vinegar to taste.
Place the potatoes in a single layer in a wide pot. Add enough water to barely cover them. Add the sea salt—the water should taste like the ocean.
Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer 20–25 minutes until the potatoes are tender when pierced with a knife.

Drain almost all the water, leaving just a splash. Return the pot to low heat and shake gently for 3–5 minutes as the remaining water evaporates. The skins will wrinkle and a white salt crust will form.
Serve the wrinkled potatoes on a plate with both mojos on the side for dipping.

drink.description: The Canary Islands' layered coffee cocktail: condensed milk on the bottom, then Licor 43 (vanilla-citrus liqueur), then espresso, then frothed milk, topped with cinnamon and a twist of lemon peel. The layers are the art—each one floats on the one below. Barraquito is the afternoon ritual of every Canarian café terrace.
steps: Pour the condensed milk into a small glass.
Slowly pour the Licor 43 over the back of a spoon to create a second layer.
Gently add the hot espresso over the spoon for a third layer.
Top with frothed milk. Dust with cinnamon and add a lemon peel twist.

dessert.description: Bienmesabe — 'it tastes good to me' — is the most loved dessert sauce in the Canary Islands, a thick, fragrant, honey-almond cream that is simultaneously ancient and simple. The name appears first in 16th-century Canarian records, though a version was already known in Arab-influenced Sicilian and Andalusian cooking under the name 'biancomangiero.' The Canarian version is pure and austere: raw almonds ground to a paste, mixed with local miel de palma (palm honey — the dark, rum-scented syrup extracted from Canarian date palms) or orange blossom honey, egg yolks, lemon zest, and a generous pour of ron miel — the sweet honey rum of the Canaries, dark gold and aromatic. The mixture is cooked gently until it thickens to a texture like warm pastry cream — voluptuous, glossy, clinging to the spoon. It is served warm or at room temperature over vanilla ice cream, on fresh fruit, spooned over almond cake, or eaten directly from the bowl with a spoon, which is the most honest way.
ingredients: 1 cup (340 g) local dark honey (miel de palma if available, or dark buckwheat honey)
2 tbsp ron miel canario (Canarian honey rum) or dark rum
Toasted almond flakes and a dusting of cinnamon for serving
steps: Toast the almonds in a dry skillet over medium heat for 4–5 minutes, tossing often, until golden and fragrant. Cool completely. Transfer to a food processor and grind to a fine powder — then continue processing until a smooth almond paste begins to form, about 3–4 minutes total. The paste should be fine and slightly oily.
In a medium heavy-bottomed saucepan, combine the honey and water. Heat over medium-low heat, stirring, until the honey dissolves and the mixture is warm.

In a bowl, whisk the egg yolks until smooth. Slowly pour about half the warm honey mixture into the yolks, whisking constantly (this tempers the eggs). Pour the tempered yolk mixture back into the saucepan with the remaining honey.

Add the ground almond paste, lemon zest, cinnamon, and salt. Cook over medium-low heat, stirring constantly with a wooden spoon, for 8–12 minutes until the mixture thickens to the consistency of a thick custard sauce — it should coat the back of the spoon heavily and leave a clear line when you drag your finger across it.

Remove from heat and stir in the ron miel. Taste — it should be intensely almond-sweet, warm with honey, and lightly spiced. Cool slightly. Serve warm over vanilla ice cream with toasted almond flakes and a dusting of cinnamon, or store covered in the refrigerator for up to 5 days (it thickens further when cold).

Cantabria.description: The hearty mountain stew of Cantabria: white beans (alubias) braised with berza (Cantabrian cabbage), chorizo, morcilla, ribs, and tocino. Unlike the chickpea-based cocidos of central Spain, this highland cocido uses the region's prized alubias and the bitter, iron-rich berza that grows in the damp green valleys below the Picos de Europa. It is stick-to-your-ribs food for a rainy Cantabrian day.
ingredients: 1 lb dried white beans (alubias), soaked 12 hours (450 g)
1/4 lb tocino (salt pork) or pancetta (110 g)
1 small head berza (Cantabrian cabbage) or savoy cabbage, quartered
steps: Drain the soaked beans. Place in a large pot with the ribs, tocino, and bay leaf. Cover with cold water by 3 inches. Bring to a gentle simmer—never boil hard.
Simmer 1.5 hours, adding splashes of cold water when the level drops. Add the chorizo and morcilla. Continue simmering 30 minutes.
Meanwhile, blanch the cabbage quarters in boiling salted water for 5 minutes. Drain.
Add the blanched cabbage to the bean pot. Simmer 30 more minutes until everything is tender and the broth is thick. Season with salt.
Remove the meats, slice them. Serve the beans and cabbage in deep bowls with the sliced meats on top.

drink.description: Cantabria's mountain digestif: orujo (grape marc spirit distilled in the Liébana valley) sweetened with local honey. Sipped warm or cold after a cocido montañés, it's the Cantabrian equivalent of grappa with honey—and twice as comforting.
steps: Warm the orujo gently (do not boil). Stir in honey until dissolved.
Serve in a small glass with a lemon peel twist. Sip slowly by the fire.

dessert.description: The Quesada Pasiega is the definitive sweet of the Pasiegos — the mountain people of the Valles Pasiegos in Cantabria, famous for their extraordinary dairy cattle and the quality of their milk, butter, and fresh cheese. This is a custard tart of great simplicity and great depth: fresh requesón (or ricotta) from the mountain creameries, mixed with eggs, sugar, butter, flour, and lemon zest, poured into a mold and baked slowly until set. It looks unassuming — a pale, flat, quivering tart. But the texture is startling: it sits between a baked cheesecake and a flan, with a crumb-free base and a cream that is simultaneously dense and trembling, rich with butter and cheese, fragrant with lemon. The quesada needs no base, no crust — it is the filling itself that is the point. Every October, Selaya in Cantabria holds a Feria de la Quesada Pasiega, and the competition for the best recipe is as serious as any in Spain.
ingredients: 2 cups (500 g) fresh requesón or whole-milk ricotta, at room temperature
1/2 cup (115 g) unsalted butter, melted and slightly cooled
steps: Preheat the oven to 350°F (175°C). Butter a 9-inch (23 cm) square baking dish or a 10-inch (25 cm) round ceramic dish generously.

If using ricotta, press it through a fine sieve to remove excess moisture and make it very smooth. In a large bowl, beat the requesón or sieved ricotta with the sugar until completely smooth and creamy — use a whisk or electric beater.

Beat in the eggs one at a time, mixing well after each addition. Beat in the melted butter, then the flour, lemon zest, vanilla, and salt. Mix until everything is perfectly smooth and combined — there should be no lumps.
Pour the batter into the prepared dish. Dust the surface generously with ground cinnamon.

Bake for 40–50 minutes until the top is golden-amber and the center is set — it should tremble only very slightly in the center when shaken. A skewer inserted in the middle should come out clean or with very few moist crumbs.

Cool completely in the dish on a rack — do not serve hot, as the texture sets as it cools. The quesada is best served at room temperature or slightly chilled. Cut into squares or wedges. Dust with more cinnamon if desired.

Castilla-La Mancha.description: La Mancha's answer to ratatouille: a slow-cooked, chunky sofrito of tomatoes, peppers, courgettes, and onion, each vegetable cut into small dice and cooked patiently in olive oil until silky and jammy. The Manchegan touch: a fried egg cracked on top, its yolk running into the vegetables. In Don Quixote's homeland, pisto is the dish of the people—humble ingredients elevated by time and olive oil. Every family in La Mancha has their own ratio.
ingredients: 4 ripe tomatoes, peeled and diced (or 1 can crushed tomatoes)
Salt and sugar (a pinch to balance acidity)
steps: Heat the olive oil in a wide, heavy skillet over medium-low heat. Add the onions and cook slowly 10 minutes until translucent.
Add the green and red peppers. Cook 10 minutes, stirring occasionally, until softened.
Add the courgettes. Cook 10 minutes more.

Add the garlic and tomatoes. Season with salt and a pinch of sugar. Reduce heat to low and cook 20–30 minutes, stirring occasionally, until everything is soft, jammy, and the oil has separated slightly. The pisto should be thick, not soupy.
Fry 4 eggs in olive oil (the edges should crisp, the yolk stay runny). Serve the pisto in a clay dish with fried eggs on top.

drink.description: La Mancha's rustic wine punch: red wine, sliced summer fruit (peach, melon, lemon), sugar, and cinnamon, served ice-cold from a clay jug at harvest festivals. Less refined than sangría, more honest, and utterly refreshing in the Castilian heat.
ingredients: 1 bottle (750 ml) young Manchegan red wine (Tempranillo)
steps: Combine wine, fruit, sugar, cinnamon, and water in a clay jug or pitcher.
Refrigerate at least 3 hours.
Serve ice-cold over ice. Eat the wine-soaked fruit.

dessert.description: Toledo has been making mazapán since the 12th century, and the Convent of San Clemente — whose nuns still make and sell it through a wooden wheel in the convent wall, without ever showing their faces — may be the oldest continuously operating sweet shop in the world. Toledo's mazapán is simply two ingredients: almonds and sugar. That is all. The city's almonds, grown in the dry dehesa landscapes of Castilla-La Mancha under a brutal sun that concentrates their oil and perfume, are ground with an equal weight of fine sugar and a few drops of water to form a paste of extraordinary richness. The ratio is sacred: one part almond, one part sugar, exactly. The paste is kneaded and shaped — traditionally into figures: little figures of saints, swans, fruits, crowns — then briefly toasted under a grill to create a barely-there browned surface. The interior remains white, moist, soft, and yielding. Toledo mazapán tastes of almond and nothing else — intensely, purely, transcendently almond.
ingredients: 2 cups (200 g) blanched almonds (the best quality you can find — Marcona almonds from La Mancha are ideal)
1 tsp orange blossom water (optional but traditional)
1 egg yolk beaten with 1 tsp water for glazing
Powdered sugar for dusting your hands while shaping
steps: Blanch the almonds if not already blanched: cover with boiling water for 1 minute, drain, slip off the skins, and spread on a tray to dry completely. If using pre-blanched almonds, ensure they are very dry.

Make the sugar syrup: Combine the granulated sugar and water in a small saucepan. Heat over medium heat, stirring until the sugar dissolves, then cook without stirring to the soft-ball stage — 240°F (115°C) on a thermometer.
While the syrup cooks, grind the almonds in a food processor to a very fine powder. Run the machine 3–4 minutes until the mixture begins to cake and looks like very fine, slightly oily crumbs.

Pour the hot sugar syrup over the ground almonds in the food processor (or in a heavy-duty stand mixer). Add the orange blossom water. Mix/pulse until the mixture comes together into a cohesive paste that pulls away from the sides. The paste will be warm. Tip onto a clean work surface and knead briefly until smooth. If too sticky, knead in a little powdered sugar. Wrap in plastic wrap and rest at room temperature 1 hour.

Preheat the broiler to high. Shape the marzipan into traditional Toledan figures — fruits, small animals, crowns, or simply ovals and cylinders — about 1 inch (2.5 cm) in size. Place on a parchment-lined baking sheet. Brush very lightly with egg yolk glaze.

Broil 2–4 minutes until just lightly golden on the surface — watch carefully, they burn quickly. Cool on the tray. Store in an airtight tin, separated by parchment, at room temperature for up to 2 weeks.

Castilla-Leon.description: Segovia's legendary roast suckling pig: a whole cochinillo (piglet no more than 3 weeks old, fed only on mother's milk) roasted in a wood-fired clay oven until the skin is glass-crisp and shattering while the meat beneath is soft as butter. In Segovia's mesones, the finished cochinillo is ceremonially carved using only the edge of a plate—if the skin is properly roasted, the plate cuts through it like a knife. The plate is then smashed on the floor for luck.
ingredients: 1 whole suckling pig (about 10–12 lbs / 4.5–5.5 kg), or 1 bone-in pork shoulder (6 lbs) as substitute
steps: Preheat oven to 400°F (200°C). Rub the pig (or pork shoulder) all over with lard and season generously with salt. Place skin-side up in a large roasting pan.
Add the garlic halves, bay leaves, thyme, wine, and water to the bottom of the pan.
Roast 30 minutes at 400°F. Reduce to 325°F (163°C) and roast 2.5–3 hours (for suckling pig) or 4–5 hours (for pork shoulder), basting every 30 minutes with the pan juices.
For the last 15 minutes, increase heat to 450°F (230°C) to blister and crisp the skin. The skin should be mahogany-colored, crackling, and glass-crisp.
Rest 15 minutes. In Segovia, the cochinillo is carved with the edge of a plate—if your skin crisped properly, try it.

drink.description: A spiced red wine punch from Old Castile: wine simmered with cinnamon, cloves, lemon, and sugar, then chilled. Served at every fiesta in the meseta, from medieval fair to village patron saint's day.
ingredients: 1 bottle (750 ml) Ribera del Duero or young Tempranillo
steps: Gently warm the wine with sugar, cinnamon, cloves, and lemon until sugar dissolves (do not boil).
Cool. Add peach if using. Refrigerate at least 4 hours.
Serve cold. Strain or leave the fruit and spices in the pitcher.

dessert.dish: Yemas de Santa Teresa de Ávila
dessert.description: The Yemas de Santa Teresa are among the most poetic sweets in all of Spain: small, golden-yellow balls of pure egg yolk and sugar, encased in a thin shell of crystallized sugar, said to have been first made by the Carmelite nuns of Ávila in the 16th century as a sweet offering at the feast of their patron Saint Teresa. The nuns were practical: the convents of Ávila used enormous quantities of egg whites to clarify their wines and to varnish paintings, leaving mountains of unused yolks. Sweet recipes for excess yolks — the tradition of convent sweets (dulces conventuales) — spread across Spain from convent to convent. The Yemas are the finest expression of this tradition: just egg yolks, cooked with sugar syrup to a thick, trembling paste, rolled while still warm into balls, and rolled in fine granulated sugar or encased in fondant. They taste of pure egg and pure sugar — rich, compact, and golden as the walls of Ávila.
ingredients: Granulated sugar for rolling (about 1/4 cup / 50 g)
steps: Pass the egg yolks through a fine sieve into a large heatproof bowl. This removes the chalaza and any egg-white threads, ensuring perfect smoothness.

In a small saucepan, combine the sugar and water. Cook over medium heat, stirring until the sugar dissolves, then cook without stirring to the thread stage — 230°F (110°C) on a candy thermometer. Remove from heat.

Pour the hot sugar syrup in a thin stream over the sieved egg yolks, whisking constantly and vigorously to prevent scrambling. The mixture will be fluid and yellow. Transfer to a double boiler (a bowl set over barely simmering water — the bowl should not touch the water).

Cook in the double boiler, stirring constantly with a wooden spoon or spatula, for 15–25 minutes. The mixture will gradually thicken from a liquid to a thick paste that pulls away from the sides of the bowl and holds its shape when scooped. Do not rush this step with too much heat. Stir in lemon zest and vanilla if using.

Remove from heat and cool the paste to room temperature — it will firm up further. Once cool enough to handle, dust your hands with powdered sugar and roll tablespoon-sized portions into smooth balls. Roll each ball in granulated sugar to coat completely.

Place in small paper cups (like those used for bonbons) if available, or on a parchment-lined tray. Allow to set at room temperature for 1–2 hours — a thin crystallized crust will form. Store in a single layer in an airtight tin at cool room temperature for up to 1 week.

Cataluña.description: Catalonia's Christmas boiled dinner: a massive pot of meats (veal, chicken, pork bones, botifarra sausage), vegetables (cabbage, potato, carrot, turnip), chickpeas, and a giant meatball called pilota is simmered for hours. The broth is served first with galets (large shell pasta) as the sopa; then the meats and vegetables are served as the second course. This is the meal that gathers every Catalan family on December 25th—the aroma of the escudella defines Christmas in Barcelona.
ingredients: 1/2 lb beef shank or veal (225 g)
1/2 lb galets pasta (large shell pasta) (225 g)

steps: Mix all ingredients. Form into one large ball (the size of an orange). It will be cooked in the broth.
Place the beef, chicken, pork bones, and soaked chickpeas in a very large pot. Cover with 4 quarts cold water. Bring to a gentle simmer, skimming foam. Cook 1 hour.
Add the carrots, turnip, potatoes, celery, butifarra, and the pilota. Simmer 1 more hour until all meats and vegetables are tender.
Remove all meats, vegetables, and the pilota. Keep warm. Strain the broth.
Cook the galets pasta in the strained broth until al dente.
Serve in two courses: first the broth with galets (the sopa), then a platter of the sliced meats, sliced pilota, vegetables, and chickpeas. Bon Nadal!

drink.description: A Catalan twist on the Venetian Bellini: cava (Catalonia's méthode champenoise sparkling wine from Penedès) with fresh white peach purée. Lighter and drier than a prosecco Bellini, with the mineral edge of good cava.
ingredients: 1 oz (30 ml) fresh white peach purée (or peach nectar)
4 oz (120 ml) brut cava, well chilled
steps: Pour the peach purée into a champagne flute.
Slowly top with chilled cava. Stir gently once.
Serve immediately.

dessert.description: Let the French have their crème brûlée — Catalonia will tell you, without raising its voice, that it did this first. Crema Catalana appears in the Llibre de Sent Soví, the oldest Catalan cookbook, in 1324 — centuries before the French version was documented. The differences are real and matter: Crema Catalana is made with milk, not cream, and thickened with cornstarch and egg yolks — giving it a looser, more silky body than its richer French cousin. It is perfumed exclusively with cinnamon and citrus zest (lemon and orange), simmered in the hot milk until it turns fragrant, then strained out. The caramel crust is made traditionally with a hierro — a flat iron disk on a long handle, heated red-hot over fire or stove and pressed against the sugar to caramelize it in an instant, without the blowtorch. Every March 19 (Sant Josep, Father's Day in Catalonia) it appears on every Catalan table. It is the dessert of a people who know exactly who they are.
ingredients: Zest of 1 lemon (peel in wide strips with a vegetable peeler)
4–6 tsp granulated sugar (for the caramel top — 1 tsp per ramekin)
steps: Combine the milk, cinnamon stick, lemon zest, and orange zest in a saucepan. Heat over medium-low heat until steaming and just about to simmer. Remove from heat and infuse for 20–30 minutes. Strain out the aromatics.
In a large bowl, whisk the egg yolks with the sugar until pale and creamy. Whisk in the cornstarch and salt until smooth — the mixture should be thick and free of lumps.
Reheat the infused milk to steaming. Pour very slowly into the egg yolk mixture, a thin stream at first, whisking constantly. This tempering step is essential to prevent scrambling.

Return the entire mixture to the saucepan over medium-low heat. Cook, stirring constantly with a flexible spatula, reaching all corners of the pan, until the cream thickens and begins to bubble — about 8–12 minutes. It should be the consistency of a medium-thick pastry cream. Do not walk away.

Pour immediately through a fine sieve into 4–6 shallow terracotta or ceramic dishes (the traditional wide, shallow shape is important for the maximum caramel surface area). Smooth the surface. Cool to room temperature then refrigerate uncovered at least 3 hours.

To serve: Sprinkle exactly 1 tsp granulated sugar evenly over each cream. Caramelize immediately with a blowtorch or traditional heated iron, working in small circles until the entire surface is amber and bubbling. Let set 1–2 minutes. The crust should shatter at the tap of a spoon. Serve immediately.

Ceuta.description: Ceuta's beloved street food: small skewers of pork or lamb marinated in a Moorish spice paste of cumin, coriander, turmeric, paprika, and garlic, then grilled over charcoal until charred and fragrant. Pinchitos morunos are the bridge between Spain and Morocco—eaten at every tapa bar in this North African Spanish city.
ingredients: 1.5 lbs pork loin or lamb, cut into 3/4-inch cubes (680 g)
steps: Mix all the spices, garlic, olive oil, lemon juice, and salt into a paste. Coat the meat cubes and marinate at least 2 hours (overnight is better).
Thread onto soaked wooden skewers. Grill over hot charcoal 3–4 minutes per side until charred.
Serve with bread and a squeeze of lemon.

drink.description: Moorish mint tea as served in Ceuta's medina: green tea with a mountain of fresh spearmint and copious sugar, poured from a height.
steps: Rinse tea with boiling water (discard). Add mint and sugar.
Pour 3 cups boiling water. Steep 3–5 minutes.
Pour from a height into small glasses to create foam.

dessert.description: In Ceuta — that remarkable Spanish city on the northern tip of Africa where Andalusian baroque churches stand alongside mosques, and Spanish and Moroccan cultures have coexisted for centuries — the sweet table belongs to the tradition of the Rif Berbers, the Moroccan Andalusians, and the Sephardic Jews who all called this crossroads home. Ka'ab el Ghzal, 'gazelle horns' in Arabic, are the most refined pastry of this tradition: crescent-shaped pastries of very thin, pliable dough filled with a fragrant almond paste perfumed with orange blossom water, cinnamon, and mastic gum, twisted at both ends into the elegant horns of a gazelle, then baked pale gold and cooled. Some versions are glazed with icing sugar; the Ceuta tradition keeps them plain, brushed with orange blossom water for fragrance, then rolled in icing sugar to create a snow-white exterior. They are eaten at Eid, at weddings, at baptisms — at any gathering where sweetness and beauty are required to mark a moment.
ingredients: For the almond filling: 2 cups (200 g) blanched almond flour or ground almonds, 1 cup (120 g) powdered sugar, 2 tbsp orange blossom water, 1/2 tsp ground cinnamon, 1/4 tsp ground mastic (or 1/4 tsp vanilla extract), 1 tbsp unsalted butter, softened
For the pastry: 2 cups (250 g) all-purpose flour, 1/4 cup (60 ml) warm water, 2 tbsp orange blossom water, 2 tbsp unsalted butter, melted, pinch of salt
1 egg white, lightly beaten, for sealing
steps: Make the almond filling: Combine the ground almonds, powdered sugar, orange blossom water, cinnamon, and mastic in a bowl. Add the softened butter and mix with your hands until a smooth, cohesive paste forms. If too dry, add a few drops more orange blossom water. Roll into small logs about 2 1/2 inches (6 cm) long and 1/2 inch (1.5 cm) in diameter. There should be 20–24 logs. Refrigerate until needed.
Make the pastry: Combine the flour and salt. Add the melted butter, orange blossom water, and warm water. Mix to form a dough; knead 5 minutes until smooth and elastic. Wrap and rest 30 minutes.
Preheat the oven to 350°F (175°C). Roll the pastry very thin — 1mm — on a lightly floured surface. Cut into rectangles about 4x3 inches (10x8 cm).

Place an almond log along the long edge of a pastry rectangle. Roll up the pastry tightly around the filling, pinching and sealing the long edge with egg white. Twist each end gently to seal, then curve the roll into a crescent shape (like a gazelle's horn) by bending it slightly over your thumb. Pinch and thin the pointed ends.
Place on a parchment-lined baking sheet and bake for 15–18 minutes — they should be very pale gold, not brown. Overbaking destroys their delicacy.
While still warm, brush with orange blossom water. Once cooled, roll generously in powdered sugar. Store in a single layer in an airtight tin at room temperature for up to 2 weeks.

Extremadura.description: Extremadura's shepherd's breakfast: stale bread torn into crumbs, then fried slowly in olive oil and pork fat with garlic until golden and crispy, studded with chorizo, panceta, and pimientos. Migas were invented by transhumant shepherds crossing the Extremaduran dehesas—they had bread, oil, garlic, and whatever pork they carried. The secret is patience: the breadcrumbs must be moistened, then fried slowly so every crumb crisps without burning.
ingredients: 1 lb stale rustic bread, crusts removed, torn into small crumbs (450 g)
1/4 lb panceta (salt pork belly) or thick-cut bacon, diced (110 g)
1 dried ñora pepper or 1 tsp pimentón
steps: The night before: sprinkle the breadcrumbs with the water and a pinch of salt. Toss to moisten evenly. Cover with a damp towel and leave overnight. The crumbs should be slightly damp but not wet.
In a large, heavy skillet, heat the olive oil over medium heat. Fry the panceta until the fat renders and it begins to crisp. Add the chorizo slices and cook until lightly browned. Remove the meats.
Add the garlic to the fat. When golden, add the ñora pepper (or pimentón). Stir 30 seconds.

Add the dampened breadcrumbs. Now begins the slow work: fry over medium-low heat, stirring and tossing constantly, for 20–30 minutes. Every crumb must turn golden and crisp—but not burn. Patience is everything.
When the migas are golden and crispy throughout, return the panceta and chorizo. Toss together. Serve immediately, traditionally with grapes, melon, or fried eggs on the side.

drink.description: Extremadura's most unusual liqueur: made from the bellota (acorn) of the holm oaks in the dehesa where the ibérico pigs roam. Sweet, nutty, and deeply earthy—a taste of the Extremaduran landscape.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) licor de bellota (or Frangelico as substitute)
steps: Pour over ice in a rocks glass.
Garnish with an orange twist. Sip as a digestif.

dessert.description: Perrunillas are the great humble cookie of Extremadura — a crumbly, dry, sweet cookie made with lard, anise, and lemon zest that has been baked in the wood-fired ovens of the region since at least the 17th century. The name (roughly 'little dog-things') is endearingly unpretentious for a cookie that has survived centuries of fashion unchanged. Lard is the essential ingredient — not butter, not oil, only manteca de cerdo from the Ibérico pig, which gives the perrunilla its unique texture: tender, crumbling immediately on the tongue, and with a richness no plant fat can replicate. Anise seed provides its signature perfume; lemon zest cuts the richness. Some versions add a drop of aguardiente or dry sherry. They are rolled, cut into rounds or ovals, and baked until pale cream-gold — they should not brown. Eaten in Extremadura at any hour, dunked in sweet wine or coffee, stacked in a tin on the kitchen table for any visitor who arrives. Pure, honest, and extraordinary.
ingredients: 1/2 cup (115 g) high-quality lard (manteca de cerdo ibérico), at room temperature
1 tsp anise seeds, lightly crushed in a mortar
1 tbsp dry anise liqueur (anís seco) or dry sherry (optional)
1 egg yolk beaten with 1 tbsp water for glaze
Granulated sugar for sprinkling the tops
steps: In a large bowl, beat the lard with the sugar until pale and fluffy, about 3 minutes. Beat in the eggs one at a time. Add the lemon zest, crushed anise seeds, and anise liqueur if using.

Sift the flour, baking powder, and salt together. Add to the lard mixture and mix with a spatula or your hands until a cohesive, soft dough forms. It will be slightly crumbly — this is correct. If it's too dry, add 1–2 tbsp cold water. Flatten into a disk, wrap in plastic, and refrigerate 30 minutes.
Preheat the oven to 350°F (175°C). Line baking sheets with parchment paper.
Roll the dough on a lightly floured surface to about 3/8 inch (1 cm) thickness. Cut into rounds or ovals using a 2.5-inch (6 cm) cookie cutter. Gently reroll scraps and cut more cookies.
Place on the prepared baking sheets. Brush lightly with the egg yolk glaze. Sprinkle a pinch of granulated sugar over each cookie.

Bake for 14–18 minutes until the cookies are pale gold — barely colored at the edges. Do not let them brown; perrunillas should be light. They will be soft when warm but firm up as they cool. Cool completely on a rack before transferring — they are fragile when warm. Store in an airtight tin at room temperature for up to 2 weeks; they improve over the first few days.

Galicia.description: Galicia's sacred octopus dish, served at every romería (patron saint's festival) and pulpería (octopus restaurant) in the region: a whole octopus is boiled in copper cauldrons, cut into rounds with scissors, and served on a wooden plate drizzled with olive oil, coarse salt, and pimentón de la Vera. The technique of dipping the octopus three times before submerging it (to curl the tentacles) is the Galician grandmother's secret. The wood plate (plato de feira) is non-negotiable—it absorbs the oil and gives the dish its identity.
ingredients: 1 tbsp pimentón de la Vera (sweet smoked Spanish paprika)
steps: Bring a very large pot of water to a rolling boil (do NOT salt the water). Hold the octopus by the head and dip the tentacles into the boiling water 3 times, letting the water return to a boil between dips. This curls and tenderizes the tentacles.

On the third dip, submerge the entire octopus. When the water returns to a boil, reduce to a simmer. Cook 45–60 minutes (about 20 minutes per pound) until a knife slides easily into the thickest part of a tentacle.
Turn off the heat and let the octopus rest in its cooking water for 10 minutes.
Remove and cut the tentacles into 1/2-inch rounds using scissors (traditional) or a sharp knife.
Arrange the rounds on a wooden plate (plato de feira). Drizzle generously with olive oil, sprinkle with coarse salt and pimentón. Serve with boiled potatoes sliced underneath if desired.

drink.description: Galicia's legendary fire ritual: orujo (grape marc spirit) is heated in a clay pot with sugar, lemon peel, and coffee beans, then SET ON FIRE while an incantation (conxuro) is chanted to ward off evil spirits. The blue flames are ladled in and out of the pot until the sugar caramelizes and the alcohol partially burns off. Queimada is drunk at Celtic festivals, after pilgrimages to Santiago, and on any dark Galician night that needs light.
ingredients: 1 cup (240 ml) orujo or aguardiente gallego
steps: In a clay queimada pot, combine the orujo, sugar, citrus peels, and coffee beans. Stir.
Using a long match, carefully ignite the surface. The orujo will burn with a blue flame.
While it burns, ladle the flaming liquid up and pour it back into the pot. Chant the conxuro if you know it.
When the flames begin to die (after 3–5 minutes), cover the pot to extinguish. Serve warm in small clay cups.

dessert.description: The Tarta de Santiago is one of the great cakes of the world — simple, ancient, and deeply meaningful. It is made from just ground almonds, eggs, and sugar, with no flour, no butter, no dairy. The result is a moist, dense, gloriously rich almond cake with a slightly crunchy top, intensely fragrant, naturally gluten-free, and unmistakably itself. What makes it the Tarta de Santiago is the dusting of its top with powdered sugar stenciled through the Cross of Saint James — the cross of the Order of Santiago, the pilgrimage symbol that has drawn pilgrims to the tomb of the apostle in Santiago de Compostela since the 9th century. The cross is left in bright white on the surface, surrounded by the golden-brown cake visible beyond its edges. Pilgrims reaching Santiago after weeks of walking the Camino are greeted with a slice on the Cathedral steps. The history of this cake is the history of medieval Europe — faith, trade, the movement of almonds from the Moorish south, and the great hunger of people who had walked very far.
ingredients: 2 1/4 cups (225 g) ground blanched almonds (almond flour — finely ground)
1/4 tsp pure almond extract (optional, for deeper flavor)
Butter and flour for the pan
Powdered sugar and a Cross of Santiago stencil (or cut one from paper) for the top
steps: Preheat the oven to 350°F (175°C). Butter and flour a 9-inch (23 cm) round springform pan, then line the bottom with parchment paper.

In a large bowl, beat the eggs and sugar with an electric mixer on high speed for 4–5 minutes until very pale, thick, and tripled in volume. The mixture should fall in wide, slow ribbons from the beater.

Gently fold in the ground almonds, lemon zest, orange zest, cinnamon, and almond extract (if using) with a large spatula. Use wide, careful folding motions from the bottom of the bowl to preserve the volume in the eggs. The batter will deflate somewhat; this is normal.

Pour into the prepared pan and smooth the top gently. Bake for 30–35 minutes until the cake is golden-brown on top, pulls away slightly from the sides, and a skewer inserted in the center comes out clean. The center may still have a very slight spring — that is perfect.

Cool completely in the pan on a rack — at least 1 hour. Unmold. Place the Cross of Santiago stencil (cutout) in the center of the cake and dust the entire surface generously with powdered sugar. Carefully lift the stencil away to reveal the white cross on the golden cake. Serve at room temperature. It keeps 3–4 days well-wrapped.

La Rioja.description: La Rioja's comfort masterpiece: potatoes braised (not fried, not boiled—braised) with chorizo in a paprika-scented broth until the potatoes are creamy and breaking apart and the broth is thick and rust-red from the chorizo fat. The potatoes must be 'cascadas' (broken by hand or roughly chopped, never cleanly cut) so the starch thickens the sauce. This is the tapa that every Riojan bar serves with a glass of Rioja Crianza.
ingredients: 2 lbs potatoes, peeled and broken into chunks (cascadas—snap them, don't slice) (900 g)
1/2 lb chorizo riojano (cured chorizo), sliced into 1/2-inch rounds (225 g)
1 dried choricero pepper (soaked, flesh scraped) or 2 tsp pimentón
3 cups chicken broth or water (720 ml)
steps: Heat olive oil in a heavy pot. Add the chorizo slices and fry until the fat renders and they lightly crisp. Remove and set aside.
In the chorizo fat, sauté the onion until soft, 8 minutes. Add garlic, cook 1 minute. Add the choricero pepper flesh (or pimentón) and stir 30 seconds.
Add the broken potato chunks. Stir to coat in the oil and spices. Add the broth and bay leaf. The liquid should just cover the potatoes.

Bring to a simmer. Cook 25–30 minutes, stirring gently a few times, until the potatoes are tender and starting to break apart, thickening the broth. The sauce should be somewhere between a soup and a stew—thick and clinging.
Return the chorizo to the pot. Simmer 5 more minutes. Season with salt. Serve in clay bowls.

drink.description: La Rioja's spiced wine punch: young Rioja red wine macerated with peaches, cinnamon, and sugar. The fiestas of San Mateo in Logroño run on zurracapote—it flows from fountains during the grape harvest celebrations.
ingredients: 1 bottle (750 ml) young Rioja red wine (joven)
steps: Combine wine, fruit, sugar, and cinnamon in a pitcher.
Refrigerate at least 4 hours (overnight is ideal).
Serve ice-cold. In Logroño, this comes in 1-litre jugs.

dessert.dish: Peras al Vino Tinto de La Rioja
dessert.description: There is no dessert in Spain more elegant in its honesty than this: whole pears, peeled but stem intact, simmered slowly in Rioja red wine with sugar, cinnamon, cloves, and orange peel until they turn the deep, trembling purple-crimson of a winter sunset over the Ebro valley. The pears drink the wine and the wine becomes the pears — sweet, spiced, tannin-rounded — and as the poaching liquid reduces to a syrup, it lacquers the fruit in a glossy, deeply colored glaze. They are served at room temperature or slightly cool, standing upright, drenched in their own reduced syrup, sometimes alongside a spoon of sheep's milk ice cream or fresh cream from Rioja's dairy farms. This dish is served in every good restaurant in Logroño at the end of a long lunch that began with the day's pimientos asados and continued through a Rioja Reserva. It asks nothing of you but the patience to let the wine and the fruit do their work.
ingredients: 4–6 firm, slightly underripe pears (Bosc or Anjou work beautifully — they hold their shape when poached)
1 bottle (750 ml) Rioja Crianza or Rioja Reserva red wine
Heavy cream, crème fraîche, or sheep's milk ice cream for serving
steps: Peel the pears carefully, leaving the stems intact. Using a melon baller or small spoon, scoop out the core from the bottom of each pear, making a neat cavity.

In a saucepan just large enough to hold the pears upright (they should fit snugly), combine the red wine, sugar, cinnamon, cloves, orange peel, lemon peel, bay leaf, and vanilla bean if using. Stir to begin dissolving the sugar. Bring to a gentle simmer.

Add the pears to the simmering wine mixture — they should be mostly submerged. If not, add a splash more wine or water. Press a piece of parchment paper over the surface, then cover the pan with a lid.

Simmer gently over medium-low heat for 25–40 minutes, depending on the ripeness and size of the pears, turning them every 10 minutes. They are done when a skewer pierces them with no resistance — perfectly tender throughout. The pears will have absorbed a deep red-purple color.

Remove the pears carefully with a slotted spoon and set aside. Bring the poaching liquid to a boil and reduce over high heat for 10–15 minutes until it has reduced to a thin syrup that coats the back of a spoon. Strain out the spices.

Serve the pears at room temperature or slightly cool, standing upright in deep bowls. Spoon the reduced Rioja syrup over and around them generously. Accompany with a spoonful of cream or sheep's milk ice cream.

Madrid.description: Madrid's monumental three-course stew, served in a ritual called 'los tres vuelcos' (three pourings): first the broth is served as soup with fideos (thin noodles); then the chickpeas and vegetables; finally the meats (beef, chicken, chorizo, morcilla, tocino, bone marrow). The cocido simmers for hours in an earthenware puchero, and the order of eating is sacred. This is the dish that fueled Madrid's Golden Age and still anchors every castizo tavern's weekly menu.
ingredients: 1 lb dried chickpeas, soaked 12 hours (450 g)
1 lb beef shank or brisket (450 g)
1/2 lb fideos (thin noodles) or angel hair pasta (225 g)
steps: Place the chickpeas, beef, chicken, tocino, and marrow bone in a very large pot. Cover with cold water by 3 inches. Bring to a gentle simmer, skimming foam constantly for the first 20 minutes.
Simmer on low heat for 2 hours. Add the chorizo and morcilla in the last 45 minutes. Add the potatoes, carrots, and cabbage in the last 30 minutes.
When everything is tender, carefully remove all the components. Strain the broth.
First vuelco: cook the fideos in the strained broth. Serve the broth and fideos as soup.
Second vuelco: arrange the chickpeas, potatoes, carrots, and cabbage on a platter. Serve.
Third vuelco: slice the meats—beef, chicken, chorizo, morcilla, tocino. Scoop the marrow from the bone. Arrange on a platter. Serve.

drink.description: Madrid's everyday summer wine cocktail—simpler and more honest than sangría: red wine and gaseosa (lemon-flavored soda water) over ice. Every terraza in Madrid serves tinto de verano from May to October. The ratio is flexible but roughly 1:1. Madrilenos consider sangría a tourist trap; tinto de verano is the real deal.
ingredients: 4 oz (120 ml) gaseosa or lemon-lime soda
steps: Fill a tall glass with ice.
Pour in the red wine. Top with gaseosa.
Add a lemon slice. Stir once. Drink on a Madrid terraza at sunset.

dessert.description: There are churros and there is Madrid's chocolate. The churro — a loop or stick of choux-adjacent fried dough, crisp outside, soft inside, coated in fine sugar — is loved across Spain and Latin America. But the Madrileño version is distinguished by what accompanies it: a cup of chocolate espeso, so thick a spoon stands upright in it, made from high-cacao dark chocolate and cornstarch, that is more a velvet sauce than a drink. The correct technique is to dip the churro all the way into the chocolate, swirl it once, and eat immediately — the contrast of fried dough and thick, bittersweet, near-black chocolate is one of the great pleasures of human civilization. Chocolaterías in Madrid — San Ginés, the oldest, has operated since 1894 — serve this combination at 3am to clubbers and at 7am to people going to work, bridging the gap between night and day. It is the food of Madrid as it truly is: nocturnal, unsentimental, and magnificent.
ingredients: For the churros dough: 1 cup (240 ml) water, 1 cup (125 g) all-purpose flour, 1 tbsp granulated sugar, 1/2 tsp fine sea salt, 1 tbsp olive oil or neutral oil
Neutral oil for deep frying (about 2 cups / 480 ml)
Fine sugar mixed with a pinch of cinnamon for coating

For the chocolate espeso: 2 cups (480 ml) whole milk, 3 1/2 oz (100 g) high-quality dark chocolate (70% cacao), finely chopped, 2 tbsp granulated sugar, 2 tbsp cornstarch, pinch of fine sea salt, 1/4 tsp ground cinnamon
steps: Make the chocolate espeso: In a small bowl, whisk together the cornstarch and 1/4 cup (60 ml) of the cold milk until completely smooth with no lumps. Heat the remaining milk with the sugar and cinnamon in a saucepan over medium heat. When steaming, add the chopped chocolate and stir until melted. Pour the cornstarch mixture into the hot chocolate in a thin stream, whisking constantly. Cook over medium heat, whisking constantly, 3–5 minutes until the chocolate thickens dramatically to a consistency thick enough to coat a spoon heavily. Keep warm over the lowest heat, stirring occasionally.

Make the churro dough: Bring the water, sugar, salt, and oil to a rolling boil in a saucepan. Remove from heat. Add the flour all at once and stir vigorously with a wooden spoon until a smooth, cohesive dough forms that pulls away from the sides of the pan. Let cool 5 minutes.

Transfer the dough to a piping bag fitted with a large star tip (1/2 inch / 12 mm). Heat 2 inches of oil in a heavy pot to 360°F (182°C). Pipe 6-inch (15 cm) lengths of dough into the hot oil, cutting with scissors or a knife. Fry in batches, turning, 3–4 minutes until deep golden and crisp all over.
Drain on paper towels for 30 seconds, then immediately roll in the cinnamon-sugar mixture. Serve immediately alongside cups of the thick hot chocolate for dipping.

Melilla.description: Melilla's crossroads couscous: fine semolina steamed over a lamb-and-vegetable stew perfumed with cinnamon, ginger, saffron, and ras el hanout—the North African spice cabinet—reflecting this Spanish city's Amazigh, Sephardic, and Riffian heritage.
ingredients: 1/2 tsp each: cinnamon, ginger, turmeric, saffron threads
steps: Brown the lamb in olive oil. Add onion, cook until soft. Add all spices, stir 1 minute.
Add 4 cups water. Simmer 1 hour until lamb is tender. Add the hard vegetables (carrot, turnip) for the last 30 minutes, zucchini and chickpeas for the last 15.
Prepare couscous per package directions (or steam over the stew in a couscoussier).
Mound couscous on a platter. Arrange the lamb and vegetables on top. Ladle broth over. Serve with harissa on the side.

drink.description: Mint tea as drunk in Melilla's Riffian cafés: sweet, scalding, and served in ornate glasses.
steps: Rinse tea. Add mint and sugar. Steep 4 minutes.
Pour from a height. Serve hot.

dessert.dish: Sfenj de Melilla con Miel de Azahar
dessert.description: Melilla's sfenj are the Spanish enclave's window into the Moroccan and Berber soul of North Africa — golden, airy, irregular rings of yeasted fried dough, crisp on the outside, almost hollow and chewy within, eaten hot from the oil-drenched paper bags of street vendors in the medina. Sfenj are not donuts — the dough is wetter, stickier, and more elastic, made simply from flour, water, yeast, and salt, with nothing to sweeten it before frying. The sweetness comes after: they are served with a generous drizzle of miel de azahar (orange blossom honey from Andalucía's orange groves, pale gold and intensely floral) and eaten immediately, before they lose their crispness and warmth. In Melilla, sfenj are the breakfast of the medina quarter — eaten at the squat benches of the souk at dawn, washed down with mint tea or black coffee, the smell of orange blossoms and hot oil announcing the start of another day between two continents.
ingredients: 3/4 cup (180 ml) warm water (approximately — add gradually)
Neutral oil for deep-frying (canola, sunflower, or light olive oil)
Cinnamon sugar for optional dusting (1/4 cup granulated sugar + 1/2 tsp cinnamon)
steps: In a large bowl, combine the flour, yeast, and salt. Add the warm water gradually while mixing with your fingers or a dough hook — the dough should be very wet, sticky, and elastic, much wetter than bread dough. Knead (or beat with a dough hook on medium-high) for 8–10 minutes until the dough is smooth and stretchy, forming long elastic threads when pulled. Cover and rise in a warm place for 1 to 1.5 hours until doubled and very puffy with bubbles on the surface.
Heat 3 inches (8 cm) of oil in a wide, heavy pot to 350°F (175°C). The oil must be deep enough for the sfenj to float freely.

To shape: Oil your hands generously — the dough is very sticky. Pull off a golf-ball-sized piece of dough. Using both oiled hands, flatten the ball between your palms and poke a hole through the center with your thumb, stretching the hole to about 1.5 inches (4 cm). The ring will be irregular and imperfect — this is authentic.

Slide the ring immediately into the hot oil. Fry 2–3 at a time for 3–4 minutes, turning once, until golden-amber on both sides. The sfenj should puff dramatically as they fry. Drain briefly on paper towels.

Serve immediately while hot: drizzle generously with orange blossom honey, or dip in honey and eat hot. Optionally roll in cinnamon sugar instead of or alongside the honey. Sfenj must be eaten fresh — within minutes of frying — while the exterior is still crackling.

Murcia.description: Murcia's silky vegetable scramble: courgettes and onions cooked very slowly in olive oil until meltingly soft, then mixed with beaten eggs and gently scrambled until just set—creamy, never dry. Zarangollo is the essence of Murcian huerta (garden) cooking: the simplest ingredients, the maximum patience. Every grandmother in the Segura valley has her own version—some add peppers, others insist on only courgette and onion. All agree the eggs must be barely set.
steps: Heat the olive oil in a wide, heavy skillet over medium-low heat. Add the onions and cook very slowly, 15 minutes, until completely translucent and sweet. Do not brown.
Add the courgettes. Season with salt. Continue cooking slowly, stirring occasionally, 15–20 minutes more until the courgettes are very soft and almost melting into the onions.

Reduce heat to the lowest setting. Pour the beaten eggs over the vegetables. Stir gently with a wooden spoon, folding and lifting, until the eggs are just barely set—creamy curds, not dry scramble. This takes 3–4 minutes. Remove from heat while still slightly wet; the residual heat finishes the cooking.
Serve immediately in the pan, or at room temperature on a plate. In Murcia, zarangollo is eaten with crusty bread as a tapa or light supper.

drink.description: Cartagena's legendary layered coffee cocktail: condensed milk, brandy, Licor 43, espresso, and a cinnamon stick, served in a small glass so you can see the layers. The Asiático was invented at Bar Pedrín in the 1940s and is now Cartagena's official drink. Every bar in the port city makes its own version, but the layers are non-negotiable.
steps: Pour condensed milk into a small glass. Slowly add brandy over the back of a spoon to layer.
Add Licor 43 as the next layer. Then gently pour the espresso.
Garnish with a cinnamon stick, a twist of lemon peel, and a few coffee beans floating on top. Do not stir—admire, then drink.

dessert.description: The Paparajote is Murcia's most singular, irreplaceable, beloved, and completely unique dessert — and one of the great eccentric sweets of the world. They are batter-fried lemon tree leaves. Let that settle. Fresh, smooth lemon tree leaves (Citrus limon) are dipped in a sweetened, cinnamon-scented batter of flour, eggs, and lemon zest and fried in olive oil until the batter puffs golden and crisp around the leaf. They are served hot, dusted in powdered sugar and cinnamon — and you eat the batter only, stripping it from the leaf with your teeth, discarding the leaf itself (which is not edible). The leaf is merely the carrier, the mold, the soul — its perfume permeates every molecule of batter, giving it a citrus fragrance unlike anything that can be achieved with lemon juice or zest alone. The paparajote is Murcia's invention and Murcia's to keep. No other region makes them. They appear at the great spring festival of the Bando de la Huerta, eaten in the streets by thousands of people in traditional huertano costume.
ingredients: 20–25 fresh lemon tree leaves, each about 3 inches (8 cm) long (washed and dried thoroughly)
1/2 cup (120 ml) cold sparkling water or regular cold water
Powdered sugar and ground cinnamon mixed for serving
steps: Ensure the lemon leaves are completely clean and bone dry — any moisture will cause dangerous oil splatter. Pat dry with towels and let air-dry for 30 minutes if needed.

Make the batter: Whisk together the flour, baking powder, granulated sugar, salt, lemon zest, and cinnamon in a large bowl. Make a well in the center. Add the eggs and cold sparkling water and whisk from the center out until a smooth, somewhat thick batter forms — about the consistency of a pancake batter.
Heat 2 inches (5 cm) of olive oil in a wide skillet or pot to 350°F (175°C). Prepare a large plate lined with paper towels.
