Working with one leaf at a time, hold it by its stem and dip it into the batter, turning to coat both sides and the edges generously. Let any excess drip off.

Lower the coated leaf into the hot oil, releasing it away from you. Fry for 2–3 minutes, turning once, until the batter is golden-brown and puffed on both sides. Remove with a slotted spoon and drain on paper towels.

Serve immediately — they must be eaten hot. Dust generously with the powdered sugar and cinnamon mixture. Warn your guests: eat only the batter — tear it away from the leaf and discard the leaf. The fragrance of lemon tree that lingers in the batter is the entire point.

Navarra.dish: Pimientos del Piquillo Rellenos de Bacalao
Navarra.description: Navarra's most refined tapa: piquillo peppers (sweet, pointed red peppers roasted over wood fires and hand-peeled in the town of Lodosa) stuffed with a brandade of salt cod, béchamel, and garlic, then baked in a light tomato sauce. The piquillos are a PDO product unique to Navarra—nowhere else grows them with the same smoky sweetness. The salt cod filling is the Basque-Navarrese obsession with bacalao meeting French finesse.
ingredients: 3/4 lb salt cod, soaked 48 hours (340 g)
Piquillo pepper sauce (see Chef's Essentials below)
Béchamel for filling (see Chef's Essentials below)

steps: Melt butter, whisk in flour, cook 1 minute. Gradually add milk, whisking constantly.
Cook until thick. Season with nutmeg, salt, and pepper.
Heat olive oil. Sauté garlic and tomato 5 minutes. Add piquillos.
Blend until smooth. Season with salt.
Poach the soaked salt cod in simmering water (do not boil) for 10 minutes. Drain, remove skin and bones, and flake the flesh finely.
Heat olive oil, cook garlic until fragrant. Add the flaked cod and stir 2 minutes. Add the béchamel and mix until you have a thick, creamy filling. Season.
Carefully stuff each piquillo pepper with the cod-béchamel mixture (use a small spoon or piping bag). Arrange in a baking dish.
Pour the piquillo pepper sauce over the stuffed peppers. Bake at 375°F (190°C) for 15 minutes until heated through and the sauce bubbles.
Serve 3 per person as a starter.

drink.description: Navarra's iconic sloe berry liqueur: endrinas (wild sloe berries picked in the Navarran hills in autumn) macerated in aguardiente with coffee beans and a vanilla pod for months until the spirit turns deep ruby and tastes of plums, almonds, and wild hedgerow. Pacharán is THE digestif of Navarra and the Basque Country—every family has bottles aging in the cellar.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) pacharán (Zoco, Etxeko, or homemade)
steps: Serve cold, neat in a small glass, or over a single ice cube.
Sip slowly after a meal. The flavor of wild sloes and anise should fill the mouth.

dessert.description: Cuajada is the oldest dairy dessert in the Basque and Navarrese tradition — a preparation of such antiquity that the wooden kaikua (a vessel carved from a single piece of wood in which it was traditionally made) has been found in Neolithic sites in the Pyrenean foothills. The technique is elemental: fresh sheep's milk is warmed, then curdled with a drop of animal rennet — the same enzyme that makes cheese, but used here only briefly so the milk sets into a trembling, snow-white, barely-firm custard. It is sweet, milky, faintly tart, with the unmistakable lanolin richness of sheep's milk from Navarra's Latxa breed, the same sheep that give Roncal and Idiazabal their cheeses. Served in small clay or wooden vessels, topped with a generous pour of miel de romero — rosemary honey from the sun-baked mountains of Navarra, golden-amber and intensely aromatic — and a scatter of crushed walnuts, the cuajada is prehistoric simplicity brought to the table: a dessert that tastes of mountains, grass, and unhurried time.
ingredients: 4 cups (960 ml) full-fat sheep's milk (or whole cow's milk if sheep's milk is unavailable — the flavor is different but the technique works)
1/2 tsp liquid animal rennet (available from cheesemaking suppliers) or 1/4 tsp powdered rennet
2 tbsp cold water (to dilute the rennet)
4–6 tbsp Navarrese honey (rosemary, thyme, or lavender honey, the darker and more aromatic the better)
1/2 cup (60 g) walnuts, lightly toasted and roughly chopped
steps: Dilute the rennet in the 2 tbsp cold water and stir to dissolve. Have 4–6 small clay bowls, individual ramekins, or small glasses ready and warmed by rinsing with hot water and drying.

Heat the sheep's milk in a saucepan over medium-low heat to exactly 100–104°F (38–40°C) — use a thermometer. This is blood temperature, the same as a lamb's stomach. At this temperature the rennet will work perfectly. Above 110°F (43°C) it is destroyed; below 95°F (35°C) it works very slowly.
Remove the pan from heat. Stir in the diluted rennet quickly and thoroughly for 30 seconds. Add the salt if using.

Pour immediately and quickly into the prepared bowls — work fast, as the rennet begins acting immediately. Do not stir once poured. Place the bowls in a warm spot (a turned-off oven with the light on, or near a warm stove) and do not disturb for 30–40 minutes until the cuajada is set — it should tremble as a whole unit when shaken, not slosh like liquid.

Once set, cover each bowl with plastic wrap and refrigerate 2–4 hours or overnight — the texture becomes cleaner and firmer with chilling. Serve cold, in their individual vessels, topped with 1 tbsp of honey per bowl and a generous scatter of toasted walnuts.

Pais Vasco.description: The great tuna-and-potato stew of the Basque fishermen: chunks of bonito del norte (white tuna) braised with potatoes, peppers, onion, and tomato in a paprika-scented broth. Marmitako means 'from the pot' (marmita) and was cooked aboard Basque tuna boats in the Bay of Biscay during the bonito season. The potatoes must be 'cascadas' (broken, not sliced) so they release starch and thicken the broth. The tuna is added at the very end and barely cooked so it stays silky.
ingredients: 1.5 lbs fresh bonito or albacore tuna, cut into 1.5-inch chunks (680 g)
2 lbs potatoes, peeled and broken into chunks (cascadas) (900 g)
2 green Italian frying peppers or 1 green bell pepper, diced
1 dried choricero pepper, soaked and flesh scraped (or 2 tsp pimentón)
3 cups fish stock or water (720 ml)
steps: Heat olive oil in a wide casserole. Sauté the onion and green peppers over medium heat until soft, 10 minutes. Add garlic, cook 1 minute.
Add the grated tomato and choricero pepper flesh (or pimentón). Cook 5 minutes until the tomato darkens.
Add the broken potatoes. Stir to coat. Add the fish stock—it should just cover the potatoes. Bring to a simmer.
Cook 20–25 minutes until the potatoes are tender and starting to break apart, thickening the broth.

Season the tuna chunks with salt. Nestle them into the stew. Cover, remove from heat, and let the residual heat cook the tuna for 5–8 minutes. The tuna should be pink and silky in the center, never overcooked.
Serve in the casserole, at the table, with crusty bread.

drink.description: The Basque Country's most democratic cocktail: cheap red wine and Coca-Cola, mixed 1:1 over ice. Invented (or at least named) at the fiestas of Getxo in 1972 when a batch of bad wine was rescued by mixing it with cola. Kalimotxo is the drink of every Basque fiesta, gaupasa (all-night party), and txosna (festival bar). It sounds terrible. It tastes perfect.
ingredients: 4 oz (120 ml) cheap young red wine
steps: Fill a tall glass with ice.
Pour wine and cola simultaneously (or wine first, then cola).
Add a lemon slice if you're feeling fancy. Drink at a Basque fiesta.

dessert.description: Goxua (sweet in Euskera, the Basque language) is Vitoria-Gasteiz's claim to dessert greatness — a layered creation of such structural beauty and flavor harmony that it has become beloved across all of the Basque Country. From bottom to top: a layer of crisp, soaked sponge cake; a thick, cool dome of freshly whipped cream; a generous pour of rich egg custard (crema pastelera); and on top, a mirror of amber caramel, still crackling from the blowtorch. Every element is present for a reason. The cake soaks up whatever liquid it's brushed with — Basque cider, or rum — making it tender and alcoholic at the base. The cream is the cool cloud. The custard is the warmth. The caramel is the drama. Eaten with a spoon that cuts through all four layers at once, it is one of the most satisfying desserts in Spain — proof that the Basque kitchen, famous for its avant-garde alta cocina, never forgot how to make something that simply, fundamentally, deeply makes people happy.
ingredients: For the sponge base: 4 ladyfinger cookies per serving (or a layer of thinly sliced génoise/sponge cake), soaked in 2 tbsp apple cider or rum mixed with 1 tbsp sugar
For the whipped cream: 1 1/2 cups (360 ml) heavy cream, very cold, 2 tbsp powdered sugar, 1/2 tsp vanilla extract
For the pastry cream: 2 cups (480 ml) whole milk, 4 egg yolks, 1/2 cup (100 g) granulated sugar, 3 tbsp cornstarch, 1 tbsp unsalted butter, 1 tsp vanilla extract
4–6 tsp granulated sugar for the caramel top
steps: Make the pastry cream: Heat the milk until steaming. Whisk egg yolks with sugar and cornstarch in a bowl until smooth. Slowly pour the hot milk into the yolk mixture, whisking. Return to the saucepan and cook over medium heat, stirring constantly, until very thick and bubbling. Cook 1 minute more. Remove from heat; stir in butter and vanilla. Press plastic wrap directly on the surface and refrigerate until cold.
Whip the cream: Beat the cold cream with powdered sugar and vanilla to firm (not stiff) peaks. Refrigerate until assembly.
Make the cider soak: Mix apple cider or rum with sugar, stir to dissolve.

Assemble (in individual serving glasses or large wine glasses): Lay 2–3 ladyfingers in the bottom, brush or pour the cider soak over them — they should be moistened but not soggy. Pipe or spoon a generous dome of whipped cream over the cake layer (it should be the tallest, most visually prominent layer). Spoon a generous layer of cold pastry cream over the whipped cream.

Refrigerate assembled goxuas for at least 2 hours or up to 24 hours. Just before serving, sprinkle 1 tsp granulated sugar evenly over the pastry cream top of each goxua. Caramelize with a blowtorch until amber and crackling. Serve immediately — the contrast between the cold layers and the hot caramel is essential.

Valencia.description: Valencia's ancient fisherman's stew from the Albufera lagoon: freshwater eels braised in a pounded sauce of garlic, dried ñora peppers, pimentón, and almonds. All i pebre means 'garlic and pepper' in Valencian, and the dish predates paella as the signature food of the Albufera wetlands south of Valencia city. If you can't find eel, monkfish or firm white fish works—but the Valencians will judge you.
ingredients: 2 lbs fresh eel, cleaned and cut into 2-inch pieces (or monkfish) (900 g)
2 dried ñora peppers, soaked 20 minutes, flesh scraped
2 cups fish stock or water (480 ml)
steps: Heat olive oil in a wide clay casserole (cazuela) or skillet. Fry the garlic cloves and almonds until golden. Remove and set aside.
In the same oil, briefly sear the eel pieces on all sides. Remove.
In a mortar (or blender), pound the fried garlic, almonds, ñora pepper flesh, pimentón, and cayenne into a paste (this is the all i pebre). Thin with a splash of the fish stock.
Add the paste to the cazuela. Pour in the remaining fish stock. Bring to a simmer, stirring.
Return the eel pieces. Simmer gently 15–20 minutes until the eel is tender and the sauce is thick and rust-colored. Season with salt.
Serve in the cazuela with crusty bread to mop up the sauce.

drink.description: Valencia's party cocktail: cava (or champagne), fresh Valencian orange juice, vodka, and gin, served in a large clay pitcher at every Valencian nightspot. Invented at the Café Madrid in Valencia in 1959, it is dangerously easy to drink and responsible for more broken curfews than any other Spanish cocktail.
ingredients: 3 oz (90 ml) fresh orange juice (Valencia oranges if possible)
2 oz (60 ml) cava or dry sparkling wine
steps: Combine orange juice, vodka, gin, and sugar in a pitcher or shaker. Stir until sugar dissolves.
Add ice. Top with cava. Stir gently once.
Serve in wine glasses or clay cups. In Valencia, this comes in pitchers for the table.

dessert.description: The Arnadí is Valencia's most ancient dessert, with roots stretching back to the Moorish kingdoms of al-Andalus — its name is derived from the Arabic 'alrnadi' (offering). It is made during the Easter season in Valencia and the Valencian interior, and it remains almost unknown outside the region, which makes encountering it feel like a discovery. It begins with sweet calabaza de invierno (winter squash or pumpkin) from the Valencian huerta, baked or boiled until very soft, then drained, squeezed absolutely dry, and combined with ground almonds, sugar, egg yolks, and cinnamon into a dense, fragrant paste. This paste is shaped into tall cones or pyramids on individual almond leaves — by hand, building each shape slowly — then studded with almonds and candied pine nuts pressed into the surface, and baked until golden and fragrant. The Arnadí is a prayer made edible: shaped like a mountain or a flame, offering sweetness and fragrance to mark the return of spring.
ingredients: 2 lbs (900 g) butternut squash or sweet pumpkin, peeled, seeded, and cubed
For decoration: 1/4 cup (35 g) whole blanched almonds, 2 tbsp pine nuts
Powdered sugar for dusting after baking
steps: Roast the squash: Preheat oven to 400°F (200°C). Place squash pieces on a baking sheet and roast for 30–40 minutes until very tender. Let cool.

Drain the squash: This step is absolutely critical. Place the cooked squash in a clean cloth or cheesecloth and squeeze as hard as you can to remove every drop of moisture. The squash must be completely dry. Measure: you need 2 cups (about 450 g) of very dry, mashed squash pulp. If still moist, spread on a clean cloth and let air-dry for 30 minutes more.

In a large bowl, combine the dry squash purée, ground almonds, sugar, egg yolks, cinnamon, cloves, lemon zest, and salt. Mix thoroughly until a stiff, cohesive paste forms. Taste and adjust sugar if needed. Refrigerate for 1 hour to firm up.

Preheat the oven to 375°F (190°C). Line a baking sheet with parchment. Using wet or lightly oiled hands, divide the paste into 8–10 portions. Shape each into a tall, pointed cone or pyramid about 3 inches (8 cm) high. Press whole almonds in a spiral around the cone, and nestle a pine nut between each almond.

Bake for 20–25 minutes until golden amber on the surface. Cool on the tray. Dust lightly with powdered sugar just before serving. Serve at room temperature — the arnadí keeps well for 2 days at room temperature.

EST.description: A peasant dish from the Mulgimaa region that conquered the nation. A rustic mash of barley and potatoes, topped with fried onions and bacon, representing the hearty soul of Estonian cuisine.
steps: Put barley in a pot with water. Place potatoes on top. Do not stir.
Boil until both are soft and water is mostly absorbed.
Mash everything together with a splash of hot milk and butter.
Fry bacon and onions until crispy.
Serve the mash topped generously with the bacon-onion mix.

drink.description: A classic Estonian serve: hot coffee spiked with Vana Tallinn liqueur and topped with cream.
ingredients: 2 tbsp lightly whipped cream (or float heavy cream)
steps: Warm a heatproof glass or mug with hot water, then discard the water.
Add Vana Tallinn (and sugar if using).
Pour in hot coffee and stir.
Gently float whipped cream on top (spoon it over the back of a spoon).
Serve hot; sip through the cream.

dessert.description: Estonia's ancient grain dessert reborn: a velvety mousse of roasted flour—barley, rye, oat, and pea ground together—mixed with tangy buttermilk or kefir and sweetened with wild honey. Kama predates written Estonian history, a staple of peasant survival that has become a symbol of national identity. The flour is nutty and deeply earthy, the dairy sharp and alive, the honey a golden bridge between them. Spooned into bowls and topped with fresh berries in summer, it tastes like the Estonian countryside distilled into a single, humble, profoundly satisfying bite.
ingredients: 1 cup (120 g) kama flour (pre-mixed roasted barley, rye, oat, and pea flour)
1 1/2 cups (360 ml) cold buttermilk or kefir
3 tbsp (45 ml) honey, plus more to taste
1/2 cup (120 ml) heavy cream, whipped to soft peaks (optional, for richness)
Fresh berries (blueberries, lingonberries, or strawberries) for serving
steps: Place the kama flour in a large bowl. Pour in the cold buttermilk or kefir gradually, whisking constantly to prevent lumps.
Add the honey and salt. Whisk until smooth and the mixture reaches a thick, mousse-like consistency. Taste and add more honey if desired.
For a lighter texture, fold in the whipped cream gently until just combined.
Spoon into individual bowls or glasses. Top with fresh berries.
Chill 15–30 minutes before serving, or enjoy immediately. In Estonia, kama is eaten for breakfast, dessert, or as a snack—there are no rules.

ETH.description: A spicy, slow-cooked chicken stew that is the hallmark of Ethiopian cooking.
ingredients: 1 Whole Chicken, cut into 12 pieces (skin removed)
steps: In a heavy pot, cook the onion puree without oil for 45-60 minutes until dry and starting to brown.
Add the Niter Kibbeh. Fry for 10 mins.
Add Berbere spice. Cook for 15 mins (adding splash of water if burning). This forms the 'Kulet' base.
Add chicken pieces. Simmer on low for 45 minutes until tender.
Score the boiled eggs and add them to the sauce for the last 10 minutes.
Serve hot atop a platter of Injera bread (fermented teff flatbread).

drink.description: An Ethiopian honey wine traditionally fermented and lightly spiced (often with gesho). This is a simplified home style.
ingredients: 1/4 tsp wine yeast (or active dry yeast for a rustic ferment)
Optional: a small piece of ginger or a strip of citrus peel
steps: Dissolve honey in water in a sanitized jar.
Add yeast and optional flavorings/raisins.
Cover with an airlock (or a loose lid) and ferment at room temperature until lightly fermented (several days).
Chill, strain if needed, and serve. (Traditional tej uses gesho; this is a simplified approximation.)

dessert.description: Ethiopia's irresistible snack-dessert: tiny nuggets of dough seasoned with berbere spice, rolled by hand, and baked until golden, crunchy, and deeply aromatic. Dabo Kolo means 'roasted bread' in Amharic, and every Ethiopian household has a jar on the counter, refilled constantly because it vanishes as fast as it appears. The nuggets are barely sweet, warmly spiced, and impossibly addictive—each piece a perfect, crunchy morsel of caramelized dough and toasted spice. Served at coffee ceremonies, holidays, and every moment in between.
ingredients: 1/4 cup (60 ml) water, plus more as needed
steps: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Line a large baking sheet with parchment paper.
In a large bowl, combine the flour, sugar, berbere, salt, cinnamon, and cardamom. Mix well.
Add the oil and mix with your hands until the flour resembles coarse crumbs. Add water gradually, kneading until a firm, non-sticky dough forms. Add more water by the teaspoon if needed.
Pinch off small pieces of dough and roll into thin ropes about 1/4 inch (6 mm) thick. Cut into 1/2-inch (1 cm) pieces.
Spread the pieces in a single layer on the baking sheet. Bake 15–20 minutes, shaking the pan halfway through, until golden brown and completely dry and crunchy.
Cool completely on the pan—they will crisp further as they cool. Store in an airtight container for up to 2 weeks (if they last that long).
Mix all spices thoroughly.
Toast gently in a dry pan for 30–60 seconds to bloom (optional).
Cool completely and store airtight up to 2–3 months.
Melt butter over very low heat. Add onion, garlic, ginger, and spices.
Simmer very gently 20–30 minutes; do not let it brown.
Strain through a fine mesh (or cheesecloth) into a jar.
Cool and refrigerate. Use within 2–3 weeks (or freeze).

FIN.description: Karelian Pies. These iconic rye crust boats filled with savory rice porridge are a protected cultural heritage. They are baked at high heat and traditionally brushed with egg butter.
ingredients: For crust: 2 cups rye flour (240 g)
For crust: 1/2 cup all-purpose flour (65 g)
For crust: 3/4 cup warm water (180 ml), plus as needed
Rice porridge filling (see preliminary step), cooled
To finish: 2 tbsp melted butter (28 g)
To finish: 1/4 cup warm milk (60 ml) (optional for brushing)
Egg butter (see preliminary step), for serving
steps: Make rice porridge filling and cool completely (see preliminary step).
Make dough: mix rye flour, all-purpose flour, and salt. Add water and knead briefly into a firm dough (it should be pliable, not sticky). Rest 10 minutes.
Divide dough into 12 pieces. Roll each into a thin oval (about 1/16 inch).
Spoon a line of cooled rice porridge down the center of each oval and spread, leaving a border.
Crimp edges upward in small pleats to form the classic open boat shape.
Bake on a hot stone or sheet at 500°F/260°C for 10–12 minutes until the crust is firm and lightly browned.
Brush hot pies with melted butter (optionally mixed with warm milk) to soften.
Serve warm with egg butter.

drink.description: Finland’s iconic “long drink” (originally popularized around the 1952 Helsinki Olympics): gin lengthened with grapefruit soda—refreshing and dangerously easy.
ingredients: 6 oz grapefruit soda (180 ml) (or homemade quick grapefruit soda)
1/2 cup grapefruit juice (120 ml) (fresh or bottled)
1 tbsp simple syrup (15 ml) (or 2 tsp sugar)
steps: Stir grapefruit juice and simple syrup (or sugar) until dissolved.
Top with club soda and stir gently.
Use immediately as the “grapefruit soda” component.
Fill a highball with ice.
Pour in gin.
Top with grapefruit soda (or the quick homemade substitute).
Stir gently and garnish with grapefruit if you like.
Serve cold.

dessert.description: Finnish Blueberry Pie—the taste of Finnish summer captured in a single golden-crusted tart. A buttery, crumbly shortcrust base cradles a generous tumble of wild Arctic blueberries (mustikka), their deep indigo juice staining the pastry purple at the edges. The berries are barely sweetened, letting their intense, slightly tart flavor shine. Baked until the crust is golden and the filling bubbles at the rim, then served warm with a pour of creamy vanilla sauce (vaniljakastike) that pools around each slice. In Finland, mustikkapiirakka is the reward for a morning spent in the forest with stained fingers and a full bucket.
ingredients: 1/2 cup (1 stick / 115 g) cold unsalted butter, cubed
3 cups (450 g) fresh or frozen wild blueberries (do not thaw if frozen)
1/4 cup (50 g) granulated sugar for the filling
2 tbsp (16 g) potato starch or cornstarch
steps: Make the crust: combine flour, 1/3 cup sugar, and salt. Cut in the cold butter with your fingers or a pastry cutter until pea-sized crumbs form. Add the egg yolk and water, mixing until the dough just comes together. Press into a 9-inch (23 cm) tart pan with a removable bottom, pushing evenly across the base and up the sides. Chill 20 minutes.
Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C).
Toss the blueberries with 1/4 cup sugar, potato starch, and lemon juice. Pour into the chilled crust, spreading evenly.
Bake 35–45 minutes until the crust is golden and the berry filling is bubbling. If using frozen berries, it may take a few minutes longer.
Cool 15 minutes before removing the tart ring. Serve warm with vanilla sauce (vaniljakastike) or vanilla ice cream.
Rinse rice briefly. Bring water to a simmer and stir in rice.
Simmer 10 minutes, stirring occasionally, until most water is absorbed.
Add milk and salt. Cook on very low heat 35–45 minutes, stirring often, until thick and creamy.
Stir in butter if using. Cool completely before filling pies.
Mash butter with a fork until spreadable.
Fold in chopped eggs and a pinch of salt.
Chill or serve at cool room temperature.

FLK.dish: Roast Mutton with Diddle Dee Jam
FLK.description: A dish born of the rugged South Atlantic landscape. With sheep outnumbering people, mutton is the staple, roasted simply and paired with the unique tartness of Diddle Dee berries, a native heath shrub that cuts through the rich meat.
ingredients: Diddle Dee Jam (or Cranberry/Redcurrant jelly substitute)
steps: Preheat oven to 350°F (180°C).
Rub mutton with garlic, rosemary, salt, and pepper.
Roast for 20 mins per lb plus 20 mins extra.
Add potatoes to the roasting pan in the last hour to cook in the fat.
Serve the roast slices with the tart jam to cut through the richness.

drink.description: A common everyday drink on the Falkland Islands is tea (British influence).
steps: Steep tea 3–5 minutes.
Add milk/sugar if desired.

dessert.description: The Falkland Islands' beloved steamed sponge pudding—a British tradition kept alive in the windswept South Atlantic. 'Smoko' is Falklands slang for a tea break, and 'duff' is the old English word for pudding. A golden, pillowy sponge is steamed until moist and tender, with a slick of strawberry or raspberry jam melting into the base that becomes a sticky, ruby glaze when turned out. Served with a generous pour of hot custard, it is comfort incarnate: the kind of pudding that warms you from the inside out after a day spent battling Falklands wind.
ingredients: 1/2 cup (1 stick / 115 g) unsalted butter, softened, plus more for greasing
1 1/2 cups (190 g) self-rising flour (or all-purpose flour with 2 tsp baking powder)
3 tbsp (60 g) strawberry or raspberry jam
steps: Generously butter a 1-quart (1 L) pudding basin or heatproof bowl. Spoon the jam into the bottom of the basin.

Cream the butter and sugar until light and fluffy, about 3 minutes. Beat in the eggs one at a time. Fold in the flour gently, then stir in the milk and vanilla until you have a smooth, dropping-consistency batter.
Pour the batter over the jam in the basin. Cover tightly with a pleated sheet of buttered parchment paper and foil, tying securely with kitchen string.

Place the basin in a large pot on a trivet or folded towel. Pour boiling water halfway up the sides of the basin. Cover the pot and steam over low heat for 1 1/2 to 2 hours, topping up water as needed, until a skewer inserted into the center comes out clean.
Remove from pot and rest 5 minutes. Run a knife around the edge and invert onto a serving plate—the jam will cascade down the sides.
Serve immediately with hot custard poured generously over the top.

FRA.description: A classic French boiled dinner: beef and marrow bones simmered gently with aromatics, then vegetables added so everything finishes tender. Traditionally served in two courses—first the broth, then the meat and vegetables with mustard, cornichons, and flaky salt.
ingredients: 3 1/2 lb beef for stewing (mix of chuck/shank/brisket), cut into large chunks (1.6 kg)
12 cups cold water (2.8 L), plus more if needed
2 tbsp kosher salt, plus more to taste
2 leeks, cleaned and cut into 3-inch pieces
4 carrots, peeled and cut into 3-inch pieces
1 bouquet garni (parsley stems + thyme + bay leaf, tied)
steps: Put beef and bones in a large pot. Cover with cold water (about 12 cups).
Bring just to a simmer over medium heat. As foam rises, skim thoroughly for a clear broth.
Add salt, onion with cloves, garlic, bouquet garni, and peppercorns. Keep at a bare simmer (tiny bubbles), partially covered, 2–2 1/2 hours.
Add leeks, carrots, turnips, and celery. Continue simmering 45–60 minutes, until vegetables are tender and beef is very tender.
Taste broth and adjust salt. Remove bouquet garni and onion.
Serve traditionally in two parts: ladle broth into bowls first, then plate the meat/bones and vegetables. Offer mustard, cornichons, and coarse salt at the table.

drink.description: A French apéritif: crème de cassis topped with Champagne (or Crémant). Lightly fruity, dry, and celebratory.
ingredients: 1/2 oz crème de cassis (blackcurrant liqueur) (15 ml)
steps: Chill a flute or small wine glass.
Pour in crème de cassis.
Top slowly with Champagne.
Give a single gentle stir to combine.
Serve immediately.

dessert.description: The Napoleon. A thousand leaves. Three layers of puff pastry baked until shatteringly crisp and deeply caramelized, sandwiching two layers of silky crème pâtissière perfumed with real vanilla. The top is glazed in a mirror of white fondant with precise chevron lines of dark chocolate, feathered with the tip of a knife into the iconic marbled pattern. Every bite is an architectural event — the pastry cracks and shatters, the cream yields, and the fondant snaps. Mille-feuille is the ultimate test of a French pâtissier's skill: the pastry must be dry and crisp (never soggy), the cream must be thick enough to hold but silky enough to melt, and the whole structure must be assembled moments before serving so the layers stay distinct. It is France's most iconic pastry — more technically demanding than a croissant, more elegant than a tart, and the dessert that every Parisian boulangerie is judged by.
ingredients: 1 lb (450 g) all-butter puff pastry (homemade or high-quality store-bought), thawed if frozen
1 vanilla bean, split and scraped (or 2 tsp pure vanilla extract)
2 tbsp (28 g) unsalted butter, cold, cut into pieces
steps: Heat milk and vanilla bean (pod and seeds) in a saucepan until just simmering. Remove from heat, cover, and steep 10 minutes.
In a bowl, whisk egg yolks, sugar, and cornstarch until thick and pale.
Gradually pour the hot milk into the egg mixture, whisking constantly to temper. Return everything to the saucepan.
Cook over medium heat, whisking vigorously and constantly, until the cream thickens and comes to a boil — it will suddenly seize up and become very thick. Cook 1 minute more.
Remove from heat. Whisk in the cold butter until melted and smooth. Press plastic wrap directly onto the surface to prevent a skin. Refrigerate until completely cold (at least 2 hours).
Mix powdered sugar with just enough warm water to make a thick, pourable glaze (it should coat the back of a spoon thickly).
Melt the dark chocolate separately. Fill a small piping bag or zip-lock bag with the corner snipped.

Roll the puff pastry into a rectangle about 1/8 inch (3 mm) thick. Dock thoroughly with a fork (every inch). Place on a parchment-lined baking sheet. Top with another sheet of parchment and another baking sheet (to keep it flat). Refrigerate 30 minutes.
Bake at 400°F (200°C) for 15 minutes, then remove the top sheet, dust with powdered sugar, and bake 10–12 more minutes until deeply golden and caramelized. Cool completely.
Trim the edges with a serrated knife to make a clean rectangle. Cut into 3 equal strips — these are your pastry layers.
Whisk the chilled crème pâtissière until smooth. Transfer to a piping bag fitted with a round tip.
Place the first pastry strip on a board. Pipe neat rows of cream across the full surface. Top with the second pastry strip. Pipe another layer of cream. Place the third strip on top, flat side up.

Spread the white fondant glaze over the top strip in a thin, even layer. Immediately pipe thin parallel lines of melted chocolate across the fondant. Drag a toothpick or knife tip through the lines in alternating directions to create the classic feathered chevron pattern.

Refrigerate 30 minutes to set. Cut into individual portions with a sharp serrated knife using a gentle sawing motion — do not press down or the layers will crush. Serve within 2 hours of assembly for maximum crispness.

Auvergne-Rhône-Alpes.description: A Savoyard gratin of potatoes, reblochon, lardons, and onions. Technique: waxy potatoes hold their shape; the cheese is cut through the middle so it melts into the layers; white wine adds acidity to cut the fat. Served blistering hot from the oven.
ingredients: 2 lbs (900 g) waxy potatoes (e.g. Charlotte, Ratte), unpeeled, scrubbed
1 whole reblochon (about 14 oz / 400 g), rind on, at room temperature
6 oz (170 g) smoked bacon lardons or thick-cut bacon cut into 1/2-inch dice
1/2 cup (120 ml) dry white wine (e.g. Apremont or other Savoie)
2 tbsp (30 g) unsalted butter, for the dish and dotting
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
steps: Mise en place: Boil the whole potatoes in well-salted water until a knife meets slight resistance (about 20–25 min). Drain; when cool enough to handle, peel and slice into 1/4-inch (6 mm) rounds. Do not overwork or they will break.
In a large skillet over medium heat, render the lardons without added fat until golden and some fat has released, 8–10 min. Transfer lardons to a plate; leave about 1 tbsp fat in the pan.
In the same pan, sauté the onions in the bacon fat until soft and lightly golden, 10–12 min. Season with a pinch of salt and pepper.

Butter a 9-by-13-inch (or equivalent) gratin dish. Spread half the potato slices in a layer; season lightly. Scatter half the onions and half the lardons. Repeat with remaining potatoes, onions, and lardons. Drizzle the wine evenly over the top.

Cut the reblochon in half horizontally through the middle (so you have two rounds). Place both halves rind-side up on top of the potatoes, or cut into pieces and distribute. Dot with butter. Bake in the center of a preheated 375°F (190°C) oven 25–35 min until the cheese is melted and bubbling and the top is golden. Rest 5 min; serve hot with cornichons and a green salad.

drink.description: A cocktail from the Alpine ski lodges: génépi (a wild herb liqueur from the Alps) shaken with fresh lemon and honey syrup. Herbal, sweet-tart, and warming after a day on the slopes.
ingredients: 1/2 oz (15 ml) honey syrup (1:1 honey and warm water)
steps: Shake génépi, lemon juice, and honey syrup with ice.
Strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with a thyme sprig.

dessert.description: The Gâteau de Savoie is one of France's oldest cakes, born in the 14th century in the Savoyard court of Amadeus VI — a cake so light it was said to float on air. Made without butter, its extraordinary lift comes entirely from six eggs beaten with sugar to the ribbon stage, then gently folded with potato starch and flour. The batter goes into a tall, fluted mold that creates those elegant, cathedral-like ridges. The result is impossibly airy — a pale gold sponge with an almost weightless crumb that dissolves on the tongue. Traditionally dusted with nothing more than a snowfall of powdered sugar, it is served with fresh fruit, jam, or crème anglaise in the valleys of the Alps. Every grandmother in Savoie has her own version — some add lemon zest, some a spoon of vanilla — but the soul is always the same: egg, patience, and the long gentle hands of the mountain.
ingredients: 6 large eggs, separated, at room temperature
1/2 cup (60 g) potato starch (fécule de pommes de terre), sifted
Butter and flour for the mold
steps: Preheat the oven to 325°F (165°C). Butter a 10-inch (25 cm) tall fluted Bundt or Kugelhopf mold generously, then dust with flour, shaking out the excess. Set aside.

In a large bowl, beat the egg yolks with 1 cup (200 g) of the sugar until the mixture is very pale, thick, and falls in a wide ribbon from the whisk — at least 5 minutes by hand or 3 minutes with an electric mixer. Beat in the lemon zest and vanilla extract.

In a completely clean, dry bowl, beat the egg whites with the salt on medium speed until foamy. Gradually add the remaining 1/4 cup (50 g) of sugar and beat to firm, glossy peaks — they should hold their shape without drooping.

Sift the flour and potato starch together over the yolk mixture and fold gently with a large rubber spatula, using wide, sweeping motions from the bottom of the bowl. Before the flour is fully incorporated, add about one-third of the whites and fold in to lighten the batter.

Add the remaining whites in two additions, folding with extreme gentleness to preserve every bit of air. The batter should be smooth, pale, and voluminous. Do not overmix — a few white streaks are better than a deflated batter.
Pour gently into the prepared mold and smooth the top. Bake for 35–40 minutes until the cake is golden, springs back when lightly touched, and a skewer inserted in the center comes out clean.

Cool in the mold on a rack for 15 minutes — no longer, or it will steam and become soggy. Invert onto the rack and cool completely. Dust very generously with powdered sugar just before serving. Serve with fresh mountain berries, jam, or a light crème anglaise.

Bourgogne-Franche-Comté.description: Burgundy's iconic braise: beef chuck, lardons, pearl onions, and mushrooms in red wine. Technique: dry the meat for a proper sear; deglaze with wine and reduce; low, steady heat so the collagen breaks down without boiling. The garniture (onions and mushrooms) is cooked separately and added at the end so it keeps texture and color.
ingredients: 2 1/2 lbs (1.1 kg) beef chuck or beef bourguignon cut, cut into 2-inch (5 cm) cubes, patted very dry
6 oz (170 g) slab bacon or thick-cut bacon, cut into lardons (1/4 by 1 inch)
1 bottle (750 ml) Burgundy or other dry, fruity red wine
2 cups (480 ml) beef stock, preferably homemade or low-sodium
1 lb (450 g) pearl onions, blanched 1 min and peeled (or frozen, thawed)
10 oz (280 g) small button or cremini mushrooms, trimmed and quartered if large
1 bouquet garni (3 sprigs thyme, 2 bay leaves, 1 small stalk celery, tied in cheesecloth or leek green)
2 tbsp neutral oil or rendered bacon fat
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
steps: In a large Dutch oven over medium heat, render the lardons until golden; transfer to a plate. Leave fat in the pot (add 1 tbsp oil if needed).
Season the beef with salt and pepper. Sear in the fat in a single layer, in batches—do not crowd—until deeply browned on at least two sides, 4–5 min per batch. Transfer to the plate with the bacon.

Lower heat; add the chopped onion and carrots. Sauté until the onion is soft and starting to color, 6–8 min. Add the garlic and tomato paste; stir 1 min. Sprinkle with the flour; stir 1 min to cook the raw flour taste off.

Deglaze with the wine, scraping up all the browned bits (fond). Add the stock, bouquet garni, and a pinch of salt. Return the beef and bacon; bring to a gentle simmer. Partially cover and braise in a 325°F (165°C) oven (or on the lowest burner setting) 2 1/2–3 hours until the beef is fork-tender. Skim fat from the surface if needed.

While the beef braises: in a skillet, brown the pearl onions in a little butter until golden; add a splash of water and cover to finish softening. In the same pan, sauté the mushrooms in butter until golden. Set aside.

When the beef is tender, remove the bouquet garni. Add the pearl onions and mushrooms; simmer 10–15 min. Taste and adjust seasoning. Serve with mashed potatoes, buttered noodles, or crusty bread; garnish with chopped parsley.

drink.description: The original Kir, invented by Canon Félix Kir, mayor of Dijon: a splash of crème de cassis from Burgundy's blackcurrant bushes topped with chilled Bourgogne Aligoté white wine. The proportions matter: too much cassis and it's syrup; too little and it's just wine.
ingredients: 1/3 oz (10 ml) crème de cassis de Dijon
5 oz (150 ml) chilled Bourgogne Aligoté (or dry white Burgundy)
Blackcurrant or lemon twist for garnish (optional)
steps: Pour the crème de cassis into a wine glass.
Top slowly with well-chilled Aligoté. Do not stir—let it swirl naturally.
The color should be a blushing rosé. Sip as an apéritif.

dessert.description: Dijon's pain d'épices is not merely spiced bread — it is the edible history of a city. Since the 14th century, when the Dukes of Burgundy first received it as tribute from the spice-trade-rich Hanseatic League, it has been a Dijon obsession. True pain d'épices de Dijon uses rye flour — nutty, earthy, slightly sour — and a deep, long-aged honey (acacia or multi-floral from Burgundy's lavender and clover fields). The spice blend is ancient and complex: anise, cinnamon, ginger, cloves, nutmeg, and sometimes a whisper of cardamom or star anise. The batter rests in the mold for 24 hours before baking, a step most home cooks skip and everyone regrets. The result is a dense, dark loaf that slices cleanly, smells like winter and wine country, and keeps for two weeks wrapped in cloth. Eaten in Burgundy in thin slices spread with salted butter, layered with foie gras, or simply on its own with a glass of Burgundy's own Crème de Cassis.
ingredients: 1 cup (340 g) strong-flavored honey (buckwheat or chestnut), warmed
1 tbsp unsalted butter, melted (for the pan)
2 tbsp sliced almonds for the top (optional)
steps: The day before baking (resting is essential): Warm the honey gently in a saucepan until fluid. In a large bowl, whisk together both flours, baking soda, baking powder, and all the spices. Add the warm honey, warm milk, eggs, brown sugar, and orange zest if using. Mix until completely smooth. The batter will be thick and fragrant. Cover the bowl tightly with plastic wrap and leave at room temperature for 24 hours. This rest period allows the spices to bloom and the rye to hydrate fully, deepening flavor dramatically.

The next day, preheat the oven to 325°F (165°C). Butter a 9x5-inch (23x13 cm) loaf pan and line it with parchment paper. Stir the batter once more — it will have thickened and darkened. Pour into the prepared pan and smooth the top. Scatter sliced almonds over the surface if using.
Bake for 50–60 minutes until a skewer inserted in the center comes out clean and the top is a deep, burnished mahogany. The loaf will not rise dramatically — this is as it should be.

Cool in the pan for 20 minutes, then unmold onto a rack. Wrap in parchment and then in a clean cloth. Let rest for at least 24 hours before cutting — the flavor and texture improve enormously. Pain d'épices keeps at room temperature for up to 2 weeks.

Bretagne.description: A buckwheat (blé noir) crêpe from Brittany filled with ham, Gruyère, and a runny egg. Technique: pure buckwheat batter with no wheat (gluten-free); resting hydrates the flour; a well-seasoned or nonstick crêpe pan and the right heat give a lacy, crisp-edged galette. The egg is cracked onto the galette and cooked just until the white is set so the yolk stays runny.
ingredients: 1 cup (120 g) buckwheat flour (farine de sarrasin)
Per galette: 1 thin slice jambon blanc or good ham, 1/4 cup (25 g) grated Gruyère, 1 large egg, salt and pepper
steps: In a bowl, whisk the buckwheat flour and salt. Make a well; add the egg and half the water. Whisk from the center outward until smooth, then whisk in the rest of the water. The batter should be the consistency of thin cream. Cover and rest at room temperature at least 1 hour (or up to 12 hours in the fridge; bring back to room temp and thin with 1–2 tbsp water if needed).

Heat a 9- or 10-inch crêpe pan or nonstick skillet over medium heat. When hot, rub with a little butter. Pour about 1/3 cup (80 ml) batter into the center; immediately tilt and swirl so the batter coats the bottom in a thin, even layer. Cook until the top is set and the edges lift easily, 1–2 min.

Place the ham and cheese on one half of the galette. Crack the egg into the center. Fold the opposite half over the filling (or fold the two sides in toward the center to leave the egg visible). Add a small knob of butter to the pan around the galette.

Cook until the egg white is set and the cheese has melted, 2–3 min. The yolk should remain runny. Season with salt and pepper. Slide onto a plate and serve immediately. Repeat with remaining batter and fillings. Serve with Breton cider in a bolée.

drink.description: Brittany's elevated cider cocktail: dry Breton cidre spiked with a measure of Calvados (Norman apple brandy, Brittany's neighbor's pride) and a dash of cassis. Sparkling, fruity, and stronger than it looks.
ingredients: 4 oz (120 ml) dry Breton cidre, well chilled
1 oz (30 ml) Calvados or Lambig (Breton apple brandy)
steps: Pour the Calvados and cassis into a large wine glass or cider bolée.
Top with chilled cidre. Stir gently once.
Garnish with a thin apple slice. Serve cold.

dessert.description: Kouign-Amann (kween AH-mahn — 'butter cake' in Breton) was born in 1860 in Douarnenez, created by baker Yves-René Scordia who, facing a shortage of ingredients, folded butter and sugar into bread dough and sent it to the oven. The result was accidental genius: a shatteringly caramelized, flaky, salty-sweet pastry that Brittany has never stopped making. The magic is in the conflict — bread dough fighting against layers of cold salted Breton butter (beurre de baratte demi-sel, nothing less), the sugar caramelizing on the bottom of the pan into lacquer, the dough puffing into crisp, laminated layers. The top is golden and crackles like ice; the edges are dark and bitter-sweet like toffee; the inside is soft, buttery, and yielding. Kouign-Amann is best eaten the same day, still slightly warm, in rough-torn pieces — it cannot and should not be elegant. It is Brittany on a plate: salty, honest, excessive, and unforgettable.
ingredients: For the dough: 2 1/4 tsp (7 g) active dry yeast, 3/4 cup (180 ml) warm water, 2 cups (250 g) bread flour, 1/2 tsp fine sea salt
For the lamination: 3/4 cup (1 1/2 sticks / 170 g) cold salted Breton butter (or unsalted butter + 1/2 tsp fleur de sel), cut into thin slabs
1/2 tsp fleur de sel or coarse sea salt for the top
1 tbsp unsalted butter, melted, for the pan
steps: Make the dough: Dissolve the yeast in the warm water and let stand 5 minutes until foamy. Combine the bread flour and salt in a large bowl, add the yeast mixture, and mix to a shaggy dough. Knead on a floured surface 5–8 minutes until smooth and supple. Shape into a ball, place in a lightly oiled bowl, cover with plastic, and rise in a warm spot 1 hour until doubled.

Prepare the butter: Lay the butter slabs between two sheets of parchment and beat with a rolling pin until pliable but still cold — it should bend without cracking. The butter must be workable but not soft. Refrigerate if needed.

On a lightly floured surface, roll the dough into a 12-inch (30 cm) square. Lay the butter slab in the center. Scatter 1/4 cup (50 g) of the sugar over the butter. Fold the dough over the butter like an envelope, pinching all edges. Rotate 90 degrees, then roll out to a long rectangle (about 8x16 inches / 20x40 cm). Sprinkle another 1/4 cup (50 g) sugar over the dough, fold in thirds (like a letter), wrap in plastic, and refrigerate 20 minutes.

Preheat the oven to 400°F (200°C). Butter a 9-inch (23 cm) round cake pan generously. Remove the dough from the fridge. Roll it out into a 10-inch (25 cm) round. Scatter the remaining 1/4 cup (50 g) sugar over the surface and press in gently. Fit the dough into the pan, folding any overhang inward. Sprinkle the top with fleur de sel. Let rest uncovered 20 minutes.

Bake for 30–35 minutes until deeply golden and caramelized — the sugar will bubble and caramelize black at the edges, which is correct. The moment it comes out of the oven, run a knife around the edge and invert it onto a rack or plate immediately. Any delay and the caramel will cement to the pan. If some caramel sticks, scrape it free with a spoon and press it back. Eat the same day while still faintly warm, torn into rough pieces.

Centre-Val de Loire.description: Tours' legendary potted meat: pork shoulder and belly slow-cooked for hours in their own fat until the meat falls apart, then shredded and packed into crocks. Rillettes de Tours has PGI status—coarser than Le Mans rillettes, with visible strands of meat. Spread cold on crusty bread with cornichons.
ingredients: 2 lbs pork shoulder cut into 2-inch cubes (900 g)
1/2 lb pork belly cut into 2-inch pieces (225 g)
Crusty bread and cornichons for serving
steps: Place all pork in a heavy pot with salt pepper allspice thyme and bay leaves. Add water. Bring to a bare simmer.
Cook uncovered on lowest heat 4-5 hours, stirring occasionally. Add splashes of water if the bottom dries before the meat is tender.
When the meat is falling apart and the liquid is mostly rendered fat, remove thyme and bay leaves. Shred the meat with two forks mixing it into the fat.
Pack into jars pressing out air pockets. Smooth the top and pour a thin layer of the rendered fat over to seal.
Cool then refrigerate. Serve cold spread on crusty bread with cornichons.

drink.description: The Loire Valley's twist on Kir: sparkling Vouvray (chenin blanc) with a splash of crème de poire (pear liqueur). The Loire is France's garden, and this drink tastes like a late-summer orchard—floral, delicate, and fizzy.
ingredients: 1/3 oz (10 ml) crème de poire (pear liqueur)
steps: Pour the crème de poire into a champagne flute.
Top slowly with chilled sparkling Vouvray.
Garnish with a thin pear slice.

dessert.description: The legendary upside-down apple tart, born from a beautiful accident at the Hôtel Tatin in Lamotte-Beuvron in the 1880s. Apples are caramelized in a deep amber butter-and-sugar base until they turn mahogany and translucent, then blanketed with buttery puff pastry and baked until golden. The moment of truth is the flip: one confident inversion reveals a glistening crown of caramelized apples, each piece holding its shape in a lacquer of toffee so dark it borders on bittersweet. The pastry beneath is shatteringly crisp, soaked just enough at the edges to meld with the caramel. Served warm with a quenelle of crème fraîche, Tarte Tatin is France's most perfect mistake — and the Loire Valley's greatest gift to pâtisserie.
ingredients: 6–8 firm, tart apples (Granny Smith or Reine des Reinettes), peeled, cored, and quartered
1 sheet all-butter puff pastry, thawed if frozen, rolled to a round 1 inch (2.5 cm) larger than your pan
1/2 cup (1 stick / 115 g) unsalted butter, cut into pieces
steps: Use a 10-inch (25 cm) ovenproof skillet (cast iron or stainless). Melt the butter over medium heat; add the sugar and salt. Stir until dissolved, then cook without stirring until the mixture turns a deep amber caramel, 8–10 minutes. Watch carefully — it can burn in seconds. Remove from heat immediately.

Arrange the apple quarters in the hot caramel in a tight spiral, rounded side down, packing them snugly so they hold together when inverted. Fill gaps with smaller pieces. Return the pan to medium-low heat and cook 15–25 minutes so the apples release their juice and the caramel thickens. The apples should be tender but still hold their shape. Remove from heat.

Lay the pastry round over the apples and tuck the edges down between the fruit and the pan. Pierce the pastry in several places with a knife to release steam. Bake in a preheated 400°F (200°C) oven 20–28 minutes until the pastry is puffed and deep golden.

Let rest exactly 5 minutes — no longer or the caramel will set and cement the tart to the pan. Place a large serving plate over the skillet. Using oven mitts, firmly hold both together and invert in one confident motion. Lift the pan away. Rearrange any apples that stuck. Serve warm with crème fraîche or vanilla ice cream.

Corse.dish: Veau aux Olives à la Corse
Corse.description: Corsica's aromatic mountain stew: veal braised with green olives, tomato, garlic, and wild maquis herbs in dry white wine. The olives give it a briny depth that is unmistakably Corsican—this is the dish of the interior villages, made with free-range veal from the chestnut forests.
ingredients: 2 lbs veal shoulder cut into 2-inch cubes (900 g)
1 cup dry white Corsican wine (240 ml)
Salt and freshly ground black pepper
Polenta or crusty bread for serving
steps: Season veal with salt and pepper. Brown in olive oil on all sides. Remove.
Sauté onion until soft. Add garlic cook 1 minute. Add tomatoes cook 5 minutes.
Return veal. Add wine olives rosemary and bay leaves. Add 1/2 cup water.
Cover and simmer on low heat 1.5-2 hours until the veal is very tender and the sauce has thickened.
Remove rosemary and bay leaves. Serve with polenta or crusty bread.

drink.description: Corsica's answer to the Aperol Spritz: Cap Corse Mattei (a bittersweet quinquina apéritif made with Corsican citrus and herbs since 1872) topped with sparkling wine and a slice of orange. Sipped at sunset on every Corsican port terrace.
ingredients: 3 oz (90 ml) dry sparkling wine or prosecco
steps: Fill a wine glass with ice.
Pour in Cap Corse, then sparkling wine, then a splash of soda.
Stir gently once. Garnish with an orange slice.

dessert.description: A light, flourless Corsican cheesecake made with brocciu or ricotta, eggs, and lemon. Technique: no crust—the mixture is blended until smooth, poured into a buttered mold, and baked until set with a slight wobble in the center. The eggs provide structure; the lemon zest is essential. Traditionally served at room temperature, often for Easter.
ingredients: 2 cups (500 g) brocciu (Corsican fresh cheese) or whole-milk ricotta, drained if watery
Zest of 2 untreated lemons, finely grated
1 tsp vanilla extract or 1/2 tsp lemon juice
Butter and flour for the pan (or use a nonstick 9-inch round pan, buttered)
steps: If using ricotta, drain in a sieve 15–30 min if it is wet; press gently. Preheat the oven to 350°F (175°C). Butter a 9-inch (23 cm) round cake pan and dust with flour, or use a springform and butter it well.

In a large bowl, beat the brocciu or ricotta with a whisk or wooden spoon until smooth and free of lumps. Add the eggs one at a time, mixing well after each. Stir in the sugar, lemon zest, and vanilla until fully combined. The mixture should be homogeneous and slightly fluid.

Pour the batter into the prepared pan and smooth the top. Bake on the middle rack 35–45 min until the edges are golden and the center is set with a slight jiggle (it will firm up as it cools). Do not overbake or the texture will be dry.
Cool in the pan on a rack 15–20 min, then unmold if using a regular pan. Cool completely. Serve at room temperature, optionally with a dusting of powdered sugar or a drizzle of honey.

Grand Est.description: Alsatian sauerkraut braised with juniper, white wine, and an array of pork and sausages. Technique: rinse the sauerkraut to control salt and soften flavor; layer with aromatics and fat (bacon, duck fat, or lard); slow braise so the kraut becomes tender and infused. Meats are nestled in and added according to cooking time—long-cook cuts first, sausages last so they do not burst.
ingredients: 2 lbs (900 g) raw sauerkraut (choucroute crue), rinsed in cold water and squeezed dry in batches
1 lb (450 g) smoked bacon (piece, e.g. poitrine fumée), rind scored
1 lb (450 g) pork shoulder or smoked pork knuckle (jarret)
4–6 Strasbourg-style or frankfurter sausages (saucisses de Strasbourg)
1 1/2 cups (360 ml) dry Alsace white wine (Riesling or Sylvaner)
1 medium onion, peeled and stuck with 2 cloves
2 tbsp duck fat or lard (optional but traditional)
Waxy potatoes (e.g. Charlotte), boiled in salted water, to serve
steps: Rinse the sauerkraut in a colander under cold water; squeeze out excess liquid in handfuls. This reduces salt and softens the flavor. Set aside.

In a large heavy pot (or cocotte), melt the duck fat if using. Spread half the sauerkraut in the bottom. Scatter half the juniper berries, the onion with cloves, bay leaves, and peppercorns. Lay the bacon and pork shoulder or knuckle on top. Cover with the remaining sauerkraut. Pour the wine and add enough water or stock to come about halfway up the kraut (do not drown it). Bring to a gentle simmer.

Cover with a tight lid or parchment and a lid. Simmer on low heat (or in a 325°F / 165°C oven) 2–2 1/2 hours until the sauerkraut is tender and the pork is cooked. Check liquid occasionally; add a little water if the bottom is dry.

Add the sausages, pushing them into the sauerkraut. Simmer 15–20 min until the sausages are heated through. Remove the onion and bay leaves. Slice the bacon and pork; arrange the meats on a platter with the sauerkraut and boiled potatoes. Serve with strong Dijon mustard and the same Alsace wine, chilled.

drink.description: The Alsatian twist on Kir: Riesling d'Alsace with a pour of crème de framboise (raspberry liqueur) instead of cassis—pink, aromatic, and perfectly Alsatian.
ingredients: 1/3 oz (10 ml) crème de framboise (raspberry liqueur)
steps: Pour the crème de framboise into a wine glass. Top with chilled Riesling.
Do not stir. Serve as an apéritif with Alsatian tarte flambée.

dessert.description: The Kouglof (or Kugelhopf) is the soul of Alsatian baking — a tall, turban-shaped yeasted cake with a hollow center, baked in its distinctive glazed terracotta mold, perfumed with kirsch, studded with plump raisins, and crowned with whole almonds pressed into the ridges. Its origins blur into legend — some say Marie Antoinette had one every morning; others trace it to the Three Kings of Bethlehem stopping in Ribeauvillé. What is certain is that every Alsatian household has a kouglof mold, passed down through generations, permanently stained a warm amber from decades of butter. The dough is enriched with eggs, butter, and milk, then slowly fermented — tradition demands it rise in the mold overnight in a cool cellar. The result is a crumb that is simultaneously airy and tight, soft and springy, deeply buttery. It keeps for days, improving in flavor, and is eaten at breakfast with café au lait, or in the afternoon with a glass of Alsatian Gewurztraminer.
ingredients: For the dough: 3 1/2 cups (450 g) all-purpose flour, 1 packet (7 g) instant yeast, 1/3 cup (65 g) granulated sugar, 1 tsp fine sea salt, 3/4 cup (180 ml) warm whole milk, 3 large eggs at room temperature, 3/4 cup (170 g) unsalted butter, softened and cubed
3 tbsp kirsch (cherry brandy) or dark rum
steps: The night before: Soak the raisins in the kirsch or rum for at least 2 hours or overnight. In a large bowl or stand mixer, combine the flour, yeast, sugar, and salt. Add the warm milk and eggs, then mix on low to bring together. Increase speed and beat 5 minutes until elastic and smooth.

Add the butter piece by piece, beating after each addition until fully absorbed before adding the next — this takes patience and about 10 minutes. The dough will be very soft and sticky, pulling away from the bowl. Beat in the lemon zest, vanilla, and the soaked raisins (drained). Cover with plastic wrap and rise at room temperature 1 hour until puffed, then refrigerate overnight.
The next day, butter the kouglof mold (or a large Bundt pan) very generously. Press one whole almond into each ridge at the bottom of the mold.

Remove the dough from the fridge. On a lightly floured surface, shape it gently into a smooth ball. With a floured finger, poke a hole through the center. Place the ring of dough into the mold, pressing it gently to fill the ridges. Cover loosely and let rise at room temperature 2–3 hours until the dough crowns just above the mold's rim.

Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C). Bake for 35–40 minutes until a deep golden brown and a skewer comes out clean. The crust should be burnished. Cool in the mold 15 minutes, then carefully invert onto a rack. Cool completely. Dust very generously with powdered sugar. Serve in thick slices with salted butter and café au lait.

Hauts-de-France.description: Flemish beef and onion stew braised in brown beer, with a touch of brown sugar and vinegar. Technique: beef is seared in batches for fond; onions are cooked slowly until deeply golden; the pain à la moutarde (bread spread with Dijon) is laid on top to thicken and flavor the sauce. Long, gentle simmer so the meat is tender and the sauce is rich and glossy.
ingredients: 2 lbs (900 g) beef chuck, cut into 1 1/2-inch (4 cm) cubes, patted dry
3 large yellow onions, halved and sliced 1/4 inch thick
2 (12 oz / 355 ml) bottles brown ale or Flanders red (e.g. Belgian dubbel)
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
steps: In a Dutch oven over medium-high heat, heat 1 tbsp oil. Season the beef with salt and pepper. Sear in a single layer in batches until well browned on at least two sides, 4–5 min per batch. Transfer to a plate. Do not crowd the pan or the meat will steam.
Lower the heat to medium. Add the remaining oil and the onions. Cook, stirring occasionally, until the onions are soft and deeply golden, 20–25 min. This builds sweetness and depth.

Return the beef and any juices to the pot. Add the beer, brown sugar, vinegar, thyme, and bay leaves. Bring to a simmer. Spread one side of each bread slice with a thin layer of Dijon and place mustard-side down on top of the stew (the bread will dissolve and thicken the sauce). Partially cover and simmer on low 2–2 1/2 hours until the beef is fork-tender. Remove the thyme and bay leaves; discard any remaining bread. Taste and adjust salt and pepper. Serve with frites, boiled potatoes, or crusty bread.

drink.description: A cocktail from France's far north: genièvre (juniper-flavored grain spirit, the ancestor of gin, distilled in Flanders since the 16th century) shaken with fresh lemon, honey, and a dash of chicory bitters. Hauts-de-France is genièvre country, and this sour honors its heritage.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) genièvre (Houlle, Loos, or Wambrechies)
steps: Shake genièvre, lemon juice, honey syrup, and bitters with ice.
Strain into a chilled coupe.
Express a lemon twist over the surface and drop it in.

dessert.description: The Gâteau Battu is Picardy's secret treasure — one of the most striking and least-known cakes in all of France. Its name means 'beaten cake,' a reference to the vigorous, almost violent mixing that gives it its extraordinary texture. It bakes in a tall, fluted cylindrical mold (traditionally a moule à gâteau battu, like a deep brioche mold) and rises to an improbable height — nearly 8 inches of soft, golden, eggy cake. Inside it is pillowy, tender, and intensely buttery, with the character of a very rich brioche crossed with a pound cake: bouncy but yielding, fragrant with vanilla and lemon. The high egg-yolk content (sometimes 10 yolks for a single cake) gives it a gorgeous saffron-yellow crumb. It is synonymous with Sunday in Picardy — sliced thick, eaten with coffee or cider, given as gifts at market. Like all great regional cakes, it is both humble and extraordinary, asking for nothing but time and good butter.
ingredients: 1 cup (225 g) unsalted butter, softened to a creamy consistency
1 egg yolk beaten with 1 tbsp cream for glaze
steps: Dissolve the yeast in the warm water with a pinch of the sugar. Let stand 10 minutes until foamy. In a large bowl, combine the flour, sugar, and salt. Make a well in the center; add the egg yolks, yeast mixture, warm milk, vanilla, and lemon zest.

Beat vigorously with a wooden spoon or dough hook on medium speed for 10 minutes — the dough will be very soft, almost batter-like. This beating is critical and non-negotiable. Add the softened butter in small pieces, beating thoroughly after each addition. Beat a further 10 minutes until the dough is smooth, silky, and pulls slightly from the bowl. It will be much softer than traditional bread dough.

Cover and rise in a warm place 1 1/2 hours until nearly doubled. Knock back gently and then fill a well-buttered tall cylindrical mold (or two small brioche molds) to about halfway — the rise is impressive. Cover and rise again 1 hour, or until the dough reaches the top of the mold.

Preheat the oven to 350°F (175°C). Brush the top gently with the egg yolk glaze. Bake for 35–40 minutes until a deep golden brown and a skewer comes out clean. The cake will have climbed impressively and look like a golden crown.
Cool in the mold for 20 minutes before unmolding. The crust is slightly crisp; the interior is tender and yellow. Serve in thick slices at room temperature. It keeps well for 3 days wrapped in cloth.

Île-de-France.description: Parisian ham-and-cheese sandwich gratinéed with béchamel and Gruyère. Technique: a proper béchamel (roux then milk, no lumps) with nutmeg; the sandwich is assembled, coated with béchamel and cheese, then baked until the sauce is bubbling and the top is golden. For Croque-Madame, add a fried egg on top.
ingredients: 8 slices pain de mie or good white sandwich bread, about 1/2 inch thick
4 thin slices jambon blanc or good cooked ham
steps: Béchamel: In a small saucepan over medium heat, melt the butter. Add the flour and stir with a wooden spoon for 1–2 min (do not let it color). Off the heat, add the warm milk in a steady stream while whisking to avoid lumps. Return to medium heat and bring to a gentle simmer; cook, stirring, until thickened, 2–3 min. Season with nutmeg, salt, and white pepper. Off the heat, stir in 1/4 cup (25 g) of the Gruyère until melted. Set aside; if it thickens too much, thin with a drop of milk.

Assemble: Lay 4 slices of bread on a baking sheet. Top each with 1 slice of ham and a good sprinkle of Gruyère. Cover with the remaining bread slices. Spread the béchamel evenly over the tops (and optionally the sides), then sprinkle with the remaining Gruyère.

Bake in a preheated 425°F (220°C) oven 10–14 min until the béchamel is bubbling and the cheese on top is golden and spotted brown. Rest 1–2 min. Serve hot, with a green salad. Optional: top each with a fried egg for Croque-Madame.

drink.description: The quintessential Parisian cocktail, born at Harry's New York Bar on Rue Daunou during World War I: gin, fresh lemon, simple syrup, and champagne. Named after the 75mm field gun for its kick. Elegant, effervescent, and lethal—pure Île-de-France.
steps: Shake gin, lemon juice, and simple syrup with ice.
Strain into a champagne flute.
Top with cold champagne. Garnish with a long lemon twist.

dessert.description: Crème brûlée belongs to Paris — or more precisely, to the kitchens of the Paris aristocracy. The first written recipe appears in François Massialot's 1691 cookbook 'Le Cuisinier Royal et Bourgeois', published for the French court. The dish is unmistakably of the haute cuisine tradition: a custard of pure cream and vanilla, baked low and slow in a bain-marie until it trembles at the center like set silk, then chilled until firm. The caramel is applied at the last possible moment — a thin veil of sugar torched to a hard amber pane that shatters at the tap of a spoon. Unlike the Catalan crema (made with milk, cornstarch, cinnamon, and citrus), the French version uses heavy cream only, vanilla bean only, and no starch — the custard sets purely from the slow coagulation of egg yolks in cream. It is a study in restraint: four ingredients, one technique, and the patience to do it without shortcuts.
ingredients: 1 vanilla bean, split lengthwise and seeds scraped
4–5 tsp granulated or raw sugar, for the caramel tops
steps: Preheat oven to 325°F (160°C). Place four 6-oz ramekins in a deep baking dish. Bring a kettle of water to a boil.

Combine the heavy cream, vanilla bean pod, and vanilla seeds in a small saucepan. Heat over medium-low until steaming and just beginning to simmer around the edges. Remove from heat, cover, and steep 15 minutes. Remove the vanilla pod.
In a bowl, whisk the egg yolks with the sugar and salt until pale and slightly thickened — about 1 minute. Do not over-whisk or you will create foam that mars the custard surface.

Pour the warm vanilla cream slowly into the egg mixture in a thin steady stream, whisking gently and constantly. Skim off any surface foam. Strain through a fine-mesh sieve into a large measuring cup for easy pouring.

Divide the custard evenly among the ramekins. Pour enough boiling water into the baking dish to come halfway up the sides of the ramekins. Bake 35–40 minutes until the custards are just set at the edges but still have a distinct wobble in the center when nudged. Do not overbake.
Remove carefully from the water bath and cool to room temperature. Refrigerate uncovered at least 2 hours, or up to 2 days covered. The surface must be completely dry before caramelizing.

To serve: Sprinkle 1 tsp sugar evenly over each custard. Caramelize with a kitchen blowtorch, holding the flame 2–3 inches from the surface and moving in small circles until the sugar melts, bubbles, and turns a deep amber. Let stand 1–2 minutes until the caramel hardens to a glassy shell. It should shatter cleanly at the first tap of a spoon. Serve immediately.

Normandie.description: Mussels steamed in dry cider with cream, shallots, and apple—a taste of the Norman coast. Technique: sweat the aromatics in butter without browning; add cider and cream, then the mussels; cover and steam over high heat so they open quickly and stay tender. Discard any that do not open. The sauce is finished with parsley and a knob of butter (monter au beurre) for shine.
ingredients: 4 lbs (1.8 kg) mussels, scrubbed and debearded (pull or cut the beard), rinsed in cold water
1/2 cup (120 ml) crème fraîche or heavy cream
1 crisp apple (e.g. Granny Smith or Reinette), peeled, cored, and cut into small dice
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
steps: Check mussels: discard any that are broken or that do not close when tapped. Rinse and drain. Set aside.

In a large pot with a tight-fitting lid (wide and deep enough to hold the mussels), melt 2 tbsp butter over medium heat. Add the shallots and sweat until soft and translucent, 2–3 min—do not brown. Add the apple and cook 1 min. Pour in the cider and bring to a boil; let reduce 1–2 min. Add the crème fraîche, stir, and bring back to a simmer.

Add the mussels all at once and cover. Increase heat to high and steam 4–6 min, shaking the pot once or twice, until the mussels have opened. Remove from heat. Discard any mussels that did not open. Stir in the remaining 1 tbsp butter and the parsley. Taste the sauce and season with salt and pepper (cider may be salty). Serve immediately in large bowls with the sauce, with frites or crusty bread and Norman cider.

drink.description: The legendary Norman palate cleanser turned cocktail: a scoop of green apple sorbet drowned in ice-cold Calvados (Norman apple brandy). Traditionally served between courses of a grand Norman feast to 'make a hole' (trou) in the stomach for more food. The cold sorbet tames the Calvados; the Calvados melts the sorbet. It is equal parts dessert, digestif, and ceremony.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) Calvados (VSOP or Hors d'Age for sipping quality)
1 thin slice of green apple for garnish
steps: Place a scoop of green apple sorbet in a chilled coupe or small glass.
Pour the Calvados slowly over the sorbet.
Garnish with a thin apple slice. Serve immediately with a small spoon—eat and drink simultaneously.

dessert.description: The Teurgoule is perhaps the most patient dessert in France. Its name in Norman dialect means 'twist the mouth' — a reference to the way it made mouths pucker with spice in the days before sugar was common. Today it is a deeply soothing, profoundly Norman thing: short-grain rice, whole milk, sugar, cinnamon, and nutmeg, combined in an earthenware pot and placed in a low oven for three to four hours. The result is not rice pudding as the world knows it — it is a slow transformation into something transcendent. The top forms a deep brown, almost lacquered crust of caramelized milk sugars and spice. Beneath it, the rice has absorbed the cream and swollen into a dense, voluptuous mass — each grain plump and suspended in a trembling, vanilla-cream matrix. Every farm in Calvados had its own earthenware teurgoule dish, scratched from years of use. It was placed in the communal bread oven as the day's bread baked, left to cook as the oven slowly cooled. It is Sunday food. It is grandmothers and cider. It is Normandy from its soul.
ingredients: 1/2 cup (100 g) short-grain rice (use pudding rice or Arborio — do not wash it)
4 1/4 cups (1 liter) whole milk (use the best full-fat milk you can find)
1 tsp pure vanilla extract or 1 vanilla pod, split
steps: Preheat the oven to 300°F (150°C). This is a very low temperature — essential for the long, slow cooking that creates the crust and the texture.

In a deep earthenware or ceramic oven dish (a 2-quart / 2-liter capacity, low and wide), combine the rice, sugar, cinnamon, nutmeg, and salt. Stir to mix. Pour in the milk, cream, and vanilla extract (or scrape in the vanilla seeds and add the pod). Stir gently to combine everything.

Place in the oven uncovered and do not touch, stir, or open the oven for the first hour. Over 3 to 4 hours, the rice will absorb the milk, the surface will turn progressively darker — from cream to gold to brown to deep mahogany. This deep-brown crust is the goal. The low oven allows the milk sugars to caramelize slowly without burning.

The teurgoule is done when the crust is a deep, glossy brown and the rice beneath is thick and creamy. A skewer inserted in the center should meet some resistance — it should be set, not liquid. Total baking time is 3 to 4 hours. If the crust is darkening too fast, lay a piece of foil loosely over the top for the last 30 minutes.

Remove from the oven and cool to room temperature before serving — ideally serve it just slightly warm. The teurgoule is traditionally eaten as-is, from the baking dish, in generous spoonfuls. Serve with thick Normandy crème fraîche and, if you have it, local apple calvados for the adults.

Nouvelle-Aquitaine.description: Duck leg preserved and slow-cooked in its own fat (confit), then crisped in a pan for serving—a Gascon and Périgord classic. Technique: dry-salting draws moisture and seasons the meat; cooking in fat at a low temperature (around 85–90°C) renders the connective tissue without boiling. Stored under fat, confit keeps for weeks. To serve, the skin is crisped in a hot pan, flesh-side briefly, then skin-side until golden.
ingredients: 4 duck legs (cuisses de canard), whole with skin
1 1/2–2 lbs (700–900 g) duck fat, or enough to submerge the legs completely
steps: Salt the duck legs on both sides with the sea salt; add the peppercorns and optional bay. Place in a dish, cover, and refrigerate 12–24 hours. This draws out moisture and seasons the meat.

Rinse the legs and pat very dry. Preheat the oven to 285°F (140°C). In a heavy ovenproof pot just large enough to hold the legs in one layer, melt the duck fat. Add the garlic and thyme. Submerge the duck legs completely in the fat (they must be covered). Bring to a very gentle simmer on the stovetop, then transfer, uncovered, to the oven. Cook 2–2 1/2 hours until the meat is tender and pulls easily from the bone. The fat should never boil—only gentle bubbles.

To store: cool the legs in the fat, then transfer to a container and cover completely with the strained fat. Refrigerate; they keep for weeks. To serve: remove the legs from the fat and scrape off excess fat. In a cold skillet, place the legs skin-side down. Turn heat to medium; cook 8–12 min until the skin is golden and crisp. Flip and warm the flesh side 1–2 min. Serve with potatoes sautéed in duck fat, or a simple green salad.

drink.description: Floc de Gascogne is Gascony's secret: unfermented grape juice blended with young Armagnac and aged in oak barrels. Served over ice with a twist of orange, it is the apéritif of the Gers countryside—fruity, warming, and impossible to stop sipping. The name 'floc' comes from the Gascon word for 'bouquet of flowers.'
ingredients: 3 oz (90 ml) Floc de Gascogne (blanc or rosé)
steps: Pour the Floc de Gascogne into a wine glass filled with ice.
Add a splash of soda. Garnish with an orange twist.
Sip slowly as an apéritif—the Gascon sunset demands it.

dessert.description: The cannelé is Bordeaux's great mystery — a small, thimble-sized cylinder of batter baked in a fluted copper mold until it achieves one of the most extraordinary paradoxes in pastry: a shell so dark it's nearly black, thick and caramelized to a lacquered crust, encasing an interior that is soft, custardy, and trembling — perfumed with rum, vanilla, and the faint sweetness of Bordeaux wine country. Its origin is contested: some say it was created in the 17th century by the Ursuline nuns of Bordeaux using flour donated from wine producers (who used egg whites to clarify their wine, leaving mountains of unused yolks). The batter is deliberately simple — milk, eggs, flour, butter, vanilla, and dark rum — but it requires patience: 24 to 48 hours of rest in the refrigerator so the gluten relaxes and the flavors deepen. The copper molds are the secret to the crust; brushed with beeswax, they conduct heat in a way that no silicone or aluminum can replicate. In Bordeaux they are eaten at 10am with a glass of cold Sauternes, still warm, the crust just set.
ingredients: 1/4 cup (60 ml) dark rum (Mount Gay or any quality dark rum)
Beeswax (or a mix of equal parts unsalted butter and coconut oil) for brushing molds
steps: Heat the milk and butter with the vanilla bean and its seeds over medium heat until just below a boil. Remove from heat and let the vanilla infuse for 10 minutes. Remove the bean.

In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, and salt. Make a well in the center. Add the eggs and yolks to the well and begin whisking from the center outward, gradually incorporating the flour. Pour the warm vanilla milk in a slow, steady stream, whisking constantly. Whisk until completely smooth — the batter will be quite liquid, like a crêpe batter. Stir in the rum.
Transfer to a jug or pitcher with a lid, or cover the bowl with plastic wrap. Refrigerate for at least 24 hours and ideally 48 hours. This rest is non-negotiable. Do not skip it.

When ready to bake, preheat the oven to 475°F (245°C) — as hot as your oven goes, at least 450°F (230°C). Melt the beeswax (or butter-coconut oil mixture) and brush every crevice of the copper molds generously. If using silicone molds, brush with melted butter.

Stir the cold batter well — it will have separated; whisk it back together. Fill the molds to within 1/4 inch (5 mm) of the top. Place on a baking sheet and bake for 15 minutes at high heat, then reduce to 400°F (200°C) and bake for a further 40–50 minutes. The cannelés are done when they are very dark — a deep mahogany-black exterior. When you unmold them, the shell should ring with a hollow sound when tapped.
Unmold immediately onto a rack. They must be eaten the same day, ideally within 2 hours of baking, when the exterior is crackingly crisp and the interior still tender and custardy.

Occitanie.description: Slow-cooked white beans with duck confit, Toulouse sausage, and pork—the soul of Languedoc. Technique: beans are cooked until tender and their cooking liquid becomes the base; meats are layered with the beans in a deep vessel; a breadcrumb crust forms on top and is deliberately broken and pushed back in (casser la croûte) several times so it thickens and flavors the whole dish. Long, gentle baking melds everything.
ingredients: 2 lbs (900 g) dried Tarbais or cannellini beans, soaked overnight in cold water, drained
4 duck confit legs (from your own confit or store-bought)
1 lb (450 g) Toulouse sausage or other garlic pork sausage, pricked
8 oz (225 g) pork shoulder or fresh pork belly, cut into 1 1/2-inch cubes
1 (14 oz / 400 g) can whole tomatoes, crushed by hand, with juice
1 bouquet garni (thyme, bay leaf, parsley stems)
2 tbsp duck fat or olive oil
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
steps: Put the soaked beans in a large pot with the quartered onion, halved carrot, smashed garlic, and bouquet garni. Cover with cold water by 2 inches. Bring to a simmer and cook until the beans are tender but not mushy, 1–1 1/2 hours (timing depends on the bean). Add salt in the last 15 min. Drain, reserving the cooking liquid; remove the bouquet garni and aromatics. You need about 4–5 cups of bean liquid.

In a skillet, brown the sausage and pork cubes in duck fat; set aside.
