Emilia-Romagna.description: The true test of Emilian mastery: tiny hand-folded pasta parcels filled with a mix of prosciutto crudo, mortadella, Parmigiano-Reggiano, and pork loin, served swimming in a crystal-clear, golden capon broth. In Bologna and Modena, this is Christmas lunch. The filling is cooked first, then minced fine—never raw. Each tortellino should be small enough to sit on a fingertip.
ingredients: For the brodo: 1 whole capon or stewing hen (about 4 lbs / 1.8 kg), 1 lb beef shank (450 g), 1 carrot, 1 celery rib, 1 onion (halved, unpeeled), salt
For the filling: 4 oz pork loin (110 g), 3 oz prosciutto crudo di Parma (85 g), 3 oz mortadella di Bologna (85 g), 1 cup finely grated Parmigiano-Reggiano (100 g), 1 large egg, pinch of nutmeg, salt
For the pasta: 3 1/2 cups '00' flour (400 g), 4 large eggs
Brodo capon broth (see Chef's Essentials below)
Sfoglia egg pasta dough (see Chef's Essentials below)
steps: Make the brodo: Place the capon, beef shank, carrot, celery, onion, and 1 tbsp salt in a large stockpot. Cover with 4 quarts cold water. Bring to a very gentle simmer, skimming foam. Cook uncovered 3 hours at a bare simmer. Strain through cheesecloth. You should have a clear, golden, intensely flavored broth.

Make the filling: Brown the pork loin in a little butter until just cooked through. Let cool. Finely mince (by knife, not processor) the pork loin, prosciutto, and mortadella together until almost a paste. Mix with the Parmigiano, egg, nutmeg, and a pinch of salt. Refrigerate 1 hour.
Make the pasta: Mound flour on a wooden board, make a well, crack in the eggs. Mix with a fork, then knead 10–15 minutes until smooth, silky, and elastic. Wrap and rest 30 minutes.

Roll the pasta as thin as possible (setting 6–7 on a pasta machine, or thin enough to read a newspaper through). Cut into 1.5-inch squares. Place a pea-sized ball of filling in the center of each. Fold diagonally into a triangle, press edges to seal, then wrap around your pinky finger, pressing the two ends together. The tortellino should look like a tiny navel.
Bring the brodo to a gentle simmer. Cook the tortellini in the broth 3–4 minutes until they float. Ladle into warm bowls—tortellini swimming in golden brodo. Serve with grated Parmigiano.

drink.description: Emilia-Romagna's sparkling red wine, served frizzante (gently fizzy) and chilled. Dry Lambrusco di Sorbara is crimson, fragrant with violets, and cuts through the richness of Emilian cuisine like nothing else. This is not the sweet Lambrusco of export—this is the real thing.
ingredients: 1 bottle Lambrusco di Sorbara DOC (dry/secco), well chilled to 50°F (10°C)
steps: Chill the bottle thoroughly to 50°F (10°C).
Open gently—it is frizzante (lightly sparkling), not spumante. Pour into tulip glasses, not flutes.
Serve with tortellini in brodo, prosciutto, or any Emilian salumi. The bubbles and acidity are the perfect counterpoint to rich, fatty food.

dessert.description: The Torta di Riso Bolognese is Bologna's ancient custard-rice tart and one of the most completely satisfying desserts in all of Italy — humble in appearance, extraordinary in effect. Short-grain rice is simmered in whole milk until it swells and the milk thickens to a cream, then combined with eggs, sugar, almonds, lemon zest, and a generous pour of Sassolino or anise liqueur, and baked in a shortcrust pastry shell until the filling sets to a trembling, golden custard studded with swollen, creamy rice grains. Its origins are documented in Bolognese cookbooks from the 14th century — it was the Easter dessert of the noble families of the Emilian plain, made when the egg stores were full after Lent's privations. Each bite gives you the yielding pastry, then the rice-custard: sweet, milky, lemon-scented, with the whisper of anise. It is served cold or at room temperature and improves overnight as the flavors meld. In Bologna it is eaten at the end of Sunday lunch, in thick slices, with nothing alongside.
ingredients: For the pastry: 1 1/2 cups (190 g) all-purpose flour, 1/2 cup (115 g) cold unsalted butter cubed, 1/4 cup (50 g) sugar, 1 egg yolk, 2–3 tbsp cold water, pinch of salt

For the filling: 1/2 cup (100 g) short-grain rice (Arborio), 2 cups (480 ml) whole milk, 1 cup (240 ml) heavy cream, 1/2 cup (100 g) granulated sugar, 4 large eggs plus 2 yolks, Zest of 1 large lemon, 1/2 cup (50 g) blanched almonds, roughly chopped and toasted, 3 tbsp Sassolino or Sambuca (anise liqueur) or dry Marsala, 1/2 tsp pure vanilla extract, Pinch of fine sea salt
steps: Make the pastry: Rub the cold butter into the flour, sugar, and salt until it resembles coarse breadcrumbs. Add the egg yolk and just enough cold water to bring the dough together. Flatten into a disk, wrap, and refrigerate 30 minutes. Preheat the oven to 375°F (190°C). Roll the pastry and line a 10-inch (25 cm) tart pan with a removable bottom. Blind-bake with parchment and weights for 15 minutes, then remove weights and bake 5 minutes more. Reduce oven to 325°F (165°C).

Cook the rice filling: Combine the rice, milk, and cream in a saucepan. Cook over medium-low heat, stirring occasionally, until the rice is just tender and has absorbed most of the liquid — about 18–22 minutes. The mixture should be very thick and creamy. Remove from heat and stir in the sugar until dissolved. Let cool for 10 minutes.
In a large bowl, beat the eggs and yolks until smooth. Slowly stir in the warm rice mixture. Add the lemon zest, toasted almonds, anise liqueur, vanilla, and salt. Stir to combine thoroughly.

Pour the filling into the blind-baked pastry shell. Bake at 325°F (165°C) for 40–50 minutes until the filling is set at the edges and barely jiggles in the center — a gentle tremble. The top should be a pale golden color.

Cool completely in the pan on a rack, then refrigerate at least 2 hours. The torta unmolds cleanly when fully chilled. Dust with powdered sugar before serving. Cut in generous slices — this is not a delicate dessert.

Toscana.description: The Florentine T-bone: a massive, thick-cut steak from Chianina cattle (or Maremmana), cooked over a scorching wood-fire grill. The steak must be at least 2 fingers thick (1.5–2 inches), brought to room temperature, grilled rare to medium-rare with no marinade—only salt after cooking. The Florentines consider anything past medium-rare a tragedy. This is the primal heart of Tuscan cooking: the best ingredient, treated with the least interference.
ingredients: 1 T-bone or porterhouse steak, at least 1.5 inches thick, preferably 2 lbs+ (900 g+), bone-in
steps: Remove the steak from the refrigerator 1.5–2 hours before cooking. It must be at room temperature throughout.
Build a very hot wood or charcoal fire (or heat a grill to its maximum—600°F/315°C+). Clean the grate and let it heat.

Do NOT season or oil the steak before grilling. Place it directly on the screaming-hot grate. Cook 5–7 minutes per side for a 1.5-inch steak, or 7–8 minutes for a 2-inch steak. Do not press, poke, or move it.
Stand the steak on its bone-edge for 2–3 minutes to render the fat along the bone.
Rest on a warm plate for 5 minutes. Only NOW season generously with coarse sea salt, cracked pepper, and a bold drizzle of Tuscan olive oil.

Slice the meat off the bone, cut against the grain into thick strips, and serve on a warm platter. The center should be ruby red (al sangue). A lemon wedge and arugula salad are traditional accompaniments.

drink.description: Tuscany's contemplative dessert pairing: amber-gold Vin Santo (holy wine), made from Trebbiano and Malvasia grapes dried on straw mats and aged in small barrels for years. Served with cantucci (twice-baked almond biscuits) for dunking.
ingredients: 3 oz (90 ml) Vin Santo del Chianti DOC, served at cool room temperature (60°F / 16°C)
steps: Pour the Vin Santo into small tulip glasses at cool room temperature.
Dip a cantuccio into the wine, hold for a moment to soften, then eat. The almond crunch meets the honeyed, oxidative wine.
Repeat slowly. This is a ritual of patience and conversation, not a drink to be hurried.

dessert.description: The Cantucci — also called biscotti di Prato — are Tuscany's great contribution to the world of biscuits: twice-baked almond cookies, bone-dry, rock-hard, honey-golden, each slice showing a cross-section of whole almonds at every angle. They were created in Prato in the 14th century, and the recipe has not changed in essential ways since. The twice-baking (biscottare — to bake twice, which is where the word 'biscotti' comes from) removes all moisture, giving them a hardness that could crack a tooth — but this is the point. They are not meant to be eaten alone. They are meant for Vin Santo, Tuscany's amber dessert wine made from semi-dried grapes — sweet, oxidative, nutty, honeyed — into which the cantucci are dunked and held for two full seconds, then eaten as the wine-softened cookie releases its almond richness in a rush. The ritual of vin santo e cantucci at the end of a Tuscan meal — after the bistecca, the pici, the pecorino — is one of the great slow pleasures of Italian eating.
ingredients: 1 1/2 cups (150 g) whole unblanched almonds (skin on — traditional)
1 egg white beaten with 1 tsp water, for glazing
steps: Preheat the oven to 350°F (175°C). Line a baking sheet with parchment paper.

In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, baking powder, and salt. Make a well in the center. Add the eggs, egg yolk, vanilla, and orange zest. Mix from the center outward until a rough dough forms. It will be quite stiff and dry-looking. Add the whole almonds and knead them in — the dough will be very stiff. If absolutely necessary, add 1 tsp of water to bring it together, but resist this if you can.

Divide the dough into two equal portions. On a lightly floured surface, shape each into a log about 12 inches (30 cm) long and 1.5 inches (4 cm) wide. The logs will be rough-surfaced — this is correct. Place on the prepared baking sheet, spaced apart. Brush the tops with the egg white glaze.

Bake for 25–30 minutes until the logs are light golden-brown and feel firm when pressed gently on top. Remove from the oven and cool on the sheet for 15 minutes — they must firm up before the second baking.

Reduce oven temperature to 300°F (150°C). Using a sharp serrated knife, cut each log diagonally into slices 1/2 inch (1.3 cm) thick — use a firm, decisive sawing motion. Lay the slices flat on the baking sheet.

Bake for a further 20–25 minutes, turning once halfway through, until completely dry and very light golden on both sides. They should feel completely hard. Cool completely. They will harden further as they cool. Store in an airtight tin for up to 1 month. Serve with Vin Santo, dipping each cantucci for at least 2 seconds before eating.

Umbria.dish: Strangozzi al Tartufo Nero di Norcia
Umbria.description: Umbria's most prized dish: hand-rolled strangozzi (thick, rustic spaghetti with no eggs) dressed with a sauce of black truffle from Norcia, garlic, anchovy, and olive oil. The truffle of Norcia (tartufo nero pregiato) is shaved raw over the hot pasta so the heat releases its intoxicating aroma. This is cucina povera elevated by a luxury ingredient that grows wild in Umbria's oak forests.
ingredients: 14 oz strangozzi or thick spaghetti (400 g)
3 oz fresh black truffle (Tuber melanosporum), cleaned (85 g)
1/3 cup extra-virgin olive oil (80 ml), Umbrian (mild, buttery)
Salt and freshly ground black pepper
steps: Finely mince about one-third of the truffle. Shave the remaining two-thirds into thin slices with a truffle slicer or mandoline. Set aside.

Warm the olive oil in a large skillet over very low heat. Add the crushed garlic and anchovy fillets. Cook gently, stirring, until the anchovies dissolve into the oil and the garlic is fragrant but not colored, about 3 minutes. Remove garlic.
Add the minced truffle to the oil. Stir for 30 seconds—no more. Remove from heat.
Cook the strangozzi in generously salted boiling water until al dente. Reserve 1/2 cup pasta water, then drain.

Toss the hot pasta in the truffle oil, adding splashes of pasta water to create a silky coating. Plate immediately, then shower each serving with the shaved truffle slices. Serve at once—the truffle aroma fades quickly.

drink.description: Umbria's ancient dessert wine made from Sagrantino grapes (one of the most tannic varieties on earth) dried on racks and vinified into a dense, sweet, garnet-colored wine with flavors of blackberry, fig, and dried roses. Traditionally served at Easter and Christmas.
ingredients: 2–3 oz (60–90 ml) Sagrantino di Montefalco Passito DOCG, served at 60°F (16°C)
steps: Serve in small glasses at slightly below room temperature.
Pair with dark chocolate, aged pecorino, or dried fruit. The massive tannins and sweetness create a wine of extraordinary complexity.
Sip slowly—this is one of Italy's rarest and most powerful dessert wines.

dessert.description: The Torciglione is one of the most theatrical and least-known desserts in Italy — an almond serpent from Perugia, coiled in an S-curve with a red cherry eye, scales pressed from a fork into its almond-paste body, baked golden and glistening. It is a Carnival sweet, made throughout Umbria in the weeks before Lent — and the serpent shape is deliberately provocative: it references both the ancient Etruscan serpent cult (Umbria sits on the heartland of the old Etruscan civilization) and the Christian symbolism of temptation. Perhaps the baker is saying that even the serpent can be beautiful and sweet. The paste is pure almond — ground almonds, sugar, egg whites, and a splash of anise liqueur — shaped entirely by hand into the snake form, the scales impressed with the tines of a fork, the tongue a split almond sliver, the eye a candied cherry glowing red. It is dense, moist, intensely almond-sweet with the fragrance of anise, and it keeps for two weeks wrapped in cloth. Every pasticceria in Perugia and every nonna's kitchen makes one for Carnival.
ingredients: 2 1/2 cups (250 g) blanched almond flour or very finely ground blanched almonds
2 tbsp anise liqueur (Mistra or Sambuca) or 1 tsp anise extract
Powdered sugar as needed for consistency
For decoration: 1 glacé cherry (for the eye), 2 sliced almonds (for the tongue/head), 1 egg yolk beaten for glaze
steps: In a large bowl, combine the ground almonds and granulated sugar. Add the egg whites, anise liqueur, lemon zest, and almond extract. Mix with your hands until a firm, smooth paste forms. If the mixture is too sticky, knead in a tablespoon of powdered sugar. The paste should hold its shape when molded and not be tacky. Wrap and refrigerate 30 minutes.
Preheat the oven to 325°F (165°C). Line a baking sheet with parchment paper.

On a surface dusted with powdered sugar, roll the paste with your hands into a long, even cylinder about 18 inches (45 cm) long and 1.5 inches (4 cm) in diameter, tapering slightly at one end (the tail). Shape one end into a wider, flatter head.

Coil the snake onto the prepared baking sheet in an S-shape, lifting the head end slightly. Using a fork, press scales all along the body by lightly pressing and dragging the tines. Shape the head area: press in the glacé cherry for the eye, and press two sliced almond slivers into the mouth area for the tongue.
Brush the entire snake gently but thoroughly with the beaten egg yolk glaze.

Bake for 20–25 minutes until golden-amber. The torciglione should be firm outside but still slightly soft inside. Cool completely on the baking sheet — do not move while warm. Serve at room temperature, displayed whole for the table and then broken into pieces. Keeps 10–14 days wrapped in parchment at room temperature.

Marche.description: The great Adriatic fish stew of Ancona: at least 13 varieties of fish and shellfish (by tradition), simmered in a saffron-tinged tomato broth sharpened with white wine vinegar. Every family in Ancona has their own recipe, but the rule is firm—no garlic, no onion, and the fish are added in order of how long they take to cook so nothing is overdone. This is fisherman's food refined by generations of coastal wisdom.
ingredients: 3 lbs mixed Adriatic-style fish and shellfish (1.4 kg): red mullet, monkfish, cuttlefish, mantis shrimp (or large shrimp), scorpionfish or rockfish, sole, clams, mussels
1 lb ripe tomatoes, peeled and chopped (or 14 oz canned San Marzano) (450 g)
Pinch of saffron threads, steeped in 2 tbsp warm water
Salt and freshly ground black pepper
Crusty bread, toasted and rubbed with garlic, for serving
steps: Clean all fish: scale, gut, and cut large fish into chunks; clean cuttlefish and cut into rings; scrub clams and mussels. Keep each type separate—they cook at different rates.
In a wide, heavy terracotta pot or Dutch oven, heat the olive oil over medium heat. Add the cuttlefish (it takes longest) and cook 5 minutes, stirring. Add the vinegar and let it evaporate.
Add the tomatoes and saffron water. Season with salt and pepper. Simmer gently 15 minutes.
Add the firm-fleshed fish (monkfish, scorpionfish) to the pot. Simmer 5 minutes.
Add the medium fish (red mullet, sole) and the shrimp. Simmer 5 minutes.
Add the clams and mussels on top, cover, and cook 3–5 minutes until they open. Discard any that stay closed.
Scatter with fresh parsley. Bring the pot to the table—brodetto is always served from the cooking vessel. Ladle into bowls over toasted, garlic-rubbed bread.

drink.description: An ancient Marchigiano tradition predating the Romans: fresh grape must is slowly cooked down to a fraction of its volume, then aged in small barrels for years. The result is a dark, syrupy, bittersweet elixir used as a sipping digestivo or drizzled over cheese. Every farmhouse in the Marche hills makes its own.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) Vino Cotto delle Marche, served at room temperature
steps: Pour into a small digestivo glass at room temperature.
Sip after dinner alongside aged pecorino or biscotti. The flavors recall dried figs, caramel, and dark fruit with a balancing bitterness.
Alternatively, drizzle a spoonful over vanilla gelato or roasted pears.

dessert.description: The Frustingo (also spelled Pristinaccio or Pistinaccio in different Marchigian valleys) is one of the most ancient cakes in Italy — a dense, dark fruit cake from the Marche that was already documented in the 14th century and has been made at Christmas ever since. It is made with dried figs from Fabriano's fig orchards, boiled soft and mashed with cocoa or chocolate, grape must (mosto cotto or sapa — the dark, sweet, reduced juice of pressed grapes, a condiment of antiquity), walnuts, almonds, pine nuts, raisins, orange zest, anise seeds, cinnamon, and cloves. Olive oil binds it, not butter. The result is a dense, glistening, intensely flavored slab — black as midnight, fragrant as a spice cabinet, sweet from the figs and mosto, complex from the nuts and spice. It is not decorative — it is serious and ancient. Eaten in thin slices at Christmas with a glass of passito Piceno. Each family in Ascoli Piceno, Macerata, and Ancona has its own version, jealously guarded.
ingredients: 1 lb (450 g) dried figs, stems removed, roughly chopped
1/3 cup (80 ml) mosto cotto or sapa (or substitute: 3 tbsp dark honey + 2 tbsp pomegranate molasses)
3/4 cup (90 g) walnuts, toasted and roughly chopped
1/2 cup (50 g) blanched almonds, toasted and roughly chopped
1/2 cup (80 g) raisins, soaked in warm water 15 minutes and drained
1 oz (30 g) dark chocolate, finely grated
Powdered sugar and a few whole almonds for the top
steps: Cook the figs: Place the chopped dried figs in a saucepan with the water. Cook over medium heat, stirring, for 15–20 minutes until the figs are very soft and have broken down to a thick paste, most of the water absorbed. Remove from heat and let cool slightly.
Preheat the oven to 350°F (175°C). Oil a 9-inch (23 cm) round cake pan or line with parchment.

In a large bowl, combine the fig paste with the mosto cotto, walnuts, almonds, pine nuts, raisins, cocoa powder, grated chocolate, orange zest, anise seeds, cinnamon, cloves, olive oil, and breadcrumbs. Mix thoroughly with your hands or a wooden spoon until completely combined — the mixture will be very stiff, dense, and fragrant. Taste and adjust sweetness or spice.
Press the mixture firmly into the prepared pan, smoothing the top with wet hands. Press whole almonds in a decorative pattern into the surface.

Bake for 30–40 minutes until the top is dry and beginning to crack slightly, and the edges pull slightly from the pan. It will not rise. Cool completely in the pan — the frustingo firms up significantly as it cools.

Unmold carefully. Dust with powdered sugar. Serve in thin slices — it is rich and a small slice goes a long way. Keeps wrapped at room temperature for up to 2 weeks; it improves over the first 3–4 days.

Lazio.description: Rome's most deceptively simple masterpiece: tonnarelli or rigatoni, Pecorino Romano, black pepper, and starchy pasta water—nothing else. The alchemy is in the technique: creating an emulsion of cheese, fat, and starch that clings to each strand in a creamy, peppery coat without clumping. Roman trattorias guard their exact method. The pepper is toasted whole in the pan, the cheese is added off-heat, and the pasta water must be concentrated and starchy.
ingredients: 14 oz tonnarelli, rigatoni, or thick spaghetti (400 g)
2 cups finely grated Pecorino Romano DOP (200 g)
1 1/2 tbsp whole black peppercorns, freshly cracked (coarse)
steps: Bring a pot of water to a boil. Use LESS water than usual (about 3 quarts for 14 oz pasta)—you want extra-starchy cooking water. Salt lightly (the Pecorino is very salty).

Toast the cracked peppercorns in a large dry skillet over medium heat for 1–2 minutes until fragrant and smoking slightly. Add 1 ladle (about 3/4 cup) of the starchy pasta water to the pepper pan. Let it simmer and reduce by half.
Meanwhile, cook the pasta until 1–2 minutes short of al dente. Reserve 2 cups of pasta water before draining.
Transfer the pasta to the pepper pan with tongs. Toss over medium heat, adding splashes of pasta water, until the pasta finishes cooking in the pan and the liquid is starchy and slightly thickened.

REMOVE THE PAN FROM HEAT. Wait 30 seconds (the pan must not be screaming hot). Add the Pecorino in three additions, tossing vigorously between each, adding small splashes of pasta water to keep the sauce fluid. The cheese should melt into a creamy, emulsified sauce—not clumpy or greasy.
Serve immediately on warm plates with an extra crack of pepper. Do not add oil, butter, cream, or Parmigiano—ever.

drink.description: Rome's original shaved-ice drink, sold from chioschi (kiosks) along the Tiber since the 1800s. A block of ice is hand-scraped with a metal blade, then doused with fresh fruit syrups and topped with chunks of fresh fruit. Grattachecca is not a granita—the ice is coarser, fluffier, and the toppings are generous.
ingredients: 2 cups shaved or crushed ice (from a block, not machine-made)
3 tbsp fresh lemon or amarena cherry syrup
2 tbsp fresh seasonal fruit (peach, strawberry, or coconut), diced
steps: Scrape a block of ice with a metal scraper (or use coarsely crushed ice) into a tall cup.
Pour the syrup generously over the ice. Add the diced fruit and a squeeze of lemon.
Eat with a spoon and straw on a hot Roman evening, preferably walking along the Lungotevere.

dessert.description: The Maritozzo is Rome's great sweet bun and one of the oldest street foods in the city — documented since the Middle Ages, when sweetened buns stuffed with raisins, pine nuts, and candied peel were sold from carts near the churches of the Forum on the first Friday of Lent. The modern Maritozzo con la Panna is simpler and more perfect: a soft, slightly sweet, golden brioche-adjacent bun, split down the middle and generously, almost violently, filled with unsweetened fresh whipped cream that piles high above the bun like a snowdrift. The bun is brushed with sugar syrup to give it a gloss and gentle sweetness; the cream inside is pure and cold; the contrast between warm bun and cold cream is everything. Romans eat maritozzi at breakfast, in pasticcerie that have been making them the same way since the 1950s, standing at the bar with an espresso, getting cream on their jacket with no particular concern. It is one of the great breakfasts of the world.
ingredients: For the maritozzi dough: 2 1/4 tsp (7 g) instant yeast, 1/3 cup (80 ml) warm milk, 3 cups (375 g) all-purpose flour, 1/3 cup (65 g) granulated sugar, 2 large eggs, 6 tbsp (85 g) unsalted butter, softened, 1 tsp orange zest, 1 tsp vanilla extract, 1/2 tsp fine sea salt, 1/3 cup (50 g) raisins, 2 tbsp pine nuts (optional, for the traditional version)
For the sugar glaze: 3 tbsp water + 2 tbsp sugar, simmered together until sugar dissolves
For the filling: 2 cups (480 ml) heavy whipping cream, very cold, 2 tbsp powdered sugar, 1 tsp vanilla extract
steps: Make the dough: Dissolve the yeast in the warm milk with a pinch of sugar; let sit 10 minutes. In a stand mixer with the dough hook, combine the flour, sugar, and salt. Add the eggs, yeast mixture, orange zest, and vanilla. Mix on low 2 minutes, then medium for 5 minutes until the dough becomes smooth. Add the softened butter, one tablespoon at a time, mixing well after each. Add the raisins and pine nuts. Knead 8 more minutes until the dough is smooth, glossy, and elastic. Cover and rise at room temperature 1.5–2 hours until doubled.

Shape the maritozzi: Divide the dough into 8–10 equal pieces (each about 70–80 g). Roll each into a smooth oval shape about 4 inches (10 cm) long. Place on parchment-lined baking sheets, spacing apart. Cover and rise 45–60 minutes until puffed and pillowy.

Preheat the oven to 375°F (190°C). Bake for 14–16 minutes until golden brown. Remove from the oven. Immediately brush with the warm sugar glaze — use it all, coating each bun generously. Transfer to a rack and cool completely.
Whip the cold cream with the powdered sugar and vanilla to firm peaks.

To assemble: Using a serrated knife, cut each bun almost in half lengthwise, keeping one long side intact (do not cut all the way through — leave a hinge). Open gently. Pipe or spoon the whipped cream in a generous, towering dome into the bun — it should overflow well above the top of the bun. Smooth the outside if desired, or leave it rustic. Eat immediately — within minutes of filling.

Abruzzo.description: Tiny lamb skewers from the Gran Sasso highlands: cubes of castrato (yearling sheep) threaded on thin wooden sticks and grilled over a special half-pipe charcoal brazier called a fornacella. The meat is seasoned with nothing but salt—the quality of the lamb speaks for itself. Abruzzese shepherds have cooked these on hillsides for centuries. The key is small cubes (3/4 inch), high heat, and constant turning.
ingredients: 2 lbs boneless lamb leg or shoulder, cut into 3/4-inch cubes (900 g)
Thin wooden skewers (8-inch), soaked in water 30 minutes
steps: Cut the lamb into uniform 3/4-inch cubes, keeping some fat on each piece (the fat bastes the meat as it grills). Thread 5–6 cubes tightly onto each soaked wooden skewer.

Prepare a hot charcoal grill. If you have a fornacella (half-pipe grill), set it up so the skewers rest across the top with the handles extending off the edge. Otherwise, use a standard grill at maximum heat.
Grill the arrosticini close to the coals, turning every 30–45 seconds, for a total of 4–6 minutes. The exterior should char lightly while the interior stays juicy and pink.
Season with fine sea salt immediately upon pulling from the grill. Serve in bundles of 10–15 per person, with crusty bread to mop up the juices and olive oil for dipping. Eat with your hands.

drink.description: A centuries-old Abruzzese cherry liqueur: sour Amarena cherries macerated in Montepulciano d'Abruzzo wine and sugar for months in the summer sun, then strained into a deep ruby digestivo. Made by nonne (grandmothers) across the region every July when the cherries ripen.
ingredients: 2 lbs sour cherries (amarene), stemmed, not pitted (900 g)
steps: Place the cherries in a large glass jar. Add the sugar, cinnamon, and cloves. Pour over the wine. Seal tightly.
Set the jar in a sunny spot (a windowsill or terrace) for 40 days, shaking gently every few days to dissolve the sugar.
After 40 days, strain through cheesecloth into bottles. Discard the cherries (or save for desserts). Age at least 2 weeks before serving.
Serve cold in small glasses as a digestivo.

dessert.description: The Parrozzo is Abruzzo's greatest confection — a dome-shaped cake that was created in 1920 by Luigi D'Amico, confectioner of Pescara, inspired by the pane rozzo (rough bread) of Abruzzo's mountain shepherds, covered in dark chocolate to evoke the charred crust of the bread baked in ash. He sent the first one to Gabriele d'Annunzio, Pescara's most famous poet, who ate it on Christmas morning 1920 and wrote a sonnet of praise in Abruzzese dialect that D'Amico printed on every box thereafter. The original Parrozzo is still made under license by one confectionery family in Pescara. The cake itself: a dome of coarse semolina and ground almonds enriched with egg yolks and butter, lemon-scented, entirely yellow-gold inside like the polenta of the mountains. The outside is completely coated in a thick shell of bittersweet dark chocolate ganache. The first bite breaks through the hard chocolate to the moist, almond-scented, yellow interior. It is the most lyrical cake in Italy.
ingredients: For the cake: 1 cup (100 g) blanched almond flour (ground almonds), 1/2 cup (85 g) fine semolina (semola rimacinata), 3/4 cup (150 g) granulated sugar, 6 large eggs, separated, 1/4 cup (55 g) unsalted butter, melted, Zest of 1 lemon, 1 tsp pure vanilla extract, Pinch of fine sea salt
For the chocolate coating: 10 oz (280 g) high-quality dark chocolate (65–70% cacao), finely chopped, 1/2 cup (120 ml) heavy cream, 1 tbsp unsalted butter
steps: Preheat the oven to 350°F (175°C). Butter and flour a 7-inch (18 cm) dome mold (or a Bundt pan with only the center tube portion, or a very rounded bowl). Alternatively, use a 9-inch (23 cm) round cake pan — the dome shape is traditional but the flavor is the same.
Beat the egg yolks with 1/2 cup (100 g) of the sugar until very pale, thick, and creamy — at least 4 minutes. Beat in the melted butter, lemon zest, and vanilla.
Combine the almond flour and semolina; fold into the yolk mixture until combined.

In a clean bowl, beat the egg whites with the salt to soft peaks. Gradually add the remaining 1/4 cup (50 g) sugar and beat to firm, glossy peaks. Fold the whites into the almond batter in three additions, gently and deliberately preserving the volume.
Pour into the prepared mold and smooth the top. Bake for 30–35 minutes until golden and a skewer comes out clean. Cool in the mold 20 minutes, then unmold and cool completely on a rack.

Make the chocolate coating: Heat the cream until simmering. Pour over the chopped chocolate in a bowl. Let sit 2 minutes, then stir from the center until completely smooth. Add the butter and stir until incorporated. Cool to room temperature until the ganache is thick enough to coat — about 30–40 minutes. Place the cooled cake on a rack over a tray. Pour the ganache over, coating completely. Let set at room temperature for 1 hour. Do not refrigerate — the chocolate should remain glossy and at room temperature.

Molise.description: Molise's soul food: hand-shaped cavatelli pasta (small, ridged shells made from semolina and water, no eggs) simmered in a slow-cooked lamb ragù fragrant with peperoncino and fresh rosemary. Molise is Italy's forgotten region—its cuisine is pastoral, deeply honest, and rooted in the transhumance shepherding traditions of the Apennines.
ingredients: For cavatelli: 3 cups fine semolina flour (durum wheat, 360 g), 3/4 cup warm water (180 ml), pinch of salt

For ragù: 1.5 lbs bone-in lamb shoulder or neck, cut into chunks (680 g), 1/4 cup olive oil, 1 onion (chopped), 2 garlic cloves, 1/2 cup dry white wine (120 ml), 1 can (14 oz) crushed San Marzano tomatoes, 1 sprig rosemary, 1 dried peperoncino (crumbled), salt
Ragù di agnello (see Chef's Essentials below)
steps: Make cavatelli: Mound semolina on a board, make a well, add warm salted water. Mix and knead 10 minutes until smooth and firm. Rest 30 minutes under a towel.

Roll small pieces of dough into thin ropes (1/2 inch diameter). Cut into 1/2-inch pieces. Press each piece with two fingertips and drag toward you on the board—creating a small cupped shell with ridges. Set on a floured tray.

Make the ragù: Heat olive oil in a heavy pot. Brown the lamb chunks deeply on all sides, 8–10 minutes. Remove. Add onion, cook until soft. Add garlic, cook 1 minute. Return the lamb, pour in wine, let it evaporate.

Add crushed tomatoes, rosemary, peperoncino, and enough water to barely cover the meat. Bring to a simmer. Cover and cook over very low heat for 2–2.5 hours until the lamb falls from the bone. Shred the meat, discard bones, and return to the sauce. Adjust salt.
Cook cavatelli in generously salted boiling water 3–4 minutes until they float. Drain. Toss with the lamb ragù. Serve with generous grated Pecorino.

drink.description: A warming winter punch from Molise's mountain villages: espresso coffee spiked with local Strega-style herbal liqueur, sugar, and lemon peel, served hot on cold Apennine evenings. Every village has its own variation.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) freshly brewed espresso, hot
1 oz (30 ml) Strega or local herbal liqueur
steps: Brew a strong espresso. Stir the sugar into the hot coffee.
Add the Strega (or herbal liqueur) and stir.
Drop in the lemon peel and clove. Serve immediately in a small heat-proof glass.

dessert.dish: Mostaccioli Molisani al Miele e Fico
dessert.description: The Mostaccioli are among the oldest Christmas sweets still made in Italy — documented in Roman literature (Cato mentions a precursor in De Agri Cultura, 160 BC) and continuous in Italian tradition ever since. Molise's version is rustic, honest, and extraordinary: small diamond-shaped cookies made with toasted flour, locally harvested honey, dried figs from the Molisan valleys, walnuts, crushed almonds, cocoa, wine must, cinnamon, cloves, and black pepper. They are spiced like a medieval apothecary's pantry — because they originated there, in the tradition of the 'speziaro' (spice merchant) who sold these same cookies to pilgrims and travelers. The dough is pressed into molds or cut into diamond shapes and baked until dark and hard, then allowed to ripen for days in a tin — like a fruitcake, they improve with rest, the spices deepening, the honey becoming more complex. They are eaten in Molise at Christmas, dunked in wine or nibbled with coffee, and given as gifts wrapped in parchment tied with string.
ingredients: 2 cups (250 g) all-purpose flour, toasted in a dry pan until pale golden
1/2 cup (170 g) dark honey (chestnut or wildflower)
1/3 cup (80 ml) red or white wine (or grape must)
6 dried figs, stems removed and finely chopped
1/2 cup (60 g) walnuts, toasted and finely chopped
1/4 cup (30 g) blanched almonds, toasted and roughly chopped
steps: Warm the honey and wine together in a small saucepan over low heat until the honey is completely fluid and combined with the wine. Remove from heat and let cool slightly.

In a large bowl, combine the toasted flour, cocoa powder, cinnamon, cloves, pepper, baking soda, orange zest, figs, walnuts, and almonds. Stir to mix. Add the warm honey-wine mixture and the olive oil. Mix with a wooden spoon, then knead briefly with your hands until a stiff, dark, cohesive dough forms. It will be dense and sticky. Wrap and rest for 30 minutes.
Preheat the oven to 350°F (175°C). Line baking sheets with parchment paper.

On a lightly floured surface, roll the dough to about 1/2 inch (1.3 cm) thickness. Cut into diamond shapes about 2 inches (5 cm) long using a sharp knife or pastry cutter. Or press into traditional carved wooden molds dusted with flour.
Place the mostaccioli on the prepared baking sheets and bake for 12–15 minutes. They should be firm and set but not hard as rocks — they will harden further as they cool and age.
Cool on a rack. They are better after 2–3 days in an airtight tin, when the spices deepen and the texture becomes ideal. They keep for 3–4 weeks. Optionally dust with powdered sugar before serving.

Campania.description: Naples' Sunday ritual: a massive pot of tomato sauce cooked for 5–6 hours with whole cuts of beef, pork, sausage, and braciole (stuffed meat rolls). The sauce (la salsa) is served over pasta as a primo; the meats are served as a secondo. The secret of the ragù guardiano (the guardian of the pot) is the pippiare—the gentle, hypnotic bubbling that sounds like someone blowing kisses. It must never boil hard.
ingredients: 2 lbs beef chuck roast, in one piece (900 g)
4 braciole: thin slices of beef top round, each stuffed with raisins, pine nuts, garlic, and parsley, rolled and tied
4 cans (28 oz each) San Marzano whole peeled tomatoes, crushed by hand
1 lb ziti or rigatoni for serving (450 g)
steps: Season all the meats with salt. In a very large, heavy pot, heat the olive oil over medium-high heat. Brown the meats in batches—deeply and on all sides. Set aside.
Reduce heat to medium. Add the onion and cook until deeply golden, about 10 minutes. Add the wine and scrape up the fond. Let the wine evaporate almost completely.
Add the tomato paste and stir for 2 minutes. Add all the crushed tomatoes and a handful of basil. Stir well, then return all the meats to the pot. The sauce should cover the meats.

Bring to the barest simmer—the surface should 'pippiate' (gently blip, not bubble violently). Cover with the lid slightly ajar. Cook for 5–6 hours over the lowest possible heat, stirring occasionally from the bottom to prevent sticking.
The ragù is done when the sauce is dark red, dense, and the meats are fork-tender. Remove the meats and set aside. Taste and salt the sauce.
Cook the ziti in salted boiling water until al dente. Toss with the sauce. Serve the pasta as a first course, followed by the sliced meats on a platter with more sauce.

drink.description: The lemon liqueur of the Amalfi Coast and Sorrento Peninsula, made from the thick, fragrant peels of Sfusato Amalfitano lemons, steeped in grain alcohol and sweetened with simple syrup. Always served ice-cold from the freezer in frozen ceramic cups.
ingredients: 1 bottle (750 ml) grain alcohol (190-proof) or vodka (100-proof)
steps: Peel the lemons with a vegetable peeler, taking only the yellow zest—no white pith (it makes the liqueur bitter).
Place the peels in a large glass jar. Pour over the alcohol. Seal and store in a cool, dark place for 10–15 days, shaking daily. The alcohol will turn bright yellow.
Make simple syrup: dissolve the sugar in the water over medium heat. Let cool completely.
Strain the lemon-infused alcohol through cheesecloth. Combine with the cooled syrup. Stir well. Bottle and store in the freezer for at least 1 week before serving.
Serve ice-cold in small frozen glasses after dinner.

dessert.description: The Sfogliatella is Naples' greatest pastry achievement and one of the most technically demanding confections in the world. Invented in the 17th century by the nuns of the Santa Rosa convent on the Amalfi Coast and reinvented in Naples by pastry maestro Pasquale Pintauro in 1818, the sfogliatella riccia (curly) is a shell of pastry that contains multitudes: dozens of water-thin, crisp, separate layers of pastry — each one individually lacquered with lard — fanned out and formed into a ridged cone shape that mimics a ribbed seashell. Inside is a filling of ricotta, semolina cooked in milk, sugar, egg, candied orange peel, cinnamon, and a drop of vanilla — cooked to a dense, aromatic custard-cream. The sfogliatella must be eaten very fresh, very warm, just out of the oven, when the layers are still shatteringly crisp and the filling is still warm. Cold sfogliatelle are a tragedy. In Naples they are eaten at 7am with an espresso, purchased from the oldest pasticcerie in the city — places where the trays come out of the oven every hour and the line forms before the shop opens.
ingredients: For the pastry dough (this makes the laminated shell): 3 cups (375 g) semolina flour (or all-purpose flour), 3/4 cup (180 ml) warm water, 1/2 tsp fine sea salt, 1 tsp honey
For laminating: 3/4 cup (170 g) high-quality lard (or solid shortening — lard gives the authentic crunch), softened to spreading consistency

For the ricotta filling: 1 cup (250 g) whole-milk ricotta, very well-drained overnight, 1/2 cup (85 g) fine semolina, 1 cup (240 ml) whole milk, 1/2 cup (100 g) granulated sugar, 1 egg, Zest of 1 orange, 1/2 tsp ground cinnamon, 1 tsp vanilla extract, 2 tbsp candied orange peel, finely chopped
steps: Make the filling first (it must be cold): In a saucepan, bring the milk to a simmer. Whisk in the semolina in a thin stream. Cook, stirring constantly, until very thick. Remove from heat, add the sugar, stir to dissolve. Cool to lukewarm. Beat the ricotta smooth. Combine ricotta, semolina mixture, egg, orange zest, cinnamon, vanilla, and candied peel. Mix thoroughly. Press plastic wrap on the surface and refrigerate until completely cold (at least 2 hours).

Make and laminate the dough: Combine the flour, water, salt, and honey to a stiff, smooth dough. Knead 10 minutes until very elastic. Wrap and rest 30 minutes. On a clean surface, roll or stretch the dough as thin as possible into a long rectangle — paper-thin. Spread the softened lard over the entire surface in a thin, even layer. Roll the dough up very tightly into a log from a long side. Wrap in plastic and refrigerate 1 hour.

Preheat the oven to 400°F (200°C). Slice the chilled log into 1/2-inch (1.3 cm) rounds. Working with one round at a time (keep others refrigerated), press the center with your thumb and expand the circle with rotating pressure from your fingers, stretching and rotating to create a cone shape — the layers fan out into a shell. Press the layers together slightly at the tip.
Fill each cone with 1 heaping tablespoon of the cold ricotta filling. Press the open end closed, pinching the layers together firmly but leaving the ridged exterior visible.

Place on a parchment-lined baking sheet. Brush with a thin coat of lard. Bake 20–25 minutes until deep golden-brown and crisp — the layers should visibly separate and the entire pastry should look like a ridged fan shell. Dust with powdered sugar immediately upon removing from the oven. Eat within 30 minutes of baking.

Puglia.description: The iconic pasta of Puglia: 'little ears' hand-shaped from semolina dough, tossed with bitter broccoli rabe (cime di rapa), garlic, peperoncino, anchovy, and olive oil. In Bari Vecchia's old town, women still sit in doorways shaping orecchiette on wooden boards. The technique of dragging the dough with a butter knife creates the concave ear shape with a rough surface that grips the sauce.
ingredients: For orecchiette: 2 cups fine semolina flour (240 g), 1 cup all-purpose flour (120 g), 3/4 cup warm water (180 ml), pinch of salt
1 large bunch broccoli rabe (cime di rapa), about 1.5 lbs (680 g), tough stems trimmed
1 dried peperoncino, crumbled (or 1/2 tsp red pepper flakes)
1/3 cup extra-virgin olive oil (80 ml), Pugliese
Grated Pecorino or toasted breadcrumbs for serving
steps: Make orecchiette: Mix the flours. Make a well, add warm salted water. Knead 10 minutes until smooth and firm. Rest 30 minutes. Roll into thin ropes (1/2 inch diameter). Cut 1/2-inch pieces. Using a butter knife, press and drag each piece across the board to form a concave disk, then invert it over your thumb to create the ear shape. Set on a floured tray.

Prepare the cime di rapa: Bring a large pot of well-salted water to a boil. Add the broccoli rabe and cook 3–4 minutes until tender but still bright green. Remove with a slotted spoon (keep the water boiling for the pasta). Chop roughly.
Cook the orecchiette in the same broccoli rabe water until they float and are al dente, about 8–10 minutes for fresh. Reserve 1 cup pasta water before draining.
In a large skillet, heat the olive oil over medium heat. Add garlic and peperoncino. When the garlic begins to color, add the anchovies, stirring until they dissolve.
Add the chopped cime di rapa to the skillet. Toss for 2 minutes. Add the drained orecchiette and toss together, adding splashes of pasta water until everything is glossy and saucy.
Serve with grated Pecorino or a shower of golden toasted breadcrumbs (the 'poor man's Parmigiano' of Puglia).

drink.description: Lecce's signature iced coffee: a shot of espresso poured over ice with latte di mandorla (sweet almond milk). Born in Salento's scorching summers, it's the most refreshing way to drink coffee in Italy—sweet, nutty, and cold.
ingredients: 3 oz (90 ml) latte di mandorla (Italian almond milk, sweetened)
steps: Fill a small glass with ice cubes.
Pour the almond milk over the ice.
Pull a fresh shot of espresso and pour it directly over the ice and almond milk. The hot espresso hitting the cold milk creates a beautiful marbled effect.
Stir gently and drink through a straw. In Lecce, this is ordered simply as 'caffè con ghiaccio e latte di mandorla.'

dessert.description: The Pasticciotto is Lecce's extraordinary gift to Italian pastry — and Lecce protects it with the same provincial pride with which the city protects its baroque architecture. It was created in 1745 by Nicola Ascalone, the confectioner of Galatina, who made a small oval pastry of frolla (Leccese shortcrust) filled with crema pasteliera, baked until golden. The Pasticciotto leccese's crust is its own distinct tradition: made with lard (not butter), strutto di maiale, which gives it a crumbly, melt-on-the-tongue texture unlike any other pastry shell in Italy — simultaneously more delicate and more substantial. The filling is pastry cream: egg yolks, sugar, flour, and milk, cooked until thick and fragrant with vanilla and lemon. The combination is perfect: cool, eggy cream inside a warm, crumbling, lard-enriched shell. In Lecce, Pasticciotto is the only acceptable breakfast — eaten standing at the bar at 7:30am with a caffè leccese (espresso poured over almond milk and ice), the entire Salento peninsula waking up around it.
ingredients: For the Leccese frolla (pastry): 2 1/2 cups (315 g) all-purpose flour, 3/4 cup (170 g) good lard (strutto), at room temperature, 3/4 cup (90 g) powdered sugar, 2 egg yolks, 2 tbsp cold water, Zest of 1 lemon, Pinch of fine sea salt, 1/2 tsp baking powder

For the pastry cream filling: 2 cups (480 ml) whole milk, 5 large egg yolks, 2/3 cup (130 g) granulated sugar, 1/3 cup (40 g) all-purpose flour (or cornstarch), 1 tsp pure vanilla extract, Zest of 1/2 lemon
1 egg yolk beaten with 1 tbsp milk for glazing
steps: Make the pastry cream: Heat the milk until just steaming. Whisk the yolks with the sugar until pale; whisk in the flour and lemon zest. Slowly pour the hot milk into the yolk mixture, whisking. Return to the saucepan over medium heat, whisking constantly, until the cream thickens and just bubbles. Cook 1 minute more, add vanilla. Press plastic wrap on the surface and refrigerate until completely cold.

Make the frolla: Beat the lard with the powdered sugar until smooth and creamy. Beat in the egg yolks, lemon zest, and water. Add the flour, baking powder, and salt. Mix until a cohesive dough forms — do not overwork. Wrap and refrigerate 30 minutes.
Preheat the oven to 375°F (190°C). Butter 8–10 oval pasticciotto molds (about 3.5x2.5 inches / 9x6 cm) or a muffin tin.

Divide the dough into two portions. Roll the first portion to 3–4mm thickness. Cut ovals slightly larger than the molds and press into each mold, pressing up the sides. Fill each with 2 generous tablespoons of cold pastry cream, mounding it slightly above the pastry rim.
Roll the second portion and cut oval tops to fit. Press the edges firmly to seal, trimming excess. Brush the tops with the egg glaze.

Bake for 20–25 minutes until the tops are a deep, even amber-gold. Cool in the molds 5 minutes, then unmold carefully onto a rack. The Pasticciotto is traditionally eaten warm, within 1–2 hours of baking, but can be refrigerated and gently warmed.

Basilicata.description: An ancient Lucanian dish dating to the Romans (Horace mentions laganum, the ancestor of lasagna): wide, flat, hand-cut pasta cooked with chickpeas, garlic, rosemary, and peperoncino in olive oil. Basilicata is one of Italy's poorest and least-known regions, and this dish embodies the genius of cucina povera—four or five humble ingredients transformed by technique into something deeply satisfying.
ingredients: For lagane: 2 cups semolina flour (240 g), 3/4 cup warm water (180 ml), pinch of salt
1 1/2 cups dried chickpeas, soaked overnight (or 2 cans, drained) (300 g dried)
Extra-virgin olive oil (Lucanian, peppery) for drizzling
steps: If using dried chickpeas: drain soaked chickpeas, place in a pot, cover with fresh water by 3 inches, add a bay leaf and simmer 1.5–2 hours until creamy-tender. Reserve 2 cups cooking liquid.

Make lagane: Knead semolina, water, and salt into a firm dough for 10 minutes. Rest 30 minutes. Roll out to 1/16 inch thick. Cut into wide strips (about 1 inch x 3 inches). Let dry on a floured tray for 15 minutes.
In a wide pan, heat the olive oil over medium heat. Add garlic, rosemary, and peperoncino. Cook until the garlic is golden and fragrant, 2 minutes.

Add two-thirds of the chickpeas with 1.5 cups of their cooking liquid. Simmer 10 minutes. Roughly mash the remaining one-third of chickpeas and stir them in—this thickens the sauce into a creamy base.

Cook the lagane in generously salted boiling water for 3–4 minutes until al dente. Drain and add to the chickpea pan. Toss together, adding more cooking liquid if needed—the consistency should be soupy-saucy, not dry.
Serve in warm bowls with a generous drizzle of raw olive oil and a crack of black pepper.

drink.description: Basilicata's most famous export: a bittersweet herbal digestivo made in Pisticci since 1894 from a secret blend of over 30 herbs and roots. Served neat, over ice, or with a splash of soda.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) Amaro Lucano, chilled or room temperature
steps: Pour the Amaro Lucano into a small tumbler—neat, over ice, or with a lemon twist.
Sip slowly after a meal as a digestivo. The flavors of wormwood, elderflower, and bitter orange unfold with each sip.

dessert.description: The Strazzate are the ancient diamond-shaped walnut and chocolate cookies of Matera — the sassi city of Basilicata, one of the oldest continuously inhabited places in the world, where humans have carved homes into the tufa limestone for 9,000 years. The Strazzate (from stracciare — 'to tear') are believed to originate in the medieval spice trade that brought cocoa and cinnamon to the deep South through the great fairs of Matera. They are small, hard, diamond-shaped cookies made with walnut flour, cocoa or grated chocolate, honey, cinnamon, cloves, citrus zest, and enough egg and flour to hold them together. They are neither soft nor yielding: they are meant to be kept for weeks, hardening over time as the spices deepen, meant to be nibbled slowly, dunked in wine or sweet liqueur, found in ceramic jars on the windowsills of Matera's ancient cave-houses. They taste of the deep South: intense, spiced, dark, and honest.
ingredients: 1 oz (30 g) dark chocolate, finely grated
1 tbsp red wine or Aglianico wine (optional)
steps: Toast the walnuts in a dry skillet or 350°F (175°C) oven for 8–10 minutes until fragrant. Cool completely. In a food processor, pulse the walnuts to a coarse, sandy texture — not a paste; you want texture and small visible pieces.
In a large bowl, combine the flour, cocoa, sugar, cinnamon, cloves, baking powder, salt, orange and lemon zest, and grated chocolate. Add the ground walnuts and stir to combine.
Add the eggs, honey, and wine if using. Mix with your hands until a stiff, slightly sticky dough forms. If too dry, add 1–2 tbsp water. The dough should just hold together when pressed.

Preheat the oven to 350°F (175°C). Line baking sheets with parchment. On a floured surface, roll the dough to about 1/2 inch (1.3 cm) thickness. Using a sharp knife or pastry cutter, cut into diamond shapes about 2 inches (5 cm) long.
Place on the prepared baking sheets. Bake for 15–18 minutes until set and firm but not quite hard — they will harden further as they cool.
Cool completely on a rack. Store in an airtight tin for up to 3 weeks — they improve with at least 2–3 days of resting. Serve with Aglianico passito or a small glass of fernet.

Calabria.dish: Fileja con 'Nduja e Cipolla di Tropea
Calabria.description: Calabria in a single dish: hand-rolled fileja pasta (twisted around a knitting needle or thin stick) tossed with 'nduja—Calabria's infamous spicy, spreadable salami from Spilinga—and sweet red onions of Tropea. The 'nduja melts into the olive oil to create a fiery, porky sauce that clings to the spiral ridges of the fileja. This is bold, unapologetic, heat-forward cooking.
ingredients: 14 oz fileja pasta (or fusilli, gemelli) (400 g)
2 medium Tropea onions (or red onions), thinly sliced
Grated Pecorino Crotonese or Ricotta Salata for serving
steps: Heat olive oil in a large skillet over medium-low heat. Add the sliced Tropea onions and cook very slowly, 10–12 minutes, until soft, sweet, and lightly caramelized. Season with a pinch of salt.
Add the cherry tomatoes and cook 3–4 minutes until they begin to soften.
Remove the pan from direct heat. Add the 'nduja in chunks and stir—it will melt into the oil and onions, creating a fiery, rust-colored sauce. If it seems thick, add a ladleful of pasta water.
Cook the fileja in generously salted boiling water until al dente. Reserve 1 cup pasta water, then drain.
Toss the fileja in the 'nduja sauce, adding splashes of pasta water until the sauce clings to the pasta in a glossy coat. Tear in basil leaves.
Serve with shaved Pecorino Crotonese or crumbled Ricotta Salata.

drink.description: A luminous citrus liqueur from the Calabrian Ionian coast, the only place on earth where bergamot oranges grow naturally. The intensely aromatic peel is steeped in alcohol and sweetened—the result is floral, citrusy, and utterly unique. Served ice-cold as a digestivo.
ingredients: 2 cups (480 ml) grain alcohol or high-proof vodka
steps: Peel the bergamots, taking only the fragrant zest (no pith). Place peels in a jar with the alcohol. Seal and steep 7–10 days in a dark place.
Make syrup: dissolve sugar in water over heat. Cool completely.
Strain the infused alcohol, combine with syrup. Bottle. Rest in the freezer 1 week.
Serve ice-cold in small glasses. The aroma is Earl Grey tea's soul, distilled.

dessert.description: The Pitta 'Mpigliata is Calabria's most extraordinary, most labor-intensive, and most ancient Christmas confection — a pinwheel or crown of yeasted pastry filled with a dense mixture of figs, walnuts, raisins, honey, cloves, cinnamon, and dark chocolate, drizzled in honey and crowned with colored sugar. The name means 'entangled pastry' in Calabrian dialect, and the visual is immediately clear: small circles of pasta frolla or yeasted dough are filled with the nut-fig-honey mixture and folded up into little open-topped pockets, arranged in a crown or flower formation, then baked golden and immediately drenched in warm honey. The effect is architectural and baroque, like the churches of the Cosenza and Reggio Calabria province. It originates from San Giovanni in Fiore, a town in the Sila massif, and it is said to have been made there since the 14th century, each family passing the recipe from grandmother to granddaughter in a direct line. Calabria will not let it go.
ingredients: For the pastry: 2 1/2 cups (315 g) all-purpose flour, 1/3 cup (65 g) granulated sugar, 1/2 cup (115 g) unsalted butter, softened, 1 egg, 1/4 cup (60 ml) white wine, Zest of 1 orange, 1/2 tsp baking powder, Pinch of salt

For the filling: 1 cup (150 g) dried figs, stems removed, very finely chopped, 3/4 cup (75 g) walnuts, toasted and finely chopped, 1/4 cup (35 g) raisins, 2 tbsp dark honey, 1 oz (30 g) dark chocolate, grated, 1/2 tsp ground cinnamon, 1/4 tsp ground cloves, Zest of 1/2 orange, 2 tbsp orange marmalade
For finishing: 1/2 cup (170 g) honey for drizzling, colored nonpareils or sesame seeds for decoration
steps: Make the filling: Combine all filling ingredients in a bowl and mix thoroughly. The mixture should be very dense and fragrant, holding together when pressed. Taste and adjust spices. Set aside.
Make the pastry: Beat the butter and sugar until smooth. Beat in the egg, white wine, and orange zest. Add the flour, baking powder, and salt; mix to a smooth dough. Wrap and refrigerate 30 minutes.
Preheat the oven to 350°F (175°C). On a floured surface, roll the pastry to 3mm thickness. Cut into circles about 4 inches (10 cm) in diameter.

Place 1 heaping tablespoon of filling in the center of each circle. Fold the edges up and pinch into a small, open-topped cup with pleated sides — like a little crown or flower. The filling should be visible on top.

Arrange the pittas close together in a ring on a parchment-lined baking sheet, touching each other so they bake into a connected crown (or bake separately for individual pittas). Bake for 25–30 minutes until the pastry is golden.

Immediately upon removing from the oven, warm the honey and drizzle it generously over the entire tray of pittas so that the honey soaks into the filling and coating. Scatter colored nonpareils or sesame seeds over the top while the honey is still warm. Cool completely before serving. They keep well for 1–2 weeks.

Sicilia.description: Catania's masterpiece, named after Bellini's opera 'Norma' because it is considered 'a work of art': penne or rigatoni with fried eggplant, tomato sauce, basil, and a snowfall of aged ricotta salata. The eggplant must be fried properly—golden, creamy, and not oily. The sauce is a quick, bright pomodoro. Simplicity is the point; quality is the method.
ingredients: 2 medium eggplants (Italian globe type), cut into 1/2-inch cubes
Olive oil for frying (about 1 cup / 240 ml)
1 can (28 oz) San Marzano whole tomatoes, crushed by hand
3 oz ricotta salata, grated or shaved (85 g)
steps: Salt the eggplant cubes generously and place in a colander for 30 minutes. This extracts bitterness and excess moisture. Rinse and pat very dry with paper towels.

Heat 1/2 inch of olive oil in a deep skillet to 350°F (175°C). Fry the eggplant cubes in batches, without crowding, until deeply golden on all sides. Drain on paper towels. Season with a pinch of salt.

In a separate pan, heat 3 tbsp olive oil over medium heat. Add the crushed garlic, cook until golden, then discard. Add the crushed tomatoes and a few basil leaves. Season with salt. Simmer 15–20 minutes until the sauce thickens and the raw tomato edge is gone.
Cook the rigatoni in generously salted water until al dente. Drain.
Toss the pasta with the tomato sauce. Fold in the fried eggplant cubes. Tear in fresh basil leaves.
Serve on warm plates with a generous shower of grated ricotta salata on top. The ricotta salata should fall like snow.

drink.description: Sicily's iconic breakfast: a glass of silky almond granita (frozen, slowly stirred to a crystalline slush) eaten with a warm, dome-shaped brioche col tuppo. You tear off pieces of brioche and dip them into the granita. In Catania and along the eastern coast, this IS breakfast from June to September.
ingredients: Warm Sicilian brioche col tuppo (or any soft brioche roll) for serving
steps: Soak the blanched almonds in 1 cup of the water overnight. Blend the almonds and their soaking water until very smooth. Strain through a fine-mesh sieve or cheesecloth, pressing hard to extract all the milk. Discard the pulp.
Dissolve the sugar in the remaining 2 cups of water over gentle heat. Cool. Combine with the almond milk and almond extract.

Pour into a shallow metal pan and freeze. Every 30 minutes for 3–4 hours, scrape and stir with a fork, breaking up ice crystals into a smooth, slushy texture. The granita should be creamy-crystalline, not a solid block.
Scoop into glasses. Serve alongside a warm brioche col tuppo—tear, dip, eat.

dessert.description: The Sicilian cannolo is the pinnacle of the island's extraordinary pastry tradition — a tradition shaped by Arab conquerors (who brought sugar cane, citrus, almonds, pistachios, and rose water), Norman kings, Spanish viceroys, and the great noble families who supported the pastry convents of Palermo and Catania. The cannolo is simply: a tube of fried, blistered pastry shell filled with sweetened ricotta cream. But the execution is everything. The shell (cialda) must be fried in lard — not oil — until it blisters and puffs in patches of amber and gold, crackles audibly when bitten, and shatters into fragments that scatter. The filling is real Sicilian ricotta — made from sheep's milk whey, drained for 24 hours, then beaten with sugar until satiny — scented with cinnamon and a whisper of vanilla, mixed with candied orange peel and dark chocolate chips. The filling is piped at the last possible moment — a cannolo that sits filled for more than 30 minutes is already past its best. The ends are dipped in chopped pistachios. On first bite it shatters. The filling is cold and sweet. The pistachio gives crunch. There is no dessert finer.
ingredients: For the cannolo shells: 2 cups (250 g) all-purpose flour, 2 tbsp granulated sugar, 1/2 tsp fine sea salt, 1/2 tsp ground cinnamon, 1 egg, 2 tbsp lard or unsalted butter, softened, 1/3 cup (80 ml) Marsala wine (dry), 1 egg white for sealing, Lard or oil for deep-frying (lard preferred for the authentic shell)

For the ricotta filling: 2 cups (500 g) whole-milk ricotta (sheep's milk if available), drained overnight in a sieve in the refrigerator until very dry, 1 cup (120 g) powdered sugar, sifted, 1/2 tsp ground cinnamon, 1 tsp pure vanilla extract, 3 oz (85 g) dark chocolate chips or chopped chocolate (at least 60% cacao), 2 tbsp candied orange peel, finely chopped
For finishing: 1/2 cup (60 g) shelled pistachios, finely chopped, Powdered sugar, Maraschino cherries or orange peel for the ends (optional)
steps: Make the shell dough: In a bowl, combine the flour, sugar, salt, and cinnamon. Make a well; add the egg, lard, and Marsala. Mix and knead 8–10 minutes to a firm, smooth, somewhat elastic dough — it should feel like stiff pasta dough. Wrap and rest 30 minutes.

Roll the dough on a lightly floured surface to paper-thin thickness (1–2mm). Cut into 4-inch (10 cm) circles or squares. Wrap each piece around a metal cannolo tube, sealing the overlapping edge with a dab of egg white and pressing firmly.

Heat lard (or oil) in a deep pot to 360°F (182°C). Fry the shell-wrapped tubes, 2–3 at a time, for 2–3 minutes until golden-brown and blistered. Remove with tongs and drain on paper towels. While warm, slide the cannolo tubes out carefully. Cool completely.

Make the filling: Beat the drained ricotta with a spatula until very smooth. Add the sifted powdered sugar, cinnamon, and vanilla; mix thoroughly. Fold in the chocolate chips and candied orange peel. Refrigerate until needed.

Fill immediately before serving: Transfer the ricotta cream to a piping bag fitted with a large round or star tip. Pipe the filling into both ends of each shell, meeting in the middle. Dip each end in the chopped pistachios. Dust with powdered sugar. Serve within 20 minutes — the shells must still be crackingly crisp.

Sardegna.description: Sardinia's hand-pinched ravioli from the wild Ogliastra coast: a thin semolina dough enclosing a filling of potato, aged Pecorino, mint, and garlic, sealed with an elaborate braid called sa spighitta (the wheat ear) that only Sardinian hands know by heart. Each pinch creates a decorative ridge that also seals the dumpling perfectly. Served with a simple fresh tomato sauce and basil.
ingredients: For dough: 3 cups fine semolina flour (360 g), 3/4 cup warm water (180 ml), 1 tbsp olive oil, pinch of salt
For filling: 1.5 lbs potatoes, boiled and riced (680 g), 1 cup grated aged Pecorino Sardo (100 g), 2 garlic cloves minced, 12 fresh mint leaves (finely chopped), 2 tbsp olive oil, salt
For sauce: 1 can (14 oz) San Marzano tomatoes, 2 tbsp olive oil, 1 garlic clove, basil, salt
Semolina pasta dough (see Chef's Essentials below)
steps: Make the filling: Boil potatoes until tender, peel and rice while hot. Mix with Pecorino, garlic, chopped mint, and olive oil. Season with salt. The filling should be smooth and fragrant. Cool.
Make the dough: Knead semolina, water, olive oil, and salt into a smooth, elastic dough, 10–12 minutes. Rest 30 minutes under a towel.

Roll the dough very thin. Cut into 3-inch circles. Place a tablespoon of filling in the center of each. To close: pinch and fold the edge over itself in a continuous braid from one end to the other, creating the decorative spighitta pattern. Press firmly at the end to seal.
Make the sauce: Heat olive oil with garlic until fragrant. Add crushed tomatoes and basil. Simmer 15 minutes. Season.
Cook the culurgiones in gently simmering salted water for 3–4 minutes (they will float). Remove with a slotted spoon.
Place in a warm bowl, spoon tomato sauce over the top, and finish with grated Pecorino Sardo.

drink.description: Sardinia's signature liqueur, distilled from the wild myrtle berries that grow in the island's macchia (scrubland). Mirto rosso (red, from the berries) is the most common—deep purple, bittersweet, and herbal. Always served ice-cold from the freezer as a digestivo.
ingredients: 1 lb fresh myrtle berries (mirto), rinsed (450 g)
2 cups (480 ml) grain alcohol or high-proof vodka
steps: Place the myrtle berries in a large glass jar. Pour over the alcohol. Seal tightly and steep in a cool, dark place for 40–60 days.
Make syrup: dissolve sugar in water over heat. Cool completely.
Strain the berry-infused alcohol through cheesecloth (press the berries to extract flavor). Combine with the syrup.
Bottle and rest in the freezer for at least 2 weeks. Serve ice-cold in small glasses after dinner.

dessert.description: The Seadas — also called Sebadas — are Sardinia's most iconic and most uniquely Sardinian dessert: deep-fried pastry pockets filled with fresh pecorino cheese and lemon zest, drizzled with Sardinia's extraordinary miele amaro di corbezzolo — the dark, intensely bitter honey made from the white flowers of the strawberry tree (Arbutus unedo), found almost nowhere else on earth. The contrast is shocking and perfect: the savory, slightly sour, melting warm cheese; the shatteringly crisp pastry; and the bittersweet, dark, almost medicinal honey. The filling is made from fresh pecorino sardo (the young, soft version) or a mixture of fresh cheese and semolina, mixed with lemon zest and a pinch of saffron in the traditional recipe. The pastry is pasta violada — a semolina-and-lard dough specific to Sardinia, thinner than pie crust, more rustic than filo. The Seadas originates from the shepherding culture of the Barbagia mountains, where they were made for the great feasts of the shepherds' calendar: the return of the flocks, the slaughter, the harvest. They are ancient, generous, and irreplaceable.
ingredients: For the pasta violada (pastry): 2 cups (250 g) fine semolina (or all-purpose flour or half and half), 1/4 cup (55 g) lard or unsalted butter, 1/2 tsp fine sea salt, 1/2 cup (120 ml) warm water (approximately)

For the cheese filling: 1 lb (450 g) fresh young pecorino sardo (or mild fresh pecorino, or a mixture of 3/4 fresh pecorino + 1/4 fresh ricotta), grated or crumbled, Zest of 2 lemons, finely grated, Pinch of saffron threads dissolved in 1 tsp warm water (optional but traditional), 1 tbsp fine semolina if the cheese is very wet
Lard or neutral oil for deep-frying
Sardinian miele amaro di corbezzolo (strawberry tree honey) for serving — or the darkest, most bitter wildflower honey available
steps: Make the pastry: Combine the semolina and salt. Rub in the lard with your fingers until the mixture resembles coarse sand. Add warm water gradually, kneading, until a firm but pliable dough forms — similar to pasta dough. Knead 5 minutes until smooth. Wrap and rest 30 minutes.

Make the filling: If the cheese is very wet, spread it on a clean cloth and press gently to remove moisture. In a bowl, combine the grated cheese, lemon zest, saffron water if using, and semolina if needed. Mix thoroughly. The filling should hold together — not runny.
Roll the pasta dough on a lightly floured surface to 2–3mm thickness. Cut into rounds of 4–5 inches (10–12 cm) in diameter.

Place a generous tablespoon of cheese filling in the center of half the rounds. Top with another round and press the edges firmly together, sealing with your fingers or a fork — a perfect, tight seal is essential to prevent the filling from leaking during frying. Trim the edges with a fluted pastry cutter for a neat finish.
Heat 3 inches (8 cm) of lard or oil to 360°F (182°C). Fry the seadas, 2 at a time, for 3–4 minutes per side until deep golden-brown and crispy. Drain briefly on paper towels.

Serve immediately — they must be eaten hot, when the cheese is still melted and the pastry is crackling. Drizzle generously with the warm honey over each seada. The bitterness of the corbezzolo honey against the sweet-savory fried cheese is the essential experience — do not substitute with mild honey if you can help it.

JAM.description: A breakfast that tells a story of the triangular trade. Saltfish from the North Atlantic meets Ackee from West Africa (brought by Captain Bligh). When cooked, the poisonous-if-unripe ackee turns into a buttery, egg-like delicacy that perfectly balances the salty cod.
steps: Soak saltfish overnight or boil in water for 20 mins to remove excess salt. Flake the fish and remove bones.
Sauté onion, peppers, and scallion in oil until soft.
Add the flaked fish and thyme. Cook for 5 mins.
Gently fold in the ackee (be careful not to mash it).
Place the whole scotch bonnet pepper on top for flavor (do not burst it). Steam for 3-5 mins.
Remove pepper. Serve with fried dumplings, boiled green bananas, or yam.

drink.description: A rum-forward tropical punch associated with Jamaica: rum, citrus, and a touch of spice.
ingredients: 1/2 oz (15 ml) grenadine (or 1/2 oz simple syrup)
steps: Shake everything with ice until cold.
Strain into a tall glass over fresh ice.
Note (quick grenadine): simmer equal parts pomegranate juice + sugar until dissolved; cool.
Note (quick grenadine): simmer equal parts pomegranate juice + sugar until dissolved; cool before using.
Note (simple syrup): stir equal parts sugar + hot water until dissolved; cool.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.
Warm pomegranate juice and sugar in a saucepan over medium heat, stirring until dissolved (avoid a hard boil).
Cool; stir in orange blossom water if using.
Bottle; add vodka if using for shelf-life.
Refrigerate and use within 3–4 weeks (longer if vodka added).

dessert.description: A dense, darkly rich fruitcake drenched in Appleton Estate rum, with burnt sugar (browning) lending its signature jet-black color and bittersweet depth. This is Jamaica's Christmas tradition—the fruits are soaked in rum for weeks (even months) before baking, and the finished cake is brushed with more rum until it glistens. A slice is equal parts cake and history, carried to the island by British colonists and transformed by Caribbean spirit.
ingredients: 1 cup (200 g) dark brown sugar, packed
1/4 cup (60 ml) Appleton Estate dark rum, plus extra for soaking
1/2 cup (75 g) mixed candied peel (citron, orange)
2 cups (480 ml) Appleton Estate dark rum (or enough to cover)
steps: Combine all dried fruits in a large glass jar. Pour over the rum (and port if using) until the fruits are completely submerged.
Seal tightly and store in a cool, dark place for at least 2 weeks—ideally 1 to 3 months. Shake the jar every few days.
Before using, strain the fruit from the rum (reserve the rum for brushing the cake). Pulse half the fruit in a food processor to a coarse paste; leave the other half as whole pieces.
Preheat oven to 325°F (165°C). Grease and line a 9-inch (23 cm) round cake pan with parchment.
Cream the butter and brown sugar until light and fluffy. Beat in the eggs one at a time.
In a separate bowl, whisk together the flour, baking powder, cinnamon, nutmeg, and allspice.
Fold the dry ingredients into the butter mixture in three additions, alternating with the browning, rum, and vanilla. Mix until just combined.
Fold in the rum-soaked fruit (both the paste and whole pieces). The batter will be dark and dense.
Pour into the prepared pan and smooth the top. Bake for 1 hour 15 minutes to 1 hour 30 minutes, or until a skewer inserted in the center comes out clean.
While still warm, poke holes across the top with a skewer and brush generously with reserved rum. Repeat the rum brushing every day for 3–5 days.
Wrap tightly in rum-soaked cheesecloth, then foil. The cake improves for weeks and keeps for months in a cool place.

JEY.description: The Jersey version of the bean jar, using a mix of beans and pig's trotter.
steps: Soak beans.
Cook all ingredients in crock pot for 8+ hours.
Remove bone. Serve.

drink.description: Jersey has a long tradition of cider production.
steps: Serve chilled and pour into a glass.

dessert.description: Figure-eight shaped fried dough, twisted and deep-fried at low tide—a Jersey tradition born of superstition, as islanders believed frying at low tide prevented the dough from absorbing too much fat. Jersey Wonders are the island's oldest pastry, dusted with sugar and eaten warm by the handful, their golden knots as much a part of Jersey's identity as the cows and the cliffs.
ingredients: 1/2 cup (100 g) granulated sugar, plus extra for dusting
steps: In a large bowl, combine the flour, sugar, baking powder, nutmeg, lemon zest, and salt. Rub in the softened butter with your fingertips until the mixture resembles fine breadcrumbs.
Make a well in the center. Add the beaten eggs and milk. Stir with a wooden spoon, then knead gently into a soft, smooth dough. Do not overwork. Cover and rest for 30 minutes.
On a floured surface, roll the dough to about 1/4 inch (6 mm) thickness. Cut into strips roughly 6 inches (15 cm) long and 1 1/2 inches (4 cm) wide.
Twist each strip into a figure-eight: fold the strip in half, twist the two halves around each other, and pinch the ends together to form the classic shape.
Heat oil to 340°F (170°C) in a deep pot or fryer. Fry the wonders 2–3 at a time for 2–3 minutes, turning once, until puffed and golden on both sides.
Drain on paper towels. Dust generously with sugar while still warm. Serve immediately—Jersey Wonders are best eaten fresh.

JOR.dish: Mansaf (منسف) — Jordanian Lamb with Jameed Sauce
JOR.description: Jordan’s iconic celebratory platter: lamb simmered tender, served over shrak bread and rice, and drenched in tangy jameed (dried yogurt) sauce with toasted nuts and sumac-like brightness.
ingredients: 3 lb (1.4 kg) lamb shoulder or shanks, bone-in chunks
2 tsp kosher salt, plus more to taste
3 cups (600 g) long-grain rice, rinsed and soaked 20 minutes, drained
3 tbsp (45 g) ghee or unsalted butter
Shrak or markook bread (or very thin lavash)
Garnish: 1/2 cup (70 g) slivered almonds or pine nuts, toasted
steps: Simmer lamb with onion, water, bay, cardamom, peppercorns, and salt until very tender, 1 1/2–2 hours. Skim as needed.
Remove lamb; keep warm. Strain broth; reserve.
Prepare jameed sauce base (see preliminary steps), then keep it warm on low.
Cook rice: in a pot, heat ghee, add drained rice and stir 1 minute. Add 4 1/2 cups (1.1 L) hot lamb broth and a pinch of salt. Bring to a boil, cover, cook on low 15 minutes; rest 10 minutes.
Assembly: Lay shrak bread on a large platter and splash with a little warm jameed sauce to soften. Mound rice on top. Arrange lamb over rice.
Ladle plenty of jameed sauce over everything. Top with toasted nuts and parsley. Serve extra sauce on the side.

ingredients: 8–10 oz (225–280 g) jameed (dried yogurt), broken up (or 2 cups jameed paste if available)
4–6 cups (950 ml–1.4 L) warm water, as needed
1 cup (240 ml) plain whole-milk yogurt (helps stability)
Reserved lamb broth (from mansaf), as needed
steps: Soak jameed in warm water at least 4 hours (overnight is best) until softened.
Blend soaked jameed with its soaking liquid until completely smooth. Strain if gritty.
Whisk in yogurt (and cornstarch if using).
Warm gently over low heat, stirring constantly. Thin with lamb broth/water to a pourable sauce. Do not let it boil hard.
Keep warm; stir occasionally until serving.

drink.description: A classic Levantine drink: jallab is a dark, caramel-fruity molasses syrup diluted over ice with rose water and topped with pine nuts and raisins.
ingredients: 1/3 cup (80 ml) jallab syrup (date and/or grape molasses blend)
steps: In a pitcher, stir jallab syrup with cold water until fully dissolved.
Stir in rose water. Taste and adjust with more syrup or water.
Fill glasses with ice, pour, and top with pine nuts and raisins.

dessert.dish: Knafeh (كنافة) — Shredded Phyllo and Cheese Pastry
dessert.description: A magnificent tray of golden, shredded phyllo pastry (kataifi) crisped in butter, layered over a bed of stretchy, molten Nabulsi cheese, baked until shattering-crisp on top and oozing within, then drenched in fragrant orange blossom syrup. Knafeh is the pride of Nablus and the obsession of Amman—cut into squares and flipped upside-down so the golden crust faces up, then crowned with a sprinkle of crushed pistachios.
ingredients: 1 lb (450 g) kataifi (shredded phyllo dough), thawed if frozen
1 lb (450 g) Nabulsi cheese (or a mix of mozzarella and ricotta), soaked in water 3–4 hours to remove salt, drained and sliced
2 tbsp (15 g) crushed pistachios for garnish

steps: Combine sugar, water, and lemon juice in a saucepan. Bring to a boil, stirring until the sugar dissolves.
Reduce heat and simmer without stirring for 8–10 minutes until the syrup thickens slightly and coats the back of a spoon.
Remove from heat and stir in the orange blossom water. Let cool completely before using—the syrup must be cold when poured over the hot knafeh.
Prepare the orange blossom syrup in advance and refrigerate until cold.
Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C). Gently pull apart and loosen the kataifi shreds in a large bowl. Pour the melted butter over the strands and toss thoroughly, separating and coating every strand.
Press half the buttered kataifi into the bottom of a 10-inch (25 cm) round baking pan or oven-safe skillet, creating a firm, even base. Press down firmly.
Arrange the sliced cheese evenly over the kataifi layer. Top with the remaining kataifi, pressing down gently to compact.
Bake for 35–40 minutes until the top and bottom are deep golden and crisp. If the top browns before the bottom crisps, cover loosely with foil.
Remove from the oven and immediately pour the cold syrup evenly over the hot knafeh. Let it absorb for 2 minutes.
Place a serving platter over the pan and flip the knafeh upside-down so the golden crust is on top. Garnish with crushed pistachios. Cut into squares and serve warm.

JPN.description: Vinegared rice paired with seafood. It's all about the rice preparation.
steps: Wash rice repeatedly until water runs clear. Cook in rice cooker.
