Dip in guajillo sauce; serve with crema and shredded lettuce.

drink.description: Spiced coffee with piloncillo and cinnamon. One recipe.
steps: Bring water and piloncillo to a boil; add cinnamon. Stir until piloncillo dissolves. Add coffee; simmer 5 min. Steep 5 min off heat. Strain into mugs. Serve hot.

Sinaloa.description: Raw shrimp or fish 'cooked' in lime and puréed cucumber, serrano, and cilantro. Sinaloa’s answer to ceviche—spicy, bright, and addictive.
steps: Blend cucumber, serrano, cilantro, and some lime into a smooth liquid. Season with salt.
Toss shrimp in lime and aguachile mix; let sit 5–10 min. Serve on tostadas with sliced onion.

drink.description: Beer with lime, salt, and spices. One recipe.
steps: Rim a tall glass with lime and salt (or Tajín). Fill with ice. Squeeze in lime; add Worcestershire and hot sauce. Pour beer; stir gently. Serve immediately.

Sonora.description: Grilled beef (often arrachera or skirt steak) with flour tortillas, frijoles, and salsa. The definitive norteño grill—simple, bold, and perfect.
steps: Marinate beef with lime, salt, and optional beer. Grill to desired doneness.
Slice; serve with warm flour tortillas, beans, salsa, lime, and guacamole.

drink.description: Fresh limeade. One recipe.
steps: In a pitcher, stir lime juice and sugar until sugar dissolves. Add water. Serve over ice with lime slices.

Tabasco.description: Garfish (pejelagarto) baked in banana leaves with achiote and herbs—a Tabasco river specialty. Unique flavor and texture.
steps: Season fish with achiote. Wrap in banana leaves with tomato and herbs.
Bake until cooked through. Serve with rice and pickled onions.

drink.description: Fermented cacao drink or Tabasco’s famous chocolate.
steps: Make pozol or hot chocolate; serve cold or hot.

Tamaulipas.description: A full plate: grilled beef strip, enchilada, guacamole, refried beans, and rice. Born in Tampico—hearty and satisfying.
steps: Grill beef. Make enchiladas with guajillo sauce.
Plate: rice, beans, sliced beef, one or two enchiladas, guacamole. Serve with tortillas.

drink.description: Fruit and wine punch. One recipe.
steps: In a pitcher, combine wine, orange juice, brandy, and sugar; stir until sugar dissolves. Add fruit; chill 1–2 hours. Serve over ice.

Tlaxcala.description: Goat meat and spine in a rich, spicy mole—a Tlaxcalan festival dish. Complex and deeply traditional.
steps: Cook goat until tender. Blend chiles, tomato, garlic, spices into mole.
Combine meat and mole; simmer. Serve with rice and tortillas.

drink.description: Oat atole: warming and comforting. One recipe.
steps: Blend oats with 1 cup milk until smooth. Heat remaining milk with cinnamon and piloncillo until steaming.
Whisk in oat mixture; simmer, stirring, 8–10 min until thick. Remove cinnamon. Serve hot.

Veracruz.description: Whole red snapper in a sauce of tomatoes, olives, capers, and jalapeños—Spanish-Mexican fusion from the port. Bright, briny, and iconic.
steps: Sauté onion, garlic; add tomatoes, olives, capers, jalapeños, bay leaf. Simmer into a sauce.
Place fish in a pan; pour sauce over. Bake or poach until fish is cooked. Serve with rice.

drink.description: Veracruz peanut-and-rum cream drink. One recipe.
steps: Blend rum, peanut butter, condensed milk, and ice until smooth and frothy. Pour into a glass. Serve immediately.

Yucatán.description: Pork marinated in achiote and sour orange, wrapped in banana leaves and slow-roasted until tender. The Yucatán’s most famous dish—served in tacos with pickled red onion.
steps: Marinate pork in achiote and sour orange 4–24 hours. Wrap in banana leaves.
Roast at 300°F for 2–3 hours. Shred; serve in tortillas with cebolla en escabeche and habanero salsa.

drink.description: Rice and cinnamon agua fresca. One recipe.
steps: Soak rice and cinnamon in 2 cups water overnight (or 2 hours). Blend until smooth; strain through cheesecloth into a pitcher.
Add remaining water, milk, sugar, and vanilla; stir. Chill. Serve over ice.

Zacatecas.description: Pork in a rich, sweet-savory sauce of ancho chiles, cinnamon, and piloncillo—Zacatecas’s wedding dish. Served with rice and tortillas.
steps: Blend rehydrated anchos with piloncillo, spices, garlic, vinegar. Strain.
Brown pork; add sauce. Simmer until tender. Serve with rice and tortillas.

drink.description: Spiced coffee with piloncillo and cinnamon. One recipe.
steps: Bring water and piloncillo to a boil; add cinnamon. Stir until piloncillo dissolves. Add coffee; simmer 5 min. Steep 5 min off heat. Strain into mugs. Serve hot.

MKD.description: Beans in a skillet. White beans are stewed with paprika and mint, then baked in traditional earthenware pots until a crust forms. It is the Friday lunch staple of North Macedonia.
ingredients: 1 lb dried white beans (Great Northern or cannellini) (450 g)
8 cups water (1.9 L), plus more as needed
steps: Soak beans overnight in plenty of water. Drain.
Simmer beans in fresh water with bay leaves until just tender, 45–75 minutes. Drain, reserving 2 cups of cooking liquid.
Sauté onion and pepper in olive oil until very soft and lightly caramelized.
Stir in paprika (and tomato paste if using) for 30 seconds, then add beans, mint, salt, and pepper.
Transfer to a baking dish (ideally an earthenware tavче). Add enough reserved bean liquid to keep beans just covered.
Bake at 375°F/190°C for 30–45 minutes until the top is lightly crusted and the sauce thickens.
Rest 10 minutes and serve warm.

drink.description: A honey-sweetened rakija infusion popular across the Balkans; easy to make at home and served as a digestif.
steps: Combine rakija, honey, lemon peel (and cinnamon if using) in a clean jar.
Seal and shake until the honey is dissolved.
Let steep 2–3 days, shaking once daily.
Strain if you want a clearer drink; bottle.
Serve at room temp or lightly chilled.

dessert.description: North Macedonia's beloved Ottoman-heritage sweet: ridged, finger-shaped choux pastry piped through a star tip, deep-fried until puffed and golden, then plunged into cold lemon-scented sugar syrup that soaks into every ridge and cranny. The result is a dessert that shatters on the outside and yields to a soft, syrup-drenched interior—a textural masterpiece found in every pastry shop from Skopje to Ohrid. Tulumba is Balkan pride baked (well, fried) into every ridged bite, served at celebrations, coffee gatherings, and holiday tables across the country.
ingredients: Vegetable oil for deep frying (about 4 cups / 960 ml)
steps: Prepare the lemon sugar syrup first and refrigerate until cold.

In a saucepan, bring water, butter, sugar, and salt to a full boil. Remove from heat and add flour all at once, stirring vigorously with a wooden spoon until a smooth dough forms and pulls from the sides of the pot.
Return to low heat and stir 1–2 minutes to dry the dough slightly. Transfer to a bowl and let cool 5 minutes.
Beat in eggs one at a time, mixing thoroughly after each, until the dough is smooth, glossy, and holds a soft peak when lifted.
Fill a piping bag fitted with a large open-star tip. Heat oil to 340°F (170°C).
Pipe 2–3 inch (5–7 cm) ridged fingers directly into the oil, cutting with oiled scissors. Fry in batches 4–5 minutes, turning occasionally, until deeply golden and puffed.
Drain briefly on paper towels for 10 seconds, then immediately drop hot tulumba into the cold syrup. Soak 2–3 minutes, turning once.
Remove with a slotted spoon and arrange on a serving platter. Serve at room temperature.
Combine sugar and water in a saucepan. Bring to a boil, stirring until sugar dissolves.
Add lemon juice and lemon peel. Simmer 8–10 minutes until slightly thickened (it will register about 220°F / 105°C).
Remove lemon peel and refrigerate syrup until completely cold. The hot-fried / cold-syrup contrast is essential for proper absorption.

MLT.description: Rabbit Stew. A dish of resistance—when the Knights of St. John restricted rabbit hunting, locals mastered cooking it as a form of defiance. Slow-cooked in red wine, tomato, and garlic until tender.
steps: Marinate rabbit in wine and garlic overnight.
Sear rabbit pieces. Remove.
Fry onions and garlic. Add tomato paste and the marinade wine.
Return rabbit. Simmer for 2 hours until tender.
Add peas near the end.
Serve sauce with pasta first, then rabbit as main, or all together with potatoes.

drink.description: A Maltese highball built on Kinnie’s bitter-sweet citrus bite—mixed with gin and amaro, finished with mint.
ingredients: 1–2 tsp sugar (or 1/2 oz simple syrup) (to taste)
Garnish: mint sprig and lime wedges
steps: Add gin, amaro, lime juice, sugar, a mint sprig, and ice to a shaker.
Shake briefly to chill, then strain into a highball filled with fresh ice and lime wedges.
Top with Kinnie.
Garnish with mint and serve.

dessert.description: Malta's take on the Sicilian classic—crispy fried pastry tubes shattered at first bite to reveal a luscious filling of sweetened fresh ricotta studded with candied orange peel, chocolate chips, and a whisper of cinnamon. Sicily's legacy lives on in every Maltese festa (village feast), where trays of these cannoli are piled high alongside imqaret and prinjolata. The Maltese version uses irkotta—the island's own fresh whey cheese, slightly grainier and tangier than Italian ricotta—giving the filling a distinctive character. Dusted with powdered sugar and served same-day for maximum crunch, these are the jewels of Maltese pastry.
ingredients: 2 tbsp (28 g) cold lard or unsalted butter, cubed
3 tbsp (45 ml) Marsala wine (or white wine)
Vegetable oil for deep frying (about 3 cups / 720 ml)
1 egg white, lightly beaten (for sealing shells)
2 cups (500 g) fresh ricotta (or irkotta), well drained overnight
1/2 cup (60 g) powdered sugar, plus more for dusting
3 tbsp (30 g) candied orange peel, finely chopped
steps: Mix flour, sugar, salt, and cinnamon. Cut in lard until crumbly. Add egg, Marsala, and vinegar; knead into a smooth dough. Wrap and chill 1 hour.
Roll dough very thin (about 1/16 inch / 1.5 mm). Cut into 4-inch (10 cm) circles.
Wrap each circle around a greased cannoli tube (or dowel), sealing the overlap with beaten egg white.
Heat oil to 360°F (180°C). Fry shells on their tubes 2–3 minutes until golden and blistered. Drain on paper towels and carefully slide off tubes. Cool completely.
For the filling: beat drained ricotta with powdered sugar and vanilla until smooth. Fold in chocolate chips and candied orange peel.
Pipe or spoon filling into both ends of each shell just before serving (to keep the shells crisp).
Dust generously with powdered sugar and serve immediately.

MMR.dish: Mohinga (မုန့်ဟင်းခါး) — Myanmar Fish Noodle Soup
MMR.description: Myanmar’s national dish: a fragrant fish broth thickened lightly, poured over rice noodles, and finished with crispy toppings, eggs, and herbs—breakfast, comfort, and identity in a bowl.
ingredients: 1 lb (450 g) catfish fillets (or other firm fish)
2 tbsp fish sauce, plus more to taste
2 tbsp toasted rice powder (see preliminary steps) or 3 tbsp chickpea flour
1 lb (450 g) rice vermicelli noodles, cooked
steps: Simmer fish with water and lemongrass 12–15 minutes until cooked. Remove fish; strain broth and discard lemongrass.
Flake fish finely, removing bones.
In a pot, heat oil and sauté onion until soft. Add garlic, ginger, and turmeric; cook 1 minute.
Add strained broth, flaked fish, and fish sauce. Simmer 10 minutes.
Whisk toasted rice powder (or chickpea flour) with a little cool water to make a slurry. Stir into soup and simmer 5 minutes until lightly thickened. Adjust seasoning.
Serve over cooked noodles with eggs, herbs, lime, and toppings.
Toast rice in a dry skillet over medium heat until golden and nutty, 10–12 minutes.
Cool, then grind to a fine powder.
Store airtight up to 1 month.

drink.dish: Laphet Yay Cho (လက်ဖက်ရည်ချို) — Burmese Milk Tea
drink.description: Rich, sweet black tea balanced with condensed milk (often with evaporated milk). Tea-shop essential across Myanmar.
ingredients: 2 tbsp loose black tea (or 3 tea bags)
steps: Bring water to a boil and steep tea 5 minutes for a strong brew; strain.
Stir in condensed milk (and evaporated milk if using). Taste and adjust sweetness.
Serve hot or over ice.

dessert.dish: Mont Lone Yay Paw (မုန့်လုံးရေပေါ်)
dessert.description: Burma's poetic 'floating rice balls'—plump dumplings of glutinous rice flour stuffed with a nugget of melting palm sugar (htanyet), set adrift in a warm, fragrant pool of coconut milk sweetened with sugar and studded with tiny tapioca pearls. The name means 'round snack floating on water,' and watching the dumplings bob to the surface of the simmering pot is how you know they are done. Served warm in bowls, each spoonful delivers the chew of the rice skin, the rush of liquid caramel from within, and the silky richness of coconut—a dessert that embodies the gentle sweetness of Burmese cuisine.
ingredients: 1/3 cup (65 g) palm sugar (jaggery), cut into small chunks
1 tbsp (8 g) toasted sesame seeds (optional garnish)
steps: Soak tapioca pearls in water for 15 minutes, then drain.
Mix glutinous rice flour with warm water, a little at a time, kneading until you have a smooth, pliable dough (like Play-Doh). It should not be sticky.
Pinch off walnut-sized pieces of dough, flatten into a disc, place a small chunk of palm sugar in the center, and seal the dough around it, rolling into a smooth ball. Repeat until all dough is used.
Bring a large pot of water to a boil. Drop the rice balls in gently. They will sink, then float to the surface when cooked—about 3–4 minutes after they float. Remove with a slotted spoon.

In a separate saucepan, combine coconut milk, water, sugar, salt, and drained tapioca pearls. Simmer over medium-low heat 10–12 minutes, stirring often, until the tapioca is translucent and the soup is creamy.
Place cooked rice balls in serving bowls. Ladle the warm coconut-tapioca soup over them.
Garnish with toasted sesame seeds and grated coconut if desired. Serve warm.

MNE.description: A heavy mountain dish designed for energy. Potatoes and wheat flour are mashed together for an hour until elastic, then melted with 'kajmak' (clotted cream) and cheese. It is a fondue-like texture eaten with wooden spoons.
ingredients: 2 large potatoes, peeled and diced small (about 12 oz / 340 g)
1 cup crumbled white cheese (sir/young cheese, feta works) (150 g)
steps: Boil diced potatoes in salted water until very tender, 12–15 minutes. Do not drain; keep the starchy water.
With the pot at a gentle boil, whisk in cornmeal in a steady stream.
Lower heat and cook, stirring often, until thick and pulling from the sides, 10–15 minutes.
Stir in butter and half the cheese until glossy.
Spoon into bowls and top with the remaining cheese. Serve hot.

drink.description: A Balkan winter warmer: rakija heated gently with sugar and spices—served hot, never boiled.
ingredients: 1 tbsp sugar or honey (15–20 g), to taste
steps: Combine rakija, sugar/honey, lemon peel, peppercorns (and cinnamon if using) in a small saucepan.
Warm very gently over low heat until steaming—do not boil.
Taste and adjust sweetness.
Strain into a small heatproof glass or mug.
Serve hot.

dessert.description: Montenegro's ancient walnut-honey pastry—thin, hand-stretched sheets of dough layered with a fragrant filling of finely ground walnuts, honey, and warm spices, then baked until golden and drenched in a honey-butter glaze. Similar in spirit to baklava but distinctly Montenegrin in its simplicity and restraint, koh uses fewer layers and lets the quality of the mountain honey and local walnuts speak for themselves. Served at slava (patron saint day) celebrations, weddings, and holidays, it is the sweet that ties every Montenegrin family to its kitchen traditions. The name 'koh' simply means 'layer'—and each one matters.
ingredients: 1/2 cup (1 stick / 113 g) unsalted butter, melted
steps: Mix flour and salt, add warm water and oil, and knead 8–10 minutes until smooth and elastic. Divide into 6 balls, cover, and rest 30 minutes.
Combine ground walnuts, 1/2 cup honey, cinnamon, and cloves in a bowl.
Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C). Grease a 9x13-inch (23x33 cm) baking pan.
On a floured surface, roll each dough ball paper-thin. Lay the first sheet in the pan, brush generously with melted butter, and spread a thin layer of the walnut-honey filling.
Repeat: layer dough, butter, filling, dough, butter, filling—finishing with a top layer of dough brushed with butter.
Score the top into diamond or square shapes with a sharp knife.
Bake 35–40 minutes until deeply golden brown.
While hot, warm 1/2 cup honey and 2 tbsp butter together until melted and combined. Pour evenly over the pastry.
Let cool completely in the pan (at least 2 hours) so the syrup absorbs before cutting and serving.

MNG.description: Mongolia’s celebratory dumplings: juicy meat filling sealed in pleated dough and steamed, especially for Tsagaan Sar (Lunar New Year).
ingredients: 1 lb ground lamb or beef (450 g)
1/2 cup finely chopped cabbage (optional but common)

steps: Mix flour and salt, add water, knead until smooth. Rest 30 minutes.

ingredients: 1 lb (450 g) ground lamb or beef
1/2 cup finely chopped cabbage (optional but common)
steps: Mix filling ingredients thoroughly; the water keeps it juicy.
Divide dough into 24 pieces. Roll each into a 3–4 inch (8–10 cm) round.
Place 1–2 tbsp filling in center. Pleat edges upward, leaving a small vent hole at the top.
Steam over boiling water 12–15 minutes until cooked through.
Serve hot.

drink.dish: Suutei Tsai (Сүүтэй цай) — Mongolian Milk Tea
drink.description: Salty milk tea brewed with tea leaves and sometimes enriched with a bit of fat—everyday warmth on the steppe.
ingredients: 1 tbsp loose green tea (or 2 green tea bags)
steps: Bring water to a simmer, add tea, and simmer 3 minutes.
Add milk and return to a gentle simmer 5 minutes.
Season with salt (and butter if using). Strain and serve hot.

dessert.description: Mongolia's festive fried pastries—golden, puffy shapes of yeast-leavened dough deep-fried until hollow and crisp, then dusted with powdered sugar or drizzled with honey. Boortsog are the centerpiece of every Naadam festival table and Tsagaan Sar (Lunar New Year) celebration, stacked into towering pyramids that symbolize prosperity and hospitality. The dough is simple—flour, butter, sugar, milk, and a touch of yeast—but the frying transforms it into something ethereal: crunchy outside, airy inside, and utterly addictive. Traditionally eaten with suutei tsai (salty milk tea) or airag (fermented mare's milk), they are the taste of the Mongolian steppe.
ingredients: Vegetable oil for deep frying (about 4 cups / 960 ml)
Powdered sugar for dusting (or honey for drizzling)
steps: Dissolve yeast in warm milk with a pinch of sugar. Let sit 5–10 minutes until foamy.
In a large bowl, combine flour, sugar, and salt. Add the yeast mixture, melted butter, egg, and warm water. Mix and knead 8–10 minutes until smooth and elastic.
Cover the dough and let rise in a warm spot 1–1 1/2 hours until doubled.

Punch down dough. Roll out on a floured surface to about 1/2 inch (1.3 cm) thick. Cut into rectangles (about 2x3 inches / 5x7 cm), diamonds, or strips. Make a small slit in the center of each piece and pull one end through to create the traditional twisted shape.
Heat oil to 350°F (175°C) in a deep pot. Fry boortsog in batches, turning once, 2–3 minutes total until puffed and deep golden on all sides.
Drain on paper towels. Dust generously with powdered sugar while still warm, or drizzle with honey.
Stack on a platter and serve with tea or airag. Boortsog keep well in an airtight container for up to a week.

MSR.description: The national obsession of the Emerald Isle of the Caribbean. Despite the thin-sounding name, this is a rich, dark, clove-scented stew inspired by Irish Irish stew but adapted with goat meat, rum, and tropical spices. It is the centerpiece of every celebration.
steps: Sear goat meat in oil. Remove.
Sauté onions and garlic. Add meat back.
Add water, herbs, and spices. Simmer for 2 hours until tender.
Mix flour with water to make a paste. Stir into stew to thicken slightly.
Add a splash of rum/whiskey at the end.
Serve with crusty bread rolls.

drink.description: Montserrat is known for “bush rum”—rum infused with local herbs/spices. This is a practical home version.
steps: Combine in a jar, seal, and infuse 5–14 days.
Strain.
Serve 1–2 oz (30–60 ml) neat or over ice.

dessert.description: Montserrat's beloved dense and fudgy baked pudding: grated fresh cassava mixed with shredded coconut, brown sugar, warm spices, and coconut milk, then baked low and slow until it sets into a sticky, caramelized block of pure Caribbean comfort. Cassava pone is the quintessential Montserratian dessert—part pudding, part cake, entirely addictive. The grating of the cassava is the labor of love; the reward is a texture unlike anything else: chewy, moist, and sweet with the deep molasses notes of brown sugar and the fragrance of nutmeg and cinnamon.
ingredients: 2 lbs (900 g) fresh cassava, peeled and finely grated
1 cup (80 g) finely shredded unsweetened coconut
1 cup (220 g) dark brown sugar, packed
2 tbsp (28 g) unsalted butter, melted, plus more for the pan
steps: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Grease an 8x8-inch (20x20 cm) baking pan generously with butter.
In a large bowl, combine the grated cassava, shredded coconut, and brown sugar. Mix well, breaking up any clumps of sugar.
Add the coconut milk, evaporated milk, melted butter, vanilla, cinnamon, nutmeg, allspice, and salt. Stir until everything is thoroughly combined into a thick, wet batter.
Pour the batter into the prepared pan and spread evenly. The mixture should be about 1.5 inches (4 cm) deep.
Bake 1 hour to 1 hour 15 minutes until the top is dark golden brown and caramelized, the edges are set, and the center is firm but still slightly moist. The pone will continue to set as it cools.
Cool completely in the pan—at least 1 hour. Cut into squares or rectangles. Cassava pone is best at room temperature or slightly warm, dense and fudgy and deeply satisfying.

MTQ.description: A vibrant red fish stew that captures the Creole spirit. Unlike a French court-bouillon which is a poaching liquid, this is a rich tomato sauce enriched with roucou (annatto) oil and fiery peppers, in which lime-marinated fish is gently poached.
ingredients: 2 lbs Red Snapper or similar fish (whole or steaks)
steps: Marinate fish in lime juice, garlic, and salt for 1 hour.
Sauté onion, scallion, and tomatoes in oil (roucou oil traditionally for red color).
Add water and bring to a boil to make a broth.
Add the fish and the marinade liquid.
Add the whole pepper. Simmer gently for 15-20 mins.
Serve with boiled cassava or breadfruit.

drink.description: Martinique’s signature: rhum agricole, lime coin, and cane sugar—bracing and aromatic.
ingredients: 1 tsp cane sugar or 1 sugar cube
steps: Add sugar and lime coin to a small glass.
Pour in rum and stir briefly.
Sip (often without ice).

dessert.description: Martinique’s crowning dessert: a trembling, silken coconut custard baked over a layer of burnt-sugar caramel, then unmolded to reveal a glossy amber crown cascading down snowy-white sides. The flan coco is where French pâtisserie meets the Antillean coconut palm—rich with coconut milk and sweetened condensed milk, perfumed with vanilla and a whisper of lime zest, and impossibly smooth. Every Martinican grandmother guards her recipe; every Sunday lunch ends with its unmolding, a moment of sweet suspense and communal delight.
ingredients: 1 can (14 oz / 396 g) sweetened condensed milk

steps: Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan over medium heat. Swirl gently (do not stir) until the sugar dissolves and turns a deep amber color, 5–7 minutes.
Immediately pour the caramel into a 9-inch (23 cm) round cake pan or flan mold, tilting to coat the bottom evenly. Set aside to harden.
Preheat oven to 325°F (163°C). Bring a kettle of water to a boil for the water bath.
In a blender, combine the coconut milk, sweetened condensed milk, eggs, egg yolks, vanilla, lime zest, and salt. Blend until perfectly smooth, about 30 seconds.
Pour the custard mixture through a fine-mesh strainer into the caramel-lined pan to ensure a silky texture.
Place the pan inside a larger roasting pan. Pour boiling water into the roasting pan until it reaches halfway up the sides of the flan mold.
Bake 55–65 minutes until the flan is set around the edges but still has a gentle wobble in the very center. Do not overbake.
Remove the flan from the water bath. Cool to room temperature, then refrigerate at least 4 hours or overnight until completely chilled and firmly set.
To unmold: run a thin knife around the edge. Place a serving plate upside down over the pan, then flip swiftly. Lift the pan—the caramel will pool around the flan in a glossy amber sauce. Serve cold.

MYS.description: Malaysia's national obsession. Fragrant coconut rice served with spicy sambal, anchovies, peanuts, and egg.
ingredients: Sambal: Dried chilies (blended), Onion, Garlic, Tamarind paste, Sugar, Shrimp paste (Belacan)
Garnishes: Fried Anchovies (Ikan Bilis), Roasted Peanuts, Cucumber slices, Hard-boiled eggs
steps: Rice: Wash rice. Cook with coconut milk, water, pandan leaves, and a pinch of salt in a rice cooker.
Sambal: Fry blended chili paste with onions and garlic in oil until oil separates. Add tamarind, sugar, and salt. Cook until deep red and thick.
Fry anchovies and peanuts until crispy.
Serve a mound of coconut rice on a banana leaf.
Top with a ladle of sambal, and arrange the anchovies, peanuts, cucumber, and egg around it.

drink.description: Malaysia’s iconic “pulled tea” with froth from repeatedly pouring between cups.
steps: Steep tea 3–5 minutes and strain.
Stir in condensed milk.
Pour back and forth between two cups to aerate and foam.
Serve hot.

dessert.description: Malaysia's most iconic iced dessert and Penang's crown jewel: a tall glass layered with shaved ice, creamy coconut milk, bright green pandan-flavored rice flour jelly noodles, and a cascade of dark, smoky palm sugar syrup. Cendol is the taste of tropical Malaysia—the pandan jelly is slippery and fragrant, the coconut milk is rich and cold, and the gula Melaka syrup adds a caramel depth that is unmistakably Southeast Asian. Hawker stalls in Penang draw snaking queues for their cendol, and the debate over the best stall is a national sport.
ingredients: Pandan jelly noodles (see Chef's Essentials below)
Palm sugar syrup (see Chef's Essentials below)
Shaved ice or finely crushed ice
1 cup (240 ml) pandan juice (from 10 pandan leaves blended with 1 cup water, strained)
1/4 tsp pandan extract (optional, for deeper color)
steps: Whisk together the rice flour, tapioca starch, pandan juice, water, pandan extract if using, and salt in a saucepan until smooth.
Cook over medium heat, stirring constantly, until the mixture thickens into a sticky, translucent green paste, about 5–7 minutes.
Press the hot paste through a cendol mold, colander, or flat sieve with large holes directly into a bowl of ice water. The strands will set immediately into short, worm-like jelly noodles.
Drain and keep chilled until assembly.

ingredients: 8 oz (225 g) gula Melaka (palm sugar), chopped or shaved
steps: Combine the palm sugar, water, and pandan leaf in a small saucepan.
Heat over medium-low, stirring until the sugar dissolves completely. Simmer 5 minutes until syrupy.
Strain out the pandan leaf. Cool to room temperature—the syrup will thicken further as it cools.
Stir the pinch of salt into the chilled coconut milk.
Fill tall glasses or bowls with a generous mound of shaved ice.
Spoon a generous portion of pandan jelly noodles over the ice. Add sweetened red beans if using.
Pour the salted coconut milk over the ice until it pools at the bottom.
Drizzle the palm sugar syrup generously over the top—it will cascade through the ice in dark amber ribbons.
Serve immediately with a spoon and straw. Eat quickly before the ice melts—though the melting is part of the pleasure, turning the glass into a sweet coconut-pandan soup.
Soak tamarind pulp in hot water 15–20 minutes.
Mash thoroughly, then press through a sieve to remove fibers/seeds.
Use immediately or refrigerate up to 1 week.
Shrimp paste is a fermented ingredient; for authenticity, purchase it.
Toast a small piece briefly in a dry pan or wrap in foil and heat until fragrant, then mash into the sauce/curry.

NGA.description: The smoky, spicy, tomato-rice dish that defines West African cuisine. The 'party' version is best.
ingredients: Base: 4 Red Bell Peppers, 3 Habanero/Scotch Bonnet peppers, 2 Onions, 4 Tomatoes (blended)
Spices: Curry powder, Thyme, Bay leaves, Bouillon cubes
steps: Heat oil. Fry sliced onions. Add tomato paste and fry for 5 mins (remove sourness).
Add the blended pepper mixture. Cook down for 15-20 mins until oil floats on top.
Add stock, spices, and salt. Bring to boil.
Wash rice thoroughly. Add to the pot. The liquid should just cover the rice.
Cover tightly with foil and a lid (steam cooks it). Turn heat to low.
Cook for 20-30 mins. Allow the bottom to burn slightly ('party jollof' smoky flavor).
Stir and serve with fried plantains and chicken.

drink.description: A traditional West African drink made from palm sap, served fresh or lightly fermented.
steps: Serve chilled.

dessert.description: Nigerian fried dough balls: fluffy, golden, lightly sweet, with a hint of nutmeg. Lagos's street food queen, sold at every corner.
steps: Whisk flour, sugar, yeast, nutmeg, and salt in a large bowl.
Add warm water gradually, stirring to form a thick, sticky batter (it should drop off a spoon in ribbons).
Cover with cling film and let rise in a warm spot for 1–2 hours until doubled and bubbly.
Heat oil to 340–350°F (170–175°C) in a deep pot (at least 3 inches / 7 cm deep).
Scoop batter with a wet spoon or oiled hand and drop small balls into the oil—do not crowd.
Fry, turning occasionally, until deep golden brown and cooked through, 4–5 minutes per batch.
Drain on paper towels. Dust with powdered sugar if desired. Serve warm.

NIC.description: A pre-Columbian survivor. 'Old Indian' is a thick, porridge-like stew that dates back to indigenous times. Shredded beef is cooked with maize dough (masa) and flavored with sour orange and mint, creating a hearty dish that is pure Nicaraguan history.
steps: Boil beef with garlic and onion until tender. Shred the meat. Save broth.
Blend the soaked tortillas with some broth to make a smooth batter.
Sauté onion, pepper, and tomato with achiote.
Add the shredded beef and fry briefly.
Pour in the tortilla batter and remaining broth. Stir constantly as it thickens.
Add sour orange juice and fresh mint. Simmer until it reaches a porridge-like consistency.
Serve with fried plantains and cuajada (cheese).

drink.description: Nicaragua’s national cocktail: rum blended with guava and lemon—fruity, bright, and tropical.
steps: Fill a shaker with ice.
Add rum, guava juice, lemon juice, and optional simple syrup.
Shake until very cold.
Strain into an ice-filled glass and serve.
Note (simple syrup): stir equal parts sugar + hot water until dissolved; cool.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.

dessert.description: Nicaraguan tres leches cake: sponge soaked in condensed milk, evaporated milk, and cream, topped with meringue. Every Nicaraguan birthday.
ingredients: Meringue: 3 large egg whites, 3/4 cup (150 g) sugar, pinch of cream of tartar
1 can (14 oz / 397 g) sweetened condensed milk
steps: Whisk condensed milk, evaporated milk, heavy cream, and vanilla together until smooth.
Chill until the cake is ready to soak.
Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Grease and flour a 9 × 13-inch (23 × 33 cm) baking pan.
Sift flour and baking powder together. Beat egg yolks with sugar until pale and thick. Stir in milk and vanilla, then fold in flour mixture.
Whip egg whites to stiff peaks. Gently fold into the batter in two additions.
Pour into the pan and bake 25–30 minutes until a toothpick comes out clean. Cool completely in the pan.
Poke the cake all over with a fork or skewer. Pour the Three-Milk Soak evenly over the cake. Refrigerate at least 4 hours (overnight is best).
For the meringue: beat 3 egg whites with cream of tartar until foamy, then gradually add sugar and beat to glossy stiff peaks. Spread or pipe over the soaked cake.
Lightly torch the meringue or broil for 1–2 minutes until golden. Dust with cinnamon and serve cold.
Toast achiote seeds 30–60 seconds.
Blend or grind seeds with vinegar, garlic, salt (and cumin) until a red paste forms.
Strain if gritty. Refrigerate up to 1 week.

NLD.description: The ultimate Dutch winter comfort. Potatoes mashed with curly kale, served with a giant smoked rookworst sausage and a dimple of gravy. It is simple, hearty, and quintessentially Dutch.
steps: Boil potatoes and kale in the same pot (kale on top) for 20 mins.
Place sausage on top to steam for the last 10 mins.
Remove sausage. Drain water.
Mash potatoes and kale with milk and butter.
Stir in crispy bacon bits.
Serve with sliced sausage and a well of gravy in the center.

drink.description: A Dutch bar tradition: an ice-cold tulip glass of genever paired with a small beer—sip the genever first, then chase with beer.
ingredients: 1 1/2 oz jonge genever, very cold (45 ml)
steps: Chill the genever glass (a small tulip) and the beer glass.
Pour genever to the brim of the tulip glass (so full you shouldn’t lift it at first).
Take the first sip by bending down to the glass.
Then drink the beer alongside it, alternating as you like.
Serve immediately while both are cold.

dessert.description: Two thin waffle cookies sandwiching warm caramel syrup. Amsterdam's most iconic treat, best eaten fresh from the waffle iron at Albert Cuyp Market.
ingredients: 1/3 cup (65 g) packed light brown sugar
Caramel Syrup / Stroop (see preliminary steps below)
1 cup (200 g) packed dark brown sugar
1/4 cup (85 g) dark corn syrup or golden syrup
steps: Combine brown sugar, butter, syrup, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat.
Stir until butter melts and sugar dissolves into a smooth caramel, about 5 minutes.
Keep warm while assembling the waffles (rewarm gently if it stiffens).
Dissolve yeast in warm milk and let stand 5 minutes until foamy.
Cream butter and brown sugar until fluffy. Beat in egg, then the yeast-milk mixture.
Add flour, cinnamon, and salt. Mix to a soft dough. Cover and let rise 1 hour.
Divide dough into walnut-sized balls (about 1 oz / 28 g each).
Preheat a pizzelle or stroopwafel iron. Press each ball into a thin waffle, about 30–45 seconds until golden.
While still hot, slice each waffle in half horizontally with a sharp knife.
Spread a generous layer of warm Stroop on the bottom half, press the top half on, and let the caramel set briefly. Serve warm.

NOR.description: Mutton in Cabbage. Norway's national dish is deceptively simple: layers of mutton and cabbage, peppercorns, and water, steamed until tender. It is celebrated every autumn with its own national day.
ingredients: 3 lb lamb shoulder (bone-in), cut into large chunks (1.4 kg)
1 large green cabbage, cut into wedges (about 2 lb / 900 g)
1 1/2 tsp kosher salt, plus more to taste
2 tbsp all-purpose flour (for thickening, optional but common)
2 cups water (480 ml), plus more if needed
steps: In a heavy pot, layer lamb and cabbage wedges, sprinkling some salt, peppercorns, and a little flour between layers.
Pour in water; it should come about 1/3 of the way up the ingredients (add more if needed).
Bring to a gentle simmer, cover, and cook very low 2–2 1/2 hours until lamb is tender and cabbage is soft.
Taste broth and adjust salt.
Serve hot, traditionally with boiled potatoes on the side.

drink.description: Norwegian gløgg: mulled red wine steeped with spices and citrus, often finished with a splash of aquavit and served with raisins and almonds.
steps: In a pot, warm water and sugar with orange zest/peel and spices until sugar dissolves.
Add red wine and heat gently until steaming (do not boil).
Cover and steep 20–30 minutes off heat.
Stir in raisins and almonds.
Add aquavit off heat if using.
Ladle into mugs and serve hot.

dessert.description: Norwegian meringue-topped sponge layered with vanilla custard cream. Voted Norway's national cake. Not humble about it.
ingredients: Sponge: 1/2 cup (115 g) unsalted butter, softened
Vanilla Custard Cream (see preliminary steps below)
1/2 cup (120 ml) heavy cream, whipped to soft peaks
steps: Whisk egg yolks, sugar, and cornstarch in a saucepan until smooth.
Gradually whisk in milk. Cook over medium heat, stirring constantly, until thickened and bubbling, about 3–4 minutes.
Remove from heat, stir in vanilla. Press plastic wrap directly onto the surface and chill completely.
Fold the whipped cream into the chilled custard until smooth.
Preheat oven to 340°F (170°C). Line a 9 × 13-inch (23 × 33 cm) pan with parchment.
Sponge: cream butter and sugar. Beat in egg yolks one at a time. Fold in flour, baking powder, and milk. Spread evenly in the pan.
Meringue: whip egg whites to soft peaks, gradually add sugar, and whip to glossy stiff peaks. Spread over the sponge batter. Scatter sliced almonds on top.
Bake 30–35 minutes until the meringue is lightly golden and crisp and the sponge springs back.
Cool completely. Carefully cut the cake horizontally into two layers.
Spread the Vanilla Custard Cream over the bottom layer and place the meringue-topped layer on top.
Refrigerate at least 1 hour before slicing. Serve cold.

NPL.description: Nepal’s everyday national meal: lentil soup (dal) with rice (bhat) and a simple vegetable curry (tarkari). It’s practical, balanced, and endlessly variable from home to home.
ingredients: Dal lentil soup (see Chef's Essentials below)
Bhat steamed rice (see Chef's Essentials below)
Tarkari vegetable curry (see Chef's Essentials below)

steps: Simmer lentils with water, turmeric, and salt until soft, 15–20 minutes.
Tadka: heat oil/ghee, add cumin; when it sizzles add onion, garlic, and ginger; cook until golden. Add tomato and cook until jammy.
Stir tadka into dal and simmer 5 minutes. Adjust thickness with water and salt to taste.
Cook rice with water (rice cooker or covered pot) until tender; fluff.
Heat oil, add cumin. Stir in coriander/curry powder. Add potatoes and cauliflower, toss to coat, add water, cover and simmer 12–15 minutes until tender. Salt to taste.
Serve rice with a ladle of dal and a scoop of tarkari; finish with cilantro and lime.

drink.dish: Masala Chiya (मसला चिया) — Nepali Spiced Milk Tea
drink.description: Nepal’s daily tea: black tea simmered with warming spices and milk, sweetened to taste.
ingredients: 2 tsp black tea leaves (or 2 tea bags)
steps: Simmer water with ginger, cardamom, and cinnamon 4–5 minutes.
Add tea and simmer 2 minutes.
Add milk and sugar and simmer 3–4 minutes. Strain and serve hot.

dessert.description: Nepali rice flour ring bread: fermented rice batter fried into golden crispy rings. Sweet, slightly chewy. A Tihar and Dashain festival essential.
ingredients: 2 cups (400 g) rice flour (or soaked and ground raw rice)
1/4 cup (55 g) ghee or melted butter
1/2 cup (120 ml) warm water (or as needed)
steps: If using raw rice: soak 2 cups rice overnight, drain, and grind to a smooth paste with minimal water.
Combine rice flour (or paste), sugar, melted ghee, cardamom, cloves, and banana if using. Mix well.
Add warm water gradually to form a thick, pourable batter (slightly thicker than pancake batter).
Cover and let the batter ferment in a warm spot for at least 8 hours or overnight.
Heat oil to 340°F (170°C) in a deep wok or pot.
Take a handful of batter and let it drip from your fist in a circular motion into the hot oil, forming a ring about 5–6 inches (13–15 cm) across.
Fry until golden brown on both sides, turning once, about 2–3 minutes per side.
Drain on paper towels. Serve warm or at room temperature.

NZL.description: A Sunday roast tradition. Tender leg of lamb served with sweet potatoes (Kumara) and mint sauce.
ingredients: 2 lbs Kumara (Sweet Potato), peeled and chunked
Mint Sauce: Fresh mint, Sugar, Vinegar, Boiling water
steps: Preheat oven to 350°F (180°C).
Make small incisions in the lamb. Stuff with garlic slivers and rosemary.
Rub lamb with oil, salt, and pepper. Place in roasting pan.
Roast for 1 hour 30 mins (medium).
Add kumara chunks to the pan around the lamb for the last 45 minutes. Toss in the meat juices.
Rest meat for 20 mins before carving.
Mix chopped mint with sugar and boiling water, then add vinegar. Serve sauce with the lamb.

drink.description: A classic Australian/New Zealand mixed drink: bright citrus with a few dashes of aromatic bitters.
ingredients: 1 tbsp lime cordial (or 1/2 oz fresh lime juice + 1 tsp simple syrup)
steps: Fill a glass with ice.
Add lime cordial (or lime juice + simple syrup).
Top with lemonade and add bitters.
Stir gently and garnish with lime if desired.
Note (simple syrup): stir equal parts sugar + hot water until dissolved; cool.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.

ingredients: Zest of 4 limes (use a microplane; avoid bitter white pith)
steps: Rub lime zest into sugar with your fingers until fragrant (this pulls out citrus oils).
Add lime juice and stir until sugar dissolves (or warm gently to dissolve faster, then cool).
Bottle and refrigerate up to 2 weeks.

dessert.description: The New Zealand version: crisp meringue shell with marshmallow center, topped with whipped cream, kiwifruit slices, and passion fruit. Yes, Australia also claims it, but this is the Kiwi version.
ingredients: 4 large egg whites, at room temperature
steps: Preheat oven to 250°F (120°C). Line a baking sheet with parchment and draw a 9-inch (23 cm) circle.
Beat egg whites with an electric mixer until soft peaks form. Gradually add caster sugar, a tablespoon at a time, beating well after each addition until glossy and stiff.
Fold in vinegar, cornstarch, and vanilla.
Pile the meringue onto the circle, shaping into a round with slightly higher edges and a shallow well in the center.
Bake 1 hour 15 minutes until the outside is dry and crisp. Turn off the oven, crack the door, and let the pavlova cool completely inside.
Whip cream with powdered sugar to soft peaks. Pile into the center of the cooled pavlova.
Top with kiwifruit slices and passion fruit pulp. Add berries if desired. Serve immediately.

OMN.description: Oman’s festival centerpiece: meat marinated with spices and aromatics and cooked slowly until it falls apart. Traditionally buried in a sand oven; at home, low-and-slow roasting gets you close.
ingredients: 2 tsp ground paprika or mild chili
1 tsp kosher salt, plus more to taste
1 cup (240 ml) water or stock (for roasting pan)
steps: Mix garlic, ginger, vinegar, oil, spices, and salt into a paste. Rub all over lamb. Cover and marinate 8–24 hours.
Heat oven to 300°F (150°C). Place lamb in a roasting pan; add water/stock to the pan.
Cover tightly with foil (or wrap lamb in parchment then foil). Roast 3 1/2–4 1/2 hours until very tender.
Uncover and roast 10–15 minutes to brown slightly.
Rest 15 minutes, then shred or slice. Serve with rice and salad.

drink.description: Oman’s aromatic coffee—light-bodied and spiced with cardamom and often saffron—served with dates as a ritual of welcome.
ingredients: 2 tbsp (10–12 g) lightly roasted ground coffee
steps: Bring water to a gentle boil. Add coffee and simmer 8–10 minutes.
Add cardamom, saffron (and cloves if using) and simmer 3–5 minutes.
Let settle, strain, and serve in small cups.

dessert.description: Omani halwa: a translucent, jewel-like confection slow-cooked from cornstarch, sugar, ghee, saffron, rosewater, and nuts. Served with Omani coffee as a sign of hospitality.
ingredients: Generous pinch saffron threads, steeped in 2 tbsp (30 ml) warm rosewater
steps: Dissolve cornstarch in 1 cup (240 ml) of the water and set aside.
In a heavy-bottomed pot, combine sugar with the remaining 1 cup (235 ml) water. Heat over medium until sugar dissolves into a clear syrup.
Slowly pour the cornstarch mixture into the syrup, stirring constantly to prevent lumps.
Add ghee a tablespoon at a time, stirring continuously over medium-low heat.
Cook, stirring without stopping, for 30–45 minutes. The mixture will thicken, become translucent, and begin to pull away from the sides of the pot.
Stir in saffron-rosewater, additional rosewater, and cardamom. Fold in nuts.
Pour into a greased dish or shape into a mound. Let cool to room temperature.
Slice or scoop portions. Serve alongside Omani kahwa (coffee).

PAK.description: A rich, slow-cooked stew made with beef shank and marrow bones, thickened with flour. Traditionally eaten for breakfast.
ingredients: Nihari Masala: Fennel seeds, Dry Ginger, Cumin, Cloves, Cardamom, Cinnamon, Chili powder
Garnish: Ginger julienne, Green chilies, Cilantro, Lemon wedges
steps: Heat oil. Fry onions until golden. Add meat and sear well.
Add the Nihari spices and salt. Fry for a few minutes.
Add 6-8 cups of water. Cover and simmer on low heat for 4-6 hours until meat is falling off the bone.
Slowly stir in the dissolved flour to thicken the gravy.
Simmer for another 15 minutes.
Serve hot, topped generously with fresh ginger, chilies, and a squeeze of lemon. Best with Naan.

drink.description: Pakistani-style milk tea, typically strong and sweet.
steps: Bring milk to a gentle simmer.
Add tea and simmer 3–5 minutes.
Strain and sweeten.

dessert.description: Fermented batter piped into pretzel-like spirals, deep-fried until crispy, and immediately dunked in saffron-cardamom sugar syrup. Lahore's sweetest morning ritual.
ingredients: 2 tbsp (20 g) rice flour or cornstarch
1/4 tsp baking soda (optional, for extra crunch)
Pinch of saffron threads dissolved in 1 tbsp warm milk
Vegetable oil or ghee, for deep-frying
Saffron-Cardamom Sugar Syrup (see preliminary steps below)

steps: Combine sugar and water in a saucepan. Stir over medium heat until sugar dissolves.
Add saffron, cardamom, and lemon juice. Simmer without stirring until the syrup reaches a one-string consistency (about 5–7 minutes).
Stir in rosewater if using. Keep warm but not hot—the syrup should be slightly warm when dunking jalebis.
Mix all-purpose flour and rice flour in a bowl. Add yogurt, warm water, and saffron milk. Whisk into a smooth batter (consistency of thick pancake batter).
Cover and let ferment in a warm place for 12–18 hours (or at least overnight). The batter should be slightly bubbly and smell faintly tangy.
Stir in baking soda if using. Transfer batter to a squeeze bottle or piping bag with a small round tip.
Heat oil or ghee to 350°F (175°C) in a wide, shallow pan.
Pipe the batter into the hot oil in tight concentric circles or pretzel shapes.
Fry until golden and crisp on both sides, about 2–3 minutes total, flipping once.
Immediately transfer hot jalebis into the warm Saffron-Cardamom Sugar Syrup. Soak for 30 seconds, then remove.
Serve hot and crispy. Best eaten within minutes of frying.
Toast whole fennel seeds briefly and grind (if using whole).
Mix with remaining spices.
Store airtight up to 3 months.

Punjab.description: Punjab’s iconic wok-style curry: chicken and tomatoes cooked in a karahi (or heavy pan) with ginger, green chilies, and minimal spices so the poultry and tomato shine. Technique: high heat to char tomatoes and reduce the gravy; finish with fresh cilantro and ginger.
ingredients: 2 lbs (900 g) bone-in chicken, cut into pieces
1/4 cup (60 ml) neutral oil or ghee
1 tbsp ginger paste, 1 tbsp garlic paste
1 tsp red chili powder (or to taste)
Fresh cilantro and ginger julienne, for garnish
steps: In a karahi or wide heavy pan, heat the oil. Add cumin seeds; when they sizzle, add ginger and garlic paste. Fry 1 min.
Add the chicken and sear over high heat 4–5 min. Add turmeric, chili powder, coriander powder, and salt; stir.
Add the tomatoes and green chilies. Cook over high heat, stirring, until the tomatoes break down and the oil separates, 15–20 min. The gravy should be thick and clinging to the chicken.
Garnish with cilantro and ginger. Serve hot with naan or roti.

drink.description: Cooling yogurt drink.
ingredients: Pinch of salt or sugar to taste
steps: Blend yogurt with water; season. Serve cold.

Sindh.description: Layered rice and meat biryani from Sindh: marinated meat (or potatoes), fragrant basmati, and a distinct layer of yogurt-mint-chili. Technique: parboil rice; layer with partially cooked meat and potatoes; seal and cook on dum (trapped steam) so the flavors meld.
ingredients: 2 cups (400 g) basmati rice, soaked 30 min
1 lb (450 g) beef or mutton, cubed
2 onions, sliced and fried until golden (birista)
2 tbsp biryani masala (or mix of cumin, coriander, cardamom, cloves, cinnamon)
Saffron soaked in 2 tbsp warm milk (optional)
steps: Marinate the meat with half the yogurt, ginger-garlic paste, half the biryani masala, and salt 1–2 hours. In a pot, brown the meat; add a little water and cook until nearly tender. Add potatoes and cook until just done. Set aside.
Parboil the rice in plenty of salted water until 70% done; drain.

In a heavy pot, layer: half the rice, then meat and potatoes, fried onion, mint, cilantro, remaining yogurt and masala, then remaining rice. Drizzle saffron milk and a little ghee. Cover tightly; cook on very low heat (dum) 25–30 min. Rest 10 min; fluff and serve with raita.

drink.description: Strong milk tea.
steps: Simmer milk with tea; strain and sweeten.

Khyber Pakhtunkhwa.description: Peshawari flat kebabs: minced meat (beef or mutton) with pomegranate seeds, coriander, and spices, pan-fried until crisp-edged. Technique: minimal binding so the kebab holds together but stays coarse; fry in enough oil or ghee to get a crisp crust.
ingredients: 1 1/2 lbs (680 g) ground beef or mutton
2 tbsp chickpea flour (besan) or cornmeal (optional, for binding)
steps: Mix the meat with onion, anardana, cilantro, green chilies, coriander, cumin, chili powder, besan if using, and salt. Knead 2–3 min. Rest 30 min.
Shape into flat round patties about 1/2 inch thick and 3–4 inches across.
Heat oil or ghee in a heavy skillet. Fry the kebabs over medium heat 4–5 min per side until browned and cooked through. Drain on paper towels. Serve with naan, chutney, and onion salad.

drink.description: Peshawari green tea with cardamom.
steps: Brew green tea with cardamom; sweeten to taste.

Balochistan.description: Balochi whole lamb or chicken, marinated with salt and green papaya (tenderizer), then roasted on a spit or in an oven until the skin is crisp and the meat is tender. Technique: minimal spices so the meat flavor dominates; slow roast so the fat bastes the meat.
ingredients: 1 whole leg of lamb (4–6 lbs) or 1 whole chicken (3–4 lbs)
1 tbsp green papaya paste or raw papaya paste (tenderizer), optional
Lemon wedges and chaat masala, to serve
steps: Score the meat. Rub with salt, pepper, and papaya paste if using. Marinate 4–6 hours or overnight in the fridge.

Roast on a spit over coals, or in an oven at 375°F (190°C) on a rack, basting occasionally, until the internal temperature reaches 145°F (63°C) for lamb or 165°F (74°C) for chicken and the outside is golden and crisp (1–2 hours depending on size).
Rest 15 min. Carve and serve with lemon and chaat masala, and flatbread.

drink.description: Cool drink with rich meat.
steps: Serve cold.

Gilgit-Baltistan.description: Mountain turnover: spiced minced meat and onion stuffed in a dough pocket and pan-fried or baked. Technique: dough is rolled thin; filling is sealed inside; cooked until the bread is golden and the meat is done.
ingredients: For dough: 2 cups (250 g) all-purpose flour, 1/2 tsp salt, water to bind
For filling: 1 lb (450 g) ground beef or mutton, 1 onion (finely chopped), 2–3 green chilies, 1 tsp cumin, 1/2 tsp chili powder, salt, cilantro
steps: Make a stiff dough with flour, salt, and water; rest 20 min.
Mix the filling ingredients. Divide the dough into 4–6 balls. Roll each into a thin round. Place filling on one half; fold and seal the edges well.
Pan-fry in a little oil over medium heat 4–5 min per side until golden and the meat is cooked, or bake at 375°F (190°C) 20–25 min. Serve hot with chutney or yogurt.

drink.description: Local tea.
steps: Brew and serve.

Islamabad.description: Creamy black lentils and kidney beans, slow-cooked with butter and cream—a staple of the capital’s dhaba and home table. Technique: soak and simmer the legumes until tender; finish with a tadka (tempering) and cream for a rich, silky texture.
ingredients: 1 cup (200 g) whole black lentils (urad dal), soaked overnight
1/4 cup (50 g) red kidney beans (rajma), soaked overnight
steps: Drain and rinse the lentils and beans. In a pressure cooker or pot, cook with 4–5 cups water until very tender (pressure cooker 3–4 whistles, or simmer 1–1 1/2 hours). Mash some of the lentils with the back of a spoon.

In a pan, melt butter; add cumin, then onion and ginger-garlic. Fry until golden. Add tomato, turmeric, chili powder, garam masala, salt. Cook until the masala releases oil. Add to the lentils; simmer 15–20 min. Stir in cream; adjust salt. Garnish with cilantro. Serve with naan or rice.

drink.description: Milk tea.
steps: Simmer; strain and sweeten.

Azad Jammu and Kashmir.description: Kashmiri-style lamb meatballs in a mild, creamy yogurt gravy—a festive dish of the region. Technique: meat is pounded with fat until very smooth, shaped into balls, and poached in the yogurt gravy so they stay tender.
ingredients: 1 lb (450 g) lamb (or mutton), minced very fine or pounded
2 tbsp lamb fat or ghee, softened
Kashmiri chili or paprika for color (optional)
steps: Mix the minced lamb with the fat, a pinch of salt, and half the fennel. Pound or process until very smooth. Shape into smooth balls (about 1 1/2 inch).
In a wide pot, whisk the yogurt with 1–2 cups water, ginger, fennel, cardamom, onion, and salt. Bring to a gentle simmer (do not boil hard or the yogurt may split).
Gently add the meatballs. Poach 15–20 min until cooked through. The gravy should be thick and creamy. Serve with rice or naan.

drink.description: Pink tea: green tea boiled with baking soda, then milk and salt.
steps: Boil tea with soda until deep red; add milk and salt; simmer until pink. Strain and serve.

PAN.description: Panama's soul in a bowl. This restorative chicken soup is famous for curing hangovers and bringing families together. Its distinct flavor comes from 'culantro' (a stronger cousin of cilantro) and the starchy creaminess of slow-cooked ñame (yam).
ingredients: 1 bunch Culantro (essential flavor, stronger than cilantro)
steps: Cut chicken into pieces. Season with garlic, oregano, and chopped culantro.
In a large pot, sear the chicken with onions.
Add water to cover. Bring to a boil.
Add the ñame chunks. Simmer until the chicken is soft and the ñame starts to dissolve (this thickens the soup naturally).
Adjust salt. The soup should be slightly thick and very aromatic.
Serve with white rice on the side (to mix in).

drink.description: A common way to enjoy Panama’s Seco Herrerano: mixed with milk/cream and sweetened to taste.
ingredients: 1–2 tsp sugar or condensed milk (to taste)
steps: Fill a glass with ice.
Add Seco and milk; sweeten to taste.
Stir well and serve.

dessert.description: Panamanian fried flatbread served with dulce de leche. Crispy, puffy dough meets silky caramel.
ingredients: 2 tbsp (28 g) unsalted butter, cold, cut into small pieces
1/2 cup (150 g) dulce de leche (store-bought or homemade)
steps: Whisk flour, sugar, baking powder, and salt in a bowl. Cut in butter with your fingers or a pastry cutter until the mixture resembles coarse crumbs.
Add warm water gradually, mixing until a soft, slightly sticky dough forms. Knead on a floured surface for 2–3 minutes until smooth.
Cover and rest the dough for 30 minutes.
Divide into 8 equal pieces. Roll each into a thin round about 6 inches (15 cm) across.
Heat oil to 350°F (175°C) in a deep pan. Fry each hojaldra until puffed and golden, about 1–2 minutes per side.
Drain on paper towels. Serve warm, drizzled or dipped with dulce de leche and a dusting of powdered sugar.

PER.description: Peru's gift to the culinary world. Born from the Moche civilization who used fermented juice, and refined by the Spanish with limes, this dish 'cooks' the freshest raw fish in 'Leche de Tigre'—a spicy, citrusy marinade that is the essence of the Peruvian coast.
ingredients: 1 lb Fresh White Fish (Sea Bass, Flounder) - semi-firm
1 Aji Limo or Habanero chili, minced
steps: Cut fish into uniform 2cm cubes. Place in a cold glass bowl.
Rub a slice of chili around the bowl for aroma.
Add salt and toss fish. Let sit 1 minute.
Add the cold lime juice. Toss. Let sit for 2-3 minutes max (you want the center raw).
Add onions, cilantro, and chopped chili. Toss gently.
Serve immediately alongside a slice of boiled sweet potato (to balance acidity) and corn.

drink.description: A South American classic (claimed by Peru and Chile): pisco shaken with lime, simple syrup, egg white, and bitters.
steps: Add pisco, lime juice, simple syrup, and egg white to a shaker (no ice) and dry-shake 15 seconds.
Add ice and shake hard 15–20 seconds until very cold and frothy.
Double-strain into a chilled coupe or rocks glass.
Dot the foam with bitters and serve immediately.
Note (simple syrup): stir equal parts sugar + hot water until dissolved; cool.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.

dessert.description: Lima's sigh: manjar blanco (dulce de leche) topped with port wine meringue. Created in the 19th century by Doña Amparo Ayarza. A sigh of pleasure.
ingredients: Manjar Blanco / Dulce de Leche base (see preliminary steps below)
Port Wine Meringue topping (see preliminary steps below)
2 cans (14 oz / 397 g each) sweetened condensed milk
steps: Combine condensed milk and evaporated milk in a heavy saucepan over medium-low heat.
Stir constantly until the mixture thickens and turns a deep caramel color, about 40–50 minutes.
Temper the egg yolks: whisk a few spoonfuls of the hot mixture into the yolks, then stir the yolks back into the pot.
Cook, stirring, for 3–4 more minutes until thick and creamy. Stir in vanilla.
Divide among serving glasses or a bowl. Let cool to room temperature.
In a heatproof bowl set over simmering water (double boiler), whisk egg whites and sugar until the sugar dissolves and the mixture is warm (about 140°F / 60°C).
Remove from heat and beat with an electric mixer until glossy stiff peaks form.
Gently fold in the port wine.
Prepare the Manjar Blanco and divide among dessert glasses or a serving dish. Let cool completely.
Prepare the Port Wine Meringue.
Pipe or spoon the meringue over the cooled manjar blanco.
Dust generously with ground cinnamon.
Chill until ready to serve. Serve cold or at room temperature.

PHL.description: The unofficial national dish. Chicken braised in vinegar, soy sauce, and garlic until tender and glazed.
steps: Combine chicken, soy sauce, and garlic in a pot. Marinate for 30 mins.
Add vinegar, bay leaves, and peppercorns. Bring to a boil. Do not stir (let vinegar cook off).
Lower heat, cover, and simmer for 30 mins.
Uncover. Simmer until sauce reduces and thickens.
Optional: Remove chicken and fry in oil to crisp the skin, then return to sauce.
Serve over white rice.

drink.description: A coconut spirit traditionally consumed as a shot or with citrus.
steps: Serve as a small pour.
Sip or take as a shot; chase with citrus if desired.

dessert.description: Manila's ultimate summer salvation — the Filipino shaved ice dessert whose name means 'mix-mix,' a glorious chaos of sweetened beans, jellies, tropical fruits, coconut, leche flan, and ube ice cream, all buried under a mountain of finely shaved ice and drowned in evaporated milk. Every sari-sari store, every turo-turo, every lola has a version. You build it in layers, then destroy those layers with a long spoon, mixing everything into a purple-tinted, creamy, crunchy, chewy kaleidoscope of textures. It is maximalism as dessert philosophy.
ingredients: 2 tbsp nata de coco (coconut gel cubes)
2 tbsp macapuno (coconut sport) strips in syrup
2 tbsp sweetened jackfruit (langka), cut into strips
1 tbsp pinipig (toasted pounded young rice flakes)
1 tbsp gulaman (agar jelly), cubed — any color
1 slice leche flan, cubed (see preliminary steps)
2 tbsp ube halaya (purple yam jam) (see preliminary steps)
1 can (14 oz / 400 ml) sweetened condensed milk
steps: Make caramel: melt sugar in a llanera or oval mold over medium heat until amber. Swirl to coat the bottom evenly. Set aside to harden.
Whisk egg yolks gently (avoid creating bubbles). Stir in condensed milk, evaporated milk, and vanilla until smooth.
Strain the mixture through a fine sieve into the caramel-lined mold.
Cover tightly with foil. Steam over simmering water for 45–50 minutes until set but still jiggly in the center.
Cool completely, then refrigerate at least 4 hours. Invert onto a plate to unmold. Slice for halo-halo.

ingredients: 1 lb (450 g) purple yam (ube), peeled and grated
steps: Combine grated ube and coconut milk in a heavy saucepan. Cook over medium heat, stirring frequently, until ube is tender, about 20 minutes.
Add sugar and butter. Continue stirring over medium-low heat until the mixture thickens into a dense, glossy jam that pulls away from the sides of the pan, 15–20 minutes more.
Stir in vanilla. Cool and refrigerate. Use as a layer in halo-halo.
Prepare all sweetened ingredients (beans, fruits, jellies) in advance; chill everything thoroughly.
In a tall glass or bowl, layer the sweetened beans, nata de coco, kaong, macapuno, jackfruit, saba banana, gulaman, and pinipig — roughly 1–2 tablespoons of each.
Pack finely shaved ice on top until the glass is heaping.
Drizzle evaporated milk generously over the ice.
Crown with a scoop of ube ice cream, a spoonful of ube halaya, and cubed leche flan.
Serve immediately with a long spoon. Mix everything together before eating — that is the whole point of halo-halo.

POL.description: The legendary 'Hunter's Stew' that dates back to medieval times. A hearty mix of sauerkraut, fresh cabbage, and various meats (sausage, pork, beef) that is traditionally cooked for days, getting better with each reheat.
steps: In a large pot, fry bacon and onion. Add pork cubes and brown.
Add fresh cabbage and a little water. Cook until soft.
Add sauerkraut, kielbasa, soaked mushrooms (and their liquid), and spices.
Pour in the wine. Cover and simmer on low heat for at least 2-3 hours (traditionally reheated over several days).
The stew should be thick and dark.
Serve with rye bread.

drink.description: A modern Polish favorite nicknamed “apple pie”: bison grass vodka mixed with cloudy apple juice and cinnamon.
ingredients: Garnish: cinnamon stick and/or apple slice
steps: Fill a highball glass with ice.
Pour in Żubrówka.
Top with apple juice and stir gently.
Garnish with a cinnamon stick (and apple slice if you like).
Serve cold.

dessert.description: Poland's iconic cheesecake — dense, creamy, and incomparably rich, made with twaróg (Polish farmer's cheese) that gives it a texture no Western cream-cheese version can replicate. Studded with raisins, perfumed with vanilla, and cradled in a buttery shortcrust shell, sernik appears at every Wigilia (Christmas Eve), every Sunday dinner, and every cukiernia (pastry shop) in Poland. It is not New York cheesecake — it is older, denser, and better.
ingredients: 2 lbs (900 g) twaróg (Polish farmer's cheese), pressed dry and passed through a sieve twice
2 tbsp (16 g) cornstarch or potato starch
1/2 cup (75 g) raisins, soaked in 2 tbsp rum or warm water

steps: Pulse flour, powdered sugar, salt, and cold butter in a food processor until it resembles coarse crumbs.
Add egg yolk and water; pulse just until dough comes together. Do not overwork.
Wrap in plastic and refrigerate 30 minutes.
Roll or press dough into the bottom (and optionally 1 inch up the sides) of a 9-inch (23 cm) springform pan. Prick with a fork.
Par-bake at 350°F (175°C) for 12–15 minutes until just set and lightly golden. Cool before filling.
Preheat oven to 325°F (165°C).
Cream butter and sugar until fluffy. Add egg yolks one at a time, beating well after each.
Add the sieved twaróg in batches, mixing until completely smooth. Stir in cornstarch, vanilla, and lemon zest.
Fold in the drained raisins.
In a separate bowl, whip egg whites with a pinch of salt to stiff peaks. Gently fold into the cheese mixture in three additions — do not deflate.
Pour filling over the par-baked crust. Smooth the top.
Bake for 60–70 minutes until set with a slight wobble in the center. Turn off the oven, crack the door, and let the sernik cool inside for 1 hour to prevent cracking.
Refrigerate overnight. Dust with powdered sugar before serving. Sernik is always better the next day.

PRI.description: An Afro-Caribbean icon derived from the West African 'fufu'. Green plantains are fried, then aggressively mashed in a wooden pilón with garlic, olive oil, and crackling pork rinds (chicharron), creating a garlicky, savory mound that is Puerto Rico's unofficial anthem.
steps: Peel plantains and cut into 1-inch chunks.
Deep fry plantains until golden but not brown (cooked through).
In a pilon (wooden mortar), mash garlic and olive oil.
Add fried plantains and chicharron pieces. Mash everything together until combined.
Add a splash of broth to keep it moist.
Form into a tight half-dome shape.
Serve with shrimp in garlic sauce or chicken broth on the side.

drink.description: A Puerto Rican classic: rum, coconut, and pineapple blended into a creamy tropical cocktail.
steps: Add rum, pineapple juice, cream of coconut, and ice to a blender.
Blend until smooth and slushy.
Pour into a chilled glass and garnish if desired.
Note (quick cream of coconut): heat 1/2 cup coconut cream + 1/2 cup sugar until dissolved; cool.
Combine coconut milk, sugar, and salt in a saucepan.
Warm gently, stirring until sugar dissolves and mixture thickens slightly.
Cool and bottle; refrigerate up to 2 weeks. Shake before use.

dessert.description: Puerto Rico's beloved coconut pudding — its name means 'wobbly' or 'jiggly,' and that is exactly what it does when you bring it to the table. Silky coconut milk set with cornstarch into a cloud-white trembling custard, dusted with a snowfall of cinnamon. Tembleque is the essential dessert of every Puerto Rican Nochebuena (Christmas Eve), every family reunion, and every Sunday dinner. It is simplicity elevated to perfection — no eggs, no gelatin, just coconut and patience.
ingredients: 2 cans (13.5 oz / 400 ml each) full-fat coconut milk
steps: In a heavy saucepan, whisk together coconut milk, sugar, cornstarch, and salt until no lumps remain.

Place over medium heat and cook, stirring constantly with a wooden spoon or whisk, until the mixture thickens and begins to pull away from the sides of the pan, 8–12 minutes. It should coat the spoon thickly.
Remove from heat and stir in vanilla (and coconut extract if using).
Pour into a lightly greased 8-inch (20 cm) round mold, individual ramekins, or a decorative gelatin mold.
Let cool to room temperature, then refrigerate at least 4 hours or overnight until firmly set.
Unmold onto a plate (run a knife around the edge if needed). Dust generously with ground cinnamon. Slice and serve cold.

PRK.description: North Korea’s most famous dish abroad: chewy buckwheat noodles in a clean, cold beef-and-dongchimi broth, topped with sliced beef, pear, and cucumber. Subtle on purpose—refreshing rather than spicy.
ingredients: For broth: 1 1/2 lb (680 g) beef brisket or shank
1 tsp kosher salt, plus more to taste
1 cup (240 ml) dongchimi brine (see preliminary steps) or mild pickle brine
For serving: 1 lb (450 g) naengmyeon buckwheat noodles
steps: Make dongchimi (see preliminary steps) at least 2–3 days ahead.
Simmer beef with water, salt, scallions, and garlic until tender, 1 1/2–2 hours. Remove beef; chill for slicing. Strain broth.
Season broth with dongchimi brine; chill until very cold (an hour in the freezer helps).
Cook noodles per package. Rinse under cold running water, then rub/agitate to remove starch; drain well.
Portion noodles into bowls, add cold broth, top with sliced beef, pear, cucumber, and egg. Serve with mustard and vinegar at the table.

ingredients: 1 lb (450 g) Korean radish (daikon), cut into 1-inch (2.5 cm) cubes
steps: Dissolve salt and sugar in water.
Add radish, garlic, ginger, scallions (and chili if using) to a clean jar; pour brine over to submerge.
Cover loosely and ferment at cool room temp 2–3 days until lightly tangy, then refrigerate.
Use the brine for naengmyeon; it continues to develop in the fridge.

drink.description: A warming, slightly bitter-sweet tea made by simmering ginseng and sweetening with honey—common across the Korean peninsula.
ingredients: 10–15 g dried ginseng slices (or 1 small fresh ginseng root, sliced)
steps: Simmer ginseng (and jujubes if using) in water 15–20 minutes.
Strain into cups and sweeten with honey to taste.

dessert.description: An ancient Korean court dessert whose name literally means 'medicine rice' — glutinous rice steamed with chestnuts, jujubes (dried red dates), pine nuts, sesame oil, soy sauce, and honey into a sweet, sticky, jewel-studded confection. Yakbap dates back to the Three Kingdoms period and was once served only to royalty. In North Korea, it remains a treasured celebratory dish for Jeongwol Daeboreum (the first full moon of the lunar new year). Every grain glistens with dark caramel from the soy and honey.
ingredients: 2 cups (400 g) glutinous rice (sweet rice), soaked overnight and drained
1/3 cup (50 g) dried jujubes (red dates), pitted and halved
steps: Steam the soaked glutinous rice in a steamer lined with cheesecloth for 25–30 minutes until fully cooked and translucent.
While rice is hot, combine honey, soy sauce, sesame oil, and brown sugar in a large bowl. Add the hot steamed rice and fold gently until every grain is coated and the mixture turns a deep amber.
Fold in chestnuts, jujubes, and cinnamon.
Transfer the mixture to a greased heatproof bowl or mold. Press firmly and cover tightly with foil.
Steam for an additional 30–40 minutes until the flavors meld and the rice becomes dense and sticky.
Let cool slightly. Unmold onto a plate, top with pine nuts and sesame seeds. Serve warm or at room temperature, cut into squares or wedges.

PRT.description: A tribute to Portugal's maritime history. Shredded salt cod (bacalhau) is sautéed with onions and shoestring potatoes, then bound together with creamy scrambled eggs. It is said there are 365 cod recipes in Portugal, but this is the favorite.
steps: Sauté onion in generous olive oil until translucent.
Add the shredded cod. Cook for 5 mins.
Add the shoestring potatoes to the pan. Toss to mix.
Lower heat. Pour in the beaten eggs. Stir constantly until eggs are just set but still creamy (do not make dry scrambled eggs).
Remove from heat immediately.
Garnish with black olives and parsley.

drink.description: Portugal’s easy aperitif: dry white port topped with tonic—citrusy, lightly sweet, and very refreshing.
ingredients: Garnish: lemon or orange wedge; optional rosemary sprig
steps: Fill a highball with ice.
Pour in the white port.
Top with tonic water.
Stir gently and garnish with citrus (and rosemary if using).

dessert.description: Portugal's legendary egg custard tart — flaky, shattering puff pastry shells filled with a rich, barely sweetened egg custard, baked at volcanic heat until the tops blister and char in spots. Invented by monks at the Jerónimos Monastery in Belém before the 1837 dissolution of religious orders, the original recipe remains a secret held by the Antiga Confeitaria de Belém. Every pastelaria in Portugal has its version, but the quest for the perfect nata — creamy center, caramelized top, audibly crisp shell — is a national obsession. Dust with cinnamon and powdered sugar. Eat warm.
ingredients: 1 sheet (about 8 oz / 225 g) all-butter puff pastry, thawed if frozen
Ground cinnamon and powdered sugar for dusting
steps: Preheat oven to 500°F (260°C) or as high as it will go. Place rack in upper third.
Heat milk with lemon peel and cinnamon stick until just simmering. Remove from heat, cover, and steep 10 minutes. Discard lemon peel and cinnamon stick.
Whisk sugar, flour, and salt in a saucepan. Gradually whisk in the warm milk. Cook over medium heat, stirring constantly, until thickened to a loose pastry cream, 3–4 minutes. Remove from heat.

Whisk egg yolks in a bowl. Temper by whisking a ladleful of the hot mixture into the yolks, then pour the yolk mixture back into the pan. Stir in vanilla. Strain through a fine sieve. Let cool slightly.
Roll the puff pastry into a tight log. Slice into 12 equal rounds. Press each round into a standard muffin cup, pushing the dough up the sides to form thin shells.
Fill each pastry shell about 3/4 full with the custard.
Bake 12–15 minutes until the pastry is deeply golden and the custard is blistered with dark spots on top.
Cool in the pan 5 minutes, then transfer to a wire rack. Dust with cinnamon and powdered sugar. Eat warm — a pastel de nata waits for no one.

PRY.description: The only 'solid soup' in the world. Legend says a 19th-century chef added too much corn flour to the President's soup, creating a bread instead. The President loved it, and this savory, cheesy, onion-laden cornbread became the national dish.
ingredients: 2 cups Corn Flour (Harina de Maíz - fine)
2 cups Queso Paraguay (or mild white cheese/Mozzarella)
steps: Boil onions in the fat/butter with a little water until soft. Let cool.
Beat eggs until frothy. Add milk, cheese, and the onion mixture.
Gradually fold in the corn flour. The batter should be thick but pourable.
Pour into a greased baking dish.
Bake at 400°F (200°C) for 30-40 minutes until golden brown and set.
Cut into squares and serve warm.

drink.description: Cold yerba mate traditionally sipped through a bombilla; this version is flavored with mint and citrus.
ingredients: Yerba mate (about 1/2 to 2/3 of the cup/gourd)
steps: Fill the guampa/gourd about 1/2–2/3 full with yerba mate.
Add mint (and a squeeze of lemon if using).
Insert the bombilla down the side to the bottom and keep it in place.
Pour in ice-cold water to wet the yerba, sip, and keep refilling with cold water as you drink.

dessert.description: Paraguay's most nostalgic sweet — dense bricks of roasted peanuts bound in dark, bittersweet cane molasses (miel de caña), cooled and broken into crunchy, caramel-dark blocks that look exactly like their namesake: ladrillos (bricks). Sold by street vendors and at every market in Asunción, ka'i ladrillo is the taste of Paraguayan childhood. The Guaraní name means 'monkey brick' — no one quite knows why, but everyone remembers the first time they cracked one with their teeth.
ingredients: 2 cups (280 g) raw peanuts, skin on
1 cup (240 ml) miel de caña (cane molasses or dark molasses)
steps: Toast peanuts in a dry skillet over medium heat, stirring constantly, until fragrant and skins begin to crack, 8–10 minutes. Set aside.

Combine molasses, brown sugar, water, and salt in a heavy saucepan. Cook over medium heat, stirring, until sugar dissolves and the mixture reaches 250°F (121°C) on a candy thermometer (hard-ball stage), about 10–12 minutes.
Remove from heat. Stir in vanilla and toasted peanuts, working quickly to coat every nut.
Pour immediately onto a greased or parchment-lined baking sheet. Press firmly into a flat slab about 1/2 inch (1.3 cm) thick using the back of a greased spatula or another sheet of parchment.
Let cool completely until hardened, about 30 minutes.
Break or cut into rectangular brick-shaped pieces. Store in an airtight container at room temperature.

PSE.dish: Musakhan (مسخّن) — Sumac Chicken on Taboon Bread
PSE.description: Often cited as Palestine’s national dish: chicken roasted with onions, olive oil, and sumac, piled onto flatbread so it drinks up the juices, then topped with toasted pine nuts.
ingredients: 1/2 cup (120 ml) extra-virgin olive oil, divided
1 1/2 tsp kosher salt, plus more to taste
steps: Heat oven to 425°F (220°C). Toss chicken with 2 tbsp olive oil, salt, pepper, and allspice. Roast 35–45 minutes until cooked.
Meanwhile, cook onions in remaining olive oil over medium-low heat until very soft and golden, 25–35 minutes.
Stir sumac into onions and cook 2 minutes. Taste and adjust salt.
Toast pine nuts in a dry pan until golden.
Assemble: lay bread on a platter, spread onion-sumac mixture over, top with chicken, drizzle pan juices, and finish with pine nuts.

drink.dish: Qamar al-Din (قمر الدين) — Apricot Leather Drink
drink.description: A Ramadan favorite across the Levant: apricot leather dissolved into a thick, tangy-sweet drink scented with orange blossom water.
ingredients: 1 sheet (about 7–8 oz / 200–225 g) apricot leather (qamar al-din) (or make it; see preliminary steps)
steps: Tear apricot leather into pieces and soak in warm water 2–4 hours (or overnight) until very soft.
Blend until smooth. Sweeten to taste and stir in orange blossom water.
Chill and serve over ice.

ingredients: 1/2 cup (100 g) sugar (adjust to sweetness of fruit)
steps: Simmer apricots with a splash of water until very soft, 10–15 minutes.
Blend to a smooth puree; stir in sugar and lemon juice. Simmer 2–3 minutes to dissolve sugar.
Spread puree thinly (about 1/8 in / 3 mm) on parchment-lined baking sheets.
Dry in a 170°F (75°C) oven 3–5 hours (or until no longer sticky). Peel and store wrapped.

dessert.description: Nablus's crown jewel and Palestine's most famous sweet — a magnificent disc of crispy, butter-soaked kataifi (shredded phyllo) noodles encasing a molten heart of soft, stretchy Nabulsi cheese, baked until golden and immediately drenched in fragrant orange blossom syrup. The contrast — shattering crunch against oozing cheese, floral sweetness against salt — is transcendent. Knafeh is eaten for breakfast, for celebration, and for pride. In Nablus, they make it in pans the size of truck tires and dye it orange with food coloring. The best knafeh you will ever eat is fresh from the oven, still dripping with syrup.
ingredients: 1 lb (450 g) kataifi (shredded phyllo dough), thawed if frozen
1/2 cup (115 g) unsalted butter, melted, plus more for the pan
1 lb (450 g) Nabulsi cheese (or low-salt Akkawi or fresh mozzarella), soaked in water 3–4 hours to remove excess salt, drained and shredded

steps: Combine sugar, water, and lemon juice in a saucepan. Stir over medium heat until sugar dissolves.
Bring to a boil and simmer without stirring for 8–10 minutes until slightly thickened (it will coat a spoon but remain pourable).
Remove from heat and stir in orange blossom water. Let cool completely — the syrup must be cold when poured over hot knafeh.
Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C).

Unravel and loosen the kataifi strands by hand, separating them gently. Place in a large bowl, pour melted butter over, and toss until every strand is coated. If using food coloring, mix it into the butter first.
Generously butter a 10-inch (25 cm) round baking pan. Press half the buttered kataifi firmly into the bottom in an even layer.
