Sprinkle semolina over the kataifi layer. Distribute the shredded cheese evenly on top.
Cover with the remaining kataifi, pressing firmly to compact. Brush the top with any remaining butter.
Bake 35–40 minutes until the top and edges are deeply golden and crisp.
Remove from oven and immediately pour the cold orange blossom syrup evenly over the hot knafeh. Let it absorb for 2–3 minutes.
Invert onto a serving platter so the crispy bottom becomes the top. Garnish with crushed pistachios. Serve immediately while the cheese is still stretchy and molten.

Puducherry.description: A unique fusion of French and Tamil cuisines. This curry uses local seafood and spices but is milder and creamier than typical South Indian curries, often using coconut milk and vinegar.
steps: Sauté fennel and curry leaves.
Add onion paste and tomato puree. Cook well.
Add prawns and cook briefly.
Stir in coconut milk and a splash of vinegar.
Simmer until prawns are pink and tender.

drink.description: A common, beloved café drink in Puducherry and across South India.
ingredients: 3 tbsp South Indian coffee-chicory blend (or dark ground coffee)
steps: Brew a strong decoction (filter preferred).
Add a few tablespoons decoction to a cup, top with hot milk and sugar.
Froth by pouring back and forth (optional).

QAT.description: Qatar’s classic one-pot rice: chicken simmered with warm spices and loomi, then rice cooked in the broth so each grain is perfumed and savory.
ingredients: 1 whole chicken (3–4 lb / 1.4–1.8 kg), cut up
2 tsp kosher salt, plus more to taste
3 cups (600 g) basmati rice, rinsed and soaked 20 minutes, drained
4 1/2 cups (1.1 L) water (or enough to cover chicken and later measure stock)
steps: Sauté onion in oil until golden. Add garlic 30 seconds.
Stir in tomato paste and tomatoes; cook until thick.
Add chicken, loomi, whole spices, ground spices, salt, and water to cover. Simmer 35–45 minutes until chicken is cooked.
Remove chicken. Measure broth to 4 1/2 cups (1.1 L), adjusting with water or reduction. Taste and salt.
Add drained rice, bring to a gentle boil, cover and cook on low 15 minutes; rest 10 minutes.
Fluff rice and serve with chicken on top.

drink.dish: Karak Chai (كرك) — Qatari Spiced Milk Tea
drink.description: Qatar’s everyday favorite: strong black tea simmered with cardamom (often with saffron) and finished with milk.
ingredients: 2 tsp loose black tea (or 2 tea bags)
6 cardamom pods, crushed (or 1/2 tsp ground cardamom)
steps: Simmer water with tea and cardamom 3–5 minutes for a strong brew.
Add milk, sugar, and saffron if using. Simmer 5–8 minutes.
Strain and serve hot.

dessert.description: The Gulf's glorious answer to bread pudding — torn pieces of flatbread (or puff pastry) baked in sweetened milk perfumed with saffron and rose water, studded with pistachios, almonds, raisins, and shredded coconut, then broiled until the top blisters into a golden, bubbling crust. Umm Ali — 'Mother of Ali' — is Egyptian in origin but embraced across the Gulf, and the Qatari version is enriched with saffron and extra cream. Served warm in the bowl it was baked in, it is pure comfort.
ingredients: 4 sheets (about 6 oz / 170 g) flatbread (regag, lavash, or puff pastry), torn into pieces
Generous pinch saffron threads, steeped in 2 tbsp warm milk
steps: Preheat oven to 400°F (200°C).
Spread the torn bread pieces in a single layer on a baking sheet. Toast in the oven for 5–8 minutes until lightly golden and dry. (If using puff pastry, bake until puffed and golden first.)
Butter a deep baking dish. Scatter the toasted bread in the dish. Sprinkle half the nuts, raisins, and coconut over the bread.
In a saucepan, heat milk, cream, sugar, and saffron (with its steeping milk) over medium heat until the sugar dissolves and the mixture is hot but not boiling. Stir in rose water.
Pour the hot milk mixture evenly over the bread. Let it soak for 10 minutes.
Scatter the remaining nuts, raisins, and coconut on top.
Bake 15–20 minutes until the pudding is set and bubbling. Switch to broil for 2–3 minutes until the top is blistered and golden — watch closely.
Serve warm directly from the dish, scooped into bowls.

ROU.description: Cabbage rolls raised to an art form. Minced pork and rice are wrapped in sour fermented cabbage leaves, then slow-cooked for hours in tomato sauce and sauerkraut juice. They are the centerpiece of every Romanian holiday.
steps: Mix pork, rice, onion, and spices.
Roll mixture tightly into cabbage leaves.
Layer rolls in a pot with chopped cabbage and smoked meat.
Pour over tomato juice and water.
Simmer on low heat for 3 hours. Serve with polenta (Mămăligă) and sour cream.

drink.description: A Romanian winter warmer: țuică heated gently with sugar and spices. It should steam—never boil.
ingredients: 1 tbsp sugar or honey (15–20 g), to taste
steps: Combine țuică, sugar/honey, lemon peel, peppercorns (and cloves if using) in a small saucepan.
Warm over very low heat until steaming (do not boil).
Taste and adjust sweetness.
Strain into a small heatproof glass and serve hot.

dessert.description: Romania's most beloved dessert: soft, round dumplings made from fresh urda cheese, eggs, and flour, fried golden in oil until puffed and crisp on the outside, pillowy within. Served immediately—topped with a generous spoonful of thick sour cream and a cascade of sour cherry jam (dulceață de vișine). The contrast of warm, airy cheese dumplings with cool tangy cream and tart-sweet jam is irresistible.
ingredients: 1 lb fresh urda cheese or ricotta (450 g)
1/2 cup all-purpose flour (65 g), plus more for dusting
1/2 cup sour cream for serving (120 ml)
1/2 cup sour cherry jam (dulceață de vișine) for serving (160 g)
steps: Drain the urda or ricotta in a fine-mesh sieve for 30 minutes to remove excess moisture. Transfer to a bowl.
Mix in eggs, sugar, vanilla, lemon zest, baking soda, and salt until smooth. Fold in flour gently—do not overwork.
With floured hands, shape the dough into round dumplings about 2 1/2 inches (6 cm) across. Shape a few small balls to use as caps.
Heat 2 inches (5 cm) of oil to 340°F (170°C). Fry the dumplings in batches, turning gently, until deep golden on all sides—about 3–4 minutes per batch. Drain on paper towels.
Stack each large dumpling with a small cap on top. Spoon sour cream over the stack and drizzle generously with sour cherry jam. Serve immediately.

RUS.description: The heart of Siberia wrapped in dough. These dumplings were originally preserved by freezing them outdoors in the Siberian winter. The thin dough holds a juicy meat filling, traditionally served with sour cream and dill.
ingredients: 3 cups all-purpose flour (390 g), plus more for dusting
3/4 cup warm water (180 ml), plus as needed
Fresh dill (optional: vinegar or black pepper)
3 cups all-purpose flour (390 g), plus more for dusting
3/4 cup warm water (180 ml), plus as needed
steps: Mix flour and salt. Add egg and water and knead 8–10 minutes until smooth; cover and rest 30 minutes.

ingredients: 2 tbsp cold water (30 ml) (keeps filling juicy)
steps: Mix meats with grated onion, salt, pepper, and cold water until tacky.
Roll dough thin. Cut 2 1/2–3 inch rounds.
Add about 1 tsp filling to each round. Fold into a half-moon and pinch sealed, then bring ends together and pinch to form the classic shape.
Freeze on a tray if not cooking immediately (then bag once solid).
Boil in salted water or broth: add pelmeni and cook until they float, then 2–3 minutes more (about 5–7 minutes total).
Serve with butter and sour cream, plus dill and black pepper.

drink.description: Traditional kvass: toasted rye bread fermented into a lightly sweet, tangy, low-alcohol drink—served cold.
ingredients: 8 oz dark rye bread, sliced (225 g)
1/2 cup sugar (100 g), plus more to taste
1/4 tsp active dry yeast (optional, speeds fermentation)
Optional: 2 strips lemon peel or a few mint leaves
steps: Toast rye bread slices until very dark to build flavor (avoid turning to ash).
Pour boiling water over toasted bread in a heatproof bowl; cover and steep 6–12 hours.
Strain out bread and stir in sugar until dissolved.
Cool to lukewarm; add yeast (or use raisins for wild fermentation).
Ferment loosely covered at room temp 12–24 hours until lightly fizzy.
Strain, bottle, and refrigerate. Serve cold; open carefully.

dessert.description: Every Russian grandmother's masterpiece: an impossibly tender honey cake built from ultra-thin layers of honey-scented sponge, stacked high with luscious sour cream frosting, then refrigerated overnight until the layers soften and meld into one silky, melt-in-your-mouth whole. The crumb topping made from trimmings adds a final textural flourish. Medovik is patience rewarded—it only gets better with time.

steps: Whip heavy cream to stiff peaks. In a separate bowl, stir sour cream, powdered sugar, and vanilla until smooth.
Fold whipped cream into sour cream mixture gently. Refrigerate until ready to assemble.

ingredients: 3 1/2 cups all-purpose flour (455 g), plus more for rolling
Sour Cream Frosting (see Chef's Essentials below)
steps: Melt butter, sugar, and honey together in a double boiler, stirring until smooth. Remove from heat and whisk in baking soda—the mixture will foam and lighten in color.
Beat in eggs one at a time. Gradually add flour, mixing until a soft, slightly sticky dough forms. Divide into 8 equal portions. Wrap and chill 1 hour.

Roll each portion into a thin round (about 8 inches / 20 cm). Trim to matching circles using a plate as a guide—save all trimmings. Bake each layer on parchment at 350°F (180°C) for 5–6 minutes until golden. Cool completely.
Bake the trimmings until golden and crisp. Crush into fine crumbs for the topping.
Assemble: spread a generous layer of Sour Cream Frosting between each cake layer, stacking evenly. Frost the top and sides with remaining frosting.
Press crushed crumbs over the top and sides. Refrigerate at least 8 hours (overnight is best) to allow the layers to soften and meld. Slice and serve cold.

Moscow.description: Born in the kitchens of Count Stroganov's Moscow household in the 1890s: thin strips of beef tenderloin seared at blistering heat, then swirled into a silky sauce of sour cream, mustard, and mushrooms. The Moscow version is the original—no tomato paste, no paprika (those are later Western corruptions). The beef must be cut against the grain into matchstick strips and cooked in small batches so it sears, not steams. Served over buttered egg noodles or with straw potatoes.
ingredients: 1.5 lbs beef tenderloin or sirloin, cut into 1/4-inch strips against the grain (680 g)
1/2 lb cremini or button mushrooms, sliced (225 g)
1 cup sour cream (240 ml), room temperature
Salt and freshly ground black pepper
steps: Pat the beef strips very dry. Season with salt and pepper. Heat oil and 1 tbsp butter in a large skillet over high heat until smoking. Sear the beef in small batches (do NOT crowd the pan)—30 seconds per side until browned but still pink inside. Transfer to a plate.
Reduce heat to medium. Add 1 tbsp butter and the mushrooms. Cook 5 minutes until golden and dry. Add the onion and remaining butter. Cook 5 minutes until softened.
Add the beef broth. Simmer 2 minutes, scraping up the fond. Reduce heat to low.
Stir the mustard into the sour cream. Add to the pan and stir gently—do not boil or the sour cream will curdle. Return the beef and any juices. Stir to coat. Heat through for 1 minute.
Garnish with fresh dill. Serve immediately over buttered egg noodles.

drink.description: The cocktail that made vodka famous in America—but it belongs to Moscow in spirit: ice-cold vodka, fiery ginger beer, and fresh lime, served in a copper mug that frosts on contact. Invented in 1941, it is the intersection of Russian vodka culture and American cocktail ingenuity.
steps: Fill a copper mug (or tall glass) with ice.
Pour in the vodka and lime juice. Top with ginger beer.
Stir gently once. Garnish with a lime wedge.

Saint Petersburg.description: Herring Under a Fur Coat—Saint Petersburg's iconic layered salad and the centerpiece of every Russian New Year's Eve table: layers of salted herring, grated boiled potato, grated boiled carrot, grated boiled beet, and mayonnaise, pressed into a mold and chilled until it slices cleanly. The beet layer on top gives it its 'fur coat' of vivid magenta. This is Soviet-era nostalgia food at its finest—every Russian has an opinion about the correct layering order.
ingredients: 1 lb salted herring fillets (or pickled herring), diced (450 g)
4 medium potatoes, boiled, cooled, and coarsely grated
3 medium carrots, boiled, cooled, and coarsely grated
3 medium beets, boiled, cooled, and coarsely grated
Salt and freshly ground black pepper
steps: Layer 1 (bottom): Spread the diced herring in an even layer on a serving plate or in a rectangular mold. Spread a thin layer of mayonnaise over it.
Layer 2: Spread the diced onion evenly over the herring. Thin layer of mayonnaise.
Layer 3: Spread the grated potato evenly. Press gently. Mayonnaise layer.
Layer 4: Spread the grated carrot evenly. Press gently. Mayonnaise layer.
Layer 5 (top): Spread the grated beet evenly—this is the 'fur coat.' Cover the top and sides with a generous layer of mayonnaise, smoothing with a spatula.
Cover with plastic wrap and refrigerate at least 4 hours (overnight is best). The layers firm and the flavors meld. Garnish with fresh dill before serving. Slice into squares.

drink.description: Vodka, coffee liqueur, and heavy cream—the decadent cocktail that the Dude made famous but Petersburg's cocktail bars perfected. Layered or stirred, it's a dessert in a glass.
ingredients: 1 oz (30 ml) Kahlúa or coffee liqueur
steps: Fill a rocks glass with ice. Pour in the vodka and Kahlúa.
Float the cream on top by pouring it slowly over the back of a spoon.
Stir gently if desired, or drink layered.

Republic of Tatarstan.description: Tatar triangular meat pies: a yeasted dough envelops a raw filling of diced lamb (or beef), potato, and onion, seasoned with nothing but salt and pepper. A small hole is left at the top of the triangle, and during baking, hot broth is poured through the hole so the filling steams and braises inside the pastry. The result is a self-contained meal—crisp golden crust, steaming juicy filling. Echpochmak is the pride of Kazan and Tatar cuisine, served at every celebration.
ingredients: 1 lb lamb or beef, cut into small dice (450 g)
2 medium potatoes, peeled and cut into small dice
Salt and freshly ground black pepper
1/2 cup warm lamb or beef broth (120 ml) for pouring during baking

steps: Dissolve yeast and sugar in warm milk. Let foam 5 minutes.
Mix flour and salt. Add the yeast mixture, egg, and melted butter. Knead 8 minutes until smooth.
Cover and let rise 1 hour until doubled.
Mix the raw diced meat, potato, and onion together. Season generously with salt and pepper. Do not cook the filling—it goes in raw.
Divide the dough into 12 pieces. Roll each into a 6-inch circle.

Place a generous mound of filling in the center of each circle. Pull up three sides of the dough to form a triangle, pinching the seams to seal. Leave a small hole (about 1/2 inch) at the top center—this is the chimney for adding broth.
Place on a baking sheet. Brush with egg wash. Bake at 375°F (190°C) for 25 minutes.
Remove from oven. Through the hole at the top of each pie, pour in 1–2 tbsp of hot broth. Return to oven and bake 15–20 more minutes until deep golden and the filling is cooked through.
Serve hot. The first bite should release steam and fragrant broth.

drink.description: A chilled salted yogurt drink central to Tatar cuisine—thinner than Turkish ayran, made from katyk (Tatar fermented milk). Refreshing, tangy, and the perfect counterpoint to rich meat pies.
ingredients: 2 cups katyk or plain whole-milk yogurt
steps: Whisk yogurt with cold water and salt until smooth and frothy.
Serve chilled with fresh mint.

Republic of Dagestan.description: Dagestan's legendary flatbread: impossibly thin dough stretched by hand until nearly translucent, filled with a generous layer of fresh herbs and farmer's cheese (or meat, or pumpkin), then cooked on a dry griddle until spotted brown. The dough must be so thin that the green filling shows through. Every Dagestani aul (village) makes chudu differently—herb chudu with urtica (nettles), wild garlic, and dill is the mountain classic.
ingredients: 2 cups fresh farmer's cheese or ricotta (450 g)
1 large bunch fresh herbs (dill, cilantro, green onions, nettles or spinach), finely chopped
steps: Make the dough: mix flour, salt, and water. Knead 5 minutes until smooth. Rest 20 minutes.
Make the filling: mix the farmer's cheese with the chopped herbs, salt, and pepper.
Divide dough into 6 balls. Roll each very thin (almost translucent). Place filling on one half, fold over, and seal the edges by pressing with a fork.
Cook on a dry, hot griddle or cast-iron skillet 2–3 minutes per side until spotted brown. The flatbread should puff slightly.
Brush immediately with butter while hot. Stack on a plate. Serve warm.

drink.description: Herbal tea from the Caucasus highlands: wild thyme (чабрец), oregano, and rose hips gathered from the mountain slopes, steeped with honey.
steps: Steep the herbs and rose hips in boiling water for 10 minutes.
Strain. Sweeten with honey. Drink hot.

Krasnodar Krai.description: The southern Russian borscht of the Kuban Cossacks: a deep crimson beet soup thickened with tomato, enriched with pork or beef, and loaded with vegetables—cabbage, potato, carrot, bell pepper. Unlike Ukrainian borscht, the Kuban version always includes tomato and sweet pepper, reflecting the sun-drenched agriculture of Russia's breadbasket. Served with a mountain of sour cream, fresh dill, and garlic pampushki (rolls).
ingredients: 1 lb pork ribs or beef shank (450 g)
Sour cream and fresh dill for serving
steps: Simmer the meat in water/broth with a bay leaf for 1 hour until tender. Remove the meat, shred it, and return to the broth.

Heat oil in a skillet. Sauté the onion and carrot until soft. Add the grated beets, bell pepper, and tomato paste. Cook 10 minutes, stirring. Add vinegar (this preserves the beet color). Add this sofrito to the broth pot.
Add the potatoes to the pot. Simmer 10 minutes. Add the shredded cabbage. Simmer 10 more minutes.
Add garlic, a pinch of sugar, and season with salt and pepper. Simmer 5 minutes. Let rest off heat 15 minutes—borscht improves as it sits.
Serve with a generous spoon of sour cream and a shower of fresh dill.

drink.description: Russia's quintessential fruit drink: fresh or dried fruits (apples, cherries, plums, apricots) simmered in water with sugar. Every Russian grandmother has a pot of kompot cooling on the stove. Served cold in summer, warm in winter.
ingredients: 2 cups mixed fruit (fresh or dried—apples, cherries, plums)
steps: Bring water and sugar to a boil. Add the fruit.
Simmer 15–20 minutes. Cool.
Serve chilled with the fruit in the glass.

Republic of Bashkortostan.description: The Bashkir national dish (shared with Kazakh and Kyrgyz culture): boiled horse meat or lamb torn into pieces and served over wide, hand-cut noodles, drenched in a rich broth with sautéed onions. Bishbarmak means 'five fingers' because it is eaten with the hands. In Bashkiria, it is prepared for honored guests and important occasions—the host offers the choicest cut to the most respected elder.
ingredients: 2 lbs bone-in lamb or horse meat (or beef) (900 g)
1/2 cup warm broth or water (120 ml)
steps: Mix flour, salt, eggs, and broth into a firm dough. Knead 10 minutes.
Rest 30 minutes. Roll very thin and cut into 3-inch squares or wide strips.
Place the meat in a large pot, cover with cold water by 3 inches. Bring to a simmer, skimming foam. Add salt. Simmer 2–3 hours until very tender.
Remove the meat. Strain and reserve the broth. Tear the meat into large pieces (not sliced—torn by hand).
Sauté the onion rings in butter until soft and golden. Season with pepper.
Cook the noodle squares in the reserved broth for 3–4 minutes until tender.

Arrange the noodles on a large platter. Top with the torn meat, then the sautéed onions. Ladle a generous amount of hot broth over everything. Sprinkle with herbs. Serve family-style—eat with your hands or a fork.

drink.description: Fermented mare's milk—the ancient drink of the Bashkir and Turkic steppe peoples. Mildly alcoholic, fizzy, tangy, and rich in vitamins. Kumys is a living drink—it ferments as you drink it.
ingredients: Fresh mare's milk (or substitute: 2 cups whole milk + 1/2 cup kefir + 1 tsp honey)
steps: If using mare's milk: let it ferment naturally at room temperature for 12–24 hours, stirring occasionally.
If substituting: mix whole milk, kefir, and honey. Let sit at room temperature 12 hours until slightly tangy and fizzy.
Serve chilled.

Sakha (Yakutia) Republic.description: Yakutia's most primal dish: raw, flash-frozen freshwater fish (usually nelma, muksun, or omul) shaved into paper-thin curls with a razor-sharp knife directly from the frozen block. The curls are eaten immediately, dipped in a mixture of salt and pepper, while still frozen—they melt on the tongue. At -50°C Yakutsk winters, everything freezes instantly. Stroganina is the sashimi of Siberia—purity of ingredient, zero cooking, maximum respect for the fish.
ingredients: 1 whole frozen freshwater fish (whitefish, arctic char, or salmon), about 3 lbs (1.4 kg), frozen solid
steps: The fish must be frozen rock-solid (ideally flash-frozen outdoors at extreme cold). Do NOT thaw.

Hold the frozen fish firmly. Using a very sharp, thin-bladed knife, shave thin curls of flesh from the fish—working from tail to head, peeling strips away from the frozen block. The curls should be paper-thin and curl naturally.
Arrange the frozen curls on a chilled plate immediately. They should stay frozen.
Serve at once with a small dish of mixed salt and pepper for dipping. Eat each curl frozen—it melts on your tongue, releasing clean, sweet fish flavor.

drink.description: Fermented mare's milk is sacred to the Yakut Ysyakh summer solstice festival. Served in birch bark cups during the ceremony of greeting the sun.
ingredients: Fermented mare's milk (or kefir as substitute)
steps: Serve chilled in small cups during celebration.

Murmansk Oblast.description: The legendary fish soup of the Pomor people—the seafaring Russians of the Arctic Kola Peninsula: a crystal-clear broth of cod, salmon, and halibut from the Barents Sea, seasoned with bay, allspice, and a splash of vodka added at the very end (the Pomor trick for clarity and warmth). Ukha is the oldest Russian soup, predating all others, and the Pomor version is the purest: no potatoes, no carrots—just fish, onion, and broth.
ingredients: 2 lbs mixed firm fish (cod, salmon, halibut), cleaned, cut into large chunks (900 g)
1 lb fish bones and heads (for stock) (450 g)
steps: Make the stock: Place fish bones and heads in a pot with the onion, allspice, bay leaves, peppercorns, and salt. Cover with 2 quarts cold water. Bring to a gentle simmer, skimming foam. Simmer 30 minutes. Strain—the broth should be clear and golden.
Bring the strained broth back to a gentle simmer. Add the fish chunks in order of firmness—cod first (needs 10 minutes), then halibut (8 minutes), then salmon (5 minutes).
When all fish is just cooked through, pour in the vodka. Stir once. Remove from heat.
Serve in deep bowls, ladling broth and fish together. Shower with chopped dill. Eat with black bread.

drink.description: The Arctic ritual: ice-cold vodka served in a frozen shot glass, chased immediately with a crunchy sour pickle (ogurets) and a bite of black bread. The pickle's brine cuts the vodka's burn. The bread absorbs. This is not a cocktail—it is a ceremony of warmth in the coldest place on earth.
steps: Keep the vodka in the freezer until syrupy-cold. Pour into a frozen shot glass.
Drink the vodka in one gulp. Immediately bite into the sour pickle, then a piece of black bread.
Exhale. Repeat.

Kaliningrad Oblast.description: A dish from Kaliningrad's Prussian past: tender veal meatballs poached in a silky white sauce of capers, lemon, and cream. When Königsberg became Kaliningrad in 1945, the German population left but the recipe stayed—adopted by the Russian settlers who recognized its genius. Today it is Kaliningrad's signature dish, a culinary bridge between Russia and Prussia.
ingredients: 1 lb ground veal (or half veal, half pork) (450 g)
2 slices white bread, crusts removed, soaked in 1/4 cup milk
4 anchovy fillets, minced (traditional—adds depth without fishiness)
3 cups chicken or veal broth (720 ml)
steps: Squeeze the milk from the bread and mash it. Mix with the ground meat, egg, diced onion, minced anchovies, salt, and white pepper. Form into golf-ball-sized meatballs (about 12).
Bring the broth to a gentle simmer. Carefully lower the meatballs in. Poach 15–20 minutes until cooked through. Remove the meatballs and keep warm. Reserve the broth.
Make the sauce: Melt butter in a saucepan. Whisk in flour, cook 1 minute (do not brown). Gradually whisk in 2 cups of the reserved poaching broth. Simmer until thickened, 3–4 minutes.

Add the capers and lemon juice. In a small bowl, whisk the egg yolks with the cream. Temper by stirring in a spoonful of hot sauce, then add to the pan. Stir gently—do not boil or the yolks will curdle.
Return the meatballs to the sauce. Serve with boiled potatoes.

drink.description: Craft beer from Russia's amber capital. Kaliningrad's microbrewery scene produces Baltic-style amber ales that nod to the region's German brewing heritage.
ingredients: 1 bottle Kaliningrad craft amber ale, chilled
steps: Pour into a glass. Serve cold alongside Klopse.

Republic of Buryatia.description: Buryatia's beloved steamed dumplings—the Siberian cousin of Mongolian buuz: a delicate dough wrapper pleated around a filling of minced beef or mutton with onion and garlic, steamed until the meat renders its juices inside the sealed dumpling. The hole at the top allows steam to escape during cooking. You drink the hot broth from inside before eating the dumpling—this is the ritual. Every Buryat family eats buuz on Sagaalgan (Lunar New Year).
ingredients: 1 lb ground beef or mutton (450 g)

steps: Mix flour, salt, and water into a smooth dough. Knead 8 minutes.
Rest covered 30 minutes.
Mix the ground meat with onion, garlic, cold water, salt, and pepper. The mixture should be moist.
Divide the dough into 16 pieces. Roll each into a thin 4-inch circle (thinner at edges, slightly thicker in center).
Place a tablespoon of filling in the center. Pleat the edges upward, making 18–20 small folds, leaving a small opening at the top.
Steam over boiling water for 20 minutes. The dumplings are done when the dough is translucent and the meat juices are bubbling inside.
Serve immediately. To eat: carefully sip the hot broth from inside through the top hole, then eat the dumpling. Dip in soy sauce.

drink.description: Buryat salted milk tea: green tea simmered with milk, butter, and salt. The nomadic tradition of the Baikal steppe—nourishing, warming, and drunk all day.
steps: Boil water with green tea for 5 minutes. Strain.
Add milk, butter, and salt. Heat until steaming.
Serve in bowls.

Kamchatka Krai.description: The king crab of Kamchatka—the largest crab on earth, pulled from the freezing waters of the Pacific and Bering Sea. The preparation is elemental: steam or boil the legs and serve with nothing but melted butter and lemon. The crab's sweetness speaks for itself. In Petropavlovsk-Kamchatsky, king crab legs are sold still alive at the harbor market and cooked within the hour.
steps: Bring a very large pot of well-salted water to a rolling boil.
Add the crab legs. Boil 6–8 minutes for pre-cooked legs (most are sold pre-cooked and frozen), or 12–15 minutes for fresh/raw legs. They're done when the shells are bright red and the meat is opaque.
Crack the shells with kitchen shears or a crab cracker. The meat should slide out in long, sweet, white-and-red pieces.
Serve with melted butter mixed with lemon juice for dipping. Eat with your hands.

drink.description: A sailor's warming grog for Kamchatka's Pacific storms: hot black tea spiked with vodka, honey, and lemon. The Russian Navy's answer to British grog.
steps: Brew strong black tea. Stir in honey until dissolved.
Add vodka and lemon juice.
Serve hot with a lemon slice. Drink watching the volcanoes steam.

Chechen Republic.description: The national dish of the Chechen people: boiled lamb or beef served alongside galnash (large corn-flour and wheat-flour dumplings, shaped like ears) and a bowl of rich meat broth infused with garlic. The three components are served separately—meat on one plate, dumplings on another, broth in a bowl—and you dip the dumplings and meat into the broth as you eat. This is the Chechen dinner of hospitality, served to every guest.
ingredients: 2 lbs bone-in lamb or beef (900 g)

steps: Mix cornmeal, flour, and salt. Add warm water and knead into a firm, smooth dough. Rest 15 minutes.
Pinch off small pieces and shape into ear-shaped or oval dumplings (about 2 inches long).
Boil the meat in salted water for 1.5–2 hours until very tender. Remove the meat and cut into large pieces. Strain the broth—reserve it.
Cook the galnash dumplings in the reserved meat broth for 10–12 minutes until they float and are cooked through. Remove with a slotted spoon.
Season the broth with minced garlic and fresh herbs.
Serve three dishes: meat on one plate, galnash on another, and a bowl of garlic broth for dipping. Eat by dipping meat and dumplings into the broth.

drink.description: Mountain herbal tea from the Caucasus: wild thyme, oregano, and mint gathered from the alpine meadows above the Argun Gorge.
steps: Steep herbs in boiling water 8–10 minutes.
Strain. Sweeten with honey.

Republic of Karelia.description: Karelia's ancient open-faced rye pastries: thin rye dough crimped into oval boats and filled with a thick millet or rice porridge (or mashed potato). Kalitki are baked until the rye crust is crisp and the filling is golden, then brushed lavishly with melted butter. These are the daily bread of Karelian peasant cuisine—made with the grain of the boreal forest and the butter of northern cows.
ingredients: 1 cup cooked millet or rice porridge (thick)
steps: Mix the rye flour, all-purpose flour, and salt. Add the buttermilk and water. Knead briefly—rye dough should not be overworked. Rest 15 minutes.
Divide into 10–12 pieces. Roll each into a thin oval (about 5 inches long).

Place a tablespoon of thick porridge in the center of each oval. Fold the edges up and crimp, pinching them at regular intervals to create a fluted border—the kalitka should look like a small open boat.
Bake at 425°F (220°C) for 12–15 minutes until the rye edges are crisp and lightly browned.
Brush immediately with melted butter while hot. Serve warm.

drink.description: A refreshing Russian berry drink from the Karelian forests: lingonberries or cranberries crushed and simmered with water and sugar, then strained. Mors is the vitamin C delivery system of the Russian north—tart, ruby-red, and brimming with antioxidants.
steps: Crush the berries and press through a sieve, reserving the juice.
Boil the berry pulp in the water for 10 minutes. Strain.
Stir in the reserved fresh juice and sugar. Chill. Serve cold.

Astrakhan Oblast.dish: Astrakhan Fish Pilaf (Астраханский Плов с Рыбой)
Astrakhan Oblast.description: A unique Volga Delta pilaf: instead of lamb, this Astrakhan version uses sturgeon or pike-perch (sudak) from the Caspian, layered with rice, saffron, onions, and dried fruits. Astrakhan sits at the crossroads of Russian, Kazakh, Tatar, and Persian cuisines, and its fish pilaf reflects this cultural intersection—the saffron is Persian, the rice technique is Central Asian, the fish is pure Volga.
ingredients: 1.5 lbs firm white fish (sturgeon, pike-perch, or halibut), cut into large chunks (680 g)
1/2 tsp saffron threads, steeped in 2 tbsp warm water
Fresh dill and lemon wedges for serving
steps: Heat oil and fry the onion rings until deeply golden, 12–15 minutes. Remove half for garnish.
Season the fish chunks with salt and pepper. Place on top of the onions in the pot.
Drain the rice and spread evenly over the fish. Add saffron water and raisins. Pour in enough water to cover the rice by 1/2 inch.
Bring to a boil, then reduce to lowest heat. Cover tightly and cook 25 minutes without lifting the lid.
Fluff gently. Serve the pilaf mounded on a platter with the fish on top, garnished with fried onions, fresh dill, and lemon wedges.

drink.description: A Volga Delta refresher: vodka mixed with fresh lemon, honey, and sparkling water. The Astrakhan summer demands something cold and sharp.
steps: Shake vodka, lemon juice, and honey syrup with ice.
Strain into a tall glass over fresh ice. Top with soda.
Garnish with a lemon wheel.

Altai Republic.description: A ceremonial Altai barley-and-meat soup: pearl barley simmered with bone-in horse meat or lamb in a rich broth until the barley is swollen and the meat falls apart. Kochi is the ancient food of the Altai Turkic people, cooked in iron cauldrons over open fires in the mountain camps where the Altai, Mongolia, China, and Kazakhstan meet. The barley gives the broth a thick, porridge-like quality that sustains through Siberian winters.
ingredients: 1.5 lbs bone-in lamb (or horse meat, or beef) (680 g)
steps: Place the meat in a large pot with cold water. Bring to a gentle simmer, skimming foam. Simmer 1 hour.
Add the pearl barley and onion. Simmer 1 more hour until the barley is swollen and the meat falls from the bone.
Remove the meat, shred it, and return to the pot. Season with salt and pepper.
Serve in deep bowls, thick and hearty, scattered with wild garlic or chives.

drink.description: Fermented mare's or cow's milk from the Altai mountains—thick, tangy, and mildly alcoholic. The Altai people drink chegen daily, believing it purifies the blood.
ingredients: 2 tbsp kefir grains or live-culture yogurt
steps: Warm milk to lukewarm. Stir in kefir grains.
Ferment 24–48 hours at room temperature. Stir and serve chilled.

Primorsky Krai.description: Vladivostok's beloved street food: steamed buns filled with spiced pork and cabbage, brought to Primorsky Krai by Korean immigrants. Pyan-se (from Korean 'pyanse') are sold from steamboxes at every Vladivostok market and bus station. The dough is fluffy and white; the filling is savory, gingery, and slightly sweet. This is the food that defines Russia's Pacific coast—a fusion of Korean technique and Russian appetite.
ingredients: Steamed bun dough (see Chef's Essentials below)

steps: Dissolve yeast and sugar in warm water. Let foam 5 minutes.
Mix flour and salt. Add the yeast water and oil. Knead 10 minutes until smooth and elastic.
Let rise covered 1 hour until doubled.
Mix the pork, cabbage, garlic, ginger, soy sauce, sesame oil, salt, and pepper. Let sit 15 minutes.
Divide the risen dough into 12 pieces. Roll each into a 5-inch circle.
Place a generous spoonful of filling in the center. Gather the edges upward and pinch to seal at the top.
Place each bun on a small square of parchment paper. Let rest 15 minutes.
Steam in a bamboo or metal steamer over boiling water for 15 minutes until the dough is fluffy and cooked through.
Serve hot. In Vladivostok, these are eaten on the go.

drink.description: Pacific sailors' grog: hot tea with honey, lemon, and a shot of vodka—the warming drink of every Vladivostok fishing boat.
steps: Stir honey into hot tea until dissolved. Add vodka and lemon juice.
Drink hot.

Sverdlovsk Oblast.description: The Ural Mountains are where pelmeni were born—Ural pelmeni are the original, with a triple-meat filling of beef, pork, and lamb (the 'troika'). In the Urals, pelmeni are a winter staple: families gather to make thousands at a time, freezing them in snowbanks for months. The Ural tradition demands the dough be rolled thinner than anywhere else in Russia, and the pelmeni smaller—each one should be eaten in a single bite.
ingredients: Sour cream and vinegar for serving
steps: Make the dough: mix flour, egg, water, and 1 tsp salt. Knead 10 minutes until smooth. Rest 30 minutes.
Make the filling: mix the three meats with grated onion, ice water, salt, and pepper.
Roll the dough very thin (1/16 inch). Cut 2.5-inch rounds. Place a teaspoon of filling in the center of each. Fold into a half-moon, pinch sealed, then bring the corners together and pinch.
Boil in salted water 5–7 minutes until they float and the dough is translucent.
Serve in bowls with broth, or drained with sour cream, a splash of vinegar, and fresh dill.

drink.description: An ancient Russian hot honey drink predating tea: honey dissolved in hot water with cinnamon, cloves, ginger, and cardamom. Sbiten vendors once walked Moscow and Yekaterinburg's streets selling it from copper samovars.
steps: Simmer water with all spices for 10 minutes.
Strain. Stir in honey until dissolved.
Serve hot in small cups.

Rostov Oblast.description: The Don River Cossacks' summer feast: live crawfish boiled in a massive pot with dill, bay leaves, allspice, and a generous amount of salt. The Don and its tributaries are Russia's crawfish heartland. Every summer, the banks of the Don near Rostov fill with families boiling buckets of crawfish, drinking beer, and cracking shells until sundown. The key: the crawfish must be alive when they hit the boiling water, and the dill must be fresh.
ingredients: 5 lbs live crawfish (2.3 kg), purged in salted water
1 large bunch fresh dill (stems and fronds)
steps: Purge the live crawfish: soak in cold salted water for 30 minutes. Discard any that are dead.
Bring a very large pot of water to a rolling boil. Add the salt, dill (the entire bunch), bay leaves, allspice, and peppercorns.
Drop the live crawfish into the boiling water. Cover. Boil 8–10 minutes until the shells are bright red.
Remove from heat. Let the crawfish steep in the seasoned water for 10 more minutes (they absorb the dill and spice flavors).
Drain and pile on a newspaper-covered table. Eat with your hands, cracking tails and sucking heads. Drink cold beer.

drink.description: A river party punch from the Don Cossack lands: chilled dry white wine spiked with vodka, honey, and fresh dill (yes, dill—it's a Cossack thing).
ingredients: 3 oz (90 ml) dry white wine, chilled
steps: Stir honey into a splash of warm wine to dissolve. Add to a glass with ice.
Pour in the remaining wine and vodka. Stir.
Garnish with a dill sprig.

Sakhalin Oblast.description: Japan met Russia on Sakhalin Island—this dish is the proof: a bowl of hot steamed rice topped with a glistening mound of fresh salmon roe (ikura), soy sauce, and a dab of wasabi. Sakhalin's rivers flood with Pacific salmon every autumn, and the roe is cured in-house by every Sakhalin family. This is the island's most prized seasonal luxury—the roe should pop between your teeth, releasing a salty, oceanic burst.
ingredients: 2 cups Japanese short-grain rice, cooked (sushi rice)
1 lb fresh salmon roe skeins (450 g)
steps: Separate the roe from the skein membrane by gently rubbing through a wire rack or in warm salted water.
Mix soy sauce, sake, and dashi. Add the clean roe. Marinate 2–4 hours in the refrigerator.
Drain. The ikura should be glistening and amber-orange.
Cook sushi rice per package directions. Fluff and keep warm.
Scoop hot rice into individual bowls. Top each generously with the soy-cured ikura.
Serve with soy sauce, wasabi, and nori strips on the side. In Sakhalin, the roe mountain should be obscenely generous.

drink.description: A nod to Sakhalin's Japanese heritage: warm sake served in a tokkuri (ceramic flask). The island was jointly Japanese-Russian for decades.
steps: Warm sake to 104–113°F (40–45°C) in a water bath.
Pour into ochoko cups. Drink alongside ikura don.

Tuva Republic.description: A warming Tuvan soup from the heart of Central Asia's last nomadic culture: lamb simmered with hand-pulled noodles in a broth enriched with fermented mare's or yak's milk (khoitpak). Tuva, nestled between Mongolia and Siberia, is one of the least visited places on earth, and its cuisine is purely nomadic—meat, dairy, and grain, prepared over an open fire in a felt yurt on the steppe.
ingredients: 1.5 lbs bone-in lamb, cut into chunks (680 g)
1 cup kefir or fermented milk (khoitpak) (240 ml)

steps: Knead flour, water, and salt into a smooth, elastic dough. Rest 30 minutes.
Pull and stretch the dough into thin strips by hand, or roll and cut into wide noodles.
Simmer the lamb chunks in water for 1.5 hours, skimming foam. Add the onion in the last 30 minutes.
Remove the lamb, shred the meat off the bones, and return to the broth.
Add the noodles to the simmering broth. Cook 3–5 minutes until tender.
Stir in the kefir/fermented milk. Season with salt and pepper. Heat through but do not boil.
Serve in large bowls. This is yurt food—eaten sitting cross-legged.

drink.description: Tuvan salted milk tea: green brick tea simmered with whole milk, butter, and salt—the nomadic fuel of the Central Asian steppe.
ingredients: 1 tbsp compressed green tea (or loose green tea)
steps: Boil tea in water for 5 minutes. Strain.
Add milk, butter, and salt. Simmer 2 minutes.
Serve hot in bowls.

Voronezh Oblast.dish: Voronezhskaya Kartoshka s Gribami (Воронежская Картошка с Грибами)
Voronezh Oblast.description: The Black Earth heartland's ultimate comfort food: layers of sliced potatoes and foraged wild mushrooms baked together in a clay pot with sour cream until bubbling and golden. Voronezh Oblast sits atop the richest chernozem soil on the planet, and its oak forests teem with chanterelles, porcini, and honey mushrooms each autumn. This dish is Sunday supper at every Voronezh dacha—earthy, deeply savory, and impossibly aromatic with a crown of fresh dill scattered over the bubbling cream.
ingredients: 2 lbs Yukon Gold potatoes, peeled and sliced 1/4 inch thick (900 g)
8 oz mixed wild mushrooms (chanterelles, porcini, or cremini), sliced (225 g)
1/2 cup chicken or vegetable broth (120 ml)
steps: Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C). Melt butter in a skillet and sauté the onion until translucent, about 5 minutes.
Add mushrooms and garlic. Cook until the mushrooms release their liquid and begin to brown, about 8 minutes. Season lightly with salt.
Layer the sliced potatoes in a clay pot (gorshochek) or deep oven-safe dish, alternating with the mushroom-onion mixture.
Whisk sour cream with broth, salt, and pepper. Pour evenly over the layers.
Cover with a lid or foil and bake 45 minutes. Uncover and bake 15 minutes more until golden and bubbling.
Shower with fresh dill and serve straight from the clay pot—this is dacha food at its purest, eaten with dark bread and nothing else.

drink.description: A cocktail honoring Voronezh's legendary chernozem orchards: vodka shaken with blackberry liqueur, fresh lemon, and wild honey from the Black Earth steppe.
steps: Shake vodka, blackberry liqueur, lemon juice, and honey syrup vigorously with ice.
Strain into a rocks glass over crushed ice.
Garnish with fresh blackberries and a lemon wheel.

Novosibirsk Oblast.description: Open-faced potato-topped buns from the heart of Western Siberia: rounds of soft yeasted dough spread thick with buttery mashed potato, baked until the tops are golden and the edges pillowy. Shangi are the soul of Siberian baking—older than any cookbook, passed from grandmother to grandmother across the frozen taiga. In Novosibirsk, they are eaten for breakfast with tea, packed into lunchboxes for schoolchildren, and served at every family gathering. The simplicity is the point: good dough, good potatoes, good butter.
ingredients: 2 lbs Yukon Gold potatoes, peeled and quartered (900 g)

steps: Dissolve yeast and sugar in warm milk. Let stand 5 minutes until foamy.
Mix flour and salt in a large bowl. Add the yeast mixture, melted butter, and egg. Knead 8–10 minutes until smooth and elastic.
Cover and let rise in a warm place for 1 hour until doubled in size.
Boil potatoes in salted water until very tender, about 20 minutes. Drain thoroughly.
Mash potatoes with butter, warm milk, salt, and pepper until thick and smooth. The topping should be stiffer than regular mashed potatoes.
Punch down the risen dough. Divide into 12 equal pieces and roll each into a ball. Flatten each ball into a 4-inch round on a floured surface.
Place rounds on parchment-lined baking sheets. Spread a generous layer of mashed potato over each round, leaving a 1/2-inch border.
Brush the potato tops and dough edges with beaten egg yolk. Let rest 15 minutes.
Bake at 400°F (200°C) for 18–22 minutes until the dough is golden and the potato topping is lightly browned.
Brush with melted butter immediately out of the oven. Serve warm—these are best eaten the same day.

drink.description: A cocktail inspired by the Siberian taiga: vodka infused with cedar nut flavor, brightened with lemon and lengthened with tonic—Novosibirsk's forests in a glass.
ingredients: 1/2 oz cedar nut liqueur or amaretto (15 ml)
Lemon wheel and pine sprig for garnish
steps: Shake vodka, cedar nut liqueur, lemon juice, and simple syrup with ice.
Strain into a tall glass filled with ice.
Top with tonic water and gently stir.
Garnish with a lemon wheel and a small pine sprig.

Stavropol Krai.description: The North Caucasus' most legendary street food: cubes of lamb marinated overnight with grated onion, vinegar, and warm spices, then threaded onto long metal skewers and grilled over smoldering vine cuttings until charred on the outside and juicy within. Stavropol Krai—the gateway to the Caucasus Mountains—is where shashlik culture reaches its zenith. Every roadside mangal sends plumes of fragrant smoke into the mountain air, and the ritual of grilling is as important as the eating: the fire must be vine or fruitwood, the meat must be lamb, and the onions must be sliced raw on the side.
ingredients: 2 lbs boneless lamb leg, cut into 1.5-inch cubes (900 g)
3 large onions, 2 grated and 1 sliced into rings for serving
steps: Combine the lamb cubes with the two grated onions, vinegar, coriander, paprika, pepper, and salt in a large bowl. Toss thoroughly, cover, and refrigerate at least 4 hours or overnight.
Prepare a charcoal grill or mangal. Let the coals burn down to glowing embers with no flame—vine cuttings or fruitwood are traditional.
Thread the marinated lamb onto long flat metal skewers, pressing the cubes together snugly.
Grill over the embers, turning every 2–3 minutes, for 10–14 minutes total until charred on the edges but still pink inside.
Slide the lamb off the skewers onto a platter. Scatter with raw onion rings, sumac, and chopped parsley.
Serve immediately with lavash, fresh herbs, and sliced tomatoes—the way it is eaten at every Stavropol roadside mangal.

drink.description: A cocktail inspired by Stavropol's vine-covered foothills: local grape brandy mixed with pomegranate juice, a squeeze of lemon, and sparkling water for a refreshing Caucasian aperitif.
ingredients: 2 oz grape brandy or cognac (60 ml)
steps: Shake brandy, pomegranate juice, lemon juice, and grenadine with ice.
Strain into a wine glass filled with ice.
Top with sparkling water.
Garnish with a scattering of pomegranate seeds.

Altai Krai.dish: Altai Krai Pelmeni s Maralom (Алтайские Пельмени с Маралом)
Altai Krai.description: The Altai Krai's prized pelmeni: filled with a mix of maral (Siberian red deer) and pork, seasoned with onion and black pepper. Maral deer roam the Altai Mountains and their lean, gamey meat makes the most distinctive pelmeni in all of Siberia. Served in broth or with sour cream.
ingredients: 1/2 lb ground venison or lean game meat (225 g)
3/4 cup cold water for dough (180 ml)
steps: Make dough: mix flour, 1 tsp salt, egg, and water. Knead 10 minutes until smooth. Rest 30 minutes.
Make filling: mix venison, pork, grated onion, ice water, salt, and pepper until tacky.
Roll dough very thin. Cut 2.5-inch rounds. Place 1 tsp filling in center. Fold into half-moon and pinch sealed. Bring corners together and pinch.
Boil in salted water or broth 5-7 minutes until they float, then 2-3 minutes more.
Serve with sour cream and fresh dill.

drink.description: A rich, velvety cocktail celebrating Altai's legendary honey: vodka shaken with fresh honey, egg yolk, and cream, dusted with nutmeg—a dessert in a glass from the mountain meadows.
ingredients: 1 oz Altai or wildflower honey (30 ml)
steps: Shake vodka, honey, egg yolk, and cream vigorously without ice (dry shake) for 15 seconds.
Add ice and shake again for another 15 seconds.
Strain into a chilled coupe glass.
Dust with freshly grated nutmeg.

dessert.description: A towering honey cake from Russia's honey capital: impossibly thin layers of honey-and-spice cake sandwiched with tangy sour cream filling, then left to soften overnight until the layers meld into a single, melt-on-the-tongue confection. Altai Krai produces the finest honey in Russia—buckwheat, wildflower, and alpine varieties gathered from hives set among the Altai Mountains' pristine meadows. This medovik is the pride of every Altai kitchen, baked for birthdays, holidays, and any occasion worthy of the region's liquid gold.
ingredients: 1/2 cup Altai or wildflower honey (170 g)
Sour cream filling (see Chef's Essentials below)

steps: Whip the heavy cream to stiff peaks.
In a separate bowl, whisk sour cream with powdered sugar and vanilla until smooth.
Gently fold the whipped cream into the sour cream mixture. Refrigerate until ready to use.
Melt butter, honey, and sugar together in a saucepan over low heat, stirring until smooth. Remove from heat and stir in baking soda—the mixture will foam and lighten in color.
Beat in the eggs one at a time. Add cinnamon, cloves, and nutmeg. Gradually stir in the flour until a soft, sticky dough forms. Chill 30 minutes.
Divide the dough into 8 equal portions. Roll each portion into a very thin round (about 8 inches) on parchment paper.
Bake each round at 350°F (175°C) for 5–6 minutes until golden and firm. Trim to even circles while still warm. Save the trimmings.
Spread the sour cream filling generously between each layer, stacking them evenly. Spread filling over the top and sides.
Crush the reserved trimmings into fine crumbs and press onto the top and sides of the cake.
Refrigerate at least 8 hours or overnight. The layers will absorb the cream and become soft and luscious. Slice and serve—this is patience rewarded.

Volgograd Oblast.description: Pan-fried Volga pike-perch—the great freshwater fish of Russia's mightiest river, dredged in seasoned flour and fried in butter until the skin shatters and the flesh inside is pearly white and sweet. Volgograd Oblast straddles the lower Volga, and sudak (pike-perch) is its most prized catch: firm-fleshed, delicate, and plentiful in the river's vast floodplains. Fishermen and babushkas alike insist on the same simple preparation—flour, butter, lemon, dill—because the fish itself is the star. This is the taste of the Volga at dawn.
ingredients: 1/2 cup all-purpose flour for dredging (65 g)
steps: Pat the pike-perch fillets dry with paper towels. Season both sides with salt and white pepper.
Mix flour with a pinch of salt and pepper on a plate. Dip each fillet in beaten egg, then dredge in the seasoned flour, shaking off the excess.
Heat butter and sunflower oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat until the butter foams.
Lay the fillets skin-side down in the skillet. Fry without moving for 4 minutes until the skin is golden and crispy.
Carefully flip and fry 3 minutes more until the flesh is opaque and flakes easily.
Transfer to a warm platter. Scatter with dill and parsley, and surround with lemon wedges. Serve immediately with boiled potatoes—the Volga fisherman's complete meal.

drink.description: A crisp, refreshing cocktail evoking the wind off the Volga: vodka lengthened with tart lingonberry juice and tonic, finished with a twist of lemon.
ingredients: 2 oz lingonberry juice (or cranberry juice) (60 ml)
steps: Pour vodka, lingonberry juice, and lemon juice into a tall glass filled with ice.
Top with tonic water and stir gently.
Garnish with a long lemon twist.

Samara Oblast.description: Samara-style pierogi filled with a luscious mixture of mashed potato and caramelized onion, boiled until the dough is silky, then served glistening with butter and crowned with a generous dollop of smetana. Samara sits where the Volga bends around the Zhiguli Mountains, and these pierogi are the city's defining comfort food—sold in every stolovaya, packed into every lunch pail, and served at every family table. The secret is in the onions: fried slowly in butter until deeply golden, they transform simple potato filling into something extraordinary.
ingredients: 2 lbs Yukon Gold potatoes, peeled and quartered (900 g)
steps: Make the dough: mix flour and 1/2 tsp salt, make a well, add the egg and warm water. Knead 8 minutes until smooth and elastic. Wrap in plastic and rest 30 minutes.
Boil potatoes in salted water until very tender. Drain and mash until smooth.
Fry the onions in 2 tbsp butter over medium-low heat for 15–20 minutes until deeply golden and sweet. Mix half the fried onions into the mashed potatoes. Season with salt and pepper.
Roll the dough thin (1/8 inch) on a floured surface. Cut 3.5-inch rounds. Place a tablespoon of potato filling in the center of each round.
Fold into half-moons, pinching the edges firmly to seal. Press the edges with a fork for a decorative crimp.
Boil the pierogi in salted water for 4–5 minutes until they float and the dough is translucent.
Drain gently and toss with the remaining 2 tbsp butter and reserved fried onions. Serve with generous smetana and a shower of fresh dill.

drink.description: A refreshing beer cocktail named for the Zhiguli Mountains overlooking the Volga at Samara: Zhigulyovskoye-style lager mixed with sparkling lemon soda and a drizzle of honey—a summer staple along the Samara embankment.
steps: Pour the lager into a chilled tall glass.
Dissolve honey in a splash of warm water and add to the glass.
Top with sparkling lemon soda and stir once gently.
Garnish with a lemon wedge on the rim.

Republic of Adygea.description: Golden, crescent-shaped fried pastries filled with warm, stretchy Adyghe cheese—the signature snack of Russia's smallest republic. Adygea, nestled in the foothills of the Western Caucasus, is famous above all for its cheese: a soft, fresh, mildly tangy cheese with a texture between feta and mozzarella. Haluzh are made by wrapping thin, elastic dough around generous handfuls of this cheese, then pan-frying in butter until the crust blisters and the filling melts into a molten, savory core. They are eaten immediately, too hot to hold, with the cheese stretching in long strings.
ingredients: 12 oz Adyghe cheese (or fresh farmer's cheese), crumbled (340 g)
2 tbsp fresh herbs (dill and cilantro), finely chopped

steps: Mix flour, baking soda, and salt in a bowl.
Whisk kefir and egg together, then add to the flour mixture. Knead 5–7 minutes until a smooth, elastic dough forms.
Cover and rest 20 minutes.
Prepare the filling: mix the crumbled Adyghe cheese with egg yolk, herbs, and a pinch of salt. The mixture should hold together when squeezed.
Divide the rested dough into 10–12 pieces. Roll each piece into a thin oval about 6 inches long.
Place 2 tablespoons of cheese filling on one half of each oval. Fold the other half over and press the edges firmly to seal, then crimp with a fork.
Heat butter in a large skillet over medium heat. Fry the haluzh 3–4 minutes per side until golden brown and blistered.
Serve immediately while the cheese is still molten and stretchy—these wait for no one.

drink.description: A light, aromatic spritz from the Caucasus foothills: grape brandy with wildflower honey, sparkling mineral water, and fresh mint—refreshing after a plate of rich cheese pastries.
steps: Muddle 3–4 mint leaves gently in a wine glass.
Add grape brandy and honey syrup with ice.
Top with sparkling mineral water and stir once.
Garnish with a mint sprig and lemon wheel.

Republic of Kalmykia.description: The ceremonial feast dish of the Kalmyk people—Russia's only Buddhist nation and descendants of the Oirat Mongols who settled the Caspian steppe. Makhan is boiled lamb served in its rich broth with broad, hand-cut flat noodles: the meat is cooked on the bone until it falls apart, the broth is deeply savory and golden with fat, and the noodles soak up every drop. This is the dish served at weddings, funerals, and the Kalmyk New Year (Tsagan Sar). It is eaten communally, with the eldest given the choicest cuts—a dish of honor, memory, and the open steppe.
ingredients: 2 lbs bone-in lamb shoulder, cut into large pieces (900 g)
Kalmyk flat noodles (see Chef's Essentials below)

steps: Mound the flour on a work surface. Make a well and add the egg, water, and salt.
Knead 10 minutes until the dough is smooth and firm. Cover and rest 30 minutes.
Roll the dough out very thin (1/16 inch). Cut into wide strips about 2 inches by 4 inches.
Place the lamb pieces in a large pot with the water. Bring to a boil, skimming all foam from the surface.
Add onions, bay leaves, peppercorns, and salt. Reduce heat and simmer gently for 2 hours until the lamb is completely tender and falling off the bone.
Remove the lamb pieces and set aside. Strain the broth and return it to the pot.
Bring the broth back to a rolling boil. Add the flat noodles and cook 5–7 minutes until tender but still chewy.
While the noodles cook, pull the lamb meat from the bones into large chunks.
Serve in deep bowls: a nest of noodles, chunks of lamb, and a generous ladle of hot broth. Garnish with fresh parsley. Eat with your hands and a spoon—as the Kalmyks do.

drink.description: A warming cocktail rooted in Kalmyk tea tradition: strong brick tea brewed with milk and butter, spiked with brandy and dusted with nutmeg—the nomadic steppe reimagined as an evening drink.
ingredients: 1 cup strong-brewed black brick tea (240 ml)
steps: Brew the brick tea strong and strain into a mug.
Stir in butter and honey until melted.
Add milk and brandy. Stir gently.
Dust the top with freshly grated nutmeg and serve hot.

Pskov Oblast.description: Tiny, silvery lake smelt fried to a shattering crisp—the ancient delicacy of Pskov, one of Russia's oldest cities. Sneti are the miniature freshwater fish that have been hauled from Lake Peipus (Chudskoye) since the time of Alexander Nevsky. Barely two inches long, they are dredged whole in seasoned flour and fried in hot oil until they crunch like potato chips. Pskovians eat them by the handful with beer, pile them on black bread, or simply devour them straight from the pan with a squeeze of lemon. The entire fish is eaten—head, tail, and all.
ingredients: 1.5 lbs fresh lake smelt (sneti), cleaned (680 g)
steps: Rinse the smelt and pat completely dry with paper towels. Removing all moisture is essential for a crisp fry.
Mix flour, salt, pepper, and garlic powder in a shallow bowl.
Toss the smelt in the seasoned flour until evenly coated, shaking off any excess.
Heat 1 inch of sunflower oil in a deep skillet or pot to 375°F (190°C).
Fry the smelt in small batches for 2–3 minutes, turning once, until deep golden and completely crispy.
Drain on paper towels and season with a pinch more salt while hot.
Pile onto a platter with lemon wedges and dill. Eat with your fingers—the whole fish, bones and all—as Pskovians have for a thousand years.

drink.description: A rich, golden cocktail from the land of medieval monasteries: vodka shaken with Pskov wildflower honey, egg yolk, and cream—a drink as old-world as the city's fortress walls.
steps: Combine vodka, honey, egg yolk, and cream in a shaker. Dry shake vigorously for 15 seconds without ice.
Add ice and shake again for 15 seconds.
Strain into a chilled coupe glass.
Dust with freshly grated nutmeg.

Leningrad Oblast.description: The spring rite of St. Petersburg and the Leningrad Oblast countryside: when the ice breaks on the Neva River each April, millions of silvery smelt (koryushka) surge upstream, and the entire city goes mad for them. Street vendors fry them on the embankments, restaurants run koryushka festivals, and every kitchen in the oblast smells of fish and hot oil. The preparation is deliberately simple—a light dredge in seasoned flour, a quick fry in sunflower oil—because the fish themselves are sweet, delicate, and gone in a few weeks. This is the taste of a Petersburg spring.
ingredients: 1.5 lbs fresh smelt (koryushka), gutted and cleaned (680 g)
steps: Rinse the smelt under cold water and pat very dry with paper towels.
Mix flour, garlic powder, paprika, salt, and pepper in a wide shallow dish.
Dredge each smelt thoroughly in the seasoned flour, shaking off the excess.
Heat 3/4 inch of sunflower oil in a heavy skillet to 370°F (185°C).
Fry the smelt in batches without crowding, 2–3 minutes per side, until golden and crispy.
Drain on paper towels. Season with a final pinch of salt.
Heap on a platter with lemon wedges and dill. In Petersburg, these are eaten standing on the Fontanka embankment, warm from the pan, with the spring wind off the Neva.

drink.description: A vibrant cocktail capturing the first light over the Neva River in spring: vodka mixed with golden sea buckthorn syrup, sparkling water, and a bright squeeze of lemon.
ingredients: 1 oz sea buckthorn syrup (or passion fruit syrup) (30 ml)
steps: Pour vodka, sea buckthorn syrup, and lemon juice into a glass filled with ice.
Top with sparkling water and stir gently.
Garnish with a lemon twist. The drink should glow golden—like dawn over the Neva.

Republic of Mordovia.dish: Medvezhya Lapka — Mordovian Bear's Paw (Медвежья Лапка)
Republic of Mordovia.description: Deep-fried liver-and-onion patties shaped to resemble a bear's paw and coated in golden breadcrumbs—a dish rooted in the Mordovian forest people's ancient reverence for the bear. The Mordvins, a Finno-Ugric people whose culture stretches back millennia in the dense forests between the Volga and Oka rivers, considered the bear sacred. These crispy, savory patties—made with finely chopped beef liver, caramelized onion, and garlic, pressed into a paw shape with 'claw' marks scored into the surface—are festive food, served at celebrations and holidays. The breadcrumb crust shatters to reveal a moist, richly flavored interior.
ingredients: 1 lb beef liver, finely chopped (450 g)
steps: Finely chop the liver (or pulse briefly in a food processor—do not purée). It should have a coarse, meaty texture.
Sauté the onions in a splash of oil over medium heat until golden and sweet, about 10 minutes. Let cool slightly.
Mix the chopped liver with fried onions, garlic, 1 egg, 2 tbsp flour, salt, pepper, and allspice. The mixture should hold its shape when formed.
Shape the mixture into oval patties about 3/4 inch thick. Score three 'claw' lines into the top of each patty with a knife to resemble a bear's paw.
Set up a breading station: flour, then beaten egg, then breadcrumbs. Dredge each patty through all three stages.
Heat 2 inches of sunflower oil to 350°F (175°C). Fry the patties in batches for 4–5 minutes, turning once, until deep golden and cooked through.
Drain on paper towels and serve hot. In Mordovia, these are eaten with pickled vegetables and dark rye bread.

drink.description: A cocktail from the depths of the Mordovian forest: gin infused with pine-needle brightness, sharpened with lemon, and lengthened with tonic—the taiga in a tall glass.
ingredients: 1/2 oz pine needle syrup (or rosemary syrup) (15 ml)
steps: Shake gin, pine needle syrup, and lemon juice with ice.
Strain into a tall glass filled with ice.
Top with tonic water and stir gently.
Garnish with a rosemary sprig.

Tula Oblast.description: Tula's version of Russia's oldest soup: sour shchi made with sauerkraut, beef, and mushrooms, simmered for hours in a clay pot. Tula sits in the heart of Russia's Black Earth belt, and its shchi is earthier and more robust than the Moscow version—sauerkraut gives it a distinctive tang.
ingredients: 1 lb beef chuck cut into chunks (450 g)
2 cups sauerkraut drained and rinsed (300 g)
1/2 oz dried porcini mushrooms soaked in 1 cup hot water (15 g)
Sour cream and fresh dill for serving
steps: Simmer beef in broth with bay leaves 1 hour until tender. Remove beef and shred.
Sauté onion and carrot in butter until soft. Add tomato paste and cook 2 minutes.
Add sauerkraut to the broth pot. Add the mushrooms with their soaking liquid (strain first). Add the sautéed vegetables.
Add potatoes. Simmer 20 minutes until potatoes are tender.
Return shredded beef. Season with salt and pepper. Simmer 10 minutes.
Serve with a generous spoon of sour cream and fresh dill.

drink.description: A warming cocktail inspired by Tula's famous samovars: strong black tea concentrate spiked with brandy, sweetened with honey, and perfumed with cinnamon and lemon—the samovar tradition with a spirited twist.
steps: Brew the tea strong using a samovar or teapot concentrate.
Warm the brandy gently in a small saucepan with the cinnamon stick, cloves, and lemon wheel for 2 minutes. Do not boil.
Combine the spiced brandy and hot tea in a glass mug. Stir in honey until dissolved.
Garnish with the cinnamon stick and lemon wheel. Drink while steaming.

dessert.description: Russia's most famous gingerbread and the edible symbol of Tula, a city as renowned for its pryaniki as for its samovars. Tulsky pryanik is not a simple cookie—it is a work of folk art: spiced honey dough pressed into hand-carved wooden molds that stamp ornate patterns and inscriptions onto the surface, filled with a layer of thick fruit jam, then baked and glazed until glossy. Tula has been producing these since the 17th century, and every Russian knows the proverb 'как тульский пряник' (like a Tula pryanik)—meaning something irresistible. The spices are warm but not overpowering; the jam filling is tangy and bright against the dense, fragrant dough.
ingredients: 3/4 cup thick fruit jam (apricot or berry) (240 g)
1 cup powdered sugar for glaze (120 g)
steps: Warm the honey and butter in a saucepan over low heat until the butter melts and the honey is liquid. Stir in the sugar until dissolved. Let cool to lukewarm.
Beat in the eggs one at a time. Add baking soda, cinnamon, ginger, nutmeg, cloves, and salt. Gradually mix in the flour until a soft, pliable dough forms.
Divide the dough in half. Roll one half into a rectangle about 1/4 inch thick on a floured surface. This is the bottom layer.
Spread the jam evenly over the bottom layer, leaving a 1/2-inch border. Roll the second half of dough to the same size and lay it over the jam. Press the edges to seal.
If you have a carved wooden mold, press it firmly into the top to imprint a pattern. Otherwise, score a decorative design with a knife or fork.
Transfer to a parchment-lined baking sheet. Bake at 350°F (175°C) for 25–30 minutes until firm and golden.
While still warm, whisk powdered sugar and milk into a smooth glaze and brush over the top. Let the glaze set completely before slicing into rectangles or squares.

Perm Krai.description: The legendary small fried pies of Perm, stuffed with juicy seasoned beef and sealed so tightly that the broth stays trapped inside until the first bite, when it explodes in your mouth—hence the name, from the old Russian 'posikat,' meaning to squirt or spurt. Posikunchiki are Perm Krai's most iconic street food, sold at every market and festival, and the subject of fierce local pride. The dough must be thin but strong enough to hold the juice; the filling must be simple—beef, onion, salt, pepper, and a splash of ice water to create steam inside the sealed pocket. They are fried quickly in hot oil and eaten immediately, burning your fingers and chin.

steps: Mix flour and salt. Make a well and add the warm milk, egg, and melted butter.
Knead 8–10 minutes until the dough is very smooth, elastic, and slightly glossy.
Wrap in plastic and rest at least 30 minutes. The dough must be supple enough to roll very thin without tearing.
Mix the ground beef with finely diced onion, ice-cold water, salt, and pepper. The water is crucial—it creates the steam that becomes the juicy broth inside the sealed pie.
Roll the rested dough very thin (1/16 inch) on a floured surface. Cut 3-inch rounds with a glass or cutter.
Place a heaping teaspoon of filling in the center of each round. Fold into a half-moon and pinch the edges shut with extreme care—there must be no gaps, or the juice will escape during frying.
Heat 1.5 inches of sunflower oil in a deep skillet to 360°F (180°C).
Fry the posikunchiki in batches for 3–4 minutes, turning once, until deep golden on both sides.
Drain on paper towels for only a moment—these must be eaten immediately, while the broth inside is still scalding. Bite carefully: the first burst of juice is the whole point.

drink.description: A refreshing cocktail built on Russia's beloved fermented bread drink: tangy kvas spiked with vodka, brightened with honey and fresh mint—Perm Krai's answer to the Moscow Mule.
steps: Muddle 4–5 mint leaves gently in a copper mug or tall glass.
Add vodka and honey syrup with ice.
Top with kvas and stir once.
Garnish with a sprig of mint and a lime wedge.

Chuvash Republic.description: The national soup of the Chuvash people—a Turkic nation settled along the Volga since antiquity. Shurpe is a hearty, deeply savory lamb-and-root-vegetable soup built on a rich bone broth, loaded with chunks of turnip, carrot, and potato. Unlike the clear broths of Central Asian shorpa, Chuvash shurpe is thick and substantial, meant to sustain farmers through the long Volga winters. The turnip is essential—the Chuvash have cultivated it for centuries, and its sweet earthiness defines the soup. Every Chuvash village has its own version, but the soul remains the same: lamb, roots, broth, and time.
ingredients: 1.5 lbs bone-in lamb, cut into chunks (680 g)
steps: Place the lamb chunks in a large pot with the water. Bring to a boil, carefully skimming all foam from the surface.
Add the onion and bay leaves. Reduce heat and simmer gently for 1.5 hours until the lamb is nearly tender.
Add the turnips, carrots, and potatoes. Continue simmering 25–30 minutes until all vegetables are soft.
Season with salt and pepper. Remove the bay leaves.
Ladle into deep bowls, making sure each serving has a generous mix of lamb and vegetables.
Shower with fresh dill and parsley. Serve with dark rye bread—this is the Chuvash farmer's complete winter meal.

drink.description: A tart, refreshing cocktail celebrating the Chuvash Republic's deep brewing traditions: local-style wheat beer sharpened with lemon, sweetened with honey syrup, and finished with a dash of aromatic bitters.
steps: Pour the lemon juice, honey syrup, and bitters into a chilled tall glass.
Slowly pour in the wheat beer, tilting the glass to preserve the head.
Stir once gently.
Garnish with a lemon wheel.

Republic of North Ossetia-Alania.dish: Ossetinski Pirog — Ossetian Three Pies (Осетинские Пироги)
Republic of North Ossetia-Alania.description: The sacred food of the Ossetian people—three round, thin-crusted pies served together at every feast, each with a different filling, representing the sun, earth, and God in Ossetian cosmology. The three traditional fillings are Uælibækh (Ossetian cheese), Kartofdzhin (potato and cheese), and Tsakhараdzhin (beet tops and cheese). The dough must be stretched paper-thin by hand so the filling-to-crust ratio favors the filling overwhelmingly—a good Ossetian pie should be more filling than bread. In North Ossetia, no celebration, prayer, or gathering begins without these three pies on the table, blessed by the eldest with a toast to God, the sun, and the good earth.
ingredients: 12 oz Ossetian or fresh brined cheese (suluguni or feta), crumbled (340 g)
8 oz fresh beet tops (or Swiss chard), chopped and wilted (225 g)
2 tbsp butter, melted, for brushing (30 g)
Ossetian pie dough (see Chef's Essentials below)

steps: Dissolve yeast and sugar in warm water. Let stand 5 minutes until foamy.
Mix flour and salt. Add the yeast water and oil. Knead 8 minutes until smooth and elastic.
Cover and let rise 1 hour until doubled. Punch down and divide into 3 equal balls.

Prepare three fillings: (1) Cheese — mix 4 oz crumbled cheese with a pinch of salt. (2) Potato-cheese — mix mashed potatoes with 4 oz crumbled cheese, salt, and pepper. (3) Beet top — squeeze all moisture from the wilted beet tops, mix with 4 oz crumbled cheese, salt, and pepper.
Take one dough ball and stretch it by hand on a floured surface into a thin 10-inch round. Place one filling in the center.

Gather the edges of the dough up over the filling, pinching them together at the top like a pouch. Flip the pouch seam-side down and gently flatten and stretch it into a round pie about 10 inches across and 3/4 inch thick. Cut a small steam vent in the center.
Repeat with the remaining two dough balls and fillings so you have three pies.
Bake each pie on a parchment-lined baking sheet at 450°F (230°C) for 12–15 minutes until golden and puffed.
Brush each pie generously with melted butter the moment it comes from the oven.
Stack the three pies on a round platter and cut into wedges. Serve together—the three pies are never separated. The eldest at the table gives the blessing before anyone eats.

drink.description: A cocktail built on Ossetian arak—the traditional Caucasian anise-flavored spirit distilled in the mountain villages of North Ossetia. Brightened with lemon and softened with honey, it is the festive drink served alongside the three sacred pies.
steps: Shake arak, lemon juice, and honey syrup with ice.
Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice.
Top with sparkling water.
Garnish with a lemon wheel. The drink will turn milky—this is the louche effect, and it is beautiful.

Nizhny Novgorod Oblast.description: The merchant city's signature soup—not to be confused with Moscow's thinner version. Nizhny Novgorod's solyanka is thick, sour, and extravagantly loaded with mixed meats, pickled cucumbers, briny olives, capers, and slices of lemon. This is the soup of the Nizhny Novgorod trade fairs, where merchants from across Russia gathered at the confluence of the Volga and Oka rivers and demanded a soup as rich and layered as their commerce. The combination of smoked sausage, beef brisket, and ham creates a triple-meat depth, while the pickles, olives, and capers deliver a sour-salty punch that makes this soup utterly addictive. Every bowl is crowned with sour cream and fresh dill.
ingredients: 8 oz smoked sausage (kielbasa), sliced into half-moons (225 g)
2 tbsp pickle brine from the jar
1/3 cup pitted Kalamata olives, halved (50 g)
steps: Melt the butter in a large pot over medium heat. Sauté the onion until softened, about 5 minutes. Add the tomato paste and cook 2 minutes until darkened and fragrant.
Add the diced beef brisket and pour in the 6 cups of beef broth. Bring to a boil, skim any foam, then reduce heat and simmer 45 minutes until the beef is tender.
Add the sliced smoked sausage, diced ham, diced pickled cucumbers, pickle brine, olives, and capers. Simmer 15 minutes more to meld the flavors.
Add bay leaves and black pepper. Taste carefully before adding salt—the pickles, olives, capers, and broth bring significant brine, so proceed cautiously.
Remove the bay leaves. Ladle into deep bowls, ensuring each serving has a generous mix of all three meats.

Top each bowl with a thin lemon slice, a spoonful of sour cream, and a shower of fresh dill. The sour-salty-smoky complexity of this soup is why Nizhny Novgorod's merchants considered solyanka the king of all soups.

drink.description: A cocktail inspired by Nizhny Novgorod's legendary trade fair culture: vodka sharpened with pickle brine and lemon, lengthened with spicy ginger beer—the merchant's refreshment after a long day of commerce on the Volga.
steps: Pour vodka, pickle brine, and lemon juice into a copper mug or tall glass over ice.
Top with ginger beer and stir once.
Garnish with a pickled cucumber spear. The brine is the soul of this drink—just like the solyanka.

Krasnoyarsk Krai.description: The prized Siberian whitefish from the Yenisei River basin, simply prepared with salt, lemon, and herbs over coals. Omul is the aristocrat of Siberian freshwater fish—a cold-water salmonid with delicate, fatty flesh that needs almost nothing to shine. In Krasnoyarsk Krai, the fish is grilled whole over charcoal with nothing more than salt, a squeeze of lemon, and a few sprigs of herbs. The smoke from alder or birch chips is the only seasoning the Yenisei fishermen trust. This is Siberian cooking at its philosophical core: the best ingredient, the simplest preparation, and the deepest respect for the river that provides.
ingredients: 2 whole omul fish (or Arctic char or whitefish), about 1 lb each (450 g each), cleaned and gutted
Alder or birch wood chips, soaked 30 minutes
steps: Rub the fish inside and out with coarse sea salt and black pepper. Stuff the cavities with dill sprigs, thyme sprigs, and a generous squeeze of lemon. Let the fish cure for 30 minutes at room temperature.
Prepare a charcoal grill or smoker. When the coals are white-hot, scatter a handful of soaked alder or birch chips directly onto the coals.

Brush the fish lightly with sunflower oil on both sides. Place on the grill grate over indirect heat, close the lid, and smoke-grill for 20–25 minutes until the flesh is opaque and flakes easily with a fork.
Transfer the whole fish to a platter and serve with lemon halves and sprigs of fresh dill. The Yenisei way is simple—the quality of the omul speaks for itself. Eat with dark bread and nothing more.

drink.description: A cocktail from the Siberian taiga: vodka infused with the spirit of the cedar forests, brightened with lemon and honey, finished with a silky egg-white foam—Krasnoyarsk's toast to the wild Yenisei.
ingredients: 2 oz cedar nut-infused vodka or plain vodka (60 ml)
steps: Dry-shake vodka, lemon juice, honey syrup, and egg white vigorously without ice for 15 seconds.
Add ice and shake again until very cold.
Strain into a coupe glass.
Dash bitters on the foam and drag a toothpick through for a taiga-inspired design.

Komi Republic.description: The daily bread of the Komi taiga people—open-faced pies of rye dough topped with a thick, generous layer of sour cream mixed with mashed potato, baked until the topping is golden and slightly puffed. Shangi are among the oldest foods of the Komi people, a Finno-Ugric nation who have lived in the vast boreal forests of northeastern Russia for millennia. The rye dough reflects the harsh northern climate where rye was the only grain that would grow, and the sour cream topping is the richness that made these simple pies sustaining enough for a day of work in the taiga. Every Komi household bakes shangi, and they are served at every meal with strong tea and berry jam.
steps: Dissolve the yeast and sugar in the warm water. Let stand 5 minutes until foamy. Mix the rye flour, all-purpose flour, and salt in a large bowl. Add the yeast mixture, warm milk, and vegetable oil. Knead 8 minutes until smooth. Cover and let rise 1 hour.
Mix the mashed potatoes with sour cream, egg yolk, melted butter, salt, and pepper until a thick, creamy topping forms.
Divide the risen dough into 8 portions. Roll each into a flat round about 5 inches across and 1/4 inch thick.
Spread a generous layer of the potato-sour cream topping over each round, leaving a small rim of bare dough around the edge.
