Place on a parchment-lined baking sheet. Bake at 400°F (200°C) for 15–18 minutes until the dough is firm and the topping is golden and slightly puffed.
Brush with melted butter immediately out of the oven. These are the daily bread of the Komi taiga—eat them warm with strong tea and a bowl of berry jam.

drink.description: A cocktail from the boreal forests of the Komi Republic: gin brightened with lingonberry syrup and lime, lengthened with tonic water—a toast to the endless taiga.
ingredients: 1 oz lingonberry syrup or cranberry syrup (30 ml)
steps: Pour gin, lingonberry syrup, and lime juice into a tall glass over ice.
Top with tonic water and stir gently.
Garnish with a few fresh cranberries floating on top.

Kabardino-Balkar Republic.description: The most important food of the Kabardian table—thin, round flatbreads stretched impossibly thin around a filling of potato and cheese, cooked on a dry griddle without any oil, then brushed generously with butter. Khychiny are the heart of Kabardino-Balkarian cuisine, served at every meal, every celebration, and every welcome. The dough is made with kefir and must be stretched so thin that the filling-to-dough ratio overwhelmingly favors the filling—a good khychin should be almost translucent. The potato-cheese filling is the classic Kabardian version, though greens and meat fillings also exist. In Kabardino-Balkaria, the skill of making khychiny is the measure of a cook.
ingredients: 12 oz Circassian cheese (or a mix of crumbled feta and shredded mozzarella) (340 g)
2 tbsp butter, softened, for brushing (30 g)

steps: Mix flour, baking soda, and salt. Add kefir and warm water gradually, mixing until a soft, pliable dough forms.
Knead 5 minutes until smooth and elastic. Cover with a damp cloth and rest 20 minutes.
Divide into 6 equal balls.
Mix the crumbled cheese with mashed potatoes, salt, and pepper until well combined. Divide the filling into 6 equal portions and shape each into a ball.
Take one dough ball and roll it into a thin 6-inch round on a floured surface. Place a filling ball in the center.

Gather the dough edges up around the filling, pinching them closed at the top like a pouch. Flip the filled ball seam-side down and gently roll or press it into a thin round about 8–9 inches across—the thinner the better, but do not tear the dough.
Heat a dry cast-iron skillet or griddle over medium heat. Cook the khychin for 2–3 minutes per side until golden-brown spots appear. No oil is used—the dry griddle is essential.
Brush both sides generously with softened butter the moment it comes off the griddle.

Stack the finished khychiny on a plate and cut into quarters. In Kabardino-Balkaria, these are served at every meal, every celebration, and every welcome—the most important food of the Kabardian table.

drink.description: A cocktail inspired by the view from the slopes of Mount Elbrus—Europe's highest peak, which towers over Kabardino-Balkaria: apricot brandy brightened with lemon and layered with pomegranate, evoking the famous Caucasian sunset.
ingredients: 2 oz apricot brandy or apricot liqueur (60 ml)
steps: Shake apricot brandy, lemon juice, and pomegranate syrup with ice.
Strain into a wine glass over fresh ice.
Top with sparkling water.
Garnish with a sprinkle of pomegranate seeds—the colors evoke sunset over Mount Elbrus.

Irkutsk Oblast.description: The legendary endemic fish of the deepest lake on Earth, hot-smoked over alder chips until golden and fragrant. Lake Baikal's omul is one of the most celebrated fish in all of Russia—a cold-water whitefish found nowhere else on the planet, evolved over millions of years in the crystal-clear waters of the world's oldest and deepest lake. In Irkutsk Oblast, the traditional preparation is hot-smoking: the fish is brined overnight with salt, sugar, and bay leaves, then slowly smoked over soaked alder chips until the flesh is firm, golden, and permeated with delicate smoke. Baikal omul is served simply—with black bread, sliced onion, and lemon—because the fish itself is the entire point.
ingredients: 2 whole omul fish (or Arctic char or whitefish), about 1 lb each (450 g each), cleaned and gutted
steps: Mix the sea salt, sugar, and cracked peppercorns. Rub the fish generously inside and out. Place bay leaves and dill sprigs inside the cavities. Refrigerate for 4–6 hours or overnight to brine.

Rinse the fish briefly under cold water and pat completely dry. Let air-dry on a wire rack for 30 minutes until the skin feels tacky to the touch—this is the pellicle, essential for proper smoke adhesion.
Set up a smoker or charcoal grill for indirect heat at 200°F (95°C). Add the soaked alder chips to the coals or smoker box.
Smoke the fish for 1.5–2 hours at low heat until the flesh is firm, deep golden, and cooked through, maintaining temperature between 180–220°F (82–104°C).
Let cool slightly before serving. Baikal omul is served simply—with black bread, thinly sliced onion, and a wedge of lemon. Nothing more is needed for the most revered fish in Siberia.

drink.description: A cocktail as deep and clear as Lake Baikal itself: vodka and blue curaçao brightened with lemon and lengthened with sparkling water—the legendary blue of the world's deepest lake captured in a glass.
steps: Shake vodka, blue curaçao, lemon juice, and simple syrup with ice.
Strain into a tall glass over fresh ice.
Top with sparkling water.
Garnish with a lemon twist. The blue color evokes the legendary clarity of Lake Baikal.

Khabarovsk Krai.dish: Khabarovsk Kimchi Borscht (Хабаровский Борщ с Кимчи)
Khabarovsk Krai.description: A Far Eastern Russian-Korean fusion that perfectly embodies Khabarovsk—a city where Russian and Korean cultures have blended for over a century. This is classic borscht made with kimchi instead of fresh cabbage, reflecting the large Korean diaspora that has called the Russian Far East home since the late 19th century. The fermented tang and spice of kimchi replaces the vinegar traditionally used to brighten borscht, while soy sauce adds an umami depth that standard borscht lacks. The result is something uniquely Far Eastern Russian: recognizably borscht, unmistakably Korean-influenced, and utterly delicious in a way that neither tradition alone could achieve.
ingredients: 1 lb beef chuck, cut into 1-inch cubes (450 g)
1.5 cups napa cabbage kimchi, chopped, with its juice (about 12 oz / 340 g)
1 tsp Korean gochugaru red pepper flakes (optional)
steps: Heat sunflower oil in a large pot over medium-high heat. Brown the beef cubes on all sides, about 5 minutes. Add the diced onion and cook until softened.
Add the grated beets and grated carrot. Stir in the tomato paste and cook 2 minutes until darkened.
Pour in the beef broth. Bring to a boil, skim any foam, then reduce heat and simmer 1 hour until the beef is tender.
Add the chopped kimchi with all its juice, diced potatoes, soy sauce, rice vinegar, and black pepper. Simmer another 20 minutes until potatoes are soft.
Add the minced garlic and optional gochugaru. Cook 2 more minutes.
Ladle into deep bowls and top with sour cream and fresh dill. This fusion dish perfectly embodies Khabarovsk—a city where Russian and Korean traditions have created something uniquely Far Eastern.

drink.description: A cocktail born of the Russian Far East's Korean heritage: smooth soju muddled with fresh shiso leaves, brightened with grapefruit and honey—the Pacific Rim in a glass.
steps: Muddle the shiso leaves gently in a shaker.
Add soju, grapefruit juice, and honey syrup with ice. Shake well.
Strain into a rocks glass over ice.
Top with sparkling water and garnish with a grapefruit slice.

Republic of Khakassia.description: Ancient Turkic nomad food from the Minusinsk Basin—a ceremonial porridge of toasted barley flour mixed with melted butter and honey. Talgan is one of the oldest foods of the Khakass people, a Turkic nation who have inhabited the steppe and mountain valleys of southern Siberia for thousands of years. The barley is first toasted in a dry skillet until deep golden and intensely fragrant, then ground to flour and cooked with butter, milk, and honey into a thick, nutty porridge. Talgan has been served at every important Khakass gathering—weddings, funerals, seasonal festivals, and shamanistic ceremonies—since long before the Russian Empire reached these lands. Its simplicity is its strength: grain, fat, and sweetness, the eternal trinity of nomad sustenance.
ingredients: 1 cup barley groats or barley flour (130 g)
steps: If starting from barley groats: toast the groats in a dry heavy skillet over medium heat, stirring constantly, for 8–10 minutes until deep golden brown and intensely fragrant. Let cool completely, then grind to a fine flour in a spice grinder or blender.
Melt the butter in a saucepan over low heat. Add the toasted barley flour and stir continuously for 3–4 minutes until the mixture is deeply aromatic and slightly darkened.
Add the warmed milk gradually, stirring constantly to prevent lumps, until a thick porridge forms.
Stir in the honey and a pinch of salt. Cook 2 more minutes, stirring gently.

Serve warm in bowls, drizzled with additional honey and topped with fresh berries if desired. This is ancient Turkic nomad food from the Minusinsk Basin—talgan has sustained the Khakass people through centuries of steppe life, a ceremonial food served at every important gathering.

drink.description: A sparkling cocktail celebrating the ancient mead traditions of the Minusinsk Basin: honey mead brightened with lemon and effervesced with sparkling water—a drink as old as the Khakass steppe itself.
ingredients: 2 oz mead or honey wine (60 ml)
steps: Shake mead, lemon juice, and honey syrup with ice.
Strain into a tall glass over fresh ice.
Top with sparkling water and stir gently.
Garnish with a lemon wheel.

Yaroslavl Oblast.description: The Golden Ring's ancient cultured dairy treasure—whole milk slow-baked in a clay pot for hours until it turns deep caramel-brown, then cultured into a thick, tangy fermented cream. Varenets is one of the oldest dairy preparations in Russia, and Yaroslavl Oblast, in the heart of the Golden Ring, has been producing it since medieval times. The key is patience: the milk bakes uncovered at low temperature for 4–5 hours, during which a golden-brown skin forms on the surface repeatedly—each time pushed gently into the milk, adding layers of caramelized richness. The result is a baked milk with a nutty, almost toffee-like depth that no modern process can replicate. After cooling, a spoonful of sour cream cultures the baked milk into varenets—thick, tangy, and profoundly satisfying.
ingredients: 1/4 cup sour cream or plain yogurt with live cultures (60 ml)
steps: Pour the whole milk into a large, heavy clay pot or oven-safe Dutch oven. Place uncovered in an oven set to 300°F (150°C).

Bake for 4–5 hours, allowing the milk to slowly reduce and develop a deep caramel-brown color. A thick golden-brown skin will form on top—push it gently into the milk with a spoon every hour or so. Each time the skin forms and is submerged, it adds richness and color.
Remove from the oven when the milk has reduced by about one-third and turned a rich amber-brown. Let cool to 105–110°F (40–43°C)—warm to the touch but not hot.
Stir in the sour cream or yogurt gently but thoroughly. Cover with a cloth and keep in a warm place at around 100°F (38°C) for 8–12 hours until set and tangy.

Refrigerate until cold and thick. Serve in bowls or glasses, optionally with a sprinkle of sugar. This is varenets—the Golden Ring's ancient cultured dairy, with a nutty caramel depth that no store-bought product can replicate.

drink.description: A rich, velvety cocktail inspired by the dairy traditions of the Golden Ring: vodka shaken with cream, honey, and a whole egg into a silky flip—as luxurious as Yaroslavl's famous varenets.
steps: Dry-shake vodka, cream, honey, and egg vigorously without ice for 15 seconds.
Add ice and shake again until very cold and frothy.
Strain into a coupe glass.
Grate fresh nutmeg over the top.

Udmurt Republic.description: The most important everyday food of the Udmurt people—yeasted blini made from a blend of buckwheat and wheat flours, served with zagusok, the essential red onion-and-egg sauce without which no Udmurt table is complete. Tabani are the national dish of the Udmurt Republic, a Finno-Ugric homeland in the Ural region. The blini themselves are thick, spongy, and tangy from the yeasted buckwheat batter, but the zagusok is what elevates them: slowly cooked red onions melted in butter, folded with chopped hard-boiled eggs and fresh dill, creating a warm, savory sauce that is spooned generously over each tabani. In every Udmurt village, tabani with zagusok is served at breakfast, lunch, and dinner—it is the edible identity of the nation.
ingredients: 2 tbsp butter, melted, plus more for cooking (30 g)

steps: Melt butter in a skillet over medium heat. Add the diced red onions and cook slowly for 10–12 minutes until deeply softened and translucent.
Remove from heat. Fold in the chopped hard-boiled eggs, salt, pepper, and dill.
Serve warm alongside the tabani—the sauce is essential, not optional.
Dissolve the yeast and sugar in the warm milk. Let stand 5 minutes until foamy. Beat in the eggs and melted butter.

Mix the buckwheat flour, all-purpose flour, and salt in a large bowl. Add the wet ingredients gradually, stirring until a smooth, pourable batter forms—thicker than crêpe batter but thinner than American pancake batter.
Cover and let rise in a warm place for 1 hour until bubbly and doubled in volume.

Heat a well-buttered cast-iron skillet over medium heat. Pour batter to form blini about 6 inches across. Cook until bubbles form on the surface and the bottom is golden, then flip and cook 1 more minute.

Stack the tabani and serve warm with the zagusok sauce spooned generously over the top. In the Udmurt Republic, tabani with zagusok is the most important everyday food—no Udmurt table is complete without it.

drink.description: A refreshing cocktail built on the spring harvest of the Udmurt forests: vodka lengthened with birch sap, brightened with lemon and simple syrup—birch sap is harvested across Udmurtia every spring and is central to the Udmurt connection with the forest.
ingredients: 3 oz birch sap or birch water (90 ml)
steps: Shake vodka, lemon juice, and simple syrup with ice.
Strain into a tall glass over fresh ice.
Top with birch sap and stir once.
Garnish with a mint sprig.

Vologda Oblast.dish: Vologda Butter Blini (Вологодские Блины с Вологодским Маслом)
Vologda Oblast.description: Delicate yeasted blini served with the legendary Vologda butter—Russia's most famous cultured butter, with a nutty, almost hazelnut-caramel flavor developed through a unique high-temperature pasteurization process perfected in Vologda since the 19th century by the great Russian butter-maker Nikolai Vereshchagin. Vologda butter is to Russia what Normandy butter is to France: a national treasure with a protected designation, prized for its distinctive aroma and rich golden color. The blini themselves are classic Russian yeasted blini, lightened with beaten egg whites for an ethereal texture. But the star is the butter—spread thick and generous, its warm, nutty flavor transforms each blin from simple to transcendent. In Vologda Oblast, this is how blini are meant to be eaten.
ingredients: 2 tbsp Vologda butter or best-quality European-style cultured butter, melted, plus extra for cooking (30 g)
4 oz Vologda butter or high-fat European cultured butter, softened, for the table (115 g)
steps: Dissolve the yeast and sugar in the warm milk. Let stand 5 minutes until foamy. Beat in the egg yolks and melted butter.
Add the flour and salt gradually, mixing until smooth. Cover and let rise in a warm place for 1 hour until doubled and bubbly.
Beat the egg whites to stiff peaks and fold gently into the risen batter—this gives Vologda blini their legendary lightness.

Heat a small skillet or blini pan over medium heat. Brush with a thin layer of Vologda butter. Pour a small ladleful of batter and cook until golden on the bottom and set on top, about 1.5 minutes. Flip and cook 30 seconds more.

Stack the blini and serve immediately with a generous dish of softened Vologda butter on the side. The butter is the star—Russia's most celebrated cultured butter, with a nutty, almost hazelnut-caramel flavor. Spread it thick and let it melt into each warm blin.

drink.description: A luxuriously rich cocktail inspired by Vologda's legendary dairy culture: vodka shaken with cream, butterscotch, and a whole egg into a velvety flip—as decadent as Vologda butter itself.
ingredients: 1/2 oz butterscotch schnapps or caramel syrup (15 ml)
Pinch of freshly grated nutmeg for garnish
steps: Dry-shake vodka, cream, butterscotch schnapps, and egg vigorously for 15 seconds without ice.
Add ice and shake again until very cold.
Strain into a coupe glass.
Garnish with grated nutmeg—a drink as rich as Vologda butter itself.

Republic of Ingushetia.description: Thin filled flatbreads from the mountains of Ingushetia, stuffed with fresh cheese and wild garlic (ramson), cooked on a dry skillet and brushed with butter—Ingush mountain food at its purest. Chapilgash are among the most beloved foods of the Ingush people, a Caucasian nation whose homeland is the dramatic mountain valleys south of the Terek River. The wild garlic (ramson or cheremscha) is gathered fresh from mountain meadows every spring, and its pungent, garlicky-green flavor against the mild fresh cheese is one of the defining tastes of Ingush cuisine. Like the Kabardian khychiny and the Ossetian pirog, chapilgash represent the ancient Caucasian flatbread tradition—but the wild garlic filling is uniquely Ingush and cannot be found elsewhere.
ingredients: 8 oz fresh Ingush cheese (or queso fresco or farmer's cheese), crumbled (225 g)
1 cup fresh wild garlic (ramson or ramps), finely chopped (about 4 oz / 115 g)
2 tbsp butter, softened, for brushing (30 g)
steps: Mix the flour, baking soda, and a pinch of salt. Add the kefir and warm water, mixing until a soft dough forms. Knead 5 minutes until smooth, cover, and rest 20 minutes.
Combine the crumbled cheese, chopped wild garlic, salt, and pepper for the filling.
Divide the dough into 6 balls. Roll each into a thin round on a floured surface. Place a generous portion of filling in the center.
Gather the dough edges up around the filling, pinch closed at the top, flip seam-side down, and gently press or roll into a thin round about 8 inches across.
Cook on a dry, hot cast-iron skillet over medium heat for 2–3 minutes per side until golden spots appear. No oil is used.

Brush immediately with softened butter on both sides. Stack and cut into wedges. In the mountains of Ingushetia, chapilgash with wild garlic is the taste of spring—the ramson gathered fresh from mountain meadows fills these impossibly thin flatbreads with green, garlicky fire.

drink.description: A crisp, herbaceous cocktail inspired by the mountain springs of Ingushetia: vodka brightened with cucumber and elderflower, lengthened with sparkling water—as clean and fresh as the mountain air.
steps: Shake vodka, cucumber juice, lime juice, and elderflower liqueur with ice.
Strain into a tall glass over fresh ice.
Top with sparkling water.
Garnish with a long cucumber ribbon.

Chelyabinsk Oblast.description: Large steamed dumplings with a lamb-and-pumpkin filling—the Ural Mountains' answer to Central Asian manti. Chelyabinsk Oblast sits at the crossroads of Europe and Asia, and its cuisine reflects centuries of contact with the Turkic and Central Asian peoples of the steppe. Ural manty are larger and more robustly filled than their Central Asian cousins, with a distinctive filling of ground lamb mixed with finely diced pumpkin that creates pockets of sweet, juicy steam inside each dumpling. The dough must be rolled thin but strong enough to hold during the long steaming. In Chelyabinsk, manty are served with sour cream and black pepper—a legacy of the Silk Road's northernmost reach into the Ural industrial heartland.
ingredients: 8 oz pumpkin or butternut squash, peeled and finely diced (225 g)
Ural manty dough (see Chef's Essentials below)

steps: Mix flour and salt. Make a well, add the egg and warm water.
Knead 10 minutes until the dough is very smooth and elastic.
Wrap in plastic and rest at least 30 minutes before rolling.
Combine the ground lamb, diced pumpkin, diced onion, cumin, salt, pepper, and ice-cold water. Mix thoroughly—the pumpkin and water will create the juicy steam inside the dumplings.
Roll the rested dough thin, about 1/16 inch. Cut into 4-inch squares.

Place a generous tablespoon of filling in the center of each square. Pinch opposite corners together over the filling, then pinch the remaining edges to form a pleated boat shape with a small opening at the top—the classic manty form.
Arrange the manty in a steamer basket lined with cabbage leaves or parchment, leaving space between each one so they do not stick.
Steam over vigorously boiling water for 40–45 minutes until the dough is translucent and the filling is cooked through.

Serve with sour cream and a generous grinding of black pepper. These are the Ural Mountains' answer to Central Asian manti—the lamb-pumpkin filling is the Chelyabinsk signature, a legacy of the Silk Road's northernmost reach.

drink.description: A strong, warming cocktail befitting the Ural industrial heartland: rye whiskey sharpened with orange and honey, finished with aromatic bitters—forged in the spirit of Chelyabinsk's steel mills.
ingredients: 2 oz rye whiskey or dark rum (60 ml)
steps: Shake rye whiskey, orange juice, and honey syrup with ice.
Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
Dash bitters on top.
Garnish with an expressed orange peel.

Arkhangelsk Oblast.description: The Pomor people's Atlantic cod stew: salt cod soaked and simmered with potatoes, onion, and bay in a simple milky broth. The White Sea Pomors lived on cod—this dish sustained them through Arctic winters. Served with black bread and butter.
ingredients: 1.5 lbs salt cod soaked 48 hours changing water 3-4 times (680 g)
steps: Drain the soaked cod. Cut into large chunks.
In a pot combine the milk, water, bay leaves, and peppercorns. Bring to a gentle simmer.
Add the potatoes and onion. Cook 10 minutes.
Add the cod chunks. Simmer gently 15 minutes until the cod flakes easily and potatoes are tender.
Stir in butter and dill. Serve in bowls with black bread.

drink.description: A warming cocktail from the Pomor coast: dark rum steeped with cinnamon, cloves, and star anise, combined with strong black tea and honey—built to survive the Arctic winter nights of Arkhangelsk.
steps: Warm the rum gently in a saucepan with the cinnamon stick, cloves, and star anise for 2 minutes—do not boil.
Combine with the hot tea in a mug. Stir in honey until dissolved.
Garnish with a lemon wheel and the cinnamon stick. Drink while steaming.

dessert.description: Arkhangelsk's legendary decorated gingerbread cookies shaped like animals—an ancient Pomor Christmas tradition going back centuries from the White Sea coast. Kozuli are not merely cookies; they are folk art, ritual objects, and edible symbols of the Pomor culture that thrived along the shores of the White and Barents Seas. The dough is spiced with cinnamon, ginger, cloves, and nutmeg, sweetened with honey, and shaped into reindeer, seals, birds, and horses—each animal carrying symbolic meaning in Pomor tradition. After baking, the kozuli are decorated with intricate patterns of white icing, then hung on Christmas trees, placed in windows, given as gifts, and eaten throughout the long Arctic winter. Every Arkhangelsk family has its own molds and patterns, passed down through generations.
ingredients: 1 cup powdered sugar for icing (120 g)
steps: In a saucepan, heat the honey, sugar, and butter over medium heat, stirring until the sugar dissolves and the mixture is smooth and amber-colored. Let cool to lukewarm.

Beat in the egg. Add the baking soda, cinnamon, ginger, cloves, nutmeg, and salt. Gradually work in the flour until a firm, aromatic, spiced dough forms. Wrap in plastic and refrigerate at least 2 hours or overnight.

Roll the chilled dough to 1/4-inch thickness on a floured surface. Cut into animal shapes—reindeer, seals, birds, horses—using cookie cutters or by hand with a knife. The Pomor tradition demands animal shapes.
Bake on a parchment-lined sheet at 350°F (175°C) for 10–12 minutes until firm and golden.
Mix the powdered sugar, milk, and lemon juice into a thick white icing. Pipe decorative patterns onto the cooled cookies using a small piping bag or a zip-lock bag with a corner snipped off.

Let the icing set completely. These kozuli are an ancient Pomor Christmas tradition from the White Sea coast—each animal shape carries symbolic meaning, and the decorated cookies are hung on trees, given as gifts, and used as window decorations throughout the long Arctic winter.

Omsk Oblast.description: Classic Siberian pelmeni with the traditional three-meat filling of beef, pork, and lamb, served swimming in rich bone broth with vinegar and black pepper—the original Siberian way. This is not the sour-cream-on-the-side pelmeni of Moscow restaurants; this is how pelmeni were meant to be eaten in Siberia, where they were born. The three-meat filling is the Omsk tradition, each meat contributing its own character: beef for depth, pork for fat and sweetness, lamb for gamey richness. The ice-cold water mixed into the filling creates steam that becomes the juicy broth trapped inside each dumpling. In Omsk, pelmeni are served in the bone broth they were boiled in, with a sharp splash of white vinegar and a blizzard of black pepper—the original Siberian pel'mennaya experience.
ingredients: 1 large onion, very finely minced or grated
6 cups rich beef or bone broth for serving (1.4 L)
1/2 cup cold water for dough (120 ml)
steps: Make the dough: mix the flour and 1/2 tsp salt, add the egg and cold water, and knead 8–10 minutes until smooth and elastic. Wrap in plastic and rest 30 minutes.

Combine the three ground meats with minced onion, pressed garlic, ice-cold water, 1 tsp salt, and pepper. Mix thoroughly—the combination of three meats is the Siberian secret, and the ice water ensures juiciness.
Roll the rested dough very thin, about 1/16 inch, and cut 2.5-inch rounds with a glass or cutter.
Place a level teaspoon of filling on each round. Fold into a half-moon and press the edges firmly to seal, then bring the two pointed ends together and pinch—forming the classic pelmeni shape.
Bring the bone broth to a rolling boil. Drop the pelmeni in batches and cook 5–7 minutes until they float and the dough is translucent.

Serve the pelmeni swimming in the hot broth in deep bowls. Splash each bowl with white vinegar and add a generous grinding of black pepper. This is the original Siberian way—not with sour cream, but in rich broth with a sharp hit of vinegar.

drink.description: A cocktail named for the great Irtysh River that flows through Omsk: vodka sharpened with lime and lengthened with spicy ginger beer, finished with a dash of bitters—Omsk's own take on the classic mule.
steps: Pour vodka and lime juice into a copper mug or tall glass over ice.
Top with ginger beer.
Add a dash of bitters and stir once.
Garnish with a lime wheel.

Chukotka Autonomous Okrug.description: Raw frozen whale skin and blubber—the traditional Chukchi delicacy from the far northeastern coast of Russia, eaten frozen in thin slices with salt. This is indigenous Arctic food at its most primal. Mantak (also known as muktuk in other Arctic cultures) has been the cornerstone of Chukchi nutrition for thousands of years, providing the essential fats, vitamins, and calories needed to survive in one of the harshest environments on Earth. The whale skin is dark, chewy, and slightly crunchy when frozen; the blubber beneath is white-pink and softens to a clean, mild richness in the mouth. The Chukchi people of the far northeastern coast have maintained their legal subsistence whale hunt for millennia, and mantak remains central to their identity, their ceremonies, and their survival. It is not a delicacy in the luxury sense—it is survival food elevated to cultural sacrament.
ingredients: 1 lb whale skin with attached blubber (muktuk/mantak), frozen solid (450 g)
Soy sauce for dipping (optional, modern addition)
steps: Ensure the mantak (whale skin with blubber) is frozen completely solid. Traditionally, the whale is harvested by Chukchi coastal communities during the legal subsistence hunt and frozen in the Arctic cold immediately.
Using an extremely sharp knife, slice the frozen mantak into thin pieces about 1/8 inch thick and 2 inches long, cutting through both the dark outer skin and the white-pink blubber beneath.
Arrange the frozen slices on a plate. Sprinkle with coarse sea salt and black pepper.

Serve immediately while still frozen—the mantak is eaten in its frozen state. The texture transforms in the mouth: the skin is chewy and slightly crunchy, while the blubber softens to a clean, mild richness.
Optionally, provide soy sauce for dipping—a modern addition from contact with Japanese and Korean traders along the Pacific coast.

This is the traditional Chukchi delicacy from the far northeastern tip of Russia, where indigenous people have practiced subsistence whaling for thousands of years. Mantak is indigenous Arctic food at its most primal—raw, frozen, and deeply connected to the survival and identity of the Chukchi people in one of the harshest environments on Earth.

drink.description: A warming cocktail built for the Arctic winter of Chukotka: vodka combined with hot lingonberry juice, honey, and warming spices—the only thing that takes the chill off at the edge of the world.
ingredients: 4 oz hot lingonberry juice or cranberry juice (120 ml)
steps: Warm the lingonberry juice in a small saucepan with the cinnamon stick, cloves, and ginger for 3 minutes—do not boil.
Pour into a mug. Add vodka and stir in honey until dissolved.
Garnish with the cinnamon stick. This warming drink is built for the Arctic winter of Chukotka.

SAU.description: The national dish of the Kingdom. Spiced rice and meat (chicken or lamb) cooked together, garnished with nuts and raisins.
ingredients: Kabsa Spice Mix: Cardamom, Cinnamon, Cloves, Black Lime powder, Nutmeg
steps: Sauté onions in a large pot. Add meat and brown.
Add tomato puree, spices, dried limes, and salt. Cook for 5 mins.
Add water to cover meat. Simmer until meat is tender.
Add the soaked rice to the pot (add more water if needed, 1 inch above rice).
Cover and cook on low heat until rice is fluffy and water absorbed.
Transfer to a large platter. Top with fried raisins and almonds.

drink.description: Lightly roasted coffee simmered with cardamom—served in small cups, often alongside dates.
ingredients: 3 tbsp lightly roasted ground Arabic coffee (or light-roast ground coffee)
1/2 tsp ground cardamom (or 4 lightly crushed cardamom pods)
steps: Bring water to a boil in a small pot.
Remove from heat, stir in coffee, and return to very low heat; simmer 8–10 minutes without letting it boil hard.
Add cardamom (and optional saffron/cloves) and steep 2 minutes off heat.
Pour carefully into a dallah or serving pot, leaving grounds behind, and serve in small cups.

dessert.description: Saudi-style kunafa: shredded phyllo pastry (kataifi) crisped in butter, layered with a molten cream cheese filling, baked until golden and shattering, then drenched in saffron-rosewater syrup. The first bite is an orchestra—crunchy, creamy, floral, and sweet all at once. Kunafa is the crown of Saudi celebrations, from Ramadan iftars to wedding feasts. It must be served hot, when the pastry crackles and the cheese stretches.

steps: Combine sugar, water, and lemon juice in a saucepan. Bring to a boil, stirring until sugar dissolves.
Reduce heat and simmer 8 minutes until slightly thickened. Add saffron and rosewater. Cool completely before using (syrup must be cold when poured over hot kunafa).

ingredients: 1 lb shredded phyllo dough (kataifi), thawed (450 g)
1 cup unsalted butter, melted (2 sticks / 230 g)
2 cups akkawi cheese or mozzarella, shredded and soaked in water 2 hours to remove salt (250 g)
steps: Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C). Pull apart the kataifi dough and toss with melted butter until every strand is coated.
Press half the buttered dough evenly into a 9x13 inch (23x33 cm) baking pan, packing it firmly.
Mix drained akkawi cheese and ricotta. Spread evenly over the dough layer.
Top with the remaining kataifi dough, pressing down gently. Bake 35–40 minutes until deeply golden and crisp.
Immediately pour cold Saffron-Rosewater Syrup evenly over the hot kunafa. Let it absorb for 5 minutes.
Flip onto a serving platter (crispy side up), sprinkle with crushed pistachios, and serve hot.

ingredients: 1/2 tsp dried lime powder (loomi) (optional but traditional)
steps: Mix all spices thoroughly.
Store airtight up to 3 months.

SGP.description: Poached chicken served with seasoned rice and chili sauce. Simple but relies on perfect execution.
ingredients: Chili Sauce: Fresh chilies, Garlic, Ginger, Lime juice, Chicken fat
steps: Stuff chicken with ginger and scallions. Poach in sub-boiling water for 40-50 mins. Plunge into ice water immediately (to stop cooking and create jelly skin).
Fry raw rice in chicken fat with minced garlic and ginger. Cook rice using the chicken poaching broth.
Rub cooked chicken with sesame oil. Chop into pieces.
Serve chicken with the savory rice, cucumber slices, and the chili dipping sauce.

drink.description: A famous Singapore cocktail built on gin, cherry, citrus, and bitters—fruity and long.
steps: Add all ingredients to a shaker filled with ice.
Shake hard until well chilled.
Strain into a tall glass with fresh ice (or serve up, if preferred).
Garnish with a pineapple wedge or cherry if desired.
Note (quick grenadine): simmer equal parts pomegranate juice + sugar until dissolved; cool before using.
Warm pomegranate juice and sugar in a saucepan over medium heat, stirring until dissolved (avoid a hard boil).
Cool; stir in orange blossom water if using.
Bottle; add vodka if using for shelf-life.
Refrigerate and use within 3–4 weeks (longer if vodka added).

dessert.description: Singaporean hawker centre perfection: a bowl of shaved ice drenched in rich coconut milk, laced with wriggling bright-green pandan rice flour jelly, and crowned with a generous pour of dark, smoky palm sugar syrup (gula melaka). The coconut milk should be thick and unapologetically creamy, the pandan jelly bouncy and fragrant, and the gula melaka syrup dark as mahogany with deep caramel flavor.

ingredients: 1/2 lb gula melaka (palm sugar), chopped (225 g)
steps: Combine palm sugar, water, and pandan leaf in a small saucepan over medium-low heat.
Stir until the sugar dissolves completely. Simmer 5 minutes until syrupy. Remove pandan leaf. Cool.

ingredients: 1 tsp pandan extract (or juice from 6 pandan leaves blended with water and strained)
Green food coloring (optional, for brighter color)
Palm Sugar Syrup / Gula Melaka (see Chef's Essentials below)
Optional: red beans, sweet corn, or grass jelly
steps: Whisk rice flour, tapioca starch, water, pandan extract, and a drop of green food coloring in a saucepan. Cook over medium heat, stirring constantly, until the mixture thickens into a smooth, thick paste—about 5 minutes.
Press the hot paste through a chendol mold or colander with large holes directly into a bowl of ice water. The jelly will form short, worm-like strands. Drain and set aside.
Stir a pinch of salt into the coconut milk.
Assemble: fill bowls with shaved ice. Top with a generous handful of pandan jelly. Pour coconut milk over the ice and drizzle liberally with Palm Sugar Syrup.
Serve immediately before the ice melts. Add red beans or sweet corn if desired.

SLV.description: A pre-Hispanic tradition that has conquered the world. These thick, handmade corn tortillas are stuffed with quesillo cheese, beans, or chicharrón before being cooked. The art is in the 'palmear'—patting the dough so the filling stays inside while the outside crisps.
ingredients: Filling: Quesillo or Mozzarella cheese (finely shredded)
steps: Mix masa and water to form a soft, non-sticky dough. Keep covered.
Take a ball of dough. Indent the center to make a cup.
Fill with cheese, beans, and pork. Pinch the top closed to seal the filling inside.
Gently pat back and forth between hands to flatten into a thick disk (do not let filling burst).
Cook on a lightly oiled griddle until browned on both sides.
Serve hot with Curtido and tomato salsa.

drink.description: A Salvadoran horchata made with morro seeds and spices (distinct from Mexican rice horchata).
ingredients: 2 tbsp horchata mix (morro-based) or prepared horchata
steps: Mix horchata base with liquid until smooth.
Sweeten to taste.
Serve over ice.

ingredients: 2 tbsp cacao nibs (or unsweetened cocoa beans/chunks)
1 tsp coriander seeds (semillas de culantro) (optional but traditional)
steps: Toast each ingredient separately over medium-low heat until fragrant (be careful not to burn the rice). Cool completely.
Grind everything to a fine powder (spice grinder or high-powered blender).
Store in a clean, dry jar. Keeps 1–2 months in a cool pantry.
To make the drink: mix 2 tbsp powder with 8 oz cold water (or a 50/50 mix of water and milk), then strain if desired and sweeten to taste.

dessert.description: A Salvadoran bakery staple: layers of sweet, enriched bread dough sandwiching a filling of pineapple jam or guava paste, topped with a crumbly streusel. Semita is the sweet bread that every Salvadoran bakery displays in tall, golden stacks—bought by the sheet and cut into generous squares. The dough is tender from butter and egg, the filling tangy-sweet, and the crumble topping adds a satisfying crunch.
ingredients: 1/2 cup unsalted butter, softened (1 stick / 115 g)
2 1/4 tsp active dry yeast (1 packet / 7 g)
1 1/2 cups pineapple jam or guava paste, softened (about 400 g)
steps: Dissolve yeast in warm milk with a pinch of sugar. Let stand 5 minutes until foamy.
Mix flour, sugar, and salt. Cut in softened butter until crumbly. Add eggs, vanilla, and yeast mixture. Knead 8–10 minutes until smooth and elastic. Cover and let rise 1 hour until doubled.
Divide dough in half. Roll one half into a rectangle to fit a greased 9x13 inch (23x33 cm) baking pan. Press into the pan.
Spread the pineapple jam or softened guava paste evenly over the dough.
Roll out the second half and place it over the filling. Press edges to seal. Let rise 30 minutes.
Bake at 350°F (180°C) for 25–30 minutes until golden brown. Cool, then cut into squares.
Toss cabbage, carrots, onion, oregano, and salt in a bowl.
Pack into a jar; add vinegar and water to cover.
Refrigerate at least 4 hours (better after 24–48 hours). Keeps 2 weeks.

Ahuachapán.description: Ahuachapán's beloved chicken stew: pieces of chicken braised in a tomato-loroco sauce. Loroco is an edible flower bud unique to El Salvador and Guatemala—its earthy, herbaceous flavor is irreplaceable and defines Salvadoran home cooking. The coffee highlands of Ahuachapán grow the finest loroco.
ingredients: 1 cup loroco buds fresh or jarred (about 4 oz / 110 g)
White rice and warm tortillas for serving
steps: Season chicken with salt and pepper. Brown in oil on all sides. Remove.
Sauté onion, garlic, and bell pepper until soft. Add tomatoes and cook 5 minutes.
Return chicken. Add broth and loroco buds. Stir gently.
Cover and simmer 30-35 minutes until chicken is cooked through and the sauce has thickened.
Serve with white rice and warm tortillas.

drink.description: Warm corn drink, sweet and thick.
steps: Blend corn with liquid; cook until thick. Sweeten and add cinnamon. Serve hot.

dessert.description: Western highlands: fresh corn tamales wrapped in plantain leaves—sweet, soft, and steamed. A staple of the coffee highlands.
ingredients: 6–8 ears fresh corn (or 4 cups corn kernels)
steps: Blend fresh corn kernels with butter, sugar, and salt until smooth. Add masa if needed for thickness.
Spread on softened plantain leaves, fold, and tie. Steam 1–1½ hours until set. Serve warm.

Cabañas.description: Central highlands tamales stuffed with black beans, wrapped in plantain leaves. Simple, hearty, and traditional.
steps: Spread masa on plantain leaves. Add a spoonful of beans, fold and tie.
Steam 1–1½ hours. Serve with salsa and crema.

drink.description: Morro-based horchata.
steps: Mix, sweeten, serve over ice.

Chalatenango.description: Northern classic: warm turkey or chicken sandwiches. The meat is marinated with Pipil spices, roasted, hand-pulled, and served with tomato, watercress, cucumber, and cabbage.
steps: Marinate and roast turkey or chicken. Shred the meat.
Stuff warm rolls with meat, tomato, watercress, cucumber, and cabbage. Serve with salsa.

drink.description: Sweet-tart tamarind drink.
steps: Soak tamarind, strain, sweeten, serve over ice.

Cuscatlán.description: Heartland classic: rooster (or chicken) braised in chicha and panela—sweet and savory, with onions, peppers, and sometimes prunes. A celebration dish in the central regions.
steps: Brown the bird; add chicha, panela, onions, peppers, and spices. Simmer until tender.
Add prunes if using. Serve with rice and tortillas.

drink.description: Traditional morro horchata.
steps: Mix and serve over ice.

La Libertad.description: Grilled steak Salvadoran-style: marinated beef served with chimol (fresh tomato-onion salsa), tortillas, and often yuca or beans. Popular along the coast and in the central valleys.
steps: Marinate steak with lime, garlic, and salt. Grill to desired doneness.
Slice and serve with chimol, tortillas, and beans or yuca.

drink.description: Pineapple juice with chopped fruits.
steps: Mix juice with chopped fruits; serve cold over ice.

La Paz.description: Home of Olocuilta—the 'City of Pupusas.' This is the pupusa capital: rice-flour and corn pupusas from the historic pupuserías along the highway, often cooked on comals over wood fire. National Pupusa Day is celebrated here the second Sunday of November.
ingredients: 4 cups Masa Harina or rice flour
steps: Mix masa and water. Form balls, fill with cheese, beans, or chicharrón; seal and pat into disks.
Cook on a comal or griddle until browned. Serve with curtido and salsa.

drink.description: Morro-based horchata—the classic pairing with pupusas in Olocuilta.
steps: Mix, sweeten, serve over ice.

La Unión.description: Gulf of Fonseca specialty: a rich seafood soup with fish, clams, octopus, squid, shrimp, and crab, seasoned with tomatoes, peppers, cumin, and achiote.
steps: Sauté tomatoes, peppers, and spices. Add seafood and enough water or broth to cover.
Simmer until seafood is cooked. Adjust seasoning. Serve with lime and tortillas.

drink.description: Refreshing tamarind drink.
steps: Soak tamarind, strain, sweeten, serve over ice.

Morazán.description: Eastern highlands: chicken soup with chipilín leaves (a Central American herb) and vegetables. Light, green, and comforting.
steps: Simmer chicken in broth with vegetables until tender.
Add chipilín leaves and cook a few minutes. Serve with lime and tortillas.

drink.description: Traditional corn and cacao drink.
steps: Toast and grind corn and cacao; simmer with spices and sugar. Serve hot or cold.

San Miguel.description: Eastern city classic: tamales stuffed with chicken and potatoes, wrapped in plantain leaves. Hearty and often served at gatherings.
steps: Spread masa on plantain leaves. Layer with chicken, potato, sauce, olive; fold and tie.
Steam 1–1½ hours. Serve with salsa and crema.

drink.description: Morro horchata.
steps: Mix, sweeten, serve over ice.

San Salvador.description: Capital street food: not the Mexican kind—crisp tortillas topped with minced meat, shredded cabbage, carrots, beets, cheese, hard-boiled egg, and tomato sauce. Colorful and filling.
steps: Fry tortillas until crisp. Top with cooked meat, cabbage, grated vegetables, cheese, egg, and tomato sauce.
Serve immediately.

drink.description: Capital favorite.
steps: Mix and serve over ice.

San Vicente.description: Central Salvadoran delicacy: cow tripe soup with plantain, corn, tomatoes, cabbage, and spices. Rich and beloved at family gatherings.
steps: Boil tripe until tender; add plantain, corn, tomatoes, cabbage, and spices.
Simmer until vegetables are soft. Serve with lime and tortillas.

drink.description: Traditional horchata.
steps: Mix, sweeten, serve over ice.

Santa Ana.description: Santa Ana’s iconic dish: boiled or fried yuca (cassava) with crispy chicharrón, curtido, and chimol. Especially popular in the western coffee region—street food and market staple.
steps: Boil or fry yuca until tender and golden. Season with salt.
Serve with chicharrón, curtido, chimol, and lime wedges.

drink.description: Santa Ana is coffee country; strong local brew.
steps: Brew coffee; serve black or with sugar.

Sonsonate.description: Pacific coast: shrimp 'cooked' in lime with tomato, onion, and cilantro. Often served with crackers or tostadas and a dash of Salsa Inglesa (Worcestershire).
steps: Chop shrimp; marinate in lime juice until opaque. Drain slightly.
Mix with tomato, onion, cilantro, salt. Serve cold with tostadas.

drink.description: Sweet-tart coastal refresco.
steps: Soak tamarind, strain, sweeten, serve over ice.

Usulután.description: Usulután's weekend ritual: a thick hearty soup built on cow's feet simmered for hours until the collagen dissolves into a rich gelatinous broth, with tripe, yuca, cabbage, corn, green banana, and chayote. Sopa de pata is the Salvadoran hangover cure and Saturday market staple.
ingredients: 2 lbs cow's feet cleaned and split (900 g)
1/2 lb honeycomb tripe cleaned and cut into pieces (225 g)
1 large yuca peeled and cut into chunks
steps: Place cow's feet and tripe in a large pot. Cover with water by 3 inches. Bring to a boil skimming foam.
Simmer 2-3 hours until the feet are very tender and the broth is gelatinous.
Add onion, garlic, and tomatoes. Simmer 20 minutes.
Add yuca, corn, green banana, and chayote. Simmer 20 minutes.
Add cabbage. Cook 10 more minutes. Season with salt.
Serve in large bowls with cilantro and lime wedges.

drink.description: Pineapple atol, sweet and warm.
steps: Blend pineapple; cook with flour and sugar until thick. Serve hot.

dessert.description: Eastern favorite: torpedo-shaped fritters made from ripe plantain dough, filled with vanilla custard, fried, and rolled in sugar. A beloved sweet snack or dessert.
steps: Mash ripe plantains into a dough. Make custard with milk, sugar, vanilla, egg.
Shape plantain around custard; fry until golden. Roll in sugar. Serve warm.

SMR.description: Meaning 'Swallow's Nests', this Sammarinese classic features fresh pasta sheets rolled with ham, cheese, and béchamel, sliced into coils, and baked until golden and bubbling. It is a comforting, oven-baked pasta dish.
steps: Lay out pasta sheets. Spread with béchamel.
Layer ham and cheese slices.
Roll up the pasta like a jelly roll.
Slice into 2-inch rounds (nests).
Place cut-side up in a baking dish. Top with more béchamel and parmesan.
Bake at 350°F (180°C) until golden.

drink.description: San Marino’s ‘Doma’ is a local citrus liqueur. This home method follows the traditional citrus-peel infusion approach used across the region.
ingredients: Peel of 6 oranges + 2 lemons (avoid white pith)
steps: Put citrus peels in a large jar and pour in the spirit. Seal and infuse 7–10 days in a cool dark place, shaking daily.
Strain out the peels and discard.
Make syrup: warm water and sugar until dissolved; cool completely.
Combine infusion and syrup (start with all syrup; adjust sweetness next day if needed).
Bottle and rest 1–2 weeks for flavors to meld.
Serve well chilled from the freezer.

dessert.description: San Marino's signature confection, named after the republic's three iconic mountain peaks (Guaita, Cesta, and Montale): crisp layers of wafer cookies sandwiched with rich hazelnut-chocolate cream, pressed together, and enrobed in a shell of dark chocolate. Each slice reveals the layered cross-section like geological strata. The Torta Tre Monti is San Marino's most famous edible export—crunchy, chocolatey, and utterly addictive.
ingredients: 12 round wafer cookies (about 7 inches / 18 cm diameter)
1 tbsp hazelnut liqueur (Frangelico) or vanilla extract
8 oz dark chocolate for coating (225 g)
1 tbsp coconut oil or cocoa butter (for coating)
steps: Process hazelnuts in a food processor until finely ground (some small chunks are fine for texture).
Melt 6 oz dark chocolate with butter over a double boiler. Stir in ground hazelnuts, powdered sugar, cocoa powder, and hazelnut liqueur until a thick, spreadable cream forms.
Spread a thin, even layer of hazelnut-chocolate cream on a wafer cookie. Stack another wafer on top. Repeat until all wafers are stacked with cream between each layer. Press gently to compact.
Wrap the stack tightly and refrigerate 2 hours until the cream sets firmly.
Melt 8 oz dark chocolate with coconut oil. Place the chilled wafer cake on a wire rack over a tray. Pour the melted chocolate over the top and sides, spreading with an offset spatula to coat evenly.
Refrigerate until the chocolate shell sets. Slice into wedges with a sharp knife dipped in hot water. Serve at cool room temperature.

SRB.description: The 'Serbian Dream'. A rolled veal or pork cutlet stuffed with kajmak (clotted cream), breaded, and fried. It resembles a soldier's order and is named after the revolutionary Karađorđe.
ingredients: 4 boneless pork cutlets (or veal), pounded thin (about 1 1/2 lb total / 680 g)
4 tbsp kajmak (or thick cream cheese + a little butter) (60 g)
4 thin slices smoked ham (optional but common)
Oil for frying (or shallow pan-fry), plus optional butter for finishing
To serve: lemon wedges; optional tartar sauce
Breading (flour, egg, breadcrumbs - see Chef's Essentials below)

steps: Set up breading station: place flour, beaten eggs, and breadcrumbs in three separate shallow dishes.
Season pounded cutlets with salt and pepper.
Spread a line of kajmak down the center of each; add a slice of ham if using.
Roll tightly, tucking ends, to make a ‘log’. Chill 15 minutes to help set.
Dredge in flour, then egg, then breadcrumbs, pressing to adhere (double-bread if you want a thicker crust).
Fry in 350°F/175°C oil (or shallow fry) until deep golden and cooked through, 4–6 minutes depending on thickness.
Drain briefly on a rack. Serve hot with lemon.

drink.description: A Serbian winter drink: rakija gently heated with sugar/honey and pepper—served hot, never boiled.
ingredients: 6 oz rakija (plum or grape brandy) (180 ml)
1 tbsp honey or sugar (15–20 g), to taste
4 whole peppercorns (or a pinch of ground black pepper)
steps: Combine rakija, honey/sugar, pepper, lemon peel (and cinnamon if using) in a small saucepan.
Warm over very low heat until steaming (do not boil).
Taste and adjust sweetness.
Strain into a small heatproof glass and serve hot.

dessert.description: Belgrade's legendary Moscow Slice: a layered cake with almond sponge, white chocolate cream, and Karađorđe-patterned decoration. The most famous cake at the Hotel Moskva, this Art Nouveau masterpiece has been served since 1977 and remains the single most iconic pastry in Serbia—a pillow of almond meringue sponge sandwiching a luscious white chocolate and almond cream, crowned with a candied cherry and the hotel's signature scroll pattern.
ingredients: 1 1/2 cups (150 g) finely ground blanched almonds
White chocolate almond cream (see Chef's Essentials below)
7 oz (200 g) white chocolate, finely chopped
1/2 cup (50 g) finely ground blanched almonds, lightly toasted
steps: Heat 1/2 cup (120 ml) of the cream until just simmering. Pour over chopped white chocolate and let sit 2 minutes, then stir until completely smooth. Cool to room temperature.
Whip remaining 1/2 cup (120 ml) cream to soft peaks.
Beat softened butter into the cooled white chocolate mixture until fluffy. Fold in whipped cream and toasted ground almonds.
Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Line two 9-inch (23 cm) round cake pans with parchment and grease lightly.
Whip egg whites with a pinch of salt to soft peaks. Gradually add sugar, beating to stiff, glossy peaks.
Gently fold in ground almonds, flour, and vanilla in three additions—work quickly to keep volume.
Divide batter between the two pans and smooth the tops.
Bake 25–30 minutes until golden and springy. Cool in pans 10 minutes, then turn out onto racks and cool completely.
Spread a thick, generous layer of white chocolate almond cream over the first sponge layer. Place the second layer on top.
Spread remaining cream over the top and sides. Dust lightly with powdered sugar.
Decorate the top with candied cherries in the iconic Karađorđe scroll pattern. Refrigerate at least 2 hours before slicing.

SUR.description: A unique fusion of Jewish and Creole cultures. Portuguese Jewish plantation owners replaced potatoes with the local Pomtayer root to make this oven casserole. Baked with chicken and citrus juices, it is the golden, crusty centerpiece of every Surinamese celebration.
steps: Season chicken with salt, pepper, and nutmeg. Fry in oil until brown. Remove chicken.
In the same oil, sauté onions and tomatoes to make a gravy. Add a little water.
Mix the grated Pomtayer with the citrus juices, sugar, and half the gravy. It should be a smooth paste.
Grease a baking dish. Layer half the Pom mixture. Place chicken on top. Cover with remaining Pom mixture.
Pour remaining gravy over the top.
Bake at 350°F (180°C) for 1.5 hours until golden brown and crusty.

drink.description: Suriname’s Borgoe rum is often enjoyed simply as a highball.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) Borgoe rum (or another dark rum)
steps: Fill a highball glass with ice.
Add rum and top with cola.
Garnish with lime if desired.

dessert.description: Surinamese cassava cake: grated cassava with coconut, condensed milk, and almond extract baked into a dense, chewy, golden cake. Javanese-Creole fusion at its most delicious—brought to Suriname by Javanese contract workers and embraced by every community in the country. Bojo is the cake of birthdays, holidays, and Sunday afternoons: impossibly moist, subtly sweet, with a texture somewhere between mochi and pudding that is utterly addictive.
ingredients: 2 lbs (900 g) frozen grated cassava, thawed and well-drained
1 1/2 cups (130 g) finely grated fresh coconut (or desiccated coconut soaked in 1/2 cup / 120 ml coconut milk)
1 can (14 oz / 400 ml) sweetened condensed milk
steps: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Grease a 9x13-inch (23x33 cm) baking dish.
Squeeze thawed grated cassava firmly in a clean kitchen towel to remove as much moisture as possible.
In a large bowl, combine the drained cassava, grated coconut, condensed milk, coconut milk, beaten eggs, sugar, melted butter, almond extract, vanilla, nutmeg, and salt. Mix thoroughly until uniform.
Pour the mixture into the prepared baking dish and spread evenly, smoothing the top.
Bake 55–65 minutes until the top is deep golden brown and the center is set (a toothpick should come out clean or slightly moist but not wet).
Cool in the pan at least 30 minutes—the cake firms as it cools. Cut into squares and serve at room temperature.

SVK.description: Slovakia's national pride. Small, soft potato dumplings (halušky) are tossed with Bryndza (a pungent fermented sheep cheese) and topped with crispy smoked bacon fat. It is rich, tangy, and filling.
ingredients: 1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour (195 g), plus more as needed
6 oz bryndza (sheep cheese) (170 g) (sub: feta + a splash of milk)
2 tbsp bacon fat (from rendering) or butter (optional)
steps: Grate potatoes finely; squeeze out excess liquid.
Mix grated potato with flour and salt to make a thick, sticky batter (add flour a tablespoon at a time if too loose).
Bring a pot of salted water to a simmer.
Press batter through a spaetzle maker/colander or cut small pieces off a board into the water.
Cook until dumplings float, then 1–2 minutes more; drain.
Meanwhile render diced bacon until crisp; reserve some fat.
Toss hot dumplings with bryndza (and a spoonful of bacon fat if needed) until creamy; top with bacon and chives.

drink.description: A Slovak highball using borovička (juniper spirit), topped with tonic and citrus.
steps: Fill a highball with ice.
Add borovička.
Top with tonic water.
Stir gently and garnish with lime.

dessert.description: Bratislava crescents: crescent-shaped pastries filled with ground walnuts and poppy seeds. Bratislava's protected regional specialty—these elegant, crescent-shaped rolls have been baked in the Slovak capital since the 18th century, when they graced the tables of Hungarian nobility and Bratislava's thriving German-speaking burgher class. The delicate yeast dough yields to a thick, aromatic filling of ground walnuts or poppy seeds sweetened with honey, and each rožok emerges from the oven with a golden sheen and a fragrance that perfumes the entire street.
ingredients: 1 egg beaten with 1 tbsp milk for egg wash
Walnut filling: 2 cups (200 g) finely ground walnuts, 1/2 cup (100 g) granulated sugar, 3 tbsp (60 g) honey, 1/4 cup (60 ml) milk, 1 tsp ground cinnamon, 1 tsp vanilla extract
Poppy seed filling: 1 1/2 cups (190 g) ground poppy seeds, 1/2 cup (100 g) granulated sugar, 3 tbsp (60 g) honey, 1/4 cup (60 ml) milk, zest of 1 lemon, 1 tsp vanilla extract
steps: Dissolve yeast and a pinch of sugar in lukewarm milk. Let stand 5–10 minutes until frothy.

In a large bowl, combine flour, sugar, and salt. Add softened butter, egg yolks, lemon zest, and the yeast mixture. Knead 8–10 minutes until a smooth, supple dough forms. Cover and let rise 1 hour until doubled.

For walnut filling: heat milk with honey and sugar until dissolved. Stir in ground walnuts, cinnamon, and vanilla. Cool. For poppy seed filling: same method with poppy seeds, sugar, honey, milk, lemon zest, and vanilla.
Punch down dough and divide into 16 equal pieces. Roll each piece into a thin oval (about 4x6 inches / 10x15 cm).
Place a line of filling along one long edge. Roll up tightly, then curve gently into a crescent shape. Place seam-side down on a parchment-lined baking sheet.
Cover and let rise 20 minutes. Brush with egg wash.
Bake at 350°F (175°C) for 18–22 minutes until deep golden brown. Cool on a wire rack.

Bratislavsky.description: Crispy, golden potato pancakes sizzling on a cast-iron griddle at a Bratislava market stall — the aroma of grated potato, garlic, and marjoram drifting through the Old Town. These lacy-edged beauties are pressed thin and fried until shatteringly crisp, then crowned with a cool dollop of sour cream and wisps of smoky meat. A street-food staple of the Slovak capital that turns the humblest tuber into something irresistible.
ingredients: 2 lbs (900 g) russet potatoes, peeled and finely grated
Vegetable oil or lard for frying (about 1/2 cup / 120 ml)
3 oz (85 g) smoked pork belly or slanina, sliced into thin strips
1/2 cup (120 ml) sour cream, for serving
steps: Squeeze grated potatoes in a clean kitchen towel, wringing out as much moisture as possible. Transfer to a large bowl.
Add grated onion, garlic, egg, flour, marjoram, salt, pepper, and paprika. Mix until a cohesive batter forms.
In a small skillet, render the smoked pork belly strips over medium heat until golden and crisp, about 5–6 minutes. Drain on paper towels and set aside.
Heat a generous layer of oil (about 1/8 inch / 3 mm) in a large heavy skillet over medium-high heat until shimmering.
Drop heaping spoonfuls of batter into the oil and press flat with the back of a spatula to about 1/3 inch (8 mm) thick.
Fry until deep golden and crisp on the bottom, about 3–4 minutes, then flip and fry 2–3 minutes more. Drain on a wire rack.
Serve hot, topped with sour cream, crispy pork belly strips, and a scattering of chives.

drink.description: A bracing cocktail built around Slovakia's revered slivovica — fiery plum brandy distilled in copper pots from ripe Bratislava-region damsons. The raw intensity of the spirit is tempered by bright lemon juice and the floral sweetness of acacia honey, shaken until ice-cold and silky. A sophisticated nod to Bratislava's café culture and centuries of plum orchards.
ingredients: 1/2 oz (15 ml) acacia honey syrup (1:1 honey dissolved in warm water)
Garnish: thin lemon wheel and a brandied plum on a pick
steps: Combine slivovica, lemon juice, honey syrup, and egg white (if using) in a cocktail shaker.
Dry-shake vigorously without ice for 15 seconds to emulsify the egg white.
Add a handful of ice and shake hard for another 15 seconds until well chilled.
Double-strain into a chilled coupe glass.
Garnish with a lemon wheel and brandied plum.

dessert.description: A PGI-protected treasure of Bratislava dating to the 17th century — crescent-shaped rolls of delicate yeast dough wrapped around a fragrant walnut-cinnamon filling. The pastry is thin and flaky, the interior dense with ground walnuts, sugar, butter, and warm spice. Once baked to a burnished gold, each rožok shatters gently at the bite, giving way to a moist, nutty heart. A pastry that has survived empires and remains Bratislava's most iconic sweet.
ingredients: Walnut-Cinnamon Crescent Dough (see Chef's Essentials below)
1 egg yolk, beaten with 1 tbsp milk (egg wash)
1/2 cup (115 g) unsalted butter, cold, cubed
steps: Whisk flour, sugar, yeast, and salt together. Cut in cold butter until pea-sized pieces remain.
Add lukewarm milk, egg yolks, vanilla, and lemon zest. Mix until a soft, slightly sticky dough forms.
Knead briefly on a floured surface, about 2 minutes — do not overwork.
Wrap in plastic and refrigerate at least 1 hour or overnight.
Combine ground walnuts, sugar, and cinnamon in a bowl.
Stir in melted butter, milk, and vanilla until a moist, spreadable paste forms.
Set aside until ready to fill.
Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C). Line baking sheets with parchment.
Roll chilled dough on a floured surface into a large circle about 1/8 inch (3 mm) thick. Cut into triangles (like croissant shapes).
Spread a thin layer of walnut-cinnamon filling across each triangle.
Roll each triangle from the wide end toward the point, curving the ends inward to form a crescent.
Place on prepared sheets, brush with egg wash.
Bake 14–18 minutes until deep golden brown.
Cool on a wire rack and dust lightly with powdered sugar before serving.

Trnavsky.description: The quintessential Slovak Christmas Eve soup and the crown jewel of Trnava's culinary tradition. A deeply savory cauldron of tangy sauerkraut, smoky kielbasa, earthy dried mushrooms, and a silken swirl of sour cream — simmered low and slow until the flavors meld into something almost spiritual. Every household in the Trnava region guards a family recipe, but the soul remains the same: sauerkraut braised to tenderness, punctuated by bursts of smoky pork and the forest-floor perfume of reconstituted porcini.
ingredients: 1 lb (450 g) sauerkraut, drained and roughly chopped
8 oz (225 g) smoked Slovak kielbasa (klobása), sliced into 1/4-inch (6 mm) rounds
4 oz (115 g) smoked pork ribs or smoked pork neck
1 oz (30 g) dried porcini mushrooms, soaked in 1 cup (240 ml) warm water for 30 minutes
2 tbsp (30 ml) vegetable oil or lard
6 cups (1.4 L) water or pork stock
2 medium waxy potatoes, peeled and diced into 1/2-inch (1.3 cm) cubes
steps: Drain soaked mushrooms, reserving the soaking liquid. Chop mushrooms finely.
Heat oil in a large pot over medium heat. Sauté onion until translucent, about 5 minutes. Add garlic and cook 30 seconds.
Stir in paprika and caraway seeds, cooking 30 seconds until fragrant.
Add sauerkraut and stir to coat. Cook 5 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Add smoked ribs, kielbasa rounds, chopped mushrooms, mushroom soaking liquid (strain through a sieve), bay leaf, pepper, and water.
Bring to a boil, then reduce to a gentle simmer. Cook partially covered for 45 minutes.
Add diced potatoes and simmer another 20 minutes until potatoes are tender and the smoked meat is falling-apart soft. Remove bones if using ribs.
Whisk sour cream with flour until smooth, then stir into the soup. Simmer 5 minutes more — do not boil vigorously.
Taste and adjust salt. Ladle into bowls and garnish with fresh dill.

drink.description: A crisp, effervescent ode to the Small Carpathian wine region that unfurls across the hills around Trnava. Locally pressed white wine — typically a bright Veltlínske Zelené or Rizling Vlašský — is lengthened with chilled soda water and served in a tall glass clinking with ice. Light, aromatic, and perfectly suited to warm summer afternoons in Trnava's baroque town square.
ingredients: 4 oz (120 ml) chilled dry Slovak white wine (Veltlínske Zelené or similar)
Garnish: thin slice of green apple or a sprig of fresh mint
steps: Fill a large wine glass or tall glass with ice cubes.
Pour in the chilled white wine.
Top with soda water and stir gently once.
Garnish with a green apple slice or mint sprig and serve immediately.

dessert.description: The mesmerizing chimney cake — a spiral of sweet yeast dough wrapped around a wooden spit, slowly rotated over glowing coals until blistered and golden, then rolled through a fragrant mixture of cinnamon, crushed walnuts, and sugar while still hot. The exterior crackles, the interior stays pillowy and warm, and the scent carries across entire market squares. A Carpathian tradition with deep roots in Trnava's festival culture.

steps: Whisk flour, yeast, sugar, and salt in a large bowl.
Add lukewarm milk, egg yolks, softened butter, vanilla, and lemon zest. Mix until a soft dough forms.
Knead on a lightly floured surface for 8–10 minutes until smooth and elastic.
Place in an oiled bowl, cover, and let rise in a warm spot for 1–1.5 hours until doubled.
Punch down risen dough. Divide into 6–8 equal portions. Roll each into a long rope about 1/2 inch (1.3 cm) thick and 24 inches (60 cm) long.
Wrap each rope in a spiral around a greased trdelník spit (or wrap around greased wooden dowels or rolled aluminum foil cylinders).
Mix sugar, cinnamon, and walnuts on a wide plate.
If grilling: Rotate slowly over medium coals for 8–12 minutes until golden and blistered. If baking: Bake at 400°F (200°C) for 15–18 minutes, rotating halfway.
Immediately brush with melted butter and roll in the cinnamon-walnut-sugar mixture while still hot.
Slide off the spit and serve warm — tear apart and eat with your hands.

Trenciansky.description: Trenčín's beloved breaded pork schnitzel — a thick boneless cutlet pounded paper-thin with a mallet, dredged through seasoned flour, dipped in beaten egg, and coated in fine golden breadcrumbs before plunging into hot oil. The result is a shatteringly crisp shell concealing juicy, tender pork within. Served alongside a creamy, tangy Slovak potato salad studded with pickles and onion, it is the embodiment of Central Slovak comfort.
ingredients: 4 boneless pork loin cutlets, about 5 oz (140 g) each
1 cup (130 g) all-purpose flour, seasoned with salt and pepper
Vegetable oil or lard for frying (about 1 cup / 240 ml)
1.5 lbs (680 g) waxy potatoes, boiled, peeled, and diced
Salt and white pepper to taste
steps: Prepare potato salad: In a large bowl, gently fold together diced potatoes, mayonnaise, sour cream, mustard, pickle, onion, and vinegar. Season with salt and white pepper. Chill while preparing the schnitzel.
Place each cutlet between two sheets of plastic wrap. Pound with a meat mallet until uniformly thin, about 1/4 inch (6 mm) thick.
Season both sides of the pounded cutlets with salt and pepper.
Set up a breading station: flour in one shallow dish, beaten eggs in a second, breadcrumbs in a third.
Dredge each cutlet in flour, shaking off excess. Dip in egg, letting excess drip off. Press firmly into breadcrumbs, coating evenly on both sides.
Heat oil in a large heavy skillet over medium-high heat until it reaches 340°F (170°C). The oil should be deep enough to come halfway up the cutlet.
Fry each schnitzel 3–4 minutes per side until deep golden brown and cooked through. Drain on a wire rack.
Serve immediately with lemon wedges and a generous scoop of potato salad, garnished with parsley.

drink.description: A sparkling, aromatic cocktail blending Slovakia's signature juniper spirit — borovička — with the delicate floral sweetness of elderflower cordial and bright soda. Born in the foothills of the Biele Karpaty mountains where juniper and elderflower both grow wild, this effervescent highball captures the botanical soul of the Trenčín region in every sip.
ingredients: 1 oz (30 ml) elderflower cordial or St-Germain
Garnish: sprig of fresh elderflower or a lemon twist
steps: Fill a highball glass with ice.
Pour in borovička, elderflower cordial, and lemon juice.
Top with soda water and stir gently to combine.
Garnish with an elderflower sprig or lemon twist.

dessert.description: Cloud-soft steamed yeast dumplings — billowy pillows of dough concealing a molten core of tangy plum jam (slivkový lekvár). Once steamed until puffed and glistening, they are tumbled onto a plate, showered with a blizzard of ground poppy seeds and sugar, and drenched in nutty melted butter. A rustic Trenčín favorite that blurs the line between dumpling and dessert.
ingredients: Steamed Dumpling Dough (see Chef's Essentials below)
1/2 cup (160 g) thick plum jam (slivkový lekvár or povidla)

steps: Combine flour, yeast, sugar, and salt in a bowl.
Add milk, egg, melted butter, and vanilla. Mix and knead for 6–8 minutes until soft and smooth.
Cover and let rise in a warm place for 45 minutes to 1 hour until doubled.
Punch down risen dough. Divide into 8 equal pieces.
Flatten each piece into a round, place a generous teaspoon of plum jam in the center, and pinch the edges tightly to seal.
Place sealed-side down on squares of parchment paper. Cover and let rise 15 minutes.
Set up a steamer. Steam dumplings in batches (do not crowd) for 12–15 minutes until puffed, glossy, and cooked through.
Mix ground poppy seeds with powdered sugar on a plate.
Place hot dumplings on a serving plate, drizzle generously with melted butter, and roll or sprinkle with the poppy seed-sugar mixture.
Serve immediately while hot and pillowy.

Nitriansky.description: Thin, supple potato flatbreads from the Nitra lowlands — the Slovak answer to a crêpe, made with a simple dough of mashed potato and flour, rolled tissue-thin, and dry-fried on a hot griddle until speckled with char. In the Nitra tradition, they are slathered with rendered duck fat and scattered with golden goose cracklings (škvarky), transforming a peasant staple into something deeply luxurious. Alternatively, they can be spread with sweet poppy seed paste and rolled up as a dessert.
ingredients: 2 lbs (900 g) russet potatoes, peeled and boiled until tender
1 1/2 cups (195 g) all-purpose flour, plus more for rolling
3 tbsp (45 ml) rendered duck fat or goose fat
4 oz (115 g) goose or duck cracklings (škvarky)
steps: Rice or mash the boiled potatoes until perfectly smooth. Let cool to warm room temperature.
Add flour, salt, and egg to the potatoes. Mix and knead gently until a smooth, pliable dough forms — not sticky, not dry.
Divide dough into 10–12 equal balls. On a well-floured surface, roll each ball into a very thin round, about 8–9 inches (20–23 cm) across.
Heat a dry cast-iron skillet or griddle over medium-high heat.
Cook each lokša for 1.5–2 minutes per side until golden spots and light char appear. Stack and keep warm under a towel.
Spread each warm lokša with duck fat, scatter with cracklings, and sprinkle with flaky salt.
Roll up or fold and serve immediately with sour cream on the side.

drink.description: A golden, lightly sweet cocktail celebrating Slovakia's own Tokaj wine region — the lesser-known but equally ancient counterpart to Hungary's Tokaji. Luscious late-harvest Tokaj wine is brightened with a squeeze of fresh lemon and stretched with sparkling soda, creating a sun-drenched aperitif that speaks of the volcanic soils and warm microclimate of the Slovak Tokaj terraces near Nitra.
ingredients: 3 oz (90 ml) Slovak Tokaj sweet white wine (Tokajský Výber or similar)
Garnish: lemon twist and a fresh grape on the rim
steps: Fill a wine glass with a few ice cubes.
Pour in the Tokaj wine and lemon juice.
Top with chilled soda water and stir gently.
Garnish with a lemon twist and a grape on the rim.

dessert.description: A magnificent poppy seed strudel from the Nitra region — gossamer-thin dough hand-stretched until you can read through it, then lavished with a luscious filling of ground poppy seeds, crushed walnuts, plump raisins, honey, and butter, rolled into a tight log, and baked until the pastry shatters and the filling turns jammy and fragrant. Sliced crosswise, each piece reveals a dense indigo swirl of poppy seed against flaky golden layers.
ingredients: Poppy Seed-Walnut Filling (see Chef's Essentials below)
3 tbsp (42 g) unsalted butter, melted (for brushing)

steps: Mound flour on a work surface, make a well. Add salt, egg, oil, water, and vinegar.
Mix and knead vigorously for 8–10 minutes until silky smooth and elastic.
Form into a ball, brush with oil, cover with a warm bowl, and rest 30 minutes.

ingredients: 1/3 cup (50 g) raisins, soaked in warm water 10 minutes and drained
steps: Warm milk and stir in ground poppy seeds. Simmer gently for 5 minutes until thick.
Remove from heat. Stir in sugar, walnuts, drained raisins, honey, melted butter, vanilla, and lemon zest.
Let cool to room temperature before using.
Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C). Line a baking sheet with parchment paper.
On a large floured cloth, gently stretch the rested strudel dough with the backs of your hands, working from the center outward until paper-thin and nearly translucent.
Brush the stretched dough with melted butter.
Spread the poppy seed-walnut filling evenly over two-thirds of the dough, leaving borders.
Using the cloth to help, roll the strudel tightly into a log, tucking the ends under.
Transfer seam-side down to the prepared baking sheet. Brush the top with more melted butter.
Bake 35–40 minutes until deep golden brown and crisp.
Cool slightly, dust with powdered sugar, and slice crosswise to serve.

Zilinsky.description: A robust, soul-warming mountain dish from the Žilina region at the foot of the Malá Fatra and Veľká Fatra ranges. Soft, pillowy halušky dumplings are tossed with long-braised sauerkraut that has mellowed into a sweet-sour tangle, crispy shards of smoked bacon (slanina), and a dusting of smoky paprika. Heartier and more rustic than classic bryndzové halušky, strapačky is the fuel of shepherds, hikers, and anyone who has spent a day in the Slovak mountains.
ingredients: 2 lbs (900 g) russet potatoes, peeled and finely grated
2 cups (260 g) all-purpose flour, plus more as needed
1 lb (450 g) sauerkraut, drained (reserve some juice)
8 oz (225 g) smoked slab bacon (slanina), diced
2 tbsp (30 ml) lard or vegetable oil
steps: Squeeze grated potatoes thoroughly in a towel. Mix with flour and salt to form a thick, sticky dumpling batter.
Bring a large pot of salted water to a gentle boil.
Press batter through a spaetzle maker or cut small irregular pieces off a wet board into the boiling water. Cook until they float plus 1–2 minutes, then drain.
Meanwhile, render diced bacon in a large skillet over medium heat until golden and crisp. Remove bacon with a slotted spoon and set aside, leaving the fat.
In the bacon fat, sauté onion until golden, about 6 minutes. Add caraway seeds and cook 30 seconds.
Add drained sauerkraut and paprika. Stir well and cook 10–12 minutes, adding sauerkraut juice to keep it moist, until the sauerkraut is tender and slightly caramelized.
Toss the drained halušky into the sauerkraut mixture. Stir over medium heat for 2–3 minutes until everything is well combined and heated through.
Serve in warm bowls, topped with crispy bacon and a generous dollop of sour cream.

drink.description: A bittersweet, herbaceous cocktail showcasing Demänovka — Slovakia's iconic herbal bitter liqueur distilled from a secret blend of 14 mountain herbs in the Liptov region, just east of Žilina. The amaro-like spirit is shaken with fresh lemon and wildflower honey, creating a complex, bracingly refreshing sour that tastes of alpine meadows and deep forest.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) Demänovka Horká (bitter herbal liqueur)
1/2 oz (15 ml) wildflower honey syrup (1:1 honey dissolved in warm water)
Garnish: lemon wheel and a sprig of fresh thyme
steps: Combine Demänovka, lemon juice, and honey syrup in a shaker with ice.
Shake vigorously for 15 seconds until well chilled.
Strain into a rocks glass over a large ice cube.
Garnish with a lemon wheel and thyme sprig.

dessert.description: Sweet potato noodles — tender, elongated dumplings made from a potato dough, boiled until silky, then tumbled in a generous coating of ground poppy seeds, powdered sugar, and rivers of golden melted butter. A beloved comfort dessert across the Žilina highlands, where poppy fields dot the landscape and potatoes are a way of life. Each bite collapses softly, the nuttiness of blue-black poppy seeds melding with buttery warmth.
ingredients: 1.5 lbs (680 g) russet potatoes, peeled, boiled, and riced while hot
steps: Combine riced potatoes (still warm), flour, egg, and salt. Knead gently into a smooth, soft dough — do not overwork.
Divide dough into portions. Roll each portion into a rope about 1/2 inch (1.3 cm) thick on a lightly floured surface.
Cut ropes into 1.5-inch (4 cm) pieces. Optionally roll each piece against the tines of a fork for texture.
Boil in salted water until they float, then 1–2 minutes more. Drain gently.
Mix ground poppy seeds with powdered sugar.
Melt butter in a pan. Toss drained šúlance in the melted butter.
Transfer to a serving plate and shower with the poppy seed-sugar mixture. Serve warm.

Banskobystricky.description: A thick, dark, deeply aromatic goulash from the heart of Central Slovakia — distinct from its Hungarian cousin in its heavier use of marjoram, its darker paprika-stained broth, and its thicker, stew-like consistency. Chunks of well-marbled beef are slow-braised with a mountain of sliced onions, generous sweet paprika, caraway, garlic, and dried marjoram until the meat surrenders completely and the sauce reduces to a velvety, rust-colored gravy. Served over pillowy bread dumplings (knedľa) that soak up every drop.
ingredients: 2 lbs (900 g) beef chuck, cut into 1.5-inch (4 cm) cubes
3 large yellow onions, halved and thinly sliced
3 tbsp (45 ml) lard or vegetable oil
steps: Prepare bread dumplings: Mix flour, yeast, and salt. Add egg and milk; knead into a smooth dough. Fold in bread cubes. Shape into 2 logs about 3 inches (7.5 cm) in diameter, wrap tightly in plastic wrap, then in foil. Steam or boil in simmering water for 25–30 minutes. Unwrap and let cool slightly before slicing into 1/2-inch (1.3 cm) rounds.
Pat beef cubes dry with paper towels. Season with salt and pepper.
Heat lard in a heavy Dutch oven over medium-high heat. Brown beef in batches, getting deep color on all sides. Remove and set aside.
Reduce heat to medium. Add sliced onions to the pot and cook, stirring occasionally, for 12–15 minutes until deeply golden and soft.
Add garlic, both paprikas, caraway, and marjoram. Stir for 30 seconds until fragrant.
Stir in tomato paste, then return the beef and any juices to the pot.
Add stock, water, and bay leaf. Bring to a boil, then reduce to a low simmer. Cover and cook 1.5–2 hours, stirring occasionally.
