Add diced bell pepper and tomato. Continue simmering uncovered for 30 minutes until the beef is fork-tender and the sauce is thick and dark.
Taste and adjust seasoning. Serve ladled over sliced bread dumplings.

drink.description: A warming, soul-fortifying cocktail built around Tatranský Čaj (Tatra Tea) — Slovakia's legendary herbal tea liqueur that ranges from a gentle 22% to a ferocious 72% ABV. For this hot cocktail, the robust 52% variant is stirred into steaming water with fresh lemon and dark forest honey, releasing waves of alpine herbs, pine, and spice. A drink born for cold Central Slovak winters and long evenings by the fire.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) Tatranský Čaj (Tatra Tea, 52% Original)
6 oz (180 ml) hot water (just off the boil)
Garnish: lemon slice and a cinnamon stick
steps: Warm a heatproof glass or mug.
Add the honey and lemon juice to the glass.
Pour in the hot water and stir until the honey dissolves.
Add the Tatranský Čaj and stir gently.
Garnish with a lemon slice and cinnamon stick. Serve immediately while hot.

dessert.description: A magnificent layered Christmas Eve cake from Central Slovakia — the edible soul of Slovak Štedrý Večer (Generous Evening). Thin sheets of pastry dough are alternated with four traditional fillings — ground walnuts, ground poppy seeds, grated apple, and sweetened tvaroh (cottage cheese) — creating a towering, striped celebration cake. Each layer tells a story: walnuts for prosperity, poppy seeds for peaceful sleep, apples for health, and tvaroh for abundance. Baked until golden and left to rest so the layers meld into a moist, fragrant whole.
ingredients: Štedrák Pastry Layers (see Chef's Essentials below)
Poppy Seed Filling (see Chef's Essentials below)
3 tbsp (42 g) unsalted butter, melted (for brushing layers)

steps: Mix flour, salt, and sugar. Add water, oil, and egg. Knead until smooth and elastic, about 5 minutes.
Divide into 5 equal portions. Cover and rest 30 minutes.
Roll each portion very thin to fit your baking pan.
Mix all ingredients until a moist, spreadable paste forms.
Warm milk with poppy seeds and sugar over low heat for 3 minutes. Stir in honey. Cool.

ingredients: 3 medium tart apples, peeled and coarsely grated
steps: Toss grated apple with sugar, cinnamon, and lemon juice. Let stand 10 minutes and squeeze out excess juice.

ingredients: 1 cup (250 g) tvaroh or dry-curd farmer's cheese
steps: Mix tvaroh with sugar, egg yolk, lemon zest, and vanilla until smooth.
Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Grease a 9x13-inch (23x33 cm) baking pan.
Place the first thin pastry layer in the pan. Brush with melted butter. Spread the walnut filling evenly.
Add the second pastry layer, brush with butter. Spread the poppy seed filling.
Add the third pastry layer, brush with butter. Spread the apple filling.
Add the fourth pastry layer, brush with butter. Spread the tvaroh filling.
Top with the fifth and final pastry layer. Brush the top with melted butter.
Bake 35–40 minutes until the top is golden brown and the pastry is crisp.
Let cool completely — the flavors improve after resting several hours or overnight. Dust with powdered sugar and cut into squares.

Presovsky.description: Eastern Slovakia's soul food — plump half-moon dumplings of tender potato dough enveloping a tangy filling of mashed potato blended with bryndza sheep cheese. Boiled until they float, then smothered with caramelized onions sizzling in butter and crowned with cool sour cream. These are the pirohy of the Šariš region around Prešov, where bryndza runs through the culinary bloodstream and every babička has her own dough technique. Each bite is a meditation on simplicity: soft dough, sharp cheese, sweet onion, and cream.
ingredients: 2 large yellow onions, halved and thinly sliced
1/2 cup (120 ml) sour cream, for serving

steps: Mound flour on a work surface, make a well. Add salt, egg, sour cream, and most of the water.
Mix from the center outward, adding remaining water as needed, until a soft, pliable dough forms.
Knead for 5–6 minutes until smooth and elastic. Cover with a damp towel and rest 30 minutes.

ingredients: 1 lb (450 g) russet potatoes, peeled, boiled, and mashed smooth
5 oz (140 g) bryndza sheep cheese (sub: feta blended with a splash of cream)
steps: While potatoes are still warm, mix in bryndza until evenly combined.
Season with pepper and salt (careful — bryndza is salty). Let cool to room temperature.
Roll out rested dough on a floured surface to about 1/8 inch (3 mm) thick.
Cut rounds using a 3-inch (7.5 cm) cutter or glass.
Place a generous teaspoon of bryndza-potato filling on each round. Fold in half and press edges firmly to seal, crimping with a fork.
Bring a large pot of salted water to a gentle boil. Cook pirohy in batches — drop in carefully and stir once to prevent sticking. They are done 2–3 minutes after they float.
Meanwhile, melt butter in a skillet over medium heat. Add sliced onions and cook slowly for 15–20 minutes, stirring occasionally, until deeply golden and caramelized.
Drain pirohy gently and transfer to a warm serving platter.
Spoon caramelized onions and butter over the pirohy. Add generous dollops of sour cream and scatter with chives.
Serve immediately.

drink.description: No cocktail — just the pure, fiery essence of Eastern Slovakia's plum orchards. Aged slivovica from the Šariš region is poured at room temperature into a small tulip glass, allowing the deep stone-fruit aroma, hints of almond, and the warming burn of double-distilled plum spirit to unfold at their own pace. A drink of ritual and pride, sipped slowly, often after a meal, with respect and a quiet toast: Na zdravie.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) aged slivovica (Slovak plum brandy), room temperature
Garnish: none — let the spirit speak
steps: Pour aged slivovica into a small tulip glass or stemmed shot glass at room temperature.
Hold the glass and warm it in your palm for a moment, allowing the aromatics to open.
Nose the spirit first — ripe plum, almond, orchard honey.
Sip slowly, letting it coat the palate. Na zdravie.

dessert.description: Pillowy, golden yeasted doughnuts from Eastern Slovakia — fried until bronzed and weightless, split open to reveal a generous heart of thick plum lekvar jam, and blanketed in a snowfall of powdered sugar. These Prešov pampúšky are simpler and more rustic than Viennese Krapfen, with a denser, breadier crumb that absorbs the tangy plum filling perfectly. A Sunday-morning tradition and festival favorite across the Šariš region.
ingredients: 1 cup (320 g) thick plum lekvar (plum butter/jam)
Vegetable oil for deep frying (about 4 cups / 960 ml)
1/2 cup (60 g) powdered sugar for dusting

steps: Combine flour, yeast, sugar, and salt in a large bowl.
Add milk, egg yolks, softened butter, vanilla, lemon zest, and rum (if using).
Knead 10 minutes until very smooth, elastic, and slightly tacky.
Cover and let rise in a warm place for 1–1.5 hours until doubled.
Punch down risen dough. Roll out on a floured surface to 1/2-inch (1.3 cm) thickness.
Cut rounds with a 3-inch (7.5 cm) cutter. Place a teaspoon of plum lekvar on half the rounds.
Top with remaining rounds and press edges firmly to seal. Alternatively, form balls and fill after frying using a piping bag.
Place on a floured tray, cover, and let rise 20–30 minutes until puffy.
Heat oil to 340°F (170°C) in a deep pot. Fry pampúšky in batches, 2–3 minutes per side, until deep golden brown.
Drain on a wire rack and dust generously with powdered sugar while still warm.
Serve fresh — they are best eaten within hours of frying.

Kosicky.description: Košice's everyday classic — thin strips of pork braised low and slow with a heap of sliced onions, generous paprika, ripe tomato, and green pepper until the sauce reduces to a thick, velvety, brick-red gravy that clings to every strand of meat. Tokáň is East Slovakia's answer to a stew, less soupy than goulash, more intensely flavored, and traditionally spooned over halušky dumplings or thick slices of bread dumplings. It is the kind of dish that simmers on the back burner all Sunday morning, filling the entire house with the perfume of paprika and onion.
ingredients: 2 lbs (900 g) boneless pork shoulder, sliced into thin 2-inch (5 cm) strips
3 large yellow onions, halved and thinly sliced
3 tbsp (45 ml) lard or vegetable oil
1 large ripe tomato, diced (or 1/2 cup / 120 ml crushed canned tomatoes)
1 large green bell pepper, seeded and diced
1/2 cup (120 ml) water or pork stock
For serving: cooked halušky or sliced bread dumplings
steps: Pat pork strips dry and season with salt and pepper.
Heat lard in a large heavy-bottomed pot or Dutch oven over medium-high heat. Brown pork strips in batches until golden on all sides. Remove and set aside.
Reduce heat to medium. Add sliced onions to the pot and cook, stirring occasionally, for 12–15 minutes until deeply golden and jammy.
Add garlic, both paprikas, caraway, and marjoram. Stir for 30 seconds until fragrant — do not let the paprika burn.
Return pork and accumulated juices to the pot. Add diced tomato, green pepper, and water.
Bring to a simmer, then reduce heat to low. Cover and braise gently for 1–1.5 hours, stirring occasionally, until the pork is very tender and the sauce is thick and concentrated.
If the sauce is too thin, uncover and simmer until reduced to the desired consistency — it should coat the meat thickly.
Taste and adjust seasoning. Serve hot over halušky or bread dumplings.

drink.description: A sweet, aromatic cocktail marrying two pillars of Slovak spirits — medovina (honey wine, the ancient mead of the Carpathians) and slivovica (plum brandy). The honeyed warmth and floral complexity of medovina is sharpened with fresh lemon juice and bolstered by the fire of slivovica, then served over ice for a refreshing yet potent libation. A drink that bridges medieval taverns and modern cocktail bars, straight from the heart of Košice.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) medovina (Slovak honey wine / mead)
1/2 oz (15 ml) simple syrup (optional, adjust to taste)
Garnish: lemon wheel and a drizzle of honey on the rim
steps: Combine medovina, slivovica, lemon juice, and simple syrup (if using) in a shaker with ice.
Shake vigorously for 15 seconds.
Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice.
Drizzle a thin line of honey over the rim and garnish with a lemon wheel.

dessert.description: A dense, moist walnut cake from Košice — the kind of cake that has graced East Slovak celebration tables for generations. Finely ground walnuts replace most of the flour, yielding a crumb that is rich, nutty, and almost fudgy. A layer of bright apricot jam is spread across the top before the whole cake is cloaked in a glossy dark chocolate glaze that cracks gently when sliced. The trifecta of walnut, apricot, and chocolate is a classic Central European combination, perfected in Košice kitchens.
ingredients: 1/2 cup (160 g) apricot jam, warmed and strained
4 oz (115 g) dark chocolate (70%), finely chopped
steps: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Grease and line a 9-inch (23 cm) round cake pan with parchment.
Whisk together ground walnuts, flour, baking powder, and salt.
Beat egg yolks with sugar until thick and pale, about 3 minutes. Stir in vanilla and orange zest.
In a separate clean bowl, whip egg whites to stiff peaks.
Fold the walnut-flour mixture into the yolk mixture. Gently fold in the whipped egg whites in three additions — do not deflate.
Pour into the prepared pan and smooth the top. Bake 30–35 minutes until a toothpick comes out with moist crumbs. Cool in pan 10 minutes, then turn out onto a rack to cool completely.
Spread the warm, strained apricot jam evenly over the top of the cooled cake.
Make the glaze: Heat cream until just simmering. Pour over chopped chocolate and butter in a bowl. Let sit 1 minute, then stir until glossy and smooth.
Pour the chocolate glaze over the apricot-topped cake, letting it drip down the sides. Let set at room temperature for 30 minutes before slicing.

SVN.description: Slovenia's rolled dumplings. A thin dough is spread with a filling (savory cottage cheese or sweet walnut), rolled up, and boiled or baked. It is a versatile dish served as a side or dessert.
ingredients: To finish: 3 tbsp butter (42 g) + toasted breadcrumbs (optional)
1/2 cup warm water (120 ml), plus as needed
steps: Mix flour and salt; add egg, oil, and water and knead until smooth. Cover and rest 30 minutes.

ingredients: 2 cups farmer cheese/cottage cheese, well-drained (450 g)
salt to taste; optional chopped herbs
steps: Combine cheese, egg, sour cream, melted butter, and salt (add herbs if using).
Roll dough very thin into a rectangle. Spread filling evenly, leaving a border.
Roll up tightly (like a jelly roll) and wrap in a clean cloth or plastic wrap suitable for boiling.
Simmer gently in water 25–30 minutes (do not hard-boil).
Unwrap, slice, and drizzle with melted butter; optionally top with toasted breadcrumbs.

drink.description: A light spritz using Slovenian brandy with local white wine and sparkling water—served cold with citrus.
steps: Fill a wine glass with ice.
Add brandy and white wine.
Top with sparkling water and stir once gently.
Garnish with an orange slice and serve.

dessert.description: Slovenian rolled nut bread: yeasted dough spread with a ground walnut filling, rolled into a spiral, and baked in a bundt pan. Slovenia's national cake, served at Christmas and Easter—no Slovenian holiday table is complete without this magnificent swirled bread. When sliced, potica reveals a hypnotic spiral of dark walnut filling against pale dough, a pattern that has graced Slovenian homes for centuries. The filling is rich with honey, butter, and rum-soaked walnuts, while the tender brioche-like dough provides a perfect vessel.
ingredients: 1 egg beaten with 1 tbsp milk for egg wash
steps: Dissolve yeast and a pinch of sugar in lukewarm milk. Let stand 5–10 minutes until frothy.
Combine flour, sugar, and salt. Add melted butter, egg yolks, lemon zest, and yeast mixture. Knead 10 minutes until smooth and elastic. Cover and let rise 1 hour until doubled.

For the filling: heat 1/3 cup milk with butter and honey until butter melts. Pour over ground walnuts and mix well. Stir in rum, vanilla, and cinnamon. Let cool slightly, then fold in lightly whisked egg whites.
Roll dough on a floured cloth into a very large, thin rectangle (about 24x18 inches / 60x45 cm). Spread walnut filling evenly to the edges.
Using the cloth to help, roll up tightly from the long side into a log. Carefully coil the log into a well-greased bundt pan, seam-side up.
Cover and let rise 30 minutes. Brush the top with egg wash.
Bake at 325°F (165°C) for 50–60 minutes until deep golden and a skewer comes out clean. If browning too fast, tent loosely with foil.
Cool in the pan 15 minutes, then invert onto a rack. Cool completely before slicing to reveal the spiral.

SWE.description: More than just furniture store food. These small, tender meatballs are a staple of Swedish home cooking. The secret is the blend of beef and pork, the use of allspice, and the essential accompaniment of tart lingonberry jam to cut the richness.
ingredients: 1/2 cup Breadcrumbs soaked in 1/2 cup Milk
Sauce: Butter, Flour, Beef Broth, Heavy Cream, Soy Sauce
steps: Mix meat, soaked breadcrumbs, onion, egg, salt, pepper, and allspice. Mix until smooth.
Roll into small balls (smaller than Italian meatballs).
Fry in butter until browned on all sides and cooked through. Remove.
Sauce: In the same pan, melt butter, whisk in flour. Add broth and cream. Simmer until thick.
Return meatballs to sauce.
Serve with mashed potatoes and lingonberry jam.

drink.description: Swedish glögg: mulled wine steeped with spices and citrus, served hot with raisins and blanched almonds.
ingredients: 1/2 cup port wine (120 ml) (optional but traditional in many versions)
Optional: 1/2 cup vodka or aquavit (120 ml)
steps: Warm water and sugar with orange zest/peel and spices until sugar dissolves.
Add red wine (and port if using) and heat gently until steaming (do not boil).
Cover and steep 20–30 minutes off heat.
Stir in raisins and almonds.
Add vodka/aquavit off heat if using.
Serve hot, including a spoonful of raisins/almonds in each mug.

dessert.description: Swedish Princess Cake: a dome-shaped masterpiece of layers of light sponge, pastry cream, and billowing whipped cream, all draped in a sheet of pale green marzipan. Every Swedish bakery's showpiece—invented in the 1930s by Jenny Åkerström, cooking teacher to the Swedish princesses, this cake is so beloved that Sweden celebrates an entire Princess Cake Week each September. The pale green dome, dusted with powdered sugar and crowned with a pink marzipan rose, is one of Scandinavia's most recognizable desserts.
ingredients: Pastry cream — vaniljkräm (see Chef's Essentials below)
12 oz (340 g) green-tinted marzipan (or white marzipan with green food coloring)

steps: Whisk egg yolks, sugar, and cornstarch together in a bowl until pale.
Heat milk in a saucepan until just simmering. Slowly pour hot milk into the yolk mixture, whisking constantly.
Return to the saucepan and cook over medium heat, stirring continuously, until the cream thickens and comes to a boil. Cook 1 minute more.
Remove from heat, stir in vanilla and butter. Press plastic wrap directly onto the surface to prevent a skin. Refrigerate until completely cold.
Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Grease and flour a 9-inch (23 cm) round cake pan.
Beat eggs and sugar with an electric mixer 8–10 minutes until very thick, pale, and tripled in volume.
Sift flour, cornstarch, baking powder, and salt together. Gently fold into the egg mixture in three additions.
Pour into the prepared pan. Bake 25–30 minutes until golden and springy. Cool completely, then slice horizontally into 3 even layers.
Whip heavy cream with powdered sugar and vanilla to stiff peaks.

Place the bottom sponge layer on a serving plate. Spread pastry cream evenly. Add the middle sponge layer. Mound whipped cream on top in a generous dome shape, using the third sponge layer pressed gently on top to create the dome structure. Shape additional whipped cream over and around the dome to create a smooth, rounded surface.

Roll out green marzipan on a surface dusted with powdered sugar into a circle large enough to drape over the entire dome. Carefully lift and lay the marzipan over the cake, smoothing it with your hands and tucking it under the base. Trim any excess.
Dust lightly with powdered sugar and place a small pink marzipan rose on top. Refrigerate at least 2 hours before serving.

Stockholm.description: The jewel of Stockholm's dining scene, born at the legendary Operakällaren restaurant under chef Tore Wretman: golden brioche piled high with hand-peeled North Sea shrimp folded into a luxurious dill-and-lemon mayonnaise, then crowned with a glistening spoonful of vendace roe and a feathery sprig of fresh dill. Elegant, briny, and unapologetically rich—Toast Skagen is the dish that put Swedish fine dining on the world map, a celebration of Scandinavian waters distilled onto a single golden triangle of bread.
ingredients: 1/2 lb (225 g) hand-peeled small shrimp (preferably North Sea coldwater)
4 thick slices brioche bread or white bread
2 tbsp fresh dill, finely chopped, plus sprigs for garnish
4 tbsp (60 g) vendace roe or whitefish roe (löjrom or sikrom)
steps: Pat the shrimp dry with paper towels. In a bowl, fold together the mayonnaise, crème fraîche, chopped dill, lemon juice, mustard, white pepper, and a pinch of salt. Gently fold in the shrimp, taking care not to crush them.
Toast or pan-fry the brioche slices in butter until golden and crisp on both sides. Trim crusts if desired and cut diagonally.
Mound the shrimp mixture generously onto each toast.
Top each with a tablespoon of roe and a sprig of fresh dill. Serve immediately with lemon wedges.

drink.description: Swedish punsch—that amber, aromatic spirit born of 18th-century trade with the East Indies—shaken ice-cold with fresh lemon in a cocktail that bridges Stockholm's golden age and its modern bar scene. Arrack-based punsch delivers exotic spice and caramel depth, while the lemon juice cuts through with bright acidity and the simple syrup rounds the edges into silk.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) Swedish punsch (such as Carlshamns Flaggpunsch)
steps: Combine the Swedish punsch, lemon juice, and simple syrup in a cocktail shaker with ice.
Shake vigorously for 15 seconds until well-chilled.
Strain into a chilled coupe glass.
Express a lemon twist over the surface and drop it in as garnish.

dessert.description: Sweden's most iconic cake, draped in a smooth dome of pale-green marzipan: layers of airy genoise sponge filled with thick vanilla custard and pillowy whipped cream, then blanketed in hand-rolled marzipan and dusted with powdered sugar. Invented in the 1930s by Jenny Åkerström—who taught the Swedish princesses to cook—Prinsesstårta is the undisputed queen of Stockholm's konditori display cases, ordered for birthdays, name days, and any celebration worthy of its regal beauty.
ingredients: 10 oz (280 g) green marzipan (or tint natural marzipan with green food coloring)

steps: Heat the milk in a saucepan until steaming. In a bowl, whisk the egg yolks, sugar, and cornstarch until pale. Slowly pour the hot milk into the yolk mixture, whisking constantly to temper.

Return to the saucepan and cook over medium heat, stirring constantly, until the custard thickens and just begins to bubble. Remove from heat and stir in the vanilla and butter. Press plastic wrap directly onto the surface and refrigerate until completely cold.
Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Butter and flour a 9-inch (23 cm) round springform pan.

Beat the eggs and sugar with an electric mixer on high speed for 8–10 minutes until very thick, pale, and tripled in volume. Sift the flour, cornstarch, and baking powder together, then fold gently into the egg mixture in three additions, taking care not to deflate the batter.
Pour into the prepared pan and bake 25–30 minutes until golden and a toothpick comes out clean. Cool completely, then slice horizontally into 3 even layers.

Whip the heavy cream with the powdered sugar and vanilla until stiff peaks form. Spread the cold custard over the bottom cake layer. Place the second layer on top and spread a thick dome of whipped cream, building it higher in the center to create the classic rounded shape.

Place the final cake layer on top. Roll the marzipan into a thin circle large enough to drape over the entire cake. Lay the marzipan over the dome, smoothing it gently and tucking the edges under. Dust with powdered sugar and top with a fresh rose if desired.

Uppsala.description: The stolid comfort of Uppland in a single baking dish: a dense, savory casserole of finely ground meat and cubed potatoes bound with cream and milk, then baked in a deep mold until the top crisps to a deep mahogany. Upplandskubb is the kind of dish grandmothers in the cathedral city serve on dark winter evenings—unadorned and unashamed, pure fuel for the Swedish soul. Best with a sharp tang of lingonberry and a cold glass of milk on the side.
ingredients: 2 lbs (900 g) waxy potatoes, peeled and cut into 1/2-inch (1.2 cm) cubes
steps: Preheat the oven to 350°F (175°C). Butter a deep 9x13-inch (23x33 cm) baking dish or a traditional cylindrical kubb mold generously.
In a large bowl, combine the ground beef, ground pork, diced potatoes, and onion. Season with salt, white pepper, and allspice. Mix with your hands until evenly combined.
Pack the mixture firmly into the prepared dish. Pour the cream and milk evenly over the top.
Bake uncovered for 1 hour and 30 minutes until the top is deeply browned and the potatoes are completely tender when pierced with a knife.
Let rest 10 minutes. Slice and serve with lingonberry jam.

drink.description: A crisp, herbaceous sour built on caraway-scented aquavit, softened with honey syrup and brightened with fresh lemon. The egg white adds the silky foam that makes this cocktail feel as refined as an evening at one of Uppsala's storied nation pubs, where students have been raising glasses since the 17th century.
ingredients: 1/2 oz (15 ml) honey syrup (1:1 honey and warm water, stirred to dissolve)
steps: Combine the aquavit, lemon juice, honey syrup, and egg white in a cocktail shaker. Dry-shake (without ice) vigorously for 15 seconds to emulsify the egg white.
Add ice and shake hard for another 15 seconds until very cold and frothy.
Strain into a chilled coupe glass. Drop three dots of Angostura bitters onto the foam and drag a toothpick through them to create a design.

dessert.description: A golden, custardy oven pancake perfumed with precious saffron and studded with rice and almonds, baked until puffed and set, then served warm with a cascade of mixed berries and whipped cream. Originally a Gotlandic specialty, saffranspannkaka became wildly popular at Uppsala's outdoor markets and student gatherings, where the fragrance of saffron drifting from cast-iron pans is the scent of celebration.
ingredients: 1 cup (200 g) short-grain rice (such as arborio)
2 tbsp unsalted butter, for the pan
1 cup (150 g) mixed fresh berries (lingonberries, raspberries, blueberries)
steps: Cook the rice in the milk and water over low heat, stirring frequently, until thick and creamy, about 25 minutes. Stir in the crushed saffron and let cool to lukewarm.
Preheat the oven to 400°F (200°C). Butter a 10-inch (25 cm) cast-iron skillet or baking dish.
Whisk the eggs and sugar until pale. Stir in the cream, almonds, salt, and the cooled rice mixture.
Pour into the prepared pan and bake 35–40 minutes until set and golden on top.
Serve warm, topped with fresh berries and a generous spoonful of whipped cream.

Södermanland.description: Stately beef roulades from the manors of Södermanland: thin slices of beef spread with a bold layer of coarse-grain mustard, topped with slivers of onion and tangy dill pickles, then rolled tight, seared to a dark crust, and braised low and slow in a red wine-enriched stock until the meat yields to a fork. This is the kind of dish Sörmland's landed gentry served on polished oak tables—robust, deeply flavored, and impossibly tender, with the mustard and pickles cutting through the richness of the braising liquid.
ingredients: 2 lbs (900 g) beef top round, sliced into 8 thin cutlets (about 1/4 inch / 6 mm thick)
1 large onion, cut into thin slivers
4 dill pickles, cut into thin strips
steps: Pound each beef cutlet to about 1/8 inch (3 mm) thickness between sheets of plastic wrap. Season with salt and pepper.
Spread a thin layer of mustard over each cutlet. Lay onion slivers and pickle strips along the center. Roll tightly and secure with kitchen twine or toothpicks.
Heat the butter and oil in a heavy Dutch oven over medium-high heat. Sear the roulades on all sides until deeply browned, about 6 minutes total. Remove and set aside.
Sprinkle the flour into the pot and stir for 1 minute. Pour in the beef stock and red wine, scraping up all the browned bits. Bring to a simmer.
Return the roulades to the pot. Cover and braise in a 325°F (165°C) oven for 1 hour and 30 minutes until fork-tender.

Remove the roulades and discard the twine. Stir the cream into the braising liquid and simmer until thickened into a glossy sauce. Serve the roulades with the sauce, boiled potatoes, and lingonberry jam.

drink.description: A sparkling, sun-dappled spritz celebrating Södermanland's orchards: dry local apple cider lengthened with elderflower liqueur and a splash of soda, served ice-cold in a wine glass. The cider brings crisp acidity, the elderflower adds floral sweetness, and the bubbles make it dangerously easy to drink on a Sörmland summer afternoon.
ingredients: 3 oz (90 ml) dry Swedish apple cider
1 oz (30 ml) elderflower liqueur (such as St-Germain)
steps: Fill a large wine glass with ice.
Pour in the elderflower liqueur, then the dry apple cider.
Top with sparkling water and stir gently once.
Garnish with a thin apple slice and a sprig of fresh mint.

dessert.dish: Sörmlands Äppelkaka (Apple Cake with Cardamom and Vanilla Sauce)
dessert.description: The essence of a Södermanland autumn captured in a golden-crusted cake: fragrant local apples folded into a cardamom-scented batter, baked until the top crisps and the fruit melts into pockets of soft sweetness, then served warm with a pool of silky vanilla sauce. Every farmhouse kitchen in the province has its own fiercely guarded recipe, but the constants are always the same—tart apples, the haunting warmth of cardamom, and that luxurious custard sauce poured generously over each slice.
ingredients: 3 medium tart apples (such as Granny Smith), peeled, cored, and diced
steps: Preheat the oven to 350°F (175°C). Butter and flour a 9-inch (23 cm) round cake pan.
Whisk the melted butter and sugar together. Add the eggs one at a time, beating well. Sift in the flour, baking powder, cardamom, and salt and fold until just combined. Fold in the diced apples.
Pour into the prepared pan and sprinkle with demerara sugar. Bake 40–45 minutes until golden and a toothpick comes out clean.

For the vanilla sauce: heat the milk until steaming. Whisk the egg yolks and sugar until pale, then slowly pour in the hot milk while whisking constantly. Return to the pan and cook over low heat, stirring constantly, until the sauce coats the back of a spoon. Remove from heat and stir in the vanilla and cream.
Serve the warm cake with a generous pour of vanilla sauce.

Östergötland.dish: Isterband (Smoked Fermented Sausage with Creamed Potatoes)
Östergötland.description: Östergötland's beloved smoked fermented sausage—a rustic link of coarsely ground pork and barley groats, lightly fermented to develop a tangy bite, then lightly smoked over juniper and birch until the casing tightens and the flavor deepens into something uniquely Swedish. Isterband is always served the same way: sliced open and pan-fried until the edges crisp, alongside velvety creamed potatoes, sharp pickled beets, and a dollop of mustard. This is the heart of östgötsk husmanskost—unpretentious home cooking at its soul-warming best.
ingredients: 2 lbs (900 g) Yukon Gold potatoes, peeled and cut into chunks
steps: Boil the potatoes in salted water until completely tender, about 18 minutes. Drain well and return to the pot over low heat to dry for 1 minute.
Mash the potatoes with butter, then gradually stir in the warmed milk and cream until smooth and creamy. Season with white pepper and salt. Keep warm.
Score the isterband sausages with a few shallow diagonal cuts. Pan-fry in a dry skillet over medium heat for 8–10 minutes, turning frequently, until the casings are golden and slightly crisp.
Serve the sausages alongside the creamed potatoes with pickled beets, a spoonful of mustard, and a sprinkle of fresh dill.

drink.description: A bracing herbal cocktail in the tradition of Östergötland's old apothecaries—wormwood-infused aquavit stirred with dry vermouth and a whisper of lemon, then served ice-cold in a small glass. In Östergötland, no proper dinner begins without a snaps and a hearty skål.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) aquavit (wormwood-infused if available, or caraway aquavit)
steps: Combine the aquavit, dry vermouth, lemon juice, and bitters in a mixing glass with ice.
Stir for 20 seconds until well-chilled.
Strain into a chilled snaps glass or small coupe.
Express a lemon peel over the glass and drop it in.

dessert.description: The simplest and most beloved of Swedish celebration cakes: layers of tender sponge sandwiched with clouds of lightly sweetened whipped cream and sliced fresh strawberries, the whole edifice swathed in more cream and crowned with the reddest berries of the season. Gräddtårta appears at every midsummer table, every birthday, every name day in Östergötland—its beauty lies in its restraint. No fondant, no frosting, just cream, berries, and cake in perfect harmony.
ingredients: 1 lb (450 g) fresh strawberries, hulled and sliced (reserve a few whole for decoration)
steps: Preheat the oven to 350°F (175°C). Butter and flour two 9-inch (23 cm) round cake pans.
Beat the eggs and sugar on high speed for 8 minutes until very thick and pale. Sift the flour and baking powder together and fold in gently. Fold in the warm milk and melted butter.
Divide between the pans and bake 20–25 minutes until golden and springy. Cool completely, then slice each layer in half horizontally to make 4 layers.
Whip the cream with powdered sugar and vanilla to soft peaks. Spread cream and sliced strawberries between each layer. Cover the top and sides with whipped cream.
Decorate with whole strawberries. Refrigerate at least 1 hour before serving to let the layers set.

Jönköping.dish: Smålands Ostkaka (Småland Baked Fresh Cheese Cake)
Jönköping.description: Not a cheesecake in any New York sense—Smålands ostkaka is an ancient, almost mystical creation: fresh milk is curdled with rennet, the whey drained, and the curds mixed with eggs, cream, sugar, and bitter almonds, then baked in a slow oven until the surface turns a deep mottled gold and the interior sets into something between custard and fresh cheese. Served warm from the oven with a river of lingonberry jam and cold cream, ostkaka is a dish of pilgrimage in Jönköping county—every village has its own fiercely guarded recipe, hotly debated at church suppers and market stalls.
ingredients: 1/4 tsp liquid rennet (or 1 rennet tablet dissolved in 1 tbsp water)
1/2 cup (70 g) blanched almonds, finely chopped
steps: Heat the milk to 98°F (37°C) in a large heavy pot. Stir the flour into a cup of the warm milk to form a smooth slurry and return it to the pot. Stir in the rennet. Let stand undisturbed for 30 minutes until the milk sets into a firm curd.
Cut the curd into 1-inch squares with a long knife. Gently heat to 105°F (40°C), stirring very gently. Let the curds settle, then carefully ladle off as much whey as possible.
Preheat the oven to 325°F (165°C). Butter a deep round baking dish or cast-iron skillet.
Beat the eggs with the sugar, cream, almonds, almond extract, and salt. Fold gently into the drained curds. Pour into the prepared dish.
Bake 50–60 minutes until the top is deeply golden and the center is just set with a gentle wobble. Serve warm with lingonberry jam and cold cream.

drink.description: In Småland, Thursday means pea soup and punsch—a tradition as old as the Swedish Army. This warm version of the classic arrack-based spirit is gently heated with whole spices and served in small stemmed glasses, its caramel-sweet, exotic warmth cutting through the chill of Jönköping's winter fog like a lantern in the dark.
ingredients: 4 oz (120 ml) Swedish punsch (such as Carlshamns Flaggpunsch)
steps: Gently warm the punsch and hot water in a small saucepan with the cinnamon stick, cloves, and orange peel over low heat until steaming. Do not boil.
Strain into two small stemmed glasses or punch cups.
Serve immediately alongside Thursday pea soup for the full Småland experience.

dessert.description: The original gooey Swedish chocolate cake, born in the kitchens of Småland: a molten-centered, crackle-topped slab of intensely chocolatey batter that is deliberately underbaked so the center stays dense, fudgy, and almost truffle-like while the surface shatters into a thin, crisp shell. The Småländsk version is darker, richer, and more intense than its countless imitators—barely sweetened, deeply bitter from good cocoa, and always served with a cold dollop of lightly whipped cream.
steps: Preheat the oven to 350°F (175°C). Butter and lightly flour an 8-inch (20 cm) round cake pan.
Melt the butter and let it cool slightly. In a bowl, whisk the eggs and sugar until combined but not overly airy. Stir in the melted butter and vanilla.
Sift in the cocoa and flour and fold until just combined. Do not overmix. Pour into the prepared pan.
Bake for exactly 15–18 minutes. The edges should be set but the center should wobble when gently shaken. The top will have a thin crackled crust.
Cool in the pan. The center will sink slightly. Dust with powdered sugar and a pinch of flaky sea salt. Serve with whipped cream.

Kronoberg.description: A stroke of Kronoberg ingenuity born from the frozen forests of Småland: a whole joint of moose is placed in the oven still frozen solid, then roasted at an astonishingly low temperature for eight hours, during which the ice crystals inside the meat slowly melt and baste the roast from within, creating flesh so tender it falls apart at the touch of a fork. The method was invented by hunters who needed to cook meat straight from the deep freeze. The result is miraculous—rosy, impossibly juicy, and fork-tender, with a depth of wild, gamey flavor that speaks of Kronoberg's dark spruce forests.
ingredients: 3 lbs (1.4 kg) frozen moose roast (or beef bottom round, frozen solid)
steps: Preheat the oven to 175°F (80°C). Place the frozen roast directly into a roasting pan—do not thaw. Rub the exposed surfaces with salt, pepper, crushed juniper berries, and thyme. Tuck the bay leaves alongside.
Pour the stock into the bottom of the pan. Cover tightly with a lid or heavy-duty aluminum foil.
Roast for 8 hours without opening the oven. The internal temperature should reach 160°F (71°C) when done.
Remove from the oven and let rest, still covered, for 20 minutes. The meat should be incredibly tender and pull apart easily.
Slice thinly against the grain. Serve with pan juices, lingonberry jam, pickled cucumbers, and Hasselback potatoes.

drink.description: Kronoberg's forests are carpeted with lingonberries, and this vibrant G&T puts them to brilliant use: gin shaken with a house-made lingonberry syrup and strained over ice, then topped with premium tonic and garnished with a sprig of fresh thyme. The lingonberries add a tart, ruby-red depth that transforms the familiar gin and tonic into something distinctly Swedish.
ingredients: 1 oz (30 ml) lingonberry syrup (simmer 1 cup lingonberries, 1/2 cup sugar, and 1/2 cup water; strain)
A few whole lingonberries, for garnish
steps: Fill a large balloon glass or copa glass with ice.
Pour in the gin and lingonberry syrup. Stir briefly to combine.
Slowly pour the tonic water down the side of the glass. Stir once gently.
Garnish with a sprig of fresh thyme and a few lingonberries.

dessert.description: Kronoberg's pepparkaka tradition runs deeper than most—these are thinner, crisper, and more intensely spiced than the average Swedish ginger cookie. Rolled to translucent thinness, cut into hearts, stars, and pigs, and baked until they snap with an audible crack, Kronobergspepparkakor are the taste of a Småland advent: clove-heavy, ginger-sharp, and with a caramel darkness from dark syrup that sets them apart from their paler cousins elsewhere in Sweden.
ingredients: 1/2 cup (170 g) dark Swedish syrup (mörk sirap) or dark corn syrup
steps: Heat the syrup, sugar, and butter in a saucepan over medium heat, stirring until the butter melts and the sugar dissolves. Let cool to lukewarm, then beat in the egg.

Sift together the flour, baking soda, ginger, cinnamon, cloves, cardamom, pepper, and salt. Stir into the syrup mixture until a smooth dough forms. Wrap in plastic and refrigerate at least 2 hours or overnight.
Preheat the oven to 375°F (190°C). Roll the dough very thin (about 1/16 inch / 1.5 mm) on a lightly floured surface. Cut into shapes with cookie cutters.
Place on parchment-lined baking sheets. Bake 6–8 minutes until deep golden and firm. They will crisp further as they cool.
Cool completely on wire racks. Store in an airtight tin.

Kalmar.description: The pride of Kalmar county: fist-sized potato dumplings with a golden, starchy exterior yielding to a savory heart of smoked pork, onions, and allspice. Making kroppkakor is a communal act—families gather around kitchen tables to peel, boil, rice, and roll, filling each dumpling by hand and pinching the seams shut with practiced fingers. The dumplings are simmered until they float, then served swimming in brown butter with a side of lingonberry jam. In Kalmar, there is no greater comfort.
ingredients: 3 lbs (1.4 kg) starchy potatoes (such as Russet), peeled
1/2 lb (225 g) smoked pork belly or salt pork, finely diced
steps: Boil the potatoes in salted water until completely tender, about 25 minutes. Drain, return to the pot over low heat to steam dry, then rice or mash until perfectly smooth. Cool to lukewarm. Mix in the flour, egg yolk, and salt to form a smooth, pliable dough.
Make the filling: fry the diced pork in a dry skillet until the fat renders and the pork begins to crisp. Add the onion and cook until soft and golden. Season with allspice and pepper. Let cool.

Divide the dough into 12 portions. Flatten each into a disc in your palm, place a spoonful of filling in the center, and pinch the dough closed, rolling into a smooth ball. Make sure there are no cracks.
Bring a large pot of salted water to a gentle boil. Lower the dumplings in carefully. They will sink, then float after 3–4 minutes. Simmer 15 minutes after they float.
Remove with a slotted spoon. Brown the butter in a small skillet until nutty and golden. Serve the dumplings drizzled with brown butter alongside lingonberry jam and cold cream.

drink.description: A lively, effervescent cocktail from Kalmar's coast: caraway aquavit shaken with fresh lemon and a touch of sugar, then topped with sparkling water for a refreshing fizz that pairs beautifully with the richness of kroppkakor. The botanicals of the aquavit sing against the bright citrus.
steps: Shake the aquavit, lemon juice, and simple syrup with ice for 15 seconds.
Strain into a tall glass over fresh ice.
Top with sparkling water and stir gently once.
Garnish with a sprig of fresh dill.

dessert.dish: Kalmar Semlor (Cardamom Buns with Almond Paste and Cream)
dessert.description: Sweden's most anticipated pastry, devoured from Christmas to Easter but nowhere with more devotion than in Kalmar: a golden, cardamom-perfumed wheat bun, its top sliced off and the interior scooped out, filled first with a rich almond paste made from the crumbs, then topped with an extravagant mound of whipped cream, and capped with the little lid dusted in powdered sugar. Eaten with a spoon and fork, ideally while sitting in a warm kitchen as winter rages outside.
ingredients: 1 cup (240 ml) whole milk, warmed to 110°F (43°C)
2 tbsp powdered sugar, plus more for dusting
steps: Stir the yeast into the warm milk with a pinch of sugar and let stand 5 minutes until frothy. Add the remaining sugar, softened butter, cardamom, salt, and flour. Knead until smooth and elastic, about 8 minutes. Cover and let rise 1 hour until doubled.
Punch down and divide into 8 pieces. Roll each into a smooth ball and place on a parchment-lined baking sheet. Cover and let rise 30 minutes. Brush with beaten egg.
Bake at 400°F (200°C) for 12–15 minutes until golden. Cool completely.
Slice the top off each bun. Scoop out some of the interior crumb. Mash the crumbs with the almond paste and a splash of milk to form a thick paste. Spoon the almond filling back into each bun.
Whip the cream with powdered sugar until stiff. Pipe or spoon a generous mound of cream on top of each filled bun. Replace the lids at a jaunty angle and dust with powdered sugar.

Gotland.dish: Gotländsk Saffranspannkaka med Salmbärssylt (Gotland Saffron Pancake with Dewberry Jam)
Gotland.description: THE dish of Gotland—a golden, fragrant oven pancake shimmering with saffron, studded with rice and almonds, baked until puffed and custard-set. On this Baltic island, saffranspannkaka is not merely food but identity: served at every medieval week feast, Christmas market, and Sunday table, always accompanied by Gotland's own salmbärssylt—a dewberry jam of such rarity it can only be gathered on the island's windswept limestone shores. The saffron, a legacy of Gotland's medieval spice trade, turns the pancake a regal gold, while the tart, dusky jam provides perfect counterpoint.
ingredients: 1 cup (200 g) short-grain rice (such as arborio)
1/2 cup (70 g) blanched almonds, roughly chopped
2 tbsp unsalted butter, for the pan
Salmbärssylt (dewberry jam) or blackberry jam, for serving
steps: Simmer the rice in the milk and water over low heat, stirring frequently, until thick and creamy, about 25 minutes. Stir the crushed saffron into 1 tablespoon of warm cream, then stir into the rice. Cool to lukewarm.
Preheat the oven to 400°F (200°C). Generously butter a 10-inch (25 cm) cast-iron skillet or ovenproof dish.
Beat the eggs and sugar until fluffy. Stir in the cream, almonds, salt, and the cooled saffron rice.
Pour into the prepared pan and bake 35–40 minutes until set, puffed, and deeply golden.
Serve warm in generous wedges with a spoonful of dewberry or blackberry jam and a cloud of whipped cream.

drink.description: Gotland has brewed mead since the Viking age, and this modern cocktail brings the honeyed spirit into the present: golden Gotlandic mead shaken with fresh lime and muddled mint, then strained over ice and topped with sparkling water. A drink that tastes of limestone, wildflowers, and a thousand years of island history.
ingredients: 6 fresh mint leaves, plus a sprig for garnish
1/2 oz (15 ml) honey syrup (1:1 honey and warm water)
steps: Gently muddle the mint leaves with the honey syrup in a cocktail shaker—press to release oils, do not shred.
Add the mead and lime juice with ice. Shake for 10 seconds.
Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice. Top with sparkling water.
Garnish with a sprig of fresh mint.

dessert.description: A Gotlandic dream made real: a buttery, vanilla-scented base baked golden, then smothered with a topping of brown butter, sugar, and shredded coconut that bakes into a chewy, caramelized crust of outrageous richness. Drömtårta earns its name honestly—the coconut topping bronzes and crisps while the interior stays soft and tender, creating a textural contrast that haunts you long after the last crumb.
steps: Preheat the oven to 350°F (175°C). Butter and flour a 9-inch (23 cm) round cake pan.
Cream the softened butter and sugar until fluffy. Add the eggs one at a time. Sift in the flour and baking powder alternately with the milk and vanilla. Pour into the prepared pan.
Bake 25–30 minutes until just set and lightly golden.
While the cake bakes, make the topping: melt the butter in a saucepan until it foams and turns golden-brown with a nutty aroma. Stir in the sugar, coconut, milk, and vanilla.
Spread the coconut topping evenly over the partially baked cake. Return to the oven and bake another 15–20 minutes until the topping is deeply golden and caramelized. Cool in the pan before serving.

Blekinge.description: Blekinge's answer to the Kalmar kroppkakor—lighter, more delicate potato dumplings with a filling of crispy fried bacon and sweet onion rather than the heavier smoked pork of their northern neighbors. Blekinge's version is shaped smaller, boiled until they bob to the surface, and served simply with melted butter and a generous side of lingonberry compote. The lighter touch reflects Blekinge's coastal character—a province that looks south toward Denmark as much as it looks north toward the Swedish heartland.
ingredients: 2 lbs (900 g) starchy potatoes (such as Russet), peeled
6 slices (170 g) thick-cut bacon, finely diced
3 tbsp unsalted butter, melted, for serving
steps: Boil the potatoes in salted water until very tender. Drain, dry over low heat for 1 minute, then rice or mash until completely smooth. Cool to lukewarm, then work in the flour, egg yolk, and salt to form a smooth dough.
Fry the diced bacon in a skillet until crisp. Add the onion and cook until golden and soft. Season with allspice and pepper. Drain on paper towels and cool.
Divide the dough into 10–12 portions. Flatten each in your palm, add a spoonful of the bacon-onion filling, and seal into smooth balls.
Lower into gently boiling salted water. When they float (after 3–4 minutes), simmer for 12 minutes more.
Serve drizzled with melted butter alongside lingonberry compote.

drink.description: A warming winter cocktail from Blekinge's apple-growing heartland: local cider mulled with cinnamon, cloves, and fresh ginger, then spiked with a slug of aquavit and finished with a float of calvados. Sweet, spiced, and deeply autumnal—the scent alone thaws frozen fingers and fills the kitchen with the spirit of a Blekinge winter.
ingredients: 8 oz (240 ml) dry Swedish apple cider
1/2 oz (15 ml) calvados or apple brandy
steps: Warm the apple cider in a small saucepan with the cinnamon stick, cloves, ginger, and orange peel over low heat until steaming and fragrant. Do not boil.
Remove from heat and stir in the honey until dissolved. Add the aquavit.
Strain into a warmed mug. Float the calvados on top.
Garnish with the cinnamon stick and serve immediately.

dessert.dish: Blekinge Äppelsmulpaj (Apple Crumble with Oat Topping)
dessert.description: Blekinge's orchards overflow with tart apples every autumn, and this homey crumble is how they are put to their highest use: sliced apples tossed with cinnamon and a squeeze of lemon, blanketed with a crunchy, buttery oat topping, and baked until the fruit bubbles and the crumble turns a deep toasty gold. Served warm with a generous pour of vanilla custard, it is the taste of a Blekinge autumn—simple, honest, and profoundly comforting.
ingredients: 4 medium tart apples (such as Granny Smith), peeled, cored, and sliced
1/3 cup (75 g) cold unsalted butter, cut into small pieces
steps: Preheat the oven to 375°F (190°C). Toss the sliced apples with sugar, cinnamon, and lemon juice. Spread in a buttered 9-inch (23 cm) baking dish.
In a bowl, mix the flour, oats, brown sugar, and salt. Cut in the cold butter with your fingers until the mixture resembles coarse crumbs with pea-sized pieces. Scatter evenly over the apples.
Bake 35–40 minutes until the topping is deeply golden and the fruit is bubbling around the edges.

For the vanilla custard: heat the milk and cream until steaming. Whisk egg yolks, sugar, and cornstarch until smooth. Slowly pour in the hot milk, whisking constantly. Return to the pan and cook over medium-low heat, stirring, until thickened enough to coat the back of a spoon. Stir in vanilla.
Serve the warm crumble with a generous pour of vanilla custard.

Skåne.dish: Äggakaka (Skåne Thick Egg Pancake with Fried Pork)
Skåne.description: Skåne's thick, golden egg pancake—a dish of deceptive simplicity that reveals the soul of southern Swedish cooking. Beaten eggs, flour, and milk are poured into a screaming-hot buttered skillet and cooked until the bottom sets into a rich, custardy layer while the top stays barely trembling. The äggakaka is then flipped onto a plate—a moment of truth for every Skåne cook—and served immediately with crisp fried salt pork and lingonberry jam. This is not a crêpe, not an omelet, not a pancake in any other tradition: it is a distinctly Skånsk creation, thick as a finger, golden as a wheat field, and irresistibly satisfying.
ingredients: 3 tbsp unsalted butter, for the pan
1/2 lb (225 g) salt pork or thick-cut bacon, sliced
steps: Whisk the eggs in a large bowl. Sift in the flour gradually while whisking to prevent lumps. Slowly pour in the milk, whisking until the batter is smooth and the consistency of thick cream. Season with salt. Let rest 15 minutes.
Fry the salt pork or bacon slices in a separate skillet until crisp and golden. Drain and keep warm.
Heat a 10-inch (25 cm) heavy cast-iron skillet over medium-high heat. Add the butter and swirl to coat. When the butter foams, pour in the batter.

Cook without disturbing for 5–6 minutes until the bottom is set and golden. Carefully flip the äggakaka (use a plate to invert if needed) and cook another 3–4 minutes. The center should remain slightly soft and custardy.
Slide onto a warm plate. Serve immediately with the fried pork and generous spoonfuls of lingonberry jam.

drink.dish: Skåne Snaps (Cumin and Fennel Aquavit Cocktail)
drink.description: The quintessential Skåne aquavit elevated into a refined cocktail: cumin-and-fennel-infused spirit stirred with dry vermouth and a dash of orange bitters, then strained ice-cold into a small glass. In Skåne, snaps is not merely a drink but a ritual—poured between bites of pickled herring and crispbread, always accompanied by a snapsvisor drinking song belted at full volume.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) Skåne-style aquavit (cumin and fennel-infused)
steps: Combine the aquavit, vermouth, lemon juice, and orange bitters in a mixing glass with ice.
Stir for 20 seconds until very cold.
Strain into a chilled snaps glass or small coupe.
Garnish with a delicate fennel frond.

dessert.description: Skåne's legendary spit cake and one of Sweden's most spectacular culinary achievements: a towering, hollow cone of egg whites and sugar, piped in thin spiraling ribbons onto a rotating spit and dried in a low oven until the entire structure turns into an impossibly delicate, crisp, lace-like confection. Making spettekaka requires a special rotating spit, hours of patient piping, and a bone-dry oven. The result is more sculpture than dessert—shatteringly crisp, meltingly sweet, and so fragile it must be cracked open with the handle of a knife at the table. A protected regional specialty, authentic spettekaka can only be made in Skåne.
steps: Preheat the oven to 300°F (150°C). Prepare a spit cake cone mold or, for a home version, wrap an inverted ovenproof funnel or cone form in parchment and grease it lightly.
Beat the egg whites with the salt until soft peaks form. Gradually add the sugar, beating until stiff and glossy. Sift the potato starch and fold in gently along with the vanilla.
Transfer the meringue to a piping bag fitted with a small round tip. Pipe thin ribbons of meringue in a spiral pattern around the cone, building up layers gradually.
Bake 45–60 minutes, rotating occasionally, until the entire surface is pale golden, completely dry, and crisp throughout. The finished cake should be hollow and sound hollow when tapped.
Cool completely before carefully removing from the mold. Crack open at the table with the handle of a knife and serve alongside strong coffee.

Halland.description: Halland's golden coastline meets its potato-growing heartland in this comforting baked pudding: layers of thinly sliced potatoes and cold-smoked salmon, drenched in a custard of eggs, cream, and dill, then baked until the top turns a glorious burnished gold and the layers meld into a creamy, smoky, impossibly savory gratin. Laxpudding is the kind of dish Halland grandmothers slide into the oven on a Saturday afternoon, filling the kitchen with the scent of dill and smoked fish—a dish that says home in every bite.
ingredients: 2 lbs (900 g) waxy potatoes (such as Yukon Gold), peeled and thinly sliced (1/8 inch / 3 mm)
3/4 lb (340 g) cold-smoked salmon (gravlax or smoked salmon), thinly sliced
1 large onion, thinly sliced into rings
3 tbsp fresh dill, chopped, plus sprigs for garnish
2 tbsp unsalted butter, for the dish
steps: Preheat the oven to 375°F (190°C). Butter a 9x13-inch (23x33 cm) baking dish generously.
Layer half the potato slices in the dish, overlapping slightly. Top with the salmon slices and onion rings, and sprinkle with half the chopped dill. Cover with the remaining potato slices.
Whisk together the eggs, milk, cream, remaining dill, salt, and white pepper. Pour the custard evenly over the layers. Dot the top with small pieces of butter.
Bake 50–60 minutes until the top is deeply golden and the potatoes are tender when pierced with a knife.
Let rest 10 minutes. Serve warm with sour cream, lemon wedges, and fresh dill sprigs.

drink.description: Halland's lanes and hedgerows froth with elderflower every June, and this bright, fizzy Collins puts the harvest to dazzling use: London dry gin shaken with elderflower cordial and fresh lemon, poured over ice, and topped with soda until the glass fizzes like a summer afternoon in the Halland countryside. Floral, citrusy, and completely refreshing.
ingredients: 1 oz (30 ml) elderflower cordial (or elderflower liqueur)
steps: Shake the gin, elderflower cordial, and lemon juice with ice for 10 seconds.
Strain into a tall Collins glass over fresh ice.
Top with soda water and stir gently once.
Garnish with a lemon wheel and a sprig of fresh elderflower if available.

dessert.dish: Halländska Våfflor (Thin Crispy Halland Waffles with Cloudberry Cream)
dessert.description: Halland's waffles are a breed apart: thinner, crispier, and lighter than the soft heart-shaped waffles served elsewhere in Sweden. Pressed in a flat iron until golden and lace-edged, they shatter at first bite before melting on the tongue, revealing a delicate sweetness perfumed with vanilla. Served warm from the iron with a dollop of cloudberry cream—that Arctic gold of berries folded into softly whipped cream—Halländska våfflor are the essential fika treat of the Swedish west coast.
ingredients: 1/2 cup (115 g) unsalted butter, melted and cooled
steps: Whisk together the flour, sugar, and salt. Stir in the melted butter, water, cream, and vanilla until smooth. Let the batter rest 15 minutes.
Heat a waffle iron (flat Scandinavian type preferred) and brush lightly with butter. Pour a thin layer of batter and cook until golden and crisp, about 2–3 minutes.
For the cloudberry cream: whip the cream and powdered sugar to soft peaks. Gently fold in the cloudberry jam, leaving visible swirls of golden jam.
Serve the waffles immediately, warm and crisp, with a generous spoonful of cloudberry cream.

Västra Götaland.description: The undisputed king of Gothenburg street food and the single dish that defines Sweden's second city: a thick slab of white bread—toasted or fresh—spread with a slick of homemade dill mayonnaise, then piled so absurdly high with hand-peeled, sweet North Sea shrimp that the bread vanishes entirely beneath a pink mountain of shellfish. A squeeze of lemon, a crown of fresh dill, and perhaps a halved boiled egg complete the masterpiece. Räkmackan is eaten at every harbor kiosk, fish market stall, and white-tablecloth restaurant in Gothenburg—proof that the simplest ingredients, when sourced from the cold, clean waters of the Skagerrak, need almost nothing to become transcendent.
ingredients: 1 lb (450 g) hand-peeled North Sea shrimp (small, cold-water shrimp, pre-cooked)
4 large slices good-quality white bread (pain de mie or sourdough), about 1/2 inch (1.3 cm) thick

steps: Fold together the mayonnaise, chopped dill, lemon juice, Dijon mustard, sugar, and white pepper. Taste and adjust lemon or salt. Refrigerate until needed.
Lightly toast the bread slices if desired (many Gothenburgers prefer untoasted). Spread each slice generously with dill mayonnaise—a thick, even layer.

Place a butter lettuce leaf on each slice. Pile the hand-peeled shrimp as high as you dare—this is Gothenburg, and restraint is not the point. A proper räkmacka should have at least 4 oz (115 g) of shrimp per sandwich.
Nestle two egg halves alongside the shrimp mountain. Squeeze a lemon wedge over the top, grind white pepper generously, and crown with a lavish tuft of fresh dill.
Serve immediately on a plate with extra lemon wedges. Eat with knife and fork—this is not a handheld affair.

drink.description: Punsch—that uniquely Swedish arrack-based liqueur—gets a sparkling Gothenburg makeover in this effervescent cocktail. The warm, spiced sweetness of punsch meets bright lemon and fizzy soda water, creating a drink that's simultaneously exotic and refreshing, a perfect companion to the briny shrimp of a räkmacka on the Gothenburg waterfront.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) Swedish punsch (Carlshamns Flaggpunsch or similar)
steps: Shake the punsch, lemon juice, and simple syrup vigorously with ice for 10 seconds.
Strain into a chilled highball glass filled with fresh ice.
Top with cold soda water and stir gently once to combine.
Garnish with a lemon twist expressed over the surface of the drink.

dessert.description: Gothenburg is the gingerbread capital of Sweden, and these Göteborgskex are the city's signature cookie: thin, shatteringly crisp gingersnaps enriched with ground almonds that add a subtle richness beneath the warm spice. Rolled thin, stamped into shapes, and baked until they darken to a deep amber, these cookies fill every Gothenburg bakery and home kitchen from November through Christmas—though true enthusiasts bake them year-round.
ingredients: 1/2 cup (50 g) finely ground almonds (almond flour)
1/3 cup (110 g) golden syrup (ljus sirap) or light corn syrup
steps: Cream the butter and sugar until light. Beat in the golden syrup and egg yolk.

Whisk together the flour, ground almonds, ginger, cinnamon, cloves, cardamom, baking soda, and salt. Stir the dry ingredients into the butter mixture until a smooth dough forms. Wrap in plastic and refrigerate at least 1 hour.

Preheat the oven to 375°F (190°C). Roll the dough very thin (about 1/8 inch / 3 mm) on a lightly floured surface. Cut into rounds or decorative shapes. Place on parchment-lined baking sheets. Press a few sliced almonds into the center of each cookie.
Bake 8–10 minutes until deep golden brown. Cool on the sheet briefly, then transfer to a wire rack. The cookies will crisp further as they cool.
Store in an airtight tin—they keep beautifully for weeks and improve with age.

Värmland.description: Värmland's legendary potato sausage is the beating heart of this forested province's food culture: coarsely ground pork and beef mixed with raw grated potato, onion, and a whisper of allspice, stuffed into natural casings and gently simmered until the potato melts into the meat, creating a sausage of extraordinary tenderness and subtle sweetness. Every Värmland family guards their own recipe proportions—some add more potato for a lighter sausage, others more pork for richness—but the result is always the same: a humble, soul-warming sausage that tastes like the Swedish countryside itself, served with mustard, pickled beets, and bread.
ingredients: 1 lb (450 g) ground pork (not lean—use shoulder)
1 1/2 lbs (680 g) starchy potatoes (such as Russet), peeled and finely grated
1/3 cup (80 ml) beef or pork stock, cold
Natural hog casings (about 3 feet / 90 cm), soaked and rinsed
steps: Squeeze the grated potato in a clean kitchen towel to remove excess starch water. In a large bowl, combine the ground pork, ground beef, grated potato, grated onion, salt, pepper, allspice, ginger, and cold stock. Mix thoroughly with your hands until evenly combined.

Slide one end of the soaked casing onto a sausage stuffing funnel or the tube of a sausage stuffer. Tie a knot at the other end. Fill the casing with the meat-potato mixture, packing firmly but not too tightly (the potato expands as it cooks). Tie off the end and twist into 6-inch (15 cm) links.

Bring a large pot of well-salted water to a gentle simmer (never a rolling boil—that bursts the casings). Prick each sausage once or twice with a needle. Lower the sausages into the simmering water and cook 45–50 minutes until firm and cooked through.
Remove and let rest 5 minutes. Optionally, brown the sausages in butter in a hot skillet for a golden crust. Serve with Swedish mustard, pickled beets, lingonberry jam, and fresh bread.

drink.dish: Värmland Glögg Cocktail (Warm Spiced Wine with Aquavit)
drink.description: In the deep forests of Värmland, where winter nights stretch endlessly and the snow piles high, this fortified glögg cocktail is the antidote to the cold: traditional Swedish mulled wine spiked with a generous measure of aquavit, intensifying the warmth of cinnamon, cardamom, and clove into a drink that radiates heat from the first sip. The aquavit's caraway and anise notes weave beautifully through the spiced wine.
ingredients: 1 1/2 oz (45 ml) aquavit (O.P. Anderson or similar)
1 tbsp (15 ml) honey or sugar, to taste
steps: Warm the red wine in a small saucepan with the cinnamon stick, cardamom pods, cloves, and orange peel over low heat until steaming (do not boil).
Stir in the honey until dissolved. Remove from heat and steep 5 minutes.
Strain into a heatproof mug. Stir in the aquavit.
Drop in the raisins and blanched almonds. Serve immediately, warm and fragrant.

dessert.dish: Värmländsk Fläskpannkaka (Thick Värmland Oven Pancake with Lingonberry)
dessert.description: Not a crêpe, not an American pancake—Värmland's fläskpannkaka is a thick, custardy oven pancake baked in a cast-iron skillet until puffed and golden, with pieces of salt pork or bacon embedded in the batter that render their fat into the pancake as it bakes, creating pockets of savory richness throughout. Served hot from the oven with a lavish spoonful of lingonberry jam, the contrast of sweet-tart berries against the salty, eggy pancake is quintessential Värmland comfort food.
ingredients: 4 oz (115 g) salt pork or thick-cut bacon, cut into small cubes
2 tbsp unsalted butter, for the pan
steps: Preheat the oven to 425°F (220°C). Place a 10-inch (25 cm) cast-iron skillet in the oven to heat.
Fry the salt pork or bacon cubes in a separate pan over medium heat until golden and the fat has rendered. Drain on paper towels, reserving the fat.
Whisk together the eggs, milk, flour, sugar, and salt until smooth (a few small lumps are fine). Stir in the fried pork cubes.
Remove the hot skillet from the oven. Add the butter (and a splash of the reserved pork fat) and swirl to coat. Pour in the batter.
Bake 20–25 minutes until puffed, set in the center, and golden brown on top. The pancake will deflate slightly as it cools.
Serve immediately in the skillet with generous spoonfuls of lingonberry jam.

Örebro.dish: Raggmunk (Crispy Swedish Potato Pancakes with Fried Pork Belly)
Örebro.description: The raggmunk is Swedish comfort food at its most elemental and satisfying: a batter of grated raw potato, flour, milk, and egg, fried in a generous slick of butter until the edges turn lacy and golden-brown while the center remains tender and custardy with shreds of potato. Served alongside thick slices of stekt fläsk (fried salt pork belly) that shatter with crispness, and a generous dollop of tangy lingonberry jam, raggmunk is the dish that bakeries and home kitchens across Örebro and the Närke heartland turn to when the autumn chill sets in and the body demands sustenance.
ingredients: 4 tbsp (60 g) unsalted butter, for frying
8 oz (225 g) salt pork belly (fläsk) or thick-cut bacon, sliced 1/4 inch (6 mm) thick
steps: Finely grate the potatoes (use the fine side of a box grater or a food processor). Do not squeeze out the liquid—the starch helps bind the pancakes.
Whisk together the eggs, milk, flour, salt, and white pepper. Stir in the grated potato to make a thick, porridge-like batter. Let stand 5 minutes.
Fry the salt pork slices in a large skillet over medium-high heat until deeply golden and crisp on both sides, about 3–4 minutes per side. Remove and keep warm.

Wipe the skillet and add a generous knob of butter. When foaming, ladle about 1/3 cup batter per pancake into the pan, spreading into 4-inch (10 cm) rounds. Fry 3–4 minutes per side until deeply golden and crisp at the edges.
Serve the raggmunk immediately, piping hot, with the crispy fried pork belly alongside and a generous spoonful of lingonberry jam.

drink.description: A Swedish twist on the classic Moscow Mule that trades vodka for caraway-scented aquavit, bringing a distinctly Scandinavian warmth to the ginger-lime combination. The aquavit's herbal complexity plays beautifully against the spicy ginger beer and bright lime, creating a refreshing yet deeply flavored cocktail worthy of Örebro's thriving craft beverage scene.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) Swedish aquavit (O.P. Anderson or Skåne Akvavit)
steps: Fill a copper mug (or rocks glass) with ice.
Pour in the aquavit and lime juice. Stir briefly.
Top with ginger beer and stir gently once.
Garnish with a lime wedge and a sprig of fresh dill.

dessert.description: The kanelbulle is Sweden's national pastry—so beloved it has its own holiday (Kanelbullens Dag, October 4th)—and the bakeries of Örebro produce some of the finest. A pillowy, cardamom-perfumed yeasted dough is rolled with a lavish filling of butter, sugar, and cinnamon, then twisted into the iconic knot shape, brushed with egg, and showered with pearl sugar that stays crunchy even as the bun turns golden in the oven. The aroma alone could bring a city to its knees.

ingredients: 1 cup (240 ml) whole milk, warmed to 110°F (43°C)
2 1/4 tsp (1 packet / 7 g) active dry yeast
1/2 cup (115 g) unsalted butter, melted and cooled
3 1/2 cups (455 g) all-purpose flour, plus more as needed
steps: Dissolve the yeast in the warm milk with a pinch of sugar. Let stand 5 minutes until foamy.
Stir in the remaining sugar, melted butter, egg, cardamom, and salt. Add the flour gradually, mixing until a soft, slightly sticky dough forms.
Knead 8–10 minutes on a floured surface until smooth and elastic. Place in a greased bowl, cover, and rise 1 hour until doubled.

ingredients: 1/3 cup (75 g) unsalted butter, very soft
steps: Mix the soft butter, sugar, and cinnamon into a smooth, spreadable paste.
Punch down the risen dough. Roll out on a floured surface into a large rectangle, about 16x20 inches (40x50 cm).
Spread the cinnamon filling evenly over the dough. Roll up tightly from the long side into a log. Cut into 12–14 pieces, about 1 1/2 inches (4 cm) wide.

To shape: take each piece and stretch it gently, then twist and coil into a knot, tucking the end underneath. Place on parchment-lined baking sheets, spaced 2 inches apart. Cover and let rise 30 minutes.
Preheat the oven to 400°F (200°C). Brush each bun with beaten egg and sprinkle generously with pearl sugar.
Bake 10–12 minutes until golden brown. Cool on a wire rack 5 minutes. Serve warm with strong Swedish coffee (bryggkaffe).

Västmanland.dish: Fläskkorv med Rotmos (Västmanland Boiled Pork Sausage with Root Vegetable Mash)
Västmanland.description: Västmanland's answer to the universal question of what to eat on a cold Tuesday night: plump, gently spiced boiled pork sausages—falukorv's rustic country cousin—served atop a mountain of rotmos, the glorious Swedish mash of turnips, carrots, and potatoes beaten together with butter and a splash of cream until impossibly smooth and golden. The sweetness of the root vegetables against the mild, peppery sausage, finished with a drizzle of sharp Swedish mustard and a side of lingonberry, is Västmanland on a plate: unpretentious, warming, and profoundly satisfying.
ingredients: 1 1/2 lbs (680 g) Swedish-style pork sausage (fläskkorv or falukorv), in large links
Root vegetable mash (see Chef's Essentials below)
1 lb (450 g) yellow turnip (rutabaga/swede), peeled and cubed
1/2 lb (225 g) carrots, peeled and cubed
1 lb (450 g) starchy potatoes, peeled and cubed
steps: Boil the turnip, carrots, and potatoes together in well-salted water until completely tender, about 20–25 minutes. Drain thoroughly.
Mash with a potato masher or pass through a ricer. Beat in the butter and warm cream until smooth and fluffy. Season with salt, white pepper, and nutmeg.
Bring a large pot of lightly salted water to a gentle simmer. Add the pork sausages and poach gently (do not boil vigorously) for 15–20 minutes until heated through and firm.
Remove the sausages and slice into thick rounds, about 1 inch (2.5 cm) thick.
Mound the hot rotmos generously on warm plates. Arrange the sliced sausage alongside or on top.
Drizzle with Swedish mustard and serve with lingonberry jam and a sprinkle of fresh parsley.

drink.description: Västmanland's orchards produce exceptional apples, and this warming toddy puts them to glorious use: fresh apple cider heated with cinnamon, cloves, and a generous pour of Swedish vodka or brandy, sweetened with honey and finished with a slice of fresh apple. It's the drink that Västmanland reaches for when the frost paints the windows.
ingredients: 1 cup (240 ml) fresh apple cider (unfiltered preferred)
1 1/2 oz (45 ml) Swedish vodka or brandy
1 thin slice of fresh apple, for garnish
steps: Warm the apple cider in a small saucepan with the cinnamon stick and cloves over low heat until steaming (do not boil).
Remove from heat and stir in the honey until dissolved.
Strain into a heatproof mug. Stir in the vodka or brandy.
Garnish with a thin apple slice floating on top. Serve warm.

dessert.description: When spring arrives in Västmanland and the rhubarb pushes its crimson stalks through the thawing earth, every kitchen in the province turns to rabarberpaj: tart, ruby-red rhubarb pieces tumbled with sugar and a squeeze of lemon, then buried under a thick, crunchy crumble topping of oats, butter, sugar, and flour that bakes to a deep golden shell. Served warm from the oven with a cascade of cold vanilla custard (vaniljsås), the contrast of hot, tart fruit and cool, sweet cream is one of Sweden's greatest dessert experiences.
ingredients: 1 1/2 lbs (680 g) fresh rhubarb, trimmed and cut into 1/2-inch (1.3 cm) pieces
Oat crumble topping (see Chef's Essentials below)
Vanilla custard (vaniljsås) or vanilla ice cream, for serving
1/2 cup (115 g) unsalted butter, cold, cut into small cubes
steps: Toss together the flour, oats, sugar, and salt. Rub the cold butter into the dry ingredients with your fingertips until the mixture resembles coarse, clumpy crumbs with some pea-sized pieces of butter remaining.
Preheat the oven to 400°F (200°C). Butter a 9-inch (23 cm) pie dish or baking dish.
Toss the rhubarb pieces with the sugar, cornstarch, and lemon juice. Spread evenly in the buttered dish.
Scatter the oat crumble topping thickly and evenly over the rhubarb. Do not press it down—a loose, craggy surface makes the best crunch.
Bake 30–35 minutes until the crumble is deep golden brown and the rhubarb juices are bubbling up around the edges.
Let cool 10 minutes (the juices thicken as they cool). Serve warm with cold vanilla custard poured generously over each serving.

Dalarna.description: Dalarna's most spectacular and ancient dish is reserved for Midsummer and special celebrations: whole pork shoulders are rubbed with salt and juniper, wrapped in birch bark, and buried in a deep pit layered with glowing charcoal and hot stones, then sealed with earth and left to slow-cook overnight. When unearthed the next morning, the meat has transformed into something extraordinary—impossibly tender, deeply smoky, infused with the resinous perfume of juniper and birch. Dalaräskit is not just food; it is a ritual that connects modern Dalarna to its Viking-age roots, a communal act of patience and celebration.
ingredients: 5 lbs (2.3 kg) bone-in pork shoulder (Boston butt)
2 cups (475 ml) dark beer or beef stock, for braising
2 tbsp dried juniper berries, crushed in a mortar
steps: Combine the salt, crushed juniper berries, black pepper, allspice, garlic, and oil into a coarse paste. Rub generously over the entire pork shoulder, pressing into all crevices. Refrigerate uncovered at least 4 hours, or ideally overnight.
Preheat the oven to 300°F (150°C). Place the quartered onions in the bottom of a large Dutch oven or deep roasting pan. Set the rubbed pork shoulder on top, fat side up.
Tuck the rosemary, thyme, and bay leaves around the pork. Pour the dark beer or stock around (not over) the meat.
Cover tightly with a lid or heavy-duty aluminum foil. Roast 5–6 hours, basting every 90 minutes, until the meat is fall-apart tender and a fork slides in without resistance.
For a traditional crust: remove the lid for the final 30 minutes and raise the heat to 425°F (220°C) to brown the top.
Let rest 20 minutes, then pull the meat into shreds with two forks. Serve on a platter with the pan juices, lingonberry jam, pickled cucumbers, and buttery new potatoes.

drink.description: No Dalarna Midsummer is complete without snaps—and the Dala snaps tradition calls for aquavit infused with bitter herbs and wildflowers, chilled to near-freezing and knocked back in a single gulp between verses of traditional drinking songs (snapsvisa). This version uses wormwood and dill for an aromatic, bracing shot that clears the palate and warms the soul.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) Swedish aquavit (such as O.P. Anderson), ice-cold
Pinch of dried wormwood or Angostura bitters (2 dashes) as a substitute
steps: Place the aquavit in a small glass or snaps glass. If using wormwood, steep a tiny pinch in the aquavit for 30 seconds and strain (or simply add 2 dashes of Angostura bitters as a modern substitute).
Drop in the dill sprig and lemon zest strip.
Chill the glass in the freezer for 5 minutes (or serve from a frozen bottle). Drink in a single toast—'Skål!'—and follow with a bite of herring or pickled cucumber.

dessert.dish: Dalakaka (Traditional Dalarna Flatbread Cake with Soured Cream and Berries)
dessert.description: Dalakaka is Dalarna's ancient flatbread transformed into dessert: a thick, slightly sweet round of barley and wheat flour baked on a griddle until speckled and golden, then split and layered with rich soured cream (gräddfil) and a tumble of wild berries—lingonberries, blueberries, and cloudberries when the season allows. Simple, rustic, and utterly delicious, dalakaka connects every bite to centuries of Dalarna baking tradition.
ingredients: 1/2 cup (65 g) barley flour (or substitute whole wheat flour)
1 cup (240 ml) gräddfil (Swedish soured cream) or crème fraîche
1 cup (150 g) mixed fresh berries (lingonberries, blueberries, cloudberries)
steps: Whisk together both flours, sugar, baking powder, and salt. Stir in the melted butter, milk, and egg until a thick, smooth batter forms.
Heat a cast-iron skillet or griddle over medium heat and grease lightly with butter. Pour the batter into the skillet to form a thick round about 8 inches (20 cm) across.
Cook 4–5 minutes until bubbles form on the surface and the bottom is golden brown. Carefully flip and cook another 3–4 minutes until cooked through.

Split the warm cake horizontally. Spread the bottom half generously with gräddfil or crème fraîche. Scatter the berries over the cream. Drizzle with honey. Place the top half back on, press gently, and cut into wedges.
Serve warm or at room temperature.

Gävleborg.description: The most notorious food in Sweden—perhaps in the world. Surströmming is Baltic herring caught in the spring, lightly salted, and left to ferment in barrels through the summer until the cans bulge with gas and the aroma inside reaches legendary intensity. Opening a can of surströmming is a ritual: always outdoors (the smell can clear a building), always with respect. But beneath the fearsome reputation lies a genuinely delicious tradition: the fermented herring, with its complex umami and sharp acidity, is eaten on thin tunnbröd flatbread with sliced almond potatoes, diced raw onion, sour cream, and fresh dill. The combination of flavors is far more nuanced than the smell suggests, and for the people of Gävleborg—ground zero of surströmming production—the August premiere is an annual celebration.
ingredients: 1 can surströmming (available at Swedish specialty stores—approximately 10 oz / 300 g)
1 lb (450 g) mandelpotatis or small waxy potatoes, boiled and sliced
1 cup (240 ml) gräddfil (Swedish soured cream) or crème fraîche
steps: CRITICAL: Open the surströmming can outdoors (or in a bucket of water to contain the spray). The pressurized brine will spray, and the aroma is extraordinarily pungent. Point the can away from yourself and any bystanders.
Drain the brine and gently rinse the herring fillets under cold running water. Carefully remove the skin and bones if desired (many eat them skin-on). Place the fillets on a plate.
