Lay out the tunnbröd sheets. Spread each with softened butter and a generous smear of gräddfil.
Place sliced potatoes and diced onion on the bread. Add a piece of surströmming fillet. Top with more sour cream and a generous crown of fresh dill.
Roll or fold the tunnbröd into a wrap (klämma). Eat immediately—preferably with an open mind and a cold drink nearby.

drink.description: There is only one proper drink to accompany surströmming: brännvin—Swedish potato aquavit served so cold it pours like silk and numbs the palate just enough to let the fermented herring sing. In Gävleborg, the bottle lives in the freezer, and the glasses are small. Skål!
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) Swedish brännvin or aquavit (such as Skåne Akvavit), stored in the freezer
steps: Store the aquavit bottle in the freezer for at least 4 hours (overnight is ideal). The spirit will become viscous and syrupy.
Pre-chill the snaps glass in the freezer for 15 minutes.
Pour the ice-cold aquavit to the brim of the small glass.
Raise your glass, sing a snapsvisa (traditional drinking song), and drink in a single gulp. Immediately follow with a bite of surströmming on tunnbröd. Repeat as tradition demands.

dessert.dish: Gävle Bock Pepparkakor (Gävle Goat-Shaped Ginger Cookies)
dessert.description: Gävle is world-famous for its giant straw Christmas goat (Gävlebocken), erected every December in the town square and often dramatically set ablaze by mischief-makers. These goat-shaped pepparkakor pay tribute to Gävle's beloved symbol: crispy, paper-thin ginger cookies cut into goat shapes, warmly spiced with ginger, cinnamon, cloves, and cardamom, and optionally decorated with a drizzle of white icing. Baking pepparkakor in goat shapes is a Gävleborg December tradition as reliable as the annual debate over the real goat's fate.
ingredients: 1/3 cup (110 g) dark Swedish syrup (mörk sirap) or dark corn syrup
Optional icing: 1 cup (120 g) powdered sugar, 1 tbsp milk, 1/2 tsp vanilla
steps: Cream the butter and sugar until fluffy. Beat in the dark syrup and egg.

Whisk together the flour, ginger, cinnamon, cloves, cardamom, baking soda, and salt. Add to the butter mixture and mix until a smooth dough forms. Wrap tightly and refrigerate at least 2 hours (overnight is best).
Preheat the oven to 375°F (190°C). Roll the dough very thin (1/8 inch / 3 mm or thinner) on a floured surface. Cut into goat shapes (Julbock cookie cutter) or any desired shapes.
Place on parchment-lined baking sheets. Bake 6–8 minutes until deep brown and firm. They will crisp as they cool.
Optional: mix the powdered sugar, milk, and vanilla into a thick icing. Pipe decorative lines onto the cooled cookies to define the goat's features. Let set before serving or gifting.

Västernorrland.dish: Pitepalt (Norrland Potato Dumplings with Salted Pork)
Västernorrland.description: The pitepalt is Norrland's great dumpling tradition: heavy, satisfying spheres made from raw grated potato mixed with barley or wheat flour, each one concealing a nugget of salted pork at its center. Boiled in salted water until they float and darken to a distinctive grey-brown, pitepalt are served swimming in melted butter with a generous side of lingonberry jam. The texture is dense and slightly chewy—a far cry from Italian gnocchi—and each bite delivers the earthy sweetness of potato followed by the salty punch of pork. In Västernorrland, pitepalt is not just a dish; it is an identity, argued over and perfected across generations.
ingredients: 2 lbs (900 g) starchy potatoes (Russet), peeled and finely grated
1 cup (130 g) barley flour (or all-purpose flour)
8 oz (225 g) salted pork belly or salt pork, cut into 12 small cubes (about 3/4 inch / 2 cm each)
4 tbsp (60 g) unsalted butter, melted, for serving
steps: Finely grate the potatoes into a bowl. Squeeze out about half the liquid through a clean kitchen towel (some starch water should remain for binding). Mix the grated potato with the barley flour and salt until a heavy, sticky dough forms.

Divide the dough into 12 equal portions (about the size of a tennis ball each). Flatten each portion in your palm, press a cube of salted pork into the center, and seal the dough around it, rolling into a smooth ball.

Bring a very large pot of well-salted water to a rolling boil. Gently lower the dumplings into the water (work in batches if needed). Boil 40–45 minutes—the dumplings will sink, then gradually float to the surface. They are done when they float steadily and feel firm.

Remove with a slotted spoon and drain briefly. Serve immediately on warm plates, drizzled generously with melted butter and accompanied by lingonberry jam. Traditionally, cold pitepalt are sliced and fried in butter the next day.

drink.description: A ruby-red cocktail that transforms Sweden's most ubiquitous berry—the lingonberry—into a sophisticated whiskey sour variant. The lingonberry's natural tartness and slight bitterness replaces the need for excessive citrus, while the whiskey (or Swedish aquavit) provides backbone. It's the cocktail equivalent of Norrland's forests: wild, beautiful, and slightly untamed.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) bourbon whiskey (or Swedish aquavit for a local twist)
3/4 oz (22 ml) lingonberry syrup (see below) or 1 tbsp lingonberry jam dissolved in 1/2 oz warm water
Fresh lingonberries or a lemon twist, for garnish
steps: If using egg white, add it to the shaker first and dry shake (without ice) vigorously for 15 seconds to build foam.
Add the whiskey, lingonberry syrup, lemon juice, and ice. Shake hard for 15 seconds.
Strain into a chilled coupe or rocks glass over a single large ice cube.
Garnish with a few fresh lingonberries or a lemon twist. The lingonberry syrup can be made by simmering 1/2 cup lingonberries with 1/4 cup sugar and 1/4 cup water for 5 minutes, then straining.

dessert.dish: Norrlands Pannkakor med Hjortronsylt (Thin Norrland Crepes with Cloudberry Jam)
dessert.description: In Norrland, pancakes are always thin—gossamer crêpes cooked in butter until the edges turn lace-crisp, then rolled around a filling of cloudberry jam, that liquid gold of the Arctic marshes. Cloudberries (hjortron) grow wild in the bogs of Västernorrland and are fiercely guarded by foragers who know their secret spots. Their unique flavor—simultaneously tart, sweet, and musky with a hint of honey—makes them the most prized jam berry in all of Scandinavia. Paired with these buttery crêpes and a dusting of powdered sugar, they become the most elegant simple dessert in Sweden.
ingredients: 2 tbsp (30 g) unsalted butter, melted, plus more for the pan
steps: Whisk together the eggs, milk, flour, sugar, salt, and melted butter until completely smooth with no lumps. Let the batter rest 15 minutes (this helps the crêpes turn tender).

Heat a non-stick or well-seasoned 8-inch (20 cm) crêpe pan over medium heat. Brush with a thin layer of butter. Pour about 3 tbsp batter into the pan, immediately tilting and swirling to coat the bottom in a thin, even layer.
Cook 1–2 minutes until the bottom is golden and the edges lift easily. Flip with a spatula (or a confident wrist-flick) and cook 30 seconds more. Stack the finished crêpes on a plate.
Spread each warm crêpe with a generous spoonful of cloudberry jam and roll or fold into quarters. Dust with powdered sugar and serve with whipped cream if desired.

Jämtland.dish: Jämtländsk Älggryta (Jämtland Moose Stew with Juniper and Wild Mushrooms)
Jämtland.description: Jämtland is Sweden's great wilderness—a vast expanse of mountain, forest, and lake where the moose is king. This stew is the definitive celebration of the autumn moose hunt: chunks of dark, lean moose meat braised low and slow with crushed juniper berries, cream, and foraged wild mushrooms until the meat yields to the gentlest pressure and the sauce has reduced to a velvety, deeply savory gravy perfumed with the forest floor. Every hunting lodge and farmhouse kitchen in Jämtland has its own version, but the essentials never change: good moose, good juniper, patience, and a cold night outside to make the warmth within feel like a blessing.
ingredients: 2 1/2 lbs (1.1 kg) moose stew meat (or substitute elk or beef chuck), cut into 1 1/2-inch (4 cm) cubes
3 tbsp (45 ml) vegetable oil or butter
2 medium carrots, peeled and cut into thick rounds
2 tbsp dried juniper berries, lightly crushed
8 oz (225 g) fresh wild mushrooms (chanterelles, porcini, or cremini), cleaned and halved
steps: Pat the moose meat very dry with paper towels. Season generously with salt and pepper. Heat the oil in a large Dutch oven over high heat and sear the meat in batches until deeply browned on all sides. Do not crowd the pot. Remove and set aside.
Reduce heat to medium. Add the onions and carrots and cook 5–6 minutes until softened. Add the garlic and cook 1 minute more. Sprinkle the flour over the vegetables and stir for 1 minute.

Pour in the red wine, scraping up all the browned bits from the bottom. Add the beef stock, cream, crushed juniper berries, thyme, and bay leaves. Return the seared moose meat to the pot. Bring to a gentle simmer.
Cover and cook over low heat (or in a 300°F / 150°C oven) for 2 1/2–3 hours, stirring occasionally, until the meat is fork-tender.
In the last 20 minutes, sauté the mushrooms separately in butter until golden and add them to the stew. Taste and adjust seasoning.
Serve the stew in deep bowls over mashed potatoes, with lingonberry jam on the side.

drink.description: Jämtland's juniper-studded forests inspire this elevated G&T: Swedish gin (or a juniper-forward London dry) served over ice with premium tonic, fresh juniper berries, and a sprig of rosemary that fills the glass with the aroma of the Jämtland mountains. Simple, crisp, and wildly aromatic.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) Swedish gin (Hernö gin or similar juniper-forward gin)
6–8 fresh or dried juniper berries, lightly crushed
steps: Fill a large copa glass (or rocks glass) with ice. Pour in the gin.
Drop in the crushed juniper berries.
Top with tonic water, pouring slowly down the side of the glass to preserve the bubbles.
Gently slap the rosemary sprig between your palms to release its oils, then tuck it into the glass. Express the lemon peel over the surface and drop it in.

dessert.description: The crown jewel of Jämtland desserts: a towering layer cake of soft sponge filled with clouds of whipped cream folded through with golden cloudberry jam, the berries' musky, honeyed sweetness perfuming every layer. Cloudberries are the amber treasure of Jämtland's mountain marshes, foraged in late July and hoarded like gold. This cake—traditionally served for birthdays, weddings, and Midsummer—is the most luxurious way to showcase them.
ingredients: Sponge cake layers (see Chef's Essentials below)
Cloudberry cream filling (see Chef's Essentials below)
Extra cloudberry jam, for the top

steps: Preheat the oven to 350°F (175°C). Grease and flour two 9-inch (23 cm) round cake pans and line the bottoms with parchment.
Beat the eggs and sugar with an electric mixer on high speed for 8–10 minutes until tripled in volume and very pale (the ribbon stage).
Sift the flour and baking powder together. Fold gently into the egg mixture in three additions, being careful not to deflate. Fold in the warm milk, melted butter, and vanilla last.
Divide the batter between the prepared pans. Bake 20–25 minutes until golden and a toothpick comes out clean. Cool in pans 10 minutes, then turn out onto wire racks to cool completely.
Whip the cream with the powdered sugar and vanilla to medium-firm peaks. Gently fold in the cloudberry jam, leaving visible golden streaks and swirls throughout.
If the cake layers domed, level the tops with a serrated knife. Optionally, split each layer horizontally for a four-layer cake.
Place the first layer on a serving plate. Spread a thick layer of cloudberry cream over the top. Add the second layer and repeat.
Cover the top and sides of the cake with the remaining cloudberry cream. Spoon a few tablespoons of extra cloudberry jam on top and swirl decoratively.
Garnish with fresh cloudberries if available. Refrigerate at least 1 hour before serving to let the layers meld.
Serve chilled, cut into generous wedges.

Västerbotten.description: The most legendary savory pie in all of Sweden, and a dish of almost mystical status: a buttery, crumbly shortcrust shell filled with a rich custard of eggs, cream, and the irreplaceable Västerbotten cheese—a tangy, crystalline aged cheese produced exclusively in the tiny village of Burträsk, where the exact recipe is a closely guarded secret and attempts to replicate it elsewhere have all failed. The cheese melts into the custard during baking, creating a pie of extraordinary depth—simultaneously nutty, sharp, creamy, and slightly granular. Västerbottensostpaj is the star of every Swedish crayfish party (kräftskiva) and Midsummer table, and arguing over whose recipe is best is a national pastime.
ingredients: Västerbotten custard filling (see Chef's Essentials below)
1/2 cup (115 g) unsalted butter, cold, cut into small cubes
steps: Pulse the flour, cold butter, and salt in a food processor until the mixture resembles coarse meal. Add ice water and pulse until the dough just comes together. Flatten into a disc, wrap in plastic, and refrigerate 30 minutes.
Roll out on a floured surface to fit a 10-inch (25 cm) tart pan with removable bottom. Press into the pan, trim the edges, and prick the bottom with a fork. Refrigerate 15 minutes.
Blind bake at 400°F (200°C) with pie weights or dried beans for 15 minutes. Remove weights and bake 5 minutes more until lightly golden.

ingredients: 10 oz (280 g) Västerbotten cheese (or substitute aged Gruyère or Comté), finely grated
steps: Whisk together the eggs, cream, milk, white pepper, and nutmeg until smooth. Stir in the grated cheese.
Preheat the oven to 375°F (190°C).
Pour the cheese custard filling into the pre-baked tart shell, spreading the cheese evenly.
Bake 25–30 minutes until the filling is set and the top is beautifully golden with spots of deeper brown where the cheese has caramelized.
Let cool 10 minutes before removing from the tart pan. Serve warm or at room temperature—both are traditional. Cut into wedges and accompany with a simple green salad.

drink.description: A Swedish Arctic twist on the Moscow Mule, swapping vodka for aquavit and adding a splash of lingonberry for a drink that's equal parts refreshing and warming. The ginger beer's spice, the aquavit's caraway notes, and the lingonberry's tart sweetness create a cocktail perfectly suited to accompany the rich, cheesy Västerbottensostpaj.
ingredients: 1/2 oz (15 ml) lingonberry syrup or 1 tbsp lingonberry jam, strained
Lime wheel and fresh lingonberries, for garnish
steps: Fill a copper mug or rocks glass with ice.
Pour in the aquavit, lingonberry syrup, and lime juice. Stir briefly to combine.
Top with ginger beer and stir gently once.
Garnish with a lime wheel and a few fresh lingonberries.

dessert.dish: Västerbotten Nyponsoppa (Cold Rose Hip Soup with Cream and Almond Cookies)
dessert.description: Nyponsoppa is one of Sweden's most unique and beloved desserts—a silky, rose-pink soup made from dried rose hips, gently sweetened and thickened with potato starch, served cold with a swirl of cream and crunchy almond cookies (mandelskorpor) for dipping. Rose hips grow wild across Västerbotten's roadsides and meadows, and the soup's flavor is hauntingly floral, fruity, and subtly tart—unlike anything else in the dessert canon. Once tasted, never forgotten.
ingredients: Rose hip soup (see Chef's Essentials below)
Heavy cream or whipped cream, for serving
1 cup (60 g) dried rose hips (or 6 oz / 170 g rose hip purée)
1/3 cup (65 g) granulated sugar, to taste
1 tbsp potato starch (or cornstarch) dissolved in 2 tbsp cold water
steps: Simmer the dried rose hips in the water for 30–40 minutes until very soft. Blend until smooth and strain through a fine-mesh sieve, pressing to extract all the pulp.
Return the strained soup to the pot. Stir in the sugar and bring to a gentle simmer. Add the dissolved potato starch and stir until the soup thickens slightly to a pouring-cream consistency.
Stir in the lemon juice. Let cool, then refrigerate until cold (at least 2 hours).
Cream the butter and sugar. Beat in the egg and almond extract. Stir in the flour, salt, and sliced almonds until a soft dough forms.
Shape the dough into a log about 2 inches (5 cm) in diameter on a parchment-lined baking sheet. Bake at 350°F (175°C) for 25 minutes until golden.

Cool 10 minutes, then slice diagonally into 1/2-inch (1.3 cm) thick cookies. Lay the slices flat on the baking sheet and bake again at 300°F (150°C) for 15 minutes until dry and crunchy. Cool completely.
Ladle the cold rose hip soup into shallow bowls.
Swirl a generous spoonful of heavy cream or a dollop of whipped cream through each bowl.
Serve with the almond cookies alongside for dipping and crunching. The contrast of the cold, silky, fruity soup with the crispy, nutty cookies is pure Swedish bliss.

Norrbotten.description: THE dish of Swedish Lapland, and the single recipe that defines Norrbotten's Arctic food culture: paper-thin shavings of reindeer meat—frozen solid and then shaved with a knife into translucent curls—sautéed in sizzling butter until just cooked, the meat's deep, gamey sweetness caramelizing at the edges. Served over creamy mashed potatoes with a generous dollop of lingonberry jam and crisp pickled cucumber, renskav is a dish of breathtaking simplicity and profound flavor. The Sami people have been cooking reindeer in these mountains for thousands of years, and every bite of renskav connects you to that ancient tradition—a taste of the Arctic tundra, the midnight sun, and the wind over the fells.
ingredients: 1 1/4 lbs (560 g) frozen reindeer meat, shaved paper-thin (or substitute venison or beef, frozen and thinly sliced)
1/2 cup (120 ml) beef stock or reindeer stock
steps: Heat a large, heavy skillet (cast iron is ideal) over high heat until very hot. Add the butter—it should foam and brown immediately.

Add the frozen shaved reindeer meat directly to the hot butter. Sear without stirring for 1–2 minutes to get color, then stir and continue cooking 3–4 minutes total until the meat is just cooked through and has developed golden-brown edges. Do not overcook—reindeer is lean and toughens quickly.
Add the sliced onion and cook 1 minute more. Pour in the stock and cream, stirring to deglaze the pan. Simmer 2–3 minutes until the sauce thickens slightly. Season with salt and pepper.
Serve immediately over a generous mound of creamy mashed potatoes. Spoon the pan sauce over the meat, add a large dollop of lingonberry jam, and arrange pickled cucumber alongside.

drink.dish: Norrbotten Arctic Vodka Martini with Lingonberry
drink.description: In the far north of Sweden, where winter temperatures plunge to -40° and the northern lights dance overhead, this Arctic martini cuts through the cold like a blade of light: ice-cold Swedish vodka stirred with a whisper of dry vermouth and a teaspoon of lingonberry juice that tints the drink a pale, ethereal pink. Served in a frozen glass with a few lingonberries sunk to the bottom like tiny Arctic rubies, it is elegance distilled to its coldest, purest essence.
ingredients: 3 oz (90 ml) Swedish vodka (Absolut Elyx or similar), stored in the freezer
1 tsp lingonberry juice or syrup (or muddle 5 fresh lingonberries)
steps: Chill a martini glass in the freezer for at least 10 minutes.
Fill a mixing glass with ice. Pour in the frozen vodka, dry vermouth, and lingonberry juice. Stir gently for 20 seconds—the drink should be brutally cold.
Strain into the frozen martini glass.
Drop 3–4 fresh lingonberries into the glass. Express a lemon twist over the surface, then discard or drape on the rim. Serve immediately.

dessert.dish: Gáhkku (Sami Flatbread with Reindeer Butter and Cloudberry Jam)
dessert.description: Gáhkku is the ancient bread of the Sami people—a soft, slightly chewy flatbread cooked on an open fire or griddle, made with simple ingredients that travel well across the tundra: flour, water, a pinch of salt, and sometimes a bit of reindeer fat for richness. Served warm and torn by hand, spread with creamy reindeer butter (or regular butter) and a generous smear of golden cloudberry jam, gáhkku is a dessert that tastes of the Arctic itself—simple, pure, and deeply satisfying. It is food with ten thousand years of history on every bite.
ingredients: 1/2 cup (65 g) whole wheat or barley flour
1 tbsp (15 g) reindeer fat, lard, or softened butter
3/4 cup (180 ml) warm water (plus more as needed)
Softened butter (reindeer butter if available, or regular unsalted butter)
steps: Mix both flours, baking powder, and salt in a bowl. Rub in the reindeer fat or butter with your fingertips until the mixture resembles coarse meal. Add the warm water gradually, stirring, until a soft but not sticky dough forms. Knead briefly until smooth.
Divide the dough into 6–8 equal pieces. Roll each piece into a round about 6 inches (15 cm) across and 1/4 inch (6 mm) thick.

Heat a dry cast-iron skillet or griddle over medium-high heat. Cook each flatbread 2–3 minutes per side until puffed, speckled with brown spots, and cooked through. Stack under a clean towel to keep warm and soft.
Serve the warm gáhkku torn into pieces, spread with butter and cloudberry jam. Drizzle with honey if desired. Eat with your hands, as the Sami have done for millennia.

SYR.dish: Kibbeh Bil Sanieh (كبة بالصينية) — Syrian Baked Kibbeh
SYR.description: A Levantine classic strongly associated with Syria: spiced ground meat and bulgur pressed into a tray with a savory filling and baked until crisp at the edges.
ingredients: 3 tbsp (45 ml) olive oil or melted butter
1 lb (450 g) ground lamb or beef
steps: Soak bulgur in hot water 10 minutes; drain well and squeeze out excess water.
Mix bulgur with ground meat, grated onion, salt, allspice, and cinnamon until it comes together into a paste-like dough (pulse briefly in a food processor for a finer texture if desired).

ingredients: 1 lb (450 g) ground lamb or beef
steps: Sauté onion in oil until golden, add meat and cook until browned. Stir in pine nuts, spices, and salt; cool.
Heat oven to 400°F (200°C). Oil a 9x13 in (23x33 cm) baking dish.
Press half the kibbeh mixture into the dish. Spread filling evenly. Top with remaining kibbeh, smoothing with wet hands.
Score into diamonds. Drizzle with olive oil/butter.
Bake 30–40 minutes until browned. Rest 10 minutes before serving.

drink.description: A tart-sweet tamarind drink common across the Levant, especially in warm weather and during Ramadan.
ingredients: 4 oz (115 g) tamarind pulp (seedless if possible)
1/2 cup (100 g) sugar, plus more to taste
steps: Soak tamarind pulp in 2 cups (475 ml) hot water 20 minutes, then mash well.
Strain through a fine sieve, pressing to extract liquid. Discard fibers/seeds.
Stir in remaining 4 cups (950 ml) cold water and sugar until dissolved. Add lemon if using.
Chill and serve over ice.

dessert.description: Syrian sweet cheese rolls: stretchy cheese dough made with semolina, rolled around clotted cream (ashta), and soaked in rosewater syrup. One of the crown jewels of Syrian confectionery, halawet el jibn originated in Hama and Homs and has become beloved across the entire Levant. The warm, elastic cheese dough—made by melting mild white cheese with semolina—is rolled paper-thin, filled with cold, fragrant ashta, and sliced into pinwheels that glisten with rosewater syrup. The contrast of warm, stretchy dough and cool, silky cream is extraordinary.
ingredients: 2 cups (250 g) shredded mozzarella cheese (low-moisture, mild)
Ashta — clotted cream (see Chef's Essentials below)

steps: Combine sugar, water, and lemon juice in a saucepan. Bring to a boil, stirring to dissolve sugar.
Simmer 8 minutes until slightly syrupy. Remove from heat, stir in rosewater and orange blossom water. Cool completely.
Dissolve cornstarch in 1/4 cup of the cold milk. Set aside.
Combine remaining milk, cream, and sugar in a saucepan. Bring to a gentle simmer.
Stir in the cornstarch slurry and cook over low heat, stirring constantly, until thickened to a pudding-like consistency, about 5–7 minutes.
Remove from heat, stir in rosewater. Pour into a shallow dish and refrigerate until cold and set.
Combine water and sugar in a wide non-stick pan over low heat, stirring until sugar dissolves.
Add shredded mozzarella and stir continuously as the cheese melts into a stretchy, smooth mass.

Gradually sprinkle in the semolina, stirring vigorously to incorporate. Continue working the dough in the pan until it forms a cohesive, elastic ball that pulls away from the sides, about 3–4 minutes.
Turn the hot cheese dough out onto a surface lightly greased with a little rosewater syrup. Working quickly while warm, roll or press the dough into a thin rectangle (about 10x14 inches / 25x35 cm).
Spread a layer of cold ashta evenly over the dough, leaving a 1/2-inch (1 cm) border.
Roll up tightly from the long side into a log. Refrigerate 20 minutes to firm.
Slice the roll into 1-inch (2.5 cm) pinwheels. Arrange on a serving plate.
Drizzle generously with cold rosewater syrup and sprinkle with crushed pistachios. Serve chilled or at room temperature.

TCA.description: The pride of the Caicos banks. The Queen Conch is so vital here it's on the flag. 'Cracked' refers to the method of pounding the tough meat until tender, before breading and frying it into a golden delicacy that rivals any calamari.
steps: Pound the conch meat with a mallet until very thin and tender (crucial).
Dip in egg wash (egg + milk).
Dredge in seasoned flour.
Deep fry at 375°F (190°C) for 2-3 minutes until golden. Do not overcook.
Serve with tartar sauce and lemon wedges.

drink.description: Turks & Caicos’ local Bambarra rum works perfectly in a simple punch build.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) Bambarra rum (or another Caribbean rum)
1 tsp sugar (or 1/2 oz / 15 ml simple syrup)
steps: Shake all ingredients with ice until cold.
Strain over fresh ice in a tall glass.
Note (simple syrup): stir equal parts sugar + hot water until dissolved; cool.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.

dessert.description: Turks and Caicos rum cake: a dense butter cake studded with rum-soaked raisins and drizzled with a warm rum glaze. This island celebration cake is the centerpiece of every holiday table, its boozy sweetness deepening with each day it sits—proof that the best Caribbean baking comes from patience and good rum.
ingredients: 1/2 cup (120 ml) dark rum, plus 3 tbsp for the glaze
1/2 lb (225 g / 2 sticks) unsalted butter, softened
For the glaze: 1/2 cup (100 g) granulated sugar
steps: Soak raisins in 1/2 cup (120 ml) rum overnight, or at least 2 hours.
Preheat oven to 325°F (165°C). Grease and flour a 9-inch (23 cm) bundt pan.
Cream butter and sugar until light and fluffy, about 4 minutes. Beat in eggs one at a time.
Whisk flour, baking powder, salt, and nutmeg together. Add to the batter alternately with milk, beginning and ending with flour. Stir in vanilla.
Fold in the rum-soaked raisins along with any remaining rum.
Pour into the prepared pan. Bake 50–60 minutes until a skewer comes out clean.
While cake is warm, make the glaze: simmer sugar and water until dissolved, remove from heat, and stir in rum.
Poke holes all over the warm cake with a skewer. Slowly spoon the rum glaze over, letting it soak in.
Cool completely before unmolding. The cake improves over 1–2 days as the rum flavor deepens.

TCD.description: A Chadian staple: a firm millet (or sorghum) boule served with a savory okra-tomato sauce.
ingredients: 2 medium tomatoes, chopped (or 1 (14 oz) can diced tomatoes)
1 tsp kosher salt (plus more to taste)
steps: Make the sauce: heat oil in a pot. Sauté onion until soft. Add garlic 30 seconds.
Add okra, tomatoes, water/stock, salt, pepper, and chile (if using). Simmer 15–20 minutes until okra is tender and sauce thickens. Keep warm.
Make the boule: bring 4 cups water and salt to a boil in a heavy pot.
Reduce heat to low. Whisk in millet flour gradually until thick. Switch to a sturdy spoon and stir vigorously 5 minutes.
Cover and cook on very low 10 minutes, stirring every couple of minutes, until smooth and elastic.
Shape boule into balls with a wet spoon. Serve with okra sauce.

drink.description: A tart hibiscus drink popular in Chad and the Sahel, served hot or iced.
steps: Bring water to a boil with hibiscus and (if using) cinnamon and ginger. Boil 2 minutes, then turn off heat.
Cover and steep 15–20 minutes.
Strain, sweeten, and serve hot, or chill and serve over ice.

dessert.description: Chadian millet porridge sweetened with sugar and flavored with vanilla—a smooth, comforting Sahelian dessert served warm in bowls. This humble porridge is nursery food, street food, and celebration food all at once, its gentle sweetness a welcome counterpoint to Chad's fiery stews.
ingredients: 1/3 cup (65 g) granulated sugar, or to taste
1 cup (240 ml) whole milk (optional, for serving)
steps: Dissolve millet flour in 1 cup (240 ml) of cold water, whisking until smooth with no lumps.
Bring the remaining 3 cups (710 ml) water to a boil in a heavy pot.
Slowly pour the millet slurry into the boiling water, stirring constantly to prevent lumps.
Reduce heat to low. Cook 15–20 minutes, stirring frequently, until the porridge is thick and smooth.
Stir in sugar, vanilla, and salt. Cook another 2 minutes.
Serve warm in bowls, drizzled with milk if desired.

TGO.description: Togo's beloved comfort meal: smooth pounded yam fufu served with a rich, thick peanut soup loaded with tomatoes, onions, and tender pieces of meat. The peanut sauce clings to each piece of fufu, creating the ultimate Togolese soul food.
ingredients: 2 lb (900 g) yam, peeled and cubed (or 2 cups instant fufu flour)
1 lb (450 g) chicken pieces or goat meat
3 medium tomatoes, chopped (or 1 (14 oz / 400 g) can crushed tomatoes)
2 tbsp (30 ml) palm oil or vegetable oil
steps: Season and brown the meat in oil. Add onion, garlic, and ginger; sauté 3 minutes.
Add tomatoes and cook 5 minutes until broken down.
Stir in peanut butter and water/stock. Bring to a boil, then reduce and simmer 30–40 minutes until meat is tender and sauce is thick.
Add Scotch bonnet whole (do not burst). Season with salt. Simmer 5 more minutes.
For the fufu: boil yam until very soft, then pound in a mortar until smooth and stretchy (or mix instant fufu flour with hot water per package directions).
Serve fufu alongside the peanut soup for dipping.

drink.description: Togo's refreshing hibiscus drink: dried hibiscus flowers steeped in water with ginger and sugar, served ice-cold. A West African staple found at every market and celebration.
ingredients: 1/2 cup (100 g) granulated sugar, or to taste
steps: Bring water to a boil. Add hibiscus flowers and ginger. Boil 5 minutes.
Remove from heat, cover, and steep 15 minutes.
Strain through a fine sieve. Stir in sugar and lime juice while still warm.
Chill thoroughly. Serve over ice.

dessert.description: Togolese coconut balls: fresh grated coconut cooked with sugar into sticky, sweet balls. Simple and beloved, these little bites are sold at every Lomé market stall and street corner—warm, fragrant, and impossibly addictive with their caramelized coconut sweetness.
ingredients: 3 cups (225 g) freshly grated coconut (or unsweetened desiccated coconut)
steps: Combine sugar and water in a heavy saucepan. Cook over medium heat, stirring, until sugar dissolves and syrup begins to simmer.
Add grated coconut, vanilla, and salt. Stir constantly over medium heat for 10–15 minutes until the mixture is thick, sticky, and pulls away from the sides of the pan.
Remove from heat. Let cool just enough to handle.
With lightly oiled hands, pinch off small portions and roll into balls about 1 inch (2.5 cm) in diameter.
Place on parchment paper to cool completely. Serve at room temperature.

THA.description: A balance of sweet, sour, and salty. Essential street food.
ingredients: Sauce: 3 tbsp Tamarind paste, 3 tbsp Fish Sauce, 2 tbsp Palm Sugar
steps: Soak noodles in warm water for 30 mins (don't boil).
Mix sauce ingredients. Taste—it should be tangy and funky.
Sear tofu and shrimp in wok. Push aside.
Add noodles and a splash of water. Stir fry until soft.
Add the sauce. Stir to coat noodles.
Push noodles aside. Scramble eggs in the empty space.
Toss everything together with sprouts, chives, and peanuts.
Serve with lime wedge and chili flakes.

drink.description: Sweet, creamy, and strongly brewed tea poured over ice—an iconic Thai street drink.
ingredients: 2 tbsp Thai tea mix (or strong black tea)
1–2 tbsp evaporated milk or whole milk
steps: Bring water to a boil, add tea, and steep 4–5 minutes.
Strain and cool slightly.
Stir in condensed milk; adjust sweetness.
Fill a glass with ice and pour tea over.
Drizzle evaporated milk (or whole milk) on top and serve.

dessert.description: Sweet sticky rice topped with ripe mango slices and drizzled with warm coconut cream and crispy mung beans—Bangkok's most perfect dessert. The sticky rice is soaked, steamed, and bathed in sweetened coconut milk until each grain glistens, then crowned with golden mango and a final drizzle of salted coconut cream.
steps: Soak sticky rice in water for at least 4 hours, or overnight. Drain.
Steam the rice in a bamboo steamer lined with cheesecloth for 20–25 minutes until tender and translucent.
While rice steams, warm coconut milk with sugar and salt until dissolved. Do not boil.
Transfer hot steamed rice to a bowl. Pour the sweetened coconut milk over. Gently fold and let sit 15 minutes, allowing rice to absorb the liquid.
Mound sticky rice on a plate. Fan mango slices alongside.
Drizzle warm coconut cream sauce over the rice. Sprinkle with crispy mung beans if using.
Serve at room temperature within 2 hours for the best texture.

ingredients: 1 cup (240 ml) coconut cream (thick top of a can)
steps: Warm coconut cream in a small saucepan over low heat.
Stir in sugar and salt until dissolved.
Keep warm until ready to drizzle. It should be pourable, not thick.
Soak tamarind pulp in hot water 15–20 minutes.
Mash thoroughly, then press through a sieve to remove fibers/seeds.
Use immediately or refrigerate up to 1 week.

TJK.description: Tajikistan’s beloved pilaf: rice steamed over a rich ‘zirvak’ base of browned meat, onions, and carrots—so culturally central it’s recognized on UNESCO’s Intangible Cultural Heritage list.
ingredients: 2 lb (900 g) lamb or beef, cut into chunks
4 large carrots, cut into matchsticks (about 6 cups / 600 g)
2 tbsp whole cumin seeds (zira), lightly crushed
1 tbsp kosher salt, plus more to taste
3 cups (600 g) long-grain rice, rinsed until water runs mostly clear
1 whole head of garlic, outer papery skin removed
Hot water, as needed (about 5–6 cups / 1.2–1.4 L)
steps: Heat oil in a heavy pot. Add onions and fry until deep golden.
Add meat and brown well. Add carrots and cook 5 minutes.
Add cumin and salt. Pour in hot water to just cover. Simmer 30–45 minutes to make the zirvak.
Spread rinsed rice over the top (do not stir). Add enough hot water so it sits about 1 inch (2.5 cm) above the rice.
When water is mostly absorbed, push garlic head into the rice. Cover tightly and steam on very low heat 20–25 minutes.
Rest off heat 10 minutes, then gently fluff, bringing some carrots/meat through. Serve hot.

drink.description: A simple, homey drink across Central Asia: fruit (often dried) simmered in water and lightly sweetened, served chilled.
ingredients: 8 oz (225 g) mixed dried fruit (apricots, apples, raisins, prunes)
1/4–1/2 cup (50–100 g) sugar or honey, to taste
steps: Rinse dried fruit. Combine with water (and cinnamon/lemon if using) in a pot.
Bring to a boil, then simmer 15–20 minutes until fruit plumps and flavors the liquid.
Sweeten to taste. Cool, then chill.
Serve cold with some fruit in the glass if you like.

dessert.description: Tajik flour halva: wheat flour slowly toasted in butter until deeply golden, then cooked with sugar syrup into a dense, rich sweet. Served at every Tajik celebration—from Navruz to weddings—this halva fills the house with a nutty, caramelized aroma that signals something joyous is happening.
steps: Melt butter in a heavy-bottomed pan over medium-low heat.
Add flour and stir constantly for 20–30 minutes, toasting until the flour turns a deep golden-brown and smells nutty. Do not rush—low and slow is essential.
While flour toasts, make the syrup: dissolve sugar in water over medium heat, bring to a boil, then simmer 2 minutes. Stir in cardamom if using.
Carefully pour the hot sugar syrup into the toasted flour mixture (it will bubble vigorously). Stir rapidly until the mixture pulls together into a smooth, thick mass.
Cook another 2–3 minutes, stirring, until the halva pulls away from the sides of the pan.
Press into a greased dish or shape into a mound. Garnish with pistachios or walnuts.
Cool slightly and serve warm or at room temperature, cut into squares or diamonds.

TKM.description: Often presented as Turkmenistan’s national dish: a hearty stuffed flatbread/pie filled with seasoned meat and vegetables, baked until browned.
ingredients: For dough: 4 cups (480 g) all-purpose flour, plus more for dusting
3 tbsp (45 ml) melted butter or oil
For filling: 1 lb (450 g) ground lamb (or beef)
steps: Make dough: mix flour and salt, add water and melted butter/oil, knead until smooth. Rest covered 30 minutes.
Mix filling ingredients; add a splash of water so it’s moist but not soupy.
Heat oven to 450°F (230°C).
Divide dough into 4 balls. Roll each into a large thin round. Place filling on one half, leaving a border.
Fold over to a half-moon and crimp edges tightly. Poke a few small vents.
Bake on a hot baking sheet 18–25 minutes until browned and cooked through. Rest 5 minutes before slicing.

drink.description: A cooling dairy drink common in Turkmen cuisine: yogurt thinned with water and lightly salted, sometimes fizzy if lightly fermented.
steps: Whisk yogurt and water until smooth and frothy.
Season with salt (and mint if using). Serve very cold.

dessert.description: Turkmen fried dough balls: small pieces of yeasted dough deep-fried until golden and coated in sugar syrup. The Turkmen celebration sweet found at every Novruz table and wedding spread—crisp on the outside, pillowy within, and glistening with sweet syrup.
ingredients: For the syrup: 1 cup (200 g) granulated sugar
steps: Mix flour, yeast, sugar, and salt. Add warm milk, egg, and melted butter. Knead into a soft, smooth dough, about 5 minutes.
Cover and let rise in a warm place for 1 hour until doubled.
Make the syrup: dissolve sugar in water, bring to a boil, add lemon juice, and simmer 5 minutes until slightly thickened. Keep warm.
Punch down dough. Pinch off small pieces (about 1 inch / 2.5 cm) and roll into balls.
Heat oil to 350°F (175°C). Fry dough balls in batches, turning, until golden brown all over, about 3–4 minutes.
Drain briefly on paper towels, then immediately toss in warm sugar syrup until coated.
Pile onto a serving plate. Serve warm or at room temperature.

TLS.dish: Batar Da'an (Batar Da’an) — Corn, Mung Bean & Squash Stew
TLS.description: A comforting Timor-Leste staple: corn, beans, and squash simmered into a simple, nourishing stew that’s both everyday food and a symbol of resilience.
ingredients: 1/2 lb (225 g) dried mung beans, rinsed
1 lb (450 g) corn kernels (fresh or frozen)
2 lb (900 g) pumpkin or butternut squash, peeled and diced
2 tsp kosher salt, plus more to taste
steps: Simmer mung beans in 4 cups (950 ml) water until nearly tender, 25–35 minutes.
Add corn and squash and simmer 15–20 minutes until squash is tender.
In a skillet, sauté onions in oil until golden, add garlic 30 seconds, then scrape into the pot.
Season with salt and pepper. Add water as needed for a stew consistency. Serve hot.

drink.description: Timor-Leste is known for its coffee. Brew it strong and serve simply; many households sweeten it lightly.
steps: Brew coffee strong (pour-over, French press, or moka pot).
Sweeten to taste; add condensed milk if desired.
Serve hot.

dessert.description: Timorese coconut rice cake: ground rice mixed with coconut milk, palm sugar, and pandan, baked in banana leaf cups until set and fragrant. A Portuguese-Timorese sweet that bridges two colonial culinary traditions, with the tropical perfume of pandan and palm sugar making it unmistakably Southeast Asian.
ingredients: 1 cup (200 g) palm sugar (gula Jawa), grated or chopped
1 tsp pandan extract (or 3 pandan leaves, knotted)
Banana leaves for lining (or parchment paper)
steps: If using pandan leaves, simmer them in the coconut milk for 5 minutes, then cool and discard the leaves.
Dissolve palm sugar in warm coconut milk, stirring until smooth. Strain if needed.
Whisk rice flour, eggs, coconut cream, salt, pandan extract (if using), and melted butter into the coconut-sugar mixture until smooth.
Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Line a 9-inch (23 cm) round pan or individual cups with banana leaves (or parchment).
Pour batter into the prepared pan(s).
Bake 35–45 minutes (15–20 for individual cups) until set and the top is golden brown.
Cool slightly. Serve warm or at room temperature.

TTO.description: The ultimate 'lime' (hangout) food. This one-pot wonder begins with 'browning'—caramelizing sugar in hot oil until nearly burnt—which gives the chicken and rice its signature nutty, sweet-savory depth. It's a melting pot of African, Indian, and colonial influences.
ingredients: Green Seasoning (blended herbs: culantro, scallion, garlic, thyme)
steps: Season chicken with Green Seasoning. Marinate.
Heat oil in a heavy pot. Add sugar. Let it melt and bubble until dark frothy brown (burnt sugar).
Immediately add chicken and stir to coat. Cook for 5 mins.
Add rice, peas, pumpkin, and coconut milk. Stir.
Cover and simmer until liquid is absorbed and rice is tender.
Serve with coleslaw and a slice of avocado.

drink.description: Trinidad and Tobago’s famed swizzle: rum, lime, and bitters churned with crushed ice until frosty.
steps: Fill a tall glass with crushed ice.
Add rum, lime juice, and simple syrup.
Swizzle (or stir vigorously) until the glass frosts.
Add bitters on top and serve with a straw.
Note (simple syrup): stir equal parts sugar + hot water until dissolved; cool.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.

dessert.description: Trinidad and Tobago's coconut bread: a rich, dense sweet bread loaded with grated coconut, dried fruits, and warm spices. Every Trini bakery essential, this beloved bread perfumes the oven with cinnamon and nutmeg while the coconut caramelizes into sweet, chewy pockets throughout. Sliced thick and eaten any time of day.
ingredients: 2 cups (160 g) freshly grated coconut (or desiccated coconut)
1/2 cup (75 g) mixed dried fruit (raisins, cherries, mixed peel)
1/4 lb (115 g / 1 stick) unsalted butter, melted
steps: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Grease a 9x5-inch (23x13 cm) loaf pan.
Whisk together flour, sugar, baking powder, salt, cinnamon, nutmeg, and allspice.
Stir in grated coconut and dried fruit until evenly distributed.
In a separate bowl, whisk melted butter, coconut milk, eggs, vanilla, and almond extract.
Pour wet ingredients into dry. Fold together until just combined—do not overmix.
Pour into the prepared pan. Bake 55–65 minutes until golden and a skewer comes out clean.
Cool in the pan 10 minutes, then turn out onto a rack. Serve warm or at room temperature, sliced thick.
Blend everything into a thick green paste, adding water as needed.
Refrigerate up to 1 week, or freeze in ice-cube portions.

TUR.description: From Bursa, Turkey. Doner meat served over bread with tomato sauce and butter.
ingredients: 1 lb Lamb/Beef Doner slices (or thinly sliced roast lamb)
steps: Cut pide bread into cubes. Toast lightly in oven.
Heat the meat in a pan.
Prepare a simple tomato sauce with butter, tomato paste, and water.
Brown the sheep's butter in a small pan until nutty.
Assembly: Layer the bread cubes on a plate. Top generously with meat.
Pour hot tomato sauce over the meat.
Drizzle the sizzling browned butter over everything.
Serve with a dollop of cold yogurt on the side.

drink.description: Strong black tea served in small tulip-shaped glasses.
steps: Brew strong tea (often via a two-pot çaydanlık method).
Dilute with hot water to taste and serve.

dessert.description: Turkish shredded phyllo and cheese dessert: crispy kataifi noodles encasing melted cheese, baked golden and soaked in sweet syrup, topped with crushed pistachios. Hatay's gift to the world—when done right, the knife crunches through the golden, buttery crust into a stretchy, molten cheese heart, all bathed in fragrant syrup. It must be served immediately, the contrast of hot cheese and cold syrup sending up wisps of sweet steam.
ingredients: 1 lb (450 g) kataifi (shredded phyllo dough), thawed
1/2 lb (225 g / 2 sticks) unsalted butter, melted
1 lb (450 g) fresh unsalted mozzarella or künefe cheese (dil peyniri), shredded
1/4 cup (30 g) crushed pistachios for garnish
steps: Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C) or heat a wide, shallow pan over medium.
Separate and loosen the kataifi strands. Toss with melted butter until every strand is coated.
Press half the kataifi into the bottom of a 10-inch (25 cm) round baking dish or pan in an even layer.
Spread the shredded cheese evenly over the kataifi. Top with the remaining kataifi, pressing down firmly.
Bake 25–30 minutes until the top and bottom are deep golden and crispy (or cook in the pan, flipping once, until golden on both sides).
Immediately pour cold simple syrup evenly over the hot künefe. Let it sizzle and absorb for 1 minute.
Invert onto a serving plate. Top with crushed pistachios.
Serve immediately—künefe waits for no one.

ingredients: 1 tbsp rose water or orange blossom water (optional)
steps: Combine sugar, water, and lemon juice in a saucepan. Stir over medium heat until sugar dissolves.
Bring to a boil and simmer 8–10 minutes until slightly thickened.
Stir in rose water if using. Cool completely before using—the syrup must be cold when poured over hot künefe.

TWN.dish: Taiwanese Beef Noodle Soup (紅燒牛肉麵)
TWN.description: Taiwan’s most iconic bowl: beef shank braised with doubanjiang, aromatics, and warm spices into a deep red broth, served with wheat noodles and pickled mustard greens.
ingredients: 2 lb (900 g) beef shank or brisket, cut into large chunks
1/4 cup (60 ml) Shaoxing wine (or dry sherry)
2 tbsp (25 g) rock sugar or brown sugar
1 lb (450 g) fresh or dried wheat noodles
steps: Blanch beef: cover beef with cold water, bring to a boil 3 minutes, drain and rinse.
Heat oil in a pot. Fry doubanjiang 1 minute. Add garlic, ginger, and scallions; cook until fragrant.
Add beef, soy sauce, wine, sugar, water/stock, and spices. Bring to a boil, then simmer 1 1/2–2 hours until tender.
Remove beef to slice. Strain broth if you want it clean; return to pot and adjust seasoning.
Cook noodles per package. Divide noodles into bowls, ladle broth, add sliced beef, bok choy, and pickled mustard greens.

preliminary_steps.item: Quick Pickled Mustard Greens (酸菜 quick)
ingredients: 3 cups (250 g) mustard greens or napa cabbage, shredded
steps: Toss greens with salt and sugar; let sit 15 minutes, then squeeze out excess liquid.
Bring vinegar and water to a simmer, then cool slightly.
Pack greens in a jar and pour over brine. Chill at least 1 hour (better overnight).

drink.description: Taiwan’s most famous drink: black tea with milk and chewy tapioca pearls, usually sweetened and served over ice.
ingredients: 2 cups (475 ml) strongly brewed black tea, cooled
2–3 tbsp sugar or brown sugar syrup (see preliminary steps)
1 cup cooked tapioca pearls (see preliminary steps)
steps: Stir sweetener into the cooled tea, then stir in milk.
Fill a tall glass with ice and add cooked tapioca pearls.
Pour in milk tea and serve with a wide straw.

ingredients: 1/2 cup (85 g) dried black tapioca pearls
steps: Bring water to a rolling boil. Add pearls and stir so they don’t stick.
Boil 20–30 minutes (check package), until centers are no longer chalky.
Turn off heat, cover, and rest 10 minutes. Drain and rinse briefly.
Toss warm pearls with brown sugar to lightly glaze.
Simmer sugar and water 2–3 minutes until slightly thickened.
Cool; refrigerate up to 2 weeks.

dessert.description: Taiwan's iconic buttery shortbread-like pastry filled with tangy pineapple jam—the souvenir every tourist brings home and every Taipei bakery's signature. These golden rectangles shatter into crumbly, melt-in-your-mouth layers that give way to a sweet-tart, chewy pineapple filling. Originally inspired by Japanese confectionery techniques during colonial rule, fènglísū became uniquely Taiwanese when local bakers perfected the pairing of powdery, butter-rich pastry with the island's prized tǔ fènglí (pineapple jam made from local pineapples). The best versions balance a sandy, fragile crust against a concentrated, slightly fibrous jam that clings to your teeth.
ingredients: 1/2 cup (1 stick / 113 g) unsalted butter, cold and cubed
steps: Make the dough: Whisk flour, powdered sugar, milk powder, and salt. Cut in cold butter with a pastry cutter or pulse in a food processor until sandy.
Add egg yolk and cream. Mix until dough just comes together. Wrap in plastic and refrigerate 30 minutes.
Divide dough into 12 equal portions (about 25 g each). Divide chilled pineapple jam into 12 portions (about 18 g each).
Flatten a dough portion in your palm, place a jam ball in the center, and wrap the dough around it, sealing completely. Roll smooth.
Press each ball into a rectangular pineapple cake mold (or shape by hand into small rectangles). Place on a parchment-lined baking sheet.
Bake at 340°F (170°C) for 20–25 minutes, rotating the pan halfway, until the edges are golden.
Cool completely in the molds before unmolding. The cakes firm up as they cool and taste best after resting overnight.

ingredients: 1 fresh pineapple (about 2 lb / 900 g), peeled, cored, and finely chopped
steps: Pulse the chopped pineapple in a food processor until finely shredded but not pureed.
Combine pineapple, sugar, and lemon juice in a heavy-bottomed saucepan. Cook over medium heat, stirring frequently, 40–50 minutes until the mixture is thick, jammy, and dark golden.
Stir in butter and cook 2 more minutes. The jam should hold its shape when mounded on a spoon.
Transfer to a bowl, press plastic wrap on the surface, and refrigerate until firm (at least 2 hours).

Taiwan.description: The national dish of Taiwan. Braised beef shank, tendon, and chewy noodles swim in a dark, aromatic broth infused with soy sauce, chili bean paste, and Chinese herbs. It is often served with pickled mustard greens.
ingredients: Broth: Star Anise, Cinnamon, Fennel, Ginger, Garlic, Doubanjiang (Bean Paste), Soy Sauce, Rock Sugar
steps: Blanch beef. Sauté aromatics and bean paste.
Add beef, soy sauce, sugar, and water. Simmer for 2-3 hours until tender.
Cook noodles separately.
Assemble: Noodles, Beef, Broth, blanched Bok Choy.
Top generously with pickled mustard greens and scallions.

drink.description: Taiwan’s most famous modern drink: sweet milk tea with chewy tapioca pearls (boba).
ingredients: 2 tbsp brown sugar (for syrup) + 2 tbsp water
1 cup (240 ml) strong black tea, chilled
steps: Boil tapioca pearls in water per package directions until chewy; drain.
Make brown sugar syrup: simmer brown sugar + water 1–2 minutes until glossy.
Toss warm pearls in syrup and let sit 5 minutes.
Add pearls to a glass, add ice, then pour in tea and milk; stir and serve with a wide straw.
Warm brown sugar and water in a saucepan, stirring until dissolved.
Cool and bottle; refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.

ingredients: 1 medium napa cabbage (about 2 lbs), cut into large pieces
2 tbsp kosher salt (about 2% by weight; adjust for cabbage size)
Optional: 2–3 slices ginger or a few Sichuan peppercorns
steps: Toss cabbage with salt and massage 2–3 minutes until it starts releasing liquid.
Pack tightly into a clean jar or crock. Add enough water to submerge if needed (a light brine).
Weight cabbage under the brine (use a fermentation weight or a small bag filled with brine).
Ferment at cool room temperature 3–7 days until pleasantly sour. Skim any surface foam as needed.
Refrigerate when it tastes right. Rinse before cooking if very salty/sour.

preliminary_steps.item: Pixian Doubanjiang (Fermented Chili Bean Paste) – sourcing note
ingredients: Authentic option: Pixian doubanjiang (recommended to purchase)
steps: Pixian doubanjiang is a long-fermented chili broad-bean paste; the traditional process takes months.
For authenticity, purchase a reputable Pixian doubanjiang and use as directed in the recipe.
If the recipe calls for cooking it, stir-fry it briefly in oil to ‘bloom’ the flavor before adding liquids.

UGA.description: Uganda's national dish. Green bananas (bitooke), or plantains outside East Africa, are steamed and mashed into a mild, slightly sweet staple—then topped with a rich groundnut (peanut) sauce. Central to Baganda culture; the word for food in Luganda is often synonymous with matoke. Served at weddings, family meals, and daily tables, often with beef stew or beans.
ingredients: 8–10 green plantains (or green cooking bananas), peeled and cut into 2-inch chunks
For the groundnut sauce: 1 cup creamy peanut butter or 1 cup finely ground roasted peanuts
Kosher salt and black pepper, to taste
steps: Put the plantain chunks in a pot with the water and salt. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer until tender, about 20–25 minutes. Drain; add milk and butter if using, then mash until smooth (like mashed potatoes). Keep warm.

For the sauce: In a large pan over medium heat, sauté the onion until softened, 4–5 minutes. Add the garlic and cook 30 seconds. Add the turmeric, cumin, coriander, bell pepper, and chile (if using); stir 1–2 minutes.

Add the vegetable broth and peanut butter (or ground peanuts). Whisk until smooth. Bring to a boil, then reduce to a simmer and cook 5–8 minutes, stirring often, until the sauce thickens. Season with salt and pepper. Stir in butter and cilantro if using.
Serve the mashed matoke in bowls, topped generously with the groundnut sauce.

drink.description: A traditional Ugandan fermented drink from the southwest: ripe bananas mashed and fermented with sorghum flour (or millet). Sweet, slightly tangy, and mildly alcoholic; often served in calabashes at weddings, births, and communal gatherings.
ingredients: 6 very ripe bananas (the riper, the better)
1/2 cup sorghum flour (lightly toasted in a dry pan)
1/4 tsp active dry yeast (optional, for reliability)
steps: Peel the bananas into a large bowl and mash thoroughly until smooth.
Add the warm water and mix well. Strain through a fine sieve or cheesecloth into a clean fermentation jar.
Stir in the toasted sorghum flour and salt. Add the yeast (if using).
Cover loosely and ferment at room temperature 12–24 hours until lightly effervescent and aromatic.
Strain again if desired, chill, and serve cold.

dessert.description: Uganda's sweet street-side treat—ripe bananas mashed with cassava flour and fried into golden, crispy-edged pancakes with a soft, sweet center. Sold by vendors across Kampala wrapped in banana leaves, kabalagala transform overripe bananas into something magical. The cassava flour gives them a distinctive chewy texture that wheat flour cannot replicate. Simple, satisfying, and beloved by every generation of Ugandans.
ingredients: 4 very ripe bananas, peeled and mashed
1 cup (130 g) cassava flour (or substitute 1/2 cup cassava flour + 1/2 cup all-purpose flour)
1/4 cup (60 ml) water (as needed for consistency)
steps: Mash the bananas thoroughly in a bowl until smooth with no large lumps.
Add cassava flour, sugar, cinnamon, and salt. Mix until a thick, scoopable batter forms. Add water a tablespoon at a time if too thick—it should be thicker than regular pancake batter.
Heat about 1/4 inch (6 mm) of oil in a skillet over medium heat.
Drop heaping spoonfuls of batter into the hot oil and flatten slightly with the back of the spoon.
Fry 2–3 minutes per side until deep golden brown and crispy on the edges.
Drain on paper towels. Serve warm—best eaten immediately with tea.
Toast the sorghum flour in a dry skillet over medium heat, stirring constantly, until lightly nutty and fragrant, 3–5 minutes.
Cool completely before adding to the drink.

UKR.description: The crimson soul of Ukraine. This sour beet soup is not just a dish but a cultural touchstone. Packed with vegetables and often meat, its signature deep red color and sweet-sour balance come from beets and fermented beet sour (kvass) or vinegar.
ingredients: 1 lb Beef shank or ribs (for broth)
1 tbsp Vinegar or Lemon juice (to keep color)
steps: Make broth: Boil beef in water for 1.5 hours. Skim foam.
Add potatoes and cabbage to broth. Cook 15 mins.
Sauté onion and carrot in oil. Add grated beets, vinegar, and tomato paste. Simmer for 10 mins.
Add the beet mixture to the soup pot. Simmer another 10 mins.
Add garlic and fresh dill. Turn off heat. Let sit for 20 mins (flavors meld).
Serve with a dollop of sour cream and Pampushky (garlic bread).

drink.description: A traditional Ukrainian-style pepper vodka: horilka infused with hot peppers and honey for a warm, aromatic bite.
steps: Combine horilka/vodka, chili peppers, honey, and optional peppercorns/lemon peel in a clean jar.
Seal and shake until honey dissolves.
Infuse 24–72 hours, tasting daily until heat level is right.
Strain out peppers (and spices) and bottle.
Rest at least 1 day before serving; serve chilled in small glasses.

dessert.description: Kyiv Cake—Ukraine's most famous and elaborate dessert: two layers of crispy, airy hazelnut-almond meringue sandwiching rich buttercream, decorated elaborately with rosettes and chocolate accents. Created in 1956 at the Karl Marx Confectionery (now Roshen) in Kyiv, reportedly by accident when a confectioner forgot to refrigerate egg whites overnight. The result—crunchy, nutty meringue yielding to smooth, vanilla-scented buttercream—became an instant Soviet-era icon and remains Ukraine's most treasured celebratory cake, unmistakable in its green-and-chestnut-leaf decorated box.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 g) dark chocolate, melted (for drizzling)
1/4 cup (30 g) toasted hazelnuts, roughly chopped (for garnish)
steps: Place one meringue layer on a serving plate. Spread a generous, thick layer of buttercream (about half) over the top.
Gently place the second meringue layer on top. Press lightly to adhere.
Frost the top and sides with the remaining buttercream, smoothing with an offset spatula.
Drizzle melted dark chocolate over the top in thin lines. Press chopped toasted hazelnuts around the sides.
Refrigerate at least 4 hours (overnight is best) so the meringue softens slightly against the buttercream, creating the signature contrast of crunchy edges and soft interior.
Remove from the refrigerator 20 minutes before serving. Slice with a sharp serrated knife.

ingredients: 6 large egg whites, at room temperature
1 cup (100 g) hazelnuts, toasted and finely ground
1/2 cup (50 g) almonds, toasted and finely ground
steps: Preheat oven to 300°F (150°C). Line two baking sheets with parchment and trace a 9-inch (23 cm) circle on each.
Whip egg whites with cream of tartar until soft peaks. Gradually add sugar and whip to stiff, glossy peaks.
Fold in ground hazelnuts, almonds, and flour gently in three additions—do not deflate.
Divide meringue between the two circles and spread evenly to the edges.
Bake 60–75 minutes until the meringues are crisp and dry on the outside but still slightly soft within. Turn off the oven and let them cool inside with the door cracked.

ingredients: 1 cup (2 sticks / 227 g) unsalted butter, softened
steps: Beat butter with an electric mixer until light and fluffy, about 4 minutes.
Add powdered sugar gradually, beating after each addition.
Stream in sweetened condensed milk and vanilla. Beat on high 3–4 minutes until silky smooth.
Add salt and adjust sweetness. Refrigerate 15 minutes if too soft to spread.

URY.description: The 'Little Goat' that contains no goat. Created in 1946 for a tourist who asked for goat meat, a quick-thinking chef threw a beef tenderloin on a bun and piled it high with ham, cheese, bacon, and egg. It became a national obsession and a monument to excess.
steps: Season beef and sear quickly on a hot griddle.
Place ham and cheese on top of the steak to melt.
Toast the bun. Spread generous mayonnaise.
Assemble: Bun, lettuce, tomato, steak with ham/cheese, bacon, egg, top bun.
Serve with French fries and Russian salad.

drink.description: Uruguay is strongly associated with mate (often prepared very strong).
steps: Prepare and sip as traditional mate, refilling with hot water repeatedly.

dessert.description: Uruguay's signature celebration cake—a tower of sponge cake soaked in peach syrup, layered with whipped cream, dulce de leche, and crumbled meringue. Created in 1927 by Orlando Castellano at Confitería Las Familias in Paysandú, it was named after the chajá bird (Southern screamer) because its layered lightness resembles the bird's fluffy plumage. Every Uruguayan birthday and holiday demands a chajá, and the city of Paysandú still claims rightful ownership of this cloud-like masterpiece.
ingredients: 1 round sponge cake (9-inch / 23 cm), sliced into 2 horizontal layers (store-bought or homemade)
1 can (15 oz / 425 g) peach halves in syrup, drained (reserve 1/2 cup / 120 ml syrup)
4 oz (115 g) store-bought meringue cookies, roughly crumbled
steps: Slice peach halves into thin wedges. Set aside.
Whip the heavy cream with sugar and vanilla to stiff peaks. Refrigerate.
Place the bottom sponge layer on a serving plate. Brush generously with half the reserved peach syrup.
Spread a layer of dulce de leche over the soaked sponge. Arrange half the peach slices on top. Spread a thick layer of whipped cream and scatter half the meringue crumbles.
Place the second sponge layer on top. Brush with remaining peach syrup.
Cover the top and sides with the remaining whipped cream. Arrange remaining peach slices on top, scatter the rest of the meringue crumbles, and dust with powdered sugar.
Refrigerate at least 2 hours before serving so the layers meld. Slice with a wet knife for clean cuts.

USA.description: The undisputed icon of American cuisine. Evolving from the steak tartare of Hamburg, Germany, it became an American phenomenon in the 20th century. A perfectly seared beef patty, melted American cheese, and a soft bun represent the ultimate comfort food exported to the globe.
steps: Divide beef into 4 loose balls. Do not overwork the meat.
Heat a cast-iron skillet or grill to high heat.
Place beef balls on hot surface and smash flat with a spatula. Season generously with salt and pepper.
Cook for 2-3 mins until a deep crust forms. Flip.
Place cheese on patties. Cook 1 min until cheese melts.
Toast the buns on the grill.
Assemble: Bun, sauce, lettuce, tomato, patty, onion, pickles, top bun.

Alabama.description: A Northern Alabama icon invented by Big Bob Gibson in 1925. Unlike the tomato-based sauces of the rest of the country, this tangy, peppery, mayonnaise-based sauce keeps smoked chicken incredibly moist.
ingredients: Sauce: 2 cups Mayonnaise, 1 cup Apple Cider Vinegar
steps: Season chicken with salt and pepper. Smoke at 250°F (120°C) with hickory wood until internal temp reaches 160°F.
Whisk sauce ingredients together. It should be thin and tangy.
Dunk the hot chicken completely into the white sauce (or brush heavily).
Return to grill for 10 mins to set the sauce.
Serve with extra white sauce on the side.

drink.description: A classic sweet highball associated with Alabama.
steps: Fill a highball glass with ice.
Add Southern Comfort, amaretto, and sloe gin.
Top with orange juice and stir gently.
Garnish if desired.

Alaska.description: The taste of the last frontier. Fresh Copper River salmon is grilled on cedar planks and glazed with a reduction of wild Alaskan berries (blueberries, cranberries, or salmonberries), marrying the ocean and the tundra.
ingredients: 1 side Wild Alaskan Salmon (Sockeye or King)
steps: Simmer berries, honey, and vinegar until berries burst and sauce thickens into a glaze. Strain if desired.
Place salmon on the soaked cedar plank. Season with salt and pepper.
Grill covered on medium-high heat.
Brush generously with berry glaze during the last 5 minutes of cooking.
Serve immediately on the plank.

drink.description: A layered shot popular in Alaska.
steps: Pour coffee liqueur into a shot glass.
Carefully layer Irish cream over the back of a spoon.
Layer whisky on top.
Serve as a layered shot.

Arizona.description: The accidental invention of Tucson. Legend says a burrito was dropped into a deep fryer, and the cook exclaimed 'Chimichanga!' (thingamajig) instead of a curse word. It is now the crispy, golden soul of Sonoran-Mexican cuisine.
ingredients: Filling: 1 lb Shredded Beef (Machaca) or Chicken
steps: Warm tortillas. Place meat, beans, and cheese in the center.
Fold in sides and roll tightly (secure with toothpick if needed).
Deep fry at 375°F (190°C) until golden brown and crispy.
Drain and serve smothered in cheese and sauce ('Enchilada style') or plain with dips.

drink.description: A tequila-and-citrus cocktail with a sunrise gradient.
steps: Fill a highball glass with ice.
Add tequila and orange juice; stir.
Slowly pour grenadine down the side; it will sink and create the gradient.
Garnish if desired.
Note (quick grenadine): simmer equal parts pomegranate juice + sugar until dissolved; cool before using.
Warm pomegranate juice and sugar in a saucepan over medium heat, stirring until dissolved (avoid a hard boil).
Cool; stir in orange blossom water if using.
Bottle; add vodka if using for shelf-life.
Refrigerate and use within 3–4 weeks (longer if vodka added).

Arkansas.description: The staple of the Delta. Farm-raised catfish is coated in a seasoned cornmeal crust and fried until it shatters, traditionally served with hushpuppies and pickled green tomatoes.
steps: Soak fillets in buttermilk for 30 mins.
Mix cornmeal, flour, and spices in a shallow dish.
Dredge fish in the mixture, pressing to adhere.
Fry in hot oil (350°F) for 5-7 minutes until floating and golden.
Serve hot with lemon and tartar sauce.

drink.description: A creamy, coffee-forward cocktail associated with Arkansas.
steps: Fill a shaker with ice.
Add vodka, rum, amaretto, coffee liqueur, and cream.
Shake well and strain into an ice-filled rocks glass.
Mix all spices thoroughly.
Store airtight up to 3 months.

California.description: San Francisco's answer to Bouillabaisse. Created by Italian fishermen in North Beach who chipped in ('chip in' -> cioppino) their catch of the day. It is a tomato-rich seafood stew loaded with Dungeness crab, clams, shrimp, and scallops.
ingredients: Broth: 1 can Crushed Tomatoes, 2 cups Fish Stock, 1 cup Red Wine, Onion, Garlic, Fennel, Basil
steps: Sauté onions, garlic, and herbs. Add wine, tomatoes, and stock. Simmer 30 mins.
Add clams and mussels. Cover and cook 5 mins.
Add crab, fish, and shrimp. Simmer gently until seafood is cooked through.
Serve in large bowls with sourdough bread to sop up the broth.

drink.description: A tiki classic (rum, citrus, and almond) often associated with California’s tiki culture.
steps: Add rum, lime juice, curaçao, orgeat, and simple syrup to a shaker with ice.
Shake briefly and pour into a glass filled with crushed ice.
Garnish if desired.
Note (simple syrup): stir equal parts sugar + hot water until dissolved; cool.
Note (quick orgeat): heat 1/2 cup almond milk + 1/2 cup sugar until dissolved; cool, then add a few drops of orange flower water if you have it.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.

ingredients: 1 1/2 cups unsweetened almond milk (or strained almond infusion)
1/2 tsp orange blossom water (or 1 tsp, to taste)
steps: Warm almond milk and sugar over medium heat, stirring until dissolved (do not boil hard).
Cool, then stir in orange blossom water (and rose water if using).
Bottle; add vodka if using.
Refrigerate and use within 2–3 weeks (longer if vodka added).

Colorado.description: The lifeblood of the Rockies. Not just a sauce, but a stew-like gravy made with Pueblo chiles, pork, and tomatoes. It is eaten in a bowl with tortillas or smothered over literally everything.
ingredients: 2 cups Roasted Green Chiles (Pueblo or Hatch), chopped
Chicken Stock, Cumin, Oregano, Flour (to thicken)
steps: Brown pork cubes in oil. Remove.
Sauté onion and garlic. Stir in flour to make a roux.
Add stock, tomatoes, spices, and pork.
Simmer for 1-2 hours until pork is tender.
Stir in the roasted green chiles. Simmer another 30 mins.
Serve with warm flour tortillas.

drink.description: A White Russian-style drink topped with cola.
steps: Fill a rocks glass with ice.
Add vodka and coffee liqueur.
Add cream and stir gently.
Top with a splash of cola.

Connecticut.description: The 'Apizza' legend of Frank Pepe. A thin, coal-fired crust topped simply with olive oil, oregano, garlic, grated pecorino, and fresh littleneck clams. No mozzarella, no tomato sauce—just pure briny perfection.
ingredients: Pizza Dough (high gluten flour, cold fermented)
1 dozen Littleneck Clams (shucked, chopped, keep juice)
steps: Stretch dough into a thin, oblong shape.
Brush heavily with olive oil.
Scatter garlic, oregano, and clams (with a little juice) over the dough.
Sprinkle generously with Pecorino.
Bake at max oven temp (ideally 500°F+ on a stone) until charred and bubbly.
Slice into irregular strips.

drink.description: A rum-and-ginger beer highball.
steps: Fill a highball glass with ice.
Add ginger beer and lime juice (if using).
Float dark rum on top.
Garnish with lime.
Note: ginger beer is usually purchased; in a pinch, use ginger ale (sweeter) or top with club soda and add a little ginger syrup.

Delaware.description: The culinary signature of the Delmarva Peninsula. Unlike fluffy Southern dumplings, these are large, flat, rectangular noodles made simply of flour and water, boiled directly in a rich, savory chicken broth until 'slippery' and tender.
steps: Boil chicken with celery, onion, and seasoning until tender. Remove chicken, shred meat, and return to pot.
Make dough: Mix flour, salt, and water until stiff. Roll out very thin on a floured surface.
Cut dough into 2-inch squares or rectangles.
Bring broth to a rolling boil. Drop dumplings in one by one.
Reduce heat and simmer until dumplings are tender and broth has thickened from the flour.
Serve hot.

drink.description: A bright citrus cocktail popular on the Mid-Atlantic coast.
steps: Fill a pint glass with ice.
Add vodka, triple sec, and orange juice; stir.
Top with lemon-lime soda.
Garnish with an orange wedge.
Mix thoroughly and crush rosemary slightly so it distributes evenly.
Store airtight up to 3 months.

Florida.description: The sandwich that built Tampa and Miami. Roast pork, sweet ham, Swiss cheese, pickles, and mustard are pressed between Cuban bread until the cheese melts and the crust cracks like eggshells.
steps: Slice bread open. Spread mustard on both sides.
Layer: Ham, Pork, Cheese, Pickles.
Close sandwich. Butter the outside crust.
Press in a plancha (sandwich press) until flat, hot, and crispy (cheese must melt).
Slice diagonally.

drink.description: A fruity vodka cocktail commonly associated with Florida.
steps: Fill a highball glass with ice.
Add vodka and peach schnapps.
Add cranberry and orange juice; stir.
Garnish if desired.

Georgia.description: Once a humble fisherman's breakfast, now a Southern delicacy. Plump wild Georgia shrimp are sautéed with bacon and served over creamy, stone-ground grits.
steps: Simmer grits in liquid until creamy (45 mins). Stir in butter and cheese.
Fry bacon until crisp. Remove, keep fat.
Sauté shrimp and garlic in bacon fat. Add a splash of lemon and stock to make a gravy.
Spoon grits into bowls. Top with shrimp, gravy, bacon bits, and scallions.

drink.description: A Southern Comfort cocktail commonly linked with Georgia.
steps: Fill a rocks glass with ice.
Add Southern Comfort, cranberry juice, and lime juice.
Stir and garnish.

Hawaii.description: The essence of the islands. 'Poke' means to slice or cut. Fresh raw yellowfin tuna is cubed and marinated in soy sauce, sesame oil, and seaweed. It is a dish that requires the highest quality fish.
ingredients: Inamona (Roasted Kukui nut) or Macadamia nuts
steps: Cut tuna into 3/4 inch cubes.
In a bowl, gently toss tuna with soy sauce, sesame oil, onions, and seaweed.
Sprinkle with crushed nuts and sesame seeds.
Serve immediately over warm rice or on its own.

drink.description: A tropical cocktail with blue curaçao and pineapple.
steps: Add rum, blue curaçao, pineapple juice, and cream of coconut to a shaker with ice.
Shake and strain into an ice-filled glass.
Note (quick cream of coconut): heat 1/2 cup coconut cream + 1/2 cup sugar until dissolved; cool.
Combine coconut milk, sugar, and salt in a saucepan.
Warm gently, stirring until sugar dissolves and mixture thickens slightly.
Cool and bottle; refrigerate up to 2 weeks. Shake before use.

Idaho.description: Idaho's claim to fame (besides potatoes). Strips of steak are battered and deep-fried, invented at the Torch Lounge in Boise. They are the ultimate bar food, best dipped in cocktail sauce.
ingredients: 1 lb Top Sirloin, cut into finger-sized strips
steps: Marinate steak strips in buttermilk and egg for 1 hour.
Season the flour with spices.
Dredge steak strips in flour.
Deep fry at 375°F (190°C) for 2-3 minutes until golden brown.
Serve with fry sauce or cocktail sauce.

drink.description: A whiskey sour accented with huckleberry (common in the Northwest).
ingredients: 3/4 oz huckleberry syrup (or huckleberry jam thinned with water)
steps: Add whiskey, lemon juice, and huckleberry syrup to a shaker with ice.
Shake and strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice.
Garnish if desired.
Simmer berries and water 5–8 minutes until berries burst.
Strain (optional), return liquid to pan, add sugar and lemon juice, and simmer 2–3 minutes until slightly syrupy.
Cool and bottle; refrigerate up to 2 weeks.

Illinois.description: Chicago's casserole-like pizza. A buttery, high-walled crust is filled with layers of mozzarella cheese, meat (sausage/pepperoni), and topped with a chunky tomato sauce. It is eaten with a knife and fork.
ingredients: Deep Dish Dough (with cornmeal and butter)
1 lb Italian Sausage (raw, removed from casing)
steps: Press dough into a deep cake pan or cast iron skillet, pushing up the sides.
Layer sliced mozzarella directly on the dough (prevents sogginess).
Press a layer of raw sausage over the cheese.
Top with the chunky tomato sauce. Sprinkle with parmesan.
Bake at 425°F (220°C) for 30-40 minutes until crust is golden.

drink.description: A classic American whiskey cocktail.
steps: Add syrup and bitters to a rocks glass.
Add whiskey and ice; stir until chilled.
Express orange peel over the glass and drop in.
Note (simple syrup): stir equal parts sugar + hot water until dissolved; cool.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.

Indiana.description: A sandwich that defies physics. A piece of pork loin is pounded until it is huge and thin, breaded, fried, and served on a bun that looks comically small in comparison.
steps: Pound pork chops between plastic wrap until very thin and wide (dinner plate size).
Dredge in flour, dip in egg wash, coat in crumbs.
Fry in oil until golden and crispy (about 3 mins per side).
Serve on a toasted bun with pickles and mustard. The meat should overhang the bun significantly.

drink.description: An Indiana-themed whiskey sour variation using apple cider and maple syrup.
steps: Add whiskey, apple cider, lemon juice, and maple syrup to a shaker with ice.
Shake hard until well chilled.
Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice (or serve up in a coupe).
Garnish with an apple slice if desired.

Iowa.description: The 'Loose Meat' sandwich. Ground beef is steamed and seasoned rather than fried into a patty, served on a bun with mustard and pickles. It's a sloppy, savory classic from 1926.
steps: Brown the beef and onion in a skillet. Break it up into fine crumbles.
Add broth, mustard, Worcestershire, and sugar.
Simmer until liquid evaporates but meat is moist and steamed.
Scoop onto warm buns. Serve with pickles.

drink.description: A mule made the Iowa way with rye (often associated with Templeton Rye) and ginger beer.
steps: Fill a copper mug or highball with ice.
Add rye and lime juice, then top with ginger beer.
Stir briefly and garnish with a lime wedge.

Kansas.description: The heart of American BBQ. Pork ribs are dry-rubbed, smoked low and slow over hickory, and finished with a thick, sweet, molasses-based tomato BBQ sauce.
ingredients: 2 racks St. Louis style Pork Ribs
Dry Rub: Brown sugar, Paprika, Garlic, Onion, Cayenne
KC BBQ Sauce: Ketchup, Molasses, Vinegar, Brown Sugar, Liquid Smoke
steps: Remove membrane from ribs. Massage with dry rub. Let sit 1 hour.
Smoke at 225°F (107°C) for 3-4 hours.
Wrap in foil with a little apple juice/butter. Cook 1 more hour.
Unwrap, brush with BBQ sauce, and grill 15 mins to caramelize.
Serve sticky and tender.

drink.description: A Kansas highball with whiskey, ginger, and bitters.
steps: Fill a highball with ice.
Add whiskey and bitters.
Top with ginger beer.
Squeeze lemon wedge in and drop it in.
Note: ginger beer is usually purchased; in a pinch, use ginger ale (sweeter) or top with club soda and add a little ginger syrup.

Kentucky.description: An open-faced sandwich created at the Brown Hotel in Louisville in 1926. Turkey and bacon are piled on toast, smothered in Mornay sauce, and broiled until bubbling.
ingredients: Mornay Sauce: Béchamel mixed with Pecorino/Romano cheese
steps: Place toast in an oven-safe dish. Top with turkey slices.
Pour Mornay sauce generously over the turkey.
Top with tomato slices and bacon strips.
Broil until the sauce is browned and bubbly.
Dust with paprika and serve hot.

drink.description: A Kentucky classic served over crushed ice.
steps: Lightly muddle mint with simple syrup in a julep cup.
Fill with crushed ice and add bourbon.
Stir until the cup frosts; top with more crushed ice.
Garnish with mint.
Note (simple syrup): stir equal parts sugar + hot water until dissolved; cool.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.

Louisiana.description: The melting pot of Louisiana. A dark roux-based stew influenced by French, African, and Spanish cuisines. It features the 'Holy Trinity' of vegetables, Andouille sausage, and filé powder (sassafras).
steps: Make the Roux: Cook flour and oil over medium heat, stirring constantly until it is the color of dark chocolate (30-45 mins). Do not burn.
Add the Trinity vegetables. Cook until soft.
