Add stock, whisking to combine. Add chicken, sausage, and seasonings.
Simmer for 1-2 hours. Skim fat.
Serve over white rice.

drink.description: A New Orleans rye cocktail finished with an absinthe rinse.
steps: Rinse a chilled rocks glass with absinthe; discard excess.
In a mixing glass, stir rye, syrup, and bitters with ice.
Strain into the rinsed glass (no ice, traditional).
Express lemon peel over the drink.
Note (simple syrup): stir equal parts sugar + hot water until dissolved; cool.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.
Mix all spices thoroughly.
Store airtight up to 3 months.

Maine.description: Summer on a bun. Sweet, cold chunks of fresh Maine lobster meat are lightly dressed with mayonnaise and served in a butter-toasted, split-top hot dog bun. Simple and luxurious.
ingredients: 1 lb Cooked Lobster Meat (claw and knuckle)
steps: Mix lobster meat with mayo, lemon, and celery. Season lightly with salt/pepper.
Generously butter the flat sides of the buns.
Toast buns in a pan until golden brown.
Stuff the cold lobster salad into the warm buns.
Serve with potato chips and a pickle.

drink.description: A Maine bar classic: Allen’s Coffee Brandy mixed with Moxie.
steps: Fill a highball with ice (optional).
Add Allen’s Coffee Brandy and top with chilled Moxie.
Stir gently. Add a splash of milk or cream if you like, and serve.

Maryland.description: The pride of the Chesapeake Bay. Made with jumbo lump blue crab meat and just enough filler to hold it together, seasoned heavily with Old Bay.
steps: Whisk egg, mayo, mustard, and spices.
Gently fold in the crab meat (do not break the lumps).
Fold in cracker crumbs just until combined.
Form into mounds. Refrigerate 30 mins.
Broil or pan-fry in butter until golden brown.
Serve with lemon wedges.

drink.description: The Preakness Stakes’ signature cocktail at Pimlico Race Course.
ingredients: Cherry and orange slice, for garnish
steps: Add vodka, St-Germain, sour mix, and orange juice to a shaker with ice.
Shake until well chilled.
Strain into a chilled Collins glass with fresh ice.
Garnish with a cherry and orange slice.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.
Whisk lemon juice, lime juice, and simple syrup together.
Bottle and refrigerate; use within 3–4 days for best flavor.

ingredients: 2 tsp crushed bay leaves (or 1 tsp ground bay)
steps: Mix all spices thoroughly.
Store airtight up to 3 months.

Massachusetts.description: A creamy white chowder that dates back to the settlers. Packed with clams, potatoes, and salt pork, it is thick, rich, and never, ever contains tomatoes.
ingredients: 1/4 lb Salt Pork or Bacon, diced
steps: Render salt pork in a pot. Remove bits.
Sauté onion in the fat. Add potatoes and clam juice (add water if needed to cover).
Simmer until potatoes are tender.
Add clams, cream, and milk. Heat through (do not boil vigorously).
Serve with oyster crackers.

drink.description: A Boston classic with rye, citrus, and grenadine.
steps: Shake all ingredients with ice.
Strain into a chilled coupe or rocks glass.
Garnish if desired.
Note (quick grenadine): simmer equal parts pomegranate juice + sugar until dissolved; cool before using.
Warm pomegranate juice and sugar in a saucepan over medium heat, stirring until dissolved (avoid a hard boil).
Cool; stir in orange blossom water if using.
Bottle; add vodka if using for shelf-life.
Refrigerate and use within 3–4 weeks (longer if vodka added).

Michigan.description: The Motor City's contribution to pizza. Baked in rectangular steel pans originally used for automotive parts, this pizza features a thick, airy crust with crispy cheese edges ('frico') and sauce ladled on top.
steps: Press dough into a greased rectangular pan. Let rise.
Press pepperoni into the dough.
Spread cheese cubes all the way to the edges (crucial for the crust).
Ladle sauce in two racing stripes down the length of the pizza.
Bake at 500°F (260°C) until cheese is caramelized and crust is dark golden.

drink.description: A Michigan ice-cream cocktail (often rum and coffee liqueur blended with vanilla ice cream).
steps: Blend rum, coffee liqueur, and ice cream until smooth.
Pour into a chilled glass and serve immediately.

Minnesota.description: The ultimate Midwestern comfort food. A casserole of ground beef, cream of mushroom soup, and vegetables, topped with a crispy army of tater tots.
steps: Brown beef with onion and garlic. Drain fat.
Mix beef with soup and vegetables. Spread into a baking dish.
Arrange tater tots in neat rows over the top.
Bake at 375°F (190°C) for 45 minutes until tots are golden brown and filling is bubbly.

drink.description: A Minnesota cabin classic built around a frozen lemonade-limeade mint base.
steps: Make Bootleg mix: In a blender, blend 1 can (12 oz) frozen lemonade concentrate + 1 can (12 oz) frozen limeade concentrate + 1 packed cup fresh mint leaves until smooth; freeze until slushy.
Fill a tall glass with ice. Add gin and 2 tablespoons of the bootleg mix.
Top with club soda and stir gently to combine.
Garnish with mint and lime if desired.

ingredients: 1 packed cup fresh mint leaves (stems removed)
steps: Blend lemonade concentrate, limeade concentrate, and mint until the mint is fully pureed and the mix is vivid green.
Freeze in a covered container until slushy/scoopable (stir once during freezing if it sets too hard).
Use by the spoonful in the Bootleg; keep frozen up to 1 month for best flavor.

Mississippi.description: A viral sensation that became a modern classic. A chuck roast is slow-cooked with ranch dressing mix, au jus mix, butter, and pepperoncini peppers until it melts apart.
steps: Place roast in a slow cooker.
Sprinkle both packets of mix over the meat.
Place the stick of butter and peppers on top.
Cover and cook on Low for 8 hours. Do not add water.
Shred meat and serve with mashed potatoes.

drink.description: A classic Mississippi cocktail combining cognac/brandy, bourbon, dark rum, lemon, and honey.
steps: Add cognac/brandy, bourbon, rum, lemon juice, and honey to a shaker with ice.
Shake until well chilled and the honey dissolves.
Strain into an ice-filled Collins or rocks glass and serve.

Missouri.description: The 'gold nuggets' of BBQ. Cut from the fatty point of a brisket, these cubes are smoked, sauced, and caramelized until they are sweet, smoky, and melt-in-your-mouth tender.
steps: Smoke the brisket point until tender (internal 200°F).
Cut into 1-inch cubes.
Toss cubes with BBQ sauce and a little broth in a pan.
Return to smoker for 1-2 hours to caramelize and become sticky.
Serve as the ultimate BBQ appetizer.

drink.description: A St. Louis–style cocktail often called a ‘Missouri Mule,’ mixing bourbon and apple brandy with bitter-orange accents.
steps: Add bourbon, apple brandy, Campari, and Cointreau to a mixing glass with ice.
Stir until well chilled.
Strain into a chilled coupe (or over a large cube in a rocks glass).
Express an orange peel over the drink if desired.

Montana.description: Montana's Big Sky country runs on bison—leaner, sweeter, and more intensely beefy than cattle. A thick-cut bison ribeye is seared over a ripping-hot cast-iron skillet (or wood fire), rested, and served with nothing but salt, pepper, and a pat of herb butter. Bison cooks faster than beef and must stay rare to medium-rare or it dries out.
ingredients: 2 bison ribeye steaks 1.25 inches thick (about 10 oz each)
steps: Remove steaks from refrigerator 45 minutes before cooking. Season generously with salt and pepper on both sides.
Heat cast-iron skillet over high heat until smoking. Add oil.
Sear steaks 3-4 minutes per side for medium-rare (internal temp 130°F/54°C). Bison cooks faster than beef—watch carefully.
In the last minute add butter thyme and garlic to the pan. Baste the steaks with the foaming butter.
Rest 8 minutes on a warm plate. Serve with the herb butter spooned over.

drink.description: A beer-and-whiskey pairing associated with Montana in the list.
steps: Serve a shot of whiskey alongside a beer.
Sip separately or drop the shot into the beer (to preference).

dessert.description: The treasure of the mountains. Wild huckleberries, which resist domestication and must be foraged by hand in bear country, are baked into a sweet-tart pie that defines Montana summers.
steps: Mix berries, sugar, flour, and lemon juice.
Pour into a pie crust lined pan. Dot with butter.
Cover with top crust, crimp edges, and cut steam vents.
Bake at 400°F (200°C) for 45-50 minutes until filling bubbles thickly.

Nebraska.description: A pocket of warmth from the Great Plains. Brought by Volga German immigrants, this yeast dough bread pocket is stuffed with a savory mixture of ground beef, cabbage, and onions.
ingredients: Salt and lots of Black Pepper
steps: Brown beef and onion. Add cabbage and a splash of water. Steam until soft.
Season heavily with pepper. Let cool.
Roll dough into rectangles. Place filling in center.
Fold dough over to seal (like a hot pocket).
Bake at 375°F (190°C) for 20 mins until golden brown.

drink.description: A Nebraska staple: beer with tomato juice.
steps: Pour tomato juice into a pint glass.
Top gently with beer.
Season to taste and stir lightly.

Nevada.description: The high-roller's dinner. A staple of Las Vegas casino buffets and steakhouses, a massive standing rib roast is crusted in herbs and salt, roasted rare, and served with jus and horseradish cream.
steps: Make a paste of herbs, garlic, salt, pepper, and olive oil. Rub all over the roast.
Roast at 450°F (230°C) for 20 mins to sear.
Lower heat to 325°F (160°C). Cook until internal temp is 120°F (rare).
Rest for 30 minutes (crucial). Slice thick.

drink.description: A Nevada Basque-American cocktail built on Amer Picon-style bitters.
steps: Fill a glass halfway with sparkling water (and ice if desired).
Add Amer Picon and stir.
Float brandy on top and garnish with lemon.

New Hampshire.description: New Hampshire's Yankee classic: a whole corned beef brisket simmered for hours with cabbage, potatoes, carrots, turnips, and onions until everything is tender and infused with the brine. This is the meal that sustained New England through centuries of winters—one pot, no fuss, deeply satisfying.
ingredients: 3 lbs corned beef brisket with spice packet (1.4 kg)
4 carrots peeled and cut into chunks
1 small head cabbage cut into wedges
steps: Place corned beef in a large pot. Cover with cold water by 2 inches. Add the spice packet bay leaves and peppercorns.
Bring to a boil then reduce to a gentle simmer. Cook 2.5-3 hours until the beef is fork-tender.
Add potatoes carrots turnips and onion to the pot. Simmer 15 minutes.
Add cabbage wedges. Simmer 15 more minutes until all vegetables are tender.
Slice the corned beef against the grain. Arrange on a platter with the vegetables. Serve with Dijon mustard and parsley.

drink.description: A simple vodka-cranberry highball.
steps: Fill a highball with ice.
Add vodka and cranberry juice.
Stir and garnish with lime.

dessert.description: The scent of autumn. Fresh apple cider is reduced to concentrate its flavor, then mixed into a cake donut batter, fried, and tossed in cinnamon sugar while still hot.
ingredients: 1 cup Apple Cider (boiled down to 1/2 cup)
steps: Reduce cider. Cool.
Mix dry ingredients. Whisk butter, sugar, egg, and reduced cider.
Combine to make a sticky dough. Chill 1 hour.
Roll out and cut donut shapes.
Fry in oil at 350°F (175°C).
Toss immediately in cinnamon sugar.

New Jersey.description: The unofficial state anthem on a roll. Taylor Ham (or Pork Roll) is a processed pork product that is sliced, griddled until the edges curl, and stacked with fried egg and American cheese on a hard roll.
steps: Score the edges of the pork roll slices (to prevent cupping).
Fry pork roll on a griddle until browned and crispy.
Fry egg (over hard or sunny side up).
Melt cheese on the egg.
Stack on the roll: Meat, Egg, Cheese. Salt and pepper.

drink.description: A classic cocktail with applejack and grenadine.
steps: Shake all ingredients with ice.
Strain into a chilled coupe.
Note (quick grenadine): simmer equal parts pomegranate juice + sugar until dissolved; cool before using.
Warm pomegranate juice and sugar in a saucepan over medium heat, stirring until dissolved (avoid a hard boil).
Cool; stir in orange blossom water if using.
Bottle; add vodka if using for shelf-life.
Refrigerate and use within 3–4 weeks (longer if vodka added).

New Mexico.description: New Mexico's answer to the rolled enchilada. Corn tortillas are lightly fried flat and layered like a lasagna with cheese, chicken, and gallons of roasted Hatch green chile sauce, topped with a fried egg.
ingredients: 2 cups Roasted Hatch Green Chile Sauce
steps: Lightly fry tortillas in oil (to soften, not crisp).
Dip tortilla in warm green chile sauce.
Place on plate. Top with cheese, onion, and chicken.
Repeat for 3 layers.
Top the stack with a fried egg and more sauce.

drink.description: A New Mexico cocktail with tequila, cider, and crème de cassis.
steps: Fill a rocks glass with ice.
Add tequila and cider and stir.
Float crème de cassis and garnish if desired.

New York.description: The bar snack that changed the world. Invented at the Anchor Bar in Buffalo in 1964. Chicken wings are deep-fried naked (no batter) until crispy, then tossed in a sauce of Frank's RedHot and butter.
steps: Fry wings in oil at 375°F (190°C) for 10-12 mins until very crispy. Do not bread them.
Whisk hot sauce and melted butter.
Toss hot wings in the sauce.
Serve immediately with celery and blue cheese.

drink.description: A classic New York cocktail of whiskey and vermouth.
steps: Stir whiskey, vermouth, and bitters with ice.
Strain into a chilled coupe.
Garnish.

North Carolina.description: The definition of Piedmont BBQ. Pork shoulder is smoked over hickory and chopped (not pulled), then dressed with a 'dip' made of vinegar, ketchup, pepper, and salt. Served with red slaw.
ingredients: Dip: 1 cup Cider Vinegar, 1/4 cup Ketchup, 1 tbsp Sugar, Red Pepper Flakes
steps: Smoke pork at 225°F (107°C) for 8-10 hours until tender.
Chop the meat (don't shred).
Mix the dip ingredients. Toss the meat with some dip.
Serve on a bun with red slaw (coleslaw made with the same BBQ dip instead of mayo).

drink.description: A historic cherry-infused spirit, traditionally made by steeping cherries in brandy (often associated with the mid-Atlantic and early American period).
steps: Pack the cherries into a clean crock or large glass jar.
Pour in the brandy, then add the sugar.
Cover and let steep 3–4 months, stirring occasionally until the sugar dissolves.
Strain and bottle. Serve a small pour over ice or at room temperature.

North Dakota.description: A German-Russian comfort classic. A thick, creamy potato soup filled with chewy, handmade dumplings (knoephla) that are cut with shears directly into the pot.
ingredients: Soup: 4 Potatoes (cubed), 1 Onion, 1 stalk Celery, 6 cups Chicken Broth
steps: Make stiff dough. Roll into ropes. Cut 1-inch pieces (knoephla).
Sauté onion and celery. Add broth and potatoes. Boil until potatoes are half done.
Drop dumplings into boiling soup. Simmer 20 mins.
Stir in cream and dill. Soup should be thick.

drink.description: A creamy cola highball with coffee liqueur.
steps: Fill a highball with ice.
Add coffee liqueur and cream; stir.
Top with cola.

Ohio.description: A Mediterranean-spiced meat sauce served over spaghetti. Flavored with cinnamon, cloves, chocolate, and allspice, it's famously ordered '5-Way': Spaghetti, Chili, Beans, Onions, and Cheese.
ingredients: 1 lb Ground Beef (boiled in water, not browned)
Spices: Cinnamon, Cloves, Allspice, Cumin, Chili Powder, Cocoa Powder
steps: Crumble raw beef into water. Boil until cooked (fine texture).
Add tomato paste and spices. Simmer uncovered for 2-3 hours until thick.
Cook spaghetti.
Assemble 5-Way: Spaghetti, Chili, Beans, Onions, Cheese.

drink.description: An Ohio cocktail combining vodka, tart cherry, basil, balsamic, and honey—served over ice.
steps: Add vodka, tart cherry juice, basil, balsamic vinegar, and honey to a shaker with ice.
Shake hard until the honey is dissolved and the drink is very cold.
Strain over fresh ice in a rocks glass.
Garnish with a basil leaf if desired.

Oklahoma.description: Born from the Depression era to stretch beef. Thinly shaved onions are smashed directly into the beef patty on the griddle, caramelizing and fusing with the meat.
steps: Form beef into balls. Place on hot griddle.
Pile a handful of onions on top of the meat ball.
Smash flat with a spatula, driving onions into the meat.
Cook until crust forms. Flip (onions are now on bottom caramelizing).
Top with cheese. Serve on steamed bun.

drink.description: An Oklahoma party drink commonly made with beer, orange juice, and amaretto.
steps: Pour orange juice into a pint glass.
Add amaretto.
Top with beer and stir lightly.

Oregon.description: A tribute to the 'Cabernet of Blackberries'. The Marionberry, developed at Oregon State University, is baked into a bubbling, purple cobbler with a biscuit topping.
ingredients: Topping: 1 cup Flour, 1/2 cup Sugar, 1 tsp Baking Powder, Butter, Milk
steps: Toss berries with sugar and cornstarch. Place in baking dish.
Mix topping ingredients to make a wet biscuit dough.
Drop spoonfuls of dough over the berries.
Bake at 375°F (190°C) for 45 mins until topping is golden and fruit is bubbling.

drink.description: An Oregon café classic (often with rum, coffee, and whipped cream).
steps: Rim a warm mug with sugar.
Add rum and coffee liqueur.
Top with hot coffee and stir.
Finish with whipped cream.

Pennsylvania.description: The heavyweight champion of sandwiches. Thinly sliced ribeye steak is griddled and chopped, smothered in melted cheese (Provolone or Whiz), and stuffed into a long Amoroso roll, often 'wit' onions.
ingredients: 1 lb Ribeye Steak (partially frozen, sliced wafer thin)
steps: Sauté onions on a griddle. Push aside.
Cook steak slices quickly. Chop with spatula while cooking.
Mix onions into steak. Shape into a line the length of the roll.
Top with cheese. Let melt.
Place roll face down on meat, scoop underneath, and flip over.

drink.description: A classic cocktail with gin, raspberry, lemon, and egg white.
steps: Dry shake (no ice) if using egg white.
Shake again with ice.
Strain into a chilled coupe.
Simmer raspberries and water 5–8 minutes; mash.
Strain (optional), return liquid to pan, add sugar and lemon juice, and simmer 2–3 minutes.
Cool and bottle; refrigerate up to 2 weeks.

Rhode Island.description: A clam shack classic. Large Quahog clams are minced and mixed with linguica sausage, breadcrumbs, and spices, then baked back in their shells.
steps: Steam clams open. Remove meat and chop. Save shells and juice.
Sauté onion and sausage.
Mix breadcrumbs, clam meat, sausage mix, and enough juice to moisten.
Mound filling into the clam shells.
Bake at 375°F (190°C) for 20 mins until crispy on top.

drink.description: A tequila-and-pomegranate sour with a spicy Tajín rim.
steps: Rim a rocks glass with Tajín (rub the rim with a lime wedge, then dip into Tajín).
Add tequila, lime juice, pomegranate juice, and simple syrup to a shaker with ice.
Shake until well chilled.
Strain into the prepared glass over fresh ice and garnish with a lime wheel if desired.
Simple syrup: simmer 1 part sugar with 1 part water until dissolved; cool before using.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.

South Carolina.description: Also known as Frogmore Stew. A one-pot communal feast of shrimp, sausage, corn, and potatoes boiled with Old Bay, dumped onto a newspaper-covered table for eating with hands.
steps: Boil water with Old Bay and lemons.
Add potatoes. Cook 10 mins.
Add sausage and corn. Cook 5 mins.
Add shrimp. Cook 3 mins (until pink).
Drain and dump onto table. Serve with cocktail sauce.

drink.description: A classic rum punch.
steps: Shake rum, juices, and syrup with ice.
Strain over ice in a tall glass.
Add bitters if desired.
Note (simple syrup): stir equal parts sugar + hot water until dissolved; cool.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.

ingredients: 2 tsp crushed bay leaves (or 1 tsp ground bay)
steps: Mix all spices thoroughly.
Store airtight up to 3 months.

South Dakota.description: The official state nosh. Cubes of red meat (traditionally mutton or lamb, sometimes beef) are deep-fried or grilled and served on toothpicks with garlic salt and saltines.
ingredients: 1 lb Lamb or Beef Sirloin, cut into 1/2 inch cubes
steps: Deep fry meat cubes at 375°F (190°C) for about 60-90 seconds (should be rare/medium rare inside).
Drain and immediately toss with garlic salt.
Serve with toothpicks and crackers.

drink.description: A South Dakota bar staple sometimes called ‘red beer’: domestic lager topped with tomato juice and garnished with olives and pickles.
steps: Chill a mug or pint glass.
Pour in the beer, then add tomato juice to fill the glass.
Drop in olives and pickle slices.
Serve immediately.

Tennessee.description: Fried chicken with a vengeance. Marinated in buttermilk, fried crisp, and then doused in a fiery oil paste made of cayenne pepper and lard. Served on white bread with pickles to soak up the heat.
ingredients: Marinade: Buttermilk, Hot Sauce, Pickle Juice
Hot Paste: 1/2 cup Lard (melted), 3 tbsp Cayenne Pepper, 1 tbsp Brown Sugar, Paprika, Garlic Powder
steps: Marinate chicken overnight.
Dredge in flour. Fry until golden and cooked through.
Whisk hot paste ingredients (use some hot frying oil to melt spices).
Brush the fried chicken heavily with the hot paste.
Serve on a slice of white bread with pickles.

drink.description: A Tennessee highball featuring Tennessee whiskey and lemonade.
steps: Fill a highball with ice.
Add whiskey, triple sec, and lemon juice; stir.
Top with lemon-lime soda.
Whisk spices into melted lard/oil until a thick paste forms.
Cool; refrigerate up to 1 week (or freeze in portions).

Texas.description: The holy grail of BBQ. Beef brisket is rubbed simply with salt and pepper (Dalmatian rub) and smoked over post oak for 12+ hours until it has a dark bark and jiggles like gelatin.
ingredients: Rub: 1/2 cup Coarse Black Pepper, 1/2 cup Kosher Salt
steps: Trim fat cap to 1/4 inch.
Apply rub generously.
Smoke at 225°F (107°C) until internal temp hits 165°F (the stall).
Wrap in butcher paper. Continue smoking until 203°F and probe tender.
Rest in a cooler for 2-4 hours before slicing.

drink.description: A Texas highball of tequila, lime, and sparkling water.
steps: Fill a highball with ice.
Add tequila and lime juice.
Top with sparkling water and stir.

Utah.description: A Mormon comfort food staple served at gatherings (not just funerals). Hash browns are baked in a creamy cheese sauce and topped with crunchy cornflakes.
steps: Mix hash browns, soup, sour cream, cheese, and onion (optional).
Spread into a greased casserole dish.
Mix cornflakes with melted butter. Sprinkle over top.
Bake at 350°F (175°C) for 45-50 mins until bubbly and golden.

drink.description: A Utah cocktail from Squatters Pub Brewery combining gin, honey, lemon, and beer.
ingredients: 4 oz beer (a crisp lager works well)
steps: Add lemon juice, honey, and gin to a shaker with ice.
Shake until very cold and the honey is dissolved.
Strain into an ice-filled pint glass.
Top with beer and give a gentle stir.

Vermont.description: Vermont's sharp white cheddar meets local craft ale in a velvety, soul-warming soup. Cabot Cheddar—made by the Cabot Cooperative since 1919—is the star. The ale adds malty depth and the soup is finished with a swirl of cream and a sprinkle of chives. This is après-ski food from the Green Mountains.
ingredients: 1 lb extra-sharp Vermont white cheddar grated (450 g)
1 bottle (12 oz) Vermont craft ale or amber ale
steps: Melt butter in a heavy pot. Sauté onion until translucent 5 minutes. Add garlic cook 1 minute.
Add flour and stir 2 minutes to make a roux. Gradually whisk in the chicken broth and ale.
Bring to a simmer. Cook 10 minutes until slightly thickened.
Reduce heat to low. Add the grated cheddar a handful at a time stirring until melted. Do not boil or the cheese will seize.
Stir in cream mustard and paprika. Season with salt and white pepper.
Serve in bowls topped with chives and crusty bread alongside.

drink.description: A gin cocktail sweetened with Vermont maple syrup and brightened with citrus.
steps: Add gin, lemon juice, orange juice, maple syrup, and bitters to a shaker with ice.
Shake until well chilled.
Strain into a chilled coupe (or over ice in a rocks glass).
Garnish with an orange twist if desired.

dessert.description: A Northern twist on a Southern classic. Pure Vermont Grade B maple syrup replaces corn syrup, creating a darker, richer, and more complex pie.
steps: Whisk eggs, sugar, butter, and maple syrup.
Arrange pecans in the pie shell.
Pour filling over pecans.
Bake at 350°F (175°C) for 40-50 mins until set but slightly jiggly in center.

Virginia.description: A thick, tomato-based stew that claims origin in Brunswick County. Historically made with squirrel, today it features smoked chicken and pork, lima beans, and corn, cooked until the spoon stands up straight.
steps: Combine meats, tomatoes, and juices in a large pot.
Simmer for 1 hour.
Add beans, corn, and seasonings.
Simmer on low for another hour until very thick.
Serve with cornbread.

drink.description: A Virginia take on the Manhattan, using local whiskey and classic bitters and vermouth.
steps: Add whiskey, sweet vermouth, and bitters to a mixing glass with ice.
Stir until well chilled.
Strain into a chilled coupe or Nick & Nora glass.
Garnish with an expressed orange peel (and a cherry if desired).

Washington.description: Seattle's ubiquitous comfort food. Chicken thighs are marinated in a sweet, ginger-heavy soy glaze, grilled over open flame for char, and served with rice and mac salad.
ingredients: Marinade/Glaze: 1 cup Soy Sauce, 1 cup Sugar, 1 tbsp Fresh Ginger (grated), Garlic
steps: Boil marinade ingredients. Thicken half with cornstarch for glaze. Cool the rest for marinade.
Marinate chicken for 4 hours.
Grill chicken over high heat to get char marks.
Slice into strips.
Drizzle heavily with the thickened glaze. Serve with rice.

drink.description: A modern cocktail often made with aquavit, sherry, and bitter liqueur.
steps: Stir all ingredients with ice.
Strain into a chilled coupe.
Garnish if desired.

West Virginia.description: The coal miner's lunch. Invented at the Country Club Bakery by Giuseppe Argiro, this soft white bread roll is baked with sticks of pepperoni inside. The spicy oil leaches into the bread, creating a soft, flavorful snack that needs no refrigeration.
ingredients: Stick Pepperoni (cut into 3-inch batons or thick slices)
steps: Divide dough into balls.
Flatten and place pepperoni inside. Roll up and seal ends tight.
Let rise for 30 mins.
Bake at 375°F (190°C) for 15-20 mins until golden.
Brush with butter while hot.

drink.description: A West Virginia-inspired martini using pawpaw purée and elderflower liqueur.
steps: Add vodka, St-Germain, and pawpaw purée to a cocktail shaker with ice.
Shake until very cold.
Strain into a chilled martini glass.
Serve immediately.

ingredients: Peels (zest strips) from 2 lemons (avoid the white pith)
Optional: peels from 1 orange (avoid the white pith)
steps: Use a vegetable peeler to remove wide strips of citrus peel, taking as little white pith as possible.
Put peels in a clean jar and pour in the vodka. Seal.
Infuse in a cool, dark place, shaking once daily.
Start tasting after 24 hours; strain when the citrus flavor is where you want it (often 3–7 days).
Strain through a fine mesh sieve (and coffee filter if you want it crystal clear). Bottle and store.

ingredients: 2–4 ripe pawpaws (enough for at least 1/2 cup pulp)
Optional: 1 tsp lemon juice (helps slow browning)
steps: Halve pawpaws lengthwise and scoop the pulp into a bowl.
Remove seeds (discard) and pick out any bits of skin/fibers.
Mash well, or blitz briefly with an immersion blender until smooth.
Optional: press through a fine sieve for a silkier purée.
Stir in lemon juice if using. Refrigerate up to 2 days, or freeze in small portions.

Wisconsin.description: The tailgate essential. Bratwurst sausages are simmered in a hot bath of beer and onions before being finished on the grill. Served on a hard roll with spicy mustard and sauerkraut.
steps: In a pot, simmer brats, onions, beer, and butter for 15-20 mins (do not boil hard).
Remove brats and grill over medium heat until browned and crisp.
Serve on a bun topped with the beer-soaked onions and mustard.

drink.description: Wisconsin’s brandy-forward Old Fashioned with muddled fruit.
steps: Muddle sugar, bitters, orange, and cherry in a rocks glass.
Add brandy and ice; stir.
Top with a splash of soda or sour mix.
Note (simple syrup): stir equal parts sugar + hot water until dissolved; cool.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.
Whisk lemon juice, lime juice, and simple syrup together.
Bottle and refrigerate; use within 3–4 days for best flavor.

Wyoming.description: A hearty bowl for the range. Lean, flavorful bison meat is slow-cooked with beans, tomatoes, and mild chilies. It's richer and sweeter than beef chili.
steps: Brown bison and onion. Drain any fat (bison is lean, so there won't be much).
Add tomatoes, beans, and spices.
Simmer for 1 hour to meld flavors.
Serve with cheddar cheese and cornbread.

drink.description: A classic ‘Rattlesnake’ whiskey sour variation with absinthe and egg white for a silky foam.
steps: Add rye, lemon juice, simple syrup, absinthe, and egg white to a shaker.
Dry-shake (no ice) for 10–15 seconds to build foam, then add ice and shake again until well chilled.
Double-strain into a chilled coupe (or a rocks glass).
Garnish with a lemon twist if desired.
Simple syrup: simmer 1 part sugar with 1 part water until dissolved; cool before using.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.

drink.description: A classic American whiskey cocktail: spirit-forward, lightly sweetened, and perfumed with citrus and bitters.
ingredients: 1 tsp water (if using a sugar cube)
steps: In a rocks glass, add the sugar cube and bitters; add 1 tsp water and muddle into a syrup (skip water if using simple syrup).
Add a large ice cube and pour in the bourbon.
Stir 15–20 seconds until chilled and lightly diluted.
Express the orange peel over the drink (pinch to spray oils), then garnish with the peel.
Serve immediately.
Note (simple syrup): stir equal parts sugar + hot water until dissolved; cool.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.

dessert.description: The original, the benchmark, the one against which all others are measured—a dense, creamy, tall cheesecake baked on a buttery graham cracker crust. Born at Lindy's restaurant in 1950s Manhattan (some say Arnold Reuben's in the 1920s), this is cheesecake at its purest: cream cheese, eggs, sugar, and a touch of vanilla, baked low and slow until just set with the slightest jiggle in the center. No fruit toppings, no sour cream layer—just the unapologetic richness of New York in every fork-cracking bite.
ingredients: 4 packages (32 oz / 900 g) cream cheese, at room temperature
steps: Preheat oven to 450°F (230°C). Press the graham cracker crust into the bottom of a 10-inch (25 cm) springform pan. Bake 10 minutes; cool.
Reduce oven to 325°F (160°C). Wrap the outside of the springform pan in a double layer of heavy-duty foil (water bath insurance).
Beat cream cheese on medium speed until smooth, scraping the bowl often. Add sugar and beat until fluffy.
Mix in vanilla, lemon zest, and flour. Add eggs and yolks one at a time, mixing on low after each—do not overbeat or incorporate air.
Stir in heavy cream by hand. Pour filling over the crust.
Place the springform pan inside a large roasting pan. Pour hot water into the roasting pan to come halfway up the sides of the springform.
Bake 55–65 minutes until the edges are set but the center still jiggles slightly.
Turn off the oven, crack the door, and let the cheesecake cool inside for 1 hour. Refrigerate at least 6 hours (overnight is best) before unmolding and serving.

ingredients: 2 cups (200 g) graham cracker crumbs (about 14 full sheets)
steps: Combine graham cracker crumbs, sugar, salt, and melted butter. Mix until evenly moistened.
Press firmly into the bottom (and optionally 1 inch up the sides) of the springform pan.
Chill 10 minutes before filling, or pre-bake at 350°F (180°C) for 10 minutes for extra crispness.

UZB.description: Uzbekistan’s national dish: rice steamed over a deeply flavored base of browned onions, lamb, and carrots with cumin (zira). Traditionally cooked in a kazan and served in generous communal platters.
ingredients: 2 lb (900 g) lamb (or beef), cut into chunks
4 large carrots, cut into matchsticks (about 6 cups / 600 g)
2 tbsp whole cumin seeds (zira), lightly crushed
1 tbsp kosher salt, plus more to taste
1 whole head of garlic, outer papery skins removed
Hot water, as needed (about 5–6 cups / 1.2–1.4 L)
steps: Heat oil in a heavy pot. Fry onions until deep golden.
Add meat and brown well. Add carrots and cook 5 minutes.
Add cumin, salt, and optional barberries/coriander. Add hot water to just cover and simmer 30–45 minutes.
Spread rice over the top without stirring. Add enough hot water to sit about 1 inch (2.5 cm) above rice.
When water is mostly absorbed, push garlic head into rice, cover tightly, and steam on very low 20–25 minutes.
Rest 10 minutes, fluff gently, and serve.

drink.dish: Kok Choy (Кўк чай) — Uzbek Green Tea
drink.description: Simple, strong green tea served throughout the day in Uzbekistan; hospitality in a bowl (piala).
steps: Heat water to about 175°F (80°C).
Steep tea 2–3 minutes. Strain and serve.

dessert.description: Uzbek flour halva—the Silk Road's sweet legacy: wheat flour slowly toasted in oil until deep golden and fragrant, then cooked with sugar syrup and milk into a rich, dense confection that melts on the tongue. Unlike the sesame halva of the Middle East, Uzbek halva is flour-based, with a fudge-like texture and a warm, toasted-grain flavor. Served at weddings, Navruz celebrations, and funerals alike, halva is the universal Uzbek gesture of hospitality and remembrance.
ingredients: 1/2 cup (120 ml) neutral oil (cottonseed is traditional; sunflower or vegetable works)
Optional: 2 tbsp chopped pistachios or walnuts for garnish
steps: Heat oil in a heavy skillet over medium-low heat. Add flour and stir continuously with a wooden spoon for 20–25 minutes until the flour turns deep golden brown and smells richly nutty. Do not rush—low and slow prevents burning.
While the flour toasts, combine sugar, milk, and water in a saucepan. Heat until sugar dissolves. Keep warm.
When the flour is ready, carefully pour the warm milk-sugar syrup into the flour-oil mixture (it will spatter). Stir vigorously.
Add cardamom and butter. Cook on low heat, stirring constantly, 5–8 minutes until the mixture pulls away from the sides of the pan and forms a thick, cohesive mass.
Transfer to a greased plate or mold, press flat, and smooth the top. Garnish with chopped pistachios or walnuts if desired.
Let cool to room temperature. Cut into diamonds or squares. Serve with green tea.

VAT.description: A Roman pasta associated with Pope Pius XII: a refined, richer cousin of carbonara—egg yolks, cheese, and prosciutto (often with onion and butter).
ingredients: 4 oz prosciutto (crudo or cotto), cut into thin strips (115 g)
Optional: 1/4 cup heavy cream (60 ml) (some modern versions)
steps: Cook pasta in well-salted water until al dente. Reserve 1 cup pasta water.
Meanwhile, melt butter in a skillet over medium-low. Add onion and cook until soft, not browned.
Add prosciutto and warm 1–2 minutes (do not crisp hard).
In a bowl, whisk egg yolks with Pecorino, Parmigiano, and lots of black pepper (and cream if using).
Drain pasta and add to skillet off heat. Toss to coat.
Quickly pour in egg-cheese mixture, tossing constantly, adding a splash of pasta water as needed to make a glossy sauce.
Serve immediately with extra pepper and cheese.

drink.description: A Roman (and Vatican-adjacent) classic: espresso ‘corrected’ with a splash of grappa—short, hot, and bracing.
steps: Brew a fresh shot of espresso.
Stir in sugar if using.
Add grappa and stir once.
Serve immediately.

dessert.description: Crispy fried pastry tubes filled with sweetened ricotta, candied orange peel, and chocolate chips—Rome's Jewish quarter heritage adopted by the Vatican table. Originally Sicilian, cannoli found a second home in Rome where the Jewish community in the Ghetto perfected fried pastries for centuries. The shell must shatter at first bite, giving way to a cool, creamy ricotta filling studded with bright pops of candied citrus and bittersweet chocolate. Filled only at the moment of serving—never before—to preserve that sacred crunch.
ingredients: For the shells: 2 cups (250 g) all-purpose flour
2 tbsp (28 g) cold lard or unsalted butter, cubed
1/4 cup (60 ml) dry Marsala wine (or white wine)
For the filling: 2 cups (500 g) fresh whole-milk ricotta, drained overnight in cheesecloth
2 tbsp (20 g) candied orange peel, finely diced
steps: Make the dough: Combine flour, sugar, salt, and cinnamon. Cut in lard/butter until crumbly. Mix egg, Marsala, and vinegar; add to flour mixture and knead until smooth and elastic, about 5 minutes. Wrap in plastic and rest 1 hour at room temperature.
Roll dough very thin (about 1/16 inch / 1.5 mm) with a pasta machine or rolling pin. Cut into 4-inch (10 cm) circles.
Wrap each circle around a metal cannoli tube, sealing the overlapping edge with a dab of egg white.
Heat oil to 350°F (180°C). Fry shells 2–3 at a time, turning once, until golden and blistered, about 2–3 minutes total. Drain on paper towels and carefully slide off the tubes while still warm.
Make the filling: Stir drained ricotta with powdered sugar and vanilla until smooth. Fold in chocolate chips and candied orange peel. Refrigerate until ready to use.
Just before serving, pipe or spoon the filling into both ends of each shell. Dip the exposed filling ends into chopped pistachios if desired. Dust with powdered sugar and serve immediately.

VCT.description: A symbol of resilience. Breadfruit, brought by Captain Bligh to feed populations, is roasted whole over an open fire until the skin chars and the inside becomes soft and smoky. Paired with crispy fried Jackfish, it is the quintessential Vincentian lunch.
steps: Score the breadfruit stem. Roast over an open flame (charcoal or gas) turning until skin is charred and inside is soft (insert skewer to test).
Peel the charred skin and slice the breadfruit.
Clean fish with lime. Rub with seasoning.
Dust fish in flour. Fry in hot oil until crispy.
Serve slices of warm roasted breadfruit with the fried fish.

drink.description: St Vincent & the Grenadines rum punch: rum, lime, tropical juice, and spice, served ice-cold.
ingredients: 1 tsp sugar (or 1/2 oz / 15 ml simple syrup)
steps: Shake with ice until cold.
Strain over fresh ice and serve.
Note (simple syrup): stir equal parts sugar + hot water until dissolved; cool.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.

dessert.description: Vincentian coconut sugar cake—grated coconut cooked with sugar and fresh ginger into a chewy, deeply caramelized candy. This is the Caribbean in a single bite: crunchy on the edges, chewy in the center, with the warmth of ginger cutting through the coconut sweetness. Made by grandmothers across St. Vincent and sold in colored cellophane at every school gate and market stall, sugar cake is the island's most nostalgic sweet. The key is patience—cook it low and slow until the sugar pulls into golden threads.
ingredients: 2 cups (160 g) freshly grated coconut (or unsweetened desiccated coconut, rehydrated in 1/4 cup warm water)
steps: Combine sugar and water in a heavy saucepan. Cook over medium heat, stirring until sugar dissolves.
Add grated coconut, grated ginger, cinnamon, salt, and food coloring if using. Stir to combine.
Cook over medium-low heat, stirring frequently, 15–20 minutes until the mixture thickens, turns golden, and begins to pull away from the sides of the pan.
Stir in vanilla extract. The mixture should be thick and sticky.
Drop spoonfuls onto a greased tray or parchment paper, shaping into small mounds or pressing flat into squares.
Let cool completely until firm and chewy. Store in an airtight container for up to 2 weeks.

VEN.description: A plate that tells the story of Venezuela's mixed heritage. Shredded beef (indigenous), white rice (European), and black beans (African) are arranged to resemble the tricolor flag. Sweet fried plantains (tajadas) are the 'railings' that hold this delicious history together.
ingredients: Sofrito: Onion, Red Pepper, Garlic, Cumin
steps: Cook steak in water until tender. Shred it.
Make Sofrito: Sauté onion, pepper, and garlic. Split in half.
Fry the shredded beef with half the sofrito and tomato sauce.
Fry the cooked black beans with the other half of the sofrito.
Fry plantain slices until golden.
Serve the four components side-by-side on a large plate.

drink.description: A classic Venezuelan refresher made with panela (unrefined cane sugar) and lime—sweet, citrusy, and cooling.
ingredients: 2 oz panela (piloncillo) (or 1/4 cup packed brown sugar as a substitute)
2 tbsp fresh lime juice (or to taste)
steps: Warm 1 cup water and dissolve the panela; cool completely.
Add remaining water and lime juice; stir and adjust sweetness and acidity.
Serve over ice.

dessert.description: Venezuela's silky caramel custard—denser than French crème caramel, lighter than Mexican flan. Made with condensed milk, eggs, and vanilla, quesillo gets its name from its resemblance to cheese (queso) due to the tiny air bubbles that form during baking, giving it a slightly porous texture. Every Venezuelan holiday table—Christmas, birthdays, Mother's Day—features this glossy, amber-topped custard unmolded onto a plate, its bittersweet caramel pooling around the edges like liquid gold. The secret is whole eggs (no separating), condensed milk (non-negotiable), and a gentle bain-marie.
ingredients: For the caramel: 3/4 cup (150 g) granulated sugar
For the custard: 1 can (14 oz / 397 g) sweetened condensed milk
steps: Make the caramel: Combine sugar and water in a saucepan over medium heat. Swirl (do not stir) until the sugar melts and turns a deep amber, about 5–7 minutes. Immediately pour into a 9-inch (23 cm) round baking pan or bundt pan, tilting to coat the bottom evenly. Set aside.
Preheat oven to 350°F (180°C). Boil a kettle of water for the bain-marie.
Blend the condensed milk, eggs, evaporated milk, vanilla, and salt in a blender until completely smooth (about 30 seconds—do not overblend or create foam).
Pour the custard mixture through a fine strainer over the caramel in the pan.
Cover the pan tightly with aluminum foil. Place it inside a larger roasting pan and pour hot water into the roasting pan until it reaches halfway up the sides of the custard pan.
Bake 50–60 minutes until the custard is set around the edges but still has a gentle jiggle in the center.
Remove from the water bath and cool to room temperature. Refrigerate at least 6 hours (overnight is ideal).
To unmold: run a thin knife around the edges, place a serving plate over the pan, and flip quickly. The caramel will cascade over the custard.

VIR.description: A dish dating back to the Danish colonial era. 'Fungi' is a smooth, polenta-like cornmeal mash that was a staple for field workers. Served with fresh fish poached in a savory butter-onion sauce, it remains the beloved comfort food of the Virgin Islands.
steps: Fungi: Boil okra in water. Whisk in cornmeal and butter. Cook until stiff and smooth (like polenta).
Fish: Clean fish with lime. Season.
Sauté onion and tomato in butter. Add a little water and vinegar to make a sauce.
Poach fish in the sauce for 10-15 mins.
Serve the fish with a scoop of fungi.

drink.description: A frozen, boozy “adult milkshake” strongly associated with the US Virgin Islands: rum, coffee liqueur, and a coconut-cream base.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) cream of coconut (store-bought or homemade)
steps: Blend everything with a generous cup of ice until smooth.
Serve immediately.
Note (quick cream of coconut): heat 1/2 cup coconut cream + 1/2 cup sugar until dissolved; cool.
Combine coconut milk, sugar, and salt in a saucepan.
Warm gently, stirring until sugar dissolves and mixture thickens slightly.
Cool and bottle; refrigerate up to 2 weeks. Shake before use.

dessert.description: Virgin Islands traditional sweet bread: a dense, lightly sweet loaf baked with shredded coconut, warm spices, and evaporated milk. 'Dumb' refers to the bread's simplicity—no kneading, no yeast, no fuss—just stir and bake. The result is a moist, fragrant bread with a golden crust and a tender, coconut-studded crumb that perfumes the entire kitchen. Dumb Bread appears at every island gathering, church function, and family cookout across St. Thomas, St. Croix, and St. John, sliced thick and eaten plain or spread with butter.
ingredients: 1/4 cup (55 g / 1/2 stick) unsalted butter, melted
steps: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Grease a 9x5 inch (23x13 cm) loaf pan.
Whisk together flour, sugar, baking powder, cinnamon, nutmeg, allspice, and salt in a large bowl. Stir in the shredded coconut.
In a separate bowl, beat the eggs with evaporated milk, coconut milk, melted butter, and vanilla until combined.
Pour the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients. Stir until just combined—do not overmix. The batter will be thick and heavy.
Pour into the prepared pan and smooth the top. Bake 50–60 minutes until golden brown and a skewer inserted in the center comes out clean.
Cool in the pan 15 minutes before turning out onto a wire rack. Slice thick. Dumb Bread is dense by design—serve at room temperature with butter or on its own at any island gathering.

VNM.description: Vietnam's soul in a bowl. A clear, aromatic bone broth simmered for hours.
ingredients: Spices: 5 Star Anise, 1 Cinnamon stick, 3 Cardamom pods, Cloves, Fennel
steps: Boil bones for 10 mins vigorously to release impurities. Dump water, scrub bones clean.
Char onion and ginger over open flame.
Simmer bones, brisket, charred aromatics, and toasted spices in clean water for 6-8 hours.
Remove brisket when tender. Strain broth. Season with fish sauce and sugar.
Assemble: Blanch noodles. Place in bowl. Add cooked brisket and raw sirloin.
Pour boiling broth over meat (cooking the raw slices instantly).
Serve with herbs (Thai basil, cilantro), bean sprouts, lime, and chili.

drink.description: Strong Vietnamese coffee sweetened with condensed milk and poured over ice.
ingredients: 2 tbsp Vietnamese ground coffee (or strong dark-roast coffee)
steps: Add condensed milk to a glass.
Brew coffee strongly (phin filter is traditional) into the glass.
Stir to combine, then pour over a glass full of ice.
Serve immediately.

dessert.description: Vietnam's dazzling three-color dessert: three distinct layers of sweetened mung bean paste, tender red beans, and vivid emerald pandan jelly, piled into a tall glass with crushed ice and drenched in rich coconut milk. Chè Ba Màu (literally 'three-color sweet soup') is Saigon's cooling gem—a study in contrasts of color, texture, and temperature that somehow harmonizes into pure refreshment. The earthy sweetness of the beans, the floral bounce of pandan jelly, and the silky richness of coconut milk make every spoonful a small revelation. Sold from glass carts on every Ho Chi Minh City sidewalk, it is Vietnam's most beautiful dessert.
ingredients: 1/2 cup (100 g) dried mung beans, soaked 2 hours
1/2 cup (100 g) dried red kidney beans or adzuki beans, soaked overnight
1/4 cup (50 g) granulated sugar (for mung bean layer)
1/4 cup (50 g) granulated sugar (for red bean layer)
1 package (1.75 oz / 50 g) pandan jelly powder (or 1 tbsp agar-agar powder with 1 tsp pandan extract)
1/4 cup (50 g) granulated sugar (for pandan jelly)
steps: Cook the soaked red beans in water until very soft, about 45 minutes. Drain. Toss with 1/4 cup sugar while still warm. Set aside to cool.
Cook the soaked mung beans in water until soft and starting to break apart, about 25 minutes. Drain. Mash lightly with a fork and stir in 1/4 cup sugar. Set aside to cool.

Combine pandan jelly powder (or agar-agar with pandan extract) with 1 cup water and 1/4 cup sugar in a saucepan. Bring to a boil, stirring until fully dissolved. Pour into a shallow dish and refrigerate until firmly set, about 1 hour. Cut into small cubes.
Warm coconut milk with 2 tbsp sugar and a pinch of salt, stirring until dissolved. Let cool to room temperature.

Assemble each glass in layers: spoon sweetened red beans on the bottom, mung bean paste in the middle, and pandan jelly cubes on top. Fill generously with crushed ice. Pour the sweetened coconut milk over everything. Stir gently before eating—Saigon's most beautiful dessert in every spoonful.

YEM.dish: Saltah (سلتة) — Yemeni Stew with Fenugreek Froth
YEM.description: Yemen’s national comfort dish: a hot bowl of meat broth and vegetables crowned with hulbah (whipped fenugreek foam) and spooned up with bread. The topping is the signature.
ingredients: For stew: 2 tbsp (30 ml) oil or ghee
4 cups (950 ml) beef or lamb broth
1 cup (150 g) cooked shredded lamb or beef (optional but common)
1 1/2 tsp kosher salt, plus more to taste
steps: Sauté onion in oil until soft. Add garlic and ginger 30 seconds.
Add tomato, cumin, and coriander; cook until thick and fragrant.
Add potato, carrot, broth, and meat if using. Simmer 15–20 minutes until vegetables are tender. Season with salt.
Ladle into bowls. Spoon sahawiq into the center and top generously with hulbah (fenugreek froth). Serve immediately with bread.
Soak fenugreek seeds in water 8–12 hours. Drain and rinse well.
Blend with 1/2 cup (120 ml) fresh water until pale and foamy.
Season with salt and lemon juice. Let sit 10 minutes; it will thicken slightly.
Blend tomatoes, chilies, garlic, cilantro, lemon juice, salt, and cumin to a coarse sauce.
Taste and adjust salt/lemon. Use immediately or refrigerate 2–3 days.

drink.description: A traditional Yemeni hot drink brewed from coffee husks (cascara/qishr) with ginger and warming spices—served sweet and fragrant.
ingredients: 1 tsp ground ginger (or 1-inch fresh ginger, sliced)
steps: Bring water to a boil. Add coffee husks, ginger, and cinnamon.
Simmer 8–10 minutes, then strain into cups.
Sweeten to taste and serve hot.

dessert.description: The queen of Yemeni sweets: a flaky, multilayered pastry of paper-thin dough sheets, each brushed lavishly with samn (clarified butter), stacked and baked until golden and shatteringly crisp, then drizzled with prized Sidr honey the moment it leaves the oven. Bint al-Sahn (literally 'daughter of the plate') is the centerpiece of every Yemeni celebration—weddings, Eid, and Friday family lunches. The art lies in stretching each dough ball as thin as tissue paper before layering it with samn, creating dozens of buttery, flaky strata that pull apart in golden sheets. The honey seeps between the layers, and the nigella seeds add an earthy, aromatic bite. No Yemeni meal is complete without it.
ingredients: 1 cup (230 g / 2 sticks) samn (clarified butter/ghee), melted and divided
1/2 cup (170 g) Sidr honey or raw floral honey for drizzling
1 tsp nigella seeds (black seed) for garnish
steps: Dissolve yeast and sugar in warm water. Let stand 10 minutes until foamy.
In a large bowl, combine flour and salt. Add eggs and yeast mixture. Knead into a soft, pliable dough, about 10 minutes. The dough should be smooth and slightly sticky.
Divide the dough into 8–10 equal balls. Cover and rest 30 minutes.
On a well-oiled surface, stretch each dough ball paper-thin with your hands—you should nearly see through it. Brush each stretched sheet generously with melted samn.
Layer the stretched dough sheets in a greased 10-inch (25 cm) round baking pan, brushing each layer with melted samn. Tuck the edges under to form a neat round.
Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Let the layered dough rest 20 minutes, then bake 25–30 minutes until golden brown and flaky.
Remove from oven and immediately drizzle generously with Sidr honey. Brush with more melted samn and sprinkle with nigella seeds. Serve warm, pulling apart the flaky layers with your hands.

ZAF.description: A Cape Malay classic. Spiced minced meat baked with a savory egg custard topping.
ingredients: Topping: 2 Eggs beaten with 1 cup Milk, Bay leaves
steps: Sauté onion. Add meat and brown.
Add curry powder, chutney, raisins, and the soaked bread (squeezed dry). Mix well.
Press the meat mixture into a baking dish.
Pour the egg and milk mixture over the meat. Top with bay leaves.
Bake at 350°F (180°C) for 30-40 minutes until the custard is set and golden.
Serve with yellow rice.

drink.description: South Africa’s famous caffeine-free herbal tea from red bush (rooibos).
ingredients: 1 tsp rooibos tea (loose leaf) per 8 oz water
steps: Add rooibos to a teapot or infuser and pour over boiling water.
Steep 5–7 minutes (rooibos tolerates longer steeping well).
Serve plain or with milk/honey/lemon.

dessert.description: South Africa's most beloved dessert and the ultimate braai ending: a spongy, caramelized apricot jam cake drenched in a hot cream-and-butter sauce the very moment it leaves the oven, so the sauce soaks deep into every pore of the pudding. Malva Pudding has Cape Dutch origins dating to the 17th century, and its name may derive from the Afrikaans word for the marshmallow plant (malva), though the connection is debated. What is not debated is its place at the center of every South African celebration—birthdays, holidays, and Sunday lunches. The apricot jam gives the sponge a subtle fruity tang, the vinegar keeps it impossibly moist, and the cream sauce transforms it into something between a cake and a warm, syrupy custard. Served with vanilla custard or ice cream, it is pure comfort.

steps: Combine cream, butter, sugar, and hot water in a saucepan over medium heat. Stir gently until the butter melts and sugar dissolves completely.
Stir in vanilla extract. Keep the sauce warm until the pudding is ready.
Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Grease a 9x13 inch (23x33 cm) baking dish.
Beat sugar and eggs together until thick and pale yellow, about 3 minutes. Beat in the apricot jam until combined.
Sift together flour, baking soda, and salt. In a separate bowl, combine milk, melted butter, vinegar, and vanilla.
Fold the dry ingredients into the egg mixture alternately with the milk mixture in three additions, stirring until just combined after each.
Pour the batter into the prepared dish. Bake 40–45 minutes until the pudding is risen, spongy, and deep golden brown on top.

Remove from the oven and immediately pour the hot Cream-Butter Sauce evenly over the entire surface, letting it soak in. The pudding will absorb the sauce and become gloriously moist and syrupy throughout. Serve warm with vanilla custard or ice cream.

GHA.description: Ghana's beloved street breakfast: rice and black-eyed beans simmered together with dried millet stalks that stain the grains a signature deep burgundy. Served from enormous roadside pots with an orchestra of toppings—shito (black pepper chili oil), spaghetti, gari, fried plantain, boiled egg, and stewed meat. Waakye is democracy on a plate: from market women to ministers, everyone queues for it at dawn.
ingredients: 1 cup dried black-eyed beans, soaked overnight
3–4 dried millet stalks or sorghum leaves (or 1 tsp baking soda for color)

steps: Heat oil in a heavy pot. Fry the blended onion, garlic, and ginger until deeply darkened, about 20 minutes.
Add tomato paste, ground shrimp, chili flakes, and black pepper. Fry on low heat, stirring constantly, 15–20 minutes until the oil separates and the shito is dark and fragrant.
Cool and store in a jar. Keeps for weeks.
Drain the soaked beans. Place in a large pot with the millet stalks, cover with water, and boil 30 minutes until the beans are half-cooked and the water turns deep red.
Add the rice. Add water to cover by 1 inch. Season with salt. Stir once.
Cover tightly and cook on low heat 25–30 minutes until the rice and beans are tender and all the water is absorbed. The grains should be a rich burgundy color.
Fluff gently. Serve in a large mound with shito, fried plantain, boiled egg, gari (toasted cassava flakes), spaghetti tossed in oil, and stewed meat.

drink.description: Ghana's vibrant ruby-red hibiscus drink, spiked with a measure of akpeteshie (local palm spirit) and fresh ginger. The tangy, spicy, floral combination is pure Accra nightlife.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) akpeteshie or white rum

steps: Boil hibiscus, ginger, and cloves in the water for 20 minutes until deep crimson.
Strain. Stir in sugar and lime juice. Chill.
Fill a tall glass with ice.
Add rum, sobolo base, lime juice, and honey. Stir well.
Garnish with a lime wheel.

SEN.description: Senegal's crown jewel and UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage (2021): a whole stuffed fish deep-fried golden, then braised in a rich tomato sauce with a garden of vegetables—cassava, cabbage, eggplant, okra, carrot—and the rice is cooked directly in the sauce until every grain is stained red and saturated with flavor. In Wolof, thiéboudienne means 'rice and fish.' This is the Sunday dish that gathers every Senegalese family around a single enormous platter, eating with their right hands.
ingredients: 2 lbs whole firm white fish (grouper, sea bass, or snapper), cleaned and scored (900 g)
1 large cassava piece, peeled and halved
1 dried fish (guedj) or fermented locust beans (nététou) for umami
Rof herb stuffing paste (see Chef's Essentials below)

steps: Blend all ingredients into a thick green paste.
Stuff into the scored cuts of the fish. Reserve any extra for the sauce base.
Heat oil in a large, deep pot. Fry the stuffed fish until golden on both sides. Remove carefully.
In the same oil, fry the remaining rof paste and tomato paste for 5 minutes until dark and caramelized. Add 6 cups water, guedj, bay leaf, salt, and pepper. Bring to a boil.
Add the hard vegetables first (cassava, carrot), simmer 10 minutes. Add cabbage, eggplant, okra. Simmer 15 more minutes. Remove vegetables and fish carefully. Keep warm.
Add the rice directly to the pot. Stir once, cover tightly, and cook on low heat 25–30 minutes until the rice absorbs all the liquid.
Mound the red rice on a large platter. Place the fish in the center and vegetables around it. Serve family-style.

drink.description: Senegal's spiritual coffee: dark-roasted beans ground with selim pepper (djar) and cloves, brewed thick and served sweet. Named after the holy city of Touba, it's sold at every Dakar street corner by women with thermos flasks. Spicy, warming, and uniquely Senegalese—this is not optional, it is ritual.
ingredients: 2 tbsp ground Café Touba (or dark roast coffee mixed with 1/2 tsp ground selim pepper)
steps: Bring water to a boil. Add the spiced coffee grounds. Boil for 3–4 minutes.
Strain through a fine cloth filter into small cups. Add sugar generously.
Drink hot, standing at a street-side stall.

dessert.description: Dakar's dessert of choice: sweetened millet couscous stirred together with thick vanilla yogurt, sweetened condensed milk, and plump raisins, then chilled until cold and creamy. Thiakry (also spelled chakery) is Senegal's answer to pudding—light, refreshing, and impossibly easy. Sold in plastic bags on every Dakar street corner, it is the dessert that every Senegalese child grows up loving.
steps: Place the millet couscous in a bowl. Pour boiling water over it, stir, cover, and let steam for 10 minutes until the grains are tender and fluffy.
Fluff with a fork and break up any clumps. Let cool to room temperature.
In a separate bowl, whisk together the yogurt, sweetened condensed milk, vanilla, and nutmeg until smooth.
Fold the cooled couscous into the yogurt mixture. Stir in the raisins.
Refrigerate at least 2 hours (overnight is ideal). Serve chilled in bowls or cups, garnished with mint if desired.

TUN.description: Tunisia's iconic street masterpiece: a paper-thin malsouka pastry folded around a raw egg, tuna, capers, harissa, and parsley, then deep-fried in seconds until the pastry is shatteringly crisp and the egg yolk inside is still gloriously runny. The art is in the fold—a perfect half-moon that seals without leaking—and the eating: bite the corner, let the yolk run, and never drip on your shirt. This is the starter of every Tunisian Ramadan iftar.
ingredients: 4 sheets malsouka pastry (or spring roll wrappers)
1 can (5 oz) tuna in olive oil, drained and flaked
1 small onion, finely diced and lightly sautéed
steps: Mix the tuna, capers, sautéed onion, parsley, and harissa. Season with salt and pepper.
Lay a malsouka sheet flat. Place a quarter of the tuna mixture on one half. Make a small well and crack a raw egg into it. Season the egg.
Fold the pastry in half to form a half-moon, pressing the edges firmly to seal.
Heat oil to 350°F (175°C). Carefully slide in the brik. Fry 1–2 minutes per side until deep golden. The yolk must stay runny.
Drain on paper towels. Serve immediately with lemon wedges.

drink.description: Boukha is Tunisia's fig spirit—a clear, fragrant eau de vie distilled from Tunisian figs since the 19th century. Mixed with fresh mint and lime, it becomes a North African fig sour that's bright, aromatic, and completely unique.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) boukha (Tunisian fig spirit, or fig vodka)
steps: Muddle mint leaves gently in a shaker.
Add boukha, lime juice, simple syrup, and ice. Shake hard.
Fine-strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with a mint sprig.

dessert.description: Tunisian date-filled semolina pastries: semolina dough wrapped around spiced date paste, deep-fried and soaked in honey. Kairouan's masterpiece—these diamond-shaped pastries are the crown jewel of Tunisian patisserie, their golden semolina shells shattering to reveal a meltingly soft date heart perfumed with orange blossom water.
ingredients: 1/2 cup (120 ml) warm water, as needed
steps: Make the dough: combine semolina, olive oil, melted butter, salt, and turmeric. Rub the fats into the semolina until it resembles wet sand.
Add warm water gradually, kneading until the dough holds together—it should be pliable but not sticky. Rest 15 minutes.
Divide dough into portions. Roll each into a rectangle about 1/4 inch (6 mm) thick and 3 inches (8 cm) wide.
Roll the spiced date paste into a log the length of the dough. Place it down the center.
Fold the dough over the filling and seal the edge. Gently flatten to about 3/4 inch (2 cm) thick.
Cut on the diagonal into diamond shapes about 2 inches (5 cm) long.
Heat oil to 325°F (165°C). Fry makroudh in batches for 3–4 minutes per side until deep golden brown. Drain briefly.
While still hot, submerge in the warm honey soak for 2–3 minutes. Remove and place on a rack to drain.
Cool completely. The pastries will firm up and become wonderfully sticky-crisp.

ingredients: 1 lb (450 g) pitted Deglet Noor dates
steps: Process dates in a food processor until a thick paste forms.
Warm butter in a pan, add date paste, cinnamon, cloves, and orange zest. Cook 3–5 minutes, stirring, until fragrant and cohesive.
Stir in orange blossom water. Cool slightly before using. The paste should be firm enough to roll into a log.
Warm honey and water together in a saucepan over low heat, stirring until combined.
Add orange blossom water and lemon juice. Keep warm (not hot) for soaking the fried pastries.

GIN.description: Guinea's version of the West African yassa: chicken marinated in a cascade of sliced onions, lemon juice, mustard, and garlic, then grilled over charcoal before being smothered in the caramelized onion sauce. The Guinean touch is the intensity of onions—the ratio should be almost 1:1 onion to chicken. Served over steamed white rice, this is the dish that perfumes every neighborhood in Conakry on Sundays.
ingredients: 1 whole chicken, cut into pieces (about 3.5 lbs / 1.6 kg)
steps: Marinate the chicken pieces with half the sliced onions, lemon juice, mustard, garlic, vinegar, salt, and pepper. Refrigerate at least 4 hours, overnight is ideal.
Remove the chicken from the marinade (reserve the onions and liquid). Grill over hot charcoal or under a broiler until charred and cooked through.
Heat peanut oil in a large pot. Add all the onions (both reserved and remaining fresh). Cook over medium heat 20–25 minutes until deeply caramelized and jammy.
Add the reserved marinade liquid, bay leaves, and whole habaneros. Simmer 10 minutes.
Nestle the grilled chicken into the onion sauce. Cover and simmer 15 minutes to marry the flavors.
Serve over steamed white rice with the onion sauce ladled generously over everything.

drink.description: Guinea's tangy hibiscus drink with a punch of fresh ginger and lime—ruby red, ice-cold, and the soundtrack of every Conakry celebration.
steps: Boil hibiscus and ginger in water for 15 minutes. Strain.
Stir in sugar and lime juice. Chill thoroughly.
Serve over ice.

TZA.description: Zanzibar and coastal Tanzania's aromatic pilau: rice slow-cooked with a complex spice paste of cumin, cardamom, cinnamon, cloves, and black pepper—the entire Zanzibar spice cabinet—with caramelized onions and tender beef. The technique of blooming whole spices in hot oil, then building layers of flavor, reflects centuries of Swahili, Arab, Indian, and Portuguese influence along the East African coast. The onions must be cooked to a deep mahogany—this is the soul of the dish.
ingredients: 1 lb beef chuck, cut into 1-inch cubes (450 g)
steps: Heat oil in a heavy pot. Add the whole spices and fry 30 seconds until fragrant and crackling.
Add sliced onions. Cook slowly, stirring often, 15–20 minutes until deeply caramelized and dark golden—this is the foundation of pilau flavor.
Add garlic and ginger, cook 2 minutes. Add the beef cubes and brown on all sides.
Stir in ground cumin and turmeric. Add broth and salt. Bring to a boil, then simmer covered 45 minutes until the beef is tender.

Drain the soaked rice and add to the pot. Add enough water so the liquid is 1 inch above the rice. Bring to a boil, then reduce to lowest heat. Cover tightly and cook 20 minutes without lifting the lid.
Remove from heat and let steam 10 minutes. Fluff gently. Garnish with cilantro. Serve with kachumbari (tomato-onion salad) and a lime wedge.

drink.description: Kenya and Tanzania's signature cocktail—the 'Swahili Caipirinha': vodka muddled with fresh lime, honey, and ice in a rocks glass with a dawa stick (a wooden honey-stirring rod). The name means 'medicine' in Swahili, and after one sip you'll understand why. Born in Nairobi's safari lodges, now the sundowner of choice across East Africa.
steps: Place the lime quarters and honey in a rocks glass.
Muddle firmly to release the lime juice and dissolve the honey.
Add crushed ice and pour the vodka over.
Stir with a dawa stick. Do not strain—drink it rustic.

dessert.description: Tanzania's beloved coconut candy—grated coconut cooked with sugar until golden and set into crunchy, caramelized squares. Found in every Zanzibar market stall and Dar es Salaam street corner, kashata is the Swahili coast's answer to a candy bar. The simplicity is deceptive: getting the sugar to the exact caramelization point—golden and crackling but not burnt—is the art. Wrapped in newspaper or cellophane, these addictive little squares are the taste of East African childhood.
ingredients: 2 cups (160 g) freshly grated coconut (or unsweetened desiccated coconut)
steps: Lightly toast the grated coconut in a dry skillet over medium heat, stirring constantly, until just fragrant and barely golden, about 3 minutes. Set aside.
Combine sugar and water in a heavy saucepan. Cook over medium heat without stirring until the sugar dissolves, then continue cooking until it turns a light amber caramel.
Immediately add the toasted coconut, cardamom, salt, and lemon juice. Stir vigorously to coat the coconut evenly in the caramel.
Pour the mixture onto a greased plate or parchment-lined tray. Press flat with an oiled spatula to about 1/2-inch (1 cm) thickness.
Score into squares while still warm. Let cool completely until hard and crunchy.
Break along score lines. Store in an airtight container at room temperature for up to 2 weeks.

MOZ.description: Mozambique's creamy, aromatic treasure from the south: young cassava leaves pounded to a paste, then simmered with ground peanuts, coconut milk, garlic, and giant prawns from the Mozambican coast. Matapa is the heart of Mozambican coastal cuisine—the fusion of indigenous African ingredients with Portuguese colonial influence and Indian Ocean trade. The cassava leaves must be pounded silky smooth; the coconut milk gives it a velvet richness that clings to each prawn.
ingredients: 1 lb young cassava leaves (or spinach as substitute), finely shredded (450 g)
1 lb large prawns, peeled and deveined (450 g)
1 cup raw peanuts, ground to a powder (140 g)
steps: If using cassava leaves: wash thoroughly, boil in water for 20 minutes to remove toxins, drain, and pound in a mortar until very smooth. If using spinach: blanch briefly and chop fine.
Heat oil in a large pot. Sauté onion until translucent. Add garlic, cook 1 minute.
Add the pounded cassava leaves. Stir and cook 5 minutes. Add ground peanuts and stir to combine.
Pour in the coconut milk. Stir well. Simmer on low heat 20 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the sauce is thick and creamy.
Add the prawns. Cook 5–7 minutes until they turn pink and curl. Season with salt, white pepper, and lemon juice.
Serve over steamed rice. In Maputo, matapa is Sunday food—slow, generous, and communal.

drink.description: Mozambique's people's sundowner: the local Tipo Tinto rum mixed with fresh lime and ice—simple, sharp, and ubiquitous from Maputo beach bars to Pemba waterfront stalls.
steps: Muddle lime juice and sugar in a glass. Add rum and ice.
Top with soda. Stir and drink watching the Indian Ocean.

dessert.description: Mozambique's signature celebration cake from Maputo: a dense, golden, gluten-free confection born from the marriage of ground cashew nuts and mashed potatoes—two of Mozambique's most abundant ingredients. Sugar, eggs, and butter bind the mixture into a batter that bakes into something between a European torte and a Mozambican revelation: impossibly moist, with the rich, toasty sweetness of cashews and the tender crumb that only potato can give. Named after Polana, the elegant seaside district of Maputo, it graces every birthday, wedding, and holiday table in the country.
ingredients: 2 cups (250 g) raw cashew nuts, finely ground to a flour
2 medium potatoes (about 12 oz / 340 g), peeled, boiled, and mashed smooth
1/2 cup (115 g / 1 stick) unsalted butter, softened
Butter and flour for the pan
steps: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Butter and flour an 8-inch (20 cm) round cake pan and line the bottom with parchment.
Cream the softened butter and sugar together until light and fluffy, about 3 minutes. Beat in the egg yolks one at a time, then stir in the vanilla and orange zest.
Fold in the mashed potato until fully incorporated and smooth. Fold in the ground cashews and salt.

In a separate clean bowl, whisk the egg whites to stiff peaks. Gently fold one-third of the whites into the batter to lighten it, then fold in the remaining whites in two additions, taking care not to deflate.
Pour the batter into the prepared pan and smooth the top.
Bake 40–50 minutes until the top is golden brown and a skewer inserted in the center comes out clean. The cake will be dense and moist—do not overbake.
Cool in the pan 15 minutes, then turn out onto a wire rack. Dust generously with powdered sugar before serving. Bolo Polana keeps beautifully for days and improves overnight.

MDG.description: Madagascar's national dish and daily comfort: a soulful one-pot stew of zebu beef simmered with anamamy (brèdes mafana—the 'buzz button' greens that tingle on the tongue), mustard greens, tomato, ginger, and garlic. The brèdes mafana are uniquely Malagasy—they contain spilanthol, which creates a mild numbing, buzzing sensation on the lips. No other African stew has this electric quality. Served over a mountain of white rice, it is eaten from the central highlands to the coast.
ingredients: 1 large bunch brèdes mafana (or watercress/spinach as substitute)
Salt and freshly ground black pepper
steps: Heat oil in a large pot. Brown the beef chunks on all sides over high heat. Remove.
Add onion and cook until softened. Add garlic and ginger, cook 2 minutes. Add tomatoes, cook 5 minutes until they break down.
Return the beef. Add enough water to cover by 1 inch. Simmer covered 1.5 hours until tender.
Add the mustard greens and brèdes mafana. Simmer 10–15 minutes until wilted. Season.
Serve in deep bowls over a generous mound of white rice.

drink.description: Madagascar's tropical rum punch: local rum (toaka gasy or Dzama), fresh coconut milk, vanilla from Madagascar's vanilla coast, and lime. The island produces the world's finest vanilla, and you can taste it.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) Malagasy rum (or white rum)
1/2 oz (15 ml) vanilla syrup (or 1/2 tsp vanilla extract + 1 tsp sugar)
steps: Shake rum, coconut milk, vanilla syrup, and lime juice with ice.
Strain over crushed ice in a rocks glass.
Dust with freshly grated nutmeg.

dessert.description: Madagascar's beloved street breakfast-dessert—sweet, crispy-edged pancakes made from rice flour, coconut milk, sugar, and a touch of vanilla, cooked in a special cast-iron mold (mofo gasy mold) with round indentations that give them their signature shape. Vendors set up their charcoal braziers at dawn across Antananarivo and every Malagasy town, the sweet coconut aroma drawing a queue before the first batch is even flipped. The batter ferments slightly overnight, giving mofo gasy a subtle tang that plays against the sweetness of coconut and sugar. Golden and caramelized on the outside, soft and pillowy within—they are eaten warm, often with a cup of strong Malagasy coffee.
ingredients: Vegetable oil or coconut oil for greasing
steps: Dissolve yeast in warm water with a pinch of sugar. Let sit 10 minutes until foamy.
In a large bowl, combine rice flour, sugar, and salt. Add coconut milk, yeast mixture, and vanilla. Whisk until smooth—the batter should be like thick pancake batter.
Cover and let ferment at room temperature overnight (or at least 4 hours). The batter will become slightly bubbly and tangy.
Heat a mofo gasy mold, æbleskiver pan, or a heavy non-stick skillet over medium heat. Brush each indentation (or the pan) generously with oil.
Pour batter into each mold, filling about three-quarters full. Cook 3–4 minutes until the bottoms are deep golden brown and the edges set.
Flip carefully with a skewer or fork and cook another 2–3 minutes until golden on both sides and cooked through.
Serve warm, stacked on a plate. Best eaten fresh with Malagasy coffee or vanilla tea.

MLI.description: Mali's beloved peanut stew: slow-simmered meat in a thick, velvety sauce of groundnut paste, tomato, onion, and garlic, served over rice. Tigadegena means 'peanut sauce' in Bambara, and it is the dish that defines Malian hospitality—always made in quantities large enough for unexpected guests. The sauce should be thick enough to coat a spoon and rich enough to make you close your eyes.
ingredients: 2 lbs chicken pieces or beef stew meat (900 g)
1 cup natural peanut butter (smooth, unsweetened, 250 g)
steps: Heat oil in a large pot. Brown the meat on all sides. Remove.
Sauté onions until golden. Add garlic and tomato paste, cook 2 minutes. Add chopped tomatoes, cook 5 minutes.
Return the meat. Add 3 cups water and the whole Scotch bonnet (do not burst it). Simmer 45 minutes until the meat is tender.
Stir in the peanut butter, mixing well until dissolved into a smooth, creamy sauce. Simmer 20 more minutes, stirring often. Season.
Remove the Scotch bonnet. Serve over white rice.

drink.description: A Malian hibiscus-ginger refresher: tart, spicy, and deeply crimson. The ginger adds a fiery kick that makes it more complex than simple bissap.
steps: Boil hibiscus and ginger in the water for 15 minutes. Strain.
Stir in sugar and lime juice. Chill well. Serve over ice.

dessert.description: The Sahel's most elegant dessert—tiny pearls of millet couscous folded into thick, creamy sweetened yogurt scented with vanilla and sometimes a hint of nutmeg. Dégué (also called thiakry) is as refreshing as it is nourishing: the millet adds a gentle, nutty chew while the cold yogurt delivers tang and sweetness in equal measure. Served chilled in cups or bowls at celebrations, after meals, or as an afternoon treat, it is the taste of Malian hospitality—simple ingredients elevated by texture and temperature. In Bamako's markets, you will find it sold in plastic bags tied at the top, sipped through a torn corner.
ingredients: 1 cup (180 g) fine millet couscous (thiéré or dégué granules)
2 tbsp (25 g) granulated sugar (or to taste)
Optional: fresh pineapple chunks or raisins for garnish
steps: Place millet couscous in a bowl. Sprinkle with warm water and oil, tossing with your fingers to separate the grains. Let sit 5 minutes.

Steam the couscous: place in a fine-mesh steamer (or colander lined with cheesecloth) over simmering water. Steam 15–20 minutes until the grains are tender but still have a slight chew. Spread on a tray to cool completely.
In a large bowl, whisk together yogurt, condensed milk, vanilla, nutmeg, salt, and sugar until smooth.
Fold the cooled millet couscous into the yogurt mixture until evenly combined. The texture should be thick and spoonable.
Refrigerate at least 1 hour (overnight is even better—the millet softens further and the flavors meld).
Serve chilled in cups or bowls. Garnish with pineapple or raisins if desired.

NER.description: Niger's legendary spiced dried meat: thin sheets of beef are sun-dried, then coated in a fiery paste of groundnut powder, ginger, onion, cayenne, and Maggi seasoning, then dried again until they become crispy, intensely flavored jerky. Kilishi is the original Sahelian protein bar, carried by Tuareg and Hausa traders across the Sahara for centuries. Each butcher guards a secret spice ratio.
ingredients: 2 lbs lean beef (top round), sliced paper-thin against the grain (900 g)
Labu spice paste (see Chef's Essentials below)
